reviews.review:
Art history, culture...Paris!. The art history, the culture food and drink. This is Paris
Make sure you enjoy this area and spend some time night or day there is something to see or do

Tres Chic. Montmartre is the perfect place to stay or just visit though once is not enough. There are elegant shops and great places to eat or just stop for coffee and people watch. Stay in an apartment and live like a local.

A lovely place for a few hours or a whole day. Using the 5-day pass for the metro and bus, got us access to the funicular train that brought us to the top of the hill. The view of Paris from there is really spectacular. There's lots to do, depending on how much time you have. We walked around a bit and then took the bold move to climb up the 300 steps to the top of the church's tower, steps that were spiraling up for the most part! Tiring but worth the entrance fee and the effort to climb. You can also see the Eiffel Tower from here. Avoid carrying bulky things that can hinder the climb up. The trip down is at another point. Then we stopped at the garden to view the artwork of the many local artists - very pretty. The whole town is a beauty I must say. If you loved gamlastan in Sweden, you would really love this rather quaint place. Everything about this place is suited for photography!

enjoy the atmosphere. we had been lucky to live in this arr. for certain months. The atmosphere is incredible: Strolling through the streets, which had also been tread by Toulouse-Lautrec, Picasso etc...Watching beautifully made up women going to perform in The Moulin Rouge or Nouvelle Eve, both cabarets to be recommended, listening to live music in "le chat noir"... Visit the musee Montmartre as well and see not only the well known artists connected with having lived and worked here, but also the ancient photos of the can can dancers of the Moulin Rouge. Incredible, how the fashion in female shape has changed...

I want to live here . I would love to live in this little town. Very artsy side of town which I had a great time exploring. Quiet and calm in some parts with something nifty to see around every corner. Also had some insanely good croissants in a local bakery. Go explore here!

So PARIS. We arrived by cab and so unintentionally avoided the steps up. There was a wine and food festival on the day we visited, crowds were huge and atmosphere was great. The food and wines were superb! Aaaah, the nougat.... The views from Montmartre are so wonderful, much better than those from the Eiffel Tower. We left on foot and wandered down little winding streets until we emerged in lower Montmartre, Boulevard de Clichy, near Moulin Rouge. The entire afternoon was spellbinding. The arts history of the place, the local culture, the locals themselves, were fascinating. Please give yourself at least an afternoon to drift around in this district.

High on the Hill. It's such a dominating feature on the Paris skyline. A must visit sort of place. Sacre-Coeur is a must visit. The surrounds and vista are to be enjoyed.You must take in the square with all it has to offer. Restaurants etc, and the artists at work. Allow a few hours to take it all in. But have some adventure in you, in Paris you need to walk to these places, take the steps not the funicular, it just adds to the visit.
My favorite part of Paris. The Montmartre area is so cool to walk around and so classically Parisian. Take a tour and learn where the bohemians and artist hung out!
Nice Place to Explore. Lots of great shops and cafes. I found this to be a great area to wander, just exploring the neighborhood a bit.
Couples France trip. Went to this area on a Saturday in September 2016, artist area behind Sacre Coeur, with outdoor cafes, beautiful area, must see.

The best. My absolute favorite part of Paris. The atmosphere and the landmarks of Montmartre enchant me every time I'm there. Watch "Le fabouleux destin d'Amelie Poulain" before going there and enjoy the location. Place du Tertre and Le Sacré-Cœur are the main attractions. Don't miss the boulangeries and cafes!

Tourist spot but interesting. Our first morning after arriving in Paris and we only had a few hours before having to go on a planned tour so walked up to Monmart from our hotel. About a 30 minute walk, quite uphill as Monmart is the highest point in the city.Pretty cobbled streets and lots of shops selling tourist stuff and plenty of food available. Great views of the city, including the Eiffel Tower and the church Sacre Bleue is a beautiful building.

Very informative.. Loved our tour with our group of Montmartre. Thoroughly enjoyed every minute and hearing about the history of the area and the artists who lived there was intriguing. This is what Paris is all about. Highly recommend this tour.

Favorite section of Paris. This is by far my favorite section of Paris. The views when you get to the top are beautiful. All the little shops along the way are quaint and unique. The local artists selling their works do so for great prices. Enjoy a few hours to walk around.

Great walking adventure.. Take Metro and start walking. Great spot to roam around and feel a part of this artist and bohemian community. Go to the top and wander through out and then walk you way down after you take in the view.

Lovely walking experience on a clear and cool day only - DO NOT take a walking tour. Our second visit, but this time we tried the 'Walking Tour" for 15Euros each. A thorough waste of money and time. The nearly 3 hours of slow walking was about 50% commercials for local businesses and 40% info that was directly from Wikipedia. No place for 'rest stop'. If it had been a hot day, folks would have dropped from the heat. If you wish, take the white tourist 'train' that moves along the streets with an audio recording (6Euros each).

Must visit!. Montmartre is a wonderful place in Paris!! It's a pretty good walk up the hill or you can rise the funicular to get to the top. There are artists everywhere hoping to draw or paint you. I have brought photos with me and had Maxim, an artist at Montmartre, paint them into portraits!! They came out beautiful!! It's a great place to spend an afternoon walking around and having a delicious lunch.

Plus ca change..... I last visited Montmartre several years ago, but found that the same awful pictures of the Eiffel Tower etc were being peddled. The area undoubtedly has charm, but lacks authenticity.
Pretty Spectacular!. Amazing to see where famous Artists painted in the Park! Lots of walking uphill, bring comfortable shoes or you will get blisters like I did!

Interesting area to walk around, but not a must-see. We visited the Sacre Coeur and then spent some time walking around the neighborhood a bit. There were some interesting shops and some interesting characters (entertainers as well as scam artists), but it felt a bit too touristy and I don't recommend it, especially since there are many other better areas and sites in Paris.
Great for foodies. I just loved this area of Paris. Such good cheese and chocolate shops. Very nice restaurants and clubs around.

Picturesque!. A must visit if you are in Paris!
Artists painting magic surround Montmarte together with family run businesses and cute cafes!
Enjoy an authentic onion soup and search for bargains whilst tasting local delights!
A nice area/place to stroll! :-)

An Overrated Area of Paris. The main attraction of this area is the Cathedral Sacre Coeur on the top of the hill. It's architecture beauty, history and views of Paris make it a favorite of locals and tourists. But remember than getting there is all up hill. Just a short walk around the corner is the artist area with fewer artists than you might think. I was a bit disappointed in the number of artists painting on the streets and especially the prices that charged for the work, but it is Paris. Back down the hill is what one might cionsider a shadier part of town where one might become more vigilant of the surroundings and people. Although the Moulin Rouge is an attraction it a one time thing to walk by, take a picture and keep moving. There are many restaurants that are very good in this area as well as plenty of souvenir shops. The entire area has its benefits. Visit and walk the area in the daytime.
Fun area to explore. Wander around the area for souvenir shopping, enjoy lunch or a drink at one of the many cafes. Wandering around the area I came across Vigne du Clos Montmarte winery.
My favorite part of Paris!. We stayed in Montmarie and I am so glad we did. The history, the cobblestone streets, the quaint shops and dining establishments made it so enjoyable and unforgettable.

A beautiful, quaint and quirky district of Paris is a must see and near to the Sacre Coeur..... I absolutely love this area. Loads of cafe's, art, little shops and although there are lots of souvenir shops its just great to have a walk round then find a cafe have a simple meal and a drink and watch the world go by.....in a completely relaxing setting. Its also close to the Sacre Coeur which is a must do place in Paris.

Great do not miss!. Excellent walking tour and an amazing part of Paris! We did it on a Sunday and were very please wi the artist in the market square and we bought handmade ceramics and a painting. Must see especially if your into art, history and the best baguettes in Paris or to see the cafe from the film 'Amelie'. Fantastic day!

A must see - but please walk away from the main tourist areas. My husband and I had visited this area of Paris a few years ago and HATED it. It was so touristy. I kept reading praising reviews about the area so I insisted we visited on our most recent trip to Pairs. They were right! You have to get away from the main tourist thoroughfares and the area is charming. I suggest walking from Sacre-Coeur to Cimetiere de Montmartre. You have to take random roads though! We did the walk on a Saturday and stumbled across a great (but very crowed) street market.

Loved the atmosphere. We visited this area before heading to Moulin Rouge, loved the atmosphere of the area, the cobbled laneways and small shops and artists everywhere, would love to return one day to stay in the area and spend more time exploring.

Wouldn't go out of my way. This has become a gross tourist trap and the number of street solicitations is overwhelming. The days of interesting artists and bohemian vibe are long gone. I would not go out of my way to visit especially if you have limited time.

Artist Impression. Beautiful little square full of artists and restaurants. We had our portraits done. You must bargain with these artists to get the price down. A charming morning spent. Restaurants pricey.

Fantastic away from the tourist areas. This would be my favourite area of Paris......full of bars and interesting people watching.It is eclectic with art, food, adult areas and interesting history.Book a walking tour of the area (Discover Walks is 1 company) and learn about the people/history of the area.It is easy to walk from any of the metro stations Blanche or Pigalle. We walked up to the Sacre-Coeur but the shops and restaurants up there are very expensive snd a tourist trap. Head down the hill and eat/drink down there.

Great quirky, artsy part of Paris. If you like the Moulin Rouge and the sex clubs, there's a whole street of those there. But Montmartre is also home to some of the city's best music gear shops, best shops overall, and most interesting artists. It also has some great cafes. It is probably the most "hilly" part of Paris, so be prepared that walking around will involve going up and down hills more than the rest of the city. Don't miss the Two Windmills cafe, as seen in the film Amelie (and which has tasty food, btw), and enjoy all the little shops along the way as well as let your kids enjoy the various ornate merry go rounds one seems to run into in Montmartre.

Strolling in Montmartre. Besides visiting the Basilica, a fun thing to do is to stroll along the streets in Montmartre. There are many excellent artists selling their art, many cafes and shops. The views are beautiful. There are also several street performers and musicians. A fun relaxing stroll.

Scenic, rare heritage . This site is a must visit, metro has a station 5 mins away at Anvers, I travelled solo on a Sunday afternoon, I visited the church which in itself is an imposing figure on mont matre, the way up is great as more and more of Paris gets visible, " an elevator train " vehicle is available up to the foot of the hill. Entry into the cathedral is free, however €6 fee is required for access to the dome where an excellent panoramic view of Paris won't disappoint. The ascend via the stairs is energy sapping and can cause a bit of dizziness if one goes fast. The views are so rewarding I would ascend again on another visit. A powerful camera will come in handy as the glare in the afternoon can affect the picture panorama. Inside the cathedral, care is to be taken , respectful silence and dress as this is still an active sanctuary for Catholics / faithful. The splendor of the architecture and interior design of it can not go unmentioned. A must visit site, I didn't need to book in advance and not many queues typical of other Parisian attractions.

Just Go!. I highly advise a visit to Montmartre. We took the subway train to this area to meet our tour guide. Will have to review Viator under a separate review. Montmartre is a quaint little area. Very quiet but hosts the most delicious cheese shops, wine shops, butcher shops and patisseries. Walking is a must. The streets are very narrow and it is fun to watch a delivery truck hold up the whole street while other drives wait behind. That is why there isn't much traffic or noise.

Great to see. Did walking tour today with Sandemans. Great to see. Very hilly but views from top amazing. Read lots of stuff about pick pockets but didn't see any problems today. If you have mobility issues would recommend you get the tram to the top.

Interesting neighborhood for walking. My wife and I stayed in the neigbourhood and enjoyed it very much. Some streets seem a bit tatty, others are charming and beautiful, all of them interesting. We saw everything by foot and felt safe throughout. The area is a residential abounding with shops, restaurants etc. It is also only a 5 minute metro ride to the centre of Paris near Notre Dame.One of the anchors here is the Sacre Cour Basilica, requiring a good climb but offering some of the best panoramic views of Paris. The Basilica itself can be a wondrous experience if you have the time to linger around a Sunday mass, which adds incredible life and ambience. Another highlight for us was finding long established mid-priced restaurants mostly patronized by area residents, not by tourists.I'd say take an afternoon and get creatively lost, it's worth it. I suggest branching out from Sacre Cour along the local streets winding downhill to some interesting main avenues.

A tourist attraction for sure. Get there early to advoid the crowds. Not our first visit here but it is always crowded as the day goes on. Lots of people trying to do your portraits etc and many tourist shops. However if you look there are also some very nice artisan shops. Plenty of just OK restaurants and cafes . Artists in the square are interesting to watch.
Mouth Watering. Such a great stroll through the streets in Montmartre .. cafes and other mouth watering food shops .. boutiques & Art shops
A view to behold. This was a very nice spot to go the view alone is one you have to see. We went here twice we bought some really beautiful artwork and had some good food. This one place is a must!

Loved it!. My family stayed in this neighborhood during our recent visit. We loved it! It is away from the crowds of central paris but easily accessible by train and but. Many great places to eat. There are many places to shop as well. Very close to Sacre Coeur. Would stay here again.

Over rated. Shabby, touristy and busy. Not worth a guided tour. Wander the streets and check it out if you must. Sacre Couer , another church.
Spend your time in better places. Traffic down below , crazy.
Beautiful. . My favourite area of Paris. Safe smart lovely. Really nice restaurants and cafes. Street artists and nice bars

It waslong walk up steep hill.. After arriving in Paris early, we could not check into our hotel in the area until later. So we decided to visit the nearby Sacre Coeur. Of course the landmark basilica is atop Paris’ highest hill. We labored up 237 steps and were greeted by street artists who wanted to do our portraits. It is an interesting area. Lots of artists. Years ago on a visit here, I bought a $35 oil painting (signed by Jean Salabet). He became slightly famous and I sold the Paris street scene for $480 much later. It’s now worth at least $2,000. There were no similar bargains on this visit. We found there was an easier way to get to the top, a lift of sorts. We admired the bright white Sacre Coeur. The Sacré-Coeur is not the favorite piece of architecture for Parisians. Tourists love it. The structure’s bone-white exterior is due to its secreting calcite when it rains, bleaching the walls.We were too tired to enjoy much, hardly getting our cameras out of their cases. We trudged down the hill, found a pizza place and had a late breakfast of pizza primavera, featuring bits of hard- boiled eggs. We washed it down with bottles of Heineken. It’s best to be rested when doing Montmarte. And use the lift.

Cool vibe.. Unfortunately we only went on our last day and did not have enough time. If ever I'm fortunate enough to visit Paris again, this will be a day trip, maybe even stay in Montmartre, as the prices are a lot better than in the city centre. The church, Sacre Coeur is a must, and there was a little ice cream shop on our way walking toward the church that sold the most delicious ice creams ever.

Beware the roaming artists. We were well and truly ripped off. A roaming artist with a sketch book sketched us both. We thought it would be a nice memento of our trip to Montmartre. It cost E50 and was nothing like us. It could have been anyone.

Spend an evening there. The famous boem quarter is a MUST SEE. This part of Paris is amazing. There are a lot of cheap restaurants and bars, there is Sacre - Coeur, and most importantly - a lot of street performances. On the stairs before the Sacre - Coeur, the ambient is amazing. People singing and dancing, great for relaxing and drinking beer or wine. I recommend spending an evening there!

Lovely arty area!. Loved meandering around here - cute boutiques, artists in the streets & great cafes to people watch too. Recommend flats for the cobbled streets & sitting fir a while to enjoy the ambience.
If in Paris..... This was an interesting part of Paris, with lots of history, no surprise. Would not miss it, and if I was ever in Paris again, would spend more time in that area.

Cool to visit, but beware the scam artists. We took the train from the center of Paris to Montmartre - easy to do. First found our way to Sacre Coeur and climbed up there and down. Lots of streets with lots of shops and cafes. Lots of cobblestones and lots of hills - so be forewarned. Loved the scenery. Artists are there doing their work and some offering to sketch you (beware of the cost before agreeing). Just as I read, there were folks trying to put bracelets on people and then charge them for it. I had to actually pull my arm away - they're kind of determined. Beautiful for a 2 hour visit, but I wouldn't plan to spent a whole day there.

Romantic. I have been many times in Paris , and every time I have visited Montmartre . you can walk in the beautiful streets , indulge you with a coffee and a piece of tasty Parisian pastry . in a middle of this neighbourhood the painters are painting and you can buy a nice tableau or a souvenir . I recommend visit the night view it is incredible . you can reach there buy metro or a mini bus from Pigal . You can visit the Sacre - couer Basilica as well , in a walking distance . strongly recommend . don't miss it.
Great area in Paris. We spent several days in this area and loved it. We had lots of fun wandering the streets shopping and sight seeing.

Cute, but overrated. This is a cute neighborhood but maybe I missed all the impressive locations. I wasn't really impressed with what I saw in real life compared to all the images online. Next time, maybe I'll try going at night?

Worth the Trip. Take the Metro or a taxi and go up for the view of Paris. Day and night views are beautiful. Stick around for dinner and check out the artists square. It was s lovely and relaxed day just walking around checking out the shops.

Great area to stay in. Our hotel was a two block walk from the metro. The area varies from seedy (moulin rouge ) to lots of local pubs and restaurants. The location is great for accessing all the sights in Paris by train.
nice place in Paris. if you have time in Paris, you need to visit Montmatre and spend some time with all the perfomance and arts around Sacre Cour - just enjoy and relax

Still a must see in Paris. If you make complete abstraction of all the tourists and street people trying to sell you something then it is really amazing. A lot of stairs to climb to the top but the view is amazing. The neighborhood of montmartre is also really enjoyable. Of course a lot of bars and clothes stores but you'll find a few little boutiques with original items. A must see in paris
outstanding. what a great place to visit in paris, very cool, chic, great district to spend a few hours in, good restaurants, shops, cafes, the views from sacre coeur across paris are amazing,

My favorite part of Paris. We loved the area at the top of the hill with all the artists, musicians, cafes, beautiful church and shops. We were especially impressed with the handmade products in the pottery shop! This is the best area for souvenirs. We enjoyed sipping wine and eating crepes while listening to the musicians. Be mindful of pickpockets and anyone approaching you to sign something or begging for change. Lots of pick pockets in this area.
Real Paris. A lot of Paris is very commercialized and Montmartre was wonderful. Took a tasting tour and visited some of the great bakeries, cafes etc. Don't go to Paris without visiting.
Cool "artsy" community. Cool artist community with unique shops and restaurants. Watch for pickpockets at night - especially in larger groups. Really cool to see (we wandered and had dinner).

Very touristy, but go for the views. Montmartre was on my agenda for this recent trip to Paris. I knew that it would be very touristy and crowded, but I still wanted to go. It was worth it to see Sacre Couer and the views from up high. I wouldn't recommend spending alot of time there due to the crowds, but it is a lovely place to visit -- especially if you get there early in the day.

Loved it. What a classic french atmosphere. It is wonderful to walk through the streets and see the artists at work. Well worth stopping in a cafe just to watch the world go by for a while. An absolute must see on any trip to Paris
despite the kitch art is pictureque. Much good food and bargain merchandise; The Montmartre Museum is a gem for art lovers and to learn about the area; Wonderful climb to it by Rue des Martyrs:

Rub shoulders with artists. This is the hangout of artists who want to paint your picture and display their artwork. We found this is the best place to buy souviniers. Nice restaurants, too. You do have to go up a zillion steps to get to it.

Sketch artist, just say no. Montmartre area is great, it is well worth the trip. Just watch out for the sketch artist. They start drawing as soon as they see you. They don't stop unless you are very firm. If they finish they want anywhere from 60 Euro to 100 Euro for the sketch. We were told not to pay over 30 Euro. Maybe even that is too much. We had two of them fighting over us because I refused to buy mine after I bought one for my wife from another so called artist. Too bad they spoil a wonderful experience.

Wonderful Neighbourhood, take the time to visit. A bit more relaxed than any other arrondissement Montmartre has been the home to painters and other artist for years. Wandering around the streets brings a surprise at every corner. There do seem to be some pick pockets, but hey they are everywhere in Paris. Just be aware of your surroundings. Tons of cafes to enjoy as you watch the crowds walk by.

Days in Montmartre. A short trip on the Metro from our hotel (Minerve) and we were in Montmartre, Visited the Sacre Coeur which was very moving and also outside offers the best views over Paris. This was the only place in Paris we saw genuine accordion players (i'm sure there are others but we saw two in one day). Walked up and down the long atmospheric staircases which characterise Montmartre, visited the square and watched portrait artists at work and walked down the hill to see Le Moulin Rouge and window shop back along to the Metro stations. Artistic, atmospheric, cultural and historical, evocative of nineteenth century France, impressionists and can-cans.

Art Everywhere!. I loved walking the sidewalks of Paris in this neighborhood, looking at all the art, talking to the artists, and stopping for lunch at an outdoor cafe. There is so much history here! We also took a little train ride around the area. Loved it!
Only for those who have never been to Paris?. Easy to get there by bus but still count on half a day, and with the crowds there are better ways to spend your time.
Fun to explore. Went to the open market on Friday morning: beautiful vegetables, fish etc. Many shops with piles of clothing at very low prices. Fabulous several blocks of fabric shops.
Up on a Hill. This area is where Sanct Coueur is located. There are shops and restaurants. There is a walk in the Rick Steves book that will take you down hill to the Moulin Rouge.

Magical Neighbourhood in Paris. The street full of souvenir shop and cute cafes which are instagram worthy. While roaming around, have a sit at any cafe and enjoy people watching while having crepe with jambon and cheese.

Best Neighboorhood Food & Shops. If you want to see the real Paris, visit this Neighboorhood.Great views, shopping and eateries. Beware of street sellers. Have a picnic on the steps and taste famous chocalitiers and macaroons. Best in chocolate, baguette and meat can be found in this neighborhood.

Enjoyed this more than expected. As well as the churches try to incude a walk in the area, it was great fun. Wonderful restaurants and bakeries etc. as well as artists for a visual feast. Funicular railway up to the summit saves a step walk for the price of 1 metro ticket.

Must see place. A little square full of artists. Painters making their pictures by different styles.
You can buy lots of nice souvenirs.

Mr. A must vist when in Paris great atmosphere good to eat alfresco for my La Mere Cathrine restaurant hold good memories plenty to see and do or just sit and people watch dont get caught by the artists wanting to draw or paint your pic as can be costly !!Enjoy
Great place to stay. We stayed in this area. Excellent cafes and just down the road from the Sacre Coeur. Good place to stay if you want to be reasonably central.
Montmatre. Abbesses the deepest Metro,in Paris look for elevator unless you are really fit See where Piccasso lived next to TimHotel

Really rough area. The cathedral is busy and crowded, the views are good from the terrace in front but the area is awful, really rough with horrible discount stores and cheap cafes. I would not wish to return.
Most magical place in Paris. . So sweet and nice place. I lived in Marais when I stayed here now, but not the next time! 😉 Really cosy streets and good places to get the "Paris feeling."

A great Paris district.. Monmartre is a good area to wander through admiring all of the street artists and cafes.
While there you should visit the Dali museum which is unbelievable in the history of Dali.
Quaint area . Lovely quaint area with the famous Sacre Couer church on the hill. Lovely shops to browse through. Take the cable car to the top if you don't want to take the stairs

Disappointing. OK, I get all hype about how this is an Art Village, so much history, etc. But this place got slimy as the sun went down. In addition, that rudeness and arrogance was present (once again) as we sat down for a meal. My wife has been studying French for the past year for our second trip to France. Outside of Paris, her French is welcomed. However, within Paris the servers seem bothered and annoyed, and eye rolling seemed to be a theme. OK, I get it, all these tourists are a pain but we're just making a polite effort to communicate. The art vendors and sketch artists however were nice, and did get ourselves sketched by a couple of locals, it was fun.Visit this place during the day to avoid the night time elements.
A sunny morning at Montmartre. Walking around Montmartre is an experience by itself. Pictures were the highlight of the day. The little restaurants and art galleries compliment the visit.
Loved it!!. Spent 4 days in the heart of Montmartre, lived the Parisian life for a while... Sun was shining... ☀️☀️ loved it! Want to go back ❤️
The artist town on the hill full of old Pairs. This is a must see place if you want to get a sense of old Pairs where the masters worked, ate and drank. Picasso's home not far.

artists abound. Have you ever wanted to get your portrait done? Or a silhouette? Do you want to take a real oil painting home of Paris. This is the place! Multiple artists, students are here and you can negotiate a price. There are paintings as small as a postcard and as large as you'd like. The little shops and restaurants are charming. My favorite is La Mare Catherine.

Lots of activity. This has unfortunately become more touristy since I was first here but still has something that keeps drawing one back. I can spend hours people watching on a daily basis over a cup of coffee or standing watching the artists do their magic. Lots to see and do.
Monmartre. We hiked up to Sacre-Coeur (a real hike -- a great many stairs, and nothing but steep hills) following an incredible cooking class with Cook'n With Class Paris.

Full of charm and well worth a visit!. We first went to Montmartre more than 20 years ago and have never had the opportunity to return due to always having such a jam-packed itinery while in Paris! However, this time we went, we found that we had more time on our hands so made a visit to Montmartre a priority!We went via the Sacré Coeur which is another wonderful site to see and climbing the multitude of white steps and being rewarded by sweeping views across the whole of Paris is absolutely worth it.From the Sacré Coeur; Montmartre is just a short walk away and the cobbled streets and diminishing traffic let you know you are nearly there! The quaint shops, restaurants and whole ambiance is wonderful, we cannot help feel it is just full of Parisian character and exudes romance and the charm of yester-years!The shops sell everything from necessities to the never-ending trinkets and souvenirs. As previous reviews suggest I will agree that there are quite a few artists there but never once were we pestered, they did ask if we would like our pictures painted but when we declined they couldn’t have been more polite and wished us a good day with the most amount of sincerity.We did enjoy watching an extremely talented ‘one-man-band’ Lady with the most amazing singing voice and if she wasn’t singing she was whistling tone-perfect!If you find yourself peckish while in Montmartre you will never go hungry, there are so many places to get treats, ice-creams, lunch, dinner and many more things besides!If you go to Montmartre on a sunny day the whole feeling you get from this place is even more enhanced (if that is possible) as it is just so easy to while away your day watching the world go by and taking in the whole atmosphere that Montmartre has to offer for both tourists and locals alike.

Very cool neighborhood. We were in the area to visit the Basilica and to go to Moulin Rouge. We walked around quite and bit and there are a lot of great sidewalk cafes and shops in the area. Very Parisian.

Great area to feel France. Great for souvineer shopping and a cheap meal then take a walk up the steps (or elevator is available) to Saint Schapelle. Easily accessible by bus. The Moulin Rouge is about 15 minute walk up the main street.

My favorite Paris neighborhood . What a beautiful little neighborhood. Loved the little restaurants around the Arts Plaza. So many artists selling, paintings, portraits, etc. Lots of shops, restaurants, and excellent food everywhere. This is definitely a must! We visited on a Sunday late afternoon/early evening. The Moulan Rouge is nearby.

Could have left it off the itinerary. I felt that it was very touristy, but definitely has a different vibe than the rest of Paris. The local 'artists' had the typical paintings that you would expect and plenty did portraits and caricatures, but I've seen that in so many other places.
A must-walk. This is a beautiful walk if the weather permits. Enjoy the architecture, the artists and the atmosphere Combine it with visiting Sacre-Coeur!
You can't go to Paris without visiting Montmarte. this is a fascinating neighborhood that is a cornucopia of life in Paris. You cannot go to Paris and not see this place.

Walking tours!!!!. I always love a casual walk through the streets in Montmartre! Seeing Parisian life, architecture, etc. is my favorite. In this area I feel very comfortable wondering around with no agenda just enjoying being in Paris!
Nice walk, great views. A lovely and historic part of Paris. I did not explore much except to have dinner and walk through the basilica. I will be back for more!

Eat and let eat.. Food was excellent here. Ate at two restaurants and all looked delicious. French food abounds. Main area is vehicle free and so picturesque with the brick roads, food shops and restaurants everywhere. I wanted to go to the Dali exhibit there but just missed it's closing time. This area is a true cultural experience that's accommodating to tourists and if you want your caricature done - this is the place!

Too many pestering artists!. If the annoying pestering portrait artists weren't here it would be just perfect! Fabulous views from the steps in front of Sacré Coeur and taking the Metro to Abbesses then the funicular lift avoids all those steps uphill! We walked downhill via the steps and lanes and enjoyed browsing the shops en route.

Walking tour. Highly recommend visiting this area of Paris!! If you can, do a walking tour so you can learn all about the area & all it's history & beauty. Our guide was spectacular & she took it slow & easy. A must for me as I have an artificial hip & bad knees... After our walking tour, we had lunch at a restaurant she recommended, followed by a tour of the D'Orsay Musee. Even with all this, I wasn't as tired as I was after going through the Louvre Musee. Such a wonderful experience!!
Disappointing. I have been there when I was a kid and I was so excited to go back. It is still an amazing area but too many poor people asking for money and stopping you on the road. I felt not safe.
ARTIST and decent food. Beyond the Bacilica Sacre Coeur is Montmartre and it is full of street artist and typical cafe food....always good wine.

Nice but not what I expected. I had been looking forward to going and it was not what I expected. First, I'm glad I went and would come back, but it was super crowed and full of souvenir shops. I enjoyed chatting with the artists and wandering around, but getting away from the center was best and wander around side streets.

Immerse yourself in history. Everyone comes for the church but the village is the real attraction. Stroll around and see where the painters lived and what they painted and then have coffee in a little cafe. Magic.

A true Yorkshire review. Loved it, call it tacky or talented it has it all from cheap tourist shops to expensive art, the vibe is infectious, the eateries varied and I would not have missed it for the world
Best part of Paris. We went there using free guided tour and that was best part of our visit to Paris.Montmartre has everything (restaurants,parks,nice view and soul :))

Loved it, very picturesque. At the turn of the 20th century, Montmartre was village on the outskirts of Paris. It is now part of the historic core of Paris, and not to be missed if you are there for more than three days. This is where the Moulin Rouge is also, at the base of the hill in a seedier neighborhood. But the upper parts of the hill are so clean, quant, with many artists painting in the streets and galleries. Many restaurants, and unfortunately tourist tomohawk shops but I just ignored them. The rest was great. The best restaurant of our trip was there (Comestibles by) Jeanne B, wowza! Fantastique!!!
Uh la la ... Loved it, the shops the cafes, the people, the vibe... ❤️❤️ worth the walk down from the basilica. Take you time enjoy the shops.

Worth a trip. We loved Montmarte and felt more authentic and not as touristy. We had lunch in one of the cafes and you can see local painters who can paint your portrait. Only annoying when they keep coming past asking you when your trying to have lunch.

Never disappoints. A hi light of our weekend in Paris, we headed up to Montmartre. You can take the metro to get close then a nice energetic walk to the top (there are other options, but we needed some exercise). Sacre Coeur is a beautiful basilica on the top of the hill with sweeping views. Go inside and take in the stained glass windows, saints and history. Light a candle for a loved one and take a moment to enjoy. After visiting the basilica, head around to the plaza. There is live music on the way and an ever-present lady who plays a giant music box and sings old french songs. She has been there as long as I can remember. Make your way down the street for a crêpe or try a famous sausage made in a giant grill.Make your way over to the artist where you may want to purchase some local art or have a portrait made. Overall, I would put this on a must visit place. Yes, it is touristy, but what isn't any more. If you want the best of both worlds, then go to Montmartre and get lost in the little windy streets. You may discover something new and get away from the crowds for a while. It is simply beautiful up there.

Look and move on. Unless you are a gullible tourist with no idea of what art is or can be or should be... come here, ooh and ahh at the buildings and then go somewhere more interesting. The place is full of con-artists trying to draw you, do your silhouette, or flog you some really quite terrible art. The cafés are expensive, the service average at best, and this place just epitomises the words "Tourist Trap". If, on the other hand, you are a gullible tourist with no idea about art or cultural life in other cities, then Montmartre is a wonderful little bustling place with some really quaint French people that you should just open your wallet to. Just make sure they take all of those funny coloured Euro notes.

Great walkabout. We had a few hours to kill before a late flight and chose here because its easy to get to on the Metro, and provides a great view of the city. But the shopping area around is very lively and interesting so recommend for a visit

Wonderful. . I loved the time we spent in Montmartre. However, do not just stay around sacre coeur. The street art and small shops that line the hills are where the true heart of the area is. Get away from the portrait artists begging to draw you. (Though I have to admit some are very good). Get away from moulin rouge. Get away from everything the artists like Toulouse lautrec would have hated and see the real area. It's worth it.
Stay here. I am glad our hotel was in Montmartre - there are so much to do and see. Very artistry. It has good restaurants and shops with easy access to subways.

Atmosphere of past and art. Up until 19th century, Montmartre was just a village nearby Paris, famous for its cabarets, dance halls, vineyards and wine. It attracted Parisians as well as artists who painted it in many of their art pieces. I would recommend getting a tour in order to really go in secret corners of the neighborhood which still considers itself being different then rest of Paris

beautiful place. paris itself is a very beautiful place. this place is very nice. we have a very nice view over the city. the church itself is just wow. the artists singing there are wonderful. and above all, the ambience there is just wow wow wow. so nice.. would love to go there again.

One of my Favorite Places. This quirky, artist-filled area is fun to stroll around and people watch. The views from the top are incredible - both in the daytime and at night. The restaurants are great for casually eating and drinking and soaking up the atmosphere. While there are plenty of cheapo souvenir shops, there are also opportunities to find high quality craftsmanship and artwork. I always make time for Montmartre when we are in Paris.
Always love to vidit!. Hope you have your walking shoes and are in good shape to get up the hills. Wonderful shops, and love the artists in the square. Must see if in Paris.

Beautiful . Nice places and a lot to see. One of my favorite places in Paris.
Always when we come to Paris we stay here.

Beautiful but beware of pick pocketers! . Beautiful area which is very old and traditional. A lot of uphill walking too. Just beautiful but rife with pick pocketers! Just a warning but would recommend visiting. Lovely food places all around including nazirs.

Tawdry and Tacky. Whatever charm Montmatre may once have had is totally subsumed by tacky souvenir shops and over-priced eateries. No doubt the Bohemian artists and intellectuals who made this area famous would be appalled. Not an area I would visit again despite its fame and romantic history.

OIK. We did not take a food tour, but did take the metro up here. There is a fabulous view of the city from the cathedral at the top. I am sure there is more to do, so the food tour would have been better.

Another higher building to view the whole city. walking up to the basilica is a good exercise :) i like the cobble-stone made pathways in the area. there are plenty of shops along the way up to the basilica which are actually bit cheaper than the shops in the eiffel tower area.just be careful because there are some pickpocketters. the church is free entry, so u can pray and take pics inside without making noises to not disturb the one who prayed. this area is on hill with greeneries so its refreshing.

An essential part of a Parisian visit.... One cannot go to Paris and not visit Montmartre. It was once the headquarters of young artists and bohemians (as immortalized in Aznavour's legendary chanson "La Boheme"), but now it's more of a tourist attraction. The two churches in the heart of Montmartre, Place du Tertre, the art galleries, Moulin Rouge - they are all worth the sight. However, it's interesting to stroll through the narrow streets and discover things off the beaten path, like Place Marcel Ayme or the poem on the fence/wall near Dalida's bust. One just needs to beware of crowds and pickpockets, and must be prepared to fend off all the artists trying to commission you for a portrait.

Fun tourist trap . This fun artist filled area was exactly like we had seen 30 years ago on our honey moon. Artists were cutting out paper silhouettes and requesting money faster than you could turn around. Luckily this time we stopped them before they had finished their silhouettes. However I think it was still a fun place to browse around and see many people, mostly tourists and various type of art.

Skip it. Although this was highly recommended, we could never in good conscious suggest this over-run tourist trap to anyone. We couldn't wait to get away from the area. Tacky shops, dirty and even the tourist information booth suggested we watch for pick pockets. If you want to see people living in (and shouting out from) cardboard boxes and piles of clothing in shops for 1 or 2 Euros each, then go there if you must. Otherwise, pick a different neighborhood.
Joyfull. Very joyfull place with all thr street artists and different restaurants and places with wonderfull deserts.
Fab!. Fab! there are no words, just do it! go on the fun road train if you can, or metro, and then the funicular......or clime 250 or so steps!
Montmartre. Beautiful part of Paris, busy and bustling yet relaxing in a strange way. Montmartre still has a village vibe and is definitely worth exploring
Seedy part of Paris. If you want to buy some sex toys or go to Moulin Rouge this is where you need to be. Try to do it in daytime as night is a little sketchy.

stylish of Paris. The most authentic french stylish place in Paris!! Situated on a hill next to sacre couer charming area of artist and their works Beautiful!! The painters , the artists spread all around are a sight to see! & the restaurants, small and cozy..amazing ambiance. Colourful. Lively. Simply beautiful! Recommended
Quaint villiage. We had a great time walking thru the village, watching the street artists painting, and walking thru the shops.

Amazing Experience with low cost in Paris .... Enjoy Beauty in Montmartre. It's really essential to visit Montmartre if you are in Paris .You can enjoy Wandering the cobbled streets of Montmartre and see some historical , beautiful landmarks .also can take the train up " Montmartre Famous small train " & see the Sacré Coeur, & enjoy the bohemian atmosphere of Artist's Square and the Café des Moulins . Where you can have a nice porter for yourself ( Take care NOT TO PAY MUCH in this activity )You must also have a look on the " Moulin Rouge " and " PIGAL " Square . And have some fun just by walking around .
High above the city!. This area is beautiful! Well worth the subway ride and walking around through the streets and shops. The cathedral is very close by too!

A bit cliche but definitely worth a look. Where many famous artists lived for a time including Renoir, Picasso and Dali among many others. It has become a bit of a tourist trap but the current artists here make a living drawing pictures of tourists or selling their talents. A wander away from the main square should be taken in to admire the interesting architecture and parks. A quick read up on history (wikipedia) of the area will make the area that much more enjoyable.
Plan a long stay!. A great pneighborhood to get lost in... any time of day. Love Place de Tertre just looking at the art and artists.

Sleazy and charmless. With the exception of the wonderful Sacre Couer Montmartre is a disappointment. Sex shops and sleazy clubs abound and the whole place could do with a good clean. Check out Sacre Couer and get out as quick as possible.
Not worset. It is typical touristic with bad food in all the restaurants ....It is not worset .... but the scenery is nice from up

Artist haven . Lovely place to sit and watch the world go by price for drinks not too bad and basilica is just close by and some quirky little shops as well at usual tourist ones ! Amazing chocolate shop maxims is worth a look for chocoholic heaven !

Montmartre. Cozy place and lot of beautiful restaurants and bars to chill. I always visit and walk in Montmarte whenever I travel to Paris. I do recommend Montmarte to whom wants to see the old and great Paris.
A must see when in paris. Chic bistros, people everywhere, artists working the streets and cosmopolitan Paris at its finest. Just pick a place to eat they are all good. Happy travels

worth a look. Just a short stroll from Sacre Cour, this square is buzzing with artists, many of whom are only too willing to paint or draw your portrait.
This is a good spot to wander or sit at one of the surrounding cafes and watch the passing parade.
interesting artsy part of Paris. We had crepes and delicious Iced Coffee at the restaurant where they filmed the movie Amelie- Cafe des 2 Moulins

Perfect . This is one of our favorite places in Paris, it's got a bit of everything.
It's risqué, it's intimate, and a great place to grab a few drinks.
Wonderful walks. Artists and art are all around. The views are wonderful. Worth the walk and you will see lots of diverse and wonderful things

Paris on a sweet relaxed Day. This place is meant to be walked on foot. Go here for a fun and relaxed day. There are many little shops,restaurants and artsy places. The view is amazing and a truly beautiful experience. Had crepes and macaroons! Buy some souvenirs and enjoy!

Artists at work. This is a fascinating part of Paris dominated by Sacre Couer. You can walk up the steps to the top of feeling energetic. We took the small train.The area is full of tourists, artists, sketchers, pickpockets (mainly young women), cafes and tourist shops. Some of the art works in the small square are rather nice but they didn't seem very cheap. You may find yourself accosted by people wanting to sketch you, for a cost. My noticeable beard caught the attention of a number of these artists. Quality of the sketches varies but I did succumb to one guy who did a very good job. It took 10 minutes in my case because of the level of detail. I haggled a price at the beginning with his 100 euros eventually dropping down to 10 euros when I keep saying 'no'.It's a nice area and probably should be on the list of Paris tourists.

Best. Layover. Ever.. En Route from ATL to Venice, I planned a 7-hour layover in Paris. We took the RER from CDG and boom! We were there! I am a huge fan of Steve Martin's Picasso at the Lapin Agile, and had been wanting to see it for years. Also a big fan of Susan Vreeland's Luncheon of the Boating Party, which mentions the Moulin de la Galette and Renoir's painting of it.It's fun to have a drink at a sidewalk cafe and people-watch, and then sit on the steps of Sacre Coeur and gaze at Paris spread out beneath your feet.

Great place for art lovers. This area is very popular among tourists and a lot of restaurants and cafes are located near.It is on the way to Sacre Coeur cathedral and only ten minutes from famous Pigalle and Moulin Rouge

Lovely place to just chill. Take time out & sit on the grass in the late afternoon & watch the sun go down or go to 1 of the many restaurants enjoy a drink & people watch. The souvenir shopping is good too

It's not a trip to Paris without seeing this!. You can't get a feel for being in Paris without visiting MontMartre. Having the attention of peddlers wanting your attention is fun and definitely Paris.

Nice area to stroll around. This is a nice little area to look around an grab a bite to eat. You can walk up the stairs or take the funicular. The church is beautiful and you get a nice view of the city. The restaurants at the top are quite pricey, but there are also lots of choices below that are more money friendly. As in most tourist areas in Paris, watch out for pickpockets and scam artists. The area we walked through to get to Momtemart was a little sketchy, but worth the time.

Fabric shopping. This in the 18th arrondissment and is a night club district. It is not an area of France that you want to be in at night. We went to discover the fabric district. We went to two fabric stores that were five stories tall each! Marche Saint-Pierre and Tissus Reine, both accept credit cards, and are handicap friendly. If you do not speak French it will be a challenge. Since this is not a tourist area, we did not find anyone who spoke English. We did manage to find some wonderful fabric to take home with us. There are a lot of small fabric stores in this area too, all on the same street. This is the area to go in Paris if you are looking for fabric!

Bohemian space. For me, one of my favourite places in Paris... the energy is really cool and quite. You could find everything for every style. The atmosphere in the coffee's are incredible!!! Preparer you camera for a nice shots of the neighbourhood and Paris. Is close to metro station. Sundays is really bussy, is better if you can go in a week day.
Nice. Nice to walk through but a little cheesy here and there the super touristy center is horrible but the outskirts are nice to see.

Steep narrow laneways & artist square. Sacre Couer is a must visit but recommend you go first thing in morning then spend rest of morning wandering laneways. Have lunch in main square. Food only ok but lots of fun watching the local artists sell their works. Is a little touristy but good people watching.
CREEPY artists. We loved the area, except for the vulgar artists. Avoid the men that want to draw your picture! They are pigs.

Lovely place but hassled a lot 😬. Loved walking around the winding little streets looking at the overpriced art ( but I spose everyone has to make a living and one or two of the artists were actually very good)When we stopped for coffee though we were bombarded by wanna be artists trying desperately to pencil our portrait which spoilt the ambience a little A lot more desperate than I remember it a few years back!Still worth a visit though
Lovely. Lovely part of the city with hidden streets, walkways and parks. Beautiful. Can spend a whole day or two exploring the area.

Great city view of Paris. Wonderful village area to take in a spectacular view of the city of Paris. You must visit the cathedral of the Sacred Heart to fully appreciate the artistic beauty of the mosaic ceilings and breathtaking architecture. You will be approached by local artists requests to do a caricature or drawing of you! Quaint village to learn more about Famous artists like Toulousse who lived in the area.

Super commercial. The church of the Sacre Coeur is really the only place to visit here the rest is a tourist area catering to the public by selling cheap and not so cheap paintings and caricatures and the ever present souvenirs. Busy, crowded and hot in Summer. Rows of shops at the foot of the stairs leading up to the church all pretty much sell the same cheap bric a brac. Much nicer places to visit.
Be careful . This was an absolutely beautiful place but there are many dodgy people around. We went at night and the view was amazing but I felt quite unsafe at times.
Nice view of paris. Nice view, good atmosphere, very artistic cathedral.We had a nice night thereBut there wasn't any bar or restaurant with balcony or view of paris

Did a food tour here . Area is being rejuvenated. The neighbourhood people are very friendly and willing to stop and chat. Young designers and artists have opened up little shops to sell there goods. One of my favourite areas of Paris. Local award winning butchers, chocolate shops, and Macaroon stores. Have Crepe hole in the wall shops. Try the Nutella best ever!

It's a Wonderful Tourist trap. We love the area, the little restaurants. Sitting at an outside table watching the people go by. Artists walking around trying to get someone to let them draw their portrait. Then there is that confection of a church. The views are terrific. It's crowded. So just go with it. Evenings are beautiful, but be aware that they close the park way down after dark. You either go way out of your way to get back to the metro station then or ride the funicular down.

Our favorite neighborhood. We went to Montmartre on our first day in Paris, just to walk around for the evening. We wound up staying until 3:00 am. Over the course of our 6 days in Paris, we kept winding up in Montmartre. We went to see Sacre Coeur, of course, but we also just kept working our way to Montmartre to wind up our days. We sat at sidewalk cafes with a bottle of wine, walked the street, talked with artists, danced some street hip hop late one night, shopped, ate macarons. It was our favorite place to be.

So many hidden treasures. I love Montmartre. I live there! Is like a little village, you get to jump into friends, you make new friends very easily and there is a lot of spots that us locals know that are tourist free. Although, tourists come here for a reason, is beautiful!Go further on your visit that just the Basilique du Sacré Coeur and Place du Tertre classic combo, and go visit the Montmartre Vineyards, the Montmartre cemetery, the Montmartre Museum, the modern art gallery "W" in rue Lepic and have a drink at rue Custine.

Day visit Montmartre. We took the Metro to get the Sacre Couer, which was quick and easy, however the area is a bit dodgy and wouldn't recommend going alone. The artist markets were amazing and we ate a great little bistro and had a fab lunch. The whole day was great walking around the back streets of this area and the view from Sacre Couer was fantastic.

All time favourite. Montmartre is probably one of my favourite areas of Paris. Lovely restaurants and bars, some well hidden. Plenty of character and best views over Paris from the Church Sacre-Coeur!

Beautiful little village. Absolutely loved this place, a little village situated just behind the Basilica.Containing shops, bars and restaurants, with artists sketching in the street and musicians playing, if ever your in Paris I would highly recommend a visit.

Beautiful part of Paris. We did a walking tour in Montmartre and our tour guide was so knowledgeable. It was definitely a highlight of our vacation. Montmartre is a beautiful hilly part of Paris. We ended up at the Sacre Coeur and were amazed by the view of Paris below. Bring good walking shoes for this area of Paris.

Nice for a weekend. We stayed in Montmarte for a long weekend whilst visiting the Moulin Rouge. We enjoyed Montmarte as our base and found a lovely place to eat. The only downside for me was that it was very hilly and there were hundreds of steps. I've also seen reviews saying the area was rough. However, not once did I feel uncomfortable or threatened in any way and I'd certainly return to this area.
Awesome view. It`s a walk up the mountain but you wont regret the view. Museum then to the outdoors to relax and enjoy a view of the city.

Interesting area. The neighborhood is full of great restaurants and shops, and the streets are long and windy. It is very hilly so you will get a good workout but the views from the top are worth it. Go during the day; late at night it seemed a lot sketchier and a number of questionable characters were begging for money. But during the day it felt very safe and we had a great meal at one of the many sidewalk cafes there.

Ah ... Montmartre. This is the second time I have come to Paris and stayed in Montmartre. To me, this is the true Paris. An artists and historian's community. Good value, wonderful surroundings. I would recommend Montmartre district as a good base from which to experience Paris. Also countless shops, cafes, restaurants, bakeries. Love it.

Fantastic Place!. It was our absolute favourite part of Paris, and I am so glad we opted to stay in Montmatre. It just has a really lovely vibe. Go and get lost in the cobbled streets on the way up to Sacre Coeur, and enjoy the atmosphere.

What to see?. Unlike the general oppinion I can say that there is nothing to see here for a tourist other than Sacre Coer. Just tons of loudy touristic restaurants, souvenir shops. There is no artificial side of this place as it was said in the previous reviews.
DALI MUSEUM. Make sure you visit the Salvador Dali museum, just off the main square. Ignore most of the 'artists'.

Where are all the artists?. Beautiful walk to the church, go to the top and look out over Paris. All the artists (?) are doing charactertures in the square (not impressed), Looked like some neat places to eat, but did not try. Famous for Picasso living there for a little while. Nice view, decent walk.

Colourful setting that lost its magic long ago. Songwriter Charles Aznavour in "La Bohème" , sings of a painter that recalls his youthful years in a Montmartre, one that has ceased to exist. "I no longer recognize the walls nor the streets, that had seen my youth. At the top of a staircase I look for the workshop of which nothing survives. In its new décor Montmartre seems sad, and the lilacs died" The words reflect the end of a bohemian period enjoyed by artists such as Dali, Monet, Picasso. And so it is - now filled with artists plying their mass production talents to tourists, and empty restaurants serving characterless world foods such as Burgers, pizzas, pastas. Where is Paris, where has the essence of France gone? Where is the character for which the world once hung on every food, art, or couture development. Its long gone, drowned in a chaotic mess better represented perhaps by a Jackson Pollock of abstract impressionism. Dull, dull, dull disappointing place filled with tacky souvenir shops, empty restaurants serving food lacking both imagination and character, filled with selfie stick wielding tourists buying artwork the artists themselves are prostituted for. France/Paris it is NOT. As the song concludes, "it doesn't mean anything anymore..... but go and have a look. Then tell the truth or it will never change. The Emperor is not wearing any clothes.
Best area in Paris. So much history here, lovely area, got to visit the sacre-coeur while you're here, would love to live here!!!
Brilliant! . Everybody should visit it! Unbelievable! The real Paris. Great artists. Great galleries. Great restaurants, great PARIS

Fabric Stores are Here!. My mom and I did get a little lost here, but if you want to go fabric shopping then this is the place to go. I highly recommend Reine (multiple floors) and Le Coupons de Saint Pierre. If you only speak English then you may have some challenges and I recommend at least learning some French numbers to be able to ask for not only price, but to specify how many meters you'd like to buy.

Loved exploring this artistic corner of Paris. We spent 4+ hours just walking the streets of Montmartre, exploring the shops and walking around the Sacre Coeur (and enjoying the stunning view from there out to Paris). Our highlight though was the Place du Tertre, where the artists are out in force. Wandering around the main square, looking at all the different paintings was wonderful.It's definitely worth a visit when you have time to soak in the atmosphere and admire the streets.

My favorite pictures. We took the funicular up to Sacre Couer and walked back down through the streets of Montmartre (a walk listed in Rick Steves' book). I couldn't stop snapping pictures as it is a very charming place. So many details in the architecture. We went to the Montmartre and Dali museums there and they were both excellent. It's just an amazing place to walk and Fawkes at the surroundings.

what's Paris without Montmartre?. take it in... just a couple of hours will suffice, but you can dine, drink, take in the Moulin Rouge, shop, visit Sacre Couer... and if you're into sex shops, this is your place to be. (There is an erotica museaum, I had no interest to visit!)

Dirty area . We walked around for blocks, actually searching for the hilltop SacreCoeur. The area is littered, some street people offensively aggressive, and generally run down. I would avoid this whole section of Paris.
Shops. We walked around here after we hopped off the metro. Get here early and you can enjoy the neighborhood. Fairly quickly it turns into a zoo with aggressive venders, and tourists!

A Nice Area. A nice area to stroll about.
Artist do their work on the streets & also caricatures & portraits if u like to have one, at a price though.
Lots of cafes & little shops for souvenirs.
Enjoyed strolling & doing a little shopping & eating.
Worth a visit if u have the time.
Amazing!. Loved this place. Went here on a tour with Retro Tours (who are fab by the way) and we loved it. Completely different to the rest of Paris with amazing views.
Fun. If your passion is very overpriced artwork, this is the place for you! It is fun to walk around and look, though.
Delightful . My favourite place in paris.Wandering around looking at all the amazing artwork then the portrait artists working while you sit and eat and drink is amazing.well worth a visit.

Heart of Paris . Not only the church is beautiful inside and outside but the view from it is amazing. You get your exercise to reach this place but you have the view of the city of Paris . You can see the Eiffel Tower coming through the roofs . After the visit of the church you can wander through the the small streets and enjoy lots of restaurants and artists selling their paintings.

Bustling artistic Paris at its best!. Hidden just around behind Sacre-Couer is the bustling artistic area of Montmartre, Place du Tertre. You must go here! Along with the usual souvenir and nic-nac shops, it's a vibrant area full of galleries, artists, cafes and restaurants. Talented artists will offer an impromptu sketch or profile cut-out every 5 meters around the square. If you don't want it done, be firm, but it is all quite friendly and charming really. The Galerie Montmarte displays impressive works by local artists, with commentary by passionate volunteer staff. And then, in this little local gallery, you stumble across a piece by Dali! "Excuse me, is this by THE Dali, as in Salvador?" "Why not, sir, this is a gallery, and at times Dali worked in Montmarte!" Genuinely did not expect this, and his own gallery is just around the corner. While you're here, take a little walk down Rue du Mont Cenis and get a beautiful elevated view of suburban Paris.

A beautiful area - make sure you get to walk this beautiful part of the city.. A beautiful walking area full of artist, food and sites to see. Check it our if you have time. I would go back again and spend more time in this area.

Cheap souvenirs and lots to do at Montmartre. We could have spent the whole day in the Montmartre area but only had about 2 hours, an hour of which was spent eating at Le Petaudiere (separate review). We bought Montmartre biscuits, walked around La Place du Tertre and enjoyed the bustling crowded tourist scene on a Saturday. We didn't get to see the Dali museum nor did we get to spend a lot of time in the galleries. We also missed the funiculaire.The only downside was the constant approach of artists asking if we wanted our portraits drawn and sometimes following us around. As a mother travelling alone with her 2 teen daughters, I didn't appreciate this extra stress. On a cooler day, we would have eaten outside in one of the canvas covered restos in the square. Great place to pick up cheap souvenirs in one concentrated area. My kids disdained anything with Paris written on it but if I had been by myself I would have brought home a suitcase of kitschy gifts.

Incredible view from the top!. It was a great walk from the heart of Paris, about 30 minutes. VERY busy place! Wall-to-wall tourists in August. Fun to sit in an outdoor cafe and people watch...Watch your belongings!!

My favorite part of Paris. Lovely neighborhood in Paris set atop a hill, filled with cafes and street artists. It gives you the real feel of Paris and simply has a feel-good atmosphere to it. Definitely worth a visit!
Magical. The atmosphere in here makes you go back at least a century. Avoid the tourist streets and walk through the alleys and the artists ways, you'll not regret.
Amazing place!. Montmartre is a beautiful and amazing place in Paris. Don´t forget to visit basilica Sacré Coeur. There is a scenic view over Paris.

Must-See!!! Lots of sites and sounds to see in Montmartre!!!. Can't just go to Paris without going to Montmartre! This area is Beautiful to say the least! Lots to do for everyone! Restaurants, sidewalk artisans, shops of all types! You name it, it's here. Take the funicular to Sacre Coeur Basilica if time permits! The Basilica over looks the city of Paris and you can take lots of photos here! You won't be disappointed! Then stroll downhill take in the sites of the area! Lots to see and do! Must-See!!!

Loaded with culture!. After strolling from the sacre couer, we fell upon this area which i had been keen to visit. It was packed full of artists and paying customers having portraits. We felt inspired and went into the dali museum - this is another great place to venture into if you have a spare 40 50minutes. Go and you wont be disappointed!

Iconic white church, chill out on the steps, giving you the best view of Paris. Iconic church, historic, artistic athomosfere, offering some of the greatest views of Paris. Sacre Coeur's hard working nuns and staff need offerings to keep the place neat and clean, so pls bring some cash for the donation box. We spotted pick-pockets dressed as up-market tourists with big jackets - even inside the pay-areas (such as inside the church and the stairs to the top of the dome etc).

Beautiful area to wander at sunset. There are artists lining the streets, painting and drawing portraits of eager tourists that meander through the area. The sacred heart church is lovely, though we went at night and I bet it is more beautiful during the day. Everything is very walkable and great for people who don't have anywhere else to be and can just burn time wandering aorund.

Bus Tour through . We only got to see Montmartre from the top of a bus. But an impression we did get. Very mixed crowd, a bit sleazy lots of bars. Basically a great place to visit after strolling through the quartiers chique

A must see... But pricey..!!. This is the traditional artist district of Paris.The views of the city are breathtaking. The history of the area is easily understood. This is an obvious tourist stop. There are souvenir shops everywhere and there many artists offering their paintings. Some might approach on the street willing to do your portrait for a price. ($$$)Recommend you take the little sightseeing train. You can see and learn a lot about the neighbourhood in a few minutes and it's reasonably priced.
Magical. Even if with the fear post terroristic attack, it is a magical place. Very characteristic and pleasant. It is a joy walk in these streets with the artist painting.
Wedding anniversary . Was great wandering around soacking up the experience of this great place. A must go to place when visiting Paris

Quaint art place but food overpriced. When visiting Paris this is always my favourite place to visit. We went here our first and last nights this trip. Unfortunately this time some artists were quite pushy trying to get you to buy. And our meal was way overpriced with very poor service. We enjoyed far better meals a brief walk from Notre Dame than at Montmartre this time around. Still, if you want to see artists and stroll cobble lanes, this is a good place to go.

Great neighborhood. Take time to visit this iconic neighborhood. It is somewhat touristy, but well,worth your time. A little difficult to get to, however, the funicular in front of Sacre Coeur gets you to the top of the hill with out too much effort. Have lunch or dinner, enjoy the shops and breathe in the atmosphere and great views of Paris!

Great Atmosphere- A must visit. You can definitely tell why artists flocked to Montmartre. It is such a lively and spirited area. You also have a view of beautiful Paris and the Eiffel Tower from Sacre Couer. I highly suggest you stay in this area or take several days to visit this special part of Paris.

Must see. After visiting Sacre Couer stay a while in Montmatre, a favourite area of Paris. Follow the Rue Lepic towards the Moulin Rouge making sure you pass some time in the Cafe des deux Moulins, where the movie Amelie was based. Fayre here too is of good quality and reasonably priced. Lemonade on draught was new to me.

up the hill.... Big hill, LOTS of stairs, but worth the exertion. The basilica is inspirational. Fun spot to walk around, but very touristy and overpriced these days. The artists and writers have moved elsewhere, although there are plenty of shops and distractions to amuse. A lot like the Village in New York. Wear comfortable shoes!

A village within a city. I just love Montmatre which combines over the top tourism, with bustling Sacre Coeur and street artists and around the next corner is the only vineyard left in Montmatre and delightful restaurants in Abesse.

Great Place to see!. Although there's lots of tourists, it's still a wonderful place to go to, feel a little bit more of Paris. Cobble stones, restaurants, artists with their beautiful little artwork!
Best area of Paris. This is Best area of Paris to stay as a tourist as there is so much to see and do. Everything is so conveniently located for all of the main tourist attractions

Walkabout around Montmare. Booked a walking tour to view and learn about the history of Montmare. Was a very sunny day and the walk consisted of cobbled paths on hilly terrain.Rich in history and nostalgia, this place is a must see for those interested in the lives of various writers, artists and creative people in the past

romantic area. although the name of the area doesnt imply that, the view from the top is so romantic.
area is full of cafes and street painters and artists. i would difinitly recommend it for couples for a romantic afternoon

A Good Tour. Very interesting area, once you are out of the tourist areas. A couple of great galleries worth seeing. Give the main strip restaurants a miss as the food is average, but the settings are wonderful.

Great atmosphere. Montmartre is excellent. The atmosphere is wonderful. Lots of artists wanting to sell their paintings. Be aware that lots also want to sketch you and your loved ones. You have to be quite forceful if you don't want them too. Lots of places for you to eat/drink at. Lovely way to spend a few hours. Metro is local also.

Great way to spend an afternoon. Well worth the visit! I recommend taking the funicular to Montmartre as there are a lot of stairs. We had fun watching all the artists at work. Several asked us if we wanted to sit and have a portrait done of us. We did and it was fun. We also enjoyed going in and out of all the little shops in the area. We found a lot of souvenirs at reasonable prices to bring back to family and friends. When you are finished for the afternoon I recommend taking the trolley back down the hill.

Fun and very safe !!!. My wife and I visited Paris in August, 2015 and again the last week of July, 2016. Both times we visited Montmartre and had the best time. The local artists will sketch you and it is worth the time and money. Great people watching!

Cool Parisian Neighborhood. Home of the Moulin Rouge, Montmartre is a cool little neighborhood with an urban appeal. I had the best salmon crepe ever in Montmartre! My mouth is watering just thinking about it.

The best of Paris. The Montmartre area is MUST-SEE in Paris. The best way to do that is join a walking tour. That's what my friend and I did. This neighborhood has so much history and until now it has maintained its unique character from the rest of the city. A great way to end the tour is to see the Sacre Ceour -- where you have a panoramic view of Paris.

crowded but joyful. I loved visiting this part of the city. The Dali museum was a delight and it was so much fun to visit all the artists painting on the square. Sacre Coeur is here, and while my friend climbed to its top, I sat on the steps and listened to street musicians. We had lunch at a small cafe around the corner from the square under blooming wisteria vines.

Hike up the steps for a beutiful sight all around. I highly recommend walking or taking an open air taxi to see this beautiful hilltop area. There was an art festival when I was there, but the place has many artists, galleries, and well-priced souvenier shops. There are sandwich and crepe shops and many street artists who are ready to please with their artwork. Just prepare for a crowd, all with their arms up in the air as they lift cameras out to capture the incredible views. The highlight is the architecture of the Basilica. Highly recommend visiting this are in Paris. The Yellow HOHO bus comes here too if you have trouble climbing or want to gert a ride there. The same bus drives by the Moulon Rouge area too.

Amazing!. Artists everywhere, stunning views, amazing shops and the Moulin Rouge. It is part of the sex industry side so be warned if taking young children with inquisitive minds! Breathing Paris! Loads of bars, patisserie shops, charcuterie etc

The most romantic place in paris. For me, by far it is the most romantic place in paris. Visit the sacre coeur, have a sandvich on the stair in front of it, view a spectacular view of Paris, visit the shops, have a coffee and let an artist make your picture for 20 euros.

Watch out for the girls with clipboards - they're professional pickpockets. Fabulous, beautiful place thronged with tourists. Pickpockets are everywhere - keep your personal belongings zipped away.Beware the sweet girls who approach you pointing to a printed sheet asking for help for deaf/mute people. My sympathetic Australian friend stopped to talk to them despite me encouraging her to walk on. She lost only a cheap pen from a pocket of her bag, but I went back to challenge them. Suddenly they could talk after all - protesting their innocence. Yeah right - nasty people preying on those who would give money to a deserving cause. Fleece you twice - take the money and while you're distracted their hands are in your bag.

A wonderful place to explore. We spent an very enjoyable day exploring Monmartre in the rain. Exploring the many alleys revealed tempting cafes and brasseries, galleries and op shops. Avoiding the tourist queues of the cathedral we enjoyed the small galleries, cosy pubs for local draft beer and finding treasures in the second hand shops.
It's lovely. A walk on Montmartre should be included in your stay in Paris, it's a place where you can really breathe in some Parisian atmosphere...

This is a great place to be.. We stayed here, ate here and sight saw here. I love this place so full of character. You must walk beyond the Moulin Rouge which is in a sleezy street and appreciate the wonderful cafes and food and the historical places. We ate at different cafes each night - some better than others. Try the Moules and confit of duck.

Pretty awesome spot to chill and watch the sunset. We went up on a warm August evening, shared a pizza and watched the sunset while sitting on the steps at the top. Watch out for scammers (the guys with loops of string) and pickpockets. There are guys walking around selling beers (they came out in more force as it got closer to sunset) for 3 euros. Cheapest we got them down to was 3 beers for €4.50.There was some cool music and street performers and we had a great time chilling, drinking beer and watching the sun go down.

Can be the most beautiful area of Paris if you know where to look. Montmartre is not only a cliché : it's indeed one of the most beautiful areas of Paris. But you have to know where to look ! Try to ask a Parisian to guide you ☺

A charming bit of history. Worth the long hike up from the Red Light District through the gauntlet of souvenir shops. The view of Paris is magnificent. Once you catch your breath, another short walk (uphill) brings you to a courtyard filled with artists and cafes. Colorful and romantic, a must see.
Best area in Paris. The best area in Paris for day and night. The view from Sacre Coeur is beautiful and the restaurants in area very good.
Must see in Paris. The Sacre Coeur church nearby and the Place du TertreMany shops and cafes for lunch, dinner and some drink underway.
