Montmartre. The most authentic french stylish place in Paris!! Beautiful!! The painters , the artists spread all around are a sight to see! & the restaurants, small and cozy..amazing ambiance. Colourful. Lively. Simply beautiful!

Best of Paris. If you want to experience Paris, you have to visit Montmarte. Yes, it's a tourist attraction, but it's also not to be missed. Watch out, you may get caught by an artist trying to sketch you, but just keep walking and enjoy the whole experience.

So Parisian it hurts. Though up by the Sacre Coeur is quite overrun by tourist traps and tat shops, there are still many original art galleries and several good ice cream places. However, if you venture down the steps and towards Place des Abbesses, you find a much more french, thriving and bustling little area full of restaurants and bars!

Avoid the tourist area and explore the back streets. It's amazing here once you get away from the touristy area. Explore the back streets and winding roads. You won't regret it. It's actually quiet and calm. Do a little research and you will have a great experience.

A Must For Art lovers. So mnay great things to see and do in Montmartre. And of course you must visit if you are any lover of art. It is the home of the Moulin Rouge and where so many of the greatest artist resided for some time or another. There is a court yard set up on a Sunday where many artists go to drawer and be inspired.

Great for first impression. . The reputation that preceded the site helped make this better. It's also a collection of things great of and by itself. The place is old, on a high spot, has a spectacular basilica, a funicular and market place with a lowbrow ambience. Steep hills. Be prepared.

Lots of shops shows and history . There is a lot to do here. It's touristy so bring your wallet and be prepared to pay. Some of the souvenirs in shops are negotiable to a certain extent if you're prepared to leave it behind. There are some very old churches and lots of great places to eat (some of the best in Paris) and some great (also of the best) bakeries in Paris. Check the reviews and you'll see great food and some fun things to do! Moulin rouge is here too!
Not impressed. Seedy, grungy, touristy. I was told I went down the wrong street toward Pigale with all of the sex shops. Understood. But looking up rue lepic didn't look any better.

Place to stay in paris . We stayed in Holiday inn in Montmartre and loved the area. There are amazing restaurants and cafes and tourist spots, so u r not bored. It is a lovely and romantic place to be in Paris . So even if u have to spend a little more to stay here, do that...,

Walk. Yes it is painful to go up and down but walking is still the best way for me. Just try to be early to avoid the crowd. You will encounter all sorts of artists - yes, they are. Some critics will say no but I respect their work. Restaurants, shops along the way. You can get a painting of the eiffel or your caricature for about 120euros. The view on top is worth the hype.

the best neighborhood in Paris. Every time I think of Paris, this neighborhood graces my memory. I spent half a day walking around looking at all the work of the artists, eating delicious french food, and enjoying the area.

Must visit..An Alternative side to Paris . The Montmarte walk was one of the most interesting parts of our trip..it's an alternative experience compared to the usual Eiffel tower and museums experience. Try to book a guided walking tour so that you don't get lost in those lanes and get to see all the important sites/ areas of attraction.

Walking Food tour of Montmartre with PJ. Our walking food tour of Montmartre with PJ was one of the highlights of our 2-week trip to London and Paris. PJ is knowledgeable, interesting, funny, generous.... Everything that you would want for this type of tour! After visiting some local shops including a boulangerie, fromagerie, boucherie, and wine store, we were able to sample the cheese, bread, wine and meat in a little "secret" dining room. PJ again gave us some tips about selecting and eating the items that we were tasting. Next we went for dessert at a crêperie, and finally we were able to take home some delicious macarons and chocolates from Chocolat Illèné. I highly recommend this tour! (**Do not eat before!!)

The views over Paris are well worth the climb. The other reviews cover just about everything but be careful on the steps up to the Sacre Coeur as there are scammers on the way up trying to literally snare unwary tourists into buying friendship bracelets - so keep hands away from them and keep walking. The views over Paris are well worth the climb but again be careful of people asking you to sign petitions – this is another scam and could cost you dearly.

Really crowded. Montmartre itself is beautiful, a really nice area. The only downside is the amount of tourists crowding the streets and the huge amounts of street vendors selling all sorts of trinkets. Sort of a downer for me.

A good Sunday trip. We asked our tour guides for a good place to go on Sunday since a lot of places are closed (especially in August) and they recommended here. Take a cab to the top by the church and walk down - it is pretty hilly. The red light district is at the bottom, but it was fine on a Sunday afternoon. It was busy. Lots of little shops/cafes in a very European neighborhood with narrow winding streets. Also lots of artists if you want a portrait drawn (we did not). We ate a nice cafe (LaRughetta) on the walk down to the red light district to get our cab back to the hotel. A good way to experience a Paris neighborhood on a Sunday.
So cute!. Super cute and what I imagined Paris to be like, lovely little lanes and cafes to watch the world go by. Much more pleasant at night as the sun is setting with mega views over Paris

Old world. Love this area of cafes and old world charm. Had a coffee and our granddaughter's portrait painted in the street. The artists are plentiful and can be a bit pushy but we already knew we wanted it done so not a problem. Make sure you choose the style though as they do vary eg; charcoal/colour/portraiture/charicature. Various prices and sizes too.

Classically Paris. Waked the district on a Saturday. It was delightful. Not too crowded. The streets were almost like a movie set view of Paris. Great shops, nice homes to see, interesting streets to walk. It a fun experience. Worth 4 hours.

A nice place to spend a sunny afternoon. Go to the Sacre Coeur for the beautiful views of the city. We were too exhausted from sightseeing all week to climb to the top of the dome inside, but still had lovely views. We also enjoyed a little train ride through the city. You can catch this train right outside the front of Sacre Coeur. We especially enjoyed strolling through the Place du Tertre (artists square) just near the Sacre Coeur. Bought a small painting from a local artist as my favourite souvenir. Many people were having portraits drawn. We got some tips from the Rick Steves' walking tour guide as to locations to visit while walking through Monmartre. One of my favourites was visiting the Cafe de 2 Moulins (Cafe from the Film "Amelie"). We found a nice Gelato shop. Walked by the Moulin Rouge, but never went inside. We also enjoyed walking through the beautiful cemetery. Peaceful and interesting. This is a beautiful district to explore on foot.

Too touristy. While everyone should consider seeing Sacre Coeur, the immediate surrounding area is over run with tourists and cheap souvenir shops. There are a few nicer shops but they are more a rarity than the normal. As you move away from Sacre Coeur, this appears to be a working class area and shops are associated with every day living.

Half and Half. Some places in this district are very pretty and have personality, other places...not so much. Our hotel was in the Montmartre district, right around the corner from the Moulin Rouge. A lot of that area was full of weird sex shops and unsavory-looking people. Be careful around there because a lot of pickpocketing and late-night crime can happen around Pigalle. Otherwise, it was lovely. Be careful of people near Sacre Coeur; there's a gang of men who will harass you to buy things or make you pay for a "friendship bracelet". The restaurants around here are good. We found a lot of little places that sold great chocolate and other sweets. Most of this area also speaks English. Just be polite and ask (in French) if they speak English. Tons of little shops with neat arts. I bought a few cat figurines and knick-knacks from hole-in-the-wall places.

Tourist trap deluxe!. Nothing like I remember it - full of tourist rubbish and although the streets are still charming beware of the being lured into touristy shops - not my happy memories of past visits
Nice view. We went up the Montmartre to see the cathedral. There we enjoyed a fantastic football and acrobatic show by a street artist. The view of the city from above was awesome. I recommend it.

A walker paradise of color and flavour. Just to walk the streets of this part of Paris takes you back to the time of VanGogh, Matisse, Lautrec, and thousands of artists who struggle to earn a living even now. It is romantic, colourful, historic and lovely. A must visit neighbourhood of Paris.

Montmartre is the artistic calmination of the Basilica.. After finishing the visit to the church. Everyone needs to relax at Montmartre square. And everyone relaxes in the presence of so many artists sitting and painting on demand. In addition to the real art of so many artists who has been doing painting for over 40 years. The visitor enjoys the view at a cafe in the square and watch a place so unique that one would love to stay as long as one could stay.

Busy area up on the hill. Our visit here was enroute to the Basilica of the Sacre Coeur. It is a busy community was the h a lot of restaurants and shops. We did visit a little square up by Sacre Coeur which was so nice and felt like what Paris is a about with artist, music and authentic Parisian food. ( if your up at Sacre Coeur, facing the basilica, it's to the left of the basilica and to the rear... Sorry I don't know the name of it but it's worth it!!)

We did a free walking tour, and it was a great morning here.. Very interesting part of France, our guide was clear that Montmartre was/is outside Paris' walls! Lovely hilly area above the city. Interesting streets and cafes, fromageries, bakeries, green grocers abound. Historic sights only a guide will help you see and appreciate. The two hours we spent on the tour were the highlight of our stay in Paris. We stayed on and saw Sacre Coure, then found a great cafe serving Viet food.

Worth the journey as it's unlike other parts of Paris. We nearly didn't go here, but read a review on tripadvisor and decided it was worth a look. We didn't regret it. Amazing views of Paris buildings and rooftops from the top. Lots of little streets and cafes and shops at the village at the top. Even if you don't go into the Sacred Heart Church at the top, it makes for great pictures from the outside and people were taking selfies galore. Also the place to get your picture drawn by one of the many artists around the little central market place. I would watch them do someone else first as some were better than others and all had different styles, so worth taking the time to see what you want. Some people were wandering around with sketch books also offering to draw people, but you might want to go to one of the ones where you get to sit down and they take their time drawing you. It wasn't cheap to sit down and eat at any of the places up there, captive audience I guess, but not that bad if you want a takeaway crepe or something. And if you want to buy the little coloured Eiffel Tower key-rings, they sell for 50 cents each in the shops up there, but the guys selling them from the floor on the main steps up, are doing 5 for 1 euro. Don't be put off if you can't get up all the steps, there was a tram up and also a little train going up the road. It is quite cobbled though, so be aware of that for pushchairs, wheelchairs etc. Also beware of the bunch of men hanging out at the steps near the bottom, as we were coming down, they were grabbing us to try and tie a string around our finger to then make a bracelet to force you to pay for it. They were quite aggressive, so I suggest making no eye contact, keep your hands in your pockets or balled up so they can't grab your fingers and trap you, and just keep walking. If you like skyline views, it really is worth it though.

Magico. This is my favorite place in Paris, it's magic, it's perfect. These streets, all the artists, the atmosphere is great... I remember that I sang with a street artist in Sacre Coeur's stairs! Beautiful memories, hoping to go back soon

Lunch and wonder. Montmartre is next to the Sacre Ceour so worth checking both out. There are lots of painters displaying work in the square along with lots of restaurants to have lunch. Montmartre church is very pretty and in the style of the Sacre Ceour. Well worth a visit. You can ride up on the funicular if you don't fancy the walk and there's a visitors train if you want driving around the village. Including lunch there's at least three hour s of entertainment, but you could shorten or lengthen that with or without a visit to the Montmartre museum.

Delightful stroll. We ventured from the Basilica Sacre Coeur down through the streets and neighborhoods of Montemarte which abound with sidewalk cafes and small neighborhood stores. A fun time of wandering!

Lovely area to wander round. We spent a pleasant morning wandering around the area. We took the Metro to Abbesses and followed directions to the small funicular that takes you to the top of the hill for the cost of a metro ticket. We enjoyed the views over Paris and of the Sacre Coeur. We then wandered slowly down the hill, avoiding the most obvious tourist traps. I'd recommend a visit to the Musee de Montmartre, a peaceful oasis of art and history of the area.

Busy. Situated on a hill next to sacre couer charming area of artist and their worksPlenty of places to eat, though a little bit touristy.You won't find traditional French Faye but a 'Disney' version of what the tourists think Paris should be like
Nice view. Go up to Montmartre for the best views of Paris. It is best to go at sundown. You will find lots of restaurants and stores. There are artists painting and doing portraits.

Great place. . This is a wonderful little place full of little bits and bobs. A real mixture of shops bars and little delicatessens. We did a walking food tour around here and we're given all the local info on where to go to get real authentic French cuisine and a few things to look out for when choose your stores for food.

A peaceful oasis. If you want to discover the more peaceful and laid back atmosphere of Paris, this is a must see. The quaint streets lined with bakeries and shops are a relief from the hustle and bustle of Paris proper. Give yourself ample time to stroll through the square where you will meet hundreds of artists. Do not be afraid to approach them and discuss their various styles and techniques as they welcome engaging you in conversation. There are several bistros at which to eat and relax while watching the artists at work. A truly relaxing experience for both young and old.
Beautiful neighbourhood. This neighbourhood is beautiful and the church is so breath taking.. This is a must see in Paris! I would go back 100 more times..

Very french.. This is the area where we had our hotel. Nice french vibes in the whole area. But in the night the old story behind the moulin rouge comes to life, that street becomes a sex shop with weird costumes and toys sold in 50% of the stores. We were not prepared for that part. But it's nice, close to many tourist attractions.

A Must to visit when in Paris. We visited here twice we enjoyed it so much, it is full of charm character and interesting people working and exhibiting their works. There is plenty of choices for places to eat and drink and enough souvenir shops to satisfy most tastes. If you are walking it is quite a steep climb but there is a funicular and buses and the metro to get you there.

The best part of town.. I stayed for a week living close to Jules Jordin which was a fantastic neighborhood to live in. Here it was nice and quiet and crowded with a lot people. I had a close walk up the streets and stairs to Sacré Couer which is a place I love to be at and my choice of hotel had much to with that. The first time I was there staying around Le Gare d'Nord going to see that church and some more parts of this part of town I imediatly felt that next time I will stay in Montmartre. So I did and enjoyed it so much that there is not an other part of town I will stay the next time either.

One of our favorite places to visit in Paris!. When we took our 2 young kids to Paris recently, we couldn't wait to take them to the top of Monmarte. My husband and I have been before, and Monmarte does not disappoint. We learned this time that the tram takes metro tickets, so we used those to try to save our kids legs for the stairs, but we probably wouldn't do it again. We love the area, and truly enjoy the hike up the stairs to experience one of the most amazing views. My 2 young kids (4, 6) made it to the top without a problem, and loved seeing the Eiffel Tower and the city. We walked through the church on the way out, and there was a service going on, which was great to experience. The people trying to get you to sign petitions or put bracelets on your hands are very prevalent in this area, but you can't beat the views!

wonderfu;. We stayed in this area and the streets are amazing to walk and see the little shops, look at the old buildings with the wrought iron railings with beautiful flowers, listen to street entertainers. A must walk area, stop in a sidewalk cafe and watch people walk by.
Got to!. The square with all the artists is just buzzing! And some of them are really good. If you want your portrait painted then have a good look round the whole square first.
Worth a meander round. Enjoyed a bus trip and a walk here. Moulin Rouge windmill is a must to see but we did not do show, as children too young.

Highlight of my trip to Paris. If I ever return to Paris I want to just spend the whole time here. You canniest wander around the charming streets to feel like a local, shop, dine and take pictures galore. So charming and fun.

IMO, a little part of Heaven. Just walking around Montmartre was like being transported back in time. People watching, it was evident the residents know they have a special place on Earth. The atmosphere, a small French village, is everywhere. We stayed at Hotel Basss on Abbessess (avenue?) which is full of excellent cafes, shops, life! Awesome crepes shop, highly recommend the smoke salmon. Visited 3 cafes for meals, all excellent! Parisians take the time to enjoy life & to take part in it in Montremarte was the best part of Paris.

Great Walk. My boyfriend and I really enjoyed this part of the trip. It was a very clean, beautiful and fun area to walk around. Lots of food, sex shops, shopping, and art. We went after visiting the basilica and were pleased that not many people were around! Very relaxing and nice to take in a different part of Paris!

Quaint part of Paris. Monmartre is a must see. It has lots of gorgeous streets you can wander and a lovely market with lots to buy from local artist. There is plenty of restaurants to choose from. One of my favourite places to visit.

Paris's most nostalgic 19th century neighborhood. If you've seen Woody Allen's Midnight in Paris, here it is. Quaint wandering streets. Artists and cafes at every turn. The Place du Tertre at its center. Go. Stay. Return. I will never tire of Montmartre.

Coca Cola doesn't Taste that good!. We enjoy the Montmartre area very much so we decided to visit the area again. After strolling through we decided to grab a bite to eat and picked a courtyard cafe. Being seated and looking over the menus picked a couple of entrees and two Coca Colas medium sized. Not seeing on the menu or asking our waitress the price for our drinks we were quite surprised too see our bill with each medium priced out at 10.5 euro. We didn't complain or comment, but did leave with buyers remorse. Next time we will Ask!

Sex Shops, Crowds of Tourists. We visited Montmartre many years ago, and thought it was a seedy, touristy area. With so many wonderful places in Paris, we never saw a reason to return. But this year, I read that the area had improved, so we decided to take another look. We won't be back. It is still a seedy, touristy area with many sex shops.
So different, so cosmopolitan too. Well worth an explore. From the amazing cathedral to the square with the fantastic restaurants and artists. So vibrant. Don't miss Dali's exhibition.

Don't miss walking along these streets!. We did a Secret Food Tour of Paris and walked along the streets of Montmartre for a few hours. This is a lovely neighborhood with amazing food. Even if you aren't going on a tour here, don't miss this area!

Crowded!. Nice street, lots of artists but oh so obviously commercialized. Didn't help that it was packed to the brim, at the cafes, on the streets, everywhere! Was here in the summer, so maybe it would have been a more pleasant visit in the off-peak period.

Excellent . This place offers a wide range of possibilities.From a quite inner piece moment in the Sacre Coeur to the nightlife scene around the Moulin rouge. Beside the typical look you can find a nice range of fabric shops around Anvers as well as sex shops. Off course it is littered with bistros and restaurants. Be careful which ones you choose.

Fun location. Montmartre is a must see location while visiting Paris. It is located at the top of a hill with excellent views of Paris. The cathedral is easy to see from many areas in Paris, but what you don't see is the very busy and fun square in front of the church. There are many artists that are selling their art and many are willing to create a painting for you. It's fun to sit at one of the many cafes, have a drink or a meal and watch all the people walking by.Lots of fun interaction with both the artists and tourist.

Bohemian. Montmartre is famous since, some of the most relevant artists ever lived there. Lively, genuine and unforgettable. if you fancy buying paintings there are tons of new artist with interesting pieces of art. I love it
Got to see. True Paris, an amazing place to see artists and be seen. Art is in the air. Also you have wonderful views of the city.

Somehow rises above the tourism. I've been there on several trips and every time feel part of an art scene. How is this, being an artist myself? "Power points on the planet?" That sounds too New Age. But, there are real working artists who really care to talk to you (and paint you!) I'd suggest seeing it after Sacre Coeur so your'e in the right mellow mood. Lovely.

Hilly part of Paris . This place is multi cultural. White church is simply a must visit even though you have to climb steps the view is wonderful. You get a lot of shops which sell wedding ware, from decor to wedding frocks.

My favorite place in Paris. Ive been to Paris 3 times and this is still my favorite place to spend a day, without a doubt. If you get of at Pigalle, walk past Moulin Rouge and up towards Sacré-Cœur, you get to see SO much of this gorgeous area of Paris. From the art, the countless amazing cafes and all the fench buildings you will not be disappointed. And finally, the view from the top is even more breathtaking than from the Eiffel tower! You will fall in love here.

Different part of Paris . It has tourist attractions Moulin Rouge and Sacred Heart Cathedral and cheap clothing shops. I bought some very nice material for my home at descent prices from Marche St Pierre. Looks it's the neighborhood of the working class. People are friendly and helpful . This place has sex shops specially near Moulin Rouge so I was dreading if my child would see them and ask difficult questions.

Enjoyed. We reached this area via the hop on/ hop off bus not knowing what to expect. What a surprise! A very busy area of Paris with lots to see and do . We went up to Sacre Coeur ( a must see) and bthen paid 10 euro's each to go on a tourist "train" which took us on a trip thru Montmartre including along the Main Street to see many sights including the "red light area"and the Moulin Rouge theatre. Lots of places to eat and relax. Don't miss seeing this area as we loved it.

Gorgeous town. Full of art shops, cafes and a square market place where you can see artists paining away and selling their works too. Very hilly and cobble stone paths so wear good comfortable shoes. Loved it. And from the top of the hill on a clear day you have a magnificent view. We took the metro and didn't have any trouble making our way around and finding our way back to Paris. Much cheaper than booking a tour or bus to take you there.

A different side of Paris!. We stumbled on this area accidentally but fell in love with it immediately. The atmosphere is fresh and lively, and everyone doesn't seem to mid you and your friends goofing around! There is lots to eat and drink around the area for reasonable prices!

Beautiful romantic place. Although bustling with tourists, it still is a rather romantic place to be. Very good restaurants all around and terraces to have coffee or drinks. Watching the people go by, all the artists busy with portraits etc. Its very nice

probably one of the most beautiful place on earth. Out of this world. Real rustic France feel in artists corner.the view from the top is out of a dream,you can not put it into words.Some of the acts by street performers are incredible too.Plenty of Lucky lucky men selling bits and bobs but there no hassle really.Taxi from Eiffel Tower 15 euros Must see!!!!!!And you must have a drawing done

Fantastic place . Great place watch out for the artists !! Some are good some are a bit iffy .. They charge quite a lot.. Lots of bars and restaurants. We had an happy hour chips and beer . Great atmosphere .. As it goes dark the lights are beautiful ... Not many toilets so make sure you use the amenities when you have a drink in the bar. We struggled to find a wc some will let you use the toilets ... It did spoil the day ..
Fabulous !. Obviously quite a tourist attraction, and very commercial, but a warm and friendly atmosphere that it contagious. Some very good art work mixed in with quite a bit of kitsch.

On of My Favorites in Paris!. Visited Montmartre for the first time, and honestly just couldn't stay away, making our way back here at least three times while in Paris. Loved everything, from the boho atmosphere to the food and the little shops throughout. We truly loved this are of Paris and cannot wait to pay it another visit some time soon!

A journey through the history of Parisian bohemians!. My wife and I took a tour with Culturefish! where we spent 3+ hours walking through Montmarte. I fell in love with this area of Paris, as well as with the rich history of bohemians, artists, and creative geniuses. This part of Paris felt majestic, from the cafe in the movie Amélie to the shared residence of Picasso, Modigliani, Van Gogh, and so many others.If you're looking for something different than the typical Paris tourist attractions, go visit Montmartre! And make sure you seek out some history and guides, as they really help bring the town to life!

We went in a deux chevaux tour.. OK it sounds touristy but we were there for only a weekend and my daughter thought it would be great for us to revisit some of our old haunts. The trip was great and included champagne. Just one of those one off things which worked out well

Awesome . We visited Montmartre many years ago, bought a painting and wanted to see it again. The first time, we walked up the steps but this time, we rode up on the tram. The view of Paris is fantastic from here. Sacre Coeur is spectacular. And again, there were many artists selling their work and we purchased an original oil that was not a cliche street scene.

Tacky, touristy and compelling. Montmartre can be a bit of on the tacky side, with all the street peddlers, pickpockets and gaudy shops stuffed with merchanduse aimed at the tourist trade. There's obviously a reason. One is the charm of the steep old streets. The crowds of tourists themselves are compelling to people like me who like to watch Thorpe human parade almost anywhere Sacre Cour is a dominating element from most of Paris and it returns the favor wit steps and other aeries. As a compulsive about cathedrals from a secular view, I also cider the divine either as designed or just occurs. Despite its considers appeal due to its site and meticulous construction and richness of detail, it is too studied and not to the minds of many. Not very inspiring as architecture. In the area of the old square and the streets that feed into it are some decent restaurants that are ideal for sitting with a drink and admiring your Fellow humans are not There is a vey good. Us rum wpwhi h outs the artustS area into perspective. Change is inevitable and views have become expensive, some of the sites that once graced the core areas, those with the best views. There was once a restaurant with a lively open air beer in the rest which offered decent beer or wine with hours of pleasant gazing over the city Waking the streets and stopping fir a drink, perhaps a Ricard, you can. Bits of why poor artists loved it so much aside from being poor. It was a home for some of old radicals who followed s commune. Clemenceau was one years before he came to the front of the French Republic, The tram up and down is a great thing for old genders. Me, and kids

Superb tour of Montmartre. We thoroughly enjoyed this brief walking tour of Montmartre and felt the history come alive through our guide's highlights of St. Denis, VanGogh, Renoir, and Picasso. We also circled back for baguettes, cheese, and beautiful fruits and vegetables from the lovely markets after visiting Sacre Coeur. Our guide Eddie, was charming, knowledge, and a delight on our rainy, chilly morning. While we arrived early enough on a sleepy August morning to make the skip-the-line tickets to the Orsay unnecessary, I am sure they would come in handy when the crowds are heavy. A worthwhile experience!

Truly amazing. A lot of the area is full of tourists. It is still worth visiting. Get a fantastic view of Paris in front of Sacre Cœur cathedral. Wander round the little lanes, see the cafe where Amelie was filmed. You get a real feel of the Parisian atmosphere and can imagine it's past history.

An absolute must. I'd never herd of this place but one of my wife's clients had recommended it. We did struggle to find it but when we did boy was it worth it. The views over Paris are amazing. Lots of stairs through the park up to the cathedral (there's a small railway to take you up there if you wish). Very much the artist area with plenty of people offering to do a portrait. Great place for lunch while you're up there & it takes you away from all the hustle & bustle of central Paris.

Usually too crowded. This is definitely a place to visit off-season, but if you must go in-season and want to see it without being buffeted by the tourist hordes, take the small Montmartre bus from the 18th arrondisement Hotel de Ville up to the top, just past Sacre Cour, near the main place and get off if the crowd is reasonably sized or, if not, just stay on the bus until it returns to where it had started. You will have just seen Montmartre on the most reasonably priced tourbus in Paris ... and can then return when the massive crowd is less daunting ... rainy days and prior to Easter weekend.

Beautiful spot on one of the hills of Paris. We had been all over Paris but never to Montmartre and I wanted to see it. On another trip to Paris I said to my wife I am going today as I have a 1936 pre-Nazi print of the steps of Montmartre by Brassai on my wall. That print kept sucking me in wanting to see those steps with the lamps posts in the fog. We went and the church was immediately evident but could not find my steps until I rounded a corner and there they were. A bucket list item crossed off. The whole experience was fantastic. Go and see it all but don't miss the steps. One last comment, all of the cab stands that day were refusing to take Americans!! We had half of Paris to cross to get to our bus at the place de la guillitine and would not make it on time on foot...we saw an empty cab double parked got in and waited for the driver and told her where we wanted to go, begrudgingly she took us. They were nasty that day unless you came out of a large hotel, then they would take you and that's how we got to Montmartre in the first place, getting back was different. We were last there in 2014.

Great hipster vibes. I might sound harsh but I never have enjoyed Paris even through I visited over 6 times in last 5 years but Montmarte district is amazing and has completely different feel. Enjoyed day walking around, stopping in lovely French caffes and boutiques

Lived and travelled here. Having travelled around this area over the years it's not until I lived here that I found it's hidden treasures. It's best to stroll around on a Sunday and take in all that is Montmartre.

Fantastic. Great part of Paris lots of shops restaurants and lots of buzz
Stayed in this area and so glad as otherwise may have missed this gem of a corner

Best area in Paris. Just go! Take the metro and spend a few hours exploring this fabulous neighbourhood. So picturesque it's like stepping back in time. Your metro ticket will also get you a ride on the cable car that takes you up to Le sacre coeur cathedral, save your legs! Read up on the history of the area before you go it will make the visit more enjoyable.

Walking Tour . We joined a Discover Paris walking tour of Montmartre. Our guide was a young up & coming artist/painter who was very passionate about the area and keen to give us a side to Montmartre that most tourists miss out on. She pointed out various eateries that the locals go to. As well as a café where Renoir painted one of his well known paintings "Bal du moulin de la Galette". She showed us other places frequented by several painters. We ended the walk at the back of Sacre Coeur. We then walked around to the front to take in the beautiful view of Paris. Montmartre is a vibrant place and very popular with tourists and petty thieves!

Best place in Paris. This area is, in my opinion, the best in Paris. So many things to do and see there, relax at cafes, have a great lunch/dinner, visit Sacre Coeur, watch the painters and shop for souvenirs. The atmoshpere is the best, the true spirit of Paris.

Beautiful church . This is a lovely area of Paris to visit. The church is nicer to look at on the outside. There is a little walk up to it and you can either take the steep route, the steadier incline or you and take a little train that shooter up the hill. The area around is filled with artist selling their wares and lots of shops and cafes and just 10 minutes walk away is the Moulin Rouge. Well worth a visit.
The perfect place for portraits!. You will find artist from all around the world, and for less than 50 euros you can have a very nice portrait. The ambience is so nice.
Social scene. Very pleasant neighborhood, with lots of tourists, artists, and young people hanging around. The cathedral is worth seeing inside.

Cute area to walk around in and see many artists and performers. This appeared to be a great location in the evenings to see different street performances, and artists. It is a little bit touristy, in that there are many shops and street vendors. But the area otherwise had a charm to it as well.

Touristy but worth visiting. The main square - Place du Tertre was very busy, even in light rain. Many artists of varying talent wanting to make a portrait for you. There are numerous cafes and tourist souvenir shops, the restaurants/cafes are more expensive for the view and you can get better value elsewhere if you want. I, as previous reviewers have mentioned, like to imagine it as it might have been in days gone by. It still has a great deal of charm and is definitely worth a visit along with the Sacre Coeur and the fabulous view of the city.

Kitchy, but a lot of fun.. Cobblestone streets and lots and lots of hills and steps. There are restaurants, small shops and lots of artists offering to sketch you on paper, with chalk or charcoal. The place is really clean and hopping, only a short walk to/from Sacre Coeur. You must read Trip Advisor to see where the good places are to eat as it can be hit-and-miss from one location to the next. The place is really lively and fun to walk around, combining olde-world, church-charm with modern conveniences. This is the second time I've been there and I would come back! I nice place to hang around and enjoy the scenery.

lovely. This is one place where you could if you wanted, spend a whole evening or afternoon, you can walk around the streets, steep ones so be ready, or just sit at one of the many cafes, bars and restaurants, or just get chocolates or pastries from the shops and keep walking and enjoying the views, the place and the crowd too cause around the square it gets crowded of course, but still, it is a nice place to spend a while. We were there as a couple, I wouldn't dare to take kids with me, but there were kids around, I just think it can be boring or too tirening for them.

Interesting, artsy, but be careful.. We had some crepes...they were great. Interesting walk, artsy atmosphere. Be careful, we watched several artists before choosing one to do our pastel portrait, but were displeased and probably should not have paid for it, there was almost no resemblance to either of us.

Artsy Paris at it's Best. Monmartre is just a cool place in the Sacre Coeur vicinity of Paris. The cobblestone streets are filled with unique shops, fantastic cafes and restaurants, and many, many local artists selling their wares or painting some incredible work of art. One can also have a caricature crested on the sport.....Beware of pricing though as most are not cheap! Also beware of pickpockets or other types of scammers that frequent the vicinity. We had no issues ourselves but another couple we know did have people approach them with the 'ring' scam. Montmartre is a place not to be missed while in Paris!
Sweet tooth . This is a must go place if you have a sweet tooth you can find a lots of mouth melting chocolates and pastries you just need to know where the shops are
really nice place to be. came up here on the tourist train, alot more authentic and a lot of artists and little shops definitely worth a visit.

Seriously, beware of Thugs - Daylight Con Robbery. I was visiting Paris with one of my friend for the weekend and this was not the first time but was my first unlucky time being encountered by thugs at the lower level entrance of Montmartre. Yes, if you are on your own, or a couple please be extra careful and try to walk or be with a bigger crowds. I think especially you are visiting during the early hours on a Sunday where it's less crowded as no police will be around.So this was what happened. I was with my friend and as soon we walked in to the the lower level entrance to the Montmartre at round morning 9-9:30am hours. We noticed on the ground there were lots of colorful strings and on the top of my mind I thought there might be a celebration or something. We both were approached with 2 black men grabbed our arms and trying to tie a string to our thumb and making a bracelet to us. We were saying 'No' 'No' 'No' but they kept insisting and then say they are from South Africa and we have to treat them with respect. Hence not wanting to cause any troubles I then let them be while they distracted my friend to one side. They would then ask for money for the bracelet. If you do, please never, and I mean never took your wallet out and as soon they spot how much you have they will take your money. This is their tactics as another men of their team will come over and start threatening you. They took €20 euros of from me a or should I rephrase, "They robbed €20 euros off me". So please be extra careful and spread awareness to anyone whom might be visiting the place. I felt disgusted for their act and it's not fair and nice to daylight rob any tourists they approach and there were no policemen at that time. Please don't be victimized by any of these thugs.

Surprises in every corner. Went there for a visit to Sacre Coeur, only. Found out that we can just sit on the stairs and watch various street performers (comics, football juggler, fire acrobat).. Walked slightly to the west side of the Sacre Coeur and found lots of cute cafes, artists, and galleries.. All so amazing. Best to visit in the afternoon just three hours or two before dusk and stay until dark - when the fire acrobat started.. Lovely! Or maybe if you've done your research it won't be too surprising but anyway..it's still amazing..

Montmartre Safety. Our family stayed in a lovely Air B&B on Rue Custine in Montmartre, Paris. This is an ethnic community with many roadside cafes, bakeries and small grocery shops. The roadside restaurants we ate at served very good food. Our flat was close enough to walk to Sacre-Coeur & to Moulin Rouge. Saturday there was a market right below the church that wound its way through the narrow, cobblestone streets. Our family of 5 felt safe in Montmartre during the day and early evening, however, we would not suggest wandering the streets after 12.

Go back in time ..... This area is outstanding..a bit like going back in time or landing in beauty and the beast set its almost magical. Lots of cobbled streets ...houses with window boxes ...just lovely ...Lots of artists wanting to sketch you...saw lots of amazing sketches and paintings. Lots of restaurants where you will pay a bit more than down the hill however you are paying for the setting also... make the trip...and be transported for a few hours ....

Great place for a guided tour. . We started at Moulin Rouge and worked our way up the hill to the Church. We spent around three hours wandering around. No safety concerns. A great morning. Lunch in a park and then back into town.

Artists town!. Fun is to sit in front of artist and let the artist make your portrait! Though not all are good! I made three portraits and one one looks like me :)) ! And the price for per portrait is from 40 euros and up depending on sketch / black and white / color!!
Overrated. We did not find this worth the trek, but the basilica Sacre Couer is lovely. And the views of Paris are nice (the view from the Eiffel Tower is better.)

Sweet place. This was the first trip to Paris and Montmartre is one of attractions I noted to visit by it's famous. I love saunter among the easels and watching all the different art styles. I had a fantastic charcoal portrait with a cheap price. A trip to Paris is more memorable with a visit to Montmartre.

Always a lovely visit. Great views from the top, with the vista across Paris simply spellbinding. The street performers are an added treat with a harpist playing this time. You need to dodge the street traders but they leave you alone if you say no. The markets are worth a saunter - if you fancy a portrait there are plenty of talented individuals. Plenty of places to eat and drink, with Cafe Rose a favourite. Great walk back down along the side streets.
Historical Paris. Must see, yet it is so crowded and touristy.I liked trying to envision how this area might have been in the 19th century.

Nice!. Interesting and nice place to visit, very nice views from the top near Sacre Coer church, but be aware there are loads of Picassos walking around and offering to paint you! We paid 40 euros for our family (3 people) and the painting was nice, but I saw other "Picassos" works which were really not good. So be aware - choose a professional to paint you, otherwise you will get "Picasso" work...

Amazing views of Paris. Traveling via bus to Montmartre, we passed many Paris landmarks. The streets are quite narrow, which made trip interesting navigating past parked vehicles. Once we reached the area we rode the funicular to near the top of the hill. We still had additional stairs to climb to reach the top. We toured the Sacre Coeur, the explored the artist colony area, stopping by a cabaret for refreshments . We looked at the art in the square, then visited a few shops before returning to our bus tour.
Very Lovely Village. This is a very lovely village to visit the Basilica of the Sacred Heart of Jesus and to walk through the streets and seek for souvenirs in the lovely shops!

Great Artistic Quarter.. This is a great artistic quarter and we always pay it a visit whenever we are in Paris. We walked all the way up the steep steps to the Sacre-Coeur and then walked around the beautiful area. It was full of tourists and artists enticing just about everyone with their art. The numerous restaurants were full of hungry diners and the other touristy shops were full of customers buying anything they could get their hands on. It was absolutely fantastic just being on top of Montmartre. The views of Paris from this hill are just wonderful. They give such a wonderful image of Paris. It is such a charming place; you just have to visit it, to experience the atmosphere. This is Paris!

My favourite part of Paris. Cluttered little streets, loads of atmosphere, keep away from the 'street hawks' and you'll have a great afternoon, there are some fantastic restaurants in the area, worth checking on trip advisor to avoid the tourist traps, but you can have a great meal at a great price. Also great when you get to the top by the sacre couer and explore the market place nearby.

Fantastic place to spend an afternoon. This was my 2nd trip to Paris. My 1st trip was over 30 years ago, and the thing I remember liking the most was my visit to Montmartre. Heading back there with my family, I was nervous it wouldn't live up to my memories, but it did! Seeing all the artists in the square is just an amazing thing. I love strolling among the easels and viewing all the different styles of art. I had a wonderful charcoal portrait done of my teens for a very reasonable price. There are wonderful cafes for meals or snacks. To me, a trip to Paris is not complete without a visit to Montmartre.

You just have to pay a visit!. This is a must do and while tourists flock here it really is important in the history of this city. Its great to watch the artists at work, observe the restauranteurs calling their wares - the food isn't all good so be discerning!

Art, Food, and Culture. We walked off the Metro to find a section of Paris teaming with artists painting, people eating in cafe's, and real Parisian life happening away from the more touristy areas. A suggested place for any visitor.

Favorite area in Paris. I love everything about this area and will stay here for my future visits. This is the Paris of old and a (somewhat) quieter area. You walk narrow , cobbled stoned streets, up staircase after staircase and you are immersed in the history of this area.
Awesome disctrict!. Enjoyed wandering the streets and eating gelato! Neat little restaurants and cafes! Sacre Coeur is a nice church you can visit with beautiful views of the city!

Quirky. Montmartre is such a different part of Paris! Quirky little shops sell touristy gifts on the way up to an incredible view at Sacre Coeur. The view is definitely worth the walk up all of those steps.

Very Busy/ Overrun with Visitors. Montmartre is a lovely and very lively neighborhood, both at night and in the daytime. We have enjoyed visiting it in past years. And, of course, the Basilica of Sacre' Coeur at the top of the hill is worth a visit in itself. It is the highest point in Paris, and it is a gorgeous Roman Catholic Church.When we were in Montmartre this summer, though, there seemed to be more illegal gambling than we have ever before seen. We saw several unhappy "customers" who were losers in the shell games that are played every few feet in the middle of the streets. The gendarmes try to keep the illegal activity under control, but there are so many customers who think they are sharp-eyed enough to win, it is difficult. There are lots of shops with interesting and often cheap (in price and quality) merchandise for sale. Wear your important documents and money close to your body.

Beautiful. I have always loved going to Paris and the 2nd stop is always Monmartre. now that they have the elevator you don't have to walk up all those stairs. at the top the artists are showing their work and it's beautiful the view of paris from here is wonderful.

Charming stroll. Hilly. We walked extensively through Montmartre, starting from the Sacre Coeur and slowly working our way down the slopes. It is charming with many restaurants. It was Sunday and VERY crowded, with a kind of craft fair outside Sacre Coeur, offering all kinds of food and souvenirs. The restaurants immediately near the church were fully booked, but further down the hill we found a wonderful family-owned restaurant with a delicious meal (roast duck). An apple dessert topped the meal.

Beautiful artists corner! The typical Parisien joie de vivre. You cannot got to Paris and not visit the artists square at Montmarte - it's my favourite place! It's petite and very busy, bustling with tourists, but the art is amazing and you could easily stand around and watch the artists sketch people without a care in the world. So fascinating! If you want a true souvenir from Paris, this is the place to go.

A must in Paris. But a little bit too ‘touristic’.. Nice neighborhood, little streets, historic places that can give you a perspective of what it was at the time. Place du Tetre with the concentration of talented artists and the possibility that they can make portraits of you is quite an experience. And off course the view of the City from Sacre Coeur !!. The only thing for me is that is too ‘touristic’, I do not believe locals go there very often. But off course is a ‘must’ in Paris and we (my wife and I) enjoyed Montmartre. I do recommend also to take the 'Petit Train', it was a good experience to see the entire place and then focus on what you really are interested in.

Not a good spot for lone female travelers. I traveled solo to Paris in July, and I'm female. I was looking forward to a walk I'd planned around Montmartre, seeing the house where Degas lived, the windmill famous from the Renoir painting, and Sacre-Couer. I did not like it. Boulevard de Clichy is like 1985 Times Square but seedier. I started my walk at the Moulin Rouge and then realized I was in the heart of the Paris sex district. Not cool when your a solo woman. I skipped much of my planned walk and just saw Sacre-Couer. It was getting to be dusk so I opted to take a taxi back to the city center. I wouldn't recommend this area to a person like me, but I'm sure it's fine as a man or with a group or others, or maybe even earlier in the day. I'd planned to arrive at Sacre-Couer at dusk to see the sunset over the city.
Beautiful. It is nice place to visit and get your picture drawed by great artists there. You can find many different style of those painters and it is fun to see yourself in a picture on a funny way!
My Favourite place in Paris. As touristic as it is, its my favorite place to go to when in Paris. Very artistic, cultural, great views and so much going on .

lovely place. Lovely part of the city, with a fantastic atmosphere, all the shops, and the really historic architecture.The artists painting in the little square was an awesome site. Lots of artists painting in the square, music.great views and cathedral was amazing. The little vendors in the streets were so cute and good quality.

Take your time thru this little place of nostagia. After a visit to the Sacre Coeur to your left is the little streets of Montmartre with its restaurants, artists, gift shops and most importantly a buzz and atmosphere on a sunny day or barmy evening which is unique to Paris and just as you imagined if visiting this stunning city for the first time. Do it!

I think I missed the good part of this area!. We stopped here when we were on the HOHO bus so I assume we were in the main area... we had a nice little lunch (much less expensive than any café in the area where we were staying) and then proceeded to Sacre Couer. Ugh. So many little souvenir shops and cheap stores lined the street and it was packed. I have to take some credit as I guess I should have been more prepared to know where to look to find quaint and artsy stuff but, in any event, we didn't see anything like that around here. Maybe some signs pointing to the artsy section might help - if there still is an artsy section
Wonderful atmosphere. Lovely part of the city, with a fantastic atmosphere, all the shops, and the really historic architecture. Makes for a great walk.

Beautiful neighborhood . Beautiful little streets and cute little shops. The artists painting in the little square was an awesome site. My daughter got her portrait drawn. Son got his silhouette cut out of paper and the resemblance was amazing. The older daughter bought a painting from an artist who paints ballerinas on a music score sheet. The idea is so unique and she is a beautiful artist. Will definitely come back here next time I'm in Paris. I didn't encounter a problem with pick pocketing or pushy artists.

Favorite part of the city! Must See!. We stumbled across this quaint village on our walk up towards the Sacred Heart Basilica at the top of the hill. It was so fun! Lots of artists painting in the square, music and we visited the Salvador Dahli museum. It was like walking back into time when we entered this part of town. This is how I pictured Paris to be. A must visit when coming to France.
Montmartre. This part of Paris had great views and cathedral was amazing. The little vendors in the streets were so cute and good quality. The food, however, was the worst we had in Paris.

My favorite area in Paris. I have been to Paris five times and always go to Montmartre. The views are so beautiful and the Sacre Couer is the most beautiful cathedral in Paris. The streets with all of the artists are so lovely and it feels like quintessential Paris.

Where the Artists of Paris Reside. Montmarte is the district where all the artists of Paris have been residing for a very long time. It is a pretty neighbourood that also houses the Sacre Coeur and the Moulin Rouge. The cobbled stone streets are charming and there is much to explore while shopping in the lanes. Just be aware of gangs pick pockets especially near the foot of Sacre Coeur and the train stations.
Village like qauter. If you want a portrait go to Montmartre. Here you will meet several artists offering their services.

Interesting to watch artists create original art on the street. Strolling around Montmartre (during the day: ONLY!) is challenging if one does not have good walking shoes, and cannot handle climbing hills. Otherwise, this area of Paris is definitely worth spending a couple of hours wandering through. The Place du Tertre still has artists creating original art.
Stop if you have time. Artists want to do your caricature. They will follow you. Pretty artists village and lots of good people watching.

My favourite place in Paris . Such a lovely area of Paris, it's hard to believe it's a part of such a big city. Monmarte is the best place to get your souvenirs and artworks, enjoy a drink and some great french food.

Lots of Hills, Good Place for Food. We stayed in Montmartre on this trip to get a different feel for Paris. There are many delicious specialty shops in the area for wine, cheese, bread, etc. Also lots of great small restaurants to choose from. It was interesting to explore, but I think next time I would prefer to come up just for dining.

beautiful but keep your eyes on the sidewalk. Montmartre has beautiful views with a lot of historical buildings, although some of that is tainted by the number of touristy set ups and gift shops. However, there are a lot of areas where people do not pick up after their dogs, more so than any other area of Paris I have visited. Generally the more populated paths are okay, but if your exploring the smaller streets beware. That being said the restaurants off the beaten path are better experience than the tourist packed area by the artists corner.Also the stairs coming up from the abbesses metro station is not for the faint of heart. The walk has gorgeous tiled art as you walk up, but the stairs are steep, spiral and seemingly never ending. I believe there is an elevator but I have never used it.

One of the most beautiful areas in Paris!. Have visited the area twice during our stay in Paris. Have taken the funicular to reach the Sacre Coeur church and then we enjoyed the view from that point.We then moved to the Place du Tertre for lunch, next to the artists sketching portraits - and not only. lot of people there with a number of bars cafe and restaurants. We then decided to stroll down passing through the narrow streets and enjoy the magic of this magnificent area of Paris. After several stops for taking photos (and ice cream) we arrived at Boulevard de Clichy where we finished our walk at the Moulin Rouge.

Beautiful neighbourhood. A beautiful neighborhood, where you can spend a nice afternoon, just walking around and having something to eat. The atmosphere is fantastic and you do feel Paris as it is supposed to be - romantic and artistic.

The artist quarter. Our conducted tour didn't really do justice to this place. What you need for this place is a nice relaxing walk. Bookshops and road side artists are a plenty. There is music in the air.

Artsy, Glitzy Montmartre!. This is one of the most lively districts of Paris, owing to the history of art and culture with numerous artists who worked in and around here. The Sacre Couer Basilica is situated here and gives you amazing views of the city. Vincent Van Gogh lived in Montmartre in 1886, his house still exists here. The pizzas here are a must have, the best in Paris. You could actually sit in a cafe or walk around to explore and experience the beauty of this notorious district. Later towards the night, the famed Moulin Rouge gathers up lines and lines of people who come to view the show, you must purchase your tickets before hand for the same. There is also a petit train which can take you around to explore the romantic atmospheric district.
Magnificent view of Paris. enjoy the walk, watching the artist either they are painting or with beautiful music, feel the love & beauty of Paris

Should be visited but rather busy. Lots of people. Great views with pleasant ambiance if you walk on the side streets and not only the tourist rat -runs. Avoid all the scams. This area along with the Eiffel tower seems to attract them.

No Paris without Montmartre. There is a very interesting part of Paris. Many people, artists, bars and restaurants. You may go or ride by funicular. The best place on Montmartre is Sacre-Coeure Basilica.

Fun, quirky, real. You can feel old Paris as you walk through the streets of Montmartre. Quirky places are springing up all over the place lending a young, modern vibe between the Japanese sushi bars and Vietnamese pho shops. The tailors and Barbers, shoe makers and fruit sellers show a part of Paris where hard work is at the core of the society. Fun place to be at 6.30, having a drink in a corner cafe people watching. Young professionals flock back from work and catch up with friends for a drink. It's young, fun Adam vibey.
Must Go. One of my favorite location in Paris. Lots of talented artist and nice restaurants around. Good to spend sometime to overlook the view of Paris from the top
Quaint and whimsical. Great little shops, booths, and an artists' delight! Had lunch, walked about, had my portrait sketched, and photographed a gorgeous cathedral!

A cultural experience. The best way to see Montmartre is by the mini train which leaves from Sacre Coeur, at only €8 for an adult it lasts just under an hour and gives you an audio guided tour of Montmartre all the way down to Pigalle where you can see the red light district and the Moulin Rouge. If you don't take the train have a wander down the side streets from Sacre Coeur as your start point and you will find the oldest cabaret in France (in a tiny cottage) and also the worlds most expensive vineyard!

No visit to Paris is complete without a visit to Montmartre. The beating heart of Paris. Hectic, yes. Busy, yes. However, take time to sit outside Le Consulate with a cold beer or glass of wine...and just enjoy the best people watching experience. Ever.
Lovely Neighborhood!. After visiting one of the nicest churches I have seen, we took a stroll thru the narrow streets of Montmartre...You will fall in love with the place!!

A Can't Miss Neighborhood in Paris. I love Montmartre. The quaint streets climbing and falling down the hills surrounding Sacre Coeur, are Paris at it's purist. I could spend days simply wandering and discovering. The area is full of cafés and bistros, that provide the perfect venue for people watching. Watching all the artists paint and draw is a show in itself. I can't imagine experiencing Paris without a day in Montmartre.
average interest. Montmartre is big hillwe saw different historical place here --we see one of the older church name -Saint-Pierre church

A Village within Paris. We spent a day in this area of Paris, away from the bustle of the city center. Took the funicular to Sacre Coeur, explored the church, and enjoyed the fantastic view from the church tower. Then we walked the cobbled streets in the area, stopping in small shops and cafes, and searching for the houses of Toulouse Lautrec and Van Gogh! Really cool little boutiques, with original clothes and designs. Just a wonderful day, relaxing and enjoying this small area of Paris. Can't wait to return...

Bursting with character. Our favourite place in Paris Fantastic to walk around and soak up the ambience, grab a crepe to munch on as you go Several places to eat, and lots of paintings to choose from if you want a (more pricey) souvenir.
Beautiful! . Best part of Paris! The boutique shops, artist hangouts, lack of tobacco smoke in the air, the walking, the quiet...can't fault it at all!
Cool area.. We really enjoyed walking the streets of the this quaint area. Lot's to look at and some really cute shops. It's a little out of the way but fun to go too.

Great place to explore.. We explored Montmartre with a private guide who filled us in on the history of Montmartre. He explained where the famous artists who have lived here lived and dined. We ended the tour at the top with amazing views of Paris.
Worth the visit. The church is wonderful. The view even better. Really worth the visit. It's a nice place where to have a picnic!

Something for everyone touring Paris!. This is a must stop type of tourist place in Paris. You can purchase tickets for an elevator to take you to the top instead of walking the multiple stairs. Seniors love this. Then you will see the magnificent Sacred Heart Basilica and take memorable pictures inside and out. Taking a stroll, you enter the artist's area with shops and shops and shops. Restaurants and bars too! From the top my husband and I took fantastic pictures of the view of Paris.This area is very typical of what we think France is all about. You will not be disappointed.

Amazing views and lots of people . This is where people gather at night time. Great views of Paris, the basilica of Sacre Coeur, the artists on Place du Tertre and the cozy restaurants in the narrow streets. Don't miss it, though it's a tourist trap big time. My suggestion is to take a walk on Montmartre, enjoy the atmosphere but have your dinner somewhere else.

A bustling blend of tacky and culture. It's a fine balance here depending on your interests. It's a 'must visit' area with the Sacre Coeur and all of the artists. But it's the only place I saw around the City that had people outside the restaurants actively trying to get you in their place.Oh yeah, it's also got a Starbucks.

Very busy and crowded. A very busy little place around Sacre Coeur. There are lots of art shops and restaurants so plenty of places to browse and eat or drink.However, the thing which put us off was the almost constant pester power of the local artists offering to draw your portrait. If it was not for them this would have been a nicer experience after the calm of Sacre Coeur.

Art Place. when you are there, and not in winter, you can be between the art's people. everything is beautiful.you can pass near the house of the famous signer DALIDA. you can here her voice ....a dream place

So typically French. Of all the attractions that Paris offers, Montmartre is the most typical of France and the French that I have ever experienced. Great restaurants, it's central to a lot of other attractions, which are within walking distance. Walk to the Sacre Coeur and take in the views of the city. A beautiful spot in a beautiful city!
Crowded. A obligatory visit in Paris. It's nice to stroll around and look at all the artists. If you want to have your portrait made, take your time to select your artist.

Must visit . An afternoon or evening here is a must for anyone visiting Paris. Walking around its lanes and browsing through the work of all the artists is an experience. Catch a coffee looking at people around. The atmosphere is brilliant with many street artists performing / at work. The souvenirs here are expensive but really pretty so if you can shell out some money, you can definitely get some here.

Only on a sunny day!. Montmartre is always crowded with tourists, and many street sellers who can be quite annoying sometimes, with a lot of shops selling crap from China.But Montmartre, and Butte Montmartre particularly remain a must see, the view on Paris is stunning, and the ambiance is very special. The restaurants on Place du tertre can be good place for a drink but I would not advise you to eat there : the restaurants pretend to be typical but they have to serve so many people and have so much pressure (running a business in a place like that means that you pay a very big rent) that you won't find anything but meals heated in the micro wave.
Best place in Paris!. Excellent view over the whole Paris. Many small family restaurants with oysters and coq au vins with table wine and creme bruleé

For the romantic in you.. A part of Paris not to be missed.If arriving on the metro from either Anvers or Abbesses walk up to Sacre Coeur via the steps and linger near to the top and take in the view to the west - especially as the sun goes down. If it has been a hot day and you are felling weary you may wish to take the funicular railway to the top. This is located to the left of the steps. You can use your metro ticket for this ride. Do take a moment to walk down a few steps to take in the view.The area is still populated by artists and in the summer you can purchase paintings - be careful as the paint may not be dry!Be aware of groups tying string around fingers and then demanding money. As in any city be careful about making eye contact with these people. These were located at the bottom of the steps on my last visit. There are lots of good artists offering to sketch you. They are open to bartering on their original quote.The main square is very atmospheric even in the winter. There are many cafes and restaurants around the area and eating simple chicken and fries in the square with a nice glass of rose in the summer is most agreeable.The cemetery may be of interest and a quick check on Google will give you an idea of notable people interred there.If you walk through the square to the south west and turn right/west at the stairs there is a fine view, just a short walk along, of the Eiffel Tower between the roof tops.I am male 67 years old.I first visited Montmartre when I was 21 years old. My next visit was when I was 23 and decided that this was the place to propose to my now wife - so be careful.
Loved it!. The area was charming, unique, old world culture with a little big of everything. Great place to take photos, people-watch, eat and drink.

Pairs Sketch. This was a treasure, walk around & wonder the streets of Montmartre. Have a sketch drawn of yourself which is a true souvenir or your adventures in Paris. Artist line the street of Montmartre. We found a perfect spot to sit and people watch as we enjoyed a pot of muscles and chips. After, we wondered the streets some more, little shops and hidden surprises at every turn. Street entertainment, music, and lots of french bakery's. Stop and have a lemon tart and enjoy whats to come.

Cheesy. Montmartre is cheesy touristy stuff. But you have to go there if you're visiting Paris for the first time. Vendors who prey on tourists with paintings, trinkets (made in China) and other such things are rampant. The Dali museum is excellent.

Best place in Paris. I have now stayed in all arrondissements in Paris, and Montmartre is the best quarter! The vibe, the food, the shops, the people. Everything is better ! And it's on a higher point, so many many hotels have great views over Paris.

A highlight of our trip. It was my daughters last night after studying abroad in Paris. We had dinner at a nice restaurant. Strolled to the arts district and bought her some paintings to remember her time in Paris. We then walked to Sacre Cuer (spelling is wrong) and saw the city from the steps. A very special evening for our family. Highly recommend you do this at night.

Very nice. Our first time ever in Paris and we Stayed right in the heart of Montmarte which was perfect walking distance to everywhere and also the option of the big red bus to get around with which came often, I found most of the the people friendly and understanding considering our minimal French. The streets were clean and restaurants we ate in were all good quality with friendly staff... If ever we come back, this is where we would stay again.

So much history to this area. Forget the grand avenues of central Paris and wander around the streets of Montmartre. There is the Sacre Coeur of course and the funicular to access (or rather choose the long trail of steps) plus the "painters area" but go beyond that and discover quiet streets, the small vineyard, the windmill and absorb the atmosphere. I would definitely recommend the Musee de Montmartre, 12 Rue Cortot to help put it all in context.
Family Vacation. Paris is such a beautiful city. I would recommend always getting a fast pass as the lines are a nightmare like any main attraction. This is a must when in Paris!

What is not to love?. Sure, it is touristy, probably a bit too expensive, but seriously, what is not to love at this place overlooking the most astounding city in the Western World? I could never tire of it.

Not what I expected. If this is your first trip you MUST go. Lots of history in those streets. However beware of the artists. Some are better than others. On one occasion an artist told my husband he had an interesting face and he wanted to draw him for free. Then expected money. Just be careful.

Many many happy returns. To me nothing feels more like Paris than waking aimlessly in Montmartre. Sure, you can end up on some touristy areas, just keep walking, or some not so "appropriate" areas, just turn and keep walking. And remember it is on a hill, so wear comfortable shoes and enjoy a good workout. Plenty of lovely places to eat and photograph! The little train is worth it - super cute!

Take your time to enjoy Montmartre. Montmartre deserves you take your time to discover the charming area. Just walk around up and down from Metro Blanche entering all tiny (or not) streets (as avenue Junot and Place Dalida) Just enjoy the charm of Montmartre.Do not miss the church Saint Pierre de Montmartre close to the Place du Tertre, some very nice shops rue Tardieu, the square of Abbesses with the wall JE T'AIME, make a stop in one of the little terraces to enjoy a drink ... buy your dinner rue Lepic, and so on and so far ... the day will be flying just like that !
Montmartre... of the conmen.. Keep your purse well locked away. But take your imagination and let it rip. Take the bus up, and enjoy the straggle back down.Tis OK but over done.

Be There Early. To avoid the crowds, be there around 8am-9am in the mornings. You don't have to worry about a thing, although the Place du Tertre might be a bit empty but you get the whole place to yourself, including the famous Sacre Coeur.

for the artists. This busy town is a must see for the art loving tourist. To wander the streets that Renoir and Picasso strolled, have your portrait sketched by the artists in the square or just sit at a cafe and watch the crowds pass by. Avoiding the street hawkers outside Sacre Cour is not too hard.

3 sisters visir. What a Quaint little area. Lovely. Loved the artisans. Loved the funicular and loves the atmosphere of an old Paris that has survived the wars and modernization and technology and yet maintained its beating heart throughout all of this. Trendy and visually delightful place to spend some time having a lunch and stroll. Cold beer and good service at the pub and funicular ride up means even the lazy ones like me can enjoy!

Something different. Montmartre is a different experience. Though when you read about it, it might feel yet another attraction. Don't know why. Maybe it was the Byzantine architecture, the food market outside, the painters painting in the square, the walk down Rue-lepic. PS: I've had the best strawberries and macaroons outside the church!

Skip the funicular. This is a beautiful area of Paris offering a unique experience and great view! There are usually a lot of tourists milling around. There is no shortage of artists offering to draw your portrait (for a fee) and some can be quite aggressive and insistent. Unfortunately, this is also an area that is prone to pickpockets particularly in the funicular. Watch your belongings!

Best Artist Ever. My daughter and I had the most wonderful trip to Paris. When we went to Monmartre for a quick visit she insisted on having her portrait done. After looking around for quite a while at the work of many of the artists, one in particular stood out above the rest. The quality and accuracy was so realistic. The name of the artist is Namo. He's kind and professional and handsomely Parisian. The portrait of my daughter was so incredible that we returned two days later in hopes of having a portrait of the two of us. We were sad when we could not find him. We decided to go to the museum and have lunch in the area and try again in a couple of hours. We were ecstatic to find him when we returned. The pictures speak for themselves. Don't miss this opportunity to take back the best "souvenir" ever. It's a true work of art!

Touristy but don't miss it! Especially the Dali museum that is here. Keep your bags close, explore the alleys and nooks and crannies away from the tourist strip, cathedral a must, walk to the top for the best view of Paris, and find the best basement interactive personal Dali gallery, well worth searching for it, no cue, no crowd, modern, lots of information, hire the English audio, loved it. Great little lanes with restaurants for Plat du jour, lots of trinkets and tourist art of you can't afford a Dali.

I LOVE IT!. It was the perfect Parisian spot! People dancing, drinking! Artists drawing or playing music!Very attractive streets and Cafés!Visiting the Sacré-Coeur then walking through Montmartre then having a nice coffee is a great program to live a nice experience in Paris!
you can walk the stairs. very nice, and i am 57 and not in shape and was perfectwe entered the church and of course walked through the area, it was our 3rd time in 20 years,always nice

Stunning!. If you go to Paris you have to take the time to go to Mont Martre. There are beautiful cobble streets where you can reminisce of Amelie (look up the address of the cafe!), you can walk up to Sacre-Coeur and enjoy the beautiful architecture and amazing views of Paris. If you get hungry, walk towards the artists plaza and pick a restaurant, it is lovely!
Walk around . If you have good knees and good stamina, walking around this area is a good idea. The shops are expensive and so is the food. But the views are fabulous
Take a tour and visit!. If you like art history, this is a place to visit. This is were all start for modern art. But definitely go with tour guide to get good info on the place.

GREAT PLACE. I loved Montmartre, hilly in parts but quite easy to walk around or there is a train that you can travel on. Lots of artists wanting to sketch your picture and quite a few shops selling souvenirs and art work, also restaurants w here you can eat or perhaps just buy a yummy sausage in a roll (we did). We also walked through the back streets where people live and saw lots of other things.

Some Dodgy Spots . We've stayed in Montmartre, just a few hundred meters from the Moulin Rouge. The area around there, along the Ave de Clichy is geared towards tourists - a certain kind. The ave is packed with strip clubs, sex shops, porno theatres, bath houses; and after a certain hour, hookers and drug dealers. The hookers and drug dealers usually come out after 11pm. It's also home to a lot of bars, cafes, and restaurants that serve well into the night. As you move away from Place de Clichy along Ave de Clichy, towards Canal St. Martin, you'll watch the neighbourhood deteriorate into a ghetto. This area is also home to the Sacred Heart, which is one of the best attractions in the city. But if you don't mind a little loud music into the night, and few dodgy folk here and there, it's not too bad of an area. Watch out for scam artists in and around the Metro stations in this area. Take the extra couple minutes to walk to Place de Clichy where there are Metro employees keeping watch.

Every bit as good as I'd hoped.. What a magnificent place. So much going on, so many people, such a hive of activity. From locals taking their dogs for walks, playing with their kids in the local parks, visiting family/friends at the cemetery, having a relaxing brunch at one of the cafes, shopping to make a wonderful meal back at home, sitting out the front of their apartments or hanging over the balcony of their apartments. We had a great day meandering around this wonderful area of Paris. We decided to approach the Sacre-Coeur from the north, so we would be able to wander the residential streets of the area. There are many stairs, lovely cemeteries with such beautiful headstones, cobbled streets, cafes, bakeries, grocery stores, plenty of every day scenes. As we got closer to the Basilica, souvenir shops, galleries, cafes, artists at work abound. This area is very popular with tourists, and as the day progresses, the crowds grow. Make sure you get plenty of time to watch some of these amazingly talented artists producing portraits and silhouettes on the run. Others are working at watercolours and oils. It is truly mesmerizing to watch them at work. The basilica is lovely and unique and worth a look.
