After our visit we took the funicular down to some more souvenir shops, much more touristy than on the north side.A definite treat that doesn't cost you a cent in Paris.

Get lost wandering the streets. Montmartre is a beautiful part of Paris. Here are you still get the old Parisian Village feel of a Paris of yesteryear. Just get lost wandering the streets, take a break and have a drink at a café and watch the People. Good mix of Parisians and tourists in this area.

Fantastic . Fantastic area not to be missed with soooooooo much in this particular area to enjoy . Walk it . See every side street . Historic buildings and beauty to see . There is a small tourist train to see a lot of it but walk it to drink in all that is there
Family getaway. Montmartre is a thriving hub of Parisian activity and a great place to sit and watch Paris life and people pass by.

Fantastic place for a food tour.... We went on our own food tour after researching places to eat on the TA website. This place is definitely more congested since the last time I was there in the mid 90's. Scammers didn't really affect us. We went to the area twice during our stay and surprisingly only one person came up to my husband on the way out during our second visit. It was one of the men who attempt to tie a bracelet on you. My husband kept walking and that was that. We got off at the Barbes-Rochechouart Metro stop on the way to Montmartre to avoid being harassed at the Abbesses stop by pick-pocketers, scammers, etc. Walking around the Barbes-Rochechouart stop to Montmartre was being in Little Africa so that was kind of interesting...

Stroll through Montmartre. This is the place to go if you are searching for original art work of Paris. We strolled through many artists booths and were fortunate to meet a local artist that helped describe his work and walked me through the images so that I bought the ones that will always remind me of Paris. There are also souvenir shops and cafes to sit and admire the breathtaking view of Paris at night. It is a good place to go when you want to "window shop"
I loved walking the side streets. The best parts of this section are not the touristy areas, but on the side streets walking down to the cemetery. And the Cemetery is a must see!
Great area. Stayed at the Mercure Montmartre Hotel. So many good restaurants in the area. Safe to walk around. Easy public transportation access.

Gorgeous area, such a pity we were harassed by the artists wanting to sketch our portrait.. Really loved this area and would have liked to sit in one of the many cafe's to have a drink while watching the world go by. Sadly we were harassed(stalked) by the many artists wanting to sketch us, for a considerable amount also. Don't pay the first or second price quoted as they will come down by at least half. The local businesses must surely lose valuable patronage by the aggressive behavior of these people.

you have not been to Paris if you have not been to Montmartre. The area still has always been a magnet for artists and it is still a bohemian centre with a great atmosphere despite some touristy additions. The cathedral Sacre Coeur is magnificent. The nearby Abbesses area is also highly recommended for its affordable and lovely cafes and bars. You can easily spend a whole day exploring the area, especially if you decide to visit some of the local museums. As many artists used to have their studios in Montmartre, they now function as galleries e.g. Dali museum. If you are on a short visit though you could do it for a few hours-half a day.

A different paris. I love to go to Montmartre. It is a different perspective on Paris. Each of Paris's neighborhoods is unique. I like to explore the cafe's of Montmartre and go into the small shops. A different and historical perspective on Paris. Must see!!!

Very French. LOADS OF INTERESTING THINGS TO SEE AND DO AND NICE PLACES TO EAT .visit la place de Tertre to the left Sacre Coeur beautiful quaint little streets and shops .Beware of artists around Sacred Coeur absolute rubbish just a con really good ones near Notre Dame

the most picturesque neighbourhood. the little streets are full of artists( many of which can paint your portrait), the cafes , bars and restaurants are lovely. In Mormartre you feel the genuine, artistic atmosphere of previous century

Get a tour guide. We booked a guide from a company near the Louvre. Well worth the money. We got transportation and an explanation of the area that was very insightful. You get a great sense of local artists in this area. Be sure to take cash to the top of the hill if you want to buy art. A working cash machine at the top could not be found when we were there.

Not to be missed. Do visit this neighbourhood, it is great with lots of beautiful roads, restaurants, cafes... Very picturesque and definitely a spot for couples. If you can, do not take the funicular, it is not worth it paying the ticket - true, there are stairs but not so so many. Also the views from Sacre Coeur will reimburse you. Be prepared for lots of tourists, but when we visited, the queue was very small and we entered very quickly! The entrance is free, but you need to keep quiet. There is someone at the door that apparently reminds you to keep quiet, but when we visited he also did not allow a girl to enter the church as she was wearing tiny shorts-apparently they seem to check dress code, but we did see other girls and ladies with shorts and skirts. Also, a visit to the place du tertre with the artists is a must, but this is a tourist trap. Do have your portrait made, but ensure that you go around and check that indeed they paint from scratch, as some seem to simply be painting over already made paintings... Take the time to see how the artist draws another person.

There is a very good little village with lots of art be Sacrecour. Fun to visit, however, I would not recommend going alone as a woman. Great photography spot! The view from Sacrecour is unbelievable, all of Paris.

Our favorite place in Paris. We spent just a day here and wished we had known how enchanting it was before. But if ever there is a next visit this is where we would spend our entire time. The narrow roads, the houses, the market just the overall atmosphere is what we were looking for in our ideal European vacation!
Lovely place. Walked around visited the shops and stalls very picturesque. Lots of things to see steeped in history. Lots of cafes and a great ice cream shop. Well worth a visit.
One of the best places in Paris. Amazing place to visit. Could spend hours wondering round the back streets, art everywhere, love this place. A must visit

Gorgeous views of paris. I definitely recommend making the trek to Sacre Couer, if only for the views of Paris from in front of it. You can get there relatively easy by Metro to the Abessess stop and then walk a few blocks to a cable car lift that takes you up the hill (avoiding the hundreds of steps). The views from up there are breathtaking and it's a wonderful place to stop and rest for an afternoon.

Vibrant area with much to see . Stepping out the cathedral, we enjoyed Montmartre on a sunny Sunday around lunchtime. There are countless artists an cafes to sit stay there for while and enjoy the atmosphere.

Great neighbourhood to visit and explore. This is a great neighbourhood to visit and explore with family or by yourself. I enjoy photography and this area has lots of great places to photograph if you enjoy street photography.The area is full of art shops and painters on the streets so if you are into art then this is the place to come and purchase a pice of artwork.

just great. Make the effort to stop in this artist community where so many of the talents had lived. The local Museum is worth a long visit. Lots of hills and small shops. The funicular will take you up (and down.) Watch out for pick-pockets. Add this to your Paris-must do list

Best area in Paris (in my opinion).. Paris on the whole is very easy to get around in, whether on foot or through use of the metro system. My wife and I found it much, much easier than London. That said, over several days in Paris, the only place we returned to was Montmartre - and we returned here twice. It was a lovely neighborhood with lots to enjoy. We found some of the best food in Paris here and enjoyed just strolling around the area, especially the steps up to Sacre Coeur, where the views were great and they had people just lounging around listening to street performers. There is a little chocolate shop/museum in the area that is worth finding. It not only has great chocolate, but giant replicas of Notre Dame, the Eiffel Tower, Gargoyles, and more, made completely out of chocolate. It was pretty neat.
Artsy town. Stroll along the streets where artists paint. Sit at one of the brassieres and enjoy a crepe and some wine. A pleasant experience here.

Last day visit. Did this this morning as flying home this afternoon. Booked it up with fat tire tours. Guide Kit was passionate and extremely knowledgable about the history the architecture and the artists who lived here, great tour. Beautiful area sacre cour well with the visit as was looking around the old town area at the top of the hill

A great place to be accosted by a group of black men. These fine fellows set up along the ramp to go to the top. They wouldn't let us by and grabbed are writs to try and put on a string bracelet. They surrounded us and tried to intimidate. They would not take no for an answer. After reading other internet reviews with people who experienced the same thing I am perplexed as to how they continue to operate in this area. Not worth the trip! Ps. Women cannot wear shorts or shirts that expose shoulders if they want to view the church however men are fine to wear them.

One of the most beautiful places in Paris. I think it's one of the most beautiful places in Paris, particularly in the evening around the sunset and after it. Walk through beautiful streets, enjoy the view on Paris from the top of the hill sitting on the stairs like hundreds other people.

Looking down on the city. At the top of Monmarte there is a beautiful church that is well worth your attention. You have to climb some steps, or take a taxi, but don't miss the opportunity to snap some photos of the beautiful city below. There are many little shops down one level from the church and they are eclectic choices for souvenir hunters.

So Disappointed...Cafes have taken over Painters' Square. On a return visit to Paris after 9 years, we were so upset to see that most artists have been pushed out of the square near Sacre Cour and cafe's have taken it over. There were already tons of nice cafes around the square and watching the painters and buying their art was super fun. Now, not nearly as nice. Bummer.

Unique Place with an Awesome View!. The views atop this hill is amazing. We drove there in the evening after 7PM and it was still really bright out. Be aware that the streets are extremely confusing (to a foreigner) and there are many one-ways forcing you to drive around small/narrow bends. If you're able to find a parking spot (like we did...very lucky!), you'll see how cool this place is. There is a square filled with artwork and surrounded by restaurants with friendly waiters. If you walk further you'll turn the corner to an amazing church that is free to enter! In front of the church is the amazing view of Paris. Although we were not able to spot Eiffel Tower, the view and the breeze satiated us for the day. Strongly recommended for a visit!

Love this charming neighbourhood! . I am so in love with Montmartre and frankly it is so so so Amélie! It is warm, colourful and simply the ambience is so so so welcoming! I feel so at home here! It is a great place to just take a walk, take in the wonderful colours of the different shops and just a nice area to relax. It is like just a neighbourhood out of a movie scene! What I really love best about Montmartre is ... it is a tourist attraction but yet the feeling I have is simply ... home. Everyone just has to come to Montmarte and only then they will be able to experience what I did.

Different. You stroll around this area not far from the sacre Coeur, and there are various shops, and restaurants, and people doing caricatures and painting pictures and selling various homemade products. It was very busy when we went so struggled to see some things, we sat outside a bar to have a drink and you constently got asked to have your picture done by various people and this was about 9 o clock at night. It was an experience but don't think I would bother again.
More eclectic neighborhood. Beautiful neighborhood that rises to the Sacred Heart Basilica. Lots of hills. The best restaurant we ate at is here, Sacree Fleur. Go there!

Sketchy. We visited Montmartre on the last afternoon of our honeymoon in Paris. It is absolutely beautiful but the day we were there, the con artists and pickpockets were absolutely out of control. We were only harassed one other time during our week-long stay by the Louvre, but it happened at least 8 times between getting off at the Anvers metro and getting to the top of Sacre Coeur. Ladies with petitions, large groups of men clogging up the pathway pretending they found your jewelry and not letting you pass, people following very close behind you trying to snatch your purse or wallet. I was aware that these were issues in the area but it was a lot worse than I thought it would be. I had to be very verbally aggressive, in French, and literally push them out of the way to make them back off. I had no jewelry or electronics and spoke only in French so do not even know why we would have been targeted. I'm glad I got to the top of Sacre Coeur for the view, but we were out of there immediately after that and I would not go back to this part of town on my next trip to Paris.

Beautiful area in Paris. Lots to see - would recommend going to the top of the hill and seeing the Basilica. Beautiful views of Paris. Lots of quirky places to eat and shop. Only inconvenience is people trying to sell you things - but they usually leave you alone if you politely say no.

VERY TourISTY and Packed. I've been here when it was slow and its fabulous with so much to see, but then been here on a top tourist day and hot outside and not so much of a good place to be. HUGELY overpriced and trendy touristy stuff mixed with fabulous old buildings. VERY VERY hilly with cobblestones so be careful for older people and small people

I <3 montmartre. Set in the peaceful hills the artists square bustles with liveliness and is a true sight to behold. Especially good if you've a few creative bones in your body. If it's not your bag, there's a few bars around and just a short wander will lead you to the quieter areas equally as beautiful and picturesque

Amazing street full of action!. I loved the Montmartre area and its street!It's full of action and for me one of the most beautiful locality of Paris.As the pictures tell, you will see many artists drawing your portrait on the street side and some of them where really great. It tells the story about how France have been a promoter and a cradle of art.There are many restaurants serving nice food and drinks and they are really happening places.You will see many tourists in this area, many of them will be heading towards the Sacre-Coure ahead.On the stairs and through the uphill climb towards Sacre-Coure you may find musical bands performing.The walk is mostly on the slope and you may get tired (if not fit or already exhausted).We really loved walking, eating, observing the art and other tourists in the Montmartre.

Full of history but too touristy. Once you have visited the Sacred Heat Basilica, I found the rest of Montmartre very touristy, I was in a group of family and we stopped for a coffee etc. and it was expensive for what is was, later on in the day we had lunch off the beaten track and paid less for the lunch that we did for the drinks.We did find a very good artist who completed a drawing from a photo and it was excellent and good value price wise, I hasten to add our artist was just dressed normally and not looking like a phony artist with paint splatted over his jeans.It is a lovely part of Paris and the view of the city are fantastic I just wish there weren't so many people there

Favourite part of the city! . Go here during the day or at night - you will not be disappointed! In the main square there are various artists set up to draw a portrait or to sell original pieces. There are so many great restaurants and creperies. Watch the sun go down on Sacre Coeur and have a seat on the steps to have the most stunning views of the city.
Feels Nostalgic. It's a beautiful place. There are plenty of restaurants nearby to hangout. Avoid going into rainy season.

The best place to watch a movie. Montmartre boasts not only about its artistic spirit (which I found a little bit overrated because nowadays it is getting more and more trendy, touristic and expensive) but also about many cinemas. Try one, e. g. Cinema Pathe Wepler if you are tired of walking.

Long uphill walk. It was not so easy to find from the Metro even with map and street directional signs and a long haul with many, many steps up the hill. I went strictly for the art, and I found artists with tourist prices and some appealing art. Many portrait artists were ready to draw your portrait, and were quite good.

Impressionist's Hangout. It's fun to walk where Renoir, Monet, Picasso, and your other favorite impressionist artists lived and played 150 years ago. Climb the stairs to the top of Sacre Coeur for a great view of the city.

Very French . This is old Paris. First time the tram was broken and I had to climb the steps. Next time rode to the top. Only way if you are 60+ or have children. We ate at Chez Eugene. Wonderful. Just be mindful of the people who want to string bracelets on your wrists.

Beautiful Cathedral on a Hill. The cathedral is beautiful and not to difficult to get into. The cathedral is on a hill and on a clear day offers amazing views of Paris. The only thing that is a problem is the walk up to the cathedral. There are so many people trying to panhandle or try to sell you string bracelets for ridiculous amounts of money. They are aggressive and will stop you and start working the bracelet. Once you get through there it is worth the visit.

Eccentric & "Hip". Montmartre is where the hipsters of Paris hang out. Home to a bustling art scene you can find dozens of painters and other artists displaying their works in the area and they do a lot of portraits for tourists. Many great restaurants line the main square and it is the home of Sacre-Coeur, a must see for your trip to Paris. It wouldn't be the same without it.

Vibrant Monmarte. After a long day with lots of walking, the vibrancy of the Montmartre and the beauty of Sacre Coeur gave us our second wind. The funicular made it possible for us to "climb" the hill! We enjoyed dinner at a sidewalk cafe while we ate and people watched. The view is incredible, the people and place fun.

Still one of the best bets in Paris. The steps of the Sacre Coeur are like a traveling market. Lots of action color and people. An impromptu guitar concert started up for us. Around the corner in the square is an artist Mecca with street artists of all kinds. Buy a picture of Paris or sit for a portrait. Get a table at a bistro and watch the painters AND shoppers. This is a five star attraction but for the throngs of pick pockets and con artists. We watched one distract my son while another went for his wallet. Good thing it was in his front pocket. It's a nice story but plenty have unhappy endings. Others are so pushy they practically assault you to ply their con. Go with company and take care of each other.

Excellent!. I really enjoyed being on the top of Montmartre. You can overlook the whole city of Paris and the view is absolutely stunning! Sadly it was raining on the day I visited but it was still worth it

Fantastic Area. So this is truly the bohemian area that shouldn't be missed, old town paris.
Artists abound, lots of talent, beautiful area.
Be careful of the pickpockets, and heavy with tourists.

Walking Montmartre. Really enjoyed a day in Montmartre - Sacre C'ouer, Montmartre Museum (for me this was a gem), lunch at a little cafe and then window shopping all the way back down the hill to my hotel. A great day!

Arty!. Montmartre is it's square with the painters, the cafes, Espace Dali, the cemetery, but most of all Sacre Coeur and the steps leading up to it! Also the view of central Paris from the hill. To visit Montmartre gives you a sense of pure joy!
Great Walking Tour. Go to Paris Walks and find this walking tour. Our tour guide enlightened us about residences of Van Gogh, Latrec and others. Quite an earthy area. Two hours well spent!

Quite old town with artists. Beautiful narrow streets with great views to Paris appearing in different places. Lot's of painters and pictures for any selection. Near several places with famous night shows like Moulin Rouge. Also many stories about well known artists like Dali and Monet working here.

A favorite spot!. Sacre Coeur and Montmartre are two of my favorite places to visit in Paris. I love visiting the local artists who set up there. I have beautiful reminders hanging in my home of my visits here. The view of the city from the steps of Sacre Coeur are phenomenal, and the Eiffel Tower is visible in the distance from the rear.

My favourite place in the whole of Paris . This is the Paris you dream of- old, hilly cobbled streets paved with artists- truly old town Paris. We wandered around the square, saw the magnificent Sacre Coeur, chatted with artists and leafed through their truly magical works of art. We ended the day sat at a bar around the corner listening to live music and drinking now Grimbergen beers in the sunshine. Heaven.
A Must...but prepare for crowds. Fun to stroll by the artists, and sit at an outdoor restaurant people watching. Dream of the famous artists of old strolling by. Lots of walking but fun.
Amazing artists. TrippersIf your into artists and paintings you must come here to visit after seeing the famous church saint pierre..These artists are fantastic..

Marvellous Montmartre!!!. What a lovely village, full of restaurants which are ok. Nice touristy shops. It is a wonderful place to walk around. Hard to get a taxi late at night, but there is a taxi stand.

A cheesy tourist spot that tries to act like an artists oasis.. The church is it's own venue. If you walk past the church and down the road you come to this area that is full of shops and cafes trying to get the tourists dollars. They have the so called artists who will draw your picture for a fee.I looked at my wife and was like.. "Let's get out of here. This is stupid.." The neighborhood is nice, but certain areas scream "tourist trap". I like to go where the locals go and those certain areas detract from your Parisian experience. Walking up there is a bit of a challenge too. The roads run circularly around and up. A map is ok, but GPS on your phone helps the most. Plenty of small restaurants with really weird hours. You will see them, but the majority are closed until they open late in the day.
Good visit to Paris market. This can be done together with your visit to Sacred Heart Basilica. Cafe nearby are a bit overpriced and untidy. But it is a good walk in the region overall.
REAL old Paris. The artists quarter of narrow cobblestone streets,packed with souvenir shops, bistros and artists selling their wares. An ESSENTIAL Paris experience.
so quaint, not to be missed. Well worth seeing, as this area of Paris is quaint with little winding roads, and Sacre Coeur well worth visiting
Lovely part of the city. You'll find a bit of everything in this neighborhood. Even the more touristic parts around Abbesses are charming.

YOU NEED TO GO - THIS IS FRANCE!. You need to make the trip here. Our conceirge even told it was far, but we went anyway! This is where the Sacred Heart Basilica is, Moulin Rouge, cute little streets. Everything we pictured France being! We even went back the next day again!

A quirky bohemian feel to this part of Paris which is a must to visit. We've been a couple of times recently and it always seems to be really busy no matter when you visit. I guess that's part of the charm. The streets are narrow and many are cobbled (so don't wear heels!) and they're packed with interesting little shops and of course bars and restaurants. There is a funicular if you don't fancy the steps up to sacre coeur but to be honest it hardly seems worth the effort of ticket buying and queuing! In summary if you're visiting Paris and you have got a few hours to do some site seeing this is a lovely part of the city which has a real buzz to it, and providing you're reasonably fit (for stairs and steep hills in places) it is a must do on your list of things to see.

An artists paradise!. You will enjoy the Rennaissance history. Sacre cur is on top of the hill. The Impressionists history is amazing. Be aware of the artists on the streets. They will harass you to draw your portrait. They are relentless. The town is old style.

Walking Tour. Did a free walking tour with Discover Tours. The 2 hours was enjoyable with plenty to see. Our guide was fantastic. Finished the night with dinner at a local restaurant and a show at the Moulin Rouge.
You have to experience this one. Again, this is part of the park. You must experience the local artists and just walk around admiring the landscape. It was pure local culture.

Such an interesting part of the city!. This is an interesting area to wander around. We saw many beautiful shops and restaurants -- all mixed in with a hodge podge of little shops selling cheap flip flops, t-shirts and Parisian souvenirs.

Lovely neighborhood . Just loved this place! The atmosphere is great! Lovely to walk around from the subway to the top, stopping on some square to eat something and enjoy the day.
On the way down I recommend stopping at its famous cemetery.
Touristy but lovely!. The area of Montmartre is the essence of quaint and cosy. Art is everywhere, and every little corner is so picturesque!

Our very favorite Paris adventure. What an excellent district filled with the un matched of the city. Everyone doing what they do trying to make some money. Street performers and artists most notably. Our daughter and Grand daughter had a drawing done of them together that will be a keepsake of this special journey for them to treasure. There are a lot of artists and styles. I suggest you spend your prep time well discerning the best artist for what you want. Haggling works well also. The shops are eclectic and the restaurants are varied in the cuisine. The people watching is the best here. The best part I felt was the views of the other areas of the city. We got a great shot of the Eiffel Tower beyond the river with a barge an small boats going by in front. I'm going to frame it!

Excellent artist neighborhood up by Sacre Coeur. This is an excellent artist neighborhood up by Sacre Coeur. The street with the church on it is safe and clean. The cafes are all great. Stay on this street! Abysses something or other. The street with the Moulin Rouge was quite full of sex shops and porn theaters. Clichy or something like that.
Beautiful place . You must visit this place. You don't have to buy anything. Just walk around to the square and admire the artists. By far my favorite part of the city.

Busy, but still a must do. Just walk around and enjoy, stop for food, drinks or snacks. We enjoyed eating crepes and just watching the world go by, it is worth exploring the bottom and the top of the church, walk behind the church for some nice old streets. It is a busy and yes a tourist trap, but the views and the experience is worth it.

Always stay somewhere different!. Whenever I go to I try to stay away from the main drag to really experience more of the realCity. This works well but always means you have more distance to travel. This is certainly the case here and because we were short of time we used taxis a fair bit. Montmartre itself is a great district full of boulangeries, bistros and interesting winding alleys. We explored greatly and found lots of hidden gems.

Best Part of Paris - MUST SEE!. This little district is the quintessential Paris experience. Once you arrive on the metro, you are at the lower, kind of smutty end of it (near muolin rouge). From here, take a cab to the cathedral at the top of the hill (it is a pretty long hike up). Tour the sacred heart cathedral - it is amazing, I liked it better than Notre Dame. Then hang out on the lower steps to watch street performers - there is tons of talent here. Locals will bring you cold Heineken beers, this is enjoyable but watch out for the rip-off. They are selling 9 oz beers and their opening price is 2 for 10 euros. With some stiff negotiating they will quickly drop to base price: 3 for 5 euros. Don't be intimidated or feel you have to accept their price because they opened it and shoved it in your hand as soon as you expressed interest. If they don't give you a fair price, hand it back - it is not your fault they opened it. Then mosey down the hill for some amazing food, drink and atmosphere. You will also discover some amazingly talented portrait artists in the square here. Keep working your way down hill and you will eventually find yourself back at the metro.
Stay in Montmartre.. We stayed in the Terrass Hotel, walking distance from all in Montmartre. We love everything about Montmartre so stay there and explore.

Full of tourists. The only area of Paris that is flooded by tourists. Originality is gone - glitter and giftshops.
If you are not in there for some specific location (like views from Sacre Coer), you might want to see other older districts of Paris for authentic feeling.

Lovely area but the church is a little underwhelming. Montmartre is a neighborhood in Paris which retains the old neighborhood layout the city was known for prior to the 19th century rebuilding of Paris by Georges-Eugène Haussmann. Montmartre was one of the few areas to be left untouched. The Sacre-Coeur church crowning the area was only finished in 1914 and has a fairly drab interior. But the church courtyard offers sweeping views of Paris.

The best of Paris. This is the real deal guys. If you havent been here, is like you have never been in Paris. Check it out, or even better get a guide to show you around, if you need some advise ask away. :)

Cosmopolitan Montmartre . Stayed in the Leclic Hotel for 2 nights and ate in the area as there are quite a few restaurants close by as well as supermarche, and a chemist .its also served by the metro which is close also there is alift in the metro station or you can use all 92 stairs in the spiral staircase to emerge from underground, theyre a bit of a workout.
For artists. in fact.... not only for artists. Just AWESOME.Walking around on the market and enjouying the atmosphere.

Good but too 'touristy'. You have to visit once. What's with Paris and pickpockets. While I was fortunate to have not lost anything everybody warns you about them. And Montmartre felt like a haven for them with the throngs of tourists crowding narrow streets. We spent a short while here, had lunch, bought some souvenirs and left.Being an artist and a fan of the impressionists I had to visit but it was overcrowded. Maybe better to visit off season.

"Charming". We loved this area of Paris, as we walked through the Moulin Rouge area up the hill, we discovered this beautiful, quant little area with a lovely village feel. This is the area where the famous Chat Noir nightclub once was. (Everywhere you go you see the Chat Noir merchandise- really kitsch) the views from this area are superb, you can see right across the city, it's breath taking. Sacré-Cœur, the Roman Catholic Church is stunning. There was an area filled with artists, which was 'stereotypically' Parisian, lovely to have witnessed. Lovely little cafes, quant winding streets, and yes there is the odd shop selling nic nacs, but they have to make a living... Full of hustle and bustle which we thought was exciting. The whole area had a fantastic atmosphere, one of our favourite spots in Paris. We felt it was traditional despite the odd review saying it's not what it 'was'. This may be true but if you've never been here before I doubt you'll be disappointed.

GREAT People Watching!. Took the metro here in no time. EASY. Wear good shoes and be prepared to walk! It was raining and we still enjoyed this area thoroughly! There is a lot to see and experience. Great people watching.

Nice way to spend a day. Start at the basilica. Take in the views. There is a nice tram ride that takes you through the area. He will point out a few highlights and you can get your bearings for when you do walk around. Several nice shops in the area. We had cheese fondue and a simple side salad for lunch. I wish I remembered the Resturant so I could recommend it here. It was awesome!

Wonderful. After seeing the Sacre Couer, walk around the area of Montmartre, it is a beautiful place. Get your picture drawn by a local artist - you can negotiate the price - and they are very friendly, some better artists than others, but all good. Lots of souvenir places to shop and lots of little cafes to slip into for a quick bite to eat or something to drink. Also a lot a galleries with beautiful painting - prices are not bad either.

Not your Father's Montmartre. We visited Montmartre after an absence of 32 years and it's no longer a charming collection of artists and galleries; it's full blown tourist and tee shirt shops. Very disappointing to see the change.
Fun Place. Big Crowds!. If you are headed to this area, you must be aware by now that you will be in yet another crowded attraction. Very nice.
A big disappointment!. It was the only place in Paris we were accosted by gypsies, swarmed in fact! I visited Montmartre years ago and it was magical ... This time, a circus!

Amazing licensed artists in the square.. Portraits and caricatures done on the spot, one or two will create charcoal drawings from photo. Take the time to walk around and see all of them before you buy, each is uniquely talented. We have been buying paintings from one artist for 25 years on every trip. Also, surrounding the square are numerous little cafes and creperies so you can enjoy people-watching with a glass of wine and decent food as part of the experience.Do not miss going into Sacre Coeur Basilica - the dome is amazing~!
Recommend. I have been to this place and trust me a place worth visit of mental peace and surprise work that was carried out in the past generations for everyone to witness.

Amazing views of the city in this charming part of Paris. The basilica is spectacular on its own, but you will also have one of the most amazing views of the city from the steeple. Pay the fee and climb the stairs to the top. It's steep and the stairs are windy, but it is so worth the view from the top. Montmartre is a charming peek into the artist/beatnik community of old Paris. It's quite touristy now, but you can still get a glimpse of what it must have been like years ago.

Bohemian. This is a bohemian part of Paris, full of art galleries, painters doing portraits, restaurant, small shops,great ice cream places. You can be a tourist and have lunch or wine, beers and watch the painters do portraits or have your portrait done. If you prefer a quiet place to eat and not so crowded, go down one of the many side streets nd find a nice cafe, bistro or restaurant and have mussels or stake tartar with French fries. Great to visit after seeing Sacre-Ceour.

Get Off the Beaten Path to be Above "Average". What crowds, what commercialism! But step off the beaten path a bit and you will find peaceful streets, a vineyards, little shops and a pretty area of Paris. We just got tangled in the food/artists wanting to draw your portrait area just behind the Basilica. It was ok, but crowded and a bit too touristy for us. Then we continued walking and exploring and had a much better time.
too crowded. Too crowded to enjoy our visit. We left without seeing or doing too much. It was very crowded, dirty and graffiti was almost everywhere. For our family it was not comfortable
Real old Paris. It's a delightful area, the little brown train looks cheesy but I enjoyed seeing the area slowly. The Secret Food tour which is located here is really a worthwhile experience.

The Art Hub of Paris. If you want to experience the true spirit of Parisian life then this is a must visit. The town from where our very own 'Amelie' hails from is just as pretty as you had imagined it to be in the movie - a circle of aspiring artists all bring to the fore their own interpretation of art to leave you spell bound. The spirit of Monmartre is so unique that you are bound to fall in love with it. So on your next trip to Paris remember to make a trip to the art hub of this city and spend at least an hour drinking a cup of coffee and appreciating the beauty of art!

Very crowded but great vibe.. Tucked away up behind the sacre coeur. A fabulous square of artists selling their works, some great sketchers and caricatures being done these were not expensive either and some were so good. Some of the paintings were very expensive, but generally something for all price ranges and styles.The restaurants were all packed out but you can get good snack food like huge hotdogs. Great place.For those who don't fancy the walk a land train will take you from the streets below sacre coeur right up to the Montmartre square and back but it's pricey €10 round trip.Alternatively you can walk up past all the shops then use a metro ticket €1.40 to get you to front of Sacre coeur then walk the steady incline upto Montmartre.Allow a good 2-3 hours. Longer if you wish to queue to go inside or up Sacre coeur. (2 seperate queues)

A different side of Paris. The Paris where the artists lived. Bohemian, charming, full of history. I strongly recommend that you take a tour of Montmartre because it gives a different meaning to the visit, I have done it on my own and with a walking tour (there are tours starting at 14 euros per person) and I felt it was a way better experience.

Great place to get lost in the Parisian culture. We walked to this area from our hotel and spent the day wandering the quaint streets, eating and drinking in the little restaurants and enjoying the beautiful views. Although we wandered up the streets to the Sacre Coeur, we did take the stairs back down (lots of stairs).

Vibrant Paris Life. So glad we went on a walking tour. The place is beautiful and you can really appreciate local Parisian life there with all the local restaurants, grocery stores, shops, and bars. It reminds me a little bit of the North End in Boston. It really has an old world charm.

Moulin rouge. On the way up to the Sacre Coeur, taking the main stairs right in front of the church, you cannot get around without seeing the African so called "bracelet guys". There young guys hang around on the stairs waiting for potential victims to come by: young couples, single women or women in small groups. They start a small conversation, shake your hand, and as soon as they have your hand they tie a small bracelet around it. And because there is no way you can get them off of your arm, they demand money. The prices they ask can get as high as 10 euro's for a worthless pieces of wool.Unique Suggestions One simple solution for this one: just say no and at all times never give them your hand.
Breathtaking and mesmerising. montmartre and sacred cleur is always charming and so full of flavour with the local buskering, hustling of beer jostlers and market sellers
Relax.... There's a different vibe in that part of town.Perhaps its the breeze and the picturesque views of city at our feet

lovely area to walk around and get the true flavor of Paris. This past and current home to artists and musicians gives a taste of the wonderful flavor of the city. The church, stairs, street vendors and charm is wonderful.

Montmartre bars and Attractions. I have been in the Montmatre area of Paris several times and found it quite enchanting. The area has all sorts of different types of bars and shops some classy and some quirky. The obvious standout attractions are The Sacre Coeur basilica and the Moulin Rouge, both are worth visiting if you are staying there a while. There are numerous other things to do like the chocolate shop they have there down one of the side streets which has some of the most incredible chocolate you will ever see including a large size Notre Dame Cathedral made out of chocolate. There is a dark side to the area to beware of monty men sometimes are around the area. These are the guys who use the three disks, shuffle them and you try to pick the one with the white dot on. You will never win from this type of game as they are using sleight of hand, the people you do see winning are in on the act with them, so don't bother be careful of even watching them as they will most likely to have pickpockets working in their group as well. The best thing to do would be to get as far away as possible. At night time the drug dealers, pimps and prostitutes come out, just ignore their advances and they probably won't bother you too much. For me I have generally enjoyed my visits here and had some great experiences. I would recommend visiting the Montmartre but with a bit of caution.

Amazing place. Truly an amazing place on top of Paris. There is an area with narrow roads where lots of cozy restaurants are located as well as shops and cafe . Lots of shops selling paintings . Most of restaurants and pubs have live music . Artists are at central area making mainly portrait painting for around €50. There are as well historical buildings and churches. As this is on top of a mountains sloping lifts are provided to take the people to lower level . There is also a sort of amphitheater where people gather to watch amateurs performances . Overall , an amazing place indeed .
Magnificent.. The walk to the very top was pretty gruelling for me but the view was so well worth it. The history of Montmarte was fascinating.

Excellent for Strolling or Dining. Montmartre is an area laden with artistic and cultural significance, but now transformed from its past seediness into a clean, safe, and attractive area suitable for strolling, dining, or taking in nearby tourist attractions such as Sacre-Coeur or the Musee Montmartre. If you stay north of the Boulevard Clichy, which is still dotted with sex shops and tawdry storefronts, the charm of the neighborhood quickly emerges. Walk along Rue des Abbesses, the key thoroughfare, for the widest array of shops and restaurants and access to other attractions.

Get your sketch from an Artist in the neighborhood where Van Gough lived # 54 Rue Lepic on the Butte Montmartre. This was a most unique souvenir. I had my daughter and niece sketched while I watched. There were many artists sitting in a sketch area near the souvenir shop between Sacre-Coeur, the Sacred Heart Basillica Catholic Church and the town square at the top of the hill.They rolled the sketches up with paper for framing upon our return. Wonderful item to have for years to come.

Quaint and great views of Paris. A visit to Sacre Cour is also in this area. The church is beautiful and has wonderful views of Paris. The quaint area around the church called Martmarte is special with stores, restaurants and artists. It is a must visi.

Vibrant neighborhood. We had a wonderful afternoon walking through Montmartre. There were great cafes and restaurants. We enjoyed the artists' square where there were painters at work and artists painting portraits. We started off by visiting Sacre-Coeur and then walked down through the neighborhood.

Top of Paris. If you want a pretty decent portrait made of yourself, there are a couple of artists in the Montmartre square that are truly amazing at replicated their sitters' likenesses in a very short period of time. The views of Paris can't be beat but the same can't be said of the food. Go to see and have an ice cream cone ☺️

Amazing views of all of Paris. Don't miss Montmartre when you visit Paris. While tourist haven...it takes you back to the days when painters were outside painting, with music flowing and people walking enjoying.
Charming!. My friend and I did a walking tour of Montemarte and we were so pleased we did. Beautiful streets, tasty restaurants and charming!

Amazing artists. We love Montmartre! We visited here in 2013 and still enjoyed watching the various artists at work. They are truly amazing!
Pity there was not more open places where you can sit and eat a prepared lunch if not wanting to eat in a restaurant/cafe.

It is a neighborhood. I lived there for almost 30 years. Explore, take detours. Take a risk and go into a cafe that is not in a guide. Eat late, especially for Americans, and, above all, take your time. I can not describe the love I have for Montparnasse.

Montmartre. We loved this place, on top of a mountain there is a small neighborhood with many small restaurants, artist, painters and entertainment every corner, and a mega basilica that you can visit for free. Outstanding, while there we had dinner on two different occasions at the Cremallere restaurant very good and at the Cadet de Gascogne, very good as well. Visited in late June and had to wear a sweater and it rained during our stay off and on.

My favourite neighbourhood . Such a quaint area of Paris that still maintains the charm you've seen in the films. Opportunities to have yourself drawn are plenty and the views are incredible. Make sure you don't get ripped off from the artists though.
Montmartre. Every visitor of Paris bus visit Montmartre. The Sacre Coeur, artists, pubs and history. A great day in Paris.
the best view from paris. Very good view but also very tourisistic place For sure its worth the visit and the walking and all th steps

Montmartre is charming. Montmartre is different from the rest of Paris. The streets wind and turn. It seems like there are outdoor cafes on almost every corner. There are fruit stands and fish markets displaying their fresh, colorful wares. It is delightful to walk around MontMartre.

Amazing place for a holiday. My first time in this area & I loved it! Everything is gorgeous & we found all the locals to be very welcoming & helpful! Many great restaurants & bars to enjoy in the evening as well
Hilly but delightful. A lovely walk in the Parisienne evening, up to the Sacre Coeur. Lots of cafes and crepe ties, plus souvenir shops.

Quaint, fun area - explore!. We began our day's tour with a guide by coming to Montmartre -- come early in the day to avoid the biggest crowds. First we stopped to admire the view of the city from the steps of Sacre Coeur, then visited the church before venturing around the square. Artists and cafes dot the main square, and there is even a Starbucks -- great place to pick up a 'Paris' mug if you're a collector like we are.Behind Sacre Coeur is a church which is said to have been built on top of the site where early Parisian Christians were martyred. In those early days of the city Christianity was forbidden, and Christians were killed for their faith - then outside of the city on top of the hill where Sacre Coeur and the oldest church in Paris, St. Pierre de Montmartre, is located. That church is small but has a wonderfully spiritual feel to it. Both churches are free to enter, but be prepared to have your bag checked (at Sacre Coeur and also at other important monuments -- a sign of these times). In the square are many artists -- our guide cautioned us that those who approach tourists to have their likenesses painted are not as good as those who do not -- personally I wasn't sure if that was truly the case but in 15 minutes time if you're willing to sit you'll take home a portrait. The later you go into the day the more crowded the area becomes -- but a fun place nonetheless.

Awesome little town. This is a must in any visit to Paris! It´s not huge and there are so many little things to do, visiting the Tertre Plaza with its artists, the Sacre Coeur Church, the small streets with its cafés, and the lively night life in the bars and the famous Moulin Rouge!

Superior to staying center stage. Montmartre is a delightful neighborhood to wander through, with many small cafes, bistros, restaurants, bakery, clothing, gelato, cheese, and food takeaway shops. The neighborhood is picturesque with a pleasant surprise around nearly every corner.We highly recommend staying in Montmartre. It is easy striking distance to the main attractions of city center for walkers, and even easier by bus or metro. While it is certainly popular, it is nowhere near as overrun with tourists as several other parts of the city.We stayed at a delightful little boutique establishment called Hotel Joke (part of the Asotel group) on Rue Blanche, which gives way a block and a half north to the delightful Rue Lepic, at the Moulin Rouge corner.

Good neighborhood. Montmartre is a bit far from attractions such as the Eiffel Tower but there is a metro a few blocks away. The biggest attraction in this neighborhood is the Sacre Coeur Basilica, which I highly recommend not to miss. We walked from our hotel (which was about 2 blocks from the metro) to the Sacre Coeur and found some cool streets. The Montmartre area has a lot of hills (some pretty steep), so if you are someone with physical disabilities (bad knees, etc), I would not recommend this area to stay, but definitely visit if you can. I believe a cab from the Latin Quarter to Montmartre was about 20 euros.

Nice view of Paris. The view of Paris from the top is wonderful. There are a lot of steps that you need to climb up but at the end is worthy. Many entertainment people around give their show. Is a good place to go and stay for a while to relax. The neighbor nearby offer a lot of food variety

Have a drawing done. The artists area of Paris is still as entertaining as it was in 1966. I had a caricature done back then and had another one done this time, 50years and I haven't changed [much]. A good couple of hours can be spent wandering the artists stalls and its surrounds.

A great day!. From the astonishing Sacré coeur to Place de la Tertre, everything in this area is awesome! Walking in its street was so much fun especially that all of them head down so you don't actually feel tired. The Moulin Rouge street was awful, men and women inviting you to nude shows or lap dances! Didn't feel comfortable there at allllll!

Amazing.... This is arguably the most amazing religious monument in the entire country and one of my favorite attractions in Paris. It is situated on a hill. You can get there by climbing the stairs or by taking the funicular.
A great neighborhood. Start at Sacre Coeur and walk down the narrow streets of Montmartre. Interesting shops and galleries and a nice artists market on the square near the church.
Charming artsy neighborhood where Sacre- Coeur is.... A little touristy but very charming with lots of little cafes and restaurants. The Dali museum is also located here.

Hill top View and beautiful surroundings. It is a nice place to visit , lively, small shops around, lots of artists making portraits and selling their paintings , and best food of my whole trip was eaten here .I have done the whole thing on foot so enjoyed the most.
Great neighborhood. Nice restaurants, a bit touristy but still a lot of fun to walk around. Lots of hills make it seem quite charming.

Stepping Back In Time. We visited Montmartre, on a whim, on our last day in Paris. I'm so glad we did! It was a short, easy Metro ride from our hotel but felt a million miles away. There are artists everywhere, begging to draw your caricature, and the town definitely has its tourist traps, but overall it is charming and picturesque, and I highly recommend just slowly wandering the streets. We climbed to the top of the Basilica dome, and the view was breathtaking. Definitely worth the burning muscles and we rewarded ourselves with a lunch at a quaint cafe in town.
Paris Village. Lovely streets at the back of the Sacre Coeur, a very nice place to while away the hours people watching and drinking wine!
A must visit. A great place to relax, enjoy street shopping and also café sitting. Lots of artists, not cheap, but interesting to look at.
pretty. Another beautiful place to explore Paris is the pretty Montmartre. You ill find around many talented artists.
Montmartre and sacre coeur.. Visited montmartre and sacre coeur. Spectacular church and amazing view of paris. Plus the,artists village was great and authentic. A must see when visit Paris!!

The atmosphere is so ambient!. Artists and musicians make this area vibrant and the crowds throng here. The Sacre Coeur is a fantastic church with a commanding position. It's worth the climb for the view. But you can use the funicular and if you have a metro pass, that is included. Some pricy gift shops and a Picasso Museum make this visit a half day, but it is also great on a fine night.
Great neighborhood. Stayed at Hotel de Arts in this neighborhood. Close to metro station, good restaurants, Starbucks, shopping... Great art for sale. Moulin Rouge is in this area, great show!

Such a cool artsy neighborhood. We loved this neighborhood. It was very cool and had a nice easy going vibe. There are a ton of artists all along the streets and small restaurants. It is a great way to spend an afternoon.

Cute artsy area with little cafes and shops. . I wish we would have been able to spend more time here. We went up to Sacre-coure and found this little square just to the left of the church. Such adorable cafes and shops, as well as artists doing live portrait sketches. If you go to see Sacre-coure go with benighted time to enjoy this area as well.

Very touristique and charming. Montmartre , Sacre Coeur , it give a sense of Paris and time gone by. A most visit , walk up to see the Cathedral Sacré Coeur, enjoy the panoramique view from atop , ,. Walk around rue d!Ortchampt, Rue Saint Rustique , have a coffe ,lunch or just a glass of wine .

One of my favorite places on earth. I love Monmartre, the atmosphere the artists, the food....The View is the best in Paris, sure its a little edgey and scruffy around the edges but that just adds to its appeal. Its right up there on my favorite places to visit.

Great place to explore. Definately put this on your list of to dos, great half day or day trip. Many nice shops, beautiful church and great views. You can take the fanicular to the top of the hill and this is quick and cheap.

food for your heart. especially if you like a romantic place, than Montmartre is the right one, with great paintings you can see for free shown by the artists, pr buy if you like some, great bars, cute small restaurants where a great onion soup could make your day!
Make time for Montmartre is excelent. Try to go with no hurry , take your time ,have a glass of wine, or a cold beer, and let an artist draw a picture of you, enjoy the ambiance

Little taste of Paris. This small area behind the mighty Sacre Coeur is typically French with its cute eateries and if you love crepé, this is the place to be.
Unfortunately since I was here last, the number of artists has dramatically shrunk and has given place to more restaurants, but it is still nice. Maybe less souvenir stores would be better......

Quaint Place. On reaching Montmarte one feels one has travelled out of Paris. Its on a hill with lovely views of the city. The place has artists painting on the streets and street performers playing different musical instruments. Plenty of shops and cafes. Easily good for a day visit.

Great area to sit and enjoy Paris. Stopped for drinks outside at night and this area was buzzing with people. When I thought of Paris this was it. It was quintessential Paris with artists and people to look at while enjoying our cocktail. The waitstaff were very nice and wish we could've returned for dinner and more of the same.
Don't Miss Montmartre. Montmartre is beautiful and definitely gives you a taste of old school Paris. The view of and from Sacre Coeur is amazing!
Montmarte. Awesome site. If you visit the dome be prepared for the climb. It is 300 steps up a very narrow spiral staircase with limited places to stop. Well worth the exercise.

My fav place in Paris. I'm a Paris fan. If I could, I would live there! I've been in the city for about 5 times, and Montmartre is definitely my favorite place to stay and discover. You can feel the history and culture of the city in every street, every corner. In Place du Montmartre you can find street artists and buy some fine pieces of art for a fair price. If you need a place to sleep, it's also a good choice. Don't forget to visit Amélie Poulin's café!

Wonderful place to stroll around look at artists or have s coffee . This area has a flavor all of its own There are many artists actually painting scenes of Paris and also some who do sketches of anyone who wishes to have one. You can purchase a painting or sketch from the artist There are lots of restaurants around the square where the Artists are where you can eat or just have coffee

Just get lost. . One of the loveliest areas to explore in Paris. Do search out Allée des Brouillards and Villa Léandre, two impossibily picturesque streets off the beaten track. Make sure to go behind the Sacré Coeur to see what most tourists skip. Avoid the Place du Terte if you can - too touristy. But do enjoy the view out front of the basilica. The streets can be very steep, and there are a lot of stairs to climb, so just be aware and go slowly if you need to. Enjoy this beautiful part of this fantastic city.

Very Parisian. Perhaps my favourite part of the city! Also one of the few places where people are not pushing cheap wares in your face to sell them, or jangling Eiffel Tower key rings. Enjoy a drink or a meal there, getting a portrait of yourself painted there, or watch the artists as they go about their creative jobs! Well worth the time spent there.

Lovely place. It's worth the walk, not too hard to get to, it's nice, local artists/shops/area. Would recommend because you really feel like you're in Paris in this one section (I know you are but the concept of it)
Enjoyable outing. . To take a reprieve from Paris, and venture out on cobblestone streets with shops and restaurants and the basilica on the hill, head here. We had a great afternoon!

Crowded, trashy. We went up to Montmartre because there was a national strike one day during our visit and the museums were all closed. There were people selling and drinking beer on the stairs leading up to the Sacre Coure! There was a good view of Paris from there but not worth the trip up or the mayhem at the top.

Pretty part of the city. Sacre Coeur is lovely and the steps offer spectacular views across Paris. Montmartre is very tourist- oriented and you have to really search for unique and interesting souvenirs among the cheap and cheerful tat, but the atmosphere is nice and although there are pick-pockets and 'chancers' everywhere, a bit of common sense is all that's needed not to fall prey to them. The artist's area is fun, to watch the artists at work, and it's interesting around the back streets where there are lots of quirky little shops.

Great walk!. You could spend a whole day in this area. Lots of little shops. Great for souvenir buying. Suggest walking up steps all the way to Sacre Ceour first and then from there slowly walk down, Makes for a more relaxing walk down hill instead of up. Bring cash for purchasing souvenirs from little shops or street art. great place to just relax and hang out for an entire day. Will definitely visit again when I go back to Paris.
The perfect neighbourhood. There is just nothing like it. To stroll around Montmartre is like going back in time, or walking into a movie set. You become very thankful that these places still exist.

Our visit to Montmartre. Got there using the Metro no problem.Great view of the city of Paris from up on top of the hill.Lots of steps to climb but not to worry if you cannot. There is a tram to the left (if facing the church) at the bottom that takes you up to the church for 3.80 Euros. It costs the same to come down and they do not accept the Paris Metro Pass, you have to pay.It was worth it since my wife was on crutches.Get there in the afternoon so you can see the city both during the day and as it gets dark.

Fantastic!. Beast thing to do in Paris. The walk isn't too hard. The view at the top is spectacular and when we visited there was live music and people selling beer. Spend a good hour or so just sitting on the steps and soaking in the atmosphere.
Love the place and,people too. Friendly and has a village life it's buzzing with music arts,and it's above Paris,where you can see all over The city below.
Could walk around for days.... Beautiful area with so much character and culture. Spent the morning walking around and grabbed some lunch, highly recommend it

A True Flavor of France!. PJ was my tour guide and he brought so much experience with him. He grew up in this area and loved the way he guided us through a boulangerie, fromagerie, wine store, chocalot and crepe stores where the locals are proud of the freshness and quality of their products and it shows. I got to try so many different wines, cheeses, meats and fresh bread and even a delicious dessert and coffee. Beautiful and charming area, it feels like a small town and Sacre Coeur was then only a few steps away afterwards. I loved it!

Fun Place to Visit. Montmartre, hill of the martyrs, is dominated by the magnificent Sacred Heart Basilica so that was our first stop. Visiting the church is free of charge. The working artists square is not to be missed. You will see all kinds of art from realistic to impressionistic to contemporary. There's a lot of activity going on in Montmartre, a little something for everyone. We found a good restaurant to dine in too (Au Cadet De Gascogne). Very fun place to visit and shows the older buildings of Paris.

Divine. When we went to college my husband and I dreaming of someday go to Montmartre , and this beautiful region of Paris were not disappointed at all. It 's all magical and bohemian as what we had imagined. Its streets lined with restaurants and small shops and street artists have a special charm that exceeded our expectations. You can access on Metro o Bus is easy and not complicated at all.

Romantic. Good old Montmartre.. I always like to visit this area. There are some very talented artist, however, some of these paintings can be expensive. Area has lots of cafes and restaurants, but do expect to pay premium price, even for a coffee.Be always on lookout for crooks and gangs playing tricks in tandem.
Quick stop. Lots of paintings and little stores. I loved walking through all the painting and watch artists paint. It wont take long for you to walk through the streets and park.
Don't miss this neighborhood. Unique for sure! Artists, outdoor cafes, galleries, all surrounding Sacre Cour. Allow 2 or 3 hours and breath in this lovely part of Paris!

don't miss out!. Most wonderful place in Paris! (I know, I am terribly biased) Make sure to check out the local artists, cute little shops and maybe even have a (albeit, more costly than usual) coffee. Lots of opportunities to snap photos, though it can be crowded too. Explore all the little streets you hear people talk about because it's worth it. Maybe take a picnic too, if the weather is good. I enjoyed the rain in the middle of Montmartre, so I can recommend that experience as well. It is a strongly touristy place, but it's one of the best spots in Paris.

Yes! Go!. Montmartre is an experience all its own. Fantastic shopping and dining. Go slowly and do the climb to the top. The view is extraordinary. Go inside the cathedral - even if you are not a believer...it, too, is incredible. One cannot deny the appeal of the architecture, and the stunning white stone.

Perfect Paris Views. We took our walk through Montmartre in the evening hoping to catch the sunset from Sacré-Cœur. For being a popular spot the neighborhoods around Montmartre are surprisingly quiet, once you're off the beaten tourist path, and the views are some of the best in Paris. Look up the Rick Steves' walking tour to learn a little more of the neighborhood highlights or just enjoy your stroll.

Fabulous artistic area.... Aside from the Basilica de Sacre Coeur, the artists square just around the corner is another 'must do' for visitors to Paris. Wander the square and watch the artists at work and even pose for your own drawing of caricature, but ask the price first.Talk to artists about their work and maybe indulge yourself in a picture fresh off the easel.With plenty of cafes and bars, this is an ideal oasis of culture and refreshment in Montmartre.
Too many tourist. Although still impressive, the area is too crowded, and has lost a bit of its own genuine atmosphere.

Wonderful residential area of Paris. My wife and I rented an Air BnB in Montmartre for 5 days. We had never traveled to Paris and didn't know what to expect. I'm so glad we ended up in Montmartre. This area is filled with a local feel, great restaurants and beautiful surroundings.We loved walking to a nearby Patisserie every morning on our way to the metro. Just a great neighborhood feel to it.It's situated on a large sloping hillside. Keep that in mind if you have trouble walking on inclines. I can't say enough about this place and hope to return one day.

So cute!. This is the area directly surrounding the Sacre Coeur. The little shops and eateries are great! There's a lot of variety. It's very much like the streets in the US that are dedicated to artsy-type shops and boutique restaurants. Everywhere you go, though, there is an "Artist" who wants to draw you. It's up to you if you want to take them up on it, but beware of scams and pickpockets.

Classic Paris. Montmartre represents classic Paris, for good and not-so-good. It is a beautiful place full of life, but one must be aware of your surroundings lest you wander into one of the less savory parts of the area. In particular, parents with small children may not want to walk down Blvd de la Rouhechouart to Pigalle with its many explicit sex-related shops.
Lovely place. Art art and art! In this place you can breath art everywhere. We walked around and were astonished by the skills of the street artists we met.

Fantastic View!. Even if we went on July, the days there were raining and moody.. the view from the top was like a painting.. It was fantastic. There were many people from everywhere seeing, sitting and having fun up there.. Once a year we are going to France because it's my husband favorite place of the world. Unfortunately this year we avoid to go because of the bad things happened there but we organized a trip there in Christmas. We love France and specially Paris all over the year so everywhere you go in Paris is like a Paradise for us!!! Je t'aime Paris!!

Old Paris. Exciting, crowded, younger crowd, edgy, old, fantastic. Great restaurants, shopping, theater (we recommend La Nouvelle Eve, better than Moulin Rouge). Even on a Sunday evening, the area was vibrant and alive.

Lovely and unique area, must stop if you have the time!. We did a free Montmartre walking tour and were so glad we did. We would have walked by so many landmarks not even knowing they where there. Even with out that it is a great place to stroll and get a drink or meal.

So pretty and filled with history!. On the way down from Sacre Coeur, I took the scenic walk through Montmartre. It is really beautiful and quaint and with so much history. I loved the windy roads and steep decline. Much better to see Montmartre going down then going up! At the end, I stopped for a picture of the Moulin Rouge! Beautiful morning and very relaxing stroll through this magical hillside.
The gem on the hill!. Walked around this area for 3 hours , more detail and charm in this area to see, especially how the town is laid out further closer to sacre coure. My favourite place to date.

Artsy community. We took the little train up to Montmate, as it's quite an uphill hike.It is an artist community, lots of typical tourist shops but also lots of artists working their craft.We bought yummy macaroons and sat in an outdoor cafe and people watched, which was fun.
The Montmartre is the heart of Paris. If you come to look at the heart of Paris, you have come to the address. From the basilicaSacré Coeur, opened the best view on the сity/

Go early , and miss the crowds. We arrived early in the day, had a coffee, and enjoyed the Cathedral without any (obvious) tour groups being present. The weather was overcast so there was not a great view of the city below but the Cathedral made up for that disappointment. It was awesome to be able to sit, to wander around with so few tourists. An hour later, it was a different story. There were buskers, street merchants, and the crowds had started. Wandering around the narrow streets is pleasant as long as you do not mind saying "no thank you" to the offers of having your portrait done, or to buying a tourist item. It is all part of the atmosphere. There is some interesting art to be seen as well as exhibitions. Meals are generally expensive compare to similar restaurants in other parts of the city.

Just love Montmartre. Stayed in a lovely apartment on Rue Constance in the heart of Montmartre and was overwhelmed by the number of independent bakeries, butchers, fishmongers, cheese shops, wine shops, the list is endless and that was just one street! There are numerous good restaurants and bars, Montmartre cemetery and Sacre Coeur are well worth a visit, a week wasn't enough!

Full of thieves!. The only reason to come here is to see the basilica. Yes, there are some great views (you can't see the Eiffel Tower from here since trees block the view). The artists chase you down and harass you in an effort to have them draw your picture. The worst are all the beggars, pickpockets, and thieves. They were everywhere and in your face, especially the guys who try to put a string loop on your finger. Ugh. Particularly vile are the beggars on the church steps. Sacre Coeur is stunning but you need to fight your way through a mess to get there.

A must see!. One of our top two neighborhoods in Paris! So much to see and learn about. Definitely worth it to take a tour with an experienced guide. Now that I know about the neighborhood, I feel like I could go back again and again.

Beware of the Vendors! . Please use caution as they will try and put items for sale on you and become extremely aggressive when you refuse. It was an uncomfortable experience for us and colored the visit to the area.

Lovely to poke around. Lots to see. . Definitely worth a visit to poke around the streets, the art market,the shops and Sacre Couer. Amazing views. Home of the Moulin Rouge. Catch the funicular up to the top and walk back down through the streets. Great restaurants and lots to see.

Stereotypical Paris. Artists doing portraits and displaying their wares. Souvenir shops, cafes, crepe vendors, organ grinders singing, lovely architecture and cobbled. The Paris most that haven't been imagine it to be.

Interesting and lively neighbourhood!. The charm of Montmartre is in its narrow winding streets, the little cute cafes and eateries, the artists with their colouful art, and of course the magnificent Sacre Coeur.

Not the same anymore. I was at Montmartre in early Jun. Was walking up the stairs up to see the cathedral but was harassed by some African men to tie some strings on the wrist. I tried walking away but was deemed rude by the men. They only stop when a cleaner approached them. However, when I came down, I met the same man and he tried to do the same thing and asked for money. I don't feel safe anymore at Montmartre and advice solo traveller to be extra careful.
Perfect when you are worn out!. This many steps were easy compared to the others. Great small town. Lots of artsy shops and small cobblestone streets.

artists and Sacre Couer. Go for the artists sketching and painting in the streets-sketching and painting you if you like-and for a trip up the funicular railway to Sacre Couer and its spectacular views of Paris.

Ignore the bad, enjoy the good. The "artists" on the streets can be aggressive, so tell them thanks and you'll come back if you want to avoid an insult. Go into the artists stalls for a better idea of what it once was. I had a little silouette of my niece done and it was inexpensive (10€), fast, fun and shockingly it looks just like her. Montmarte is what you make it. Grab a seat in the sun, order a beer and enjoy yourself. It's a neighborhood that shouldn't be missed.

Great views and lovely cafes. Montmartre is a lively, hilly neighborhood with beautiful architecture, interesting shops and cafes and restaurants. Many famous artists lived and worked here. Some houses have lovely gardens and there's even a working vineyard. We visited Basilica de Sacre Coeur and walked up winding staircase to top of dome and were rewarded with fabulous views. But you can get fabulous views of all of Paris just standing in front of church. It might be our favorite neighborhood in Paris.

Wanderlust. If you have few hours to kill, or are looking for some souvenirs, or a good cup of coffee, this is one of your best bets. Impressive narrow streets full of shops, gallerys and restaurants will greet you and take care of you.Beware you might have to go up and down on the streets for a bit, but it's all worth it!

Different. I've wanted to visit this area every since we started visiting Paris so the build up was pretty monumental. Unfortunately, the reality was a little underwhelming. Its a cool neighborhood with lots of life, but just a bit more touristy than I prefer. I actually liked the vibe so we'll give it a second chance the next time we are in town.

Fun area with a real "Paris feel". If you go to the area outside of the Sacre Basilica there are lots of artists willing to paint or draw your picture and lots of cute little sidewalk cafes to people watch. We loved this area

Favourite part of Paris!. Montemartre is a great place to stay if you are visiting Paris. Very pretty, cobbled streets & lots of cafés & bars... Have been visiting family here for many years & love it.

Great area of Paris. Came across this area by chance walking out of the side of the Sacre Couer. Found some gorgeous little side streets, plenty of cafes, souvenir shops and a lovely square full of artists painfully trying to tempt tourists to paint their portraits, and waiters in their typical French aprons. Great atmosphere.

Paris during floods.. We stayed in this high area of Paris so were not effected by the flooding here. It is a lovely area to walk around and explore. Good pastries and pretty churches close by. Easy enough access to public transportation.

Great day spent in Montmarte. We caught the Metro to Anvers and walked up to Sacre Coeur which was beautiful. Also worth paying the 6 euro to walk up to the dome lookout. 300 narrow winding steps to get there but the view is amazing. After lunch we walked down the hill towards Moulin Rouge. The little village along Rue Lepic was gorgeous with some great shopping especially the cheese shops! Caught the metro back from just outside Moulin Rouge. Great Day, definitely worth a visit if you have a spare day in Paris!

Just walk here. Come to montmartre and walk. Walk past the two old men playing chess with a third man watching the game while smoking his siggy. Walk passed the architecture and the tourist shops. Walk down winding lanes and see if you find the highschool student singing opera on a street corner walk passed the Daling museum. Walk up the steps and turn back, enjoy the view. Relax and don't rush it.

Amazing district of Paris. Do include this district to visit in your itinerary.Things to do here.1.Sacred heart Basilica.2.Souvenir Shpping.3.Eat in a open Cafe.4.Wach the Moulin Rouge.5.Stroll around this district.
Very special.. This is very special. Loved all the artwork and the ambience of the place, but such a strenuous trek up there. Well worth it though.

Don't Miss This Paris Gem. We might have missed this quaint neighborhood if it wasn't for our French guide Sabine. To reach Montmarte, it's a climb up the hill but worth every step. (There was a bus driving through the streets but we drove partway and then walked.) The colony boasts of former residents like VanGogh, Monet, Picasso, etc. and artists still gravitate there. In my 14 year old granddaughter's words, "It's just what I always pictured Paris as being like." She fell in love with the ambiance of the area with its street artists, street-side cafes, shops, etc. It's not your usual tourist trap and you should plan to do some leisurely wandering and exploring. While in the area, don't neglect to spend time at the landmark Basilica of Sacre Couer on the top of the mount. We were there on a Sunday and the music was as beautiful as the building.

If you have Time In Paris. If you have some extra time while visiting paris, go to Montmartre. The minor trouble of going there will be well rewarded. it is an absolutely charming afternoon interlude into what was the center of the paris artistic community. Take a walking tour around the neighborhood, than go to lunch at Le Coq Rico

So many artists and street art. We loved woalking around this quarter, seeing so many artists and their varied views on many subjects, mainly of Paris and instant painting of people visiting.
Nice for a couple of hours and having a meal while people/artist watching.

Don't miss this. An easy walk from our hotel in the 9th district, Montmartre is a large 130 metre high hill in Paris's 18th district. This historic district of the city is primarily known for the beautiful white-domed Basilica of the Sacré-Cœur on its summit and as a nightclub district. Many local arts can also be found in the square selling a wide variety of local art. This is a great place to spent a lazy day in Paris.
Recommended. This is the best neighborhood, if you're visiting go with tourist guide, you will definitely learn a lot interesting facts. Nice and different souvenir shops copared to others in Paris.

Beautiful. We stayed for 8 days in this area. It is very quaint easy to access by train. It is a great family location Lots of good stores and a few small supermarkets. Sunday mornings the place seems to overflow with people out enjoying the weekend
Beaut area to visit. Went to Basillica and Moulin Rouge. Stopped off along the way for a couple of beers. Good cafes around the area to have a break. Plenty to see and do.

Wonderful artist area of Paris with great views of city. If you have an extra day in Paris I highly recommend a visit to Montmartre. Such a vibrant area of the city. Picasso and other famous artists lived in this area. Today you can stroll the center for a piece of artwork to take home or have your portrait made. Warning- We bought a nice little painting and while he was wrapping it for us he tried to exchange it with one that was similar but not as good so buyer beware and watch while they are wrapping your painting to make sure you get what you want. Must visit Saceur-Cour while you are here.
