Interesting. We had a tour guide with us and it really added to the experience to see houses and gardens where many famous painters lived and painted. The views looking down into Paris were spectacular. Being early in the day, there were only a handful of painters in the touristy area. Actually, most of the busy streets at the top are touristy, so walking down a few blocks into the neighborhood was more enjoyable.

One of the Romantic Places in Paris. The lovely little streets and the quintessential Parisian feel to this little hamlet on the hill has to be seen if you only ever visit Paris once. The architecture and streets have a very special mix, street artists abound and sometimes get in the way but there is too much to love to be bothered by a bit of commercialism.

Kiwis in Monmartre. Good location to central city easy walks to metro. We spent most of our time away from Monmartre but ate there a couple of times , a number of bars and restaurants a good shopping area.We would stay in Monmartre again while in Paris.

Montmartre. I recommend taking a guided walking tour to learn the history of the neighborhood and the famous Impressinist painters. Fat Tire Tours and guide Hannah provided interesting, fun facts. Wear comfortable shoes because the streets are very steep and there are lots of stairs in many places. I do not recommend bringing small children or strollers. Unfortunately, many parts of the neighborhood are inaccessible to anyone in a wheelchair or with ambulatory concerns. Otherwise, cafes, shops, boulangeries, and souvenirs make Montmarte worth a visit. Give yourself several hours to explore.
Two words: very beautiful. We have visited this cathedral on the 30th of April 2016 and I can just say it is very beautiful and a lot of people were there in that evening

over time it has lost most of its character . so for people like me who have been there over 60 years ago, quite sad. it used to have lots of character , real atmosphere, and it is now one of the worse tourist traps, terrible shops ,bad restaurants, and nothing genuine at all. so for me who have been living for a long time in paris and coming to <paris as a child , it is a really sad experience . for newcomers, they have to see it , and maybe try and imagine what it could have been like it. quite a challenge

Perfect for a teen. This was my 14 year old granddaughters favorite area to wander around. It offered much to see and feels like a big party all the time. Sacre Coeur is magnificent and the views from the steps beautiful.
An Experience. More interesting in the evening this touristic infested area offers all kind of restaurants bistros bars and night clubs

Beautiful area, walked through at night. We walked through this area on the way to the Basilica one night after 11pm. We didn’t know there was a train up the mountain to the Basilica and we walked it. It took us more than 30 minutes to get up there and it was a hike. We climbed back down also after about an hour, before the trains closed for the night. It took us about 20 minutes or so to get back down, a different way to a different subway station. But walking through all those back streets late at night was interesting. Not sure how safe it is, but there were three of us, so we felt fine. The buildings in the area are beautiful and so are the streets. I would almost have to recommend walking up and back through all the small streets rather than taking the trains or however you get up there normally. However, you need to have a good sense of direction, though up is up and down is down, but there are many ways to get there, and I do not remember any signs.

great place to relax and enjoy the views and fellow travelers. great area, lots of art, food, great people. it's also high above the city so a lot of people sit of the steps of Sacre Coeur enjoying all that there is to offer. musicians and mimes vie for your spare change - it's a great place to relax after walking up and down the Champs.

Living beauty and vibrancy. We were there on a wet day and it did nothing to spoil the vibrancy and enjoyment if the day.There were many cafes to have a hot chocolate and watch the daily life pass by.Many tourists were bargaining sith one of the many artists who had their brilluant work on display and for sale.Itvwas great to walk around and look at this living open air art gallery.There were also many little shops that had colourful displays and goods begging to be purchased andvtaken home.A great day out in all weather.

A view across the roof tops. I have always walked up Montmartre to admire the approach to SacreCoeur and to turn and admire the view back. Unfortunately the trinket vendors (beggars) located on the steps have become more aggressive than in the past and one actually grabbed my arm trying to persuade me to buy a souvenir. I gently reminded him that he should not impede/ touch a pilgrim. A visit to Sacre Coeur is a must, to light a candle or two, say a prayer, and reflect. Also don't forget to go to the left hand side and climb the 300 steps to the top and enjoy the view across the roof tops.

Pretty but totally unaccessible for the disabled and some shops are vile.. Place de Tertre is a pretty place for a photo but nothing more. No accessibility for wheelchair (not even the Tourist information office). Starbucks were positively vile, forcing my disabled wife (struggling up some steps) to wait and buy coffee before using the loo. When we asked for a ramp they put a pamp from the door to the edge of a high curb and when asked how we get up the ramp just responded "not our problem" and walked away. Blatant discrimination, obnoxious and unwelcoming. My wife was in tears as we went away.

Good view from the height of Paris.. You can walk you way to the church, or you can take the tram to the top. If you are in good health, it is better to walk the stairs all the way. From there you get a good view.Entrance in the church is free and you can buy classic souvenirs in the church itself.You can go to the Dome where you have a splendid view, but beware, there are 300 steps to get to the top and you have to pay 6 Euro for that privilege. The staircase is very narrow.Make sure you go there early because as from 10 in the morning, there starts to have too many people.

Walk around. Starting at the top fo the hill at the Church of the sacred heart then going gradually lower is the best way. Try the Monmartre museum for some gravures and a few paintings but mostly for the magnificent garden, wander around the streets and alleys preferably the most remote ones where you will discover hidden treasures for your photographic instinct. If you must have your portrait done by an artist ry to make a very quick pass- or not- through the most touristic spots that spoil the magical atmosphere of the Monmartre. Its true value lies elsewhere.

Definitely a TOP choice to visit. The artists here are, in a word, amazing. So many adjectives to describe their tremendous talent. Stopping at the market area west of Sacre Coeur is one of my favorite things, and you MUST get a drawing. Should I call it a drawing? It isn't a painting and not a sketch. The artists use charcoal pencils and they can draw people in 30 minutes so that the finished product looks like a photograph. Truly astounding and a lifelong keepsake for generations later. I highly, highly recommend.

Walking tour of Montmartre with Estaban (Sandemans New Europe). Estaban is knowledgeable & entertaining! We learned a lot about the history, interesting people, and the lifestyle of the people (esp artists of the 19th and 20th century).
very good place to see and visit. This is the place where you can visit when passing by and watch the beauty of old structures still looking good

Must see in Paris. Montmarte is a little out of the way for the tourists as it is in a different area but I absolutely recommend going here. Lots of cheap finds from food, drinks, souvenirs. Buy your souvenirs here. It's half the price compared to the ones being sold at Eiffel & Arc de Triomphe. Sacre Coeur is also a must if you visit Montmarte.

The heart of the artistic center of Paris. Want to feel like the artistic greats of centuries gone by? Want to see where Van Goh lived while in Paris? Care to try some of the best crepes and other french fare? This is the place to really sit and people watch and feel like the bohemian artists of yester year. DO hold on to your wallets and cell phones carefully as artists are not the only ones who enjoy spending time in this area.

Charming. We love to just walk the streets in Montmartre and having lunch in the cafes there. The artist in the square are talented and you can purchase original art that is well priced. We never can resist a piece or two each trip to bring home as our Paris souvenir.

Beautiful but getting a bit messy. This is always my favourite in Paris, because its a beautiful building and you can have the best view of Paris. But recently there are too many tourists there and some people dont know how to keep it clean. It makes this place become a bit dirty and have bad smelly at some spots. Still recommend
Great Location, Beautiful Buldings. Easy to get around,even with a dog, very cheap by bus, leave your car in the garage!Places to drink and eat by the bucket load!
Great place to stay. Hotels are cheap and pretty, the metro is closeby and the area is very safe. I came and went at all hours with my best friend. We're both female and never felt unsafe.
Vibrant area, amazing structures very friendly people. This is a safe area and getting lost and having a wander around is a brilliant way to experience it.

Love Montmartre. Monmartre has lots of contrasts with its unseemly side but also art, buildings, food and history.
I love wondering round here. A guided working tour is a great idea to see it all.

Get off the beaten path. the best way to view Montmatre or Mountain or Martyrs is with a free walking tour (use trip advisor to find one). Everyone goes to the big places but miss the small more nuanced places with lost in just meandering. Take free tour where you pay by tips and you will enjoy it so much more.

One of my favourite areas. Love Montmartre. Great areas to visit. Great view of the city. Lots of tourist shops but then we were tourists. Cool restaurants and bars. Things too see: the amazing looking moulin rouge, sacre cour, a chocolate shop with sculptures of famous Paris landmarks made from chocolate. All very cool. Easy to get to on metro You have to go if for the view alone.

Must visit. Sacre Coeur, incredible view of Paris and Montmartre. We got Uber to take us from St. Germain to Montmartre - not to the steps/elevator, but up the hill for only $15. Such a deal!! Sacre Coeur is beautiful, but the view of Paris from this spot is spectacular. Around the corner from the church begins the restaurants and shopping of Montmartre. A lot of touristy stuff, but you can buy some really great, relatively cheap art. My friend bought a Van Gogh copy and a really interesting nighttime scene. Both oils for about 150E. Four years ago I got a wonderful oil of St. Bernard puppies. Same place. Fun little restaurants with outside dining. And then the Marketplace. Full of artists and their original artwork. My friend and I bought pieces from Samar, a female artist. But, there is art there for every taste. On the walk down, find the kitchen store - Pylones. Very cool, very unique French kitchen stuff and more!

Favorite area of Paris!. We absolutely loved this area. Next time I hope to stay in this location of Paris which is the northern area. It feels so very homy with so much to see and do! If you really want to get into the culture of Paris this is where to go. We loved the artist area called Palce du Tertre, we even bought a painting there. Also the area we walked is where Vincent van Gogh lived and Dalida, the Italian-French actress.

Got To See - At Least Once. Find a cafe off the main square. We found Chez Plume Au on the south side of the square. Ordered a charcuterie plate of cheeses and meats. We save half and still had more than enough for another meal. Watch the sunset from the steps of Sacre Cour before heading back down on the funicular (it is a Metro ticket).

Total tourist trap, but not to be missed. I haven't been here for 40 years but it doesn't seem to have changed at all. It's extremely touristy, I'm not sure Parisians would ever go there, but it's definitely worth a visit if you have the time

Go here to walk around and love Paris. This is the second time I have spent the day walking around this lovely town. I love the art everywhere. If you have a chance go see Bruno at Art 21 - he has artists works for sale that are affordable and beautiful. The restaurants are good but make sure you walk down some side streets to really get a flavor for the town. Very relaxing and interesting

A place of two halves - be warned. The front of sacre couer on the tourist side is full of thieves and vagabonds. Having to push people away from giving bracelets isn't a nice feeling and it just doesn't feel safe. Just horrible. However once over the hill and past the church things were wonderful. Peaceful and arty the area is quiet and enjoyable. A good stroll down to the moulin rouge.

Touristy, but enjoyable. This was my 3rd trip to Paris, and also my 3rd trip up the hill. It's touristy yes, can be crowded, but a can't miss on your travels to Paris. Once you visit the basilica, exit left of front and continue up. You will find your self in the square, full of restaurants and shops where you can stop for lunch or a drink. There are also numerous artists, where for 50+ US dollars, you can have a sketch drawn. We did this for my daughter, and the finished product was just beautiful. Continue around and down the narrow stairway past the square and you will be nearby the cafe in the movie Amelie, and can see the old windmills. This is a beautiful area and should not be missed. I would recommend you take the Metro to Pigalle (Moulin Rouge) and walk from there to fully experience the area.

Buzzing and beautiful . Love this area, buzzing - great for panoramic views of the city, people watching and looking round the stalls and shops You are constantly approached to have your picture/caricature done but other than that it's a great place to be

Artists' Paradise!. Montmartre is a lovely neighbourhood, with hilly streets and colourful shops. I really enjoyed spending time in the square where 40-50 artists were painting and selling their art work. We even bought one!  Montmartre really brings out the artistic/creative side of Paris! Walking around the area for 2-3 hours is something I suggest travellers should do.

My very favorite part of Paris. When planning our trip to Paris, this was the one place that I was really excited to go to again. The village around Sacre Cour is quaint, and such a pleasure to just stroll through. We highly recommend a trip up the hill. And although there are some stairs to climb, there is also a funicular for part of the climb. This is a must see!

My favourite area of Paris so far.... I went on a tour of Montmartre and was surprised by the history, development and artistic past of the area. So many artists, musicians and writers have lived in the area (including Picasso, Van Gogh and Renoir) and still nowadays the district is still very lively and popular with younger crowds at night. It is full of little restaurants, shops and cafes as well as a few churches and the beautiful Sacré Cœur Basilica. Well worth a visit. I personally fell in love with this district of Paris.
Moulin Rouge. Montmartre is a heart of Paris as for me. You have to visit it . Charles Aznavour La Boheme is about it. Famous authors and artists use to live here.

A beautiful area ruined by string men and pickpockets. I visited the Sacre-Couer, and on the path on the way up you encounter whats known as the string men of Paris. A group of 6 or so guys who will pester tourists and try to get you to have a bracelet of string from them. One of them will grab your wrist, and even after saying I had no money they insisted, and are so forceful they will just hold onto your wrist until they get their way. They chat and seem nice enough, and eventually when he finished he asked for money, but as I reached for coins in my pocket he said no he wanted only notes. I said I had none and he pointed to a square bulge in my pocket saying it was my wallet and he needed at least 20. Once I showed him it was a battery pack for my phone he said coins will do, and he just took all the coins I had which was probably close to €8. What makes all this more annoying is when I informed some gendarmes walking around the area they didn't care, they were patrolling the entire area except where the string men worked.Once I got to the top I wasn't in the mood to go inside the church as now all my coins were taken, and the experience ruined my visit. Obviously this isn't an accurate reflection on the church itself, but the area is a hive of pick pockets and scammers and no one seems to be doing a thing.

My favourite area of Paris. It's lovely here. Lots of little shops, bars which are laid back during the day and buzzing in the evening, nice park areas adding greenery and some excellent restaurants. Famous landmarks for the Sacre Coeur (with fabulous views across the whole of Paris) and the Moulin Rouge. The little road-train which runs from outside the Sacre Coeur gives a nice 40 minute tour of the area without the effort of walking up all the hills.

Plan to Visit After Dark - Romantic and Should Not Be Missed. I had visited this area before, but I had not gone in the cathedral . Don't miss it. A mass was going on, and it was a wonderful experience. Go for dinner. There are some good restaurants at the very top and the prices are not bad. We had already eaten, and we had wished we had waited until we got to the top. The view of Paris is not to be missed.

Big Time Favourite. Have stayed in a few different areas of Paris,but Montmarte tops them all. Oozing charm. Fantastic local food stores ,cafes and restaurants . Brilliant place to explore(can be a bit hilly) and of course has Sacre Coeur!! Surely one of the most magnificent settings in the World,looking out over the entire City of Paris

Lively and entertaining.. I enjoyed my time here so much that I went twice. Very active and lively neighborhood with lots of art, tiny little fun streets, great food and street entertainment. It was very touristy and crowded (at all times of the day) so if thats not your scene, you may want to give this one a miss.Lots of people trying to draw caricatures and sell you trinkets, not sure they're worth it but to each his own. However they weren't pushy at all, If you're not interested, a simple "no, thank you" would suffice.
Good spot for mementos. Stop by to pick up paintings, sketches, jewelry from the artisans. No need to plan a lot of time here, but nice to visit.

Must go when in Paris!!. If you go to Sacre-Coeur you must go. Its just around the corner from it. There is a lot of artist that tries to paint you, so if you don't want it just say no. They will go away. I went on a rainy day, so it was almost empty. Si down at La Boheme for a quick bite, and it was a pleasant one. The food was more than great
A gentle stroll. Take your time to wander the street of this artistic area, pop in to the museum and have coffee or lunch at one of the many restaurants/cafes.

Touristy, but great views and great art. The climb up the stairs is totally worth the wonderful view of Paris you see when you reach the top. It's great to walk around and look at the artists painting, but be careful of men trying to do a caricature of you for money. Try to find a restaurant off the beaten path to avoid just another tourist trap.

One of the most touristy places I've been . It could have been nice if it wasn't so crowded and maybe more authentic. We passed through quickly trying to get a feel for the whole place but it was as busy as the Tokyo subway at rush hour. There are definitely better ways to spend an afternoon in Paris.

Beautiful, eclectic, heart-warming. I love Montmartre - the people there, the buildings, the atmosphere. It is a beautiful place that I have been back to several times, and would recommend to anybody visiting Paris. Try it - it is hard to explain the feeling... even walking the stairs, and going through the small alleys that lead to it feel magical.

Wonderful neighborhood. We were in Paris attending an event in Montmatre so we stayed in this area I have never visited. I LOVED it!!! The neighborhood was beautiful, active and full of surprises. Hidden parks, little museums, great restaurants and cute boutiques.

Very touristy but for the best reasons. Montmartre is a tourist magnet ... no doubt. But if you can get past the caricaturists hawking their offers to draw you, you will see some really talented artists actually painting the scenes they offer for sale. The mood is very warm and friendly, the feel of the old quarter will bring a smile to even hardened travelers. And, the pitchmen are actually very easy-going and freely offer good suggestions for sightseers.

Tourist Trap. This is a very picturesque part of Paris with lots of restaurants and artists trying to sell you paintings. Our tour guide told us many of the paintings are from China so beware of spending lots of money on a painting. It is always very crowded and really just a place for tourists to leave their money on a mediocre meal and cheap trinkets to take home. Worth a visit to see what all the hype is about but keep your money in your pocket and eat elsewhere.
Cute. This was a really cute little area, I really enjoyed walking in the small cute streets of this area. There's plenty of cafes and restaurants around

Enjoy the view of misty Paris, and watch out for gypsy kids.. The church is non-descript, the area is raucous and teeming. But at the top, the view is wonderful, and the meandering side streets are fun.

Artist's District. Montmatre is touted to be the artist's district of Paris - this is mainly because all the famous artists like Picasso, Van Gogh, Toulouse Lautrec, Renoir etc lived and worked there. It is still a very bohemian and hip place with a lot of artists painting and displaying there w ork in Place du Tetre, many well known musiciants play and promote their latest albums in the area so its always good to walk around the area. For the tourists there are ample souvenir shops and restaurants and of course Sacre Couer church, Dali museum, the steps of Monmatre, the bust of Dalida, the street where Amelie was filmed, the vinyards of Montmatre and the panoramic view in front of the church make it a very pleasant morning or afternoon to spend in the area. This area also has some of the finest boulangeries in Paris - do stop by to buy a baguette or two!

So so so so pretty. I absolutely love this area!!! It really epitomises French culture for me!! There are lovely little cafes and chocolaterias around!! There are also a lot of cute little of the beat and track shops, some really nice vintage shops too, well worth a ramble around!!!
Lovely area. Wewandered through the streets after visiting the sacre coeur. I loved all the little shops. Selling fruit veg fish cheese pasties. A very nice area to stroll around.
nice and romantic place. One of the best places in the town. Don t forget to walk among the painters and have beautiful photos above the whole city.

May be better at night. I was so disappointed returning to Montmartre , the arty vibe of the past was replaced with tacky tourist shops, material shops and unimaginable crowds heading to Sacre Coeur...not a place I will return to

Lovely and Lively Area. We rented an apartment for couple of days right next to Sacre Coeur so had a chance to see the area on foot. There were three kids in our company and they also enjoyed exploring the area. Lovely architecture and details all over, plenty to see and do as well as places to eat.
busy area of Paris. This area is owrth visitng if only to climb the hill to visit the cacre courchurch. You don't hve to climb all the way up as there is a funicular railway available to you.
Interesting Area. After seeing the church and looking at the view from the top of the hill the walk around the markets with the artists displaying their work was interesting. Well worth seeing

A very cool place. The Sacre Coueur cathedral wasn't that big an attraction for us, but the artists around the square were awesome! We could have spent the whole day just watching them paint and draw and enjoying their finished works. All reasonably priced, too!
Behind Sacre Coure. Favorite part of Paris, beautiful buildings, artwork everywhere, cafes etc. Still fairly touristy and expensive but the further away you go from Sacre Coure the quieter it gets

Nice views but a bit of a tourist trap. Its a lovely thing to walk up the steps on the Square Louise Michelle on a Sunday afternoon. Great atmosphere but spoiled by chaps wanting to make friendship bracelets as you climb. This was a bit disconcerting. There are plenty of places to eat and shop at the top but I would advise going to the right of the Basilica (the quieter side) onto Rue Lamarck for the quieter cafes. Had a smashing crepe in a small creparie that was great value and had a free toilet.

Arty area.. Loved being in Montmarte. Went with Marielle from Culture Fish Tours. Great to be following in the footsteps of Picasso, Toulouse Lautrec, Amelie etc. Like being back in the movie "Midnight in Paris".

Interesting place to see. We went to see Montmarte with our tour Insight vacations and they had a local guide who told us about interesting facts about this place. There are a lot of famous painters who live here so you can find good paintings here. Also, there are painters who can make a portrait of you so if you have the time and want to make one then definitely do it here.Also there are quite a few cafes here with few shops selling local art. Good place to visit for a afternoon.

Don't miss the Montmartre Museum. The Musee de Montmartre is a fascinating jewel in this quirky area of Paris. Many paintings by Utrillo and his life story, together with that of his mother make this a very interesting and well worth visiting museum.

Eclectic art hangout behind the Sacred Heart Basilica. This little collection of shops, cafes and street artists was a local hangout for the great artists many years ago. Get your portrait done by street artists or find a painting to hand in your home.
Okay. Well the area is okay but it's not as romantic as the movies make it out to be. It's basically just a calm neighbourhood.
Interesting area and shops. This area has something for everyone, kitchen stores, fashion, books, etc, it's very crowded, but safe, many bank ATMs to get money from, easy walk, many cafes, bistros.

A fading former charmer. Montmartre suffers miserably from the over exposure and excess of commercialization which erodes it's will to live. Hawkers pester passersby so insistently that strolling the gorgeous cobblestone streets is exhausting. It's too much.

Tough walk but worth it. Arranged for a private guide (Harriet Evans) through Viator. Was a bit taken back when a blonde Brit showed up but she was excellent. KNew all the history and told it like she lived it. Glad a booked a private tour as we needed several rest stops to climb the hill. Nice tourist shopping area and outdoor artist areal on the top. Did not go in the church. Lots of history in this area.

A place to remember . This neighborhood got something special about it.The street artists. the style of its buildings and streets. Overall it's a nice place to spend time in and enjoy every second of it. We started the tour from down the hill we took a small touristic train. It took us up to place de tartre where the artists and cafés. It's so close to sacre coeur basilica so we took a walk there then we entered the Sacre Coeur basilica. Through our way we have seen the place where toulouse lautrec lived. Near place de tartre is perfect for buying souvenirs from Paris as it got many shops with a variety of gifts different than what I have seen in every souvenirs shops in Paris. We walked down the way till we found the Moulin Rouge. We weren't planning to do anything there. So that was the end of our day in Montmartre. In my personal opinion I will recommend visiting Montmartre during your stay in Paris. Totally worth it.

Only Ic. You are close. Nothing t important it's too commercial and faux Too dangereos gitanes and bad people hereMake attention Please In september the sunset it's really romanticJust to view, of you want, but not necessary

The artistic neighborhood of Paris. You would do the mistake to miss this part of Paris. Painters working around the picturesque streets, classy cafes and restaurants, a magic aura. Walk around Montmartre and head straigh to Sacré-Cœur where the view is breathtaking.

Romantic little artist town. Very touristy but cute and beautiful, with small streets branching out and you could walk around without getting lost much because it's not too big. It sits on top of a hill, so you can either go by the funicular, or climb the stairs to experience the real Montmartre. It was raining when I was there, so there wasn't a big crowd which I liked, peaceful and quiet. Lots of artists offering to do live portraits as well, I believe this is where the art culture in Paris originated.
Charming Visit of Historical Site.. A historical site with the famous Sacre Cour Cathedral to tour, many artisans surrounding the area with live painting, great views of Paris.

Can't-miss destination in Paris. You cannot afford to miss this historic, if not most decadent, neighborhood in Paris. It's best to start your tour with a visit to the Basilica of Sacre-Coeur, which sits on a hill and is accessible via a series of steep steps or a tram. A silent prayer at this magnificent cathedral may absolve you of the trespasses you will ultimately commit when you go down the bottom of the hill and explore the cobbled boulevards lined with bars, cafes, artisan shops, patisseries, art studios and of course, the ubiquitous sex shops. This is an attraction you can't miss, if only for its colorful appeal.
a hilly wander. a must do in Paris but it can get crowded with tourists nevertheless it is unique and great fun. Having your portrait drawn is a fun thing to do and a great momento

Interesting Part of Paris - worth a visit. If you like art, music, reasonable shopping, then you will like Montmartre district. It is filled with small shops, cafes and a square that is filled with street artists doing delightful work. You can get your own portrait done for 40-60 Euros. There are street musicians playing sweet music and quaint cafes to eat at. I found the souvenir shopping in this area cheaper than in main center of Paris - so buy your souvenirs here.

Buy a painting. This is a life experience. Go here, climb the stairs, eat a warm crepe and buy yourself a painting to always remind yourself of your trip to Paris. I love spending time strolling around Montmarte, so will you!

Perfect! . Montmartre is perfect for the ultimate Parisian bohemian experience plenty of quaint little shops, artwork and stunning restaurants! You could easily spend hours sitting and watching the world go by! When I return to Paris I will be returning to Montartre!

Charming . This area reminds me of San Francisco. The artistic atmosphere, all the small shops, and each street has its own personality. The metro was easy to maneuver and the tour buses where easy to navigate.

A lovely mourning walk in Paris. A must go neighborhood if in Paris! Lots of nice cafes, souvenir stores and the sacré cour church! We walked around during a mourning and it was a great start of a day!! The view of the city up there is amazing!

Always magical.. We decided to make our base in Montmartre and stayed at the Best Western. This area is full of beautiful architecture and great little cafes. Make sure you head off the well worn tourist tracks (Walking from Moulin Rouge to Sacre Coeur) so as to avoid the large crowds.

My favorite place in France!. I love this place! It provides the best view of Paris! Avoid the touristy shops but be sure to go to the square where the local painters set up shop. I loved the view, the quaint restaurants, and the art.

Don't Believe It!. We have just got back from a few days staying in Paris, in the heart of Montmarte and found the area friendly and anything but threatening as mentioned several times on here. There is indeed a street filled with strip clubs, sex shops and table dancing clubs, justbalong fromnthe Moulin Rouge, where ladies of the night ply their trade and yes, if you want to walk down there at night , you will be accosted. So if this does offend you, do as we did and just don't go there. Problem solved.

A classic even for a short visit. It is pleasant to be there and have some onion soup and a glass of red wine. Watch the other tourists. Take photos of clever and quick artists. Have your portrait made.
Lots of stamp dealers ( think movie Charade). Not as Scruffy looking as it used to be but not an area that is charming for a tourist visit. Hotel told me not many good places to eat in area.

Very Glad I Visited. Loved the historic artist focus throughout the area. There were some good street artists, which you do not always see. Big crowds did not diminish the great views of Paris. Watch your pockets and enjoy Montmartre.

The church . The church in monmartre was really interesting, but I have heard a lot good things about monmartre and I was disappointed.. very touristic place with bad cafe and restaurants. Not my favorite place in Paris.

Lovley and fun area. This area of Paris is so interesting and fun. I spent three nights in Paris and stayed in Montmartre for all of them. I really like the atmosphere in the area and I love everything about it. An amazing area.

Fun Area for foodies and shoppers alike!. This area is a bustling area great for foodies and shoppers alike! filled with authentic produce shops sprinkled amidst local boutique shops this area is a fun afternoon getaway.

Most Picturesque Area. What a beautiful district. All the artists seem to gather here and each street is more quaint and glorious than the next. Do the walking tour of the area to really appreciate it. The area includes the Moulin Rouge, Sacre Coeur the Wall of Love.
Such and interesting little place. So lovely tolook out over Paris from the steps, wander around at sunset, and dine outside in the courtyards. Amazing atmosphere.
Lovely area to explore. We really enjoyed our time exploring Montmartre area. There were so many stalls and shops selling food, souvenirs and many things.

a must visit. a really good taste of parisians doing every day business and turist going arround
the shops are cute, the artist doing portraits are amazing
you have to climb the steps up the hill very carefully

Fun Neighborhood. I spent seven days in Paris, living in an apartment in Montmartre, so I got to know the area relatively well. It reminded me a lot of the Village in New York. If you want to be in the heart of Paris with a touristy experience, then this is not for you. But if you want a more "how the natives live" experience, then this is a good possibility. Travel to all the major sites is easy by metro so you can choose to live either as a tourist or as a native here.

Neighborhood Paris. Spent time wondering this area of Paris and found it very enjoyable. There is something to see around every corner, and with it being the highest point of the city, there can be some amazing views. Restaurants galore as well as shops. One of my favorite districts in this city.

Great stop for views and artists. Once you get past the artists by the church, spend time around the main square. Some very talented people. Ask for their cards , some have a great history. Great place to stop for lunch and admire the artists at work. If you choose, get a portrait done of a family member - great memories. Also the views are great particularly on a nice day.
Paris holiday . Good are to stay in lots of local French restaurants to choose from. Good location close to amnesties. Easy access to transport links.

Busy but worth it . A must do for any visit to Paris, climb the hill slowly stopping to browse shops or for a coffee whilst watching the world go by. You can navigate away from the crowds to some extent but the views from the top are unavoidably busy but worth it!
nice place to visit. We took a self guided walking tour of Montmartre and it was very enjoyable, it is like a village in the middle of Paris

The bohemian Paris. I loved everything about this area: the magnificent view of Paris from the top of the hill, the lovely streets with pittoresque restaurants, the bohemian air that is everywhere. Just walk the streets, with no destination in mind, it is pure beauty. If possible pick a less crowded period of the year. Would not recommend for food, as most of the restaurants are tourist traps.

Funky French town with character. We stayed in Montmartre for 4 days and enjoyed it immensely. The Sacre Coeur is a beautiful church and the view over Paris is impressive. Lots of street vendors and music made for a fun day.

Fascinating.. Truly a Parissean experience that is a must do.Take your time meandering the little streets and watch the street artists at work and then rest a while enjoying the scenery at one of the numerous pavement cafes.
A cheerful corner of Paris. With painters on the roads, colourful restaurants on the roadside and hand-made art objects in little shops, this district has its own attraction for the tourists.

The highest point in Paris. The Basilica, the view, the place of artists behind the Basilica, all is very beatiful and makes the visti worth, even climbing hundred of steps to reach the top. Too crowded on Sunday.

Always an option. I am in love with Montmarte. No matter how many times I go there, there are always new restaurants to try, new small streets to get lost in, and it would never cease to amaze me with its charm. I think it is the best place for romantic dinners, or even simply walks. Also lot of restaurants serve Absinthe in its traditional way.

DO IT! Dine at the top!. Had a beautiful walk up to the top of Montmartre but you can get the bus or a cable car. Ignore the pick pockets who try ambush you at the base of the steps. Hold your bags tight and do not speak to them. Other than that it is perfection

Christmas in Monmartre. Montmartre can be touristy but also a very wonderful place to stay when you want a real Parisian feel to your experience. My teenage daughters first time travelling from Australia. We stayed in a small apartment behind the Moulin Rouge it was fantastic. Christmas markets, the smell of food cooking and shops open even over Christmas. Even small resturants without needing reservations. Moulin Rouge Christmas Night was AWESOME
Cool district. I repeat myself, but this is a cool district. It has to be experienced. Get a hop on hop off ticket and enjoy the day!

It's the history after all. I was a bit dissappointed that everything has converted to the money. The charm is there but mainly because of the movies and stories, otherwise a lot of cheap tricks to get your money out of your pocket. Very few real artists

Best Area of Paris. If you want to be in a great area of Paris this is it. There is everything you could want there. The markets are fresh and stocked daily. There are bakery's, cafe's, restaurants, bars of all kinds and many of them. The variety is amazing. The history and sights to see are more than you can take in. We saw Van Gohs house, Picaso's studio, the Basilica of Sacre Coer, had lunch in the artists square nearby and even had my portrait done. I can't wait to go back again.

Gorgeous area of Paris. It was a great place to spend the day. I spent a good few hours exploring, there's so much to do without getting bored. Lots of shops, cafes, bars, it has beautiful views if you can be bothered to climb all of the steps. Only thing I disliked was being a solo female around this area, lots of men trying to grab my wrists to give me a 'friendship bracelet'... luckily they scattered when the police arrived.
Artistic. Very good place with lots of artists in the street, showing theire job and trying to catch more costumers.Too many cafes and bistros to have a sit .A place for lover could be .

Great place to spend the day!. We went to this area for a food tour and ended up spending the whole day here. It has great food, beautiful views if your happy to walk up a steep hill, and some great little shops. Would definitely go back to this area.
Great experience. really loved it. beautiful place with great ambiance. you could spend a whole day here without getting bored. highly recommended

Interesting. The route to Montmartre via the Hop-On Hop-Off bus takes ages, and you travel through some seedy parts of the city, past sex shops and run-down establishments. Leaving the bus, you have to wind your way down a crowded street full of tacky stores selling T-shirts, miniature Eiffel Towers and cheap luggage. When you get to Place du Tertre, soak up the atmosphere, have a quick drink if you want, but don't be fooled into thinking this is an authentic representation of the city. It's over-the-top touristy, but there's a certain charm to it. You won't need to spend a lot of time here.

A great little attraction.... Montmartre is a little piece of heaven away from the hustle and bustle of the city. A great time to visit is during the street fairs. Local artisans have specialties such as cheeses, wines, honey, etc. There are also some local shops that are well worth the visit as well.

So much going on at the same time!. This place is really nice! From the church to all the street art and the musicians. Just be careful of the tourist traps! There everywhere! So if someone comes to you do make a bracelet for you, just say no and continue walking, even if they are persistent!

Loved walking around at Montmarte. Nice relaxing stroll through Montmarte on a cloudy day makes for a perfect afternoon of leisure. A place too meet with the artists of Paris an perhaps even get a portrait made

What a day of beautiful day to experience Montmartre!. One of the highlights of Paris is to see all the artists and all the beautiful works of art they have to offer! All the shops and with all the things they sell so you can remember what a gorgeous place you are visiting! The food and the restaurants are just to die for. The Basilica of Sacre-Coeur or church at the top of the hill must have been what all the poets must have been looking at while they wrote about the beauty and culture that Montmartre has to offer. The sights of Paris from this viewpoint is unbelievable and I had to pinch myself to really believe I was seeing this breathtaking beauty and think of all of the people who have experienced this same amazing experience and feeling what I was feeling.

Great fun. Excellent ambiance. Watch out for pickpockets! Say a firm "Non, Merci!" toanyone who stuffs a clipboard towards you - an accomplice will be nearby! There will be hucksters galore but enjoy the sights, the cafes, the historic, boring buildings where famous people lived. Walk around and explore. Find the other remaining "moulin" other than the red one!

Love this neighborhood!. This is such a quaint and interesting area. Love the Sacre Coeur Church and all of the artists as well as the cafes. Can't wait to return. Not to mention, the Moulin Rouge which was a great experience!

Meh. This place is not a must go if you are not really into seeing Sacre Couer. Area is dirty and at night not really safe as locals said to us. We went there to eat but was not satisfied with what we were offered. There is a chocolate shop when you enter at Cite d'Orsel. Now that was where we lost it and got lots of varieties of chocolate bars and took photos of Eiffel Tower made by chocolate. If you want to see that, then go. Also take the finicular up hill to see some interesting streets and Sacre Couer area.

Stayed just below Sacre Couer at Square D"anvers. Visited this area my first day in paris. It wa sjust up a hill from my hotel . The area around the basilica is very busy ( and very dirty - lots of litter which was disappointing :() . Once you are there , take the little side streets and discover this very interensting area, and great views of the City of paris at your feet
Something special. Worth going to and seeing the artists working and selling their art. More importantly the Dali Museum is a treat.

Charming place!. perfect neighborhood for walking around, charming places, bars, views and atmosphere! I totally recommend spending half a day there! Bars and restaurants closes around midnight during the week, do not expect a lot of nightlife beyond this hour.

Take the subway to Lamarck Caulaincourt for easy access. The Lamarck Caulaincourt subway is north of the mount but close to the top. There is a lift in the station to take you to the street. From there you can climb a few steps to get to the Sacre Couer from the side entrance. Lots of nice narrow streets to explore on this side and fewer tourists. Then it is downhill to the Moulin Rouge and the subway at Pigalle or the buses.

Paris as it was.. Great restaurants, lots of street artists with different styles and abilities, beautiful views from so many spots you never get bored, and of course the Basilica of the Sacred Heart is a must see.

Moulin Rouge and the Ameleie Cafe!!. Here you'll find the world famous Moulin Rouge. Film lovers may want to pay a visit to the lovely café du deux moulins - the actual café of the "Amelie" movie" fame. Reasonable prices.

Lots of tourists and artists wanting to sketch you. We visited Montmartre on recommendation of several friends who had been to Paris multiple times. I was a little disappointed. While I did find the artists interesting and the work generally pretty good, the area was really overrun with tourists and you would get peppered with questions about artists wanting to do your sketch. If you want to see the artists or the Basilica de Sacre Coeur, then you should go to the Montmartre area. However, you can find cafes just as good but not completely overrun with tourists in other areas of Paris (our preference was the 7th arr.).

Enjoyed our walk. We enjoyed walking thru this part of time our walk was wet but the cafe where we had lunch was welcoming and it was a great place to purchase souvenirs and momentos of our visit to Paris..

Lovely walk with lovely views. I always enjoy walking around this area and visiting the Chapel with once again a wonderful view of Paris. It's fun to see the artists and musicians and the crowds enjoying both.

Best part of Paris . We were lucky enough to have booked our airbnb in this area and it remains my favourite area of Paris, we had fantastic butchers, cheese shops, chocolate shops, beer and wine shops on our road, and a short walk away were loads of cafes, restaurants, bars etc. Lots of steps and hills (obviously) but a lovely safe and very French feeling place to stay or visit.

You have to go. Montmartre, home of Toulouse Le'Trec, the Moulin Rouge and the Sacre Couer Church is also home to the best view of Paris and probably my favorite breakfast place. It is definitely worth a trip.

Go for the views. Watch the artists at work and do buy one of the paintings! There's a little Greek chap there, does lovely work. Nice place to walk around, few cafes and restaurants, busy up by Sacre Coeur however.

Go early. Do not take a tour. Montmartre used to be where poor artists lived and painted but now it is very touristy and an extremely expensive place to live. Avoid the crowds by taking the Metro green line to Abbesses early in the morning (9am is good) and walk around the streets on your own, guided by the large tourist maps around and remembering that Sacre Coeur is at the top of the hill. Ignore the souvenier shops and the tour groups around Sacre Coeur and Place du Tertre and use your imagination to recapture the atmosphere that existed here early last century. The view of Paris from the steps below Sacre Coeur is amazing, and the narrow cobbled streets and the beautiful apartment houses are delightful. If you go on a Sunday there are services in Sacre Coeur and singing, as will as a carillion from the bell tower. Le Café Templier in Rue de Abbesses serves two courses for 15 euros and quite a reasonable sauvignon. We visited on a rainy day and this probably kept the crowds down, but added more atmosphere
good view of PAris. very nice place to see Paris from the top of the city.beautiful charge on top of hill. in the down of hill there are some black man I did not feel calm with them

Lovely Part of Paris. Montmarte was an area of Paris I wanted to check out for the arts scene. It has quite a view and a great atmosphere. It is full of small shops and cafes so you can spend hours just walking around taking it all in. Even though I was there for several hours I think I have much more to discover when I return.

just awesom. its like a little town in the middle of paris. there is a lot of places to eat y watch everything. even its crowded all the time you always can find a place to eat something or have a coffee

Fun Place to Visit. A fun place to visit. Great to go to the cathedral. When we were there, there happened to be a wine festival. Lots of people but still fun. The cemetery is great too and some cute souvenir shops!
Great neighborhood. Walked here from our hotel (15 minute walk) and must have passed 300 sidewalk cafes and restaurants along the way.

Over-rated and over priced. I was really looking forward to my visit to Montmartre but was disappointed as it is a real tourist trap with everything over-priced. Two hot chocolates and a bowl of chips cost us 15 euros - rip off. I wasn't impressed by the artists' work on sale, at all an the square is now filled with restaurants so the artists are just around the perimeter.Give it a miss
Tourist friendly and lively. Probably the best neighborhood if you're looking to live like a local instead of a tourist. 24/7 sandwich shops and international restaurants.

Beware of Pick Pockets. Had my cell phone lifted from a jacket pocket within about 5 minutes of getting off the Abbesses metro at the entrance to the Montmartre Funicular - so the rest of my visit enthusiasm was somewhat diminished. It was also rainy and cold during our trip - am sure most people have had a more pleasant experience.
very nice view, historical!. nice view, around some cafe shops touristic local shops parfuem not famous, the best france qualities

Quaint and hilly.. Village life and scenery is the best way to describe Montmartre. You will love a day here to explore the alley ways and the highest point in Paris. This is also the home of Moulin Rouge.

A Little Crazy and Very Special. Montmartre is a little crazy, beautiful and special. The perfect place to go for a fabulous meal and people watching. I first went to a Mere Catherine, a wonderful restaurant with with my mother 35 years ago and have been going with my husband for the past 20 years. The restaurant has been around since the 18th century, a fun experience! Artists and their work and tourists are everywhere. A small vineyard is just down the hill. A wonderful and special place to spend an afternoon.
Take a walking tour. We took a walking tour of the area and were not disappointed. This quirky area has tons of history and having a tour guide brought some of it to life. Would recommend!
week in Montmartre. Rented an apartment here for a week....love the area. Great little cafes and lots of quirky shops. Friendly people and felt really safe.
So much to do and see. I enjoyed all the art! Stopped and had breakfast in a cute little café...lots of walking up hill but it was fine...
Interesting area of Paris. Fascinating to walk in the footsteps of Toulouse in this neighbourhood. This hilly area has cobble stone roads and a lot of character.

Take the funicular up; walk down. The highest place in Paris, Montmartre provides a great view of the city, and there's no end of souvenir shops. Sure, it's one of the most touristy areas, but so what? There's the Sacre-Coeur basilica to visit, and the Place du Tertre, with its artists and cafes. Charles Aznavour sang of this place. Treat yourself to a visit, and think about the old days of "La Vie Boheme."

A trip back in time. Montmarte feels like going back in time, with it's windy cobbled streets and tiny shops, it's a welcome break from the grandour of big buildings and large streets down below. There are some lovely little cafe's and hotels situated here where you can while away time watcing the artists work, and the little square still has a market on some day's which is lovely. Worth taking some time out for a stroll.
Great atmosphere of Old Paris. Cafés, Chocolateries, Bakeries, Artisan shops, etc. Walk to Sacré-coeur and enjoy a beautiful view of Paris

Hidden gems. It is worth taking a Free Discovery guided tour (give a tip according to your pleasure, so effectively not free!) to find the more hidden parts of Montmartre and learn the history (and debunk the myths)

A bit seedy be cautious with kids. We went with the kids to Moulin Rouge, which is in this area. The area looks lovely from far - esp that beautiful cathedral on the hill. However, inside there are quite a number of porn shops and there's a definite red light district flavor to it. The taxis are prone to rip tourists off too. My recommendation is to do a tour in a group rather and if you're going to moulin rouge, like we did, take a taxi. The hotel recommended it and I'm glad for that advice.

Very tourist centred with loads of street artists but still lovely. It fells like a little step back in time - cafe culture all around, artists touting for trade. Cobbled streets and a wide range of eateries to choose from. Lovely.
Le quartier artistique. A place to visit when in Paris, where all artists gather. A train ride was nice in the area, yet a bit too noisy

Secret Food Tour of Montmartre. Stroll through small cheese, butcher, pastry and more. Then relax in a little cafe and have our charming young guide tell us all about the food and area as we eat and drink 5 cheeses, pates, hams, the wines macaroons, crepes. It was food too an all new level.
nice place to visit. easy to reach this area , many shops and restaurants , the place is very nice , you can relax there and have a good round in the area

where the parisians live. if you like to walk the neighborhoods, mingle with locals, shop eat this is the area. Moulon Rouge is located here, many historic artists began here so there is a lot of history also but it's also bustling with locals. very colorful. sidewalk bistros everywhere, narrow winding streets leading up the the cathedral, or stairs and even a fununcular (sp). two permanent merry go rounds, small parks etc. loved it!

a Must for artists, don't forget to go to the Sacre' Cour. an experience never to forget.. just abouve the Moulin rouge' district there are stairs or escalators , or enter by the Moulin Rouge........ ( another place to visit when in Paris ) and walk by the many painters and artist performing.. so vivid are the colours and so life like.. we had a great time watching the Artists at work and displaying their work.... p.s. Top Tip some of the cheapest places to eat by the Moulin rouge area... and wine shops !

Absolutely Fabulous. My first time in Paris and I was been only 4 days, but I was been twice in Montmartre. I am feel when I am at the beginning of the twentieth century, during the Belle Époque,, artist, spirit, amazing. Many pleasant cafes and restaurants.

Take your time with this visit!. Enjoy climbing the stairs all the way for the views of Paris. Allow time to sit at a cafe and shop up on top and have your portrait painted by one of the many artists that will offer. Tons of souvenir shops in this area as well.

artists at work. If you want a drawing or painting from yourselve or a relative present, you can let one made here, its in all kinds of ways those artists made those, so look around admirer them and maybe let one make a painting from you.... (not cheap but quick and good)

A Highlight of Any Visit to Paris. Not only do you have the Basilica but you have the history of famous artists all around you. There is still an active artist colony and the square is a gathering place for not only caricaturists but more accomplished artists. A great place to purchase a remembrance of your trip to Paris.

A Must See. Definitely Old Paris with winding cobblestone streets. To truly appreciate the area you should walk the 200 steps to the Sacre and view Paris. There are many cafes and shops, but the beauty of the area is its Old World character.
Beautiful. Very nice area, make sure to walk around the streets there is more to see than the views of Paris and the Church , some beautiful little streets , some nice restaurants and quirky shops.
Fun area. This is a great area for walking. There are lots of street vendors and it has a lively atmosphere. Prices are a bit less expensive, too.
Really worth coming back again. In spite of all the tourists, Montmarte is really worth it. you can stick to the main areas or wander in the side streets at the back and enjoy some quiet moments.

Great painters/artists!. You can original paintings this place and take away with you as unique Paris souvenir. I payed one experiences artist to paint me and this is the most memorable unique souvenir that I got from Paris trip!

Worth every minute.... We stayed in Montmartre 4 years ago and only went for the day this past weekend. But even though we only spent a few hours there, we enjoyed every second. This area has a unique old charm about it with so many quaint little restaurants, cafes and shops. This is one of my favorite Arrondissement in all of Paris!

highlight of Paris Trip. Hopped on the Metro and emerged outside of Montmarte, we climbed to the Sacre Couer basilica, then up the 300 steps to the top of the basilica. The views are stunning! A worthwhile stop on your next visit to Paris. Afterward, we stopped at a corner bar for wine, meats and cheese! Perfect!

Charming!. We took the morning to walk up the "hill". Nice stop for pastry and coffee on the way. The church at the top was amazing and so was the museum church at the top. Great views from the top and leisurely stroll down. We had a great crepe at the top but prices are tourist traps. $5.00 for a small bottle of water??? I would recommend the visit!

Food Tour. There is so much to see and do in Montmartre, I recommend starting with a good food tour. You'll see the most beautiful fruit stands and artisanal bread and cheeses which will give you energy to climb the stairs to Sacre Cour. Wear good walking shoes, as you should anyway in Paris, because the cobblestones are everywhere.

Seeing Paris as it once might have been. We took a long walk through the quarter. We began with the Marche (Market) St. Pierre, which has many fabric stores and even yarn stores. Then we continued toward the Sacre Coeur, where we took the funicular up the hill. The view from there is of course amazing. Then we walked around the quarter, with its narrow streets art galleries and its quaint vineyard.

Free walking tours in Montmartre!. My husband and I took one of the free walking tours Montmartre and it was absolutely fabulous! All the tour guides of the company are true Parisians who guide you true the city with passionated facts from history, local gossip and private thoughts. We loved our Montmartre. The tour guide spoke perfect English, had very interesting remarks on the different landmarks and minor personal favorites in the area. This is a tour that takes you way beyond google facts and dusty books. I truly recommend everyone to take this tour, it gave me a whole new appreciation of the Montmartre area!

Interesting part of Paris. We walked from the Marais to Montmartre which took us through some different neighborhoods than one usually sees while visiting tourist attractions. Still not sure if that was a good idea but it was an adventure. The fun part of this was arriving at Sacre Coeur from behind the Basilica without another soul to be found. Once we walked around the building, we found the tourists. Definitely worth the visit for the amazing views. The square located around the corner from Sacre Coeur was fun and festive with many artists displaying their wares. We followed a walk outlined in a Rick Steve's book that took us beyond this very touristy area past the stomping grounds of Picasso & Van Gogh. We ended up having lunch at Cafe Bruant on Rue des Abbesses, where I had the largest bowl of mussels and fries (Moules & frites) I've ever seen in the garlic & olive oil. In America, you'd get half the mussels for twice the price. Since my return I've read some mixed reviews on Tripadvisor but that wasn't our experience. The food was fine and the price seemed fair. We ended our walk by Moulin Rouge. Now that's an interesting street. An Uber home to Rue Saint Martin finished up a great day.
Best area around . Spend the day taking in the sights and looking at the local artists work. Haggle for prices! See all the sights and have lunch and dinner there. Bring your walking shoes!!

Cosy but.... Cosy to walk around but you have to be there early, before too many turists arrive and all "would be artists" acost you to do you portrait.Get a good map and walk all the small streets or preferebly, do a guided tour!

The nicest area in Paris. Obviously Montmartre is my all time favorite area in Paris, from the Place de Clichy walk past the Montmartre cemetry, continue your walk through Les Abbesses street, towards the Sacré-coeur basilica and then upwards (either on foot or by cable car) to la Place du Tertre.Meanwhile you will have walked by a plethora of bars and bistrots where you can sample everyting from the basic pancakes to the more gastronomic "formules".Never mind the street vendors who will obviously try to sell you worthless trinkets, but explore this area filled with small shops, wine boutiques etc...It's a bohemian area where old meets new, tradition meets (r)evolution, art meets kitsch .....Just enjoy it.

Love the ambience!. This quaint little town is very awesome! There are several artists and great shop So! The view is also great! It is not far from Sacre Coeur. So you can see two beautiful places very close together! The artists are friendly and if you buy some art and have to travel, let them know as they will package it safely for you!

So much to see. Montmartre is more than just Sacré-Cœur and the Moulin Rouge. The narrow streets, which thread their way through historic neighborhoods, are lined with cafés and shops of all kinds. The plaques on the walls tell of the artists and writers who flourished in Montmartre. The buildings vary from seedy to superlative. It's a wonderful mixture.

Very touristic. Probably been here 3 times already and this one was the last. It is very touristic and commercial. The city view from the top is a view of a lot of buildings and not a good scene. The park around is pleasant.

Best area of Paris. Full of tiny streets and little shops it's a great place for coffee and strolling. Don't miss out on visiting the area after you've been to Sacre Cœur - it's got a great 'buzzy' vibe and it's lovely to see art is still being made there.

Must visit & you get to see all what Paris has to offer. Obviously you'll be impressed by the basilica (Sacré Coeur).The little streets, albeit very touristy, are charming with the little shops and restaurants in the church's neighbourhood. Further down (esp when you head towards Pigalle), you enjoy Paris' diversity with many shops, bistros, little parks, avenues, the famous or less inspiring cabarets and so on.No matter, what you are looking for, you might find it here.

So much to do!. Although a small area, you can easily spend an entire day near Sacre Couer. Visit the Basilica and sit on the steps outside and listen to local musicians while enjoying a wonderful view of the city below. There is a small train for the kids to ride and dozens of restaurants and shops are right around the corner. You can also walk around and watch different artists as they paint scenes of various sites in Paris.

A beattiful part of Paris. A must see the buildings are stunning the cafe's all around the square are very traditional with amazing cakes. The artists are very talented and I picked up 2 beautiful paintings. There are lots of touristy shops as you move out of the square but even they remain traditionally french

The dream of Paris is this neighborhood. We took the lift up the hill and then we meandered down. Lovely and historic neighborhoods. Small squares appear at random and we imagined Picasso sitting there in the evening with wine and engaged in conversation. If you are lucky you can lose your way and discover the small streets and their inhabitants. Look for the plaques noting where writers and artists once lived. Didn't realize Van Gogh lived briefly in Paris. At the foot of the hill we skipped the theatre and stores and enjoyed our recent memories.
Favourite part of Paris. A must when visiting Paris, especially in the evening! The artists, the food, the wine, the music...AMAZING!

What a pity. My fond memories of strolling Montmarte and watching artists are only distant memories now. The crowds were massive, and you couldn't really stop to watch the "artists". Sadly, most of the art I saw was completed, not a work in progress, and looked to be rubber stamped or mass produced. I came to Paris planning to buy a painting but I couldn't find anything at all.
Artists and the real Paris. This neighbourhood is very representative of the real Paris with its wonderful artists and enticing architecture !

The Place To Be. Okay, so it is full of tourist but I had a great time once I figured out where the locals hung out..don't waste your time at the strip clubs, they are super shady. But take a stroll down the smaller streets and be pleasantly surprised with the cool bars and cafes you find!

Art... Love... Wine!. woah!.. you can't go to Paris and miss this Spot. one of the oldest places in Paris.. with the True Parisian Feeling!! Art..painters everywher ein this square! the Salvador dali museum steps away.. wine! food! ,,,woah!! 10/10!!

Overtaken by cafes. We visited this area over 25 years ago and it has changed, the central square used to be full of happy artists, yes there were Cafes then but they were around the perimeter of the square and they all specialised on mussels and chips, which were to die for, unfortunately now the cafes have taken over the whole square with just a few artists sitting around the perimeter in the squares gutter. It is now just a tourist trap with very expansive tasteless tourists food on offer, what a pity.The buildings still are beautiful and the laneways haven't changed but why did they let the cafes ruin what was such a beautiful spot, such a pity

Beautiful Area Of Paris!. This is one of the most truly beautiful areas of Paris! There is so much history here, along with absolutely amazing cafes & restaurants! If you visit Paris, definitely place a visit to Montmartre. You will not regret it!
Intriguing area to walk around. Quite an eclectic blend of stores, historic building and people. You can discover a new experience on every block.

Visit to the Artistic Quarter. Montmartre is a lively area, which overlooks much of Paris and affords gorgeous views. It is known as the artists quarter, and you can watch artists at work, or have someone do your caricature as well. Plenty of dining opportunities are available and it's a great spot to people watch and take in the fun atmosphere!

Beautiful view !. Nice walking in the streets. A lot of people, nice cafés,a lot of souvenirs shops. Up next to cathedral we can enjoy a really nice view on Paris. It was worth of visiting . Unforgettable experience!

Lovely place. Lovely place but if you have problems with walking, there are alot of (really a lot, everywhere!) steps. In a high season it must be very touristy and overcrowded, but in a middle season, in a rainy day, it was OK, full of atmosphere. And wonderful views to Paris.

Favorite part of our trip. This is a quaint little area with rolling hills and lots of artists. You have to be able to walk hills to enjoy this area, not for those with mobility issues. The area is full of history and little shops of local artisans.

Quaint, artsy area. We met a friend for lunch in a nice cafe in Montmarte. Our first time here--painters and sketch artists everywhere. Lots of pedestrians browsing the local shops and sitting in the cafes. It was beautiful weather which made walking around the tiny cobbled streets that much more enjoyable. Nice day out.

Wander Thru a Bohemian Wonder of Old!. Montmartre has much amusing and unique history in its past. Today, the city of Paris has worked hard to clean up the questionable elements and emphasize the special things. Do take a wander thru, get your picture sketched by one of the neighborhood's many artist, and sample some wine in the open air restaurants.

Spend at least 3-4 hours in Montmartre - and enjoy!. If you're not on an organized tour you should plan 3-4 hours for Montmartre. It is key to stroll around, sip a drink in one of the bars or restaurants while watching people and the real life in Montmartre, walk up and down the stairs, buy a painting or get yourself painted or buy whatever real art. You'll never regret bringing something home. This is the place where you'll find the real nice things (and skip all of the souvenir shops).

Be prepared for crowds. Very colourful and crowded. Many local artists willing to draw your picture. Many restaurants to choose from but like it said, it will be busy. Did not go in the evening so I can not comment on this. Very enjoyable and also lots of shops

Charming & Yet Crowded. As the temporary home of so many famous artists and the Sacre Coeur you can not come to Paris without seeing Montmartre. The streets are charming and Sacre Coeur inspirational. However, I'm very happy we are not staying in the area because of the crowds. We visited in May and were stunned at how difficult it was to move around the church and squares. It's worth a visit but I would think twice before staying in the neighborhood unless you enjoy meeting a lot of people.
Great for strolling and lunch. Great spot on a nice day! Try to get a table off the beaten path to avoid crowds.Line up to get in Sacre Couer was long so we didnt go in this time( increased security)
fabtastic. great vibes in this area of the city. bit of a treck up there at the end of each day but so worth it for the food, life, and atmosphere
wonderful. a very coasy area with great restaurants and cool shops. surprisingly friendly people and lots of little cafes and bistros where people sit outside
super place. on the hill top, it is a beautiful location and you will enjoy walking to get there. you may find lot of people sketching and it is awesome experience

Great district, fun food and shopping but beware. Fun little shopping district and historic area, leads up to Sacre Couer. Beware of the "gamers," those in the street enticing you to play the shell game or other such games. It seems innocent, but I watched for a while and they have a team of "bystanders" that will egg you on and even change the shell placement with their feet when you take your eyes off of it. Instead of picking your pockets, you are complicit in their ability to take money out of your wallet.

Artistic centre of Paris. I like Montmartre very much. It is the artistic centre of Paris. The sights are interesting, including Sacre-Coure, one of the great churches of Paris. You will usually see artists painting "en plein air," that is, outdoors. You may be able to buy a painting, they are often on sale. You can often get a good meal at a moderate price, restaurants abound.
Lovely views!. Great views of Paris and a nice place to walk around and people watch. I would not recommend walking around here at night as it is sketchy.
Full of life!. So much life and fun there! A great way to experience the true french culture, while tourists can also be touristy.

Loved it . I loved visiting here. Yes there are crowds. It's busy and there are a few hustlers selling rubbish or trying to scam you but don't at all let this put you off just push past and ignore them. It's vibrant and interesting. Take time to wander through the many rustic streets. Look at the places where Picasso or Van Gough lived and worked. Go to a vantage point and take a pic of Paris or the Eiffel Tower in the distance. Make sure you don't miss Montmartre.
Best district in Paris. Loved the very arty and laid back atmosphere........The abundance of restaurants, bars, cafes, bakeries and really the general atmosphere...Love Lovel Love!

Still very much a village feel. As long as you are ok with steep narrow and often cobbled streets, as well as long flights of steps, Montmartre is steeped in art history as well as the famous Sacre Coeur perched at the top of the Butte de Montmartre. With plenty of cafes and restaurants you can idle a day away quite easily maybe even fitting in a visit to the Musee de Montmartre which anyone interested in French Impressionism will not want to leave.The streets are crammed with tourist shops and artists, but if this is not your thing they are easy to ignore.

A place u should visit. Monylartre , its where u can feel the old Paris , sacree coeur church , many resturants , artist , cafe , so nice for walking , stairs up and down ... its one of the places u must see in paris ..;u will love it
virbrant. too many pickpockets in this area, some interesting antique shops ,boheme charm, many sex shops in place pigalle :)

Paris Montmarte. When visitig Paris do not miss Montmarte - it is a must see.
Very romantic walks , life on streets with a bistros and night life.
Must see

Fascinating mix of real life and tourist tat. Walking around you mix with Parisiennes shopping from some fantastic small food shops, bakeries, fishmongers etc whilst there are dozens of tourist shops selling berets, tea towels and fluorescent Eiffel Towers

Always a Great Place To Explore. Montmartre is always a great place to wander around or sit in a cafe. The neighborhood has a rich character all its own. It's easy to get to via the Anvers Metro stop and a funicular (or a long flight of steps).
cute. such a cute neighborhood. I wished I had visited on any day but Sunday (most everything was closed), as it would have been fun wandering in and out of all the little stores.

Very scenic neghbourhood!. You ll find yourself in a place that looks like old Paris!Very scenic streets and houses!You ll find numerous bistros and small restaurants for brunch or dinner in Place des Tertres. Around there are everywere local artists that can either draw you in seconds or sell you some of their paintings! Very nice place to spend a Sunday! Don't miss the Espace Dali where the famous artist lived and now is a museum with his famous paintings!

Had a lovely wander . Came to the area in the early morning.Wandered through the cobbled streets, soaking in the sights before the crowds came in. And when they did, the square came to life with festivities, trinkets and art pieces you could buy off local artists.

Colourful and vibey place!. We loved exploring the cathedral and the surrounding areas - great colour and vibe! Visit during the day and at night for two completely different experiences and loads of great photographs. The Dali museum is in the nearby village too ... explore all around. It's charming modern and old Paris at it's best.

Vibrant area, great way to spend a day. . This is full of touristy shops and bars. Souvenirs are fun rather than high end, but good to browse through especially in the evenings or a Sunday if other shops are closed. Watch your wallets, but this is not a dangerous area

City On a Hill Beautiful View. This is worth the trip this city on a hill is amazing. The view from the Sacred Heart Cathedral. You have an option to walk up the steps to the cathedral or take a tram to the top. The city has amazing alleys and you can walk to the Moulin Rouge.

Montmartre is very captivating.... There are so many free-lance artists around, the art and souvenir shops are abundant... nice cafes, etc. Just do not succumb to getting your caricature drawn because it costs a lot of money... but folks have to make a living in what they do well...
The creative area. I came here to see the cafe and some scenes in the movie"Le Fabuleux Destin d'Amélie Poulain", but it's totally more than that!
Artsy Place du Tertre. It sets an artsy-classy tone to your otherwise plain and touristy visit to Paris. Start your trek from Clichy up to Montmartre to feel a different vibe.

Crowded. It's a lovely place to visit early in the morning or very late at night, as crowds tend to be lesser than in the middle of the day. Montmartre is like a little village with little roads to discover on a sunny day, you'll find painters and artists displaying their work in the middle of the place just 10 minutes away from the Sacré Coeur cathedral. The painting souvenirs-like boutiques are filled with cheap and often imported paintings. If you're looking for something more authentic, buy a smaller painting from a real artist just a couple of minutes away from those shops and help them make a living from their passion. Families with babies and strollers, take into account that the village is on a steepy hill, yet manageable, there's a good load of stairs. Don't fall into tourist traps like the games that are presented to you (Asking you to tie a thread around your finger, making you sign a fake petition, etc.) This applied everywhere around Paris.

Typical of Paris. If you want to see what Paris really looks like, you must go to Montmartre!You'll find one of the most beautiful spot to see the whole city.Moreover there are lots of restaurants and a very good atmosphere. Sometimes some singers are present to entertain tourists and people.Also, in Place du Tertre, you'll have lots of painters and it's very pleasant.You'll also get the chance to visit the Basilica which is splendid.Something not to miss for your tripto Paris.
Heart of Paris. Montmartre with its cafes, artists, squares and many other is the beautiest and the most characteristic part of Paris. Just love it!
Best district in Paris IMHO. Loved walking the streets and sampling the bakeries and cafes. So many surprises and a bit of French Revolution history thrown in for free.

Very touristy. I think it is a must see because of all the artist that sit around and do their painting but take it for what it is. It is very crowded and over priced if you plan on eating or having a beverage at the market.

very thick historical culture. Montmartre is one of my favorite places to visit while in Paris. Lots of art, lots of restaurants and walking distance to Sacre-Coeur. Beautiful building and houses around. its very european.
