Commercialised trap. Visited on a cold wet day in April so rehabs not the best time. There are now many more artists trying to sell their work than I remember from my last visit (admittedly a long time ago). Still interesting but felt I couldn't stop to see the art unless I was going to buy.

A great place to stay. We stayed next to the Moulin Rouge in Montmatre plenty of hustle and bustle ample places to eat , visit the Sacre-Coeur or visit the moulin Rouge for a show.the area is served by Blanche and place de clitchy metro stations.
Nice area to viset. A nice neighborhood to walk through. Lots of artists out with their easels and canvases painting away.
A Must see. The best thing to do in Paris. romantic, beautiful, although a little crowded. Even the touristic restaurants are better than in other areas.

The View of Paris. From Sacre Coure you can see all of Paris. If you are North of the river it is a must for me.There are a lot of overpriced cafes and bistros about but just soldier on past them and the streets lined with tourist tat and you will be pleased you did. IT is a bit Disney in parts but has to be seen. Perhaps take a picnic and make the most of the lovely park.

It's A Must To Visit. What a fabulous place this is. The varying culture and interesting things to see are truly amazing.There are some fabulous restaurants to visit selling a wide variety of food.The square with all its artists working and selling their pictures is great.You can sit in a cafe for hours just watching the world go by.This place is a must to visit if you are in Paris.

Great Atmosphere. Great place to visit on a Sunday, but quiet a walk from the centre of Paris, so best get a cab or metro. Cathedral is lovely, but so many people disrespecting the signs stating no photos. Please support the church and buy the pics from the souvenir shop!. Lots of artists around the square asking to draw your picture, beware some are expensive. Some great art on show, but be warned some may not be from the artist selling it and there are reports that some are from China. Lovely cafes near by to sit and watch the world go by. Definitely a great place to visit if your in Paris.

Got Kicked out of a Bookstore by Angry French Lady. You'd think by the title of my review that this would be a negative, but not in Monmartre. The bookstore is some antique French book shop which sells only French books. I was walking around and taking pictures, picking things up gently and putting them down when the devil herself sneered at me. She demanded to know "do you want to purchase something?" I said, I was just browsing and then she proceeded to push, literally shove me out of the shop. And just then I thought after all the nice people I'd met, including a shop owner just on the next street who gave me free batteries for my camera, this was the REAL RUDE PARIS I'd wanted to experience and I'd got it. I got a similar vibe from this woman on the Champs D'Elysseys who was manning the movie theater ticket booth, but she didn't have a chance to rise to new levels of rudeness. Anyway, Monmartre . . . it's that place where Amelie's cafe is. There are cobblestone streets, a beautiful church and a sweeping view of Paris. It is the must-walk-through place in Paris. Even Moulin Rouge is nearby. Walk to it, enjoy.
Artistic Paris . The high point in Paris. Right next to the church with a great common area surrounded by artists Paris on steroids.
Take the Montmartre sighseeing train!. The area is interesting as the Moulin Rouge is there and was the inspiration for Toulouse Lautrek's can-can paintings. Worth a quick visit.

Friendly Place. Went to Paris recently after 32 years - 2nd ish honeymoon and not at all as I remembered. The Parisians were friendly and helpful ( especially on the Metro) and the restaurants we visited were invariably welcoming
I wont leave it for another 32 years before I return !
Montmartre was bustling and slightly hectic but well worth the visit

My sister lives there!. I would love to live in this neighbourhood... The best of art, food and people. In this neighbourhood you feel like there's something involving your heart all the time you stay there...worth the visit!

Paris Perfect. Just walk and when you're done - walk again, get lost, best place in Paris to do this. It can be a little frustrating trying to avoid the tourist traps, but hey just remember you are a tourist and enjoy. Great view of Paris from on top of the Butte.

Just make sure you like to walk. Home of Sacre Couer, the square filled with artists plying their wares,and various museums and shops. We spent the better part of a day there and were sorry when it was time to leave. Feel free to bargain with the artists, but don't insult them by taking pictures of their art if you aren't buying.

Italian food . If you ever go to Montmartre, Paris, have a dinner at Cucina Tentazioni Italiana in 26, rue Tholoze. Tel 01 53 28 45 20. The friendly Sicilian family Leopardi, who are the owners, gave us a very good service and delicious Sicilian, homemade food for a reasonable price. Bon apetit!

Thierry's tour is tops!. Opted to take a walking tour of Montmartre with tour guide Thierry. He was wonderful and for four fun filled hours showed us all the sights. Although it was a very crowded Sunday afternoon. the guide led us from place to place with no problems. Having done Montmartre on my own many time I would highly recommend an organized tour for any first time visitors. Experience really does count.

Picturesque part of Paris!. I loved the streets of Montmartre, so picturesque, just what you would expect from Paris. Although it is quite tourist oriented, you can still enjoy lovely buildings and charming streets. Only thing I found extremely irritating is a ton of street artists offering to make a portrait of you. It is impossible to enjoy a coffee and croissant without someone interupting you every 5 minutes. Also, prices in the caffes and restaurants are quite high but it is understandable since it is a tourist attraction.
My Favourite part of Paris. A trip to Paris wouldn't be complete without a stop off in Montmarte! This is where you can get your portrait painted or enjoy a coffee in the famous piazza.

Romantic little streets of Paris. Climb high to the hill where the Basilica is located and go exploring lovely streets of Montmartre. They are stunning! Check out the street where La Maison Rose is located. Also don't forget the love wall: Le mur des je t'aime.

Montmartre. Montmartre is a great area to visit; it is full of lively painters and restaurants. The architecture is gorgeous with intricate details. Not the safest area, though, but the perfect spot to spend a day in!
Genuinely Parisian art festival on a daily basis. Hundreds of local artists show there wears. Be sure to walk around and see the side streets too. Local feel fun day

Perfection. My husband and I spent an incredible week in Paris, based out of a charming little apartment in Montmartre just steps away from the gorgeous Sacré Cœur Basilica. Trip of a lifetime. We will definitely be staying in Montmartre on our next visit as well!

Very nice but scary too. This is a hugely popular attraction that has a lot of street vendors and con-artists. Watch your back, your bag, and your safety. the souvenirs here are the cheapest, but it is a very scary area.
art district. Painters everywhere, amazing atmospt here, and the place to get a portrait done. stroll around and enjoy paris at its fullest

Very nice. We had a wonderful day and a extra bit attached my wife was pick-pocketed. The streets were exciting the church was fantastic the police station was not meant to be on the list of things to do but got to do that as well.If you go be very careful the criminals there are very good they have look outs everywhere and good luckWorth the visit if you don't lose your money.

You have to go to this area to see a different side of Paris from all of the touristy sights.. On a tip from a friend, we went and spent the day up on this high hill with a cathedral on it. It is free and open to the public. We are not Catholic, but took the opportunity to pray and give thanks for our blessings on our first trip to Europe. We walked down the hill and found shops and a market area that was buzzing. We had wine and i was sketched by a local artist, there are many there. It was my 50th birthday and an extremely memorable event. I purchased chocolates and cookies to bring back for friends and families. There are lots of places to shop, eat and hang out. Beautiful and I highly recommend you go!

Watch your walet. This was not the romantic bohemian, artsy district of 40 years ago. It is crowded, overpriced and smarmy. The area is filled with pickpockets and souvenir peddlers. The restaurants are expensive. It is too bad that you have to travel through this undesirable village to get to Sacre-Coeur Basilica.

The most vibrant area of Paris. I love this area - it reminds me of my own Notting Hill with its huge mixture of cross-sections of society and includes everything from the sacred (sacre coeur) at the top, to the profane (try the erotic museum) at the bottom. There's always a buzz about the place and if you like a bit of an atmosphere, this is the place I recommend to base yourself when staying in Paris. Just watch out for the hills!

Must do!. This is where I feel most at home in Paris. I love the vibe and the history behind this area. However, it was absolutely teaming with tourists (like moi!) and I'd been well warned to be super vigilant re pick-pockets.Thankfuuly, I enjoyed a wonderful afternoon there sitting in the sunshine on the steps of the Sacre Coeur after a prayer inside, just watching all over Paris. Local restaurants were in abundance and most reasonably priced.
Full of life!!!!. Τhe place is full of life !!! Paris as it was and still is !!! Lovely with sunshine !!! Shops everywhere, world, artists, small streets, picturesque! You can not miss !!!
Great place to stay. Montmartre is a wonderful location to stay in. Taxis to the sites are only about 7€ . Up here you have lovely restaurants and shops too. It is quaint, old and beautiful.
Be Wary of Paintings. Evidently the are several "artists" who use paintings done in China by art students and sit pretending to paint...this was recently exposed by French jounalists!!
Pretty. Pretty place, where you get to see the whole town. At the church you can pay some money to get up on a viewpoint.
A tourist trap set in a lovely area. Excellent views of the city but, unfortunately, so many trinket vendors make the experience less than optimal.

Lively atmosphere.. This was my favourite place during short visit to Paris. It felt 'very french'! You can get a cable car up to the cathedral or if you prefer you can walk up the many steps. Best to get the car up and walk down. At the top there is a magnificant view of Paris. Good for taking photographs.Sketch artists are walking all round the main square but if you want a sketch of yourself you need to haggle before agreeing. There are quaint shops and stalls selling various tourist goods and ceramics. Lots of cafes and eateries. Very busy square but well worth a visit.

Entire area surrounding Montmarte is amazing. This is next to Sacre Coeur cathedral. You can take metro to Abesses station (ignore minor spelling error). It's a short climb from there. The streets are full of artists of all kinds - amazing painters, musicians, living statues, etc. There are some good shops to buy souvenirs and some very good cafes as well. We loved walking on the narrow beautiful streets in the locality.

Great area to wander around. It's a great area to just wander around and people watch, lots of history, cafes/restaurants, and of course the very impressive Sacre Coeur.We actually stayed in Montmartre for our Paris visit just a few mins down the hill on the far side of Sacre Coeur. It was great and had a nice quiet neighbourhood feel, lots of restaurants (in Montmartre) to choose from in the evening. I would probably stay a little more central and closer to the Seine if we visit Paris again, just to make going for a jog or early morning/evening stroll along the river easier, and being more central to the major sites etc.

Highly suggest staying in this neighborhood. We were in Paris for one week and decided based on suggestions to stay in Montmartre. There are many places to eat, cafes, bakeries, meat and cheese shops etc.
Love tha area. I love walking around montmartre.Nice views can be seen of paris.Went to the artists square to see the original creations the artists have made. Bit busy but all light hearted fun.

A perfect day out. Montmartre is an almost must visit of all neighbourhoods in Paris and one of the best way to do is to get lost in it. Either that, or get lost with a guide. There's plenty of walking tours in Paris and all of them would have offered a walking tour of Montmartre. It's a great way to spend the day.Start your day with a hearty breakfast at Le Grenier à Pain. Located just at the foot of Montmartre, this French bakery has won countless awards including the right to supply bread to the French president! It’s definitely one of the best baguette I had in Paris (very likely due to the “award” effect). Look at that ham baguette. I’m just wetting the floor yearning for this.Secret steps up and down Montmartre, to me one of the most charming way to explore Montmartre. Even random streets look so pretty on Montmartre. One of them is Rue du Calvaire and from below it leads you straight to the main square near Sacré-Coeur, the Place du Tertre.Montmartre grew around this village square and today is surrounded with restaurants and cafes. Sitting in one of the cafes, you can watch as artists, painters, even musicians tend to the flock of tourists that visit this square.In the early 1900s, Montmartre was a magnet for what we would today consider the best artists of the 20th century. Monet, van Gogh, Picasso all lived in this hill overlooking Paris. These masters of impressionist art found inspiration here. If you venture on the the top on Place du Tertre, you can still artists gather, selling their paintings and offering to put you in one of the masterpieces you can take home as a souvenir.Just around the corner from Place du Tertre you can find a gallery dedicated to the art of Salvadore Dalí. Before you step inside, soak in the view of the city. It’s a quiet corner.The “crown” of Montmartre, the Sacred Heart of Jesus, aka Sacré-Cœur. Compared to many other basilicas, this one is pretty new as it was completed only about 100 years ago. The square outside offers perhaps the best panoramic view of the city of Paris.On a cooler winter’s day and blessed with a blue clear sky, I sat myself down on the steps of the Sacré-Cœur and try my hardest to inch this view into my memory. The sound of a harp playing nearby, the bustle of people up and down the steps, the cool breeze of the wind, it’s just perfect.

Great place to visit in Paris.. Located on a hillside in Paris this area offers nice views over the city. But the main attraction is the artists located in the square You can get your portrait sketched for as little as 8 Euros. Stroll around and look at the art work or have a bite to eat at one of the restaurants. A must stop while in Paris. The best way to get there is on the Metro. Take the green line to Abbesses and follow the signs from there.

A visit to see the church and the city is worth it on a clear day! Far too many gypsies, etc.. If it is a clear day, GO! My friend and I went alone and would have been better off going with a guided tour. On a clear day you can see forever!

Great views. Windmills. We walked up the hill to Montmartre and stopped in a little park. We found the windmills on our walk and met people who were so disappointed because they hadn't found them. Walked down and had great crepes at a little creperie just under the beautiful church.

Incredible views. Montmatre is a romantic, artistic area that we fell in love with! You'll see painters in the square while you sip cocktails at the outdoor cafes. The food & shops are wonderful. We stayed in Montmatre & took the Metro all throughout the city. It is very accessible, especially with a smart phone. The views from Sacre Couer are incredible. You can see the whole city.Beware that there are many steep streets & stairways. Also, our only negative was that dog owners do not clean up after their pets! It was unbelievable in such a lovely city, that you must be aware of poop on the streets.

Lots of little shop and excellent cafes. We wandered round the streets in the early evening in and out of the souvenir shops. There are plenty of cafes with a la carte menus and fixed piece meals all of them vying for trade. Consequently we found this one of the cheapest places to eat.
Great area. I love this area of Paris. Just go and enjoy! No other advice just go. Great for half a day or even a full one. I hope this helps
Most romantic place un paris. One of the best and most romantic place in paris is montmarte just grab the hand of your beloved one and walk down the street ...........

An interesting neighborhood in Paris. Montmartre has lots to offer for the visitor to Paris. The Sacre Coeur Cathedral is beautiful and offers a panoramic view of the city. Behind the cathedral is the location for artis and cafes, a very colorful scene. At the bottom of the steps to Sacre Coeur are a number of nice shops, like Fragonard, in addition to the ones that carry typical touristy items. I would advise taking a taxi here from most Paris locations as it's a very steep upward incline if you tried to walk.

A village within a city. We decided to stay in montmartre on our recent visit to Paris and only ventured out of this area once in the 4 days we were there because there was that much to do hereThere were hundreds of bars and restaurants along with speciality shops and all the people here are so friendly. We tried to speak French when there very badly I may add but because we were seen to be trying the locals helped us as if we were part of the furnitureThere are a lot of the major tourist attractions near here ie sacre couer , moulin rouge and all within walking distanceIf travelling here whilst in Paris go on a Sunday as the whole area is buzzing. All the locals were out, there were street markets, fun fares , antique sales. And loads moreIf I return to Paris this is where I'll be staying

Artsy,touristy, but an absolute must!. Very very touristy. But hey what's wrong in it if you are a tourist here! I loved the feel of the place, the whole 'atmosphere' of this area is very different. Street art, painters on the roadside displaying their paintings, eateries for casual dining, jugglers and musicians all add spice to the place. Ideally a place to spend a day as Sacre Couvre is right in the heart of this area. Just watch out for typical touristy traps in this area, the beggars and the pickpockets etc.

Wonderfully romantic - even for the French!. Having lived in France for 25 years, I still never miss an opportunity to visit Montmartre. The Place du Tertre is always full of tourists, but it's a fabulous place to stop and watch, drink a white wine or eat an onion soup. The level of artwork is questionable, but it will still make you think of "An American in Paris"! At the bottom of the hill, you can visit the fabric stores - a crafytsperson's dream! Highly recommended.

Worth the trip. As always we walked to Montmartre, some 5 KM from hotel, but worth the long walk and lot's of things to see on the way, and for sure lots to see in Montmartre. Besides the church and dome, we also visited the museums and enjoyed a nice lunch as well. You can easily spend 3-5 hours there.
Artistic Monmartre. Definitely worth the visit. Very artistic and colorful.Find your way to Sacre Coeur to get magnificent views to Paris.

Artists and original art. There is a long climb up the stairs to Montmatre. If walking is difficult, there is an elevator available. You must purchase a ticket to ride, however. There are many different vendors, restaurants and shops. Of course, walking through the plaza with all the artists creating is so interesting. Pick an artist to draw your portrait for a very special memory of Paris. The view of the city and touring the cathedral is breathtaking. Montmatre is different than any other section of Paris. Don't miss it.

The best of both worlds. Sacre Coure Church and souvenir shopping are located in Montmartre. There is too much going on in the area so be careful with pickpockets. But do not be dissuaded because it is worth it.

Take a guided tour. We took a guided tour offered by Viator. Our guide was excellent and pointed out some of the key spots and history of Montmartre. We started at Moulin Rouge and worked our way up to the cathedral at the summit. Our guide had very good knowledge of the history of the area and pointed out where Van Gogh and other famous people had lived. The cathedral site is very crowded but offers a good view of the city. Avoid the area directly below the church on the east side as it is very touristy.

Fun place to see artists at work. We had a lovely time at Montmartre. It's a great place to look out over Paris, see Sacre Coeur and watch local artists draw and paint. It is bustling and filled with people. Watch your wallet :)

Interesting . Interesting area, I enjoyed walking around. However the restaurants are a bit annoying. they hunt you down but then couldn't be bothered to take your order. We went in one of them but left after 5 minutes but noone even noticed it.

Too commercial. This place was packed! We found it extremely commercial, with "artists" dressed like painters from the late 1800s walking around with palettes and brushes and white pants stained with paint and berets. It was a bit much. Everything around is busy with tourists and very expensive. While it was fun to see, you are just seeing shops with souvenirs and expensive coffee.
Lively quarter. Montmartre is surely worth of visit, lively quarter with a lot of litlle caffes, streets and artists painting on the street.
magnificent montmarte. Make your way here to get an hilltop view of paris .Always lots of tourists here but worth seeing despite the beggars on the church steps
Love it!. Best place to go into the small ruettes and to have cup of coffee or a glass of wine or to buy souvenirs. My favorite shop is La Boutique Des Anges

Nice neighborhood. My hotel was at Monmarte. The last night bofore i return i walked around the area. Many cafe, bistro, bakerys etc. You can enjoy food or just to walk. There are many places to eat in good prices. If I go to Paris again, i will stay in Monmartre and i move around this area becouse it is traditional and very beutifull.
Take a walking tour and then come back on your own for lunch or dinner. We took a Viator walking tour. The pretty Parisian grad student Anna was very pleasant and told us all we wanted to know.

ok now this is a dream ticked off my list. Being an artist I have longed to walk round the Montemarte market and experience the full senses of Montemarte .It didn't disappoint . I just wish I could've spent longer there. Again , I want to go back ( live there if I could ) Take time if you can slow down and breathe , smell the air , listen to the locals , watch the artists paint . If you have money they can even paint you whilst you sit . The local cafes are amazing and the bakery too. Ok I am drifting on a dream of years gone by now . Wish I was there !

Cute and worth the uphill trek. Really nice area! Touristy but worth checking out. It's the most "Parisian" area ie winding streets, cute shops, great restaurants. You have to walk up a steep hill but it's worth going up.

Montmatre if full of life. Ate here twice during our trip, Once at Lunchtime and once in the Evening. Very different feel from night to day. I love it here it is so full of life and watching the artists is quite relaxing. Be warned though their prices can be a bit steep.

Interesting neighborhood to explore. There is a Metro stop that will drop you there. BEWARE....take the large elevator up, as the walk to the street from below is approximately 10+ floors of steps. The architecture alone is worth the trip. Stroll down the Avenue of the Martyrs and discover lovely antique shops, a flea market on weekends and many unique shops. Located in the 18th, don't miss the Basilica of Sacre-Coeur
must visit neighborhood. A Metro ride away brings one to the high point in Paris and the historic home of many French artistes. Take the walking tour with Adele of City-guide.
I love it!. I love it! although there is a lot of tourists, you can feel the unique atmosphere and experience fantastic view over the city.

A Little Bohemian for my Tastes. Montmartre is as billed a touristy, artsy area. The Basilica is beautiful but the area is full of folk singers passing around a cup and artists trying to sketch you. But it offers a beautiful of Paris from high and a huge collection of shops and restaurants to choose from. With the right attitude, it is very enjoyable.

Finest view is Paris. We were travelling back from Gard du Nore and used this as a time filler between leaving and heading home it was very busy but we did pick a Sunday to go the church has a wonderful position on the top of the hill we took a few pictures of the magnificent view. We walked through the little square with lots of stalls and people asking to draw your picture surprisingly there was a Starbucks which I would never of guessed might of been there similar prices to home so we had a nice coffee and cake before making our way back down. A lady suggested that the safest metro line to use was Anvers so we walked down the long flight of steps then through a road full of shops and men doing the pea under the cup gambling game. The station was very busy and people were significantly pushing so much so we lost a member of our party who managed to get on the train but she waited for us at the next station. Definitely worth the visit but be careful of where you travel to to walk there or get home.

You love it or hate it. OK, right from the off I'll say I hate it. It's the worst kind of tourist trap with everything overpriced and constant harassment from street peddlers not to mention the notorious pickpockets. To me the only reason to go it to get to the Sacre Coure which is certainly worth a visit, but that's just me, others seem to love it. If you are in the area, take some time to walk around the Montmartre cemetery, it's on Trip Advisor, it's rather nice on a sunny day.
Atmospheric. An atmospheric place to walk around, with wonderful views. Lots of "artists" with lots of small restaurants, too. Vernicular was useful to get to the top, too. Well worth a visit.

This section of the city should not be missed!. I stayed at a wonderful boutique hotel, B Montmartre, right off the main thoroughfare that was convenient for exploring this wonderful part of Pars. The shoppes, restaurants and clubs offer something for everyone! I wish that there had been more time to explore!

Love Montmartre. Make sure you go right up the hill, stairs or funicular to see Sacre Couer and the two streets away the artisan quarter with many artists ready to sketch your profile. The start of the walk is right behind the Moulin Rouge

Nice and cheap. Great place to get food and souvenirs. There are plenty of restaurants at the top and the food is cheap. Along the way up there is plenty of souvenir shops all cheap. Easy enough to get to and is a must do to see a great view at the top.

Must-visit, but be careful not to meet bad guys !!!. Actually, this village should be visited for all foreign visitors. You can find beautiful scenes at many alleys. But, you should know this area is not safe at all. Many swindlers and pickpockets are there !

Lovely narrow streets. It's a wonderful place with beautiful little side streets. If you want to peacefully explore, I suggest avoiding the main roads where all the tourists are. Montmartre offers lots of hidden beautiful views and parks. I also suggest doing a tour (I did Culturefish! free walking tour) if you want to learn more and get the most of it. Lots of great artists lived and painted there, and the place also has a very interesting history. You never know when you might be walking through a painting... Furthermore, many artists currently paint and sell their beautiful art there for affordable prices. If you love art and would like to support them, you can get some paintings as original gifts and souvenirs.Also, the film Amélie (2001) was shot in certain locations there, and, as a fan of the film, it was interesting for me to see them live.It's definitely one of my favourite places in Paris, but I really did not like the super crowded main streets.

Simply beautiful district . I had not here before It is just breathtaking beauty and character of the areaI love it lots We took lots of pics just like everyone else who seemed to be on holiday The people are pleasant and friendly It's just one of those iconic sights and a happy place to be A must see

Tainted. With the exception of the Basilica itself the surrounding area has the feel of being run down and unsafe. A place were you have to watch your belongings if carrying haversacks etc. Though the artists abound I sensed it lacked something. Everything seemed fast paced - geared towards making money. IT did not speak to me about rest, enjoy - soak it up!

Maintains its own character and charm. Have visited several times over 30 years and have not noticed any significant change in the ambience. great views over the city from the steps, and plenty of "people watching" going on

A feel for the old Paris . Village charm especially away from the the Place de Tetre. Lovely streets around to the north and east. Musee de Montmartre well worth a visit. Oh, and so is the wonderful Sacre Coeur

A beautiful area of Paris. We had a family holiday in Paris and very much enjoyed walking around Montmatre. Not for the couch potato though, as it is it on the highest ground around Paris. It is worth walking up the hill, as the views are stunning. There is lots to see and do, with artists, fine restaurants, Sacre Coeur, the Funiclaire, galleries and gift shops. A must see on any visit to Paris. We went twice, once in the rain and once in the dry. Probably better to enjoy on a sunny day.

Get charcoaled by a local artist. We had a charcoal done of my daughter - it is one of my favorite things we brought home from our trip to Paris. You can wander around and see the artist's work before you select the one you want to do yours.

The most interesting district . Montmartre is one of the most interesting district in Paris. An incredible amount of arts or history monuments are hidden in those tiny streets in this area. I would recommend to art and history lovers to visit here with a guide.
Lovely area. Always enjoy coming here. Probably very "touristy" for some but we loved the atmosphere. Nice carousel for the kids and they enjoyed the funicular railway.
Montmarte and Sacre Couer a must see. This area which is the highest area in Paris has breath taking views of the city and beyond. The Church Sacre Couer at the top is a must see
Charming. So this is where all the cool young people live in Paris! It's fun to walk around & just see a little of the Parisian life go by.

Great atmosphere and more 'Parisian'? . Not sure if that makes sense and may be down to a lot of movies being made here but the overall feel of Montmartre is more relaxed and to a large extent more an outsiders impression of what Paris is expected to be. It's a good mix of cultures lifestyles but if walking then a tough physical challenge as some routes are stair-laden and vertical! Breathless but satisfying overall and justifies some of the great culinary delights which await on some of the streets - overall some good value cafes offering high quality with good service - easy to spend a day and still want to come back tomorrow :)

Worth a visit!. Walking through Montmarte is a worthwhile experience for the views from the top atleast. The cobbled streets are great although you will get hassled from a number of street artists wanting to do your portrait!

Buy a Paris Metro Navigo Pass to get up the hill. The view from the top of Montemarte is well worth the long climb up the hill. Better yet, take the funicular up the hill and save your legs. Normally, the funicular costs 6 euros each way. With a Paris Metro Navigo pass, it's free. If you're touring around Paris, the Metro is the fastest and cheapest way around. The Navigo is the easiest pass and least expensive. In Montmartre, the church is well worth the visit. There are far fewer painters on the square than in years past, and they are very aggressive in wanting to sketch your portrait. Avoid the restaurants on the square unless you are willing to pay top dollar for the location.

Nostalgic but a bit touristy. The older part of Paris with lots of tourist spots. We visited during the day and took advantage of the sunny weather and took a guided walk. Fabulous architecture and stunning views from Sacre Coure. The top of the hill is very touristy with lots of artists badgering you to have your picture done - nearer the Moulin Rouge had more traffic but had a better choice of cafes. The area is brilliant to walk around and each bend has its own vista. Would recommend but bring your walking shoes - lots of cobbled streets.

Steep in places.. Our hotel was in this area near the Palace de Clichy and this area had more activity than many other places in Paris. A Lot of young people and many many ethnicities. We ate in several of the cafes.

French culture as we imagine yet still living. Had a fantastic time walking around the streets and eating, going to Mass in the Basilica, looking in windows and pottering. And drinking coffee and eating in the evening. Allow two days at least.

Hop on Hop Off bus is great way to see this area. We used the hop on hop off bus to tour this area and see shopping areas, Moulin Rouge and Sacre Coeur. This is a lovely area, with lots of shops and mainstream fast food restaurants if that is what you are looking for.

Stepped into picture book Paris!. After a long climb from Anvers we arrived in the Montmatre. Welcomed by a wonderful atmosphere of French music, artists and flower sellers. Delighted to see that the original Paris still exists and thrilled to show my teenage daughter a taste of the proper Parisienne history. I feel so sorry for the Parisiennes after the wake of the terrorists attacks but delighted to see that continue to be strong and continue they way of life! Do still visit!

Brilliant Sandemanns tour here!. We thought the tour really brought this area to life away from the crazy tourist traps round Place du Tetre. You really get a feel for the artists who lived there and how their life's changed the course of art.

Great Neighborhood. We stayed in this neighbor hood for 10 day and found it to be a perfect location for all attractions. There are many great cafes, bars and resturants. There are several metro stops within the area and are easy to get to. The Sacra Cour is here and also nearby artist who will paint or draw you likeness. There are several small stores throughout the neighborhood and a larger store on the Main Street.
A tourist trap. Mobs of tourists descending on Sacre Coeur and on the main square. There is even a Starbucks on the main square. There didn't seem to be much of an authentic feel to the whole thing.
The Greenwich Village of Paris. Wonderful local neighborhood to stroll...! Lots of history with the Moulin Rouge, cemetery of Montmartre, Sacre Coeur, artists and more!

Sancerre at the moulin rouge. It's a fabulous place but very touristy, there are less artists and more cafes filling the square these days. In the square the prices are outrageous but I sat there in the sun people watching for an hour sipping my wine and it was worth every penny. It's a must for any visitor. The view from the sacre couer is a must see but there is a foul smell if the wind blows the wrong way

Interesting exciting area. This area is beautiful very arty & interesting has a lovely atmosphere - place du tetre (the artists square) is stunning but make sure u visit & buy from an 'active' artist so u know you are purchasing an original painting by the artist himself! check out 'Pavlos' his work is simply stunning & he is so interesting & you can enjoy watching him create classic scenes of beautiful Paris x

Sandemans Montmartre Tour. After the free walking tour, we signed up to the Montmartre walking Tour with our new friend, Onno. It was such a beautiful evening, so walking up the gorgeous, winding streets of Montmartre as the sun was going down was absolutely picturesque. We stopped at famous houses or taverns where artists lived or visited. We saw the only vineyard in Paris. The stories of the artists and authors was a highlight. Again, I learned so much and highly recommend this tour.

Go were the locals are. Avoid the heavy tourist spots, and go were the locals go. We did a food tour in the area which was fabulous. We of course went to Sacre Cour, which should not be missed as it is spectacular. The heavy tourist are around the basilica was one t-shirt shop after the other, but the rest of it is lovely. I highly recommend letting yourself get lost in the area.

Get their early.. Take time to get their a bit early, before the crowds, and enjoy the views and atmosphere. Nice selection of cafes to take a break from the constant barrage of artists approaching you to draw you. They seem to come in swarms!!! Still, worth having one done for 15 euros.

The real Paris. Lovely part of Paris , a visit is a must. City bus tour now has Montmartre as a new route so very easy to get there. Atmosphere is buzzing, lots of bars and restaurants to choose from but be prepared to be accosted by street artists if you sit outside - though did not spoil the visit.

Gorgeous village . Great village to get out of central Paris and explore a bit further. Great place if you're into souvenirs also. Lots of market stalls to banter with for your bits and pieces. Be sure to visit the sacred heart cathedral

BEWARE OF INCESSANT BADGERING FROM RUDE PUSHERS OF CRAP. This is so sad to see becasue this has always been a beautiful area to visit. I've been visiting here for over 20 years but yesterday while walking up from Pigalle is was disgusting. People were trying to sell us everything under the sun every step of the way. At one point on the stairs some guy grabbed my hand and tried to braid some string on my finger- I had to literally tell him to step away and don't touch me. The city should really curb this behaviour. So, do go and enjoy the church, scenary and surround neighbourhood- just beware.
Lovely . Little streets with markets, restaurant and little shops all around I really enjoyed, space Dali very neat and moulin rouge, great walk on sunny day

beautiful basilica , narrow streets. This area is a must visit while you are in paris. It has interesting streets and a beautiful saccre cour basilica you can go to. You can get down to anvers or abesesses metro station and walk around from there .

Great visit. Make sure you explore the tourist area and avoid the rough bits. Wouldn't go there at night time. Take the land train up to the sacre curr and see all the great street artists and restaurants just outside the base of the church.
Beautiful . Highest point in Paris where all the great painter used to live and paint. Cute town with little shops and lots of artists working. Beautiful cathedral to go inside too.

Fabulous time wasting spot!. The family enjoyed wandering around Montmartre and just taking in the sights of the area.We spent a lot of time in the Place de Tertre looking at all of the artists at work and then went to behold the Sacre Coeur and the views from it across Paris - not to be missed! Lots of different performers kept the crowds entertained and there were great to watch whilst overlooking Paris.Montmartre is a great place to visit as a family - highly recommended!

Soak up the atmosphere. A little train takes you from outside Moulin Rouge through some narrow streets and up the hill to Montmartre and the Sacre Coeur. As you turn the corner the Montmartre Village is just there. A small enclave of artists, each set up with their easels and umbrellas. and painting street scenes or Eiffel Towers, each with their own style, or walking around with sketch pads reading to draw your portrait in charcoal, pastels or some other medium. My daughter had a portrait of her dog drawn! Surrounded by cafes and restaurants, galleries and the inevitable tourist shops, a place not be missed, along with Sacre Coeur.

Hipsterland!. There is no other place in the world where you could ever feel as hipster as in this place! And not in the bad way. The music, art in the streets, street performers and cafés make of this a great place. Visit during the summer, it is jus marvelous. Don't forget to visit L'espace Dalí.

Lovely Place. This place in the northern part of Paris is very different to the central part. This has got the hill and a beautiful church(Basilica of the Sacré-Cœur ) from where you can see almost whole of Paris. The surrounding market is very good and gives good value to the money spent.Other than that this place is also known as the nightclub district of Paris.

Looooooooved this!!!!. We went twice on our visit to Paris. The views are spectacular and if you go on the weekend vs a week day you'll get a totally different experience. We went on a Sunday and it was pure magic, live music, drinks, sun, crisp air.. And back on a week day and it was special and different.
Cute. What a cute neighborhood! So many little shops and cafes to look around and they all have so much characters. Next time I am definitely spending more time here to explore all it has to offer.

busy busy busy. Just how I imagined it to be, lovely narrow cobbled streets, loads of restaurants and little bistros, artists and their work everywhere on display and for sale and the usual little tourist shops selling everything that you don't need.
Very nice and cozy.. The artists are fun to watch. Lost of good restaurants around and a wonderful plaza setting. Just like in the movies. The view from the top of the hill is worth it.
Always Fun. Lively part of town, always something fun to see and do. Feels like a neighbourhood where regular people still live. Worth while making the trip.
Love this place!. Went there at night. Live music, loads of people, amazing view. Really great place to visit and walk to.

Great part of Paris. My wife and I got here via the Hop on Hop off bus. We climbed to the top of Sacre Couer and then walked the cobbled alleyways nearby picking up a crepe and a macaron at a few of the many shops to chose from. Just a beautiful old spot.

Well worth a visit. It's worth doing this with a tour, the tour we used was Sandermans and our guide was Naill (he's Irish, speaks French), he is the most knowledgeable person I've ever met about all things French. I bet he knows more than most French people! There are certain things you should see in Montmartre and he covered them all. We saw where Van Gough lived and heard about his tragic life, saw the man who walked through walls, the only vineyard in paris!, the restaurant where Picasso used to eat. The Cathederal was also magnificent of course!

Best View of the City. Montmartre is a must visit part of the city. From the elegant (Sacre Coeur) to the tourist filled shopping streets to the restaurants you experience a vibe and feel unlike any other part of the city. Family friendly as well.

Probably shouldn't have visited here on a holiday weekend. Took the Metro here, but the village at the base of Sacre Couers was so crowded, and a bit sketchy, including street thugs doing shill games in the middle of the street. Took the funicular up to the Cathedral, which definitely beats walking up. You can use Metro passes for the funicular. Not impressed.

Favourite part of Paris!!. The wife and I loved visiting the Montmatre area of Paris, it actually felt like we were in the old parts of Paris that you see in the films or read about in books. We just enjoyed sitting at a small cafe drinking coffee, chatting and watching the world go by.
Near our Hotel in Pigalle. Montmartre is a nice neighborhood; tons of bistros and restaurants; train station; a cathedral, with many things to do... I loved staying in this area of Paris.

Take The Tram (Venicular?) . Cathedral on an important hill. This is a climb, so take their tram up the grade. From the front door, you are looking at the entire City of Lights. And of course, from most of the City, you can see the Cathedral. It's far more imposing than you can imagine. Afterwards, find a small cafe nearby and relax. Then, go out to dinner.

You haven't been to Paris unless you visit Montmartre!. One of my favourite areas of Paris.Full of atmosphere and history. Lovely open air cafes....restaurants. Sit here and watch the world go by surrounded by a flavour of of a bygone age. Pigalle and Sacre Coeur are in this area. Definite for your trip
Artist Hub. Have been several times and purchased from the same artist. Could not go to Paris and not visit this area so much to see full of different shops and places to eat.

Artists galore everywhere! Great place to spend a light sunny day. The place is well connected by Metro (Anvers Metro station), offers decent food options and is just next to the sacred and beautiful Sacre Coeur Basilica. There are some stairs which you would enjoy to climb unless you want to use funicular to go to the top. The view from the top is breathtaking and perfect for a panaroma. In my opinion this place offers much more variety of souvenirs than anywhere else. Just keep soaking the warmth of the village while you walk you would feel like you are in a different Paris. There's a museum dedicated to Salvador Dali which is worth spending your time in case you are fond of his work (Museum offers a discount if you have a valid Paris Visite pass). While roaming the streets you would be surrounding by artists who would be willing to paint your portrait in a quick time. Overall, this place should remain a must visit place in your itinerary and should ideally be clubbed with your basilica visit.

Still my favorite spot in Paris.. Just finished my third trip to Paris and my favorite place to visit there is still the many artists, restaurants and shops on top of the hill right behind the Sacre Ceour. I love watching the artists doing caricatures and portraits and it wasn't until this year that I finally decided to dio one myself and out was well worth it. The ship's have allot more art to look through and the food is always great and there are allot of choices. Most restaurants up there are also great for people watching while you eat because of all the people that that make the trip up the hill to see the church. Good atmosphere is what I think makes this place a must see for anyone visiting Paris. Oh yeah, and the church is beautiful inside and out which is a bonus for getting up that hill.
Old Paris. we stayed in monmartre for 3days and found everything was close to us. Good food, drinks and metro stops. We were able to plan out our days events startng in Monmartre.

Favorite Location. We did a walking food and wine tour with a company called A Movable Feast!!!! It was great we learned a lot about Montmartre and the local culture. The Restaurants on our tour were great along with the wine. We fell in love with this quaint little spot on up high called Montmartre.

Magnetic neighborhood. Montmartre is certainly a very hip and cool neighborhood. In addition to the artist's home, the neighborhood itself has a distinct feel and is worth walking around the streets and finding little shops to visit. It has a handful of interesting cafes and restaurants. If you are a women traveling on your own beware of unwanted attention by vendors, and other men, located in the steps to the church. This could easily be avoided by going around the steps, or using the cable car on the left hand side of the steps. Aside from that the view from Montmartre from the Sacre Cour is a certainly a sight to see!
Nice views. Its a nice place for a stroll, take the Metro and enjoy the area of the artists, it is great to get there early before the crowds turn upif you can and feel the vibes of the place.
Charming!. A charming and artistic escape from Paris's busy areas with many calm coffee shops and live painting. Amazing view of the city, beautiful cathedral. Espace Dali is not to be missed!
Charming!. A charming artistic and calm escape from the busy sides of Paris with live paintings. Amazing view over Paris. Do not miss Espace Dali as well.

Best view point of Paris . Still the same vibes with all artists on place des Tertres.
Fantastic view of Paris.
Stroll around the little back streets to discover little gems .

What an interesting area !. had read and heard so much about it and I am glad to say that Montmartre lived up to its reputation ... street artists, some of them with amazing paintings done by them ... a beautiful Basilica ... and buzzing with activity ... bargain shops ..

I think it was my favorite part of the trip. We started at the Tuileries and walked up to the Sacre Coeur. it doesn't really matter which street you take, as they all have adorable little shops and cafes. We stopped in a Breton creperie and about ten chocolate shops. We went to an epicerie and were treated to free samples of oils and sweets. Our saleswoman wore the apron that her grandfather, a charcuterieur (sp?) wore scores of years before. I have never seen such beautiful strawberries, blueberries and eggplants. The church was pretty but it was the lively scene around it that was most fun. We walked to the very top but took a quick funicular for the steep downhill, mostly because it was fun. My kids, 9 and 12, weren't at all bored.

A Must See When in Paris. The Montmartre area is very interesting. At the top of the hill is a lovely church. The Montmartre area is the area where all the famous painters created their works. Now you can find dozens of artists plying their trade. If you go in the evening, you will find artists doing portraits. This is a lovely souvenir to take home with you. Travel with a mailing tube if you think that you are going to go and get a portrait done. Mailing tubes fit quite easily into knapsacks and suitcases and are easy to find at home but not always so easy to find when traveling. There are dozens of nice coffee and dining attractions in the area as well. There is a funicular to the left of the main steps leading up to Montmartre. It costs one subway token.
Best Place in Paris. A MUST DO...eat lunch and enjoy the artists , people watch and the atmosphere! Lots of souvenirs shopping and visit Basiilique du Sacre-Couer.

Stayed here a week. You get a nice feel of what it would be like to live in Paris by staying here. All the tourists come by 9 am but depart mostly by 6 pm. Lots of stairs to walk up and down, quaint streets to explore. A must for anyone's first time to Paris.

Genuine old charm. I've heard good things and bad about Montmartre, but i liked it!It reminded me of the feel of say Camden in London or Greenwich Village in New York. That old, bohemian but stylish (in my view) feel.The area is dominated by the Sacre Coeur of course, but there are some really lovely shops, bars, cafes and markets.

A beautiful place terrorised by all the people bothering you to make drawings. Montmartre has to be a beautiful and peaceful place. Sadly enough a lot of self-made painters are now terrorising everyone coming there and bothering them to paint them. Stay away from those people and look in the city for people making drawings or silhouettes. In the city there are people doing this for 75% less than they ask on Montmartre. Overall still a lovely place to come and have a beautiful view on paris. Stay on the stairs and enjoy the artists singing, dancing

History abounds in this neighborhood. We completely enjoyed our tour of this neighborhood with a local guide who pointed out where a lot of the artists and musicians lived. We also stopped by the local museum, which only added to our experience of the neighborhood. Sacre Coeur was a don't miss as well!

Yes . A great small town within the city of Paris. Very quaint. Lots of art and a great place to sit for coffee and or a meal. Very busy on major holidays. A little touristy buy if you look past that the community is awesome

Paris Corners. My kind of visit, simply. A good walk, artsy corners, souvenirs, sweets... and we had a perfect day, in January. Take your time to climb the stairs up to the Sacre Coeur Dome, for cool air and a beautiful view of Paris.

Wander up the hill,, avoid the stairs. Worth avoiding the huge staircase and going through the winding roads up the hill towards Sacre Coeur. Wander up the hill to enjoy the small roads and the incredible views

What an Amazing Area. Go relax and wander around the streets or relax in one of the many café/bars and watch the world go by it's perfect (on a dry day!) We spent most of a day wandering the area and what a lovely place. The amount of artists working on a daily basis was staggering. Such a lovely atmosphere all around plus the stunning Sacre-Coeur. Walking down the street we saw so many paintings and drawings that we fell in love with we ended up purchasing a canvas painting that has pride of place on our wall and is a daily reminder of an amazing area and an amazing day.

Beautiful Paris gem. A must visit when in Paris. We stayed in Montmartre and we were very lucky to be able to explore the different restaurants for brunch. The place is suitable for families, friends and couples. You'll be able to see the different side of Paris here, from the nice restaurants to artist by the streets and the illegal gambling booth.
Artistic. Compulsory point to visit when staying in Paris. Amazing Sacre-Coeur and a view over Paris... it's here where Amelia Poulain worked and lived. Beautiful area.
Very nice and charming neighbourhood. Very nice and charming neighbourhood. Although, very touristy, there are still a lot of nice places to see and do. A must see on every trip to Paris!
take a walk .. You are in Paris. Paris is meant to see it on foot, or a bike... take a walk around, very busy with stand shoppers and good quick french food on the go.
Highlight . We visited Monmartre on our way the the church on the hill. It has an artistic edgy feel to it. They have loads cheap eats and bars to chill out in. Definitely worth a visit.

Everyone has to visit this area!. This neighborhood is the place where all the great painters lived and worked.Every time I visit Paris,I visit Sacre-Coeur and then I enjoy the view and I walk through the narrow streets of Montmartre.We had been painted from a great street artist some years before.

Fabulous neighbourhood. We were most impressed with the never-ending array of shops in Montmartre... including fromageries, boulangeries, flower shops, seafood stores with some of the best selection ever seen! it's a great walking neighbourhood, with lots of hills and steps, but most charming. Great bistros everywhere.

Great area. Bustling area filled with small streets, gotta watch those pickpockets though in the crowds... very arty bohemian district - all food that we had here was yum and of course its home to Sacre Cour Basilica

Very French!. This area of Paris was very authentic, people painting all over the place. French restaurants and bars along with a rustic charm of Paris, wonderful!
Well worth a visit if you visit Paris!

Leisure . Love the Montmartre. Took a friend who had never been. Had some gorgeous food while watching the many artists do their thing. Ended up buying a painting....of the cuff yes but there you go!! It's how you expect France to be. If nothing else just go and have food for the joy of eating.

Great place to people watch!. The Artists square is hype with artists doing what they do best! You can have your portrait done or watch others. You can buy a piece of artwork that is truly original and French! We loved it and loved the little streets and laneways.

Montmartre can't be missed. This area of Paris has its own distinct character and shouldn't be missed- its steep, winding streets are filled with charming shops and restaurants. Explore for a while before heading up to the star of the show- the Sacre Coeur, and the beautiful view of the city below.

Art and charm. Bustling with artists, this is the place to be for any bohemian spirit. The little alleys, shops and cafés are so charming you will want to come back the next time you are in Paris! What I like the most about the Basilica is that it is visible almost from every corner in town. Simply amazing.

Evening visit. Ride the funicular to top, and walk thru Sacre-Coeur Basilica.If you are fortunate there will be a mass ongoing, making it a very memorable visit. Arrive before sunset, then see the city lit up when you exit Basilica. Stroll around the corner to village of artists. Enjoy one of the great little restaurants in the village square, Lively little area, fun night out.
a must do -- once.. you have to do this once in your life but it's crowded and that was first thing in the morning. The views are to die for and give you a great perspective on the city.
Perfect if you are interested in art. This part of the city is bustling with artists working and selling their pieces. Very lively. Good atmosphere.

The place for artists. The church on the hills is so beautiful, the square is where all the artists are. Get an original painting or have your portrait drawn. Lots of shops and some amazing street performers. The view from the top of hill overlooking Paris is amazing! Watch for pickpockets. They're all over!

If you ever want a caricature, do it there. Prices may vary (around 40-50 euros), however it is nice to do it there as when you look back at it you will remember the place and that's all about a painting. Take care of your belongings however at all times - and that's why I can't give 5stars.

My Favorite Area - Art, Dining & Vistas. Best plan to visit from central Paris: Take subway to the famous Abbesses station (one of the last remaining 1890's 'Art Nouveau' canopies), walk up the several flights of stairs to Place du Tertre (literally Mound Square) for the open-air art sales and dining options. Nearby is Basilique du Sacre Coeur with amazing views over the city. If the climb seems daunting, you can take a taxi up direct to the square. What an amazing day!

A lovely 19th century village within Paris. Montmartre is one of the most popular districts in Paris for tourists. It is the village of painters. Most tourists love to have their portrait made by one of the numerous painters of la Place du Tertre.I recommend to travel in the bus "Montmartrobus" to be taken from the Town Hall of the 18th arrondissement of Paris. It is cheap with an ordinary bus ticket and the drive around Montmartre is absolutel ovely.

Liked the area. Stayed here for 4 nights & found one try to do & even thought that the Pigalle area wasn't too bad. Great selection of bars & restaurants but not much in the way of shopping but that's not too far away.

Best Views!. The long climb up was well worth it as the views of the city were amazing! (there is an elevator available for those that can not do stairs), The view was much better then the Eiffel Tower's views. There are several cafes and shops at the top. The Sacred Heart Basilica is also located at the top.

Favorite part of Paris. A trip to Paris is not complete without a visit to Montmartre. Quaint wonderful district. Quaint shops and cafe's - and of course the gem of Montmartre: Socre' Coure- the highest elevation in Paris. The main Blvd. where the Moulin Rouge is located should probably be avoided after dark, but the rest of the area is just beautiful and fun and relaxing. Quite a walk up but well worth it, especially the cemetery at Montartre. If you have difficulty walking it would be best to take the Metro to the district. We stayed on Haussman and walked to Montmartre.

A place worth visitng. Not only the Sacre-Coer Cathedral, which is better to visit from the outside, avoinding the main stairs (there are straight stairs just a couple of blocks away), but the whole neighborhood, a plaasure to walk thru.

Artists abound--. Travelled in a group of 4-----Absolutely charming once you get into the Artists section---painting and displaying their Art for Sale. Each of bought Art to bring home to the States. Wonderful Oils of Paris, Seine, Notre Dame, Sacre Couer.....very talented, high quality---and the prices----very good!I am so pleased with what I bought and after we all shopped for our Parisian Art----we shared a Bottle of Wine at an Outdoor Café----Very quaint area!---Just watch out for Scam artists----don't let anyone hand you a questionnaire to complete, or start painting your picture without permission-------I made it clear--I was looking at Art being displayed and we all left right when Dusk was upon us. The view of Paris is amazing!

Try some of the back streets. Montmartre's a neat place, but fairly crowded on a nice day. It's worth a walkabout in this highest point of Paris; great views over the city. Try going away from the front of Sacré-Coeur down some of the back streets that have quaint squares and cafés. We came across a film set under construction; they were preparing for scenes from 'Un sac de billes' by Joseph Joffo. (Worth the read! I want to see the film when it comes out.)

beautiful!. very nice place, relaxing and very pitorestic!Be carfull with the people that are drawing they are very expensive - ask first for the price, then let them paint you!This area has nice coffes!
My favorite!. Montmarte is one of my favorite places to visit in Paris. The views are amazing and the Sacre Coeur is a work of art. Get there early!

Iconic place. Not expensive quartier, and one of the most parisien experiences you can have. Great cafés, "pâtisseries", "boulangeries". Not as clean as the main "arrondissements", but you cannot miss it.
Artistic street . Very interesting street , painters doing what they do best and all the handcrafts artists belong in this amazing street . If you are a fan or art don't miss Montmartre .

lovely architecture but not great area. lots to see and lovely views but illegal vendors everywhere and the public toilets stink up the whole hill.
Keep your hands in your pockets or one of the vendors will have a friendship bracelet tightly knotted on to you and demanding money in seconds. maybe keep your hand on your wallet too..

Don't take the main stairs, take side street and avoid scam artists. Instead of entering enclosed area by the carousel gates in front of Sacre Coeur, walk to the right and take the side street up the hill! SO much nicer and you avoid the very aggressive trinket sellers and scam artists and pick pocketers. Once atop, get to the back streets and enjoy yourself!

You have to make the effort. If in Paris this is another district you should visit , not very big , but very interesting , lots of artists working outside and in the market , do be very aware of
People asking you to sign a survey sheet -- and if you want a photo taken , and the beggers , so be careful

Scuzzy but great. As the place infamous for ladies of the night and saucy cabaret shows, there's something naturally seedy about Montmartre. But it's also the place to be for excellent nightlife, reasonably-priced restaurants, great shops and of course, the amazing view from the of Sacre Coeur. I think this is my favourite part of Paris.

Amazing art. This was probably the highlight of my trip to ParisMany artists set up with their paintings and plenty of cafésSacred Heart Church was beautifulYou have to climb plenty of steps to get up there so probably not a great idea for people who are elderly or have walking difficulties although they may have other options to get up there

Sunset on the mountain is just paradise.. The train for $6 euro will bring you on a ride all around the neighborhood of old Montmartre. Great time for old and young. The Basilica is food for the soul.
Pluses and minuses.. I found the cutest little shops, boulangeries, bistrots and cafes there but the streets are full of teenage hooligans even in the middle of the day.
If you are in Paris you must visit here. We stayed just near here and walked to Montmartre . Got to go to Moulin Rouge as well as you are right by it. A must for tourists

Delightful artists' quarter. During my Paris walking tour last month, a stroll through Montmartre was a definite notable experience. The shops and boutiques artfully designed window displays and artist agora can inspire the staunchest of philistine. A walk through this celebrated artistic quarter is highly recommended!

Beautiful part of Paris . We spent a brief time in this part of the city with our guide. I wish we could spend more time there. Walking along cobblestone streets lined with local art and artists. Small quaint cafes just made you really feel like you were in Paris. It was cold when we went but I can only imagine how beautiful itis in the summer months.

A walk through art. It is definitely the go to spot for all art lovers from around the world. Get your face sketched by the artist and dont get hustled, also keep your hands in your pockets and always check your wallet.

Stayed here, wandered here. Lovely area, some cute shops, lots of 'artists' and lovely little cafes. This place is more bohemian and calmer than central Paris. We stayed in the area and there is plenty to see and it's great for shopping if that what you are looking for. It's nice to have some different shops rather than all of the souvenir places.
Best area of Paris. Loved it,loved it, loved it, great area of Paris, everything you could ever need, great friendly people, and 15 minutes to the Champs Elysees.

Best area in Paris!. This was most definitely my favourite area of Paris! Much more relaxed and less busy than other areas! The streets are cobble stoned and are very historic as Paris used to be!It is also full of really great cafes and other eating establishments! We took a food tour around the area which was also amazing!

Read a guide before you visit!. There so much to see around the back streets of Monmatre, please read a guidebook or website or take one of the walking tours etc before visiting otherwise you will miss out on the stories and the heritage behind this amazing area of Paris!

So glad we went. I didn't get to go to Montmartre during my last trip to Paris and I am SO glad we did! The church is just supremely beautiful and the views from the top can't be beat. Make sure you take the time to go!

Enjoy the Square from a Cafe!. Montmartre is such a great experience, best enjoyed over a glass of wine from one of the many sidewalk cafes. The large group of artists who create there provide an entertaining scene; and you can request a painting, drawing or caricature on-the-spot!

Beautiful place :). My partner and I came here on our last day! Was about an hour away on the train but once there it was so worth it. We got the little train thing up and then wondered round. The views were spectacular and we loved sitting on the steps listening to the buskers that were performing!

Amazing street market - a must visit. What an amazing street to walk down/up. Everything from bakeries, fresh fish, clothing to amazing chocolatiers and often live street music. We visited on a Sunday late morning and there was such a buzz in the street. It was so great to walk down the street and to pop into all the little shops. Some of the chocolatiers were absolutely amazing in their attention to detail. One shop sold chocolate cheshire cats, i have no other way to describe these. It was this large smiley cartoon cat head made of, and filled with, delectable chocolate. Such a great variety of cheeses, some great little boutique clothing stores and somewhere to get items to fill your pantry with. Well worth a visit for those of you who love markets

Almost best after midnight. Certainly both one of the more romantic spots in Paris as well as one of the more touristic ones.Between March and October always crowded during the day, it still affords excellent views over a lot of Paris in any case.My personal tip would be to do it at night, when the crowds have died down just a little and a romantic walk will add another level to the experience...Almost better in the off-season on a sunny winter's day/night than during more crowded time.Not to be missed in any case.

Old City Charm. We visited the Montmarte fabric district, because we were lucky enough to be staying in the area through AirBnB. There are some beautiful shops, and fabric stalls to be seen along here, where we were told all the big names still come to buy their fabric samples and swatches, including the Moulin Rouge. The artists in residence also have some wonderful art that is worth seeing. Just a gorgeous area to wander and lose yourself in the cobblestones of Paris.

A busy but delightful area. Lots to see and well worth walking around - so many artists and writers were here in previous centuries. wander up and down (literally!) the old streets and drink in the atmosphere. Take care to avoid the street sellers and the cartoon artists, all of whom can be very intimidating. The last surviving vineyard of Paris is here; the man walking through a wall; windmills and theaters and little cafes. Tourist prices but worth doing for fun!
Nice area behind Sacre Coeur with pseudo artists. I walk up that hill every time I am in paris. Little annoying are painters running behind tourists and wanting to paint them.
Great place to visit. Fun area with masses of restaurants and artists willing to paint your portrait.Lively young place.We enjoyed wandering round the side streets.
Love this area. Lovely cute shops and market, I have bought so many souvenirs up here (not the tacky kind) Perfect place to sit outside and have a drink. The street artists are brilliant too

Really good area to be in . Something for everyone and every taste. The area is very cultured, packed with both day time and night time activities. Bars, clubs and restaurants to suit all palette and tastes. Close to several other attractions. Definitely a place to see or stay in Paris.

have to visit every year. Family tradition to visit and always have a Grand Marnier crepe at Au Clarion des Chasseurs Brasserie. Beware of the people selling trinkets on the steps up to Sacre Coeur Church by the historic merry go round, they can be very intimidating if you don't buy. We tend to walk up by a different route to avoid them.
Great place. Montmartre is really a charming place. Walking through its street is fantastic. This is old Paris at its best.

This is a beautiful are full of artist. Go on good clear days and there will be artist for day. Go on a bad day and there will be few to none. I love this area off the red light district and is on a huge hill. The shops are amazing and there is everything your heart could want from tourist to antiques to boutiques. I start on top of the hill and work my way down so I am not climbing this large hill with my hands full. You can get a take a the road train up the hill for a small amount and walk back down and once down there are metros stops all over to get you back to you hotel. As usual hold tight to your belonging and always have you eyes open and be aware of who is up on you and around you. Paris is the worst for scams and pick pockets. But is one of the best cities I have every been to.

Life is beautiful. Absolutely love this area of Paris. Quaint small bistros, wine bars, artists galleries, music and small shops. The main square on Sunday's with all the local artists displaying their artwork is impressive. I absolutely recommend spending an afternoon here.

Montmartre, take the funicular or the steps either way, its worth it. Once you have entered Montmartre, you can visit the cathedral or wonder round the town, there are pubs or a Starbucks with a lovely sitting area if you need a break from sightseeing. There are also opportunities to buy painting by local artists.

Artistic area. This is the best part of Paris. Colorful and artistic with Sacré-Cœur! It's crowded and touristic but also romantic and just lovely. Many street artists and small shops. Great area for a dinner.
Take a Tour. I took the Sandmans walking tour and it was AMAZING. yes this area is wonderful to just walk around, but taking a tour lets you learn the wild and beautiful history

An Artist's Mecca. When you come to Montmartre and have ANY passion for art, this is the place to feel it happen. In the past and now, artists come to embrace the beauty of the city. don't miss it but do your homework first, it's worth it!

Very touristy. Montmartre is a must-see on your Paris list, but be prepared for plenty of crowds and the usual tourist traps. Try to avoid the main streets and instead wind your way along the smaller side streets to avoid the crowds and see the real Paris.

Words cannot describe. I visited this place in spring and it was one of the highlights of my trip. This neighbourhood was in bloom when I visited it and there was a great feel of peace. Aside of the Place du Tertre and the basilique du Sacre-Cœur (which are well worth visiting) there's the quiet cobbled streets. These places don't receive as many tourists (that mainly go through the Sacre-Cœur and the Place du Tertre) but are incredibly picturesque. One of the most memorable experiences was (late in the afternoon) sitting under a tree in a small park, eating a sandwich. It was so enjoyable and the best thing: hardly any tourists in the most visited city in the world. If you go to Montmartre I would seriously recommend you get off the beaten track and take in the village atmosphere.
Iatmosphere hard to beat. Yes it's touristy yes it's busy but still a favourite place to people watch and soak up the sights and sounds and imagine life 100 years ago. Love it

Love this neighborhood. Picturesque cobble stone streets, nice shops and restaurants, and great views from the beautiful Sacre Couer Cathedral. Montmarte was one of the highlights of our trip to Paris

Beautiful elevated view. I highly recommend exploring the Montmartre area. Put on your walking shoes and climb the steps up and up and up for a wonderful view of the Sacré-Cœur Basilica and the whole of Paris from the mountaintop! Visit La Place du Tertre for some souvenir poster art.

One of our best days in Paris. After visiting Sacre Couer, follow the crowds travelling west and come to the Place de Tertre. There are artists wandering the street that will draw a quick caricature, or you can move to the center of the square for the artist's market. The two cafes on the square have good prices, but a short walk down the side streets will get you crepes at an even better price. Just wander for a couple of hours - this is a charming area with a good vibe.

for any time of the year. a must when visiting paris.. One can not go miss Montmartre when visiting Paris for the first time. You can take the metro to boulevard de clichy and then you can take the small buses that take you up to the basilic or you can also walk there. I would not recommend to eat at the restaurants at Montmartre because they are literally the most touristic kind. however, there are a few good restaurants below Montmartre.

Lovely Area to Explore. My husband and I took a cab ride to the Sacre Coeur as our hotel was about 2 miles from the Basilica. We decided to cab there and walk back so we could have time to explore the surrounding areas. A very good idea. The views from the Basilica were beautiful and all of the exploring after that were down hill :-). The area is full of cute shops (and some touristy shops). Lots of great restaurants as well. You even pass the Moulin Rouge. Worth a stroll for sure.

Beautiful area to wander through, an absolute must see!. I love Montmartre; yes it's touristy, yes go off the beaten track to eat and drink, but go! Wander through the cobbled streets and get lost (it's easy to find your way back to a landmark), marvel at the classicly French buildings and old bistros, imagine all those bohemians in the late 1800s living here! The atmosphere is relaxed and friendly, it's bustling and villagey. Sadly, the graffiti and the stinking, overflowing bins take a little of the beauty away for me... heart-breaking! And I'm sure it's a pick-pocketer's dream, the "artists" in the main square probably make a fair buck, but so what. Standing in the square with the bistros, the artists, the trees, the lamp-posts, well it certainly brought a smile to my face! From here walk down to Place de Abbesses for many more bistros and individual shops. Enjoy.

Lovely views, too many scammers in the area. The gardens and streets in the area are lovely, with great views across Paris. The problem is the number of people selling things and trying to scam or pressure you out of money. You can't go more than a minute without being asked to buy something or someone trying to tie a string around your wrist and demand money for it. It's a pity, as you can;t relax or really enjoy the area because of it.
3 day stay. Lovely place - lots of little shops and great places to eat. Some steep steps/ inclines if you are climbing to the Sacre Coeur and the roads around there but take it slowly and explore :)

A fantastic Districts, must to see. A must to see in Paris. I think it is an artistic place full of painters and musicians. You can lost in its alleys for 2-3 hours and enjoy the nice and small shops and beautiful streets.
Take your time.. Amazing area of Paris. Enjoyed the artists around the village. Had lunch at a little eatery and bought very expensive chocolate at the chocolate shop. Worth a visit.

Tourist Trap. I had read so much about Montmartre and felt a little disappointed that it was full of tourists and very expensive to eat. Worth a visit if you're in the area at Sacre Coeur but otherwise don't make a special trip. Go to Le Marais instead!

One of my favorite Paris neighborhoods!. Lovely all around. Be picky when selecting an artist if you wish to have your portrait drawn. Some of the artists can be pushy. Try the Montparnasse Tavern for some delicious food in a very rustic ambiance. It's a small restaurant so you may have to wait a bit but it is worth it.

amaizing. A lot of people say that Montmartre is so commercialized, so touristy. True, but if you explore deeper into the steeper part of this hilly quarter, you will discover a mellow and more attractive side of it. It’s a lovely place to lose yourself.

Not the Montmartre of the impressionist era.. It is still the same land, most of the same buildings, fun to walk through but romantic history ends there. It is now a tourist trap for hawkers of cheap souvenirs, fake artistes, and inundated with cars and stinky bus traffic. Buses so huge they can barely maneuver the narrow streets and corners. There are a few true artists dwelling here, artists of pastries and pottery but don't expect to find a Monet or Manet hanging around.

Arty part of Paris. Loved all the artists hard at work in the square and the lovely old buildings.
