Didn't love all the steps (no one in my group wanted to use the funicular) especially as we had mistakenly shunned the lift at Abbesses and climbed 91 steps up to the street! Still, there are plenty of nice cafes to drink wine in once you get there and the trip down was much better! Only use the steps if you are fit......

Un classique sur Paris!. Some may say this place is full of tourists and they are correct. But if this place is always full of people, it is because is so easy to enjoy your visit! Come with time, take a walk through the back streets and discover great local flavors and the best bread in Paris and of course, wonderful views of the city. Restaurants are pricey, but you can also get your favorite things at one of the close supermarkets and enjoy your picnic on the grass. It's the spirit!

Montmartre 1993, 1996, 2010, 2015. Montmartre is the hilly part of Paris. There are stairs to reach the top. The famous Sacré Coeur Cathedral perched at the top, and it looms over Paris. There is another church on the hill, the older Saint Pierre de Montmartre, which is the founding place of the Jesuits.The area is also famous for its nightlife and artists. The Moulin Rouge is here, and Pigalle is known both for being the red-light district and for its rock music venues. Artists including Picasso, van Gogh, Monet, Modigliani, Renoir and Dali all lived and/or worked in the area. The Dali Espace museum is also worth a visit.

Great place to walk around, fabulous views and lots of history. I recommend taking the funicular up to the Sacre Coeur if you are with kids and then walking back down through the area (saves on too much moaning and is very good value). I also recommend you go at sunset to see Paris light up and then make your way down to the Moulin Rouge once it is dark.

worth a visit. This little corner of Paris is well worth visiting...you can get the tour bus and then walk up all the steps to the top, not as bad as they look.some nice places to eat or hav a coffee, with some artists doing their work, good place to get a little painting as a souvenir.
Beautiful Area. Love this area of Paris. Lovely old buildings and charm through the streets. The view is breath taking!

Don't miss this neighborhood of Paris. This is a really quaint area of Paris....lots of little Bistros, shops, winding streets and wonderful views of the city. You can get up there by walking up the steps, if you are fit or taking the funicular for an easy approach. We went up in early evening...walked around, had dinner, enjoyed the view after dark and then walked down. The base of Montmartre is very close to Moulin Rouge, so we were able to take a comfortable stroll prior to seeing the show.
Amazing, beautiful and super architecture. Peaceful, architectural, lovely and relaxing location with a wonderful view to admire while walking up to the Sacree Coeur

lovely Nieghborhood. we loved staying in the area. people were lovely and so many different nationalities. it was close to the metro, walking distance to the river and catherdral. all in all a lovely Community

Hilly walking of the red light district. Historically, this is where all the famous impressionist painters went to work in studios along the windy narrow streets. Ive been to Montmartre twice: first time did tourist route (metro to center by Moulin Rouge and walked to top--a good workout). The top area is square with artists (who have to pay to be there) but it is really just a major tourist trap. Second time I went on walking tour (Sight Seekers Delight--see separate review) that was much easier route winding up the hill at manageable pace. Still saw windmills and Scre-Coeur Basilica (built in 11th century), but avoided all the tourists and crowds (except when at the church and the top main square). There is a lot to see here besides the awesome view of the whole city of Paris: the "I Love you wall" (Square des Abbesses) and the "Walker through Walls" sculpture (Place Marcel-Ayme: a story worth googling) and all of the creative, unique art tucked on walls, doorways and buildings. The area is basically a seedier part of town (the Red Light district--historically where the prostitutes were). There are some better shops and eateries, but you have to get away from the main drag (Pigalle station). It is lively area and definitely worth checking out--but be ready to walk up hilly cobblestone streets and do stairs.

Good for blowing the cobwebs away. If you walk up the steps to the top of la butte Montmartre and the Sacré Coeur basilica. Alternatively there is a clean little funicular which will save your legs, especially if you have climbed the 90 steps up from the deepest metro station at Les Abesses rather than take the lift!Montmartre is very touristy and very busy, even on a cold dry Sunday morning. Sometimes clichés are to be embraced rather than shunned and Paris shone today. La Place du Tertre was full of tourists; French and foreigners alike seem to enjoy themselves. You can just walk about or go the the basilica or even better the Musée Montmartre.

Top o' the Hill. The church is curiously dull, even rather garish, but the views from the hill are beautiful. It was always one of the poorer areas of Paris, but it now is more and more like a T-shirt souk

Just lovely, sit in the sunshine and watch the world go by, or later and enjoy the atmosphere at night.. Unashamedly touristy but still a "must visit" place in Paris. Up by the Sacre-coeur church. Still full of artists trying to sketch you a portrait.

Lovely but kinda touristy. I only visited at night and it certainly has charm with the small, cobbled streets and dim lighting. However i felt it was very tourist orientated at night. Only tacky tourist shops open but i did see some quaint stores so it may be better to visit during the day.The food I ate here was some of the best in Paris though. I ate two lovely three course dinners here so I recommend coming here if you are looking for somewhere to nice to eat.
A must in PARIS. Go there to have diversified experience. Artists are loitering. Beggars are also there. A collage of everything. Culture of Paris may be understood a bit.
Touristy. Adjoining Sacre Coure, this is full or artists and restaurants. The walks in the streets adjoiing are also very interesting.
From the Sacré Cæur to the Chocolate Museum, c'est magnifique!. Walking is the best way to enjoy any city, and that's certainly true of the Monmartre section of Paris.

charming, fabulous place to visit. We spent the most wonderful time in Montmartre
the area is beautiful, very charming and full of lovely arty shops and restaurants.
Definetely a place to visit

Pittoresk little town.. A very nice and a huge contrast from a Paris that sometimes can be a bit hectic. Interesting to visit the square were the artists eagerly want to make a painting of you. Also very nice small shops with mostly souvenirs. There is very nice restaurants of different pricesranges.

Glad I convinced my spouse! . Montemarte was the highlight of our trip. Yes, I'd take Montemarte over the Eiffel Tower, the Louvre, Versailles, etc. Very old world charm, open markets, an artists square and amazing cuisine. You are insane to pass this location up on a multi-day trip to Paris.
Very chic atmosphere. Narrow curvy streets lined with small shops and bistros. You can enjoy the artists painting on the square and even treat yourself with a beautiful painting.

Art Lover's Paradise. We spent an afternoon in Montmartre and enjoyed it so much went back again later in our trip. You have to watch the artist's sketch people as they sit and model in the chairs provided. It is a great place to have a glass or two of red and enjoy the surroundings. We would do it again!
amazing and memorable. a beautiful setting filled with artists and history- a walk up the historic steps leads you to this haven. A great afternoon can be spent strolling the artist lined roads.

Lovely area. Shops, cheap food and drink, restaurants, street artist - its all here.
I went on a Sunday and the area seemed very relaxed and chilled compared to Le Marais area the previous day.
Worth while having a slow half day here.

Home. I live in this neighbourhood and I absolutely love it. When you want to get a away from all the mainstream spots of the city centre, visit montmartre. After midnight it can be a little 'intresting' so I recommend a trip during the day time.

Old Paris atmosphere. My favorite place...Art capital of Paris,artists in the square,full of beautiful cafes,restaurants,souvenir shops,little streets...At the top of the Montmartre the Sacre-Cceur basilica/great views/ stands out in the Paris skyline.Two surviving Montmartre windmills/Renoirs famous painting/ stands on a private street-best be seen from 75 Rue Lepic.Moulin Rouge is close+++

Shopping at Marchè St Pierre, Montmartre. Anyone interested in getting fabrics of any kind; this is a must visit. 5 Floors of all kinds of fabrics and accessories at good prices. We were looking for upholstery fabric and we're done within half an hour. Not much English spoken but ask for Luc and you'll be OK!

Overrated and expensive. As a huge art and Henri de Toulouse-Lautrec fan I was expecting something totally different. The place was far from authentic and it was super touristy (thats quite understandable though) and lacked any type of soul or Parisian feel to it. The Moulan Rouge was absolutely horrible and all the pubs were pretty expensive. If you wanna get that urban, bohemian feeling go to Bastille or Oberkampf, not Montmartre.
Always interesting. Just a stroll around Montmartre is the way to absorb the atmosphere of Paris . Some lovely art even if it is mass produced for the tourists.

Even if the place attracts only tourists, I go there every time I visit Paris, because I am a tourist!. Good exercise to climb up and a beautiful view over Paris. Always something going on, artists drawing portraits, musicians playing and restaurants trying to get you in. One wine yards of Montmartre is still there to remain of the past. Anytime of day is the right time to visit Montmartre.

Fascinating glimpse into artistic past. Definitely take time to climb the hill to joutney back in time 100 years into the bohemian past. Sett off from the Moulin Rough (Blanche Metro) and stroll up hill twards Sacre Ceur. If your feeling flush take a beer or glass of wine in the square and get great pictures if the city from the church. The Montmartre museum is worth a fascinating cheap detour to see where Renoir (among others) stayed for a while and painted. Remember to keep looking up for wall plaques (eg 'Vincent Van Gogh and his brtother Theo live here')

Original pieces of art. Amongst the usual tourist "tat" there are some wonderfully talented artists. We brought a piece of original art for €35 and we are delighted with it. Even if you are not buying it's a great place to wander around.

Art Central With Some Great Views. Montmarte is quite literally the art capital of Paris, the area is full of the stuff! It is a great stop for the weekend traveller who is wanting to take in the real Paris as this has a very special feel to the area. Great views can be had from the Sacre Coeur but do watch out for the street sellers as they are very forward which can be quite intimidating and they will also target children so please be warned.
The view! . Superb views across Paris. Only draw back for me was all the lucky lucky men. Made me feel a bit on edge. Wouldn't recommend going here at night.

Have to go here!. In summer it seethes with tourists and is too crowed but any other time it is sublime. Look out over Paris from the Sacre Coeur. Have a quite vin blanc in the square and watch the passers by. Have a crepe at the Tire Bouchon restaurant or lunch at the Poulbot! Don't leave Paris without coming here.

Beautiful art and amazing food. Montmarte is such a cool area of Paris. It's fun to stroll through the streets and look watch local artists create new works. There are A LOT of artists roaming around talking tourists into having their portraits drawn. Be a bit careful of this. We decided to have ours drawn after my husband low-balled the artist into a reasonable price. I would recommend talking the price down, I think the original offer from the artist was the equivalent of $150! The results of the drawing are varied, the portrait looks like us.... but not really. A fun experience none the less!

The artist district of Paris. This charming Paris district, situated around the hill of Montmartre in the northern part of the city, is home to many famous Paris landmarks. It is best known for the beautiful Sacre-Coeur Basilica on top of the hill as well as the legendary cabaret of Moulin Rouge. Montmartre was originally a village located just outside of the city limits. Although it has long been part of the city of Paris, this area still has that charming village feel to it. This lovely district has always been popular among artists. Many famous painters, such as Salvador Dali, Vincent van Gogh, and Pablo Picasso, worked and lived in this area. Even today, Montmartre is still well known as being the artist district. This area is full of cosy cafés, restaurants, and lovely little shops. You could spend a whole day wandering around the crooked little streets, exploring this wonderful neighbourhood, and absorbing the charming atmosphere.

A Lovely Small Village. As it is written in the description, "Montmartre is located in the 18th Arrondissement, this elevated rural neighborhood on the outskirts of the city has a collection of upscale shops and cafés and still exudes hints of old village charm."This place is really a small neighborhood where you can find small cafes and shops. The village enables you to see the Paris from an upper and wide angle. It is very nice, lively, small place where you can feel some relaxation. Actually, I cannot say that you should go there and there in Montmarte but you should visit there. There are some lovely small streets, street artists, lots of people from many countries... I think you can fee the Paris there. By the way, if you walk around the Montmartre area your walk would end up with Moulin Rouge.If you go to Montmartre in the evening you should care your personal safety (especially pickpockets).

Magic Montmartre:). A place where art is raised to the highest step.I am thrilled every corner of this place.Bohemian quarter, elation, excitement..Magnificent sight Sacre Coeur,that rises and throws a beautiful view of the city..Parisians call it a hill, because it is the highest point,So I read:)So You must climb the stairs pretty, but nothing terrible for what you'll see.Main market glances at Sacred Heart Church,so there are tourists,and many sellers of souvenirs,stalls selling food,we tried some biscuits with a spread of duck pate,unusual taste..Particularly fascinating to me are tucked streets, supporting small squares,a lot of people, street artists who paint portraits and caricatures fast,street musicians and vendors..how great it was ,memories,memories:)We visited the Salvador Dali Museum,we suggest you visit,exposed to a lot of sculptures and drawings of the famous surrealist..You must visit the cemetery,Moulin Rouge..Overall the part of the city is known for its art, bohemians.Exudes uniqueness, and yes, this is my favorite part of Paris.

Special flair. Maybe it's because it sits on hill that Montmartre always felt special.... I used to live near the cemetary and loved and still love walking around up and down the streets of this neighborhood.... there is of course Sacré Coeur and all the touristy stuff, and place de Tertre has become more run of the mill touristy, but it's still totally worth the trip...

Monmartre. Having reservations about Monmatre because of all the steep walks we saw Sacre Coeur and its all its hundreds of steps to reach it. Then noticed the Fernicular lift and foe just a few euros each took you all the way to the top. The cathedral was beautiful and from the top you could see the most spectacular views of Paris. Well worth the visit!

Place to visit in Paris!. I could be enjoying to get lost around here. Cute neighborhood with little cafe around and nice view from up. I went there on sunset time, climbing up to the top and enjoyed the city view from up, was really beautiful. Also visited the cathedral and was good experience too. Love the architecture inside.

Like Walking in an Impressionist Painting.... Montmartre is the ultimate place to just wander around aimlessly. You will love every step of the way. Walk up to Sacre Couer. The view from the top is outstanding. Get a crepe in a little adorable spot. Greet the artists in the square and let your mind just wander.
A must to see when visiting Paris. We went on a cold day with a little rain but the atmosphere of this area is still worth a visit.Everything is expensive but it just has to be seen.
The top of the city. Montmartre is a lovely area of Paris - one that has inspired artists through the ages. Hilly and very picturesque, full of cafes, restaurants and shops.

Beautiful place ❤️❤️❤️. Lovely, very pretty place with lots of artists ready to sketch you for very reasonable prices. We loved our visit here, the views are lovely from the top of the steps and just a beautiful area overall. Enjoyable day ☀️☀️☀️

Parisian party!. This is the true heart of Paris with lovely restaurants tucked in the little streets and the views for miles! The ambience is great, with lots of cafes and bars and street musicians. We went quite late at night and saw no street artists, however, the streets were alive with people having a good time. Sacre Coeur is stunning and worth a visit if in Montmartre. There are lots of souvenir shops in the area and the Moulin Rouge is closeby. It is just perfect for a walk through this wonderful city whether it is day or night.

Lovely place to visit!. My favourite area in Paris. The shops, cafes and cobbled streets are just so attractive - coupled with the artists doing live paintings. Very nice atmosphere to stroll around and find some good painting keepsakes!

So amazing. This is a wonderful quarter of Paris. I love it here. The ambiance is amazing and the views beautiful. There are quite a few tourist shops and things like that. But there are also good restaurants on the little streets that are more tucked in.

Favourite!. Wonderful part of Paris - lots of artists working in the square, lots of Cafes where you can sip wine and watch the people go by and have a bite of lunch. Quite a few shops selling oil paintings - some are quite stunning and not expensive - if you want a memory of Paris, this is the place to go. The shop assistants, the artists and the cafe staff are all wonderfully friendly, especially if you give the French language a go! If you are in Paris, this is a must do.
Take the walk.... Take the stairs. Walk on a sunday morning up. Few tourists. No people who try to rip you of with armbands etc. Just a magnificient view on Paris. Relaxing. Even in February!
Fantastic views. Fabulous views from the top but very touristy with a lot of people trying to get you to sit for a portrait. Sacre Ceour is a beautiful building.

First visit to Paris!. My husband and I travelled to Paris for our Silver Wedding and it was all I had dreamed of! We stayed in the outskirts of Paris and travelled on the Metro to the heart of all the action. Our first stop was the Notre Dame which was spectacular and hearing the bells ring was truly wonderful! Such a busy busy place full of eager tourists to see the sights maybe just too busy for us so we continued walking along the south bank admiring the views and fabulous shops. What I really wanted to see was THE tower! and I wasn't disappointed! a magnificent sight, breathtaking! We had purchased skip-the-line tickets with a guide (strongly recommended!) and our guide Nico was full of knowledge and great stories. We went to the top level and the views were truly spectacular and although very busy we enjoyed our visit immensly. Our second tour was with Delicious Paris and the lovely Olga who showed us around the beautiful Montmarte and Sacre Couer. She showed us around and told great stories of the artists and painters who had a great time living it up! We shared a delicious cake from a pristine patisserie, drank coffee in a quiet cafe away from the hustle and bustle and sat in a beautiful courtyard taking in the views and atmosphere. This tour was so much more enjoyable it was very relaxing and Olga was in no hurry to rush us along, a lovely warm and engaging person who really knows her history and showed a great interest in our history too! She recommended places to eat and showed us some lovely areas which we would never have explored on our own. All in all a very unique and very enjoyable tour which took us off the well beaten track and showed a different side to the Paris we all think we know. A place I hope we will come back and visit many more times.

Well worth a wander. One of the more famous free sights in Paris, this is where you can have your portrait or caricature painted by a wide range of static and peripatetic artists. The coffee is not bad either but you will be hard pressed to find one at much less than 5 euros. Just round the corner from the Sacre Coeur, it's a good place to escape to after a freezing February visit to the church.

Great place to start or end your day. Montmatre is a beautiful part of Paris. While it's wonderful no matter what time of day you visit it's at its best either early morning or late evening.We would often head up there early morning just as the shops were opening up and the street cleaners were doing their thing. It was always like watching the city wake up and then we would walk back down to river and take a different route each time.It's also beautiful in the evening with all the outdoor cafes and the wonderful sunset views over the city.

Busy street. We just drop off the Big Bus Paris and to our surprise we found this beautiful street. Touristy street but lovely to see the street painters all over the place. Great food too and not that expensive unlike cafes near champ de elysee. Sweet!
Worth the walk!. Beautiful area and full of amazing sights. Spectacular views. Join a tour to walk up the hill in a roundabout way so you learn about the area. At the top relax and enjoy the sights.
Lovely View of the city. Spent 15 minutes climbing a hill but it was definitely worth it!! got a couple souvenirs, got a portrait done by MAXIM!! and too a bunch of pictures!!

Could probably live here!. What a great place! Reminds me of Greenwich Village in NYC.
Lots of shops, restaurants, artists in the square!

Super busy but beautiful.. This location is easily one of the tourist hotbeds in Paris centre, but worth the views and gorgeous sights of the skyline and ancient cathedral. Be sure to head to this location near dawn or dusk to take advantage of good light, less people, and enjoyment from the workers who "shush".

Cute neighborhood, lots of views (i.e. hills!). This might have been my favorite neighborhood in Paris. There were amazing views of the city from Sacred Heart and the nearby area was full of bakeries, restaurants, and 'artsy-types'. Had the best cheese at one of the shops by the square (forget the name - but if you ask, everyone will know..it's famous)

Great vibe... unique experience. We loved our visit to Montmarte! So much shopping (all touristy), but most of all, an amazing vibe and crowd. Music on the streets and at Basilica de Sacre Coeur (where you get one of the best views of Paris).

Want a self portrait. This one of the many beautiful places around Paris. With the number of artists here if you want your own self-portrait this is the place to come.If you don't mind walking, making your way up to Montmarte via rue Lepic goes all the way to Mont Martre and after you enjoy viewing the different artists works it is only a short walk to Sacre Couer. On a clear sunny day on the steps of the church you can get spectacular Photos of Paris and its surrounds. Or you can go the extra mile and climb the 300 or so steps to the top of the church dome and get a 360 degree uninterrupted view of Paris.If you decide to return back to the St Pierre district via the grounds in front of the church, be aware that this is a popular hangout for pickpockets and scammers. Don't stop, if they follow you make sure your bags are closed and secure, they usually only follow you if your show interest in their games. The police and the locals know they are here why they don't do any thing about them is beyond me.Alternatively make your way back via the same rue Lepic and admire the Moulins, (old windmills).

One of the best bits. Lots of things and places to see in Monmartre, as well as the windmill of the Moulin Rouge, you can visit the Sacre Coure, the cemetery where Jim Morrison is buried, some of the most amazing restaurants - of the beaten track. some of the cheapest shops. Music museum is worth an hour of your time. Just walk and keep your eyes open, its just great

A must see. This is one of my favorite places in Paris (I live nearby). I recommend for those who have a bit of time to wander in the non touristic side, the atmosphere is unique. Don't miss it if you re in Paris.

Pretty and French. Lots of street performers and artists, beautiful architecture and a unique ambiance. Lovely area. Sacre Coeur at the top of the hill is a wonderful sight, pure white stone...akin to Minas Tirith. Superb views!
budding artists. Really amazing value for paintings whether it be water oils etc value for money by local artists such talent

Wonderful. What you really need to do is just enjoy the walk and the surrounding, specially during winter season, which is my favorite, I "go with flow" there is art in each and every little detail in Montmartre area.

A Touch of Belle Epoque. The Belle Époque was France from around 1871 until WWI. A time of gentility and high fashion. A walk through Montmartre will permit you glimpses into that era as you walk its streets. There is an underlying current of languid leisure underlying the bustle of residents and visitors. Small cafes, artists at their easels in the tree lined square. Bits of art nouveau peeking out from here and there all combine to make this area of Paris worth spending time in it. Stop at a café for an espresso or beverage of choice. Look around at the sights and citizens as they carry on their daily endeavors. Enjoy the day. Take a stroll around the streets to find the hidden treasures of Montmartre. You won't regret taking the time.

Best Place to stay in Paris. Montmartre is my favorite place to stay in Paris. It's more affordable & has plenty of shops & restaurants.I love having dinner at the sidewalk cafes & watching the people walk by especially the pretty women. The area is also more quiet but not too much. Eateries are open late. I stayed on Rue Abbesses which is probably more sedate than where I'll be staying this year, we'll see.I remarked to a waiter that the French had an undeserved reputation. I said everyone was friendly & overlooked my poor French (actually I could speak it better then I could understand someone else). He replied that of course you're our customers. I said it was more than that just directions from people on the street was a pleasant experience. I highly recommend staying in Montmartre for you Parisian excursions.

Not sure!!. Im really glad we went to see Sacre-Coeur. We walked to the very top, Its a long way 234 steps!! The views are unbelievable, a 'must see'. we walked past the Cimetiere do Montmartre to get to it. (You need a good map). This we thought was the best route very pretty. We walked down the steps when finished. NOT a good idea, we were pestered by people trying or should I say forcing us to buy bracelets DO NOT let them hold your hand, as they then say you have bought something from them. NOT very nice. Walking straight through the town that was the worst bit of our Paris trip. We walked VERY fast to get out of the area.

Fabulous . Could have stayed all day! Even though it's very touristy we still felt we were in the true Paris. We also stayed near so popped up a couple of evenings and just took in the atmosphere while people watching!

Quaint Area.... We visited Montmartre after visiting the Cathedral. We didn't love the smells of the area at all (trash / urine); but the square itself was pretty and watching all of the artists was absolutely a good time! There are plenty of cafes along the way; and it definitely has a cozy feel. Not sure I would go out of the way to return next time in Paris - but if you have never been before, you should definitely have it on your list! Be careful for pick pockets in this area for sure...
The place to be. I want to live there. Artistic quarter of Paris. Nice hills and vineyards, great food and wine. I could get used to it

Montmartre walking tour and Musee Orsay Tickets. We utilized Discoverwalks.com to book a walking tour of Montmartre (the area where many of the Impressionists lived, worked, and partied) that included skip-the-line Musee d'Orsay tickets. The walking tour of Montmartre was very, very nice. Our guide took us through the neighborhoods where the painters lived, recounted colorful stories of what happened at various venues, and took us to locations not frequented by tourists. Unfortunately, the original studies where many of the Impressionists lived and worked (Bateau Lavoir) was destroyed by fire in 1965. However, it has been rebuilt and there is a plaque on the building. The building is not accessible to the public. The tour also takes you to the location of two of the remaining windmills from the 19th century. Windmills were famous gathering spots for picnics and later breweries and cafes. You will be taken to the Moulin de la Galette, the setting for one of Renoir's famous paintings. The tour ends at a lovely garden behind Sacra Coeur that affords you a beautiful vista of the church and is a great location to take selfies. The garden itself is very nice and is away from the tourist crush. After the tour you may wish to go to a nice local cafe, or even the Moulin de la Galette (although it is priced for tourists). We chose to walk to the front of Sacra Coeur and take in the great view of the city from this vantage.After lunch or a snack, with your Muse d'Orsay tickets in hand, go and enjoy the art there. We were fortunate enough to attend on a weekend when the museum was punctuating the art with musicians of all kinds. Of course, in the Impressionist room, it was string quartets. It was a lovely atmosphere. But even without the musical performances, seeing the great works of art is stunning.

Energetic Place. An area full of energy, restaurants and artists with amazing talent!You can visit for a break on a shopping spree day but can be really bad if it rains, unfortunately the day we visited it had rained and was really annoying
Lovely, quaint marketplace. Lovely little bistrots, cafes and shops around. Wonderful to ramble around with views of Sacre Coeur.

Awful experience . After visiting the church on the hill we decided to walk down the hill.
We got lost and couldn't find our way out.
Nobody helped. Taxi drivers ignoring us.Awful frightening experience for my husband who uses a wheelchair and myself.

Could spend hours watching the Artists!. We could have spent hours just walking round and watching the Artists sketching people as they were sat there for there own personal pictures. Well worth a gander.

Quaint and charming! . Even though it was a little out of town we love staying up in Monmarte. you really get a feeling of the true Paris and if you can find a hotel with a few high floors you can look out over the whole city and see Sacre Coure in the distance. just walking the streets and taking pictures of all the charming food vendors and little stalls is enough to make an afternoon complete, in addition to sampling the delicious pastries that are everywhere. Very romantic!

A lively place!. There are lots of restaurants, souvenir shops, ice cream parlors, bakeries in the area as well as night clubs. Sketch artists, painters, living statue, singers greet you as you walk the hilly streets of Montmartre.

Beautiful stores and restaurants along the way to the hill.. The famous site was not so impressive. The place looked so tacky and almost looked like a set for a movie. But the small stores and houses were beautiful.
A must visit. . Great day out. Pleasant walk. Great artist showing their wares. Nice cafes. Street entertainers. Montmartre is a must place to visit.
Loved our stay. This was a first trip for both of us and we couldn't have stayed in a better area. People are friendly and very helpful, food is good and location is perfect.
Definitely get to this burg in Paris. Such a mixture of things to see. Sacré-Cœur church, a Renoir museum, an artists square, the last vineyard in Paris. Many little eateries to try.
Love it!. Outstanding and full of excitement everytime I visit this place! Love walking around and checking out the art work and some really nice restaurants here!

Beautiful historic section of Paris. I enjoyed riding the funiculare, a sort of mountain elevator, to get to the top of Montmartre. It is a beautiful, historic area with ancient buildings and cobblestone streets.

Disappointed . Maybe my expectations were too high. From the moment we stepped off the bus we experienced a very different kind of Paris, one grittier and less welcoming. Walking up to the top of Sacre Couer we were accosted by a group of Men who lined themselves up on both sides of the walkway so you had to walk past them to reach the top of the hill where the church sits. They insisted on grabbing you to show you a bracelet they wanted to make for you. All this is probably a ruse to take your money. They held onto both my husbands and my arms. My husband told them to let go and they refused. He had to yell at them and then they acted offended. Police were everywhere for security reasons, just not in that location till our decent which helped. The view was beautiful from the top but between that experience and the numerous attempts to divert our attention with requests to buy iPhones and "do you speak English" we were on edge to keep our possessions on our persons. We ended our visit to the neighborhood on a worse note, someone tried to pick pocket my 6ft 250lb husband while we boarded the metro. He did not take too kindly to this and grabbed the thief, pulling him back onto the train where the guy dropped the phone and my husband proceeded to shame him. Maybe this was just a random experience but we will never step foot into that part of Paris again. There are too many other wonderful neighborhoods to visit.

Lovely place. After visiting the sacre coeur it was also a delight to wander around this lovely old area of Paris. Fantastic little shops added to a great atmosphere. Lots of tourist shops too..but every area has those. Stay at the top of the hill to see the best of this lovely area.
Such a beautiful area..a must see. A must when visiting Paris, the artist area has beautiful views, gorgeous cafes and lovely shops. Great walk up the hill and down.
Always something going on. Montmartre is a wonderful locale; full of life, art, food.... always something going on. can get a bit crowded and great place for pick pocketers.

Montmartre......, A very nice area to visit.. You simply fall in love with this place, it is really different from Modern Paris. You can enjoy the great atmosphere while strolling in its narrow streets, watching artists selling their paints, having your portrait painted or just by sitting at any of the restaurant at place du Tertre to have lunch or a cup of coffee. Tips: for your portrait, bargain as much as you can.....Visit it..... you won't regret

Wonderful place but we got harassed . This is wonderful place with great view. You can walk up the hill or take the sky ride, both very fun. We didn't like that some people who are selling some kind of bracelets didn't leave us alone, they were very aggressive towards tourists which ruined a bit our experience

Views, views,views. A must go to place when visiting Paris for the first time. Apart from 360* views of the city, the artists square is so typically French, and some great quality works to be seen. Wander through the old town streets, people watch while having lunch in one of the many bistros and cafes, and just soak up Paris!

A stroll through the Bohemian neighborhood of Paris. I began my 4 hours stroll through Montmartre on a Monday afternoon coming from the Anvers metro station. After a couple of minutes stop at Maison Georges Larnicol on Rue de Steinkerque for a macarons treat ( 6 pieces for 4 Euro) I payed a 90 minutes visit to the Basilique du Sacré-Coeur, which you can get either by stairs or by a funicular (the cost is one metro ticket). Passying by the St. Pierre de Montmartre Church in Rue de Eleuthere, I took a walk through the Place du Tertre, the headquarters of French street artists, went North on Rue des Saules to see the Clos Montmartre and the famous cabaret „Au Lapin Agile”, got up the stairs to Rue Girardon to reach the Place Dalida, continued on Rue Girardon to the crossroad with Rue Norvans where „Le Passe-Muraille”, Jean Marais` sculpture passing a wall is located (Place Ayme). At the South end of Rue Girardon I found „Le Moulin de la Galette”, the oldest mill in Montmartre painted by Renoir, Picasso and Lautrec, housing today a restaurant, then going South I entered the Rue d`Orchampt looking for the house where Dalida lived for almost 15 years. After a stop for a beer at „Le relais de la Butte”, walking on Rue Ravignan I got on Rue des Abbesses. To the left I found the Rictus Square, where the Wall of Love was erected. Turning right on Rue des Abbesses I got to Pigalle and the Moulin Rouge, where my tour to Montmartre came to its end. It was a walk to remember.

Favorite place in Paris!!. Already listed in my favorite place in Paris, though not yet been to somewhere else. Too comfortable, you can see the city view of Paris from this little tall hill of Montmartre. Pretty relaxing walking through those streets, or just sit outside a café and enjoy the sunshine, watching people passing by.A must-visit if you like scenery, just don't forget to take care of your belongings while enjoy the beautiful panorama.

Best area in Paris. We booked an Hotel right in Place de Clichy, and we didn't regret it! The area is so vibrant and lively that you feel like you want to spend all your time over there. I would definitely recommend to eat in one of the lovely and delicious brasserie in Rue Lapic, do shopping in Rue des abbeses and pay a visit to pere lachaise cemetery and Le moulin de la Galette!

Montmartre is Paris. If I ever come back to Paris, I will spend more than one day in Montmartre and even find a place to stay in this particular part of the city. It is magical. I think it is what actually Paris is supposed to be. In my opinion, if you want to feel the real spirit of the (old) Paris, forget Eiffel Tower, Champs Elysees and other typical stops on the tourist routes and spend some time walking aroud Montmartre, stop for a croissant or a cup of coffee at Place du Tertre, or just sit on the steps of the Sacre Coeur and watch the people that pass by. Just don't get tricked by the guys who knit some bracelets that cost 20 euros ;)

Paris a l' ancien!. Monmartre is a journey back in time! Being there you feel like walking in the old Paris, visitng cafes or restaurants, eating crepes, enjoying the magnificent view from the top or visiting the famous Sacre Coeur. Very touristic, yet is it THE must see!

art is in the air. I didn't asked to be painted by the artists (who were practically everywhere) but I did enjoy to see how they work, and the artworks they are selling at the shops. A unique experience.
Must see. An absolutely must see spot in Paris. The scenery is spectacular and the inside of the cathedral is great. Do walk around and enjoy the historic streets and squares. Lovely,

Very artistic place. Montmartre is a very artistic place where you can find the road full of painters. The church is one of the most beautiful in the world and the scenery from there is very nice.I highly recommend it.

Love this place. Took this tour with our cruise. Love this place. Got our homemade macaroon's here. They were gone before we even got back to the hotel. Beautiful archietechure. Went into several churches. Strolling down the side streets was the fun part. Can't wait to come back again
Sacre Coeur. This to me is one of the most beautiful views of Paris. Take a bus up to the Sacre Coeur, enjoy the little streets and take in the view from the top over looking the city.

Great to see such talent!. We came here twice in three days, just to watch the artists and the world go by. The painters are there working on pieces, and often are happy to chat (in broken English/French/hand gestures) about their work. Just around the corner from Sacre Coeur, it is a beautiful spot on top of Paris...

Didn't Live Up To Its Reputation. I was sort of surprised at how underwhelmed I was by Montmartre. I expected... I don't know, something more artsy? I guess I just missed it, or maybe Montmartre has just changed.

Mount of Mars. Pablo Picasso, Vincent Van Gogh and Salvodar Dali had been there, would you like to know what they had seen? Apart from being popular place for artist like above, this place has been captured in many hit films as well. Go there at evening and sit like a painter on the lawn and take some pictures of the city (in my opinion, better view than from top of Eiffel Tower). The other thing you can do is take a walk inside the Basilica of the Sacred Heart of Jesus on top of this hill. And, while walking around that area, do visit a nearby restaurant Le Bouillon Chartier on 7 Rue du Faubourg Montmartre. You can taste authentic French delicacies and have some good wine too.
Very nice. Very nice views, walks & art. Really really liked the art in the square up the huge hill at Montmartre. Got a caricature done & it was amazing.
it's soo touisteeee. Great shops but lots just for tourists - less is more.Well worth a visit though as it has amazing views and beautiful buildings
lovely view from the top of the hill. incredibly busy and full or "artists" pestering people to have their silhouettes cut out from black paper. restaurants in the locality are incredibly expensive.

Historical Arty Touristy. A great little area of Paris, see the highlights of Paris from the view of the hill walk around cobbled streets. Yes it's full of street sellers offering to do your portraits but it is the art section of Paris so you would expect that! They a jovial you either stop and have it done or just walk on. Beautiful church on the hill and lots of other things to do which you would have to get off the normal tourist track. I liked it.

The artistic side of Paris. Every time I went to Paris, I always asked myself " What's the fuss with Paris and art?" Also, Paris, for me, doesn't look French anymore. Then I stumbled in Montmarte.A lot of stuff could be seen in Montmarte. First, you would see Sacré-Cœur here, then Place Du Tetre were artist gathered and they could paint you, Le Chat noir and the Lapin Agile cabarets were located here, so as Moulin Rouge in Pigalle and many more.You will not run out of things to see in Montmatre. Just be careful with pickpockets and scammers. Be careful with things you are "signing" and things that you are "touching" (from Hawkers).In Pigalle, be careful with "live shows". They prey on tourist a lot. There modus operandi is they will offer "cheap" shows then once you are in, they will charge you with ridiculous amount of money. So if you hear someone calls you and invites you inside a stipper club, be weary.

Spectacular views and fun to walk up all those stairs! . Put your walking shoes on and climb the 150+ stairs instead of waiting for the funicular. The views are worth it to overlook all of Paris. We went on a weekday in January so there were no crowds but locals told us it is packed and very crowded-in the summer months. There is a spooky crypt if you walk underneath.

Touristy but in a French Way. I think the trick to enjoying Montmartre is to wander off the main streets and find the hidden gems that not all the tourists are finding. A beautiful historic area with great views and a great buzz. Spend at least one day there.

Reserve enough time. The area has so many options so give yourself several hours. Sacre Coeur (sacred), Pigale (profane), the artists' squares at the very top of the hill next to Sacre Coeur, the restaurants, and even a couple of carousels for the kids. Lots of typical tourist stores filled with Eiffel Towers, t-shirts, and chapeaus made in China. What a mix.
A perfect day-tour in Paris. This area in Paris is definitely worth your visit. It is a lot calmer than the rest of the city. Small stands and cozy cafées. Take a day to explore Montmartre

Art centre of Paris. If you are wanting art in Paris - this is where to go. There are street artists everywhere! And if you don't have time to stop for a portrait you can purchase ready made drawings and paintings of the sights of Paris that are fabulous.
Bustling square. The monte Marte is well worth a visit to pick up some beautiful original Parisian art work. A bustling square filled with artists, surrounded by small gift shops and cafes.

Arstistic Environment. If you love arts this is your place! Everything is there! One of the most charming places in Paris. I could not point out anything special there just the place. Go there just for walk is already a nice experience.

Paradise of art lovers!. A must visit for any art lovers and also for common travellers this place has loads of tale to tell. Starting from the stories of wind-mills to Monet and then to Picasso, surly those will thrill you for your interest in art and legendary artists. Famous film Amelie was shoot mostly in this area. Must spend some time in the famous cafe here.
Beautiful. Like a picture postcard being painted by one of the many budding artists who gather in the area. Quaint bistros, cafes, and patisseries surround.

Unique area in Paris with great views. This is a great area of Paris. It is filled with unique shops, restaurants and artists. This area also has a great view of Paris and has the famous Sacre Coeur Church. This area is a must see when in Paris!

Disappointed. This was really the most god awful touristy place I saw in Paris. For one, the basilica is not that great and secondly the streets are jammed with annoying tourists and like, six hundred bums trying to draw your picture. Would not recommend

Montmarte / Paris. Some years ago I visit Montmartre, it's like a village in the heart of Paris (Place du Tertre)On the hill I had an overlooking of Paris. I visit the Sacré Coeur basilica, she is in a romano/byzantine style, is made in limestone, is a dazzling whitness, so you see it on allhill every where. To get on the hill I choose to climb the pleasant stairs in front of the church among romantic garden. On the place du "Tertre" with spirit "Titi parisien", it'sthe birth of many great artistic painters etc. (Futurisme and Surrealisme)It was nice to drink a coffee on a terrace near Sacré Coeur, it's a different atmosphere as in Paris, I feel me in a quiet nice old village
Lovely views of Paris. I enjoy visiting this area to walk around, see the Basilica, enjoy the views and shop. At Christmas time, the decorations are beautiful, as is true throughout Paris.
A Must when In Paris!. This area the artist's area, has lovely windy streets and as you climb up, the view of Paris gets better and better. Don't miss the Basilica and museum of Montmartre.
Worth the climb. This is a fantastic part of Paris full of lovely little shops and restaurants, walk through this of your way to the sacre cour and take in the view over Paris. Not to be missed

Beautiful Area . Montmartre was right near our hostel so on our first day in Paris myself and my sister decided to go for a walk and see the area.
Really beautiful ! The local artists are just incredible in the square ! Really one of my favourite places in Paris.
FULL OF CHARM. We had the perfect day as in the sun was shining and the sky was deep blue so the views over Paris were outstanding

Great place to explore. It was rainy and chilly but we still enjoyed our time wandering around. Ate at a nice cafe near the Basilica but wished we had explored a little more because later we saw some intriguing place down small side streets. Great chocolate shops!

Ok Shopping District. But mostly it was a poor area. Like the hood. I didnt like this area except for the bargain sales I got but I didnt feel safe in this area so I left just as quickly as I entered.

The quarter to be in Paris. Explore all the little streets in montmartre village and you might find a statue of dalila, an improvised theater stage, a street-art exhibition in the dali museum and so much more. Enjoy So-Pi and its boutique hotels and bars. Enjoy Montmartre.

The artist's way. Loved it! If you want to get inspired, see artists and their works in the street, and get the vibrant Parisian vibe, but also the silence of a church, go to Montmartre and then end you journey in Sacre Coeur. From the top you can see a panorama of the city - and if the weather is good it will be fantastic. I just loved how the artsy energy blended with the travellers in that neighborhood. Interesting thing was that you could spot old cabarets in some places.

Far from its artistic past. A famous hill in the northern part of the city, well-known for being the home and a gathering place of many artists through the years. Even today you can find the traces of an authentic village atmosphere, but mostly the place is congested with street vendors, tourists and pickpockets.

Best part of Paris. We did a walking food tour around this area, and I quickly fell in love with it. If you take the time to do a walking tour of this area, you will see why. It is a chock full of delicious artisan chocolateries, boulangerie's/bakeries, fromageries and much more. This is also where the gorgeous Sacre Coer is location, and is well worth the visit. Stunning from the outside and the view of Paris from up there is sensational. Add it to your Paris itinerary. You will not regret it!
Lovely location to wander in. We took a walking tour of Montmatre emphasizing Impressionism. It was definitely worth it. Started at Moulin Rouge and ended at Sacre Coeur.

Not great!. Went during a mid-day week. Found the whole area a bit seedy, and full of tourist tat shops and not so great places to eat. Some pretty aggressive tourist touts/pickpockets as well! Definitely watch your pockets.

Lovely area to wander. So much to wander round and discover artists studios in the little roads of Montmartre. Amazing views from Sacre Coeur. Little artists studios. yes you get a little bit of harassment form the portrait artists in the square but easily handled with some friendly banter. Look out for the hot chocolate with chilli and spices 'brewed' by an amazing contraption at a stall by the top op the quake in the church courtyard - like something out of a film set.
Very good place for tourist. Its good place for tourist use the taxi to go there try crepe thereIts so deliciousGood place for artist not safe at night

bohemian Paris at its best. when you go there, you must see Sacred Cuore church ,you can climb 220 steps or take funicular, after it , walk on the small side streets, where Hemingway and S. Fitzgerald walked before, lots of artists and small cafes, be careful with your belongings though , carry your bag in front of you , check your surroundings at all times , but is mainly safe , get a hand painted portrait on the square , worth the money , unique experience , dring hot wine

Has a lot of history but just do not love it. I want to love Montmartre; my parents used to come here in the 60s and 70s and it sounded like so much fun. But when I come now (and the other times I have been to Paris in the past 10 yrs), I find it so touristy and inauthentic. Worth seeing Sacre Coeur, but could easily miss the rest.

Best Neighborhood in Paris. This neighborhood in the 18th Arrondissement is my favorite in Paris, and my only regret was not having more time to explore this area. It's the highest point in the city and without a doubt, carries its own aura and character. It looks like a small village with its windy roads, narrow alleys, cobbled streets, and Old World feel. There are plenty of cafes, restaurants, and shops to occupy a full day here, so stroll around the district and visit the famous Sacre-Coeur Cathedral atop the hill. To get here, the nearest metro station is Abbesses on Line 12. If you plan on using the metro frequently--which isn't a necessity because Paris is a fairly walkable town--buy a carnet of 10 metro tickets for 14.10 euros, rather than paying 1.80 euros for each ticket individually. The 1-Day Mobilis tickets (for unlimited 24-hr use of public transit) are only economical if you plan on using public transportation more than 4 trips per day since it costs 7 euros.

Artists all over. Avery trendy area close to basilica Sacre Ceur and with the cemetry where lots of important writers have been burried. Many galeries of different stiles together with lots of restaurants and bars. A must to every Paris visitor.
Lovely area. What an area to walk around, breath in Paris with it's ambience, fine eating and drinking, art and views. Lovely stuff.

Oooooohlala..... Think Paris rooftops and skyline.Think early morning cafe au lait and pain au chocolat.Think Amelie.Think Monsieur Lautrec, Modigliani, etc etc.Think Paris in springtime.Think Bohemia.Think Mimi in La Boheme.A truly wonderful place.

Great for art and people watching. My husband and I went to Montmartre and had a lovely afternoon there. Many years ago my husband had a bowl of French Onion Soup in a small cafe there and was determined to find it again if it was possible. Well we actually found it right on painters square and of course he had his soup which was great and I had the beef stew which was also really nice. Meanwhile a very persistent gentleman wanted to do my portrait and after a couple of glasses of wine I finally gave in! He actually did a wonderful job and spent about a 45 minutes while I was munching away. You will be pestered if you venture into this area but he really did an excellent job so I can not complain. A small word of warning, there is a stairway and also a hillside tram that takes you to below Sacre Coeur. We took the stairway to try to find a cab back to our hotel. This area is not really great and made me very nervous walking around there so we found a cafe and got them to ring for a cab. I definitely would not be comfortable walking around this area at night as it is a tourist magnet and as a result attracts a lot of seedy characters.

Romantic place for dinner. I came here in Oct so the air was a bit chilling. Montmartre offered me great view over Paris city. I had a lovely dessert in a local restaurant and had my portrait painted by a Hungarian painter who later told me about his early life before he became a street painter for a living.

Spectacular. The view from this area is fantastic. Especially if you go to Basilica of the Sacré-Cœur. Definitely worth hiking up the hill for. Amazing side streets, arts, music and of course beautiful photo opportunities. Definitely worth heading over early in the morning before the crowds arrive. Highly recommend this area. Just so pretty.

My favorite area in Paris. Can't decide what's the best - the shops, the food, the restaurants, climbing the hill to Sacre Couer, or just being in a fun but also residential area of Paris - would love to live here for a year or more!

Quirky, fun and I liked it. It's lively, quirky fun, original and I think it's all neat. We enjoyed strolling the area and checking out the different stores, restaurants. If you want something a little different then check this area out.

Loved Montmarte!. I loved this area. It touched the artistic heart and gave one a taste of old Paris. Loved Sacre Coeur. The area below Sacre Coeur was a fabric district which I loved. The view from Sacre Coeur was stunning. I will be sure to spend more time there.

Magical Montmartre, the "Mount of Martyrs". Montmartre, located in the heart of the 18th Arrondissement (district) is a most beautiful experience for the mind body and spirit. As you approach the town the rich architectural and historical ambiance captivates your senses. This is a special place. As you stroll up the main street lined with shops, cozy restaurants and boutiques your eyes lock in on the Towering Majesty of the 12th century Sacre-Coeur Basilica Church which reflects the sun rays by day and glows in the moonlight from high atop Mountmartre. As you approach, a sea of what seems to be endless stairs unfold cascading upward in stages to the top. If you are a strong stair climber enjoy the trek, if not hop on the incline car and motor your way up while enjoying the views. At the top, the Architectural Majesty of the Sacre- Coeur and the 360 Panoramic Views are Heavenly! You can tour the magnificent interior and or stay for Mass. Easy to get to by bus and then some walking. Bus 30 ,31, 80 or 85 all stop at the foot of the Church.

Adorable part of Paris with great views. Everyone must make a trip to Montmartre when in Paris. The Sacre Couer is beautiful and there are stunning views of Paris. Beware of the men outside the church though. They try to put a bracelet on you and then make you buy it.

Lovely place. I love visiting Montmartre which is very bohemian. Wander around and look at the artists painting, the lovely side streets, the view from in front of the Sacre Couer and maybe ride the funicular. There are some lovely restaurants too.
Very atmospheric.. I wanted to sit with a black rollneck sweater and a cigarette holder in a gloomy bar, writing the definitive twenty-first century novel.
Old Paris. Gives you that old Paris feeling that you've seen in the movies. Plenty of great places to eat and a lot of places to visit.

Walk through the area for art.. This is a beautiful part of Paris. Sacre Coeur is the major attraction of this area. Streets around are full of sketch artists, galleries, small shops and some good food. One can spend a morning nicely by just wandering around the area.

My Favorite. Montmartre was one of my absolute favorite places us France. It was a lurks slice of heaven. The was so much to see and do. I couldn't possibly name all of the exciting things that make this a spectacular place to visit. Well worth it! !
Too much fun to pass up!!. Walk the streets, admire the arts and the artists still making, sample the food, and drink in the atmosphere. This is a area not to be missed!!

nothing special. maybe because its winter,or because it was raining,or because i come from a country with very special places(Greece) and i am used to see very beautiful spots....Monmartre was a disappointment

Always an inspiration. Was there today. Spent some time viewing artists work around the place du Tetra. Then visited all the other galleries and museums in the neighborhood. Quite an inspirational day if you are interested in art. The Dali espace was amazing and is a must see.

Great fun atmosphere just remember about the hills. Great tourist locations with amazing views over paris atmosphere is fun and lievley even in the middle of winter.
Definitly worth a visit

Just wander and take in the experience. A beautiful part of Paris next to the Sacre-Coeur. This is a nice place to wander and see the street artists and take it the views of the city from the front of the Sacre-Coeur. The Dali museum is here as well.

A nice place to visit. Once you have seen the Church, you must visit this part of the village, which is called; Montmartre. You would be impressed by the nice artists who are gathered there to make their living through the market of live painting of the visitors.
Educational. Another "must see" when in Paris. Took my wife and three children ranging in age from mid-teens to 22 years old. Very easy to get to from the Eiffel Tower.

great views from the top. if you go to Sacre Cour, the views ara amazing. use the funecular. i htough we could use the metro ticket, but apparently we could not and had to get new ones. on the way down there were some extremely cheap places and people were going crazy... it was a bit dirtier than I remembered...

Impressive!. We visited at night and the view of Paris from the plaza in front of Sacre-Coeur there was beautiful. Sacre-Coeur itself is so impressive. The main stairway is well-lit, so walkers can navigate it easily.

Cultured and classy . A gorgeous little strip of Paris which reminds you of its yummy baked goods, markets and culture. A must do and definitely on an empty stomach so you can sample as many yummy treats. Will be back for more.
Very cozy day trip. It is worth it to make a trip through this area of the city and experience one of the cozier parts of Paris, amidst the modern shops and such things. Very beautiful

Best Place in the Entire City. We booked our Christmas getaway if Montmartre and upon arrival on Christmas Eve, we fell in love with the place.A lovely bohemian atmosphere filled with artists, writers, musicians, cafes, culture and Christmas Cheer.We spent hours just wandering down narrow cobbled streets and popping into cost little haunts popular with locals and tourists alike.Highlights for us were The Wall of Love and Montmartre Cemetery both worth a visit.

Sacre Couer and so much more. I really like this section of Paris - it used to be just outside the city limits and a place where people went to have fun and avoid the laws of the city. Many restaurants and bars, many that have been in place for hundreds of years and were hang outs for famous artists. There is a very active art community and you can wander around a square and watch them create their masterpieces and buy one if you like.

Great vibe, amazing neighborhood!. Montmartre is such a beautiful neighborhood full of restaurants, cafes, art, and great vibes. It is unique in a sense of the diverse travelers and locals that visit this district. One of my favorite hang out spots in the summer weekends.

Absolutely lovely. We loved Montmartre, it is definitely our favourite area of Paris and I'd recommend a trip there to anyone visiting this fabulous city. The whole atmosphere is just different up there, the restaurants are lovely, the artists doing their thing was so nice to see and experience and the views down to Paris were amazing over the rooftops of Parisian houses, it reminded me of the aristocats Disney film! Loved it.
Over looking the city. So much is happening here. Artist busy with painting and drawing, great place to buy something that catches your eye, enjoy the view. awesome view of the city.
Great Visit!. If you go to Paris, visiting Montmartre is a must! Do not miss out on such a great experience! Great views throughout!

A beautiful part of Paris that is a must see.. We were there in the spring at dusk. The view of Paris was remarkable. There were too many cafes to count. Take a walk up and down the streets until you settle on one. We found a traditional French restaurant were we had both frog's legs and escargot. A memorable evening!

Artist square and restaurants. Grab a glass of wine and look at some art. The cobble stone streets are teeming with artists. I've never been one to get a portrait done but. Did here and it was worth every penny. What am experience. I took my time in choosing an artist that had the right style and he did a fabulous job.

Montmarte is a Must. Walking around Montmarte on your own is OK and we did that on our first visit. On our second visit, we booked a small group walking tour through Viator. The tour was a two hour walk around the Montmarte area with an English speaking guide. He provided facts and history and then concluded the trip at the top of Montmarte for us to enjoy on our own. It was perfect.
Must see area!. This is a very nice area. Cobble stone roads, neat shops, cafes, bars. The area is a bit hilly in parts so be prepared for a workout. I would come back here again.

The best place to be in Paris. Montmartre is a peaceful and calm neighborhood that you can get in touch with a lot of tourists in Sacre Coeur or just walk by Rue des Abbesses looking to its stores and nices cafes. It really worths the visit, day and night.

Picture perfect. Art and history merge here. The area was a bit seedy some years ago, but it has been cleaned up. It is now a magical place to wonder through, enjoying art, architecture, and fabulous food side by side.

Beautiful!. This is a beautiful place to go on a clear day! Be prepared for crowds and act accordingly! Be sure to NOT FALL FOR THE SHELL GAME SWINDLERS on the streets. They are all part of a gang. When no one is betting one of the gang will throw money down and will win. We watched those individuals move from game to game and then walk away together. They must make a lot of money because there were lots of them!

One of the most beautiful places in Paris!!!. Visiting Montmartre and the Sacre Cour was one of the most beautiful experiences of our trip to Europe. This place is surrounded by art, by History, by artists that make it unique...The main square where you can find artists painting portraits, the shops full of original art, the cafes, bakeries and the spectacular view of Paris and the surroundings... The amazing church of the Sacre Cour... You must visit this place during your trip to Paris!

An interesting artist center. This district in Paris is full of artists, and also gift shops! Don't let the shops distract you from the atmosphere and quaintness of the area. You can also visit the Basilica of Sacre Coeur from there.

Quaint little area. Everyone should spend some time hanging around Montmartre. You must climb many stairs or take the Funicular to Montmartre.Lots of artist are painting in the square and there are great shops and a vineyard.
Know it well , used to work in an art gallery.. Lost some of it's charm from the old days, due to being pestered by SDF people. Great for tourist, good views of Paris.

When the bohemien inside you comes out. All around you, you can feel the art calling out. Artist everywhere painting in completely different styles, colourful restaurants and bars. Ok, I am aware that mostly it is for the tourists but for me it was amazing. And the best macarons ever....

bought some watercolor art. we decided to buy ourselves some art in montemarte. after walking through the various galleries, we stopped at the artists square. there are a lot of hassling artists trying to do your portraits, but we just said no and walked on. we stopped by a quiet lady who was busy with watercolor, and after thoroughly inspecting it, we bought 3. we then walked around and walked through the tourist shops. there seem to be a few dodgy characters doing little magic tricks etc in the busy street leading up to sacre coeur, but we just walked on. i have heard that this is a pickpocket hot spot so be aware.

Charming little place full of artists.... Lovely place full of artists, you can have a funny or serious portret of yourself. A moment to rest after climbing high to Sacre Cour and after super view over Paris. This is something you really have to see in Paris! That is why take a break here is also nice!
A must. Even if the locals are missing, it is full of artist and you feel like a true parisian. The view is great too.

True Beauty. The old paris a true gem and a foodies dream. incredibly beautiful and a must see. The views from the top are amazing you can see the whole of Paris. Make sure you pick up the award winning baguette form the bakery that came 1st in the whole of Paris.

1st of January!. Beautiful place, lovely view of Paris from the Cathedral of Sacre Coeur. We also took the little train that goes around Sacre Coeur and Montmartre streets showing all the historical places. A lots of artists offering portraits, restaurants and cafes. It is crowded so keep an eye on your wallet!

This is Paris. This is actually a very large section of Paris, but is mainly centered around Sacre Couer, and Place Pigalle. It has an elevation gain of over 400feet so bring your walking shoes. Loaded with shops, eateries and artists, some of whom will sketch your likeness for €50+\-. This is the Paris the way Lautrec and Renoir saw it, and the way it is shown in movies.

I love this place, but it was hard to excite the teenagers. I find this the most mesmerising part of Paris. I love it. So evocative of days gone by, little lanes and little bits of history and glitz all combined. It is a wonderful place to visit and meander, ending up looking out over the city from the basilica.But my teenage sons were quite bored....not much to interest them. Next time, I will leave them at the hotel.

Wear your hiking boots. Montmartre is one of the great places to visit in Paris-- Sacre Coeur, St. Pierre, Place Du Terte, Van Gogh's apartment. Just know that the hills are very, very steep, especially if you plan to venture beyond Sacre Coeur. The funicular helps, but you will do some hard walking if you go.
I like it except the scams.. Be sure to climb 300 steps to get to the top of the dome. Very nice view of the city.The cathedral is located at the top of a hill, so wear comfy shoes!

Lovely District. Montmarte is a must visit area if going to Paris for the first time. There are so many amazing buildings to see. It is a great place to people watch and have coffee. I loved watching the artists in the area paint. It was a great visit.

Wonderful. We did the L'Open Tour to Montmartre and loved it. We then took ourselves back via the Metro to do our own walking tour. It is a beautiful district of Paris. Such beautiful streets filled with lots of treasures. We visited the cemetery and loved the history.

Love Montmarte. I love the artsy, unpretentious vibe of Montmarte. We took a city bus and walk the rest of the time. Many great cafes and street vendors. We ate a sandwich as we walked the small streets. Artist abound in the streets asking to draw your picture. Lazarus, a kind gentleman drew an exceptional picture of us I will cherish for years to come.

Perfect place to stay!. We chose to stay in Montmartre because I was using hotel points and this is what was available. In truth, I was worried about the distance to the heart of Paris. I was wrong! Montmartre is a perfect location for exploring Paris. The heart of the city seems like it is just down the street. Montmarte has 3, very easy to access Metro stations that get you anywhere you want to be easily. We liked using the Abbesses Metro stop because the street that it is on, has so many fun restaurants and shops. So the bonus of staying in Montmartre is that not only do you have easy access to Paris but Montmarte itself is amazing. The tour buses even go through it now because it has so many interesting places to see. Montmartre is now my first choice of places to stay in Paris.

Historic area with great cafes. I enjoy walking around Montmartre since it has so much history, cafes, shops and souvenir stores all nearby. You can walk from the Moulin Rouge up towards Sacre Coeur and stop at Cafe Des Deux Moulins (Amelie was filmed here). Along the way, get fresh bread from Le Grenier a Pain and cheese from La Butte Fromagerie, both on rue des Abbesses. Pick up a bottle of wine and you are all set to have a nice picnic overlooking the city when your reach Sacre Coeur.

Paris . Great place to visit. Various ways to get up there. Would recommend anyone who has a disability or breathing ailments to go up on the little train or I think there are some sort of lifts. I have have been a few times and is a pleasant place to look at the artists or go for a coffee etc.

Absolutely amazingggggggg. My friend had been to here years ago and barely remembered how to get back. But we figured it , with maps of course. If I ever moved, I would live in this area. LOTS of stairs. The artist square was amazing. The artist Samvel, did stunning portraits of my friend and I. It was $50, but by far the best money I spent on the trip. The top of the hill with the basilica, st. peters(?), gorgeous. Hang out on the stairs, take in the view.I mean, I loved everything about Paris, but probably my favorite area.

Really romantic area. Once you visit Montmartre it stays with you forever, especially as a caricature sheet and the CD of local street musical bands (like in our case), as material things serve us to keep the sweetest memories, and what can be more exciting than to have a caricature of your crazy group of friends or a romantic portrait of a couple drawn/painted.Besides the view from the cathedral hill is gorgeous, the total area around is cozy to walk, there are enough eateries to have a bite and for lunch.
Nice place to see locals!. I loved it and all was open on the 1st of January. Nice shops and cafes! Many places to eat and sit around watching the people go by.

Walk in there footsteps. The artist colony where many of the impressionist met, talked, ate and danced. Still populated with artists you can find them all around the square selling their masterpieces.

square of fine arts. Lovely square full of painters, sketchers and performing artists.
Great combination with a visit to the Sacre Ceur church.

San Telmo, Argentina. If you have gone to Argentina, and specially visited San Telmo, youll feel like you already know montmartre, when they say buenos aires is like Paris, definitely they refeer to montmartre, the streets, the ambience, and the atmosphere is too similar, its always nice to go to the sacred heart or stroll to the garde du nord station. This district is really different from the central ones of course, but its still a very nice place to visit in paris.
Wander the streets. A lovely part of Paris to spend time just wandering about. Get a portrait drawn, have lunch and check out he beautiful views ovr the city.

One of THE most beautiful places in Paris. Absolutely amazing. One of the most beautiful places in Paris! Do not, and I mean do not, pass the strolling in this fine neighbourhood's streets. The view is absolutely stunning. Seat down and relax on one of the numerous coffee houses or restaurants this place has to offer and watch the artists in the work. Get inside one or two or three even of the art galleries or be "brave" enough and get your portrait drawn by one of the street's artists. Don't miss this place if you're in Paris, because it's simply one of Paris' best!

The BEST part of Paris! Spend a whole day here!. As a traveler, I love eye-opening experiences and Montmarte offered exactly this! Just spend an entire day walking around the streets, food tasting, and observing people & merchants. The spectrum of food, architecture, and street culture was just so surreal. The plus point is that Sacre Couer basilica is also in Montmarte so you can make that the finale for the day! Best part of my Paris trip by far!

Interesting plaxe. Although the walk up to Montmartre from the metro station is quite difficult the square with a range of different artists is lovely to look around and you get a feel for the culture. Once we reached sacre coeur we were approached by a caricaturist (Dino) who drew us for a good price and spoke very good English so had a chat while he was doing it and he was hilarious!

Almost missed it.. Our trip was coming to and in Paris, but we had about four hours to just walk wherever before our transport came to the hotel. We looked at the map and decided to walk through Montmartre. WE LOVED IT!!! This part of Paris might be my favorite. No matter what parts we come to explore next, I will always find myself back here.

Intimate Walking and Warm Food!. Classic Parisian streets and buildings. Tight beautiful streets. Intimate crowds especially on holidays. Many diners and cafes with reasonable prices. Many grocery markets and fruits sellers.In general, a very pleasant walk and dining place. Yet, it is not recommended on night.

our favorite place. Lots of hills but worth the trip up there. Artists on the square and was decorated so great for Christmas! The cemetery is really fantastic! We had dinner at Le Coq Rico which definitely requires reservations, but was a great meal.
It's a Climb!. Be prepared to walk up lots of steps! Better to take the tram up. Lots of hills but a charming neighborhood worth seeing.

Definitely Visit. I initially was underwhelmed by Paris during my New Year's visit, but this neighborhood changed my mind. Yes, do the Moulin Rouge & the church, but spend a few hours wondering around and eating the food. It's worth it!

Totally charming, paradise for artists. This is a really charming place. You get a good view of Sacre-Coeur and this area also is heaven for artists, especially for those who are painting and drawing.

Art Lovers Paradise. Montmartre may be known for its Cabrets and night life but I relate to it more for its artistic background. Place du Tertre is my favourite besides Basalica Sacre-Coeur. Small cobbled roads lined with cafes and bars can throw a surprise anytime.

Charming!. This is my favorite neighborhood in Paris. It's like you stepped into a classic Parisian painting. There are a ton of shops, restaurants, and stands all along tiny charming cobblestone streets. A MUST see!!!

Sacre-Coeur will bring you here, but there's so much more . We planned an entire day for the area as it had plenty of things we wanted to see. Sacre-Coeur is obviously a must, but there's so much more. You can easily spend an hour in place de tetre at the top of the hill. The square is filled with cafes and artists. Here you can have your portrait done by some talented artists as my daughter and wife did. Down the street there's the Dahli museum, a must for any fan. At the base of the hill my wife spent hours at a the fabric shops, flea markets and specialty shops gathering materials for her next big project. If your a designer or work in fashion this area is a must! Tips -small playground for young children at base of the park that leads up to the church.-tram will take you to the top, accepts metro tickets -small tour train (hop on/off) also tours the area. -the artists can be 'haggled'. The portraits started at €30 for a kid and €50 for my wife. We had both for €40 by the time we left. -Take a small break at the top and enjoy one of the cafes, even a Starbucks for those missing home.

Artist haven. Great place to visit. Painters are selling their pieces everywhere. Lots of touristy stuff to see and buy. Boutiques galore with many cafes and hidden spots to eat and grab a coffee of a glass of Vino!!

Lively. Its always interesting to visit Montmartre and see all the action from street performers, to food vendors, to the beautiful church. It has an atmosphere all its own. The view of Paris is fantastic.

Inspiring. Went to Montmartre today for the first time. We were on a private tour so had no problems getting up the hill. Evidently unless you are a local resident or with a tour or taxi you are not allowed to drive to the top. Fantastic views of Paris from in front of the church, and we really enjoyed watching the artists at work in the nearby artists square!
