We ended up buying each of our children a small painting as a memento! Probably the highlight of our days tour!

A wonderfully preserved, full of character, organically harmonized district still retaining the bohemian air. The more time one spends in Montmartre, the more one understands it, enjoys its many quaint streets, corners,richly decorated buildings and parcs and invariably ends up loving it. Whether one spends few hours visiting the wonderful basilique and the surrounding butte, a day getting lost in the little village rustic, bohemian atmosphere or a week waking up every day perched up admiring some of Paris' most prized vistas, Montmartre will certainly continue to inspire, reward, amaze, delight and create timeless memories.
worth visit for art enthusiastic. there is a square full of artist and their great art works. But must pay extra attention when walking around, there were a lot of pickpocket at this area!

Always come back . This is and area of Paris I love to visit by day or night. While it is small you can easily get lost in time between the cafes, restaurants, markets, shops and museum. Almost every step provides a new glimpse at a bohemian history.

Great area!. We stayed here for 3 days as part of our honeymoon and loved it here.
It was a great place for views of the Eiffel Tower and had great places to eat whilst also being close to the Moulin Rouge.
We wondered around here late at night and never felt in any danger. Would definitely stay in this location again.

Very worth some hill-climbing. Excellent panoramic view of the city when standing at Sacre-Coeur. There will be plenty of other people there to enjoy the view with, also some street vendors. Fun, hilly, side streets to stroll around. We didn’t go to most of the main tourist areas where there are restaurants and shops, just wandered around enjoying the atmosphere and trying to imagine what it must have been like in years past…

Beautiful! . If you're looking to escape the busyness of Paris, then head to Montmarte to enjoy beautiful views and amazing food. The streets are full of wonderful shops and friendly locals. We wish we spent more time in Montmarte and will defiantly return ! Best time to go is the early morning to watch the sun rise over Paris and have breakfast from one of the local patisseries.

Scare Coeur and Monte Martre. Catch metro and get off at Abysses station. Best catch funicular (cable car) which is a short walk from the station, because it's about 900 or more steps up to the Sacre Coeur! Fare for funicular included in your metro ticket.

Very nice, friendly place in Paris. Great atmosphere with some nice restaurants, best part is the artists in the middle square drawing portraits of people. It is worth doing if you have some time to kill, also some nice artwork on sale which you can get for a good figure with negotiation.

Our favorite neighborhood.... Despite the throngs of tourists marching up to Sacre Coeur, we just love this little village with its winding, picturesque streets, and tiny restaurants/bars. Plenty of tourists yes and you will get lots of exercise walking up and down the hill, but you cannot beat the charm of this neighborhood.

Awesome neighborhood . This is one of the best little neighborhoods we've found in Paris and definitely worthy a look on your way to the sacre-coeur. Lots of eateries and shops line the cute windy streets-loved it! Be warned tho, its mostly up hill!

Feels like Paris. Liked staying here in an apartment as it feels more Parisian than a touristy hotel. Easy for the metro and Sacre-Coeur. Only a few stops from everything, including the Gare du Nord, so very convenient.

MONTMARTRE IS MORE THAN THE PLACE DU TERTRE. During my recent trip to Montmartre, I ventured out to the rue des Martyrs, across the rue des Abbesses and found a village I loved. In a place where part of Truffaut's 400 BLOWS was filmed, I fell in love with the neighborhood and plan to return on next trip. Don't miss it! I came home and immediately read THE ONLY STREET IN PARIS: the rue des Martyrs

Tourist Mecca but do it once.. This is the neighborhood of all of the bohemian scene of all the Hollywood movies if the 40's, 50's, and 60's. Quaint cafes, artists painting in the street, neat little buildings that Gene Kelly danced in front of. And of course the Moulin Rouge. It's all here. There is also a sleezier side with the sex shops and peep shows but that's pretty limited. Just know, it's a tourist trap. Guard your wallet, avoid the scammers and if you buy something know you've paid too much. Enjoy!

Fun and local. I have been here a couple timesThis year I had a artist sketch me which is common among the touristThan I visit TATE which is a huge store that locals shop at You can fine absolutely everything here !!!
Our favorite. The best location to be when visiting paris. Montmartre has it all. So many good places to eat, things to do and see. Centrally located, it is perfect for tourists

Wouldn't recommend. While the views are lovely and the back streets can be charming I would not recommend this area for a visit.On our arrival we walked up to the church only to be accosted by a group of African men who tried to tie strings to our wrists. When I refused they grabbed me very painfully and despite my yelling and obvious discomfort they would not let me go, and no one came to help. It took all my strength to get away from them and I was quite sore from their rough grasp. Meanwhile my husband was surrounded by them and couldn't help me either. It was an unpleasant experience to say the least. The rest of the area is full of hawkers and cheap outlets, and was not really worth the metro ride out there. I would definitely NOT recommend this place for solo travelers as it would be quite scary.

Monmartre is the artist's hill in Paris and one of my favorite stops in the city!. The hilltop provides incredible views of the city with an artsy, relaxing feel. Take the metro to Anvers M (line 2) then up Rue de Steinkerque which is a steep short street to either climb the many stairs up the hill or ride the Funiculaire Monmartre- Station Superierure cable car to the top if you prefer. We chose to walk the narrow, steep stairs and found it fun, if work, to get to the top. However, if you need a break there are many little rest stops along the way in the form of bars and restaurants with a couple of funny guiding remarks carved into the step fronts on the way up. At the top is Sacre Couer/Sacred Heart Basilica and if you follow the path around and slightly uphill, the artist's village. There is a square of sorts with painters and artwork displayed throughout as well as a few meandering cobble stone streets to explore. This is a great area to take a sidewalk table to peoplewatch while you eat. We chose a restaurant in the midst of the square. While touristy in pricing, the awnings and atmosphere were great and we enjoyed a late afternoon lunch in the shade before shopping the artist's displays. Once you have enjoyed the atmosphere and character of the artist's venue, move to the front of the Basilica down the front steps to enjoy the view with a pleasant plaza, park and path meandering down the hill you climbed earlier in the day.There are many natives and tourists enjoying pleasant afternoons in this plaza area so take a moment, sit on the steps and enjoy the view and good weather!

Take a stroll through a park on a hill and enjoy the view and atmosphere. The Monte-Matre is essentially a little Park on a hill surrounded by some other sightseeing jewels such as historic churches (Sacre coeur) on top of it. Every house in Paris around the monte-matre is build with a certain allowed number of levels in this area - this enables one to see quit far and make out other (historic) high rising buildings on the other end of the city - when viewing down at it from the top.

Nice Neighborhood. We went there after we saw Sacre coeur. It is a very nice quarter with lots of restaurants, shops, and a lot of activities happening during the day. Take your time for a nice walk and discover many hidden treasures and attractions in the area.

Watch the Artists Work. In a courtyard near Sacre Cour, look for the artists who will do caricatures, silhouettes, or portraits of you or your family (even from a photo). Also fun to shop their work and buy directly from the artists themselves. Tubes are available for purchase to protect your pieces. Beware of pickpockets and go in the daylight.

13-Year Old Son's Favorite! Has a Life of Its Own. . Montmartre, especially the area right to the left of the church (when facing), has a life and buzz of its own. Recommend going on a day you sleep late - get there in the late afternoon so you can see the church, overlook Paris by day, and then overlook it by night (not to mention the sunset). The artists on the block are ever-changing. Ignore the hustlers to draw your portrait - the good ones don't have to hustle if you want it done. The little shops range from unique to tourist commercial (would have been nice if they zoned to protect this area from commercial tourist shops). Great place to buy gifts however. Lots of good, cheap restaurants if you walk away from the block or if you love people-watching then go for one On the block. From the RER Abbesses, take the first street to the left (Yvonne). Go 3-4 short blocks to a glass greenhouse looking structure for the funacle or stairs (on left). You metro pass works for the funacle (lift). BEWARE OF THE PICKPOCKETS - one of the most "worked" areas in Paris. They are very, very skilled in this area and are often dressed and act like tourists. Keep everything in front of you.
Wonderful city. great area for walking round lots of bars , restaurants and shops with a great view of paris from Sacre coeur
Wonderful. High up you get beautiful views of Paris. Lovely to stroll around and watch the artists little shops to browse in. Great way to spend a few hours.

The place to visit and to stay forever.. Not far away from famous Pegale, but here i found the most romantic atmosphere, which I was expected from Paris.Many small, charm cafes,old style buildings, place where great singer Dalida lived. You can spend a lot of time walking there and it always will not be enough, so next visit to Paris, you have to be there again...

Day of Exploration . Spent a good part of my day here walking around. So many famed artists called this area home, including Picasso and Renoir. It's a great place to pick up original artwork (go to the square next to the Sacre Couer) or have a little risqué fun at the Moulin Rouge and nearby sex shops. Be wary though of the many climbs to access streets. Lots of stairs in this neighborhood!
Love this area!. Montmartre is a lovely area for a stroll. Take the funicular to the top or walk up the stairs. Do not walk if you find stairs difficult!! Beautiful view at the top.

My third visit, the worst so far. My last visit was 11 years ago. so many things have changed. i felt it was sprawling with pick pockets and scammers. I should have taken the Abesses Metro. Anvers station was where my son's wallet was stolen.

French rudeness. Alert - there are lots of guys at this place trying to get you to guess under which container the ball is. DO NOT FALL FOR IT. Bunch of lies and thieves. Stay away. Rogues and they will get what is coming to them in life.
Must see in Paris!. Must see in Paris for the gorgeous View of the city, Sacre Coeur is here along with many wonderful artists and cafes, you will love it!
Perfect view over the city. This is a must see if you are in Paris. I loved the view here. Also it's area with lots of places to see and a lot of restaurants.

Truly what I imagined Paris to be.. While our hotel was on the Champs Elysees in the middle of many sites, winter markets and shopping, we enjoyed spending much of our time in the Montmartre area. The ability to walk to see the views, neighborhoods and history provided many memories for us on our visit to Paris. Visit both in the daytime and at sunset or night time to get the most out of the area.

Very nice. A very enjoyable visit where you can find local painters trying to sell their art at reasonable prices. Don't expect to find the next Picasso there but you can relax and have lunch overlooking great Paris views.
Charming. After a visit to Sacre Couer a wander through the streets is well worth the time. Many tourist shops, boutiques and dining options!
favourite area. quaint paty of paris, lovely place du tertre with painters selling their art on the square, huge slection of restaurants in the area

Not to be missed. Even if you are not an art lover, it is a must visit area, as it has monuments and important places to see anyway, it is famous for its painters and artists that display their works on the street. Sell their works of art and do expect to be bargain if you like that sort of thing. Busiest on week ends of course and rather touristic but highly recommended.

very nice. At that day I had flu but I enjoyed it a lot. I went to the sacre church and took a selfie wth whole paris. I went in a small train that you can pick and saw most of the area. nice buildings and features. good for shopping also. the church location is very nice. it is worth a visit.

Freedom, Beauty, Truth and Love..... Kind of a given if you are a Moulin Rouge (movie) fan! Just around the corner from Sacre Coeur, the small cobbled streets are busy with tourists but beautiful. Check out the artists in the small square, they have some amazingly beautiful work. A rich history in this area also - check out the little museum, or have a coffee at Le Mere Catherine.

Beautiful little village.. I love Montmarte. If you are looking to purchase a painting you should find one here. In the square you will find several artist at work. I suggest finding a outside table at one of the cafes and spend time people watching.

See the Basilica of Sacre Couer and the neighborhood. Though relatively new, Sacre Couer is stunning. We were lucky to be there on Sunday and sat quietly and listened to the choir. Review the murals and the church, quietly and without pictures please. Then follow signs and see the Musee' de Montmartre where an amazing array of famous artists lived, go to the town square and check out the artists. We bought two great little paintings for a pittance. Pick up and guide to the town and see all the places of interest. Then down to the "main" drag. Here is the famous Moulin Rouge. If you are young or adventurous, go east from there and see the "red light" district.

Such an atmosphere. Montmartre is always a beautiful place for a stroll and really emphasises the feelings of Paris. There is always so much to see and sitting having a coffee watching the world go by is a must.

An Excellent place to stay. I thoroughly enjoyed this part of Paris. It was an excellent place to shop, to do the 'touristy' thing. The shopping was great, the people very friendly. There are some very quaint little café and restaurants a block up the hill from the main shopping area. Also very easy and convenient rail travel to the city.
Fun place to visit. Lots of fun visiting the hill. Nice streets with restaurants, shops, vendors, artists, kiosks, etc. Very good food everywhere.

Very interesting walk. Montmartre should be walked up to from the other areas of Paris. The best is straight route to the basilica of Sacre Coeur the dominant landmark of Montmartre. It is still the section of Paris associated with artists but nowadays more historically. Walking the Pigalle street to the Moulin rouge gives a taste of a bit different flavor with Pigalle's many sex shops and the local red district.

Cozy neighbourhood. A lot of small shops of cheese, meat, fruits, etc. A lot of boulangeries, cafes, and restaurants - small ones, not too many tourist traps. A lot to walk, and there is a funicular going to the top of the hill; it works with the metro ticket. I'll consider staying here the next time also!

Montmartre, one of the most touristic places inParis. As a parisian, myself, I come up the hill every 2/3 years, and often during Christmas !! never can be tired to visit this astonishing place. It is the Quintescence of romance, from a tourist point of view!!! The PLace du Tertre, with its famous painters ( and often would be painters, is the caricature of Romantic Paris itself, but it's so great to walk along the narrow paved streets around the Sacred Heart!!

Even when the weather is poor, this is a must do for any visit.. Unless the weather is horrible there are usually at least a few artists painting in the square. It's a great people watching area as folks who seem to think they are much better looking than they actually are sit to have their portraits painted or sketched. Fun.
artists abound. a pace just to walk & admire,the place for art beautiful architecture & food.The real history is here
Amazing atmospere. To sit in the square, drinking beer, listening to music and watching artists painting, its pure heaven.
Really beauful area. I particularly like visiting here on a Sunday. Quite touristy, but look past this to a very atmospheric area of Paris.

Any visit to paris would not be complete without a visit to Montmartre. If you plan to visit Paris for a celebration please don't miss a visit to the Montmartre area. It is a beautiful, busy and very romantic part of the city. Plan for a late evening and a visit to the Moulin Rouge!!
Interesting but the artists are pushy.. Worth seeing if you're there to visit Sacre Coeur. Very touristy and commercial but not particularily exciting.

Truly Amazing Place. There are so many restaurants here all over and also quaint shops. In the square where the artists congregate the buildings look so dated which is the charm. The cost of beers are quite high which is a shame.I visited here several times as I worked in Paris for 6 months.

Montmartre combines family with the Parisian chic. Montmartre has everything you need to feel like a resident of Paris instead of a tourist. We spent a split week here and when we returned from Normandy it was like coming home. The scale of Montmartre is such that you can readily find your favorite boulangerie or pattiserie. The food is so beautiful is hurts and is also inexpensive. Montmartre is chock full of museums and historical interest. There are lovely winding paths and stairs and rues all over the hill, each leading to a romantic spot. There are hotels on the Mont and in the area below it.

Best place in Paris. Montmartre is special: it seems not to be in a big city as Paris is, but just a little village of artists. The best moment to visit it, in my opinion, is at night, cause you can appreciate the view of the Tour Eiffel and the lights of the city from the Sacre Coeur.The steep way to reach it from Pigalle (Moulin Rouge) it's worth it.

Two neighborhoods in one. Montmartre is really at least two separate things -- there's the tourist part on the hill near Sacre-Coeur that you'll want to visit, but definitely avoid like the plague otherwise. Eating or shopping in this tourist area near Sacre-Coeur is a tremendous mistake, but you'll want to visit the gorgeous church there both for the church itself and moreso for the wonderful vistas of the entire city.Montmartre is believed to be Mars Hill or similar from the Romans and is one of the higher points in the city with splendid views. Take two hours or so and walk from Metro Abbesses up the hill through narrow streets to the church, but avoid shopping or eating near the church.Closer to Metro Abbesses or Blanche is the real residential part of Montmartre which is home to 2 or 3 of the best baguette/bread shops in Paris and many other splendid diners and such. This is a great neighborhood for walking and shopping and people watching and unlike the part on the hill, has far fewer tourists and more residents. Of course further down near Metro Pigalle is the Moulin Rouge area and the sex shops and so forth which is worth a quick visit but not really worth exploring further or staying in that area unless you are buying dirty magazines or sex tools and so forth.

A special part of Paris . This little corner (hill) of Paris is really quite lovely. The views, cafes and art are great. Some of the artists can get little pushy so don't hesitate to say "non"! You must climb this hill, enjoy the atmosphere and visit the Bacilica.

Stunning place!. I really love Montmartre and the atmosphere of this area. We really enjoyed walking around, visiting the cheese and wine shops, the authentic bars... For me the views were a little bit disappointing, but I had an amazing experience feeling like a local in Paris. Plus we did a tour with a local photographer of trip4real who was really nice and took really good photos. You can't miss Montmartre!

Over commercialised.. I visited Montmartre 15 years ago a loved it. I now find it over commercialised, expensive and extremely busy. Ok for first time visitors, but if you are a return visitor, expect to be disappointed.

Big difference between day and night. A quarter of Paris with a different mood than the other arrondisements. I like Montmartre more in the night when large groups of tourists disappear and locals crowd small pubs.

I had to sketch in Montmartre. I intended to do some sketching in Montmartre in 2014, but our travel plans changed. For our revisit to Paris this year, I made sure that it happened. We sat in a corner bistrot and I pulled out the folio while we ate lunch. We also visited the Museum of Montmartre and Renoir Gardens.One caution. Montmartre is a tourist magnet. Hit the side streets to avoid the mob. It's also a pickpocket/backpack hustle magnet. Watch your things, especially the Métro station.
Lovely neighbourhood. Lovely neighbourhood to walk around and get lost in the many small streets. Find the square where you can get a cartoon of yourself by very gifted artists

Art lovers . We were starting near the Montmartre area, it's very beautiful full of markets, gift shops and many choices of restaurants. The area always full of tourists and Artists. The streets joyful to walk around in the day and at night. Don't miss out on Montmartre.

Overrated artist Colony. Great Views. Out of the Way and a Bit too Touristy. It is a fun neighborhood to explore once you get away from the touristy section surrounding the Sacre Couer. It is a former artist colony but the view at the top of the hill is lovely. It isn't our favorite arrondissement, but you can have a marvelous time in the Marais if you steer away form the crowds.
The real Paris appears in Montmartre. Love this quartier! For me it's the synonyme for Paris. Lovely little ruelles, shops and bars and coffeshops.

A must see when in Paris. This is such a beautiful part of Paris. Gorgeous architecture and views. Some very cute little side streets and restaurants that can be visited, and the views are amazing. Definitely a must see when visiting Paris.
Beautiful place. There were just too many activities for me; lots of street vendors and musicians and general hubbub. Not as bad as at notre dame, though

Beautiful area of Paris. Visited by metro from the Latin quarter. Visited sacre clear and then walked the streets. Not as many street artists as seen in previous visits. Recommend getting a walking guide and seeing the vin yards etc.
Always fun!. Montmartre is a must-visit place in Paris. And so close to le Sacre Coeur too. Spend time whiling away the hours sipping a vin rouge and people watching.
Lovely, unknown area of Paris. Really enjoyed exploring this area, hadn't previously spent much time here but its so beautiful! Rua des Martys is a must :)

One of those place. The perfect walk, a lot to see, do and enjoy! The only down side is the significant amount of tourist at once, especially around the market place. Definitely a very touristique place, but a must do for anyone visiting Paris.
Lovely vibe, great artists!. Very cute market type vibe, only a short stroll from Sacré Cœur. Great for a coffee and people watching or to get your portrait drawn and support local artists.

The real heart of Paris. Fortunately, this place still keeps its identity and specific spirit of XIX artistic La Boheme, despite all the craziness and tragedy of the current days. It was so nice to sit outside at some street cafe with the glass of the hot mulled red wine and watch local artists trying to earn some money making sketches of tourists. Love the atmosphere.

Great place to visit. We loved the ebb and flow of the artisan lifestyle and many artists adorned the streets, all wanting to draw your picture, for a fee of course. But, we stopped for lunch in the Place du Tertre (La Boheme) and took in all the sights and sounds.
It's worth it!. If you have time and no money, Montmartre is a very nice option to spend some pleasant time. Either w families or friends! Try to go during the Spring!!!

A Great Walking Tour. Startin at Sacre-Coeur you can walk down hill and take in many sites; the studio where impressionists painted, home of Van Gogh while he was in Paris, a great original windmill used to pump water, a vineyard, artist market, and many restaurants and shops to browse.Well work taking a few hours to check out the area.

Exhausting. Such a long walk, for what?! People wanting to paint your picture, that is what awaits you at the top.
Nice view but you get an even better one from the tower ;)

Walking Tour made a huge difference. We've been to Paris several times and always make our way to Montmartre. This time we did a free walking tour with CultureFish! Tours. It was a terrific 2 hour walking tour our knowledgeable tour guide, Matty. He added stories about the history of the area, lively artist colony and great stories about them.

Late night visit. We were taken there by a friend, late at night. Everywhere was closed and quiet. A group of carol singers enlivened the eveming for a little while. The 'portrait sketchers' were around, but departed courteously when so asked,

Go early. We arrived early in Montmartre as the streets are quieter. We were visiting in December and on our last visit in August we found it very busy.In August Place du Tertre was full of tables from the surrounding cafes but in December the square is given back to the artists, I think I prefer it this way.The Christmas market at Abbesses was small but very nice.Montmartre is a great area and I thoroughly recommend a visit as there is so much to see.
Fun!. Hard to get fast food and the Cafes are a bit overpriced. You are chased a little by some of the artists too but overall a fascinating place with some good street musicians.

This is it. Shopping, cafe life, people, THE GOOD LIFE!. All the charms of Paris in one arondissement. You have it all here. Quiet streets. Tourist traps. Great shopping. Bargain hunting. Second hand stores. Posh stores. Good food. And the Sacre Coeur to oversee it all. Well worth a visit. Check out the chocolate botuiqe just upwards from the Metro. Impressive works on display and great chocolate to buy!

Do a semi private tour!. So many interesting little streets with such ambiance. As you move upward the neighborhoods change. So cool to see the variety of styles and so unique in the feel of the influences. One of the most interesting districts to explore and then to the top to the most amazing views and of course the amazing church. Have a guide give you all the great details- worth it!

Do The Touristy Things...Then Get Lost.. After you've visited the tourist attraction then go on a walk in the narrow streets around the Sacre Coeur and get lost. Of course it's hard to get lost these days with smartphones and GPS, but you know what I mean. See and get a feel for what an older part of Paris is like. Don't worry it's safe.

Must See. Montmarte is a must see area and can be approached by taking the small train, walking, bus or taxi. Once you are at the top of Montmarte the views are stunning and it is a wonderful place to walk around. This can be a very busy area, the market area has plenty of places to eat and of course the artists are everywhere.A lovely area and you see so much if you walk up or down.

Excellent quarter to roam. This is a great quarter to roam around......of course there is the main square with the artists and the Sacre Coeur Basilica but go into the Church of St Pierre, roam the back streets and eat off the beaten path.

MontMartre. A Beautiful Church.visited my first afternoon in Paris.Great view of Paris,Loved the carousel,plenty of tourist to enjoy the view,great atmosphere.Loved the coffee and restaurants in the area
My favorite part of Paris. I love the narrow streets, cafés and shops in Mortmartre . And of course Sacré Coeur and the beautiful view from there.

Facinating part of Paris. Located high on a hill and the sight of Moulin Rouge and other dance halls plus Sacre Coeur cathedral. It's a very lively spot. Can be accessed by funicular that runs up and down the escarpment.

A beautiful and special part of Paris. We decided to visit Montmartre with The Discovery Walking tours. We had a wonderful guide and visited the places in Montmartre which were frequented by the famous painters and artists of France and Europe. The stories and history of this neighborhood is fascinating. Today Montmartre is an elegant, upmarket area but once and even today attracts the bohemia and artists as the preferred neighborhood to reside. Definitely worth visiting and especially with a guide

Great place to base operations. Stayed here for a week, a great place to centre activities, lots of fun affordable places to eat and drink, great apartment via airbnb. One word of caution, lots of petty thievery activity. Pickpockets, street scams, don't take your wallet out, be aware of your surroundings. That said, I felt very safe walking around at night.

Fantastic. . A wonderful area to stroll round and have a coffee whilst watching the world go by. I got a portrait of my daughter - at 50 euros it was a little pricey but we chose out artist carefully and I am very happy with the result. The pace is a little slower here and it is great.
Great area. Great area with great views above Paris, lots of Restaurants and bars; however lots of tourists around.

Montmartre - A long way to the top for a perfect view!. On 9/9/15 my husband and I made (my) a long awaited trip to Montmartre. We caught the Metro as suggested by Trip Advisor - REALLY good tip! - then went straight to the cemetery. What a peaceful place! We even found a crypt with the family name on it!. It was an interesting place to visit. We then walked up through some absolutely gorgeous streets with stunning views to the Musee de Montmartre (originally the house of Renoir). This was a small but beautifully laid out art museum that housed some amazing art and details of the history of the artists, the commune and bohemians who lived there in the late 1800's - certainly worth the visit.I loved it! Onwards (just around the corner) to the church of Sacre Coeur which was not finished until about 1902. I thought the interior reflected the art of the time. The view from the Church was stunning - overlooking all of Paris! I would definitely go back to Montmartre!

One of my favorite areas - sit in the square on a rainy day. The square and this area are both just lovely. It feels like old Paris. The people selling pictures can be a bit annoying, but overall its a great place to walk around and visit the local shops.

Great views . Great views and off the beaten path a bit. The views are amazing, up high above the city so you can take it all in. There's a gorgeous church on top of Montmarte Village. The artists paint and sell their art on top as well. They are a bit pricey but you're paying for talent! We purchased 2 paintings for 30 euros each in a nearby studio by the painters wife. It's quite a walk from the other tourist attractions but there is a Metro (subway) nearby. It's near the moulin rouge as well.
. . Had one day to see the sites. Montmartre well worth the hike. See cathedral, outdoor artists, museums. Great bohemian atmosphere.

Best view in paris. Best view in paris, a very beautiful church, massive, all with white stone that enjoys the best view in Paris. Under the church you will find loads of small artists that can paint your portrait and you can buy paintings of the Montmartre. As you walk down the stairs under it is full of pickpockets so watch out!!!Definitely recommend it, just check before you go. It is raining you won't enjoy it that much.
Montmartre. Not as great as everyone says....! Go to the sacred heart of basilica and then move on...not much to see...

A Must Visit while in Paris. This is a great cathedral, with great history. When you are done touring it go on up the hill and you will find an outdoor market full of artwork, Souvenirs, and quaint restaurants. Plan on a full day, a memorable day, bring a good camera. You will love it, if you are into this type of energy expenditure. Couch potatoes stay on the couch, we don't need you clogging up this already crowded scenario.

Great place to stay. I'd like to put in a word in favor of staying in Montmartre during your time in Paris. We had an apartment in Rue Tardieu, very close to the bottom of the funicular up to Sacre Coeur. It's a wonderful neighborhood with many restaurants, bakeries, shops, places to wander. Some of the best restaurants in Paris are within a short walk. We loved being there -- people singing, accordions playing; it's a very lively place. I also want to say that in the several times we were at Place du Tertre or Sacre Coeur, we were never bothered by pickpockets or scam artists -- one woman approached me to sign a petition for the deaf, I said "no," clearly, and she went away. Yes, if you're having a drink on the Place, the *portrait artists* (not scammers) will solicit your business, but if you just tell them no thank you, they'll move on to someone else. Montmartre is a wonderful place to stay; just stay on the west side of Sacre Coeur, away from a very touristy area to the east.
Full of pickpockets. This is a typical quarter of Paris but is extremely full of pickpockets. We liked the view and the cathedral. NIce place after all.
Joy. Walk, look, enjoy, find a bargain, sheer pleasure to mingle with the crowds, with an open eye for any wrongdoers, I love it...
Terrible. It's full of tourists and thieves. I didn't have a good time there at all. Its very dirty and smelly. It's not a romantic and free spirited place anymore.
Amazing Spot. an amazing spot to spend your evening. Beautiful scenery nice old cafes and restaurants, artists everywhere,
Incredible. The views from this location in Paris are incredible. This is a must see while visiting Paris. I look forward to going back.

adorable beautiful area to visit. Montmartre is not to be missed when visiting Paris. There are many shops to visit, a church and some cute restaurants. The view from the church overlooking Paris was spectacular. There are many hands on artists in the little square too.

Interesting Area. I enjoy going to Montmartre to see Sacre Coeur and all the working artists. I do not enjoy all the street merchants and scammers. There is a constant feeling that pickpockets are abundant.

Yes it is a tourist trap. - but still worth the effort . Montmartre is a focal point for this beautiful city - a must do for any visitor - yes, it is full of hawkers and artists (Place Tertre) however, if you have the time walk around the quarter you will discover many beautiful sights (oldest vineyard in Paris )

Montmartre Sacre Coeur. Nice church , closed to place du tertre with the sketch artists , however too many pick pockets in this area , be on the lookout , watch your purses ladies and men do me a favor you place your wallet front pocket , the enjoy

Must visit . Beautiful place to visit its all the way up you have a option to take lift to go up 100 meters price is 1,80 euro a way the view is fantastic there are a lot of café and painters its a must .

Check out the great artists!. It was great wandering around looking at the beautiful artworks. There are so many different styles in the way each artist approaches their work. Choose the style you like and get your portrait painted or just buy one of the many beautiful works.

Visit up the hill to Montmartre. I visited this area of Paris with my little sister who lives in Paris. Compared to the rest of the city, Montmartre is different. It has a different feel, a different city structure, and a different, amazing view. The feel is very small-town; I loved it. All the shops are small and quaint and there was a really amazing street artist market in the central square. This part of the city has tiny, poky streets instead of the big avenues of the heart of Paris, and the view from there shows all of Paris, since it is the highest point in the city. If you stand on the steps of the Sacre Coeur, you can see the entire skyline and its wonderful.
Visit. This is a very good place to have good view.This is a tourist spot with tourists.A good area to hangaround and have a coffee and snacks.
Paris ,,,,je t' aime. It is always a fantastic pleasure to go to Montmartre...it is representing Paris....historically.....nice cafe,nice long walk,artist,and good food...

Its all about the view. The area is kind of rough and the buildings not that nice except the church of SacreCoeur. There are some small nice shops here and you can find alot of artists on the small plaza that sell paitings and they also offer to paint a picture of yourself.The main thing here is free and that is the view wich might be the best in Paris. Try to be here at sunset and you can see all of Paris swimming in light,

A Lovely, quirky part of Paris. Montmartre is full of history and interesting stories. We were guided around the area by Karen who seemed full of interesting facts. The cathedral is beautiful, though relatively new for Paris, but still well worth a look.

Bohemian Paris. Was just like I imagined it to be. There was a real buzz. Full of artists, cafes and small shops. Lots of "street artists" who approach you as you wander around - the drawings are very good. Small Tourist Information Office on main square. Lots of interesting things to see - museums, vineyard, old buildings etc

A Must Visit when in Paris. A great spot to visit, most beautiful church, handy nick-knack tourist shops, restaurants and bars and what a view over Paris. Great by day or night. Get the cable car up (and down) if you don't fancy the climb.

Lovely neighborhood.. Montmarte is my favorite place to wander in Paris. The views of the city, the charm and personality, all of the galleries, its just so amazing. Wear comfortable shoes and be prepared for a lot of hills and steps! One of the most romantic and beautiful spots in the city.
Important Area. While Montmartre has a heart and soul, it is not my favourite coin. But, for art lovers and those who have frequented Paris it remains a wonderful neighbourhood.
Very traditional.. Lovely shops in the area which comes across as very traditional despite the thousands of tourists which flock here daily.Be prepared for hills!

Loveliest place in Paris, especially during the twilight hours. Probably the most romantic part of Paris, Montmartre is a hill featuring the Sacre-Coeur Basilica, magnificent view of Paris and romantic narrow streets full of artists, cafes and brasseries.I strongly suggest that you make this an evening visit, as there is much less tourists there at these hours, you can enjoy the view of sunset and the twilight enforces the romantic atmosphere of the place.

Walk in the footsteps of Hemingway and Fitzgerald.. Montmartre for us is a must see and do.One must walk "behind" the Sacre Coeur to arrive at the town square.It has a pavilion for the artists and some of the restaurants and is a great place to have your portrait drawn. Do be aware that many of the so called silohuette artists will bug you for a "free" cut out of you and then demand money.The real artists will not bug you...not to say they won't try to embarrass you into buying...they will.But, don't stop here, continue down the side streets and be prepared to be awed by the views.

If you love art!. By all means, you MUST visit Monmarte when in Paris. The "starving" artists produce for sale some remarkable works. Our only regret is we didn't but more. Located at the highest point in Paris, you also can visit the Sacre Cur church while there. Then , The Moulin Rouge is at the bottom of the hill. Get tickets and go!
Great place!. This is a great touristy area! The moulin rouge is around here and other trendy spots...great place to bike around also if you are into that sort of thing.

Art, fun, nice food - but be careful with fake artists. Montmartre is the place to be if you want to experience Paris bohemian site. Take the funiculaire or exercise and use the stairs to get to the commercial/turistic area. Walk around some narrow streets, taste the crepes ( cheese and ham or banana and chocolate are to die for), visit the many shops, have your portrait done (but only at the square where there are a number of good artists and avoid the ones walking on the streets). Admire the Sacre Coeur and climb to the top where you can have a fantastic view of Paris. Take your time to enjoy each part of it. Going down you can have a coffee at the Cafe de Deux Moulins ( where Amelie was filmed) at Rue Lepic or try any of the delicious pastries and sweets in the many boulangeries around. And let's not forget the Moulin Rouge - a little salty, around $190 euros for the show and a glass of champagne. But, hey it's Paris and have fun with "la vie en rose" and some very good wine.
Touristy but Fun. This area is very touristy, but its winding streets, the presence of Sacre Coeur and views of the city are worth the visit.

Great feel of Paris artists. This is where you can see local artists at work while eating at an outside cafe and buy a few souvenirs. Sacred Heart cathedral is close by which is beautiful and there is a lovely panoramic view of parts of Paris. I enjoyed a lovely day outside taking in the sights, foods, wine, and culture of Paris.

getting lost in Montmatre. Firstly I used the funicular to the top and started walking around Montmartre.The little restaurant everywhere and in the middle of the street or on the footpath can be fund the artists doing their paint work. you can truly get the Paris feeling while walking around

Watch the Artists at work. Walking the cobblestone streets watching artists painting at their easels, also viewing their artwork on sale is great. Many artists wandering amidst the tourists asking if they can sketch you for a fee, of course, we checked out a few of the different portraits as they finished and they looked very good. Many great cafés with lots of good affordable deals

True Paris. This was an amazing place! There are so many art and food vendors on Montmartre and the views from the mountain are absolutely stunning! This was a true taste of Paris and a wonderful place to buy non-cliche (and cliche) Paris souvenirs
FUN DAY. Great day to get your painting done! walk around, lots of cafes and places to eat and art Galleries we ate at a tiny cafe which had great prices, and great ambiance, quick friendly service.

love the history. i fell in love with Montmartre on my first visit to Paris so long ago. I bought a painting which still hangs in my office. So i associate the place with its historic art roots, and though it's changed art is still around. The cobble stones and buildings will remind you of so many movies. Charming and a must for Paris visitors

Charming district. Probably my favorite Arrondissement (district) of Paris. Has amazing views of Paris, and the streets and scenery is so charming. Great restaurants and bars. Worth the trip to see if you are staying in central Paris.

A touristic sight. Montmartre is a must see for tourists visiting Paris. It is a hill with stairs going all the way up to the Basilica of Sacre -coeur . All the way mounting are traditional souvenir stores. The sight of Paris that high on the hill is breath taking. You can go up using other way than the stairs , but climbing on feet gives you the opportunity to look at every detail and look behind you at the wonderful sights. Reaching the top you can visit the Basilica and also the Dali museum. What I found so charming, although a lot of people don't, is the square with the many artists who are paining the scenery or who propose to paint your portrait. I think these artists make the place look more alive . Pass by a coffee shop on your way down or eat in a pastry shop it will make your visit a bit charmer and longer . Hope you will enjoy the visit as much as I did .

Lovely artist area!. This is a great place to watch artists at work, drawing, painting, etc. You can sit and they will gladly sketch you, which I did! Great prices on hand made art work too! There are many cafes surrounding the square and on a sunny day you could spend hours here. It is right around the corner from the Sacre Couer so it is easy to see as well. Would highly recommend.

Mountain of art. Montmartre has long been a haven for artists. You are likely to find artists sketching in 'plein air", that is, out in the open. You should also see Sacre Coeur, the iconic church sitting on the hill. It is rather odd, lkike a piece of Bysantium transported to Paris,.

Hilly & picturesque plus. Spent five days here. Location a bit outside the area w/ museums & art galleries. Took guided tour. Saw many sites we would never have seen. Many good outdoor bistros, bakeries, butcher shops & wine shops. And a Starbucks, just across the street from Moulin Rouge. Easy access to Paris sites by bus or Metro. Must see in the Cemetery. Walking through it, is a trip through time.

Artistic and Quirky. A lovely walk up to Monmartre was not disappointing as the square was awash with street artists.It was great walking between them, taking pictures and just enjoying the atmosphere although a little subdued following Paris attacks. Quaint little streets with equally quirky coffee shops, restaurants and shops. Make sure you visit!

Go during the day, Not the evening.. The neighborhood is full of artists, and it is like a mountain range in Paris. Nice to see the church, the central courtyard of Monmatre has style, but definitely not a place for dinner or lunch. It's nice to walk up the stairs! In the evening, I would avoid the area around Anvers Metro Station. It is extinct in my experience, but during the day very touristic.

surprised how dirty it was since last visit. Montmarte has lost much of its charm, since last visit. I was surprised how dirty it was. Many of the artist in the square was gone, replaced with an outdoor cafe. Most shops were typical touristy ones.

Wonderful experience. A fabulous place to visit, the area is so interesting and the view just stunning. There was free entertainment on the steps leading to the top the day I visited so very crowded but still a great experience. Loved all the shops to look at, bought any gifts to take home.
Everything is very close and within easy walking distance.. Beautiful to walk around and enjoy the architecture and French ambiance. Many sidewalk artists and vendors.

A great neighborhood to stay. We loved our little apartment in Montmartre. So fun to stay in the neighborhood where great artists like Renoir and Picasso painted. It is very easy to get around to all the attractions in Paris from here because the Metro Blanche station is right next to the Moulin Rouge, only 2 blocks from our apartment. Walk up the cobblestone streets to the top of the neighborhood and you are at Sacre Coeur with spectacular views of the entire city.

My favourite neighbourhood. I would just love to live here. It is such a romantic place. I loved walking around and trying to "absorb" with my eyes as much as possible. I suggest you visit on a sunny or lightly cloudy (not raining) the Sacred Heart Basilica and enjoy the sunset there. Then walk in the little street and spend time appreciating the paintings of the various painters in the main square. Look around the buildings, the trees, the little restaurants and the coffee places which are quite expensive but you have to pay for the place and the view around you :-)Enjoy the smell of tasty crepes and if the weather is good sit outside and enjoy at least a coffee in one of the numerous places.

worth the hike. The view from the top is better than the Eiffel view! The church itself is breathtaking; and while the area around the Moulin Rouge is seedy...the area between Mont Martre and there is full of great shops and restaurants.Don't miss the beautiful and eerie cemetery there as well!

Great area. Better prices. Spent afternoon here on a food tour. Really enjoyed this unique area. Very hilly and different from other areas of Paris. Be adventurous and head to moulin rouge to walk and people watch
Such a lovely area! . I stayed here a weekend in November. Great area with a lot to see and a huge variety of cosy restaurants.

Overview. This is my second time to Montmartre. We wLked around looking at paintings from different artists. Painting are beautiful. It was very difficult to select one specific painting therefore we were there for quite sometime. The artists were extremely friendly and helpful. Had lunch there. Sat outside, people watched and was entertained by a singer. Definitely will be returning. This is my favorite place in Paris.

Infamous Montmartre.. All we needed was Absinthe and Toulouse-Lautrec to complete the picture. Aside from the Moulin Rouge the area is full of eateries, artists at work and lots of interesting places. For those seeking spectacular views of Paris and some religious solace, the short journey up the hill to Scare Coeur is an absolute must. The Church itself is spectacular and the back streets are full of further interesting finds. A must see also at nightfall.

Its touristy, but its interesting..... I'm not a huge fan of the area due to the volume of people running through it and the tourist-geared trinkets and trash stores, but there are some REAL GEMS to be found if you poke around a bit more.... Take a lovely stroll with some time on your hands and you might find something a little more unique.

Not much to do but watch out for pick pockets. Came here because it was near the moulin rouge theater. We walked to the basilica had lunch near the church. While eating we had a picture drawn of us. The artist did a great job.Now the bad part. While waiting on the subway I noticed a group of young girls sitting on the bench. The subway came, the wife and I got on, so did the girls. The surrounded us and one girl next to me tried the bump and grab for my wallet. I felt something and smacked a hand and started yelling at the girl. They all then ran towards the other end. By the time anyone could help they were already off the next stop which was a few minutes. So everyone do be careful. Always keep aware of your surroundings and items. I was told they were gypsy and are known to pick pocket.
Charming and Romantic. This place is perfect to stroll through its meandering streets! it has quaint shops and restaurants.
Very popular for a reason. Wonderful to see hordes of people wandering throughout the area drawn by art, ambience and eateries.
Amazing!. Love each minute on this place, the atmosphere, the place, the history, the view, absolutely a place you have to visit if you are in Paris.
so romantic. this is our favorite spot in all of paris...so real and gritty. Perfect spot for an afternoon lunch and people watching. beautiful view of the city
Very nice. Very romantic place, great place for photo shooting. Quite commercial though but should take a walk there and the area near by.

The hill. The stairs. The views.. Touristy, yes. But . . . quintessentially Paris. Once you get to the top, visit the church. It is quite love and worth the time. The surrounding area is filled with artists of various styles and attitudes. Some times the artists are finer than others. It is a wonderful place to find an lovely treasure by which to remember your climb. The Dali gallery and museum are interesting and worth a visit. The cafes are geared to tourists but the croissants are buttery and fresh.

Yes. Yes. Yes.. So much to do and see here. The Basilica. The view. The stores. Let's not forget the fresh Crepe stands. YUM! Bring your camera. Strap on your comfortable shoes. There are many steep hills and lots of steps. Make a day of it.

If You've Already Seen the Louvre etc.. Wonderful way to spend a day, or part of a day--depending on your time limits. We had been to Paris and done all the museums etc. last year. Since we were meeting our cruise ship here, we had a day to ourselves and decided to go to Montmartre. Definitely a worthwhile visit. Just walk around, enjoy the views, have a coffee--easy to get back and forth by Metro
Love it!!. Lovely area of Paris full of restaurants, cafés and artists (Place du Tertre). The view from the Sacré Coeur is fabulous!
Nice for a casual stroll . Pretty place to take a walk and have a look around. Interesting things to see and buy. Had a look after sacre cœur, it's nearby.

Lovely. Simply lovely! This place is different from any other corner in Paris. I did get a caricature portrait with my partner for a fair price by one of the artist and will be the best souvenir of our holiday. Shops for other kind of souvenirs (fridge magnets, bags, purses etc.) are cheaper than the other shops in other famous Paris places!
Oh so touristy!. But...one cannot go to Montmartre without stopping at Sacre-Coeur church and going to painters' square.

Panoramic view of Paris!. It is excellent for sightseeing and wandering around! It has lots of souvenir shops. In the square, you can find street artists painting and drawing. I also recommend it to see the sunset..

Not recommended!!! Pickpockets and thieves !!. Def not recommended !!! Pickpockets and thieves are everywhere!! And saw they using violence against the tourits also! Even if u see the police dnt think they are not gonna try to steal you!! They are some meters away from the cops. Thieves are at the stairs going up to sacre coeur or also in the elevator. Get away from this place. Is beatifull but not safe at all!

New Year in Montmarte. Maybe one of the best locations to stay and 'feel' a bit French. It is vibrant and fun. We rented an apartment thru Airbnb that was well located to join new year festivities as well as lazy morning breakfasts in the Place du Tertre and watch the world go by. A Viti to Montmarte must include a visit to the beautiful Basilica Sacre-Coeur but don't just pose out the front for a happy snap-go inside and experience its beauty. Wander down the cobble roads and take your time so you can admire the architecture and soak up the history as you head toward the city.

A wonderful area to visit - not to be missed in Paris!. My favourite area of Paris. Lots of good places to eat; many artists working and displaying their wares; street musicians - a really nice place to walk, day or evening.
Art lover paradise.. You need to spend a whole day here.Lovely vibe just see artists at work, eat at the little restaurants and do novelty shopping.Great place to visit a must.
A getaway from Paris within Paris. Montmarte feels more like a village within a city. Cobbled pathways and the architecture give the place its village feel. The view of the city is great as well.

Based here during City break. Our hotel was in this area during a recent city break to Paris. It has a good choice of restaurants and cafes for local eating and is fairly quiet (for Paris). The Metro takes you to the Eiffel Tower in 20 minutes and to the Louvre in 25 minutes - so also a great transport hub.
The same atmosphere as ever!. Artists,cafes,boutique stores and the Dali Espace museum as a must see! Lovely morning touring Montmartre,with easy access by the furnicular to the Sacre Couer.

Enjoyable atmosphere. We were there in Februar 2015. I think there will be much more people at summer time. In February there was quiet and we can enjoy atmosphere for that place. There are many artists offering to do the painting of you. They are selling his paintings which is ripened on the spot. Near the square there are several small cafes where you can sit and enjoy your cafe.
Holy spirit. This must be your first place when visiting Paris. Enjoy the greatest view of the city. It's very far from the center. There is no good communication with bus, tram, subway, etc...

Quaint and Lovely. We stayed in Montmartre when we visited France earlier this year. Absolutely loved staying just off the beat and path of Paris, but having easy access to the city on a daily basis. The Metro is phenomenal. The only thing to be aware of is the insane amount of scam artists outside of the Sacre Coeur. Keep your hands close cause they will grab them! But found several lovely restaurants and shops. Loved Montmartre overall!

It Still has Charm. Over 20 years since I was last here and I didn't know what do expect, but do you know, it still works its magic. It's still charming, there are still artists and restaurants and cafes. Go and enjoy it...
A PLACE, A VIEW, CHARMING. This is a must in Paris, you should visit no matter what. Art, food, architecture and History combine in one place. Sunset is priceless.

Good to see once..... ...but not necessarily again. I was here 10 years ago, and it is now ever so much more commercialized. This is the most crowded place in Paris. Maybe it's the small streets, but I really felt like I was in a sardine can. There are great photo opps, but you'll have to find places that are less crowded, so try to walk away from the tourists. If you don't like to walk the many charming stairs up to Sacre Coeur you can take the funiculaire for the price of one metro ticket. There are plenty of nice looking restaurants. Shops offer anything from art to kitsch. You will find that souvenirs are lower priced that around the Eiffel Tower or Arc Triomphe.

Love this area!!!!!!!!!!!!. Everytime we go to Paris, Montmartre is on our tour stop. We love the ambiance, artists, restaurants and views. The only thing we are not happy about is that they put restaurants in the park where the artists use to be. They are still there, but on the outside of the park. I guess this area got so popular the restaurants had to expand. I also love visiting the Salvador Dali Museum/gift store. They have my favorite perfume there. You should stop in and get a spray of Dali's perfume. The bottle it comes from is a sculpture of his wife's lips.

One of my favorite places in the world!. This neighborhood is so full of culture, beauty and fun! Both times I've visited the city, Montmartre was a main highlight. There are quaint coffee shops and cheese shops all over the place and every corner you take seems to be a new, exciting experience. This part of the city deserves at least of day of your time exploring, but be ready for stairs! By about 3pm one day, we'd hit 46 climbed flights on the pedometer!
Busy Area!. We accessed this from the Hop on Hop off bus. We also walked around the area some. I would like to have had more time to explore Montmartre.
interesting area to expore. you can walk all around this area red light, café, bar and churches etc great people watching any time of the day or night there is always something going on

Great place to wander.. Very charming. We had a lot of fun wandering around the narrow streets, looking at the architecture and walking through shops. We made constant stops in cafes and spent a half a day here. Not one thing jumps out as rememberable, more so the whole experience of the area. It’s definitely quieter and more quaint than a lot of other areas.

Felt harassed. There were rude street vendors and men "making bracelets" then demanding money from you that made us feel very uncomfortable in this part of town. It ruined the "charm" that we had heard so much about.

Not great in Winter. This part of Paris is definitely a Summer time thing. Also the tourist sellers are out in full force before you get up the hill and it was really uncomfortable rainy and cold at night. Not quite the ambience I had in Summer. Plus the metro is not that easy to get to from here.

Charming part of Paris!. Montmartre is a lovely part of the city where all the impressionists and other artists like to hang out. Today you can still see artists creating portraits of tourists at the street cafes.

Broken glass and rubbish everywhere.. Whilst the church itself is beautiful, the queuing to get in is real pain, and once inside the crowds are horrible. Outside there was broken glass and rubbish everywhere. This was extremely disappointing as it really detracted from the magnificence of the church and the wonderful views.

Got to visit. The area is famous for it's art and night life and you won't be disappointed if you are looking for either. Quaint café bars and typical Parisian restaurants are everywhere you look. Relax and enjoy the atmosphere.

Romance on top. Montmartre is one of the most romantic areas of Paris. It is on top of the mountain, but climbing makes it worth while. Little streets, Place Tertre with all its artists, the restaurants, bistros and before the Basilica, the view over Paris. Do not visit it when it is raining, you will miss a lot.
Good area. Good area to explore but too touristy, avoid eateries on main road expensive poor food! Good views of the city.
Beautiful. Beautiful view, cozy streets, if you walk way down there are streets with nice boutiques as well. And Marlette is nice for breakfast lunch or coffee!

Loved this neighborhood. We took a walking through this neighborhood and fell in love. It's beautiful, quiet, clean and has so much character. You can tell it's an expensive neighborhood to live in, but they try to maintain their art roots. I'd recommend taking a formal walking tour through here so you can learn and really appreciate the neighborhood.

Back to the time of big painters. Here is the place that you feel a time travel, when not many buildings were there, and big painters came to paint Paris from the top.Now you find many painters work in this square.If you go there an evening can see beautiful Paris in the night . DON'T forget espace Dali, there is a small exhibition. So smaller than what you can find in Figueres, Cadaques, and pubol, but surely worth a visit.
Great day. We really enjoyed the atmosphere of the place. Had a couple portraits done by some of the very talented artists. Definitely worth a visit if travelling to Paris
Perfect area for walking. We spend quite some time there and enjoyed a lot the open spaces and the surroundings.If you wish to walk around there is plenty of opportunities.

Not just the top of the hill. We toiled up to the Sacre Couer, the street artists, the wonderful views, the small individual shops and loved it. We also did the ride on the little street train, but the highlight for my fashion student grand daughter was the area with all the haberdashery and fabric shops. Some were cheap and cheerful and others more upmarket. We are still in Paris and guess we will be revisiting that area again before departing. A lovely wander but comfortable shoes are essential.

The highlight of my trip in Paris. The winding cobble stone streets and bounty of food stops makes this place magical! If you're fan of the movie Amelie - rewatch the movie and check out this neighborhood. Many scenes were shot in and around this area.

Walking Tours. I highly recommend taking one of the free local led walking tours of the Montmartre neighbourhood. The tour guides are knowledgeable and informative and these tours area great way to learn about the district and get tips on places to see and eat.

Great atmosphere, talented artists. We spent an afternoon at Montmarte taking in the sights and atmosphere and enjoying the people watching. The artists are all very talented, with some standing up above the rest, it was a restful and enjoyable way to spend a few hours and well worth the visit. Don't let the annoying hawkers deter you, it is worth the journey....
Love the morning. I enjoyed taking a walk to Place du Terte and the streets nearby in the morning, and grab a bite at a boulangerie along the way before the crowds and tour groups appear.
Quaint and pretty. Certainly worth a visit as it's very pretty but very touristy. I wouldn't recommend eating in one of the restaurants here but it's great for a wander around and a drink.

Great place outside of city center. Rented an apartment through Airbnb off Rue Houdon. Could not be happier with the location. Our apt was on the 6th floor and had a awesome view of of the church and of the Eiffel Tower. Great location to catch the metro into the city. Lots of great little cafes and restaurants UP the hill (away from the main street). Cliche things to see/do like Moulin Rouge.
Great shops and restaurants. Great part of Paris to walk around, especially on good weather days. We bought paintings and ate at restaurants without breaking the bank

best view of Paris. its right off the red-light district and quite uphill but its a great area to visit for nightlife and also stay if you are visiting. Great views from the top of the hill. Tons of nice and tons of tourist traps so read your trip advisor reviews before picking, but the options are endless.
Nice atmosphere . Walking round the cafe areas and shops behind Sacre Coure was lovely . Lots of artists around sketching visitors. Some lovely little steps to walk down very Parisien.

Lots of artists want to paint your face. A place where artists, painters, sex & follies all come together in Montmarte. A great wander around the place with Moulin Rouge to go and watch a show if you like. There is a car trolley that can take you around the area at a price.

Just "meander!". This is such a great area to meander and take in the people, shops, and get in your walking! Stop at a cafe, get something to eat or a drink and just watch the sights around you. You'll feel like a real Parisian!
Among the many popular sites in Paris. Its major attraction are two churches atop a hill in the Montmartre district of Paris. Good shopping there as well

Special!. Montmartre is well worth a visit. Obviously the main attraction is the Sacre Coeur however it is also a great place to take in the many flavours of Paris. Being the local hangout for budding artists it is interesting to wander around and watch as they sit and paint or sketch. You can also get your portrait done if you wish.Spend some time walking the streets of Montmartre. If you enjoy baguettes then look for La Grenier du Pain bakery as they continually win the award for the best Parisien baguette. Buy one and rip the top off and enjoy!

Fantastic area. Fantastic part to visit. Fabulous views over Paris. A real buzzy place with cosy wee restaurants most with reasonable two course dinner deals. Creperies bars and cafes surrounded by artists and street stalls Top of my visit list
Very disappointing.... The whole district near the Moulin Rouge is dreadful, full of sex shops....would not recommend that area at night.

Loved every minute of Montmartre. Stayed in this area and could have spent a lot more time here. Alive at night, including Moulin Rouge, loads of lovely eating places of different price levels and so much to see and do in the day.
Poetic. Loved browsing thru the busy streets, the artists and the extra special stores with all sorts of goodies not found in the "usual" tourist shops. A must do /see while in Paris.
Loved the aritist corner!. Such a cool place to look over the whole Paris and to visit Sacre Couer. make sure to visit the cozy cafes and restaurant on the hill and the artists square.

a nice walk around. walking around in Montmartre is quite interesting. There is always some special cultural event to visit. Or you can look for a drink in one of the many bars. At the top of Montmartre, b ehing the Sacre Coer, there is a smaller church. It's a beautiful one, just beside the famous cemetery.

It's a classic!. It might be cliche but it's a must during your Paris visit!
Montmartre is splendid for its history and its high hill looking over Paris.
Go at sunset time.

DAY TIME ACTIVITY. Its Paris, and this is an awesome place
(IN DAY LIGHT..)
Go see all the main attractions on your first time there. If you don't you really don't feel like you've seen Paris :)

full of tourists but very nice. Have a good breakfast or lunch just to have energy to go upstairs...I counted up to 140 steps, but it worth to make the effort. The view from the top is very nice and walk through the streets or seat in a coffe bar is a very good way to enjoy and feel the atmosphere.

Nice to be, horrible to eat.. Very nice place, the Place du Tertre is a nice walk, but is a tourist trap.
Never eat there or buy something, unless you want to pay twice the regular cost and end disapointed.

Enjoying Montmartre. Visiting Montmarte is always interesting and fun. I do have some suggestions for visiting this interesting section of Paris. You can easily spend a half day visiting both Montmarte and Sacr’e-Coeur which is just a short walk from Montmarte. Also getting up to this area I want to warn people there are numerous steps to get to the top. However there is a funicular that will take you up to the foot of Sacr’e-Coeur and then you can walk from there. When you do get to the top you will be rewarded with a beautiful view of Paris. Try to visit Montmarte on either a Saturday or Sunday when the market area is filled with artist selling their art work. There are several different artists showing their art of Paris and there are also artists that will do your portrait if you would like. Always ask the cost up front so you are not surprised once they are done, and present you with their finished artwork and the BILL!! If you are interested in getting a portrait done, take some time and walk around and see who you think will do the best work for you. The best artists are the ones in the park working in their stalls not the ones that are walking around and approaching people, these people are usually just out for the money and are not the most reputable.I always try to remind people to be aware of their surroundings and what is going on around them. The Montmarte area and the area around Sacr’e-Coeur is known for “Pick Pockets” so just be alert and you will be fineHope you have found this information helpful and if I can be of any additional help please contact me. Paris is a beautiful city, so while visiting, be adventuresome and venture out and see what all the City Of Lights has to offer.Lary1047

Wonderful charming Paris area. When I go to Paris for a few days, I always stay in the Montmartre area. It is just a lovely area to stay with plenty of restaurants and shops. The atmosphere is just really cosy and romantic. Even in winter the atmosphere is incredible. I especially enjoy the fact that even when it's cold the terrasses have heaters and everybody is just sitting outside.

Artistic. This is the artistic arrondissement of Paris. It's also quite touristic, so in my opinion this part of Paris is losing it's original touch. But if you are in Paris for the first time, this is a place you have to see and go stroll by. Don't forget to go to the Sacre Coeur! Beware of pick pockets over there as it's very crowded with people all the time.
The best place in Paris. I'm happy that I came here. I'm loving the place. A lot of artists and cafe's. That's how I had imagined Paris.

NO DALI, MONET, VINCENT, PACASSO OR JOSEPHINE BAKER NOW! THEY ARE LONG GONE!. But you will find scores of 'would be artists' wishing to draw your portrait - for a price; and dozens of their Paris paintings. - but don't expect a bargain - they don't give them away.Montmartre - The Mount of Martyrs - but mainly Saint Denis - Bishop of Paris, who in the year 250 was decapitated here. In disgust he then picked up his head, wandered off down the North Slope, and then died. ?? Make of that what you will!!In 1790 - a year after the Bastille, this area became a gypsum mine. So to erect the Basilica of Sacre Coeur foundations of 40 meters were required. The Cathedral was erected to commemorate the French who had died when Germany conquered Paris in 1871 in the Franco- Prussian War.Brian, from Perth. W. Australia.
Beautiful. Such an amazing area to visit. I loved all the shops, we had an amazing lunch in the area. Defiantly want to go back soon!

Take your time, walk up and down to and from Sacré-Cœur. Plan a walking itinerary to go up to and come down from Sacre-Coeur bu visitons différent street and areas of Montmartre. You will see classics seen in movies, post cards and magazine articles. It is well worth the while to prepare. Spend some time zigzagging on various streets in the neighbourhood. This was at least my 3rd time going to Montmartre but my first visit of Montmartre also.A great place for restaurants for Parisens and not tourists only, well reflects in more acceptable pricing. Great service everywhere we went.

Dangerous. As we were walking with other tourists towards Sacre' Coeur, we were approached by a gang of about 8 men blocking the path. We were fortunate to have a French Family with us who took the lead and we were able to get past. The homeless use the gardens around the basilica as their toilet. The police are nowhere to be found. We loved the Salvador Dali Museum there; but would probably only return with a reputable tour due to the surrounding area. We decided not to return that night to go to a club in the area due to the unsafe conditions.

Just avoid this place "DO NOT GO". It is absolutely disgusting. The place is not safe at all, be aware of pick pockets. They distract your attention by trying to sell you something next your wallet is taking from your pocket. Number of African men trying to tie a string into your wrist, you tell them to go away but they grab your arm and become aggressive. Lots of fast food outlets, cheap souvenir shop and second hand cloth shops. All sort of scams going on in the streets. Don't waste your time by going there. Stay away.Montmartre is not what it used to be. The place is full of beggars, homeless people and aggressive sellers harassing people. French police were are you?

Always too crowded. I suggest you go very early in the morning (which unfortunately I haven't done yet). I have been here several times and don't find it that pleasant with so many people. The view of Paris can be great if it's a clear day. So I suggest only going on a clear day and research which "cute" restaurant has the best reviews before you plunk down your euros. I like walking up the steps rather than taking the funicular.

Visit to Montmartre and Sacre Coeur cathedral. It was great fun after visiting sacre coeur cathedral and walking along the streets of Montmartre enjoying the artists painting and the little shops with simple merchandise

Terrific area to stay in Paris. We enjoy staying away from the city center hub bub, but close enough to get to anything in a few minutes by Metro, bus or taxi. Montmarte is perfect...beautiful area with its own unique history. Away from the trendy, touristy areas, we found many wonderful (and inexpensive) cafes. We also enjoyed the neighborhood shops instead of the big touristy ones, plus the neighborhood open air markets...even a neighborhood flea market! Plenty of smaller museums and other attractions, too.

A must for any visit. Montmartre is, well Montmartre. It has gotten more touristy in recent years, but still spending time away from the central square and the church, gives one the feel that drew the artists of the late 1800's and early 1900's to Montmartre.Worth the better part of a day. For lunch, get away from the central square. The food is better and cheaper.Also, get to know the artists of today. I am sure there are no future Piccasso's or Van Gough's but who knows. They do provide a great souvenir
The charming Paris. A very romantic area from Paris representing well the glorious history of this city. There were artists everywhere.
Beautiful part of Paris. This was my favourite part of Paris, beautiful streets, buildings, history and art. Lots to visit here including the windmills well worth the trip

interesting church and market. The view from the church is maybe worth the trip. The church is interesting, although not in the top half of those in Paris, IMHO. There is a market a block or two over with food and many artists selling paintings that seemed to be fairly priced

Wonderful view of the city. Montmarte used to be a bohemian neighborhood, now it's one of the many important tourist sights in Paris. Worth the visit, but don't take long - crowds of tourists can be very annoying

The real deal. While visiting Sacre Coeur, we took an hour to visit some of the surrounding streets and shops. There are still artists working and selling their goods, and this seems like the real France. Take the time to stroll around and peak into the galleries to see what is available. We spent some enjoyable time here.

An Enjoyable Afternoon Visit. We weren't sure we would find the time to get here on our three and a half day visit to Paris but so glad we did. The atmosphere of Montmartre is unique, the artists' work fun to view (and purchase) and the view spectacular. The climb was too much for my knees but the funicular solved that problem. A great afternoon visit!

Immerse yourself!. One of the great areas of Paris. A bit overrated in description for many and by many, regardless, a great place to walk around, eat, enjoy the Paris scene as it once was and still is in many respects.

Lovely streets!. We walked up the steps to the Basilica and the views are amazing. We really enjoyed walking around the little streets up top and stopping in some shops and having a drink at a little café. I'm really happy we took the time to take the Metro (very quick from our hotel around Opera) to enjoy this area during the day. As it started getting dark, the area was turning more into a clubbing crowd so perfect time for us to head back to our area for dinner. Loved it!

Village of arts. You can't say you've seen Paris without at least an evening spent in Montmartre. Village of artists, with a nostalgic feel, just stroll down the streets and enjoy the feel of it. Lots of tourists, sometimes negotiating with the stret artists about the cost of their portrait, can brusquely break the charm... But don't let that stop you from visiting it

Christmas . You can't go to Paris and miss on this amazing site.It is a large hill, 130 metres high, primarily known for the white-domed Basilica of the Sacré-Cœur on its summit and as a nightclub district. You feel the a serene sense of peace and you will enjoy seeing parts of Paris from above.The other, older, church on the hill is Saint Pierre de Montmartre, which is also a must visit.Sometimes musicians gather infront of the church and sing in open air.

SIGHTSEEING. Took Metro to Monmartre - lovely area. Took a road train trip round area for a general feel of the area. If you have a Metro pass this can be used on the funicular up to Sacre Coeur unless you enjoy working up endless steps.
