your other face. i like always stressless moments. just sitting on the terras of one of the many restaurants eating an oniunsoup.watching people watching painters watching portretists.its nice to see when you let make a quick portret or when your are sitting for half an hour that you always have another face when the painting is ready than you thougt you had. And always you will smile ,look happy and pay to much. for a moment you are special and you take a nice memmory to home. who is this gay anyhow? take your time there spent almost whole the day ,spot the local , see the tourists , the artist tolk to them ask questions over their work and eat a pancake and perfect bonbons.
A fun little excursioun. We just went up and walked around for half the day looking at various things and shops and had a nice little lunch at one of the cafes.
Gorgeous View. It is totally worth it to climb up Montmartre and Enjoy the View over Paris! Would go anytime again...

Cute but a tourist trap so you have to be vigilant. The Sacred Heart Cathedral is in this neighborhood so it is quite popular for tourist. There are some cute shops and good food but it doesn't feel particularly Parisian. This is totally just an opinion, but it felt like we were being hoarded into this one area to look at shops but anytime you exited small tacky tourist shop you were accosted by people who wanted to paint you or for you to sign a petition ( don't do this it is a trick that young gypsy girls are taught so that other young girls can steal your belongings ). It was overall unpleasant but very scenic and beautiful at the same time .

Great Artists. This area is located next to Sacre Cour. The meandering streets are crowded with visitors, shops, artists and restaurants. We counted over 20 street artists trying to convince the visitors to sit at their stand and get their faces sketched. The central courtyard was a tent city, filled with artists selling beautiful oil paintings of various sizes. Many restaurants are located here. The takeout menu is much cheaper than if you want to sit at a table.
art. Lovely area and you can wander away from all the tourists. There are many artists behind Sacre Coeur and shopping and cafe's all around. Go off the beaten paths to find the best prices.

Beautiful. We loved this area, there were painters in the cobblestone streets and some amazing little cafés to drink coffee or have a snack. Lots of little unusual shops to browse in. Just a lovely place to stroll and chill out

Must see. Many tourists go to Paris and skip this place, and its really worth seeing. It is crowded with artists trying to make you a sketch although this can be annoying sometimes, the atmosphere here is great. there are a million souvenir shops, and coffee places. you also have the sacre-coeur Basilica which is beautiful.

A village within Paris. Montmartre is our favorite neighborhood to stay in while in Paris. It's charming village atmosphere makes you feel more like a local than a visitor. Although it is located on the northern outskirts of the city, it is only minutes away from all the major Parisian attractions whether in taxi, bus or subway. It is home of the famous Moulin Rouge and was home to Van Gogh and Picasso amongst others.It was no coincidence that the Parisian modern fairy tale " Amélie Poulain" was pretty much entirely shot in this neighborhood. It is one of the last ones that still carry that pre-Haussmanian bohemian feeling that defined the "popular" Paris (as opposed to the "chic" Paris of the "grands boulevards").

Amazing People Watching. This is a wonderful neighborhood in Paris and includes Basilica
Sacre Coeur, interesting shops and many restaurants. We ate at
Brasserie La Mascotte, great fun and very friendly.

Its heavenly ........ Well worth the climb (although there are other options to get to the top) up the steps for the view over the city, the magnificent Sacre Coeur building and contents, the street artists and the lovely cafes.

Don't skip this.. Take the Metro. Not hard to do if you can read pictures. We happened to be there during a wine festival so it was more crowded than we expected but had fun! We grabbed a small tableat an outdoor cafe on the square where the artists paint. Great people watching and kind of cool to be sipping wine, eating cheese and watching artists paint.

Crazy busy, steep climb to a lovely view of Paris. A hodge podge of criss cross streets leading up to Sacre Cour. Lots of cafes and restaurants make this are boisterous with crowds of merry-makers. Ascending to the top of the hill is well worth it because of the panoramic view of Paris.

Can't say you've seen Paris without a stop in Montmartre. The last time we were in Paris and walked around Montmartre it poured down so this time we were pleased to have a day that was cloudy but dry. Okay, the art isn't all great and there are probably a lot of 'painters' whose day jobs are elsewhere, but it's fun to watch tourists being sketched and to look for a few of the genuine artists who carry on working regardless of rubberneckers. It's crowded and chaotic but that just adds to the fun, and if you get hungry there are lots of places where you can eat without leaving the district. We did see a couple of guided tours trying to stick together while they wandered through the multitude of easels and artists but if you do a bit of homework so you'll know more about the place it's good to just do some wandering by yourself and get the feel of Montmartre.
Walking Tour. Wonderful guide. great experience. Would recommend to anyone. All the little quaint spots. It was a high spot of the visit. Greta shops.

Done to Death. What the French do best is turn things into an art form.What can you say about a place which nurtured the dynamic, revolutionary forces of Impressionism and Modernism, even if it failed to reward most of the practitioners?Answer... dirty, plagued by rubberneckers and overrun with the would-be's- if-they-could-be's.He he, same as it ever was!And, despite a century of tourism, Montmartre remains a bohemian picture in itself.On top of the mont squats the johnny-come-lately cathedral of Sacre Coeur, ever glorious in its white coat of sparkling gypsum blocks.No older than the revolutionary artworks themselves, the 5 domed Byzantine basilica sits there a perfect bleached skullcap.Unfortunately, after all these decades, it's a bit like the moneylenders and the barely talented have taken over the outside of the temple.Indeed, the entire temple mount - from church to gallery to restaurant to historical must-see is like one gigantic, ever-turning tourist hamster wheel.But I cannot look away!

The highlight of our visit. We had been to Paris several times, but never got to Montmartre , so it was a must do on this trip. I must say, the steps almost got the better of me! The church is really just another European church, but the neighborhood surrounding it lives up to it's reputation. The cafe Consulat is well with a visit, being excellently located, and one can feel the Parisian vibe, for want of a better expression.
Beautiful. This was our favourite part of Paris as it was relatively clean and had so much character.The views are stunning.There are so many cafes and bars which give the true feel of Paris
2014. The place to visit! Great little cafes and bistros, lots of artists with their paintings for sale, a great experience for artwork and French cusine!!

Very Touristy... but can be nice. We didn't spend too much time here. Apart from visiting the Sacred Heart Basilica (which is beautiful and separate review for this), we mainly wanted to see the local artists and maybe pick up something they made for our home. Unfortunately, everyone was doing either portraits or the typical Parisian skyline. Very boring if you ask me. Luckily, Place de Tertre had other things to offer. Nice little knick knack shops for anyone who's looking for cheap gifts for back home, the typical Parisian dining experience (a bistro with tables facing to the world so you can enjoy a cafe and watch the world go by... very nice).They also have a jeep style "bus/train" that takes you all around Montmartre which we didn't take but is a good way to see the area.
ART and STROLL. A must do for one afternoon. You can watch the artists do portraits, feed the pidgeons, have a crepe from a cart, and just enjoy what everyone else does when in Montmarte.
Painters on the street.. Painters on the street,nice cafe and bars be very-very carefull with the prices.Always a lot of people there.
Nice area but beware of scammers. Nice setting, but beware of street performers conning you for money! Walk away!Otherwise, the place is pretty cool. Loads of Cafes etc etc

The arty village in the city. Many famous people have lived here, the 'butte' is walkable, though certain areas a quite touristy. We've stayed in Montmartre and also below with views of Sacre Coeur. Lots of small boutiques admid some more touristy souvenir shops, an excellent boulangerie and plenty of cafés to relax and unwind.

A place to visit in sunshine or snow. The chapel Sacre Coeur is visible from many place in Paris. This year we found a dramatic view from the Centre Pompidou.The interior is perhaps smaller than an exterior view across the city would suggest, but well worth a visit.My favorite memory of Montmarte is from Christmas Eve 1992 when I stood outside the chapel at midnight as snow fell and voices raised in song floated out into the night. April of 2015 we visited the interior one sunny day.

Experience a little unusual culture. This area of Paris is renowned as an art district. Many stalls with art for sale and artists painting in the streets. A little commercialised with portraits done cheap and on the spot. It's very vibrant and quirky. I'm not an art connoisseur so I thought it a nice experience and enjoyable. Experts in art review it as average and pricey. I think it's a part of Paris's historic past and a guided tour is advised if you want to learn about why it is a tourist area. As a solo traveller wandering through uniformed, I just thought it was a lovely area and different. I smiled walking all through these streets and lanes.

Not a must visit. Not a must visit. It is a decent place to buy some souvenir nearby. As it stays open late night, the place tends to get filled with drunk people later in the evening.There are some street performances going on most of the times.

Worth the trip out. If you're staying in the centre of Paris, it may seem like a long way out just to go to Moulin Rouge, but the Montmartre district is beautiful! Full of little stores, artists and cafes, it's big enough to wander around for a morning.
So romantic. This was my favorite area in Paris. It is a big cliché but still wonderfully romantic. The view from Sacre Couer is fantastic and the street musicians make an untrue feeling.

Nice at nighy. I ve been there with a friend at night And it Was super nice. There Are a lot of young people there at night sitting on the stairs or on the floor and you can see the whole paris lighten up.

A hidden Gem. I wonder how many people think only of Sacre Coure in Monmartre. Do yourself a favour and walk to the other end of Rue de Abyse and see the real majesty of Montmartre with Fromargerie, Bouchers, Boullongeries, gellati stores etc
Fun day to look around. Very crowded but fun . More restaurants than artist but still worth the visit.it is worth your time to take a ealk down the laneways

Like every other tacky tourist place in the world. Interesting to walk through but keep walking. Funny how tourist places all have the same feel. Tacky shops, bad food, in fact the worst meal we had in Paris.

Over-hyped, but don't miss it!!. You can't visit Paris without taking in Montmarte. Having said that, it is over-hyped, the artwork for sale is average and overpriced, and the cafes are overpriced as well. But what the heck, you are in Paris and this is one of the classic tour spots that you cannot ignore.

Be careful!. This place has a great view, and lots of good food. Unfortunately it is also packed with pickpockets and the like. I was stopped by some African guys who tied a string around my arm and then demanded money. When I refused they started getting a bit more threatening. They surrounded me and told me to open my wallet. Then I got loud and said, "you don't know me. Do I need to call someone?!" After that they backed down and ripped the stupid string thing off my arm. Be careful in this place!
Loved this area. We went on a food tour in the area and really fell in love with it. Lots of little shops and streets to wonder around and explore. Wish we had more time.

Little surprises. Not as much history or emphasis on the location as was indicated in guide books. Turned out to be a lot of curb-side artists doing sketches. Pressure to buy a sitting. At least the cathedral was interesting as the home of where the Jesuits order was founded.

Charming arty part of Paris. Had a walk around after visiting basilicaCute, arty area with street artists offering to sketch you, we deferred due to lack of time but the sketches looked pretty old. Bough some limited edition sculptures at reasonable prices. Very festive feel with tents and people offering food tastes

A visit to Paris not complete without going to Montmartre. After the long walk walk up the steep hill to ScareCoeur you come to the Montmartre area. This is a great area to explore and see the quaint streets. We stopped a the top square where the artist were painting and decided to have some lunch. I had a large bowl of mussels which was actually very good and not badly priced for this touristy area. An added attraction was a street performer was entertaining us while we ate. A nice way to spend a few hours seeing one of the most historic areas of Paris.
Up and down - take your time. You can use an hour or you can use a week. Some stay for life. Wonderful atmosphere, small cafes and restaurants. Unfortunately I could only stay for one whole day.
Impressionists. You need a tour guide to take you through the up and down streets and alleys and to point out all the artists, etc. that lived here over a hundred years ago.
Too touristic. I do not know how it was when it acquired its fame but it is a very touristic place. Charming but cheap and crowded. Tge view to Paris is nice.

Montmartre. A beautiful, artistic area of Paris. Situated on a hill so be aware and lots of cobbles are tough on the feet. Lots of artists willing to draw you or sell you their paintings and friendly locals offering free cultural advice. Some nice restaurants and gift boutiques.

A nice area to spend the morning or afternoon. We spent the morning here after our visit to Sacre Coeur. It is just a short walk from there. It is a quaint little area renowned for the artists that congregate around the square to paint scenes of Paris or do portraits. There are some really beautiful old village like buildings that you would expect to find in the French countryside. There are also numerous restaurants to relax and have lunch or coffee at and watch the world go by.

Incredible place. Go on Sunday if you can.. Went up to Sacre-Couer on Sunday and it was amazing. Wine and cheese tents everywhere. Artists, restaurants and churches, what more could you ask for. It is outside and great for a nice sunny day.

Souvenirs, tree-lined avenue and Ooh La La!. We took a ride on the hop-on, hop-off tourist bus to Montmartre, primarily to visit the beautiful Sacre Coeur cathedral. After we had visited the cathedral, we decided to explore part of Monmartre on foot. We headed down the narrow street directly in front of the cathedral. This street was called the Rue de Steinquerke. It would have been an interesting street, if you happened to have a particular fascination for souvenirs and cheap ladies’ clothing. The street was home to many souvenir shops, cheap clothing outlets and cafes. Other than that, there wasn’t much else. After a cursory glance in a few of the shops, we then walked on until we reached the Boulevard de Rochechouart, where we turned right and headed in the general direction of the Moulin Rouge. This boulevard had the potential to be a beautiful city street. It had a tree-lined walking path and park area in between the two traffic lanes. However, it was spoilt for us as, we moved closer to the site of the Moulin Rouge. In this area, lining either side of the boulevard was a large number of sex shops and sleazy strip clubs. Not exactly the type of area where you would want to go walking, if you happened to have children with you. Fortunately, we did not.When we finally reached the Moulin Rouge, we had a quick look at it and then began our return walk to the hop-on, hop-off bus stop. We had been to the Moulin Rouge at night-time during a previous visit to Paris. The building looks much more impressive at night-time than it did on this occasion, during the daylight hours. In summary, we were not greatly impressed by the part of Monmartre which we saw during this walk. Sacre Coeur was by far, the most impressive attraction which we saw in the area. Perhaps we should have done more research before we went there, so that we could have seen the nice arty part of Monmartre.

Great shopping!. Great bustling part of Paris close to the Eiffel Tower. Great place to pick a bargain. There are many little shops displaying their goods for sale. Many restaurants in the area attracting great crowds. Just be prepared for the climb to the top with a flight of steps or you can take the funicular. Many museums to visits as well as see a cabaret show at the Moulin Rouge.

Montmartre. This is a beautiful Cathedral. Up on a hill so you will have a very good view of Paris. We took a tour by minivan and were taken right to the cathedral itself. Don't miss seeing this place.
Very romantic and touristic. This is where i always stay when in Paris. It is great to walk in its streets, shop, eat and have coffee.

Go to the cemetary. Just a neat old cemetary with very eloborate crypts Oscar Wilde Poet and Jim Morrison of the doors is buried here Jims grave sight isn't much but the grunge go there and throw him cigarettes what a laugh
Love this area. So many streets to explore so much to see, venture away from the tourist traps and explore well worth the visit and better still stay for a few nights

Great atmosphere . Yes the cafes here can be pricey but there is also a Starbucks there. It is a great place to get your portrait done but remember to bargain a bit with the artists as there are many.

Loved Montmartre. We stayed for three days in Montmartre. The location is a little far a field, but you truly feel as if you are in a neighborhood. We loved the little shops and bought wine, bread and cheeses for our picnics. It seemed a bit quieter here than being in the Paris hub area. We had visited Sacre-Coeur on our last trip to Paris, so this time we chose to view some other attractions. The metro makes it so easy to access all of the other arrondissements. I suggest that you become familiar with the areas you want to visit ahead of time, so you don't become lost. As for Montmartre it is a great little area, but beware there are a lot of steep streets and walking uphill was part of our daily routine. I would not suggest this area for a person who has fitness issues. Finally a caution, it was necessary on about four occasions to use a taxis service. Make absolutely sure that the driver is shown your destination location on a map. We had number of unpleasant experiences, in which our driver took us to the wrong location or on circuitous route. You may end up paying far more than is necessary for your ride.

Magical . We have been to Paris multiple times and always come here for the ambience and food. Great for strolling around the streets and finding hidden gems in bgsck alleys. Recommend for any first timers ot seasoned traveler to Paris. Only tip be prepared for the crowds.
Must visit. Lovely place to stroll around, many do. Artists of every description, items to buy or pose for a portraits or sketch. Numerous cafes, bars, restaurants to watch the world go by
Magical. A must-see in Paris! Lovely to see all the artists doing what they love, and typical French cafe's is just lovely.

The arty Paris, where the artists congregate and sell their wares.. It's a little carny... with the number of caricature illustrators doing caricatures of the tourists for 20 euro or so in the square. But if you explore further afield int he streets of Montemarte their are artists everywhere on street corners, in the middle of the street, and displaying on street side retaining walls. very bohemian, a little cliched, but the cliche seems to fit this part of the world. The steep streets and multitude of back alleys with treasures everywhere makes Montemarte,....well Montemarte.

Run down. This area of Paris was historically separate. It used to house artists etc. it has turned into an ugly tourist Mecca. Over priced, very hilly and insincere. Packed with tourists. Not recommended
Must see!. Beautiful area. Full of churches, shopping and other little gems. Could easily spend days wandering here alone! Easily accessible by metro

Montmarte. First visit over 50 years ago and was charming and quaint. Now very crowded and not so enjoyable. I think January and February may be better months to avoid the crowds. If it is your 1st visit the little train ride to Place du Tertre is a nice look at Montmarte on the way to Sacre Coeur. Enjoy.

A Great Place to Visit. To enjoy Montmartre, get away from Sacre Coeur/Place du Tertre and explore the steps and backstreets. Yes, going up and down the hills can be tiring but there are plenty of cafes and brasseries to rest a while. Be sure to have a guide book with you to pass and don’t miss the important sites. Even better, talk a walking tour with a reputable company (Paris Walks- my favourite).

My favorite area to visit. We travel to Paris every year at least once. And this is always a place I return. My favorite is Sacre Couer Basillica. And then afterwards, I tour Montmatre, enjoying the quaint shops and watching the artisans in progress.

Just a Short Visit But Interesting. We took in a bit of Montmarte as we were going to and coming from Sacre Couer. It looks to be a lively area and it has a colourful past. I recommend spending a day at least if you have time.
a must see... however a little disappointed. I had heard how amazing this was and while i'm glad we did go and see it, it was a little too touristy for my liking.
Spring 2015. Very nice area with all the painters with their artwork. You can find really nice paintings and there are many great bistrits and cafes!!!

Interesting area in more ways than one!. Old Paris streets, but unfortunately full of souvenir shops.However there were one or two galleries if you like art. The street artists were interesting to watch , if you want a portrait look around them all first as there are a variety of styles. Here you can see and visit the Sacre Coeur and walk downhill to the Moulin Rouge . Be careful here as there are lots of 'Chancers' trying to entice you into their gambling games.

beautiful view -"criminal enviroment ". montmarte offers a great view of Paris!especially at night!you can see the lights of the city and the tour eiffel and you can hear locals and tourists singing and hanging around!But: its a really dangerous place because there are a lot of people stealing .I go my laptop stollen from my car.so try not to be late and keep always an eye on your belongings!so my feelings are bittersweet,

Artists Haunt. The bustling suare is home to artisits from all over the world who flock to this district of Paris. As you stroll around there are artists painting the aged architecture or the Basilica of Sacre Coeur or perhaps you would like a caracature of yourself sketched by the many artisits who sit around.

Beautiful, artsy area. This is a beautiful location for watching the sun set after a day of walking around Paris. Be careful of over-eager street hawkers trying to sell their wares - one grabbed me by the wrist and I had to physically wrench myself from his grasp. Other than that, wander the area and find the hidden artwork such as bottle-glass mosaics on the walls of random buildings!
Charming. Quaint and secluded from the hustle and bustle of downtown. Picturesque streets. Amazing view of Paris. Take a guided tour to really appreciate the area.

Lots of tourists, but worth the trek. Montmartre makes for a great day out. Start at the Sacre-Coeur Cathedral and wend your way down the hill to Place Blanche or the seedier Place Pigalle. This is the land of La Boheme and once you get past the touristy Place de Tertre, there are some very good shops and restaurants. Not to mention the VIEW from the top of the hill over all of Paris.

Yes yes yes, my kind of Paris but.... What is there not to love about this part of the city. Of course, one climbs up the hill and enjoys the lovely view over the city, and than stroll around the square where most visitors hang out. SO this can be crowdy. But we found going down the hill, at the other site of the hill, a more quiet Mont Martre. Strolling through small streets and finding little stores with the most strange collections of anything, little cafe's and nice restaurants. One your way, visit the Mont Martre museum and keep going down. Really a lovely stroll.
something not to miss!!!. street vendors, the buildings the stairs and the view just to name a few of the beautiful sights here!!!
Always Nice for Sunsets. Spent more sunsets than I can count on these steps. Haggle with the beer vendors and don't pay more than a euro for a little Heinken to sip while you watch the sun go down.

A Wonderful Spot to Visit. High above Paris, the area is a festive piece of good natured fun. Visit the shops, buy a painting, eat the delicious food and visit the beautiful Sacre Couer before enjoying the view of Paris from up high.

Montmartre. This was not my favorite time in Paris. It may be suited to others but I did not find the streets any more charming that Le Marais or St Germaine. What we did find were a lot of crowds and street vendors. The art would have been interesting but it was clearly produced by a formula to paint a certain scene and it was exceptionally overpriced. We also did not find Sacre Couer to be as amazing as Notre Dame or Saint Chapelle. If your schedule is tight, we would recommend prioritizing other areas of Paris.

Great area to people watch. Love this area to people watch, have a seat at one of the outdoor cafes and watch the world go by. A bit of a hike to get there from the metro, but well worth it once you have arrived. I biked up to the 'summit' one time, will never do that again! It was brutal...
Very picturesque. Very interesting place to just sit, have a coffee and watch the world go by. Very relaxing with lots of great art.
Montmartre a must see. Spend at least a half day wondering within and around Montmartre. Walk the steps and the arts square.

My favorite place in Paris. I love this place and the ambiance. The church has an amazing view of Paris. It is located in a very hippy neighborhood of Paris, the artist town. So if you go there don't miss the opportunity to walk around the street and stop in some of the souvenir shops.
THE BEST!!!. The Basilica in Montmartre was where we started. From there we went into the artist area and visited with the artists and each bought art work to bring home. Just wonderful!!

It always was great and it still is . Most tourists follow well trodden paths. There are alleys and corners in Montmartre however that many tourists never see. Spend at least a day in this lovely quartier and, if you look carefully, you'll find why this is still a real gem. Even better, find a hotel close-by and take even more time to discover what this part of Paris has to offer. Everybody will warn you for pickpockets, they operate especially around Sacré-Cœur and Pigalle, but in October, when it is slightly quieter than in summer, we've still seen tourists with open rucksacks on their back. Handbags are sometimes pulled off and the thieves disappear on a scooter. Quieter times makes people careless but it really is important to remain vigilant, especially here.

My best place in Paris. Despite the limited car parking there, once you step out your car and walk around you feel the life of painters who are scattered there doing whar they do best. It is up hill so you may experience some difficulties going around but it is worth it. Highly recommended.

Disappointed. We were disappointed in not seeing any painters here. Vendor stands were also taken down so other than the view and visit the church which was beautiful, the experience was less than expected

Busy, lively and full of character. Montmartre is a very distinct sector of Paris. Good for exploring especially the side streets where there are lots of little shops, and there is plenty of character

A village inside the big city. We went to the Sacre-Coeur and then picked up a walk through Montmartre from the Lonely Planet guide. I really like this area because of it's atmosphere. It is like a village inside the big city. On the small square in the heart of Montmartre you find the painters. Not really to make a paining of the nice square but more to make drawings of the tourists (on demand) and sell overpriced paintings. Not very authentic but nice to walk around.The area around the square with the painters contains several art galleries and many old buildings and is nice to walk around. You can even find a small vineyard on the hill. We walked down through the streets and ended up at the subway station catching a glimpse of the Moulin Rouge.
Great area to feel the Paris "ambiance". I always spend some time in Montmartre when I come to Paris. I enjoy the narrow streets, the Place du Tertre with its painters, and friendly cafes.

Awesome neighborhood, bring your stair-climbin' shoes. Comfortable shoes. This is a nice little neighborhood up on a hill. Comfortable shoes. There are lots of different sites to see in the area. Comfortable shoes. Couldn't find the Love Wall, but we saw Salvador Dali's place. Comfortable shoes...

The View-Is It Really Worth It?. OK, today was rainy and cloudy so there was not really a view. I did not walk up to the Sacre Couer because there was so much crap being hawked by vendors in every square inch. It was like a carnival. The area probably has some nice shops but right around the butte or hill, it is just junk. Unless it is a clear day and you have run out of things to do ( in Paris??!!!), don't waste your time.
Such a lovely place to wander around. Boutiques and shops line the streets of Montmarte. Find a nice cafe and sit to people watch. Also go up the cable car to Sacre Coeur.

Paris Views & Local Art. You should not go to Paris without going to Montmartre and be sure to save your Metro ticket as it gives you use of the Funicular that takes you up the hill. When you walk around the left side of the building you will find a street to your left that has all kinds of good shops and at the end you get to the square where the artists are and it is great to have lunch and people watch and observe the artists, many will be painting during the day.

The best and most colorful neighborhood from Paris!. Can't miss taking the "Funiculaire" to the top of the hill to visit the "Basilica du Sacre-Coeur" or walk all the steps to the hill. The view of Paris is one of the most wonderful especially on a cool December day! and do not miss a stop outside the "Moulin Rouge" to take your background photo of this famous place. If you have the budget ($$$) may you enjoy the show which is something not to miss if you are in Paris. Recommend this area to any tourist for the 1st time visiting Paris!
Parisian splendour and market squares with lovely cafes and artist.. Super place to watch people, sit at a cafe or have your Portrait done. Very Parisian and the Sacre Couer is magnificent.

Good area to stay. We loved being in Montmartre. Easy access to the Metro and short walking distance to main shopping districts, cafes and live shows. We found quaint little shops that were extremely affordable for latest fashion including shoes and clothing along with fantastic bakeries and restaurants. There are loads of accommodation places and affordable prices. My daughter and I stayed in a really small hotel but the area was safe and clean.
Take a wander. Take a wander in Montmartre and up the hill to Sacre Coeur for fantastic views of Paris. You won't be disappointed
Passingthrough. Really cannot give significant review as sitting on open top bus tour Worth the trip of course but get off I did nt as at that time it was raining

Very pinturesque. Lobely place to visit. It is a place easily recognized by the Sacred Heart Church, the hills, painters everywhere, and nightclubs. I really enjoyed visiting and would love to come back soon. Very pinturesque is the way I would best describe this place.

Another must see in Paris. A great area for discovering some local artists as well as visiting the Sacre Coeur. Caution, many of the restaurants are BAD offering set courses with no options and terrible quality.

love this little arty streets. always a vibrant buzz around these streets, a cheap family friendly people watching place to wander around and just see life happening. A must do whilst in Paris. Enjoy!

Great place to stay!. We stayed at Montmartre and i would recommend it to any traveler.
Great location with lots of cafes and restaurants, Moulin Rouge, Sacre-Coeur walking distance of each other.

Beautiful view. Go when it's almost sundown and sit iin the marble stairs of the church till sun sets when the crowd is not at it's thickest and enjoy the cool breeze and bask on that beautiful view of Paris at night and it is really pretty awesome!!! After that, dine at one of the restaurants al fresco. With a glass of wine in my hand, I am in Paris baby and I did not break the bank.

The best................. We stayed in an apartment in Rue des trois freres...........what a wonderful spot, right opposite the shop famous for its Amelie connection........while we were there it coincided with an art festival all around us, and the grape harvest festival that went on over three days..........bit hilly, but that's expected....wonderful cobbled streets, wonderful places to eat and drink........we absolutely loved it and have already left a deposit on our apartment for next year

Worth a visit if you have extra time.. The best thing here is the view and feeling of being out of the city a bit. Be prepared, though, that the "art in the street" scene is much more about getting you to sit for portraits in a square of people competing for your business than it is a bunch of artists creatively painting (at least it was when we were there) . Some cool galleries, but many seeming to sell mass produced art. Was our last stop of our trip. Glad we did it, but fine to be last.

My favorite part of town. It is hard to explain the attraction of Montmartre, it has to be experienced. Beautiful streets, nice little stores and restaurants. A lot "cleaner" than it was ten years ago. Keep an eye on the beautiful doors and art on the walls. Higher up Montmartre gets pretty steep, so were good shoes and take your time.

Artsy & fun. Put this on your visit to Paris list. Reminded me of the Village in the 60's! Many, many artists will draw your picture or anything you want. they are seasoned artists & vey talented. Lots of artsy shops & cafes. One of my favorite parts of the trip to Paris. Bought my daughter an interesting glass dish. she loved it!

interesting area of paris. It worth heading up to this part of Paris for a day. It gave us a real sense of 'france' and boasted some wonderful shops and eating establishments as well as some spectacular views into the main city. visit the cemetery, the basilica and enjoy a coffee!

Montmartre. The place not nice at all , you have to take care on your money when you goes up from the beak pocket, the smell not good at all , The only good is the view that you can see all Paris from the top and the signer that on everywhere also we can`t forget the fresh air i am afriad to take round with my family from the beakpocket so i am not see the artist who drow you :(

Great view. Montmarte is way up so therefore a great place for a fantastic view of Paris. The Metro gets you to Montmarte but you still have a ways to go to get to the top. We walked up the steps, a lot of steps. If you're in shape, no problem, if not you may want to take the metro and then follow the signs to the Funicular. The Funicular goes up and down the steep hills. Another alternative is to take a cab both ways.Once you're at the top, take in the view or sit and relax at one of the many cafes with a glass orfwine or have a bite to eat. You may even want to have your portrait done by the many artists in this area.Sacre Coeur is also here if you wish to see it. We did not go during this trip since we have visited this beautiful church in the past.
Art lovers. If you love art this a good place to meet the local artists up close. Also it has some of the most beautiful views of the city.
Excellent atmosphere. Montmartre has its own electric atmosphere. Some cool artists there, good restaurants and great for people watching.

Should have stayed longer to visit more places. What a wonderful area, lots to see, Bohemian like atmosphere, open air cafes attached to restaurants, lots of artist painting in the streets, art shops - can take little train from Moulin Rouge to summit (very steep hill)

Charming and creative atmosphere. We explored this area of Paris through Discover Walks walking tour and it was amazing. Try it with the tour as you get more info of the area. Bohemian in its essence, the Moulin Rouge was close by and next to it are a couple of blocks of sex shops and strip clubs. You walk up the hill roads and you come across the cafes and shops as well as the different places where artists like Van Gogh, Monet, and Picasso lived and hung out. The Sacre Coeur Basilica was there too. It was such a easygoing, laid-back vibe that it makes you want to live there.

The perfect place to see the real life of Paris. Walking though the streets in Montmartre is what expect paris to be like. Local shops and restaurants everywhere and baguetts to die for. If you plan to dine outside of the tourist areas this is the place to eat and feel like a local.

Soak it up!. We were fortunate enough to get there early in the day. The artists were just sitting up their displays. We wandered around and went in some shops. After a while it started getting more active and crowded. We ate lunch in one of the covered patios. As an Impressionist lover it was so much fun to feel the vibe. I could close my eyes and see the greats sitting around discussing art. This area has changed very little since they were there. I highly recommend.

Bit touristy. I visited Montmartre on my last day in Paris to wrap the trip up with the view of Paris. The view of course was beautiful, but I found the place to be a bit touristy. While it is true that tourists, and a lot of tourists, will be there at any major attraction, I could not really feel the so-called la boheme feel of Montmartre.

Tourist Area, but worthy of a Look!. I enjoyed a guided walk to see the streets and sights of arty little Montmartre. A narrated "tram" ride took us to the top of the hill Sacre Coeur. The area was very crowded on a Monday afternoon- very touristy. In the square is an open air market where many artists ( of different talents and abilities) offer any style of takeaway painting you like! Also stopped to watch the caricature and portrait artists. Ice cream stand, outdoor cafe- and Starbucks- there too. The narrow and twisting streets are fun to walk. Saw the only vineyard in Paris. The view from top of hill and Sacre Coeur memorable. Steps of Sacre Coeur were for sitting- big crowd. Rather off putting was miked souvenir man at foot of steps. As always, beware of pickpockets. My fellow tourist saw her purse strap start to move while she sat on steps! With more time, I would have stopped into a museum.

Funicular is part of the attraction. Give the place an hour.. Nice streets, expensive food, great street show and amazing view. We do feel that a major part of the attraction is the funicular that takes you from the bottom of the hill to the top.Our weekly Navigo pass allowed us free and unlimited rides. Check ahead if you transportation pass includes the Montmartre funicular.Don't skip it since it is one of the most famous neighborhoods of Paris.

The Absolut best view of Paris. This is our Absolut favorite in Paris. Anytime of the day or at night. Avoid weekends if you can, since the place can get crowded. Have a glass of wine place du Tertre and just go back in history. You will never be disappointed, no matter how offen you go.

Living the art. Monmartre really has a different feeling from the rest of Paris, especially if you stick to the smaller streets (and avoid the Sacre Coeur, which the locals do as well). We took a guided tour (focused on the impressionists), which is highly recommended but not a must.

Vendanges de Montmartre. We had a wonderful evening at the wine harvest festival with lots of interesting stalls of food, wine and champagne. That is until about 8.45pm when a stallholder told us there would be a fireworks display at 9pm so we thought we would wait for it. We moved to the front of Sacre Coeur and found a space to watch it from. But that space got smaller and smaller until I was being incredibly intimate with strangers. At 9.35pm with no sign of anything happening I decided I wanted to leave but that was easier said than done. There was absolutely no way out of the crowd. Lots of pushing, jostling, elbowing and still more people thrusting their way in. It was an accident waiting to happen. I think we got out of the crowd about 11pm - and the fireworks weren't worth it! A frightening end to what had been a lovely evening.

A very Charming district of Paris. With attractions like Sacre Coeur Basilica and Moulin Rouge this charming district is a must visit in Paris. You can also visit Van Gogh's flat and the locations for Amelie movie. Nest to take a walking tour to explore the area.

Death by Mass Tourism. The first time I visited Montmartre was in 2007. In 2007 was touristy but not at this level. The place reminds me the worst parts of Venice or Prague. Full of tacky souvenir shops, bad quality restaurants (most of them), at this stage I would say that the area lost its charm. The romanticized Montmartre is gone, it is now a tourist trap. The only way to recover the area is avoid at all cost buying garbage at the souvenir shops and all these neon signed restaurants. Avoid these area, if it is your first time in Paris, it will break your heart.

Expect a lot of tourists and cheesy souvenir shops at Montmartre. Upon visiting Montmartre, I found it to be much more touristy than I expected. The area around the Moulin Rouge and at the base of Sacre Coeur was also very cheesy. Other than that and the guys that try to tie strings on your fingers as you walk up the steps to the basilica, it is an interesting area. The entrances to the Metro stations are very beautiful. Still, I would probably visit again because of Sacre Coeur, the Moulin Rouge and to see the artwork of the artists at Montmartre.
Touristy neighbohood. Sacre Coeur is lovely. The streets nearby (away from Place du Tertre) are quiet, but the area near Place du Tertre is full of tourists and painters who hawk their caricatures.

Touristy but you have to go to Paris's most well known area. Touristy but if you go early in the morning you will miss the crowds and can wander around in relative peace. There are excellent personal walking tours you can read about or download onto your phone.

Gem. This place is beautiful and amazing. I realized not so many arabic tourists are there which they should go and explore. Beautiful area with small streets and cafes all over the street and the amazing art work. I was told this is the area where most artists live and u can definitely see that.. Go during a sunny day and enjoy this beautiful area. We didnt book a tour guy, we just enjoyed walking all over it. Highly recommended

Crowded, noisy fun!. I love Montmartre! From its leafy boulevards to its crowded souvenir shops, Montmartre has something for everyone. The cafe's and crepe stands are very good, and the climb to the Sacre Coeur (they have a funicular for the less adventurous) provides an iconic view of Paris that is not to be missed.

Proper Parisian Feeling!. This place is amazing! It reminds of the olden Paris! The streets are narrow with eatery and craft shops. The whole area around the Sacre Couer is so nice. Here you can enjoy the fresh steamed corn on cob and jaggery peanuts..... There are a number of souvenir shops around and also few second hand branded clothing shops to suit choices! There was a local live band performing. The best way to reach here is by the Petit train starting from Moulin Rouge. We got to see the whole of Montmatre sitting in the train and also saved time by not having to climb up to the top. The hop on- hop off train journey is just amazing and not to miss!

Worth a Visit to the Beautiful Sacre Coeur Cathedral in Monmartre. Enjoyed visiting Montmartre for the first time, we loved the Sacre Cour Cathedral and also loved visiting the small Musee De Montmartre Jardins Renoir - Lovely district of Paris. Worth climbing all the steps and the long hard uphill walk.
Montmartre forever. Montmartre is too touristy but still charming in its own way. Obviously Sacre Coeur is my biggest inducement but the bustle of Montmartre is energizing.

Do not miss a trip to the XVIII and XIX century ... and nightlife today for fans. Do not miss a trip to the XVIII and XIX century ... and nightlife today for fans
In the early twentieth century , many famous painters have frequented the place : Dali, Van Gogh , Modigliani , Monet, Pissaro such And do not miss the Sacre Coeur basilica, built on a "Gruyere limestone", with stunning views Paris.
Art in the streets.. This is such a beautiful place, i wanted to go here because of the movie Amelie and i was not disappointed, such an artistic place... So beautiful!!!

view of the city. fun place to visit, but be prepared to walk and the many people who visit. There was a man entertaining with a soccer ball today who was very talented and fireworks display tonight. Plenty of alcohol and trinket sellers.

Take time to enjoy the ambience. Our son and daughter in law was married at st Pierres at Mont Marte, so we spent some time here. We wandered through Sacre Coure- carried along in the river of people, while a mass was taking place. Very impressive church. St Pierre nearby is the oldest church in Paris and has roman columns - well worth a visit! We went to a Sunday service - mixing with the regular congregation. We had a baguette/ Sandwich and coffee at a little cafe - not terribly well run, but honest it is called Le cafe Montmartre at 9 Rue Norvins, 75018 Paris, France

Go To This Area. I love this area of Paris. We went up in the late afternoon to sit on the steps of Sacre Coeur to see the sunset and it did not disappoint. What a lovely view of the city of Paris. Montmarte is a real happening place.

Don't miss it !. Montmartre is a simple metro ride from Champs Elysees although depending on location you may need to transfer - very simple - just look for the main station where you can pick up a train running to Abbesses (toward Cligancourt) - BE SURE TO KEEP YOUR TICKET STUB ! Montmartre is where Sacre Coeur basilica is located, the beautiful white church you see to the north-northwest from various locations or sites in Paris - don't short change yourself by missing this location! There is a lot of uphill and downhill walking but there is a tram also. The Montmartre area is a artist/tourist hangout and is very crowded but just fun for walking around, sitting outside for a drink or meal, and just enjoying.
Montmartre - Paris. Wonderful place to visit during the summer, you can have a 180degree view of Paris. You need to be fit. lots of steps.

Hip way before Hippies .... The famous Artist's quarter is fun to walk, explore & dine. You can have a charcoal done or watch one being done. Trendy shops & Sacre Coeur nearby. Can grab a taxi near the entrance to the square. A favorite spot for people watching. I enjoy it most here in the evening - less people and it's magical with lights ....
Another must do guided walking tour. A lot of history here , a good guide for a walking tour here is totally worth it. Finish at the sacred heart basilica, the lunch and people watching

Lack the charm of other tourist areas. It's not very charming here. Full of old theatres that have been turned into clubs. Nice if you likes clubs I guess. I noticed a lot of bars and people coming out drunk. The area is full of restaurants geared to tourists. The cafes are all expensive and all the same. It lacks the quant side streets in other Paris neighborhoods. I happened to catch a flea market which was nice. Other than that I would have been really bored in this neighborhood.

The Fabled Artists' Neighbourhood. It would be hard to miss the Place du Tertre in Montmartre. It was originally the main square of the village of Montmartre. If you interested of Catalan surrealist style artworks, just go west of Place du Tertre to visit the Dali Espace Montmarte. It has more 300 works by Salvador Dali on display.

Charming. The streets walked by the great artists have been gentrified but make for a good walk. Lots of interesting museums etc and the beautiful vineyard to see plus the cemetery. Some of the souvenir shops are tacky but on the whole not too bad. Cafes seem reasonable value.

It's not Paris until you've been here. Whether you're seeing the Sacre Coeur or just wandering around the artists' square or having a spot of lunch, Montmartre is a must. The seedier, heartier, more culturally historic side of Paris, it's well worth the hike up the mountain. Get the metro to the highest point you can, if it's hot or you're just not feeling the stairs today. Oh and make sure you look out for random wall art and the funny details others might not spot.

Montmartre - hard to walk it, nice to see it. Montmartre is a charming area worth seeing. Our taxi driver did not speak English well and did not understand where in Montmartre to drop us. This caused us to miss the walking tour which in hindsight was a blessing. The hills are extremely steep and a walking tour would have been tough. Instead, we had a coffee at a cafe, took pictures of Paris in front of Sacre Couer (what a view), and paid for a ride through Montmartre on a white "train". Great way to see the sights, and unlike the guidebook guru's comments, nobody laughed at us for doing this.
Best neighborhood in Paris!. Walking around Montmartre was wonderful. So many places to explore! There is a beautiful view of the city from the butte.
Nice views of paris. Definitely has great views of the old paris, but the crowd and very few number of taxis passing nearby makes it a bit of a hassle to get out of there

Montmartre visit. Love the restaurants and the shopping experience!! Very bohemian! Lots of great art!!! It was rainy day so everyone hanged-out with an umbrella. Use comfortable shoes. Lots of walking involved!

A little rough but nice. Had a nice little walk during the day from Moulin Rouge to Sacre Coeur. There were several small shops and galleries. You got the feeling of a small town within the city, however a little worn down.
Mountain of the Martyr and Artists. We toured this area on foot with Karen of Sight Seekers Delight. She was a delight ...offering us history and humor and interesting tidbits!

rare view of Paris. Of course this is a very touristy place, yet it is a beautiful walk up there and the view is worth it. Together with Eiffel tower, Tour Montparnasse and Beaubour it is one of the few places were you can view Paris as a whole

Our guide for Montmarte, Christine, was fantastic. Our guide Christine was absolutely fabulous....so passionate and interesting on our Montmartre/Sacre Coeur Walking Tour. We began at the Moulin Rouge, learning the history; heard about Dalida, van Gogh, Picasso and so many other interesting facts about the area.
Great place to walk around. Many shops, historic streets, lots of tourists, beautiful church (free entrance), wonderful view of Paris.

Looks better from afar.. Lots of tourists and vendors selling knick knacks. As you get to the top of the hill -- via the funicular or walking the stairs (we took the stairs), strong smell of urine. The road to get there from the metro is crowded with shops and people. Wouldn't put it on your list if your time is limited.

Artistic delight in a quaint market atmosphere. This delightful market square is located beside Sacra Cur Catholic church, itself a rewarding hilltop walk. Montmarte is a market atmosphere of paintings and craft by local artists who are happy to draw a potrait while you sit and enjoy delightful coffee and cakes from the surrounding eateries. We loved it.

Be sure to buy a wonderful keepsake. Be sure to stop her and buy yourself a wonderful keepsake of your trip. Didn't care for the character drawings, but there are many beautiful paintings are a very wide range of prices. Some very reasonable and some ridiculous.
Walk around.. Walk around this neighborhood. It is historic, fun and has great architecture. Parts are crowded and touristy but worth it.
Lacking flavor and tourist heavy.. Somewhat quaint but full of tourists. If taking photos of much changed former artists residences is your thing then this is it.
Fascinating Montmatre. must not miss Montmatre. Fantastic place, friendly, bustling with locals and tourists. Lots of lovely shops and boutiques, history, what more could you want.

A must see, worth spending 4 or 5 hours here.. I stayed in Montmartre for 4 days, just below Sacre Coure, so I had a lot of time to take in the sights.You will need to take some time when doing a walking tour, as there are a lot of steps & hills, but taking a break by turning right or left at the top of a hill, will help to keep from getting too tired.Sacre Coure is worth seeing by day & night.There are a lot of people trying to sell you stuff, near Sacre Coure but just ignore them with a "no merci". Don't take anything from them.I never got bothered, but I say some people that were, 100% due to them confronting the seller or being nasty.Plenty of places to eat & drink.There can be huge crowds there, but this shouldn't take from your visit, just expect it and enjoy the visit.

A village in the city. Montmartre offers not only great views over the city of Paris, but also a great atmosphere. It is quiet and relaxing and just a little bit quirky. Despite the masses of tourists, it somehow manages to maintain a village atmosphere despite being a stone's throw from Paris proper. Well worth an afternoon and, perhaps, an evening.

Great place for view of Paris. We came here to experience the Basilica and the views over Paris. We weren't disappointed by the views. The Basilica itself was wonderful. Interesting there were lots of children beggars being shooed away by armed soldiers. And there were loads of African Negros pestering tourists with Selfie stick and cheaps tourist trinkets. Best to just walk straight past. We walked through the town to find a nice eclectic cafes but after and hours walked decided to head back to Paris on the subway. This was the best way to get to and from the location.

Liked this place. We were in a hotel in Bibliotheque Fr Mitterrand in May2015 and took Line 14 Metro, got down at St Lazare and then took Line 12 to Abbesses. From Abbesses, it was about 5-10 mins walking to reach the funicular for going to top. As we had the day pass, we didn’t need any ticket for the funicular.We went to the Basilica and after that roamed the area. At the back side of the basilica, there was a place for the artists who were painting various sketches and drawings. Those were also for sell. We also explored the area, witnessed the original Moulin Rougue.Last but not the least, we saw that guy who showed various tricks and gymnastics with a football. That was superb. I had seen him in couple of movies but seeing him by my own eyes with football tricks was worth to watch.This is my the favourite area of Paris and will come back again whenever we would go to Paris.
Must see!. One of the must see! We went nighttime...Wonderfull..everything! The church, the view, the restaurants! It worths a visit for some hours!

Great place for a walk and shopping. If you are a student of French Art, particularly of the Impressionist period, you will want to read the history of this part of Paris before your visit. It was fun to tread along the streets where so many famous artists, such as Picasso, Monet, Manet, etc. spent time painting and sharing ideas. Take comfy walking shoes. Many lovely shops and sights, including the Moulin Rouge in this area.
A must see. Another must see in Paris and to learn the history of the building. again a very busy area but well worth it.

You can't miss this part of Paris.. This is probably my favorite part of Paris. Although a lot of tourists, there are fun little shops to go in and you can't leave without buying some type of art. it is away from the "hoity toyty" people in Paris -- the true feeling of the city is here. I can't come to Paris, if even for a layover, without coming here -- love it.

Great atmosphere!. One of my favourite places in Paris. This neighbourhood is full of life with lots of artists, individual little shops and good cafés/restaurants. Here you can mingle with the locals and get a feel of the real parisian way of life! This is an absolute gem in Paris and a great location to stay with good connections to the centre of Paris.

Great place to chill with even better views. We had a lovely few hours at Montmartre with a lovely lunch at the top.We took the tram train thing from outside Moulin Rouge, which took us up to the top and later on back to the bottom. well worth it.

Must see. A place you must see when you're in Paris. Some VERY good painters, and also some more average ones. When you want to buy good quality, you have to pay much. Spend your money well, but and expensive place for drinks around the market.

Perfect, charming place in Paris. Last visited Paris 10 years ago. Remembered Mont Marte as one of my favorite places. It did not disappoint. The accordion player added to the nice ambiance. Love the cathedral there. The view is breathtaking! The funicular is a fun way to get to the top. Lots of nice shops and wonderful artists.

Montmartre: The Gem in Paris. What a wonderful area of Paris. It is full of history and the atmosphere of the area is spectacular. Once home to many artists, strolling the hilly streets puts you right back in the time of Van Gough and Picasso. Sacre Coure is the cherry on top. Take the time to visit this area if you are in Paris. It will not disappoint you.
Great for Shopping. If you are into shopping this is the district for you. From the Bon Marche to the Galleries de Lafayette to t he small boutiques.., you can easily spend the day and lots of cash.

Heritage, Culture, Atmosphere. We walked for hours around the Montmartre and could easily return time after time. The avenues are filled with character, with inviting and interesting shops and galleries, with bistros and restaurants, and with smiling, relaxed people. No trip to Paris would be complete without a ramble through Montmartre.

Dinner at Montmartre. We went to Montmartre while we toured Sacre Coeur. The town is full of history, and interesting to see. We had dinner there and it was a wonderful experience. Our waiter was a jolly guy, who we enjoyed talking to. We watched the artists in the town square. I was a little nervous about the pick pockets, but we did not encounter any of them.

A must visit while in France.. A must visit and great experience to witness the artists and atmosphere of Montmarte. We make sure we visit each time in Paris. It is a very hilly area with lots of steps.

Hiking through Montmartre. My wife and I took a Viator walking tour of Montmartre one afternoon. The guide was a young man who lived in the area and was obviously proud of his community. The tour was a lot of fun but no time was available to shop. We went from the Moulin Rouge up the hill to Sacre Couer so it was quite a hike. Once there we were on our own getting a cab to get back to our hotel. We really enjoyed the day but be prepared to walk.

Worth the visit, but be careful. Monmarte itself is very much full of history and served as the catalyst for Impressionism and under-worldly activities. Today, the area is filled with porn shops, "massage" parlors and beggars. We went on an Impressionist walk, which was great, but the main drag through Montmarte leaves a lot to be desired. This was the only place in Paris we felt unsafe... which we did end up thwarting 4 men trying to rob us. Word of advice, be careful, don't put your money in your back pockets and leave your purse at home. I am giving this a 4 star because I refuse to let the pickpockets ruin the beautiful parts of Montmarte.

One of our best days in Paris. This day had to be a favorite waking one., Montmartre and the beautiful Sacrè-Coure Bascillia. Here , on top (of the world) is a miraculous view of the entire city of Paris, including the Eiffel Tower in all its glory. Here is where many artists spend their time painting what would become masterpieces, Picasso , Van Gogh to names few  We spent the whole day browsing here. It is a day to not rush. Take a good guide book and you do not need to join a tour. We felt it much more enjoyable to do this area at our own pace.

Walking round Montmartre. A walk around Montmartre is well worthwhile. The old houses, the winding streets, the wandering artists and whole atmosphere is worth spending a couple of hours. And all for free unless the shops and bars tempt you.

Romance is in the air at Montmartre. Narrow winding streets, restaurants and cafes perfect for people watching, sounds of accordion and bohemian artsy vibes everywhere. Absolutely in love with this part of the city, If you're looking for a romantic place to stay - its just perfect. Arrive to Abbesses metro station (line 12). When exiting the metro - "Wall of Love" is just in front of you - have few photos here and find words "I Love You" in your language than head to Coquelicot - small bakery and restaurant where you can enjoy one of the most delicious breakfasts in Paris. Have a friendly chat with the bubbly waitress who doesn't speak any english but still manages to make you laugh and get the order just right - (hot chocolate here is epic btw.) Fuelled by this great french breakfast start climbing the hill to reach Sacre Cour - have a quick glimpse at the Basilica and wander around the art market next to it. Yes there is some beggars around but just ignore them and they leave you be. Trust me you will love this place !

Always tres Parisiene.. Always interesting, if not for the same reasons as what it became famous, it is always amusing to be there, be it for the lively action of the place du terre, the crepes du sucre or the lousy painters this place will always offer something to be amused. It s always a place to visit and imagine that you are a character of La Boheme Famous Opera.

A Must for 1st trip to Paris. This is my favorite area of Paris.once a separate village where Picasso and the lad's went to retreat from craziness of the big city.Although very touristy it still maintains its charm I believe.Its just got that charm that you imagine and hope to see and feel when you come to Paris for the 1st time

Montmartre? Ah, Oui! Oui! Oui!. Although this area is not so easily accessed from the rest of Paris, especially the Left Bank, just being there is well worth the trip. From the beauty of Sacre Coeur to the wonderful vistas overlooking the city, to the experience of working artists in the Place du Tertre, to the quaint winding streets, to the cafes and other restaurants, this is a part of Paris not to be missed. So, don't miss it!
Love the Neighborhood!. We stood in a nice apartment in Montmartre earlier this month. There are several sites to visit and plenty of great places to have lunch and/or dinner.
must see. One of the my personal top must see in Paris! Amazing and very artistic place! a bit different than other parts of Paris.

Artists of Montmatre. Absolutely loved exploring the streets around Montmartre. We went a couple of times, once we walked up all the steps and next time we took the furnicular - cheap and much easier than the walk! Although it was crowded when we went we were still able to see everything, and watching the artists work was fascinating. We sat outside one of the bars and watched the world go by. Lots of buskers here too, the whole place was very colourful and an essential part of a visit to Paris.

Bohemian Paris. This area is just few steps from Sacre Coeur. Dinner over there is a must. Very romantic. If you ever have the time go to one of the painters and have them draw a picture for you. This is the bedt souvenir you can get from paris. The area is full if souvenirs shop and restaurants and can be easily reached from the church.

Nice but very touristy . Still have the charms of old Paris with artists all over. Restaurants in the main square are not good and very expensive and all artists do the same things. But still I wouldn't miss walking around.
To see Place du Tertre and Sacre Cour. You can see Sacre Cour and Place du Tertre here. Both of them lovely. But be careful about swindlers button of Sacre Cour. You can loose your money :)

Great views, fun place, lots going on!. Visited on a beautiful sunny day, climbed the steps of Sacre Coeur for some spectacular views, bought some souvenirs, had lunch and ice cream. Metro stop is right at the street that goes directly up to Sacre Coeur; a fun few hours.

Great Place for a Picnic. We had a blast in Montmarte my wife and I enjoyed a fabulous picnic from Paris Picnic on the lawn adjacent to the Steps to Sacre Cour. Fabulous. The artists in the square are terrific.

Lovely vibe and some great food options!. It's a different side of Paris and you can almost immediately feel it as you walk around. Be prepared to climb a lot of stairs / walk up steep slopes but it's quite enjoyable. And the food options around are great too!

This is Paris !!. This beautiful part of the city must be the epitome of what is Paris. A beautiful charming area with all of the atmosphere associated with the city of Paris. Beautiful cobbled streets, lots of steps to climb, a gracious but bustling area. One can only imagine the streets as they would have been a century ago. This was an afternoon well spent, the whole Montmartre area is a place to soak up the memories of artists and poets gathering to share a glass of wine and talk of the days events. A very popular area but not noisy or strident. A place to thoroughly enjoy !!!

Very "Arty". I love this area of Paris, lots of artists and crafty things, and the views from here are just wonderful. Plenty of restaurants to sit and have a meal or just a coffee and sit and take it all in.
Very charming. A beautiful historic neighberhood with very authentic buildings, artists and all that makes the city of Paris so charming.

great view and nice on a sunny day. We visited this area on a nice sunny day and so we were able to walk around and enjoy the views and the church and shops plus we sat on the grass and relaxed. There are lots of places to eat or grab a ice cream. Beware of the scams as the africans try to put the stringon your wrist as you walm up the hill but tell then no or I say dont touch me when they approach and they back off quickly plus they all run away when they see the police. There were also quite a few people running the ball under three cones scam and lots of people were falling for it. Dont give away your money with this scam as they were asking people for 50 euro a time plus you always see people winning to start with but these are their helpers.
Old artists' haunt. Very picturesque place where itinerant French impressionists hung out. Today very touristy with lots of quick sketch artists. Galleries and cafes abound.

Can't be missed!. To come to Paris and not see Montmartre would be like not visiting Paris at all! Authentic and rustic Paris ambience. Great place to stroll the narrow hilly streets, admire the artists and buy souvenirs to take home. Most times you can enjoy free concerts from the musicians performing French classics right on the streets. Enjoy dinner or a coffee in one of the countless establishments.

Worth a visit but don't expect too much. You have to go and see it but don't expect to be overly impressed. However, there are a few very good artists selling original works at sensible prices although most seem to be selling tourist junk. And go down some of the streets away from the main square. There is some interesting stuff to see and some quiet gardens for sitting and getting your breath back.

Must see when in Paris. Half the fun of visiting Paris is hopping on the Metro and plan your own day.
Montemarte is a quaint little town north of the city and wear your walking shoes.
Small shops and restaurants adore every street. The local shop owners were all quiet nice to me as well.

Got robbed of my wallet in a zipped purse while sitting on the steps of the church. Beware!. Very crowded and while sitting on the steps had an African main stand in front of me to sell a buy. Within second my zipped up purse sitting right next to me was emptied of. My wallet and then reIpped without my hearing or feeling a thing! Awful experience! And I am a seasoned traveler. Ruined my whole trip to this area today not to mention losing all my credit cards and ID cards. Beware of this area. Very dangerous! The funicular was very crowded with thieves as well!!

Comme ci-comme sa. I took a cab up and the driver said to stay for about 2 hours to avoid traffic getting back to the 6th. I lasted about 20 minutes. The views and the church are gorgeous but it is very crowded and touristy. I would recommend the Marais over this area-unless you like to look at art created on the street by about 40 artists all trying to get you to buy something from them.
Ambiance and Art. After taking pics of the church, head around back to the artist displays and have frites at La Sabot Rouge.

worth the walk. well worth the walk up the stairs, to the La Basilique du Sacré Cœur de Montmartre, but even the walk around the district is great, cafes and restaurants, and an interesting selection of sex shops and strip joints as you exit the metro, to keep things entertaining.Watch out for aggressive hawkers at the bottom of the stairs

My favourite area in Paris. I've been here countless times and each time I enjoy it more and more. It's an area that is interesting both in the day and at night, with lots to see and great narrow lanes to explore so don't forget to walk further afield than just Place de Tetre.My tips is to arrive at Anvers metro station and walk up the hill. Do beware of gypsies though.

amazing but beware of theif. one of my favorite places in paris- you can see the whole city and have a nice stroll in the alleys upstairs. have a drink in the artist square, and I really liked the Dali museum which is located near by. be very careful at the stairs because their are some aggressive hawkers and thief - thats a shame the ruin the place like that

Great art abounds but don't come if you can't handle crowds. We loved seeing the various creations by local artists. There is everything from street artists drawing your face in charcoal to wonderful acrylics and oils of local sights or more abstract things.

The Hilly area of Paris with White Marble Cathedral. Excluding Eiffel Tower, Montmartre is the highest place in Paris (North west). Its one of the oldest settlement and narrow streets and old buildings are now the beauty of place. In the Centre of Montmartre is "sacré-coeur", a white marble Cathedral, one of the city's great landmarks, towering above Paris from high on the butte Montmartre. There are several other monuments in Montmartre and here you also find the Artists displaying their work and also making instant Portraits and caricature. I have travelled to Paris couple of time for vacation as well official trips duri g last 20 years.

A most lovely part of Paris.. A dry, sunny, not too warm day would be ideal. Go here to chill out and soak up the atmosphere but beware of your wallet at all times. Landmarks are all so close together with atmospheric cafes and interesting people everywhere, creating a relaxed bustle. You will need to sit in the cafes as the hills pull on the back, shoulders, knees, calves and feet. You have been warned but do it, anyway.

A Gem at the top of Paris. Montmartre was one of our favorite places to go to! The shopping is wonderful and this artsy district is so unique. It is quite a hike, but absolutely worth it. You can get your portrait done, but don't be afraid to negotiate with the people there. The art is wonderful and this place has the cheapest souvenirs so wait until you get up there to buy them. You can take a tram to the top, but walking really gets you the best pictures and views of the city!

Don t miss Montmartre., take a free walking tour. The authentic french taste, old buildings in historic place, many artists lived and lives there, inspiration in the air, small streets, climb the hill discovering history in each step walk, many ateliers, restaurants, and the majestic Sacre Cour. There is a free wallking tour Sandelsman every day in the afternoon
See the artists in action. Here you find artist displaying their work and at the same time you see them working. A must for all visitors to Paris.

The essence of bohemian Paris is reflected and enjoyed here. It is gorgeous!. Fantastic arty, bohemian side of Paris. Go here and spend the day marvelling at the affordable artists work. Friendly, happy people everywhere. Many great little restaurants serving piping hot fresh French food. Sit and watch the passing parade or wander at your leisure. You must visit the Monmarte Museum taking the Petit train there. It is very cheap and a fun way to zip around Monmarte. Renoir and Van Gogh lived here in Monmatre as poor struggling artists, exchanging paintings for food and drink. Amazing wonderful history of art right here.

Not what it was. We saw no indication whatsoever of any relationship to the area's reputation for being the Bohemian art centre of the last century. All that can be found now, are overpriced eateries and shops selling the usual tourist trap guff.

A stroll in Historic Neighborhood . One of many must do's in Paris. Although over run with tourist, artists and gypsies. It's like a walk back in time. Plenty of good art & a lot of tourist art. The people watching is worth the visit. Be careful of pickpockets.

very commercial but hasn't lost it's charm. Last visit was 30 years ago & still a very special part of Paris --great atmosphere with many bars ,restaurants & cafes .Lots of tourists but worth spending time there regardless .Unfortunately the areas closeby down the hill have become quite seedy , so watch out for your valuables .
Very cool place. This was a very cool place, at every corner you would have different shops and nice people around doing several things, impossible not to like

First visit to Paris. Monmartre was very interesting, walked from the Champs Elysee which was quite a walk but saw different parts of Paris. Lots of little shops and artists in Monmartre and the Renoir Museum was very interesting and Sacre Coeur. It is quite Hilly.

A sadly changed placed. The day we visited. Monmarte was overrun with people aggressively attempting to scam, steal and pickpocket by any means necessary. Though we'd been warned about the pickpocketing we weren't prepared for the aggression. A sad place today. Maybe it can be saved.

Home away from Home. If you only have a few days or hours in Paris make sure to stop by Montmartre before leaving. This charming town a few minutes away from Paris central is a lovely view of what Paris has to offer other than the typical touristic icons; Montmartre itself is an icon with the French film, Amelie making it popular.Vintage French steps, delightful cafes and an the local charm is what makes this part of town a must see. Strolling through the narrow, cobble stoned streets are as French as you can get.
Always worth a visit in any schedule. Busy, interesting, has character, and some great people watching to be done over a coffee at one of the many restaurants.

A stroll around the area. After a trip to Sacre Coeur, take a stroll around Montmarte. There are many street artists showcasing their works on the street which are available to purchase. There are street artists doing portrait painting of you on the spot as well. An interesting sight to see and experience.

Spend a few hours out of the city!. This is a really neat small neighborhood in Paris. Artist galore! I loved walking around the little square. The Basilica sits right the top of the hill. You can get a great shot of all of Paris. Best part is they don't allow large tour buses up there anymore. Parking and driving is still crazy. You can purchase lots of different types of artwork from local artist in the square.

A Different Side of Paris. This is a unique neighborhood that has an interesting vibe. I was expecting something along the line of Bourbon Street in New Orleans, but it was a bit more seedy than that and not as fun(no audible music coming from bars or on the street). We did not meander through all the streets, just walked the main road.

Beautiful views of Paris. Montmartre contains a lot of history (Vincent van Gogh among many other artists lived and worked here.) The cobble stone neighborhood is charming to wander through and easy to get lost in. The streets are full of shops, cafes and talented locals painting portraits for travelers. The Basilica of Sacre-Coeur (Roman Catholic church) sits on the crest of the hill along with a beautiful view of Paris. 3 things - steep, stairs and hills - bare in mind when visiting and wear comfortable shoes. You can take the cable car up to the Sacre-Coeur, near the Abbesses metro station, but i suggest taking a map with you and walking the streets to the top once you get off the station, it's a lot more interesting :)
Must experience. Great place to get a portrait done, or just walk around, have coffee, lunch, an ice cream and then a stroll back down the hill to Moulin Rouge.

An absolute must! . Let's just say it's one of the quietest places in Paris. Walking from near the river to Montmartre, it's hustle and bustle, dodging in and out of Parisiennes. It's enough to get one aggravated. But as the roads begin to climb, fewer and fewer people impede your ascent. Soon you will be ducking down side streets and up stairways to be greeted by street artists, cafes, and pure Paris charm. Have some wine and cheese in the square or a romantic lunch/dinner in one of the any excellent restaurants in the area.
