See Sacre Couer and Vistas of Paris from one of its highest points short of the Eiffel Tower itself.
Beautiful!. Beautiful! Very lovely neighborhood behind Sacre Coeur, very "French", a must see when in Paris. Careful of the "artists" however!

View worth the climb!. We visited for an afternoon and took the long walk up to the basilica, beautiful views of Paris. As with most touristic attractions it was overrun with selfie-stick & key ring sellers, but did not diminish our experience at all :)

Sidewalk cafes and hilly streets. Montmartre is a fun and bohemian neighborhood. Its twisting narrow streets are filled with souvenir shops and kitsch, but off the usual paths leading to Sacre Coeur, there are very good restaurants and some lovely architecture.
Must visit. Charming. It's different from any other area in Paris. So it's so unique. U can enjoy the painters here. The atmosphere is nice. Just remember u can reach up bu the metro cable car.
Arty. Lovely place , in the area of the Sacre Coeur Basilica. Very arty place , extremely talented locals doing portraits of travellers !

Enjoyed the village. We really enjoyed the day we spent in Monmartre. We did a food tour there which was delightful--great specialty food shops. We really loved the village feel of the area and appreciated the free, clean toilets!

Must See. Beware steps and hills! Take the funicular! But it is beautiful up here and there are lots of artists still painting. Renoir, Matisse, Picasso, Van Gogh, Toulouse Lautrec, Mondrian, Pisarro and Degas had homes here. And Sacre Coeur crowns it. I've read it is noisy with nightlife, so you might not want a hotel here. But I'd recommend staying on the Left Bank near Blvd. St. Germain, along a side street for quiet but close to the boulevard for strolling!
nice setting. lovely setting. so glad we visited here. so relaxed and fantastic pictures. would go back if i go to paris again

Not what I remembered. I saw is area 45 years ago and I was disappointed in my visit this time. The area has become very commercialized and there is this big restaurant in the middle of the area where artists used to paint. Ther are artists around the edges. There are so many buildings all around it is hard to imagine famous artists painting up there.

A must visit area of Paris. Great area to walk through towards the Basilica du Sacre Coeur. A good place to start is the Pigalle area, after seeing Moulin Rouge. You can leave the Metro at Pigalle and walk West for a few minutes, or to come out closest to the Moulin Rouge get off at Blanche metro station. Walk up Rue Lepic which is the first road heading North from the right hand side of Moulin Rouge to head into the Montmartre area. Rue Lepic is full of souvenir shops, food shops, cafes and bars and it remains a very popular cafe and tourist filled area all the way up to the Sacre Coeur.
Feel Paris!. Charming area of Paris that makes you feel like you are in the real Paris. Street artists, Cafe's, and music .. all the sights and sounds of Paris at your feet.

Worth the visit. Montmarte is a quick metro ride out of Paris and a charming and special part of the city. It is an adventure climbing the stairs up the steep hill and wandering around the charming streets full of shops, cafes and creperies. The artists in the Place de Tetre are often finishing their work right in front of you and it is a great place to pick up a beautiful and original piece for a good price.
Paris 2015. What a great area to walk around and to eat. I think this community embodies what people envision Paris to be. Don't miss it.

Beautiful part of Paris . Yes it has its seedy district of which the Moulin Rouge forms part, but it also contains a lot of history (Vincent van Gough lived in area) and bustling cafes, restaurants and markets. There is a small train which you can take from the sacred heart on a 30min circuit of the area with on board commentary. A definite must do when in Paris.

Cute area to explore. Really neat neighbourhood to explore. Surprisingly charming, given its history. Rick Steves has a really fun scavenger hunt kind of walking tour that points out artists' houses and studios that I'd recommend.

Romantic area - great views over Paris. This a really charming area for walking around, look at the view, eat and drink and just spend some hours people-watching. I guess going here on a saturday/sunday is too crowded - so if you have the chance to go on another day - that's maybe better.
wonderful. Montmartre is the place where you feel the arts and the life of the artists, where you can go back in the past and feel the life then, where you can feel the arts in any kinds

One rotten apple dosnt ruin the whole bowl!!!!. What i mean by my title is I am just back from paris and this was one of my last places to visit the church is amazing we even went to mass in the church even though i didnt understand what was been said the atmostphre was beautiful.It was on my approach to the chapel i got grabbed very aggressively by this black man who proceeded to tell me i needed to have this piece of string attached to my finger for luck to go up to the church. I have bruising on my wrist as he was holiding me so tightly and i was very afraid he proceeded to walk me towards two other men and my husband was grabbed another man but being a man he just brushed them off i had to scream into his face before he released my arm and i felt very upset and taken back by the whole experience i was hoping to see a police man about but unfortunately there was none. These men were there in force about twenty of them and i think it should be stopped its very aggressive and annoying and my wrist is still sore today. I continued on up the steps to the church and i was not dissappointed the view from the top was class and the chapel i just loved it. Dont be put off by these men just be aware that they are there and be ready to refuse them your time i just didnt know what was going on ego the title one rotten apple dosent ruin the whole bowl. Loved Paris just make sure you take appropriate walking shoes

Get lost and wander the street. After visiting the Sacre-Couer we wandered around this delightful area. We really enjoyed just following random streets to look for a nice lunch (see a previous review). I had to chuckle regarding a previous reviewer mentioning some street scammer trying to tie something on to two of my fingers - he was 5 seconds away from eating a knuckle sandwich. I laughed about that experience at the time, and am still smiling about it. Overall, yes, a touristy spot but if you just walk you might find a little bit of Paris off the beaten track.

Climbing the stairs at Montmartre. We courageously climbed the stairs, daunting but worth it. The view of Paris laid out before you is truly worth it and with Sacre Coeur in the background, it is amazing. I can see how something so breathtakingly beautiful can make you feel closer to God.

Montmartre and the Bohemians.. Up beside the Sacre Coeur cathedral Montparnasse is famed for its artists now all around the Place du Tertre where Toulouse-Lautrec and the original bohemians lived. Lively atmosphere and many places to sit and have a glass of wine and some lunch. Note most places open for lunch 12-3 and dinner 7:30 to 10 only, a few all day but not the 'good' ones.

loved it!. we stopped at Lamarck – Caulaincourt metro and walked gently uphill Montmartre. the spires of the basilica can be seen from anywhere so we followed those to the top. lovely little town, lots of artist ready to draw you!! very charming :) and the view is amazing!

Over rated tourist trap. My husband warned me that we should not go to this area but I was insistent that we do having seen great Instagram photos (filtered!). We went on a rainy day and had to transfer once or twice on the train. The church itself was beautiful but crowded, Notre Dame is more worthwhile. The town itself was extremely crowded with tourists/buses and shops/vendors selling trinkets. There were many guys on the streets trying to sell items and one even grabbed my husband's hand trying to braid something on it. On a clear day the views may be lovely but if this is your first time to Paris I would put it toward the bottom of your list.
Great area for shops and restaurants!. Fantastic area of Paris with a multitude of little shops and restaurants all up and down the side streets. A must see area of Paris.

Too much hype. Very touristy!. A tall hill, lots of stairs, a church (again) and for the most part cheap art along the sidewalks for sale. At one time this was probably all new and real. It is not today. I consider it a waste of time for anything other than the view. I've visited this sight since I was 15, 30 and 40. There are so many more sights to see that are more meaningful from a historic perspective. The " Musee "D'Orsay, Vaux-le-Vicomte, Malmaision" are of true cultural value.
Incredible views of Paris. Great exercise if you walk up. View is wonderful. Very touristy but you could say that about almost all of Paris and so what. If you come to Paris a must visit

Funky and Great!. We spent a great half-day with Alex, our tour guide, walking through Montmartre. It's a funky, interesting, really fun area that we recommend to anyone who is visiting Paris. There is an artists market in one of the squares where very talented artists work and sell their art. Many famous people (i.e. Van Gogh, Picasso, Dali, etc.) lived here and you can see their houses. The winding streets and charming buildings are really great. Bring your camera!

A walk through the cemetery. If you are looking for some peace, this is a great place for relief. Your pace slows down and the noise of the street disappears and the crowds dwindle. The mature trees and cobbled stone are pleasing. This is beautiful and serene on a sunny day. The centuries old sepulchres are interesting . Each one has a point of interest. There is sculpture here that is breathtaking. There are maps available at the entrance . Good information maps throughout the cemetery and street names which help if you are searching for particular sites.

One of Paris' must see areas. It's a fantastic area just to walk around. There is an eclectic mix of shops, artists, eateries, galleries and something for all tastes. Start off at the Sacre Coeur and walk down through the area, as it's a great way to spend a few hours .

For me very touristic but nice place (not in my "most do" list). Montmarte is an area in Paris with some cool things. The church of Sacre-Coeure is on top of the hill with a great view of Paris. You can climb to the top through the stairs beside the garden or by using the funicular beside the stairs. In the left exterior side of the church you access to the cozy area: just turn left at the first street and then left again and you will arrive to the artists plaza that is surrounded by coffee terraces. Nice place but my advice is visit this area just if you have seen already the other major attractions as it is far away from everything and for me is not the best part of Paris.

Not what it used to be. We stayed in this area for 5 nights after spending our honeymoon here 20 years ago. Unfortunately, the area has gone way down hill. It's very touristy now, kind of cheesy. There are people trying to sell crap everywhere, and most of the restaurants are overpriced tourist traps with less than average food. I would definitely not stay in this area again, many, many better spots in the city.

Montmartre a faded elegance. Definitely worth a visit not just for the Basilical but also for the view. It is quite a climb but you will be rewarded. Try and pick a sunny day. Then descend one of the off the beaten track steps which can take you to secret bistros. There are always lots of people.

Book a Room Here!. We booked a small apartment via airbnb and had the most marvelous time. It was our first time actually staying in Montmartre, versus simply visiting the area. Loaded with excellent restaurants, wine shops and boutiques, it is a delightful place to live and work and move around. Less crowded than the center of Paris, too. MOST HIGHLY RECOMMENDED!
Quaint town. I love Montmarte. Seems like there are less artists there than there were 5 years ago. Just a peaceful little town to stroll through. A lot of uphill walking!!

Very touristic, but very beautiful.. It is a beautiful place to visit. Because it is a hill that overlooks the city of Paris, has beautiful and varied horizons to be contemplated. It is also a very nice neighborhood, full of life, with many artists and typical scenes of the city. It is imperative sit in one of many restaurants and eat some moulles with white wine

Plenty to see and do. We loved this district and had a delicious lunch in one of the pavement cafes. As it was a sunny day there were many tourists wandering around and there was a definite buzz. The hundreds of souvenir shops were doing a roaring trade.

Charming part of town, great views overlooking the city. My favorite neighborhood! My son got his caricature sketched (after some minor haggling for a decent price and an artist who seemed good). The other highlight was taking the funicular, which is free with a metro pass.

Gets busier by the year. There's a reason Paris is consistently in the top 5 cities to visit. A vast metropolis but manages to retain villages of individual character within it. Montmartre is one of them, best seen out of season, early or late but the streets just yards away from Sacre Coeur are quiet even in peak tourist hours and have many tales to tell.

Absorb the athmosphere Montmartre. Stayed in hotel near Montmartre only a few minutes walk away. Great atmosphere and a buss about the place Montmartre district. Some lovely cafe's and bars to sit outside and watch the world go by. Steeped in history with some lovely old buildings. Would suggest planning a guided walking tour, I hear that they are free and frequent. I was disorganized and by the time I found details I had no time to go. Even so, beautiful area capped by a splendid Basilica on the very top.

Gorgeous Artists Part of Town. One of my favorite parts of Paris, this area has art and culture galore! Check out the Basilica on the hill and the amazing little shops and restaurants along the way. Just make sure to watch your bag and don't play the three cups game, that's where picpockets like to hang out.

Most romantic part of Paris. Montmatre and the climb up to the church is perhaps the most romantic part of Paris. Tons of artists, cute shops, cafes and more. If you're not up for the walk there is a little train service that will take you from the top and back down to the Metro or Moulin Rouge.
Lovely area. Well worth a walk around this area, lots of cute little streets and squares with local patisseries and restaurants.

Beautiful cathedral; lovely neighborhood. Took a city bus to Montmarte from Rue Cler. The artists, shops and cafes were great fun. Sacre Coeur is beautiful. Climbed the 300 steps to the dome. Loved it all.
Disliked the seedy area we stumbled into when trying to find our bus stop to return.

Breathtaking!. This is an absolute must! In my opinion, it offers the most breathtaking views of Paris. There's a market, food and places to sit on the grass and just relax. The basilica is beautiful. Be prepared to walk up and down many, many steps, and hills. Huge crowd.

Local flavor and history -- loved this area. We loved this area. We used our guide books to take the historic walking tour and enjoyed each stop. Found a lovely quaint restaurant along the way for an exceptional meal. All the hills are worth the view at the top. But if you are not up for the walk taxi or tram to the top and walk down.

A Must Must See. We did the Free Walking Tour here and it was great. Being led around the back alleys and laneways of Montemarte is great and having some of the history explained was fabulous...there is so much to learn about this very interesting village. Tip....take up the offer of the Free Walking Tours...they are great and led by guides who have so much passion and knowledge about the place.
happening. Happening. Definitely visit and eat here. Easy to get there lots to see and do. Fine and casual dining

Not outstanding food, but a great experience.. Montmartre is a very old part of Paris that holds many surprises for someone interested in strolling through the narrow streets. Sacre Coeur is the most famous attraction and we also have a favorite restaurant in this area, too. Search for the Chartier Restaurant at 7 rue de Faubourg-Montemartre. The restaurant has been placed in a former Post Office and it's fun to look around for the signs of the former occupants of this cavernous space.

Great souvenir shopping place, beautiful church,. Loads of souvenir shopping. Beautiful Sacred Heart Basilica. Take Funicular up to top and walk down. Be careful with your wallets someone with us had hers taken by a little girls.
Artists hangout.. I would not buy any of the art work sold by the vendors. They are overpriced and reproductions. However, the charcoal sketch artists are excellent.
Disapointing. Interesting place, but most of the painters that made this place famous and interesting are gonereplaced by restaurants which they are plentiful in the area anyway.
bohemian ifestyle encapsulated. We love Mont Marte and spend most of our time here when in paris, le mare catherine for best authentic cuisine and music...

History Comes Alive. Excellent Place to visit.
You need to block out the whole day to enjoy Montmartre. You will particularly love this if you enjoy history; it makes history come alive.
Be sure to take the audio kit to enjoy a clear description of the whole place.

Vibrant area. Lovely but expensive for drinking. We were advised to eat lower down as people tend to get ripped off higher up and glad we did. We stopped for a drink after our meal at the top and were charged 23 E for a glass of wine and a vodka and tonic!Apart from this, I would definitely visit again but would just be more careful in future!
Love this little village.. I loved this little village, lots of cafes, eateries, shops, open parklands great just walking around feeling the place.

Fabulous place to meander around, could find somewhere different to eat every night!. Lovely area of Paris. Visited Paris many years ago and this area was full of artists and their easels. This time not so many artists, more restaurants up there, but neverthess it hasn't lost it's charm. Plenty of lovely typical french restaurants.

Interesting stroll. What a fantastic place and so rich in stories. I walked the streets of Montmartre where Van Gogh and Picasso lived. The place has really quaint restaurants and houses many cabarets.

Don't miss Montmartre. Really enjoyed visiting Montmartre. Took the Hop on/Hop off tour and was able to get off here. We had lunch which was very nice - lots of cafes. Climbing the steps takes some effort, but is is fun to say you have done it. The view of Paris is amazing.

For a different experience, visit Montmartre. If you are looking for the off-the-beaten path, visit Montmartre. It's a smallish area with several cafes, lots of souvenir shops and some specialties. Don't expect warm and friendly service - these people have seen it all!

Oh Boy!. Grande buildings with great architecture, many restaurants, shops and people everywhere. Lots of vendors, sellers and artist who follow you around trying to draw your picture and make you pay for it be firm in you no!

A nice way to spend an early morning. Great views even if you don't get up to the dome. The walk from the nearest Metro is short and gives you a view from the bottom up. Nearby I had the best mille-feuille (Napoleon) of my visit to Paris.

Relaxing despite number of tourists!. I tend not to be too keen on this area because of the number of tourists etc., however, the view from the front of Sacré Coeur down on Paris is always overwhelming. I was here on a sunny September day and it just felt good walking down the steps and seeing people relax on the benches and on the grass. The various sellers were quite low key.

An Experience!. I loved Montmartre, but my husband and kids did not. They felt very uncomfortable with all of the artists asking to draw their portraits, women asking for money, street vendors and street gamblers. I, on the other hand, found it terribly interesting and entertaining. I loved walking around the square and looking at the artists at work. Some of them are incredibly talented and you can purchase some beautiful work for a very reasonable price. If you are up for an adventure and don't get too turned off by aggressive street vendors , then you'll love Montmartre. Women should be especially careful, however, because some of the vendors can be very aggressive. A vendor trying to sell me a bracelet grabbed my arm and would not let me walk away until I got very loud with him.
Beautiful. Great place to visit. Lots of pictures and opportunity to learn more about the atrocities of the church while Proclaiming the need to "spread the word".
TIRED ICONIC AREA. Historic location but area now infiltrated with drug dealers and the area is less appealing as a result. Stick to "Midnight in Paris' where it looks best at night!
Beautiful View. Lots of tourist. Beautiful view, Churches, Artists, Eateries. A few shops in the area we were in. Steep climb, or ride the tram.
Lives up to reputation.. A nice day to walk around and see sights, watch world go by visit artists quarter, Sacre Coeur, Pigalle, Moulin Rouge,

Average hotel experience. Our stay in Montmartre started with being approached by "Gypsys" trying to scam us as we obviously looked like lost tourists. Be wary as soon as you step onto the streets in this area and watch your bags, we felt safe in built up areas but wouldn't want to walk around at night, we had 2 children with us. Our hotel Grand De Paris was very average and disappointing as no air conditioning, safe, TV and felt a bit dirty and old. Should have researched the area better. Ok for backpackers and couples on a budget but I wouldn't recommend for a family wanting good quality accommodation. Our trip to Paris excluding this experience was excellent and the hotel was in a good location to Gare De Nore Train Station.
Authentic Paris!. Very cute and nice to walk around here as a couple. I had an amazing time with my girlfriend, even if its rainy I still recommend it!

Beautiful old Paris. Walked up to Sacre Ceour on a beautiful August evening with a view to watching the sun set over Paris. The perfect place to do just that. Ignore the tacky sellers that unfortunately plague Paris. Get a seat and relax and soak up the romance. While you're up there have a walk around and enjoy the street artists and the quaint cafes restaurants and bars around Montemarte, perfect place to enjoy the old style Paris. My favourite area of Paris and can't wait to return. Make sure you visit this area
Great view and nice atmosphere. The artistic part of the city, good food and a great view if you decide to climb the 300 steps to the top of Sacre Coeur.

Experience the real Paris. We stayed for 4 nights in Paris in Montmartre, at the foot of the beautiful Sacre Coeur basilica. We did a lot of the sights in Paris, but every evening we walked up the hill of Montmartre to experience the atmosphere, surrounded by other tourists, locals and artists. This really is the hightlight of our trip to Paris! Enloy the many restaurants and souvenir shops.
Great for a walk around. Nice area of town to walk around, see the local crafts, and grab something at a cafe. Great view from the top.
Wonderful place. It's one the places I liked the most in Paris. Artists painting in the street, nice streets and of course, the Sacré-Coeur.
Keep Moving. Atmospheric section of Paris. Tourist trap, pestered by 'artist; who want you to sit for them, for a price of course. Mainly went there to take photographs.
Great place to sit and watch the world go by. Interesting little area. Great place for a drink or coffee sit back and let the world go by. Visit the church for a little piece and quite

Fall in love with the view of Paris and the village. A must for first-time and repeat travelers. Called the "old-fashion village of Paris." Funiculars will get you up the hill if you don't want to walk.

An Oldie & Still a Goodie. An oldie and still a goodie. The section has retained much of its charm over the years. The restaurants however, are close together with a crowded roadway surrounding the common outdoor eating area. Years ago the wait staff would cross a road (still do) to bring food however, it feels touristy now more than unique. Mer Catherine was my favorite restaurant on many trips. Food is good, but not what it was. Artists surround the common eating area which is sort of fun...again crowded. On the whole do not miss this section of Paris and do take the Tram. Quite a ways up.

Nice change to stay here. We spent four nights in an apartment in the Montmartre instead of our usual stay in the middle of Paris. We were pleasantly surprised at the village feel and friendliness of the area. The Metro was 200 m away and when we walked out our front door we were spoiled for choice of cute local restaurants and bars. We could walk up the stairs to Sacre Coeur. Montmartre is a fascinating area and even has a vineyard! We will definitely be staying here again.

Must visit. No visit to Paris would be complete without a visit to Montmartre and the artist quarter. A beautiful panoramic view of the city and some interesting characters channeling their bestDali or Picasso.

Beautiful views of the city. Montmartre is a section of paris on a large hill which has the basilica Sacre-Cour at its summit. My wife and i went at night, after dark, and the views of the city were spectactular. Montmartre used to be the artists section of town before it became unnafordable, but it still maintains a feel like Greenwich Village in NYC. A great place to walk around especially at night.

The perfect places for an analog selfie!. Every time I visited Paris (I'm originally from Belgium, close to the French boarder, so been here often) I alway go to Montmarte, I simple love the atmosphere here. I think by now I have about 4 self-portraits from different artists here. Simply sit back on one of the terraces.. have nice little coffee and enjoy the vibe... don't try to find good food here, the restaurant are overpriced and tourist traps, you'll find better deals and much better food further away from here in the less busy streets..
Things have changed. Rather disappointed in the commericalism of the art on display. There were more portraits being painted/sketched instead of the real artist at work.

A wonderful walk . Unforgettable.. This visit to Montmartre was the highlight of my visit to Paris. We followed the walk given in Our guide book where every point of interest was marked with a no. Wear comfortable shoes to enjoy the walk. It is mysterious at times, full of wonders and surprises. One can imagine the lives of Picasso,Renoir and Van Gogh who lived here. The Moulin Rouge is a reminder that they used real models from here. The windmill of Renoir was fascinating.The house where Van Gogh lived. It is romantic and fascinating.
Lovely neighbourhood.. If you are looking for the funkier, artful side of Paris, this is the best area for a walkabout. Do be careful about pickpockets.

Lovely old area of Montmarte. An interesting area to walk around, lots of hilly areas too, so wear good walking shoes. There is a station that stops off near the entrance to the basilica, so make sure you chose the right one.

Wear comfy shoes for the cobbles and hills!. Interesting neighbourhood when you want something a bit more daring. There are charms too: sitting in a park listening to an accordion player, wandering around the hills and discovering little shops (I found one with beautifully unique -and affordable - necklaces). I will say Moulin Rouge was anticlimactic (although I did not venture in). Sacre Coeur is just the icing on the cake.

Charming Montmarte definitely worth a visit. We spent half a day seeing this fantastic area of Paris. We started by ascending the funicular to the Sacre Coeur church. We followed the Rick Steves Monmarte walk and saw the notable sites of the neighborhood like the windmill featured in Renoir's painting, the cabaret where many famous artists and writers relaxed and ended at the Moulin Rouge. It is fascinating to walk through the square looking at the artists' painting. There are lots of shops and places to grab an ice cream or lunch. Truly charming.

Must see when in Paris. Montmartre is such a cosy lovely area in Paris with the Sacre Coeur on the hill. Lovely area with Place du Tetre where you can find local artists. The streets are typical French, small and cosy. Nice cafes, restaurants, local souvenir shops and typical French galleries can be found here as well. Really a must see when you visit Paris.
Don't miss Montmartre. Don't go to Paris without a visit to Montmartre. Very hilly so be ready to do some hiking, but very interesting to see. Go to church of Sacred Heart if nothing else

Well worth a visit. Great area to explore and learn about what it meant in the past to painters and the other people who lived and worked (and partied!) there. Many small markets where the locals shop with displays of fresh pastries, fruits & vegetables and seafood--very colorful.

Beautiful Sacre Coeur and much more. If in Paris, I would highly recommend you visit this area. Sacre coeur is an amazing and beautiful building. The street artist area is unique and fun to walk around. And of course there's the Moulon Rouge. This is a great place to spend an afternoon or evening.

A Must See Neighborhood in Paris!. Such a great area to explore. I'd recommend taking the Culturefish Free walking tour here! So much history! I appreciate the Parisian vibe and artisan culture. Go eat crepes and buy fruit!
This is old Paris. My favorite Arrondissement. It gets a little touristy in the square but on the back streets it just has that "feel". If you know what I mean.

Fun Evening with thousands of other tourists :). Fun spot to spend an evening. Start at the Basilica of Sacre-Coeur ( which in itself is gorgeous and worth a visit ) and wind your way up the hill. Of course this is a very touristy place and there are multitudes of artists peddling everything from portraits to caricatures to scenic paintings. In spite of the overpriced food and throngs of tourists, we still had a great time here and bought a few portraits just for kicks.

Walk and discover Montmartre. After visiting the church we hung around here for dinner and drinks. If you go little early, you will also come across many parisian Artists and interesting shops. This is very different form the rest of Paris. there are many stairs to climb and the streets are cobbled so be prepared for a nice walk. There are many restaurants around here where you can have a nice dinner and spend a nice evening. We followed this http://www.paris48.com/montmartre-walk.html

Fantastic. To actually stand were some of the worlds most brilliant impressionist artist has worked, lived and loved was a such a very special feeling, one that will last for a life time, planning my next trip to Montmartre.

If you have extra time you might enjoy the area.. This is very subjective. If you have extra time it is worth a visit. The Basilica of Saint Denis would be the better church to visit. Charles Martel is buried there. He stopped the Moors in 732 AD. I prefer the local street markets that appear in the various arrondissements. For casual eating and shopping the Latin quarter is the better choice.
Worth seeing. It's nice to walk through. We haven't spotted too many artists. But worth the trip with great city views
A famous place for your ckatch. There is NO way you should miss this square when visiting Paris. Just a note, if coming with metro on Pigalle, USE the elevator, otherwise, there is too many steps

It is a must if you are visiting Paris. The place is great, although too touristy. There are many restaurants selling tourist deals that are not convenient at all. I advice to eat something small around and then go somewhere else to search for proper food.The views are astonishing, and it is beautiful to see all those artists painting in the square. Also I strongly recommend visiting the Montmartre museum if you love arts, it is a bit pricy but it can keep you engaged for a few hours. Beware of some people on the stairs to the Sacre Coeur trying to rip off tourist, they start talking in a friendly way but in the end they can be also intimidating, asking you to give them tens of euros for little string bracelets and not letting you pass. So be careful of that.
A zone of art. Had a fine time over a cup of coffee looking at the young painters sketching their pictures, against the background of the Sacre-Coeur.

Historical landmark. Montmartre is a large hill in Paris's 18th arrondissement. It is 130 metres high.Just off the top of the butte, Espace Dalí showcases surrealist artist Salvador Dalí's work. Nearby, day and night, tourists visit such sights as Place du Tertre and the cabaret du Lapin Agile, where the artists had worked and gathered. Many renowned artists are buried in the Cimetière de Montmartre and the Cimetière Saint-Vincent.
Charming Area. Lovely neighborhood; very unique. Felt like I was stepping back in time. Great views of Paris from the steps of Sacre Coeur.
Sacre Coeur and Place Du Tertre not to be Missed!. We loved Place du Tertre and had lovely lunch on the pavement cafe around the square while we soaked up the atmosphere

Great place to visit. Got the hop on hop off bus to Anvers Metro then walked up to Montmatre. Caught the funicular up to Montmatre but beware of gypsies/pick pockets who enter the funicular. Lovely atmosphere up there with all the artists, cafes etc. had delicious French onion soup. Had a ride in the tourist train around Montmatre, good to see area but very bumpy on cobblestones. Nice view looking down into Paris, so many chimneys. Lots of security presence up there which is good.

Be cautious of the portrait artist. Be cautious of the portrait artists.They pester you and will ask you only to help them out by being a model to draws others in. Even while you protest they endure. I stood for three minutes and then he wanted an exorberant fee for a half finished picture I didn't want to begin with. When I refused he became verbally abusive.

Artsy Paris.. Take the furnicular up to Sacre Couer and walk downhill throughout Monmarte ending up near Moulin Rouge. An organised walking tour really helps to understand the history and point out the highlights.

A Must See Place in Paris!. This is probably the most Parisian place that you see in Paris. You will see cute narrow streets, buildings, shops, restaurants, walking painters, and of course, with the Place Du Tertre where the street painters are sitting and showing off their paintings. Some of the paintings are really nice, but rather expensive. You can also have a beautiful top view of Paris from Montmartre. A must see over there is the Sacred Heart Basilica Church that is another magnificent and monumental structures in Paris. If you are in Paris, go and see the place. Don't miss it.

A Different Experience. We were lucky enough to arrive in Montmartre on a day when they had a neighborhood "garage" sale. Lots of interesting things for sale. Everything's negotiable.The streets are narrow and windy and steep. It has a different feel than the flat streets bordering the Seine. It was nice to hang out here for a while. There are plenty of restaurants to choose from.The Church at the top of the stairs offers a spectacular view of the city. Worth the climb! We happened to arrive during a Sunday evening mass. We were allowed to walk around inside, even as mass was being held. Spectacular!
Beware of artists wanting to draw your picture. We got snagged by some artists wanting to draw our charcoal likeness. Beware that they want 50 - 80 euros for their drawings.

Tourist trap but such a lovely one.. The painters square must be one of the most romantic spots in the whole Paris. I would not dare to eat there but simply loves sitting there with a coffee or a drink.
Would Do It Again In A Heartbeat. Just go experience the culture. Walk around, observe, sit, people watch, soak up your surroundings. It's amazing!

disappointing. Perhaps my view was skewed by having watched "Amelie" but the neighborhood was much grittier than I expected. I felt the Sacre Coeur and park were the only thing worth while, just watch out for the aggressive people trying to put swindle you (if you see someone with bracelets, turn around).

Unexpected Delight. We had a reservation at Tort Croger placed through Trip Adviser and spent 14.30 Euros. When we arrived, we found they were out of business. A real bummer. We had walked all around Montmatre looking for a restaurant that appealed to us, we finally came upon Rouge Bis. We had a Mojito and Prawns over pasta. We found the food and service to be wonderful.

Interesting building, Interesting neighborhood. You can see Montmartre and the Sacre Coeur church from much of Paris, even from the Eiffel Tower. Very interesting architecture and somewhat interesting history. Yet the surrounding area, the artist's quarter, and the surrounding neighborhood add another dimension to your Parisian visit. Download a walking tour from a well-known tour book author and really enjoy your surroundings. So much to do in Paris -- you will be planning your next trip before you finish the first one.
Haggle for a good price. One of the most exciting parts of the trip in Paris. Seeing the different artists and their work and the talent is amazing. Remember you can haggle.
Walking and shopping. A good place where to walk around and where to buy some souvenirs at a cheaper price! You can also find some cheap place where to eat here.

Lovely part of paris. we were fortunate enough to be staying in Montmartre and found the area was every bit as good as we had hoped, with the bars, shops and restaurants all providing a great variety of attractions as well as the atmosphere and spectacle of Montmartre itself. Go-you will not regret it.

Charming Neighborhood. Charming Neighborhood, very busy & packed with tourists strolling through the steep town built on a hill. Lots of local stores , food , Chocolates , bakeries. Just be prepared for a lot of walking as you make your way up to the top. Browse through the shops in the area, some you will not see anywhere else in Paris.

Ah so charming !. This place is perfect - the cute cafes, cobblestone street and live music in some restaurants! This place will give you such a Parisian feel !Go to sacre coeur to get great views of the city and then stop by montemarte for drinks / dinner.Do not miss this place !
Beatifull. Nice and cosy.Its so full of art music and foodBut expensiveFor a redwine glass one beer one mojito and a coca cola we paid 60€.

Best Area in Paris. Stay here, take your meals here and socialise here. We loved this area. Many good restaurants, many good cafés, get walking and site seeing, good selection of hotels, easy access to all main areas in Paris and just plain good fun. Loved this area!!
Sister trip. This was the cutest most delightful town with amazing shopping that didn't break our bank. Beautiful sights with artists painting right there on the street.

Great area to stay. Absolutely loved Montmartre. Really lovely area to stay with lots of interesting shops and bars. Great area to chill
Stop and have a drink at one of the many bars and go up the funicular to Sacre Coeur. There are some great clothes shops as well.

There is only one Montmartes. By going to see the Sacre Coeur, you get to see Montmartes.
It is well worth the effort to climb the184 steps, or thereabouts, if you don't want to take the Funicular railway. Tip - do it in the morning, before your legs get tired of other sightseeing and then have lunch before descending.

One of the best areas in Paris to walk around. Walk slowly around enjoy yourself and experience this charming part of the city with is nice houses, butiques, cafees, resturants etc, the only drawback is that you are not alone, other tourists have discovered this area as well.

Must visit. Very cute neighborhood. Has a lot of history and charm. Easy access from Subway.Even though it's famous in part by its Basilica, this is one place that can be easily observed from outside as part of the area. It's not that special. Other places, i.e. houses with a lot of history, famous bakeries and local stores should not be missed.I highly recommend getting a walking tour to get your experience more enjoyable.

Feel like a local. This is an amazing part of Paris, the architecture around here is amazing and pretty stunning. You get a good feel of how it would be to be a local as this is a great authentic neighborhood.

A place to chill. What a wonderful place to just spend a few hours watching the world go by. Sit at one of the many cafes watch the artists painting....just lovely. Walk around Montmartre fabulous buildings with lots of history...perfect.

A must see part of Paris.. Montmartre is a unique little village rich in history, art, artists, musicians, singers, famous Basilica on the highest hill in Paris, infamous Red Light District and home to the best cabaret show on earth: Moulin Rouge.
Wander around. Wander around and take a look at what the local artists are painting or drawing, if you have the time have one of them sketch you, I did , and now I have a unique memento of my visit.
Charming. Walk around, take the train, visit little exhibits, stop by a cafe. The whole place is enchanting. Bohemian and lovely.
A beautiful place. A beautiful hill with a splendid view of Paris. Lovely restaurants and Sacre clear Bsalicca at the top , which is the highest point in Paris. A must visit

Classic Parisian Streets and Lots to do. Upon exiting the metro station I knew we needed to walk up the hill, however much my wife did not want to, but when you get to the top it is certainly worth it. This is the first place recommend to us by friends and family that had visited Paris. The shops are filled with art and very reasonably (cheap) priced copies of artwork, 4 for €6 or at other places 5 for €8, we are looking forward to getting them framed and putting in our hallway. Be prepared to be harassed to have your portrait drawn and they will ask top dollar for it. We actually wanted our portrait drawn but only for a good price, we were offered a drawing of us both for €50 if you are poor or €80 if you are rich, I explained I was very poor so would pay no more than €30, still probably too much but I appreciate people have to make a living, it took around 20 minutes and after we were no longer harassed by all the other artists as we just showed them our rolled up portrait and we could wander around freely.We were warned about pickpockets but I did not see any and did not lose any belongings, however keep your eyes everywhere and your money in your front pockets as we know people who have been pick pocketed here.There are many places to eat crepes here and with the incredible views of the city outside the Basilica of the Sacré-Cœur they are best enjoyed whilst sitting in the steps just in front of the building.
Really nice neighbourhood. Went here 3 times out of the 4 visits in Paris. 2 times at night. I love the people sitting outside for dinner and the artists on the street.
Great. One of the most romantic and artistic areas in Paris. We had a portrai made for us with my girlfriend which was fairly priced.

"World of artists". "Basilica of Sacre-Coeur" the big white church is the main attraction on this hill.... Montmatre is known for some of famous artists who had worked in or around it ....you can find portrait sketchers and caricaturists in the adjacent street... beware of pickpocketing, thanks to our guide who had pre informed this.
Sacre Coeur. A littlebit "side" area and not the best restaurangs.If you have time to find you will do that (behandling Molinrouge area.

My favorite arrondissement in Paris.... One of my favorite arrondissement in Paris. The streets are so narrow and go uphill, the cafes, the bakeries, the street waterfountains, Sacre Cour, Moulin Rouge...just fabulous!!! You will love it. Checkout the free walking tours by locals. They are fabulous. Please tip them, many are students trying to make a few Euros and are truly appreciative of your kindness.

A fun Parisian place to see. I love the entire vibe of this area, just around the corner from the Sacre Coeur. It's lovely to sit and watch the painters and street vendors about their business. They can hassle a little but it's light-hearted and easy to brush off. This trip my daughter sat for a portrait but we stopped the artist mid-way as we just didn't think it was a good enough likeness of her - there is no obligation to buy if you're not happy with the portrait. As we walked around we saw some lovely portraits being done but also a few howlers - all part of the fun of the place!

Loved this area and visited twice!. Take the challenge and walk the hundreds of steps to the top. Lots to see on the way and of course the summit is worth the view. There's so much to see and do I went twice to the area. It's a wonderful part of Paris and stands apart from the rest. Likely because of the ambience, artsy characters you'll meet, fantastic views, quaint shops and restaurants. It just feels sooo French! Just a heads up, that some of the artists do not like to be photographed.
Vibrant area. Going to the Montmarte district is a must filled with great shopping and wonderful cafés and street artists

A unique place. Full of cobbled streets and lovely wine bars and restaurant. There are so many lovely places to eat and drin. Along with lots of lovely individual shops including so many ribbon and fabric shops!!

A really artisan place to visit. Artisan and very interesting. You could have spent a great morning browsing around the cobbled streets looking a the interesting shops. Then finish off by having a light lunch and drink at the various cafes located around Montmartre
Nice hood!. Love this area although it is crowded...lots of nice cafes, bakery shops ...the closer you get to Sacre Couer the more people...
Cozy!. Super cozy, nice bars (but a bit more expensive). Tons of artists. Also a good workout, always up or down a "hill", or stairs. Though there is a little "train" to take you up as well.

Too touristy. Its really very touristy but having said that,I enjoyed going there but wouldnt return in a hurry.
Has to seen but only once

Lovely Place to visit but Beware of the people in the stairs. We visited Montmarte in august 2015, The church is a very nice attraction,But please be careful while you walk up the stairs from the main entrance. we got mugged with a group of people who try to block your way and demanded money with tieing a thread in the name of the church and demanded money with knife.We tried to complain to the cops in the front of the church, but it does not help.We never felt safe in this area.I would like to make you cautious about this menace and enjoy the place peacefully.

Delightful artistic area of town. This is such a fun area of town. There are many artists selling their wares in the street. Get your money ready to have your portraits drawn by local street artists! It is a souvenir you can enjoy years later! Taste some of the vendor's foods too. The Croque Monsieur is a baked ham and cheese sandwich that is somehow grilled like a grilled cheese. It is delicious and is sold in many of the restaurants in the area. The chocolate crepes are also good! Be ready to climb a lot of stairs to this area, unless you take a taxi!

All the way Alive. My wife and I moved to Paris for three months, took French Language Classes and also took free walking tours about Paris including Montmartre. This area has something for everyone. There are many Shops offering, Fresh Fish, Just baked bread which is still hot, rotisserie chickens, fresh made sausages and take out food if you wish. The history of the area is so interesting. It was outside the old city of Paris which grew to incorporate it. The Moulin Rouge is here, Cathedrial Sacre-Coeur and other famous sights. I recommend "Discover Walks Paris" for a free walking tour of this and other areas of Paris.

Beautiful and scenic. Bring water!. We had a lovely time in Montmartre. Definitely recommend climbing the staircase - but bring water with you, or be prepared to pay through the nose for it from a vendor or local cafe. I'm pretty sure we paid about $4 US for a soft drink... :-/The scenery was lovely, though, and the view could not be beat. Worth every bit!
Wonderful experience. It rained the whole time we visited but it buzzing atmosphere made my visit just as dazzling had it been in the hot summer. I love love love Montmartre

A true gem of a place.. We wandered up here not too sure what to expect as we only came to see Sacre Coeur. After going inside Sacre Coeur (which is stunning) we wandered round the busy cobbled winding streets with cafes, bistros, cake shops, ice cream parlours, artists & musicians, there is even a motor train to take you a 30 min tour of the area. Even though it was very busy we never once felt intimidated by beggars or dodgy characters - which is nice! Montmarte gives you a true taste of Paris and the views of the city are stunning. In my opinion this area is a must see when in Paris and possibly my favourite thing during my week long visit. :)
Great for art lovers. A must see in Paris. One of the most inspiring places a tourist should see in France..especially art lovers

Nice place for a walk. Nice place for a stroll up on the hill with the Sacré Cœur great views of the city. Not a difficult climb if you don't mind a few steps. There is a funicular but the queue was very long quite quickly. Lots of little 'arty' shops and cafes.

Charming Montmartre. An enchanting area of Paris, we're so glad we stayed there. Lots of lovely little cobbled streets, plenty of history to stimulate the imagination and lots of quirky little cafes and bars.

My favourite part of Paris. Montmartre should be on everyone's to do list. Not only is the area packed with places to eat and drink, the little cobbled streets might lead you to still relatively undiscovered places, little boutiques or cafes. It used to be a place for artists to meet, it still has that atmosphere of nonchalance. It is possible to spend the whole day just strolling there, enjoying a freshly baked baguette, the views from the Cathedral and a bowl of coffee. There are street artists too. A fantastic place to be. Touristy - but where in Paris is it not.

Last visit. Nostalgic visit here but it's popular now. Sadly now just a tourist trap and not easy to find somewhere to eat if you're alone in the middle of the tourist season. Go for the experience and the view if you've not been before, otherwise, Paris has better attractions.

Tourist trap land !. What else to say about that place, it's just a huge tourist trap, the land of the fake and the cliché.if you want to have a real parisian experience, then just stay away from this poor man version of Paris ... full of chinese paints and street scamers.

Great Parisian area. We visited Montmartre area by climbing the stairs and skipping the cable car. Not easy but great fun. When we arrived to the top we went to the Church area to see the view and all the people that came with us. It is lovely area and tranquil place to walk around . We went down by the stairs from the other side so we could see all the area from all directions.

Explore this great part of Paris. Walk - and try to walk off the much treaded part, where tourists squeeze through the masses tab the much hyped Place du Tertre. And I'm sure you will find small cozy shops, great little restaurants and meet the locals. Just as we happily did.And remember to walk! And do avoid Place du Tertre - a marketplace filled with not only tourists but also souvenirs (made in China), plastic Eiffel Towers and amateur "artists".

Lovely little tresures hidden around every corner.. A lovely little district, with stunning little streets with a mix between worn out and shabby chic feel mixed in. As for the street artists, this is a real mixture between excellent and some who left me wondering why they were truly there.

Beautiful location just be wary . We visited this beautiful spot on a steamy August afternoon. Outstanding views over the southern part of the city. Had a wonderful time browsing different little shops selling various wares. there was quite a lot of tourist traffic and with it comes the scammers, pickpockets and seedy types. Personally I have never had any real problems with them as I try to always be very aware and conscious of my surroundings. It does detract from the place that you have to be like this to feel safe, but alas that is the Paris of 2015. I have read several reviews complaining about these vega bonds destroying the very things that tourists go to enjoy and ask why the Police aren't doing more. Well it's really quite simple, they outnumber the police ten fold. Until the Parisian government address the issues of these criminals ruining these precious tourist attractions the onus is placed upon the tourist themselves to not become a target. Sad, very sad but true.

Favorite quarter. My favorite Parisian neighborhood with its village feel and hilly winding streets. Best in early morning or late evening. Walked rue Saint Vincent, & rue L'Abreuvoir, rue Norvins down to Place Abbesses. Postcard perfect!
My favourite place in Paris. Despite is so touristic, I love that area. The square with the artists, the street musicians playing typical Paris songs, the bistros, everything. Nice to go up and down.

Stroll, Explore and Enjoy. We had a day dedicated to exploring Montmartre and it was a day well spent. There were plenty of shops to see, restaurants to try and shoping for souvenirs was great. In the past, many artist had made their home in this area and till today you would be able to find plenty of artist having their galleries here. We found Dali's home while randomly walking around and one of the top 5 artisanal ice cream maker. This is also where you would be able to find Christoph Russel, a chocolatier who makes such perfect chocolates. They only have one store. There were also plenty of biscuits, chocolates and pastry makers which you can find as you walk around which makes it so interesting as each has different things to offer. We also found Plyones which is a French nicknac maker, and its worth to explore if you are looking at functional gifts for friends or family. We really had a good time checking out the sights and walking about in the sun and will definately recommend if you have a day to spare while in Paris.

YOU DON'T FEEL AS IF YOU ARE IN THE MIDDLE OF A CAPITAL CITY. I love Montmartre and have been here off and on for almost 40 years. It is famous for its artists in the Place du Tertre but you really can imagine when it was a village of its own, not just part of a major capital city. Yes, it's very touristy but it does have a certain atmosphere all of its own. The nearest Metro stop is Abbesses and then you can either walk to the top or use the funicular railway (you need to use another Metro ticket/use your travel pass etc for this part of the journey). There are endless cafes, restaurants and gift shops of varying quality and you might get pestered to have your silhouette cut or your portrait done but it's not desperately intrusive and is all part of the Montmartre experience. There are some great views over the city from the steps of the Sacre Coeur - if you can fight your way through the hundreds of students who all congregate there and slightly further down, there are a couple of viewing platforms too.

Well worth a visit. I really like Montmartre. Originally an artists' haven, it's very touristy now. It's full of cafes, buskers, caricaturists, cobblestoned alleys and the best views in Paris. The Basilica de Sacre Coeur is worth the trip alone. Take the metro to Anvers and walk up - unless you're disabled in some way the walk is not remotely challenging. Take your time enjoying Montmartre, and wander your way down to Abesses, and on to Pigalle - both charming areas in their own right.
My favourtie. Fantastic fun wandering around looking at art. All slightly overpriced but honestly worth the fun of exploring!

Favourite part of Paris. Love Montmartre day or night...............amazing view across the city...........the artists quarter (had my portrait done but was totally unimpressed) walked up here at night and watched the lights of city come up and the sun go down-just lovely with impromptu street entertainers and a laid back atmosphere. Ate at one of the outdoor restaurants in the evening and you know you are going to pay more but it is a lovely experience. They even provide blankets on chilly nights but being british ;-) tee hee lots ov steps to climb but they make lovely pics to take also day or night and lots of little bars and cafes to sit at...............love this ecclectic area !
Montmartre - not to be missed. Pretty area. Great for strolling, eating, drinking and shopping. If you have the energy, an uphill walk (or taxo) to Sacre Coeur is worthwhile.

Great Area. Fantastic area to walk around for awhile. Very artsy area. Great shopping. You will definitely find some unique pieces here.
Take the time out to come and check the area out not just the basilica.

back in time. apart from the crowds, this place is really lovely.walking around looking at the artists indulged in their work. many little places to take a snack also and have a drink. I believe head in early morning to get a better feel of the place.

Neighborhood okay but gets not-so-great fast.. We went up there to see the Basilica and decided to walk the neighborhood. We found some very trendy, very hip shops and ended up buying a few things. Then we ended up walking down a street that reminded me of Chinatown in NYC, not because there were Chinese restaurants because there weren't. But it was packed and there was one souvenir shop after the next all selling the same cheap gifts for too high a price. It was just tacky stuff. When we got to the bottom of that street, we passed a few clothes stores that had a ton of clothes thrown into bins outside and people were going through them and throwing them all over the place. Not my kind of shopping. Maybe it's better up more toward the Basilica and we didn't get a chance to do that.

Steps, steps and more steps.. Steps, steps and more steps. We caught the Hop On Hop Off bus to the end of the road and walked up to Monmartre which was very busy. It was a beautiful hot day and it had definitely brought the tourists out. We were short on time so didn't get a chance to go into the Basilica but it didn't look like the queue to get in was too bad. Maybe next time.

Popular Spoy. A bit hard for those with mobility problems but there is a tour train running from the main road, prices can be a bit high as it is a popular tourist destination. Avoid the trinket sellers on the steps as they only sell cheap rubbish but it is entertaining watching the police chase them, surprising how fast they can move, cafes are a bit more expensive but there is a Starbucks

Montmartre, a great stop while in Paris. Well worth your time to visit. Loads of shops and restaurants to visit as well as seeing the Montmartre Museum. Be prepared for big crowds, especially if visiting on Sunday. Be sure to check out the local artists - very nice artwork can be found at reasonable prices.

Montmarte. Was excited to go to Montmartre and it is pretty. We enjoyed the walk and the marketplace buzz at first but the street vendors were rude and aggressive and it was very crowded. We walk a few blocks and found the area deteriorated and became dirty. We had planned to stay and eat dinner there but left for somewhere a little cleaner.
A wonderful area in Paris which far fewer tourists. We walked around the Montmarte and gathered a picnic that was outstanding. It was so nice to go to an area that had far more locals than tourists.

Love This Neighborhood. Has always been our favorite neighborhood to walk through and admire the art and local shops...a bit more touristy this trip...but you can't miss...walk the streets away from the square to get away from the throngs..lovely.
Must see!. What an interesting place! I had my granddaughter's portrait done. We also had a great lunch with escargot! We also bought some beautiful art work!
try the french onion soup. interesting place to see, a church and a few restaurants around must try the french onion soup, each restaurant's makes it differently but it was nice to see new place

Up the Mountain.... Not even the rain could stop me from my mount! Arriving all soaked was fun in itself - and made it even more romantic! At dinner, the choice of wines was another plus. Drying out as we sat eating was a breeze - no problem. Our group was well taken care of and we were able to complete this visit (despite the rain) in our time schedule. Thanks to those who were responsible for looking after our group and who ensured we were well looked after - making it another wonderful romantic experience in this Romantic City.
So-So. My least favorite part of the city, although the views from Sacre Couer are beautiful and we enjoyed Moulin Rouge.

my all-time favorite place. Romantic, arty, cute and alive, Montmartre is Paris as you saw it in the movies! I live for 7 years near Paris and this place has always been my favourite district in Paris. Even if located far from the main monuments, it's a must-see in the city of lights!

Get lost in Montmarte, so much to see and do. This was probably my favorite part of my first trip to Paris last September. First of all, we stayed down near the Eiffel Tower and found the metro to get to Montmarte was quite easy to navigate. I believe we got off at the Abbesses stop.This area of Paris is very hilly, so if you have trouble walking, it might be better to take a guided tour where they can drive you places.We went on foot and it was amazing. The city has an indescribable feel to it... It feels, well, Parisian. There are several shops and restaurants on the way to the top, but it was in the main square where all the action was. You'll find dozens of local painters selling their handcrafted artwork, artists will offer to do a charcoal drawing of you (they'll come up to you a lot, but they are nice if you politely decline -- for the most part), and you can really embrace the artistic culture.Further, we found some of the best food in this area. I can't recall the name of the restaurant we went to, but we had the best french onion soup and sandwich of the whole trip (best FO soup I've ever had). There is also a winery tucked into Montmarte that is worth a visit. We didn't get to do a tour or tasting, but it is quite a sight to behold. We bought a painting from a woman who did not speak English and that is perhaps our favorite purchase of the trip. Take cash when you go as many of the street vendors do not take credit cards (some do -- for us it was hit or miss).Plus, you'll experience some of the best views of the city from Sacre Coeur on the hillside.This, in my opinion, is a must visit area of Paris. The next time we go back, we will probably try to book a hotel in Montmarte and spend much more time there.
A great place to visit!. It is such a great place to visit with all the different artists and their wonderful art work. I enjoyed it very much!

Neighbourhood you must not miss. We spent almost one full day in this neighbourhood. It was all planned on the Bastile Day and we started with Red Light area. We walked to Lovel Wall and then to Sacré-Cœur Basilica. Lot of shops to eat, shopping, and best place to enjoy your day. Dont forget to visit the Love Wall

Our favorite area in Paris. I am not in to art that much but this was one of my favorite areas in Paris. It was great to walk around, beautiful views of the city, and the artists were great. My 8 year old daughter just loved the art and artists. Well worth the visit.

Spend at least a day. Do yourself a favour and spend the day wandering around this beautiful area of cobbled stone streets, shops and streetside artists with their goods on display. It is right next to the Moulin Rouge, so there is plenty to see and do in this area.
Paris Sightseeing. The street side markets are vibrant, with lots of fresh fruits and food stuff. There are many restaurants.

Montmatre. Love this place it is so bohemian style. You can walk and see all the artists and their paintings or other crafts that they create. there are many restaurants around as well and don't miss the church right across the street Sacre Cure.. The view of the Eiffel Tower is also stunning. definetly can spend the entire day exploring the are

Food and Arts District!. This little area was wonderful! All kinds of great little shops, galleries, and restaurants. Wonderful area to find more unique gifts in Paris and grab an excellent meal! Many great artists studied in this little town and you can visit the former area they lived which was very interesting! I would highly recommend checking Montmarte out if you have a nice afternoon to stroll around. The Subway goes right to the heart of town, just beware of the thousand stairs coming out of the subway!

My favourite place in Paris. The quaint streets, pavement artists and the hustle and bustle of Montmartre make this a place to definitely visit. There are loads of lovely, reasonably priced restaurants and gift shops to visit and the views from the Sacre Coeur are amazing. Take the Funicular up from Abbesses or walk up the 222 steps. I suggest you wear flat shoes because of the cobbled pavements at the top..

Quintessential Paris !. Ahhhh, the place that truly describes the Paris of movies! Quaint, old.....with sidewalk cafes. Also crowded, and definitely go with someone [for a couple of reasons] One, it is more safe for a female, second, this just calls for a shared experience. I recommend going in the early, early evening and having a fondue at one of the sidewalk cafes. Don't expect courtesy, as you are lucky when you get this in Paris [sigh...unless you speak French, which can change things for you dramatically] but do expect some charm from French men in the cafes. Lovely stroll thru old charming streets.
Arty district. Bustling and interesting art district surrounding Sacre Coeur. Not to be missed if you enjoy browsing both modern and traditional art.

Grandson bought his first painting!. This area has many busy cafes, and lots of artists selling their work. Our 14-year old grandson was so pleased with himself--he bought a painting for 20 euro directly from the artist. The paint must have still been wet and it stuck to the envelope provided, but he was able to peel the paper off when he got home. I'm sure he will always treasure his first original piece of artwork.
Fun. This is one of our favorite places to visit when we are in Paris. It's a steep walk from the "town" up to Montmartre so you can take the furnicular you want.

Bistro heaven. The best place to stay in Paris. You are close to 3 metro lines and it is easy to get around. Montmartre is lively at night, full of little bistro and very safe to walk around, much safer than near the Eiffel Tower. If I go back to Paris, I would definitely stay in Montmartre again.

Love the Montmatre (and the surrounding neighborhood). Wonderful to visit, as well as the small shopping area surrounding it! The view from the front of the Montmartre is awesome! Please see it if you ever visit Paris!
Lovely place to stroll. Cafes, street stalls, restaurants. Be prepared to climb. Lovely place to stroll. Worth the trip. Must stop in Paris.

Artists at work. Montmartre was a wonderful surprise. Watching artists on this hilltop village was so fun and had surprisingly great paintings. We watched sketching being done alongside artists who had paintings to sell. We were able to pick up pictures very reasonably to take home and frame. This area was surrounded by brasseries so you could rest and have wine or beer as you people watched. Be prepared to climb steps up to the area where the artists are.

Best neighborhood in the beautiful city!. We went to Paris for a vacation and chose to stay in a hotel in this place itself as it is such a vibrant area with a European feel. Walking down its streets in itself a romantic thing. The most popular Sacre-Couer and Moulin Rouge are located in this beautiful neighborhood only.The walk up through the hilly paths to the Sacred Heart Basilica is just lovely. You can get the top view of the city from Basilica which looks mesmerizing at night. Packed with cafes and beautifully lit streets , it has its own charm. This place appears to be slightly different from the rest of the city in the sense that it gives altogether a different feel with cobbled streets and cafes. Moreover, it is very well connected by public transport and has a Metro station centrally.There is also a toy train that takes you around Montmartre with an audio guided tour at economic price.

GREAT ATMOSPHERE. We did a short walking tour of the area and it was Great , the atmosphere was Buzzing !!very steep streets , but lots of interesting buildings to look at ,a lot of them relating to famous artists we stopped off for a coffee and sat people watching , which was fun Had a Great Atmosphere and i wish we had more time to spend there , if we ever go to Paris again we will defo go again Did get midered off an artist who wanted to draw hubby , but im a loud mouth scouser , who had to shout at him to move on !! Dont be pressured into doing anything you don't want just shout at them !!

I love Montmartre. This is one of my favorite places in Paris. I feel as if I was in another time. This place equals Paris for me. There are good places to eat and just walking in these streets is fabulous.

Walk through its streets.. Very nice area to have a walk and to get lost through its streets. Do not be lazy, you have to climb some stairs, despite you can also take an old train or the cable car.Enjoy its soul and try to spend a nice evening, best time to visit.Having food or drinks in this neighbourhood is quite expensive, but I recommend it to try at least once.

Bit Expensive. It is hometown of the art, and you can walk around with beautiful scene. But Be sure to think twice before you spend money. This place is bit expensive. But I recommend Nutella in Montmartre.

So vibrant . You can easily find yourself walking and exploring the area for hours. It is packed with cafés, small art shops, street artists. I recommend first to climb up to Sacred Court and than work your way down.
Top of the hill in Paris. Marble Church on the top of Paris is valued to take a visit.Its more safe once we visited as no migrant disturbed us.
Art market. Nice 'arty' atmosphere. Lovely little streets and a busy market. Nice to buy a painting directly from the artist.

Overrated. Very touristy, lots of trash being sold and too many people trying to swindle tourists using the 3 cups and a ball game. Saw 1 couple lose 400 euros in 2 minutes and it left a bad taste. The city should clean this area up.

Nice area to stroll around. After a visit to Sacre Couer this is a very nice area to spend time. Lots of artists offering to do your portrait and there are galleries and restaurants aplenty. It's a very busy area and be careful to keep an eye on your belongings. Be sure to wander down Rue Lepic and visit Cafe des Deux Moulins (as featured in the film Amelie) and look for the plaque at number 54 which shows where Vincent van Gogh lived from 1886-88.

Fantastic views with a touch of art. We visited late in the afternoon. Montmartre is somewhere that you have to visit when in Paris, but you need to accept that every other tourist will be doing the same thing. We have visited at quieter times of the year, whilst less busy, the hustle and bustle does add to the atmosphere. The easiest way to get there is either via the Metro (the stop is Anvers) or on a hop on hop off bus. There is a small walk from the Metro through a street full of souvenir shops and street gamblers (don't get suckered in to the find the ball game as many tourists seemed to be). To get to the top of Montmartre you can either climb the steps or take the funicular railway. We opted for the railway! It uses the same tickets as you would use on the Metro. It was very busy at the top but we still had fantastic views over Paris. We stopped for a drink and an ice cream (not the cheapest but the restaurant owners have a captive audience!). Our main reason for visiting was that we wanted a street side portrait of our daughter. There were plenty of options, the artists were all very nice and not pushy. My tip here is haggle! We paid 20 euros having originally been quoted 60 euros. We finished our visit with a walk inside Sacre-Coeur. This was a major let down. Not because of the church itself but the tourists. Despite the numerous signs requesting people refrain from taking pictures, the building was awash with selfie sticks and camera flashes. Frankly, if you intend to visit but you can't respect the sanctity of a religious site, you should stay away.

Full of life, see something different every day. We stayed near to the Anvers metro line, surrounded by quirky shops and good restaurants, Montmartre is full of art around every corner, whilst the more touristy areas such as The Sacra-Coeur are populated by beggars and people trying to sell souvenirs and selfie sticks, furthermore the nightlife is lacking in this area during the week. Apart from that it is a great place to stay and would happily return to Montmartre.

Am I missing something?. I remembered this place as being really buzzing and having loads of cafés, pavement artists etc so was disappointed to find none of that on this visit. Maybe we'd chosen the wrong day of the week? There are nice cafés and shops around, but it was certainly a bit flat when we visited this time.

Don't bother. We went there because it was once the place for artists to go. There is not much remaining except the church on the hill. We stopped for lunch at a small creperie and were totally ignored by the proprietor. We eventually just walked out and found a delightful restaurant a bit down the hill. Despite what the guidebooks say, there just is not much here any more.

Busy, busy, busy. We normally visit Montmatre at the end of January so on a visit in August we found it much busier. Also we were surprised to find the Place du Tertre covered with tables from the nearby restaurants as in January only the artists occupy the square.However we stilled enjoyed strolling around the area and stopped for a coffee on Rue Abbessess
Wonderful Artist Haven. Great place for portrait drawing! Nice to stroll and observe artists creating caricatures of the tourists!

Several shops and restaurants with a bohemian ambiance. My family and I went in July. This is a nice neighborhood with several bars and restaurants, shops, painters with different styles. Public washrooms are not common, keep away from people who give you an accomplishment because it is the way painter catch your attention.I have read is not a nice neighborhood when it is dark, but I do not know. Times I have gone, I always have stayed until 5 or 6 pm.

Lively, if crowded place with a wonderful view over Paris.. Paris has changed in the past 10 years, much of it seems drab and often shops and restaurants are closed. Not Montmartre though, it has always been somewhere to visit when in Paris and still is. The wonderful view over the city from the steps of the Sacré-Coeur is marvellous. This does get crowded though at peak times, but the funicular rail and tourist road-train do make it a fun place to visit. The artists are plentiful and there are fair ground rides for the kids. Gardeners are catered for too! The restaurants are plentiful and not too expensive. Of course for the Can-Can hungry there is the Moulin Rouge - book though, as tickets sell out quickly despite the high price.
Local market place. This place is a local market place to buy souvenirs, enjoy local food and enjoy the walk in the market area. There is a ancient Roman catholic church within close proximity.
Lots of people....... A district to see where Moulin Rouge is located. Walk up the hill to see Sacre Coeur Basilica. This quaint part is a haven for artists, plenty of eateries here.

MY FAVORITE!!. My favorite part of Paris. From the time we got off the Metro and took the tram-train up the hills of Montmartewe were simply enthralled by this special place. To just imagine what this place was like during the time of al lthe famous artists who called it home and studied there was just fantastic for me - one of the highlights of my visit to Paris!

A must in Paris. Ideal place to visit at the end of the day, early evening, to stroll around the narrow streets on the hilltop, enjoying the view of the street vendors and maybe having our own portrait painted.The magnificent Sacre Coeur basilica remains open till late in the evening, so it can be visited after strolling and sipping a glass of wine. Some bars have live music.

Boheme location!. Narrow streets, nice coffee shops, lovely detailes, arts, paintings and painters, it is a magic corner of big Paris! It's right next to the Sacre Coeur, very easy to climb, nice view of the city from this place!

Stunning. If you've ever seen Amelie and loved the scene where she gives him clues all the way up to the man pointing at the sky, then you should come see this. It's truly stunning, especially on nice days, and gives a great view of the city. It can get crowded in the summer.

A terrible area to get to a beautiful cathedral.. The actual building is beautiful but the area is so sketchy with beggers, pickpockets and junk stores and very dirty!!!! The city does not take care of this area at all. So sad.

Charming village in the city!. Small streets, charming details, possible hill climbing, arts, paintings, painters, charming little cafes... this is all Montmartre. Loved it! I am a film lover and more than one of my favourite films were filmed here (eg.: French Kiss, 1995 Sabrina...), so it was a must see for me.Didn't disappoint, also a must see in Paris!

great place to be. Mont Mantre is a place, there people enjoy there hollyday and for have same nice food. A lot of Groups going tru that area for see highlits of Paris.. A lot of fine Buildings are in that area.
My fave city of Europe. This is my most favorite place in Europe. I can climb the hill, sit there all day long to see the whole of Paris while listening to the street artists' singing

A must do when in Paris. We didn't have a lot of time while in Paris ,so had planned our sightseeing very carefully. Montmartre was everything we had expected. Yes ,it was crowded and bustling with tourists,but that didn't detract from it at all. It was amazing watching all the talented artists painting and selling their art. We were able to walk from Sacre Coeur church from there (whether or not you are religious, this is absolutely stunning inside ) and we also were able to walk down the road to see the Moulin Rouge.
