There are many cafes and bars in Montmartre to indulge in a drink and French fare as you take in the surroundings. We used the hop on hop off bus to get there.Don't leave Paris without a visit here.

Great but too touristy. I wanted to give it a 4 for architecture and the feel of the place, but because it is so touristy it is expensive and not as good as I am sure it is/was/could be. The streets are fabulously cobbled in older parts, with great views of the city and pockets of fabulous art deco and nouveaux architecture.

Amazing walks. The most beautiful quarter in Paris. We enjoyed walks, small shops and restaurants, beautiful residential buildings etc. There are moreover few sights, which are on the "must see" list in Paris.

Not to miss. It's such a beautiful neighborhood as I remembered it from the movie Amelie. We enjoyed walking by the streets, visited Sacre Coure, admired the view. It is a lively neighborhood with many shops, sidewalk cafes and restaurants. On our anniversary we dined in one of those sidewalk restaurants and had a lovely evening.

Packed with tourists. We went on a rainy Friday and the streets were packed and slippery. It still had its quaint charm with tree-filled squares and drlicious patisseries. A visit to Musee de Monmatre helped to understand the history of this new district.

Nice area to walk around . There are overlooks of the city. This is a nice area just to walk around a bit
Street artist will draw your sketch for a fair price

Strongly recommended!. One of the nice and beautiful place in the World.
Full of a wonderful smell.
Walk around the cafeterias and streets. It is recommended to have a coffee or dinner there too!
Furthiremore, there are many nice place to visit as I love you wall.
But what is important is ambiance of Montmartre that you never forget it.

Not to be missed. This is my most favorite part of Paris..after a panoramic view of Paris and a visit inside the Sacre-Coeur Basilica, a stop in the picturesque Place du Tertre for lunch or an afternoon café is a must. This painter's quarter bursts with color and is surrounded with typical French cafés and restaurants. Don't miss the Parisian stairs beside the funiculaire ;-)
Beautiful area. As a lover of the film Amélie, I loved wandering in Montmartre. You can really get a glimpse of French culture and there are some beautiful views of the city.

Best place in paris!. Even this place was so crowded with people, the view from here was fantastic! you can see all around Paris from here. A cup of coffee, many artists will make you smile! Best place in paris!

Beautiful Area of Paris. We spent the day in Montmarte. We traveled by subway from the Champs-Élysées with no difficulty at all...right to Montmarte. The area is historic and beautiful...the cathedral sits on top of a hill which affords excellent views of Paris down below. There are many quaint shops and restaurants. And areas where local artists paint and exhibit their works. A great way to spend a day in Paris!
My favorite part of Paris. This is by far, our favorite part of Paris. Quaint shops, sidewalk cafes, sidewalk artists. This is eye candy for photographers and artists.

Unforgettable !. Soul of Paris, Montmartre and the impressionism, and the wonderful Place Dutertre. Between artists, accordeon and painters, u ll face Sacre Coeur one side and the other, the all paris !!!!! UNFORGETTABLE !

A must see!. The Montmartre district is a must see attraction in Paris. Indeed it is the city's artistic district, mostly know for being the birthplace of the Bohemian revolution! It houses some of Paris's major landmarks, including the Sacré-Coeur and the Moulin de la Galette. Beware though, it's a tourist trap and packed with pickpockets!!!

Interesting Area. The heart of the Bohemian movement. Lots to see in this area. As you get close to the Moulin Rouge, it is a lot more adult oriented with streets of strip bars and porno shops. I am not sure why they need so many but there it is.

Nice stroll during the day. From my point of view, this neighbourhood is very nice during the day: artistic shops, vintage products, nice caffees, just perfect for a pleasant afternoon. And it all culminates with the Sacre Coeur Basilica on top of the hill and a romantic view over Paris.The prices are cheaper than in other parts of the city, I bought a lot of souvenirs here at reasonable prices. At night, I found it a bit dangerous, so I would just go for a short walk to see Moulin Rouge at night.

THE place for art and crepes!. The top of the hill gives you a great view of Paris. There are many cafes to get a drink and a crepe and have your portrait drawn by a local artist. It is also a nice break from the heat if you go in the summer.
A top see I believe. This is a very cool site to visit. I would also recommend a tour to anyone never having been here. There is much to see, and a guide will tell and show you the highlights.
Montmartre in Paris. It's beautiful ! Everything there has a particularity that makes of it wonderful! The atmosphere is so artistic and open for creativity! Go and visit that place! It's worthy!

Different expectations.... As for many thing in Paris my expectations were disappointed. I tought that Montmartre was very different from what I saw: souvenirs in every corner, too many portaitists stopping you and nothing really worth seeing around.I suggest to spend there not more than 20 mins and then visit the Dalí museum. There you can easily spend two hours and be amazed.
Great area to get lost in Paris. Tons of little shops with locals shopping around. You get a great feel to the area and how things have been here for hundreds of years.

Beautiful area of Paris. Of all the places in Paris, I wish we had spent more time in Montmartre. It's a charming area of Paris, and to me, perfectly embodies the look and feel of the "real" Paris. It doesn't seem as touristy as other areas (e.g. Champs Elysees), although there are definitely lots of tourists walking around. There are plenty of little shops and cafes that really highlight the unique culture and vibe of Paris. Overall, really beautiful and picturesque.

A Must in Paris!. This is one of my favourite areas in Paris, it's views over the city are amazing and it's culture and streets are filled with so many beautiful buildings and places to stop and have a coffee or wine! Not to mention my favourite Artists workshop is on 16, Rue Chappe - a short walk down from the Sacre Coeur, Robert Ricart's work is just amazing!!

Live neighborhood of Paris for late nights . It was a long walk up the hills and all those stairs were killing me but it worths the pain. Once you are in a main square,it is full of life, small souvenir shops, restaurants, cafes and every step somebody wants to draw your picture or make something for you.And at the end the Sacré coeur basilica with the stairs full of young people drinking. Smoking having fun was a blast.Definitely recommend it
I love the place. The view to the city is stunning, Sacre Coeur nice to visit. but I'm really enjoy staing on Place du Teartre.
Unique and cultural. Breathtaking view of Paris, an uncanny sighting of the local unique culture, the street is lined with talented artiste from around the world.
holiday. amazing palce, full of arts, trendsteers, incredible food. you can really feel the heart of paris, with beautiful facades and streets.

You HAVE to have a tour...... We did a tour of Montmarte - we had a beautiful tour into the "bones" of Montemarte and the artists that lived here - so much history -so much art - you HAVE to take a tour!!
Montmartre. Wonderful place to visit. Provides great views of Paris. Happened to have regional farm tents showcasing their foods and products during our visit, which was an unexpected gift.

The Romantic Side of Life. Montmartre is stunning... The french/parisian lifestyle you see in movies you see here... and it's so romantic. I recommend watching the movie Amelie (2001) and then visiting Montmartre. You'll understand why after you see the movie.

Lifely France.. I was with my father and my daughter during evening hours at the Montmartre. From the entrance of Sacre Coeur there is a great view over the nightly Paris. It is also a great quarter to buy in little stores or just to sit down and enjoy the street life.

Definitely TOP 3 things to do in Paris!. If you travel to Paris for the first time then make sure you include 3-4 hrs for Montmatre in your itinerary. Walking around this entire historical, Artistic, Old-Paris styled hilly area is so much fun in itself.

On must see list. Must see place
It's charming ,has this bohemian touch and of cours a lot of history and.....stairs .
If some one can't take stairs ,there is little monmart trains that will bring you up to Monmart and than bring you back down .

Village charm of Old Paris. Wear sensible shoes. Lots of cobbled stones who and down hill streets. No good if you have a walking disability. Very touristy at Place de Tetre but so what. This IS Paris. THE place to have a portrait done. Do not have lunch here or you will be ripped off. Best to walk around the back Rue Mont Cenis/Marcadet/Lamark. Lots of steps. Beware. Hilly. Rue Lepic and surrounds is charming. Look at a street map first. Abbesses surrounds is charming too and plenty of eating places. A village atmosphere that is unique in a Paris. 18th district. Metro Abesse and take the funicular. Do not climb the steps in the metro that go on for ever! Unless you are young that is! Take your camera. Even a vineyard. Go to the charming Musee de Montmatre.

Must see. Artistic or not its a must see stop on your tour of Paris.... Naturally full to brim with artists and teeming with artistic history... Lots of portrait painters offering their services... Worth a vist

Climbing the Everest of Tourism Sites in Paris. We started out at Ile Saint Louis, where we were staying, and walked from there to Montmarte through neighbourhoods less touristy than colourful in character, to say the least. But it was interesting - I enjoy seeing the other side. Close by appears to be wedding gown land, and very close is fabric land - then comes the steps to Montmarte itself, where the tourists (and locals perhaps?) flock. We did not feel threatened, probably the three machine-gun laden army people might have had something to do with that. The view from the Cathedral is truly awesome and we loved every minute of it. The site is bustling and it almost feels like Times Square in its craziness, even with a character like "Paris guy" (ok, picture the Elmos in Times Square, but a character dressed up with a beret and a baguette...). It was all fun. I loved the cathedral and the entire area, with its little shops and restaurants. This was my third trip to Paris, and the first time I had gone. It is worth the effort if you enjoy a bit of hustle and bustle.

Lovely older area of Paris. Worth the visit just to get to the Sacre Coeur. Our hotel was placed just outside Montmartre and it is a lovely old part of Paris, a bit of a hike to get there, and most of it uphill. Fantastic range of restaurants, pubs, cafes etc all around. Has been turned into a little bit of a tourist trap (as most of Paris is) but some lovely views, park areas and architecture to be appreciated.

The Arty District of France. We have traveled to Paris before so this was not a sight seeing trip, but rather a 2 night get a way. We loved the hotel we stayed at. It is a FIND, called Les Plumes on Rue Lamartine. Also on that street was a restaurant we ate at for lunch on day and dinner the next. Great Italian restaurant called Moriarty, reasonable and delicious. The area around church was very crowded and had lots of souvenir shops lining the street up to the church. The café we stopped in was just average with below average waiters. The shopping was disappointing since I was looking for a more upscale painting. Most were cheap souvenir pictures. But that said, we did enjoy just wandering around and did manage to go to the Champs Elysees for my favorite restaurant and bakery on the Champs called Luduree. Opt for the French toast then go to the bakery and try French Macroons.

Dangerous area. On arriving, our tour guide informed us she had been robbed at an ATM that morning. On the walk to Sacre Coeur, I was grabbed and forcibly held while a man tied coloured strings to my arm. Only through using force to remove the mans hand, did he go away. In the background I heard a women scream to another man, "Get your hands off me."There was no sign of police or any security and other tourists or locals didn't offer to assist.Later, sitting down to have coffee, I had to pay to use the toilet where I was the customer.There's lot's of safe welcoming places to go on Paris, and its a shame that this area has been allowed to be spoiled by thieves and unwelcoming proprietors, while local police show apathy in addressing these issues.

beautiful day climbing all those steps. Took the hop on/off bus to visit and most enjoyable views over Paris. Plenty of steps to climb and plenty of touristy shops to stop and browse for souvieniers. the actuall town behind the church is full of eateries and sweet shops to get your Macarons.. I'm glad I was able to visit

SO much fun. Be sure to spend some time here.. In this concentrated epicenter of Paris's historical art scene, it is easy to see why artists were drawn here by the thousands. Inspiration is in the air, and the shopping isn't too bad either.

Walk around Montmartre. Just walking around and soaking in the charm, shopping for paintings. Take time and do a round before you buy. Wear sturdy walking shoes, water and a light bag. Walk into Sacre Coeour and spend an hour inside as well.

Fun, fair like atmosphere. There is a fair like atmosphere around the cathedral that is fun to experience. The prices in the restaurants are a little high but it's worth it for the experience. We had our granddaughters portraits done for the kick of it but stay aware of pickpockets.

Nice but touristy. Once you reach the top of the hill, it is wonderful. The views are great and the basilica is beautiful. Make sure you walk around the back and explore the streets and square behind where there are many artists and little cafes. A bit touristy...but feels wonderfully French. The downside is the street on the way up the hill from the metro station - lots of tricksters and pickpockets....so watch out.

Very Enjoyable. Very enjoyable part of Paris with lots of atmosphere and charm. While it was very busy when we visited (Easter weekend), you still can find some quieter spots to enjoy. Lots of places to eat and drink and if you look around enough, you can find some very good value places. Be prepared for lots of step hills.

Gorgeous town. Must visit while in Paris.. Beautiful place - gorgeous cafes and boutiques, and a lovely atmosphere. The markets were also amazing, and Montmartre in general is just a fantastic little town. I was a little weary of pickpocketers but it was fine while I was there. :) Please try the food while you're there - either at the markets or the shops along the streets, they're all pretty delicious!
Love it !. Probably the best płace in Paris where art and the atmosphere of old Paris are everywhere. Commercialized, that's true, but still very Real.

Not just for artists. This area of Paris, ever popular with artists, writers, musicians and the like, offers a range of attractions like the Sacre Coeur church, museums, the Moulin Rouge, hundreds of bars and cafes, and interesting shops as well as the usual touristy tat. It is a great place to wander around, especially being located on a hill, and if one is fit enough, there are thousands of steps to climb, or descend, to who knows what. Personally I prefer Le Marais, but this comes a close second.

Vibrant and yet Charming Neighborhood.... Great place to stay, close to the locals. Friendly neighborhood and very close to cafes, mini marts and restaurants. Walking distance to Metro Station too.Plenty to explore within walking distance.

Atmospheric area. Start your visit at the Abbesse metro entrance - a beautiful art-nouveau entrance. Use the funicular railway to get up to Sacre Coeur (use one of your metro tickets). Splendid views over the city from there. Take your time to slowly explore the bustling streets of this charming quarter as you gradually descend. No shortage of places to eat or snack. Allow the best part of a day and don't be afraid to just wander.

Very touristy. It is a very touristy area. If you like touristy areas selling souvenirs like tshirts, berets and all kinds of Made in China goods, then you will like this place. Otherwise, head about 5 blocks west and its less busy and still retains the chic and charm of the old. Nice cobblestone streets and the famous Montmartre stairs. The church at the top was also packed with tourists. Tourists sitting on the stairs leading up to the church, drinking cold Heinekens (some sellers were hawking those).
Beautiful sight. It's a bit of a hike to the top but totally worth it! The view over the city is amazing and the church itselt too!

Great area to stroll and sip coffee while people viewing.. Wonderful artist area. Great to stroll around look and buy the paintings. Lovely small cafes and restaurants. Also small shops in some of the back streets. Nearby Sacre Couer also a major attraction.

Amazing square with artists painting wonderful pieces to,steel.. I love this area of Paris, the amazing little square where the artists paint in from of your eyes and sell their painting. I have bought quite a few pieces from here which are hanging in my home for fond memories. It is quite a claim up to it, but well worth it and the shops and cafes are so gorgeous.

Parisian air. This is the true heart of Paris, when you walk down the stoned roads and hear piano music on the background walking thru painters on the main park you know you are in Paris and can sense that Parisian air all over the place

Wander Around. I think you'll enjoy Montmartre if your expectations are that it's an interesting, offbeat area of Paris that provides a lot of fascinating scenery while you walk through. Don't pay much attention to the touristy stuff and focus on other things.

Interesting day out. The cathedral Itself is beautiful..rich in history and a place where many obviously go to reflect and pray. I enjoyed visiting here. However the surrounding area (on the way up) is full of people trying to sell dodgy items on the street and can be a bit rowdy For families with small children for example.

Charming. It's always great fun to walk around Montmartre. Seeing the artists work and visiting some of the shops is delightful. And, of course a crepe filled with bananas/ice cream and chocolate sauce is a great way to enjoy the time there, too.

Nice private museums, but don't believe the hype. village-like atmosphere, sacre-coeur, blahblahblah... Montmartre is OK for a quick stroll and for visiting a few private museums, but don't believe the hype: most of this area is just a tourist trap.

Less than what I expected. Was looking forward to experiencing Montmartre and was only slightly amused seeing the crowd of tourists and locals as well as artists sketching for a living. The area was too busy, disorganized and dirty. The food served in one of the restaurants was average or less. The only highlight was our visit to the Sacre Coeur and riding the funicular.
Amazing shopping. Loved the area and shops. The prices for food were decent but drinks were steep... We paid the equivalent of $40 USD for four 20oz sodas.

Living history. Montmartre is like going back in time. The little streets with cafes and the many artists painting or drawing portraits of the tourists is a real joy to see. If you want to see old Paris this is the pace to go.
Loved it. The highest point in the city. Montmartre is bursting with Cafes, little shops and street artists. We loved it.

amazing place. We sent to Montmartre in the morning but it was full of tourist because it was a must see place in Paris and we really enjoyed visiting the Sacre Coeur and seeing Paris from the top of this Basilica

Must walk here. Cosy and nice. Really Paris.
We walked here twice. It is the place you may just walk and relax. A lot of cafe and bars

Sacre Coeur. What a fabulous place to see and to look out over Paris.Very busy and everyone told us to beware of pick pockets but we had a really enjoyable afternoon looking around Sacre Coeur and then sitting looking at the view. A steep climb up steps but you could take funicular if you had too. Very hot, take water with you so as not to buy from dubious sellers There are some lovely streets around that go well into Montmartre which was alive and buzzing. Great atmosphere. nice bars and restaurants and I thought really friendly people. Like most cities think about your bad and safety but also enjoy the flavour of this part of ParisWill go back and stay there again definately

Impromptu lunch on the stops of the Sacre Coeur. we took a bus to Montmartre our last day in Paris and had our "Paris moment" on the steps of the church while eating a fresh bagette, some olives and feta, and a drink of French wine. Lots of folks stopping in envy as we enjoyed our lunch. Momtmartre offered the beautiful Sacre Coeur, great views of Paris, great food and shopping. Good day trip from the City.

Dirty, not in a good way!. This area is really run-down (it might have always been). Filthy streets, sketchy area (pickpockets, drunks, and the drugged), and the most amusing thing I saw was twittering, giggling middle-aged American ladies sneaking into the Moulin Rouge for a naughty show. It was just... I don't know, disappointing? Trying too hard? No locals, except those who were there for addiction reasons. Not a nice part of town, and to be honest, not any more interesting than any other 'red light district' in any city, European or otherwise. Too bad.

Montmartre . A place so colorful, so beautiful and full of artists. I was so inspired to be there, to be able to see all those talanted artists, painting on the street, to be able to buy one of their works; to just sit on a cafe and look at them working. Once you visit Montmartre you'll always remember the warm atmosphere that also gives you one of Paris' best parts.

Nice. This place was very nice and what I think of when I think of France. The rest of Paris was not nice and mostly disappointing. It is dirty and crowded and overly touristy. This place is what they show you when they advertise Paris. Very pretty

Total view of Paris. The beautiful Sacre-Coeur is at the top of a 130 metre high hill. There are many stairs up to the top but also steep narrow roads if you dont fancy steps. It has a brilliant nightlife with bars restaurants and shops. A really must see if you are visiting Paris. The church is magnificent and the view of Paris breathtaking
Amazing Atmosphere. Amazing atmosphere, there is just something about this place that draws me in and I can't miss it every time I go to Paris

Artists and garretts?. Whilst it feels a bit touristy in places...it also has the atmosphere of the great long lost artists. There are plenty of street artists willing to sketch as well as places to eat. It has its own unique place in Paris. I wish we had explored it more

A beautiful view from the ghetto. We went to Sacre Couer after a recommendation from a tour guide and a fellow Aussie. We had only beautiful memories of Paris up until then and I wish I hadn't wasted precious hours coming here. Sacre Couer itself is ok, the architecture obviously different to the rest of the churches in Paris; however, it was overcrowded with rude tourists and pushy street vendors. The area of Montmarte itself reminded us of the Bronx and was a ghetto complete with homeless people and Gypsies everywhere. I did not feel safe and we left promptly after visiting the church. If you want to come here, only do so for the view and Sacre Couer.
Charming.... Cute old town...Walking streets are charming...I loved montmatre when i went to Sacré Coeur Church, Dalida's houseMUST SEE :))))

A strollers paradise. This area is the highest point in Paris so there are wonderful views of the city - especially from Sacre Coeur Basilica - but it is also lovely to stroll around and grab some dinner. Granted it is extremely touristy but in a good way! There will be lots of artists milling around asking you if you want your portrait or silhouette drawn. We had a wonderful meal outside and enjoyed the area. We took the metro there and back from the Arc di Triomphe and had no issues or feelings of concern re: safety, although some had warned us to be careful in the evening. I can see that it would be a haven for pickpockets but as long as you are aware you should be fine.

Such a Neat Place!. I was a little unsure about visiting this area. I might have been slightly influenced by a certain movie about a certain place in Montmatre. BUT I went and it was a great experience. This is one of those places that leaves a lasting impression on what Paris was all about. A great experience. I highly recommend visiting.
Cool. get your picture painted, a caricature done or by some outstanding original painting. you can relax in one of the cafes or just stroll around. It is one of the most relaxed places in Paris.
Lovely suburb. This was my favourite area of Paris. We did the touristy stuff and then came here. We ate dinner here every night, and just wandered around the beautiful streets.

I love this area. Artists. Quaint streets. The Sacre Caeur. It is just a lovely place to wander around... if the weather is kind to you because it is so high, if the weather is not great, it gets worse. Don't be put off when you get off the tube, it looks like a dodgy area. If you walk up you are going in the right direction. When you have done at the top, find one of the sets of little steps to walk down, coming back down on the back street via steps, it is very beautiful. Allow a couple of hours at least to wander around.

Great overview of city of Paris. According to the locals Montmartre is above and apart from Paris; the consider themselves to be from Montmartre and not Paris. Either way, it's worth the trip up. The view from the Basilica Sacre Couer is breathtaking as is the Basilica itself. The artist section and surrounding restaurants was very crowded but we picked up a nice piece of original artwork

Highest point in Paris-- great views!. If you plan to visit the Montmartre area, take the Line 12 metro and get off at the Abbesses stop. From there, go up the steps to take the elevator up to the street level. It is a long ride up as this area used to be gypsum stone quarries. Upon getting up notice the Art Nouveau metro sign (one of a few left in Paris). Continue down on your left to head over to the base of Sacre Couer Basilica. From there if you have a Paris Metro pass , you may choose the option to take the funiculaire cable car ride up to the Sacre Coeur, otherwise you may walk the stairs adjacent or the path in the center.Be careful of a lot of street vendors that come up to you. If you touch or accept their merchandise, keychains, selfie sticks, etc., they expect you to pay up. We actually saw one being arrested by undercover for selling their wares to passerbyers. Not a good scene but obviously this is predominant in this busy area of Paris.The views from the outside of the Sacre Coeur Basilica are great if the sky is clear as it is the highest point in Paris. You can view the Montparnasse Towers (highest bldg. in Paris), Pompidou Centre (famous for its red, blue, yellow, green, and white exterior pipes) amongst the rest of Paris. So much to see and do in this area as there are a lot of quaint shops -- this was the area where aspiring singers, artists, actors, and actresses hung out before they got famous- like Edith Piaf, Renoir, Van Gogh, and Toulouse-Lautrec. There are a lot of souvenir shops along rue Steinkerque. Be wary of people asking you to take a risk or gamble over some bet on the streets here. Very busy area. Shops offer a great assortment of Paris souvenirs and the prices are reasonable.The Place de Tetre has changed somewhat over the years as there are less street artists selling their work. Restaurants have taken over a good portion of the square and it is not that nostalgic as before. Just have to enjoy what artists there are and try to relive those memories from years ago of the old Montmartre.Make sure you visit the interior of the Sacre Coeur Basilica-a unique interior with the mosaic tile. No photos are allowed inside. All in all it well worth a visit to this area of Paris.
The atmosphere!. The atmosphere is outstanding!! If you can, stop for a few minutes and have a lovely cup of coffee....But be aware, the painters are sometimes too obtrusive.

Touristy but interesting too. During our visit on a Sunday the narrow cobble stone streets were crowded with tourist but we still managed to find a quiet lunch spot, after our visit to the Cathedral.Recommended metro stop for a visit is Anvers on line 2.

Beautiful Village. I recommend taking a walk from the Moulin Rouge all the way up to the Sacre Couer. This is exactly what we did one fine morning, and it was an unforgettable experience! I loved all the quaint shops we passed by, the artists we saw painting right there in the plaza, loved the a capella singers performing right outside Sacre Couer (!), loved the smell of freshly baked bread and pastries coming out of those patiseries, and all the souvenir shops we passed along the way. Would definitely go back!

Very beautiful. Most impressive place to visit in the Paris. Beautiful from both inside but outside is even more impressive. The front and back side of the buildings are so beautiful - almost half day can be spend around it. Even the surrounding area exude old charm.
Nice area. It is a very nice area which contains different activities. I liked a lot the squar which is full of artists drawing.

The Paris Viewpoint !~. http://wp.me/p5Lw9a-dCThe higher you go, the farther you see. It is also the more you see. I love reaching high points and appreciate the city layout, grids, architecture and cityscape. Actually there are different places to do that in Paris :) Due to the direction of where the church is facing, we didn’t see the Eiffel tower at the parvis du Sacré-Coeur. The good thing about Montmartre is that it is a historic, romantic, and artistic district in town while we wandered around and enjoyed the view for FREE. However, the district is filled with tourists, as well as questionable con-artists and pickpockets that we could fill we were surrounded by them. It was a bit annoying.

An Interesting Art Colony, a la Parisienne. From the moment we got off the taxi that took us to the hill, to when we got into another taxi to leave the area, we were surrounded by artists offering to do a quick sketch, drawing or painting for us. I would have loved to do so and return to the U.S. with a nice memento of our Parisian trip, but I didn't want to slow down my traveling companions. We spent a half hour appreciating the panoramic vista of the city of Paris from the steps of the Sacre Coeur Cathedral, visiting inside the Cathedral, and lunching alfresco at the town plaza while watching some street performers sing some songs. On another evening, we returned to Montmartre for the Moulin Rouge dinner and show. The friendly taxi driver who drove us back to our hotel after the Moulin Rouge show, warned us that the Montmartre area is not as safe an area at night as other Parisian districts. I had formed a similar opinion of the area before he shared that with us. The streets and storefronts are not as kept up.

A view that is spectacular. a short metro ride here and your metro ticket could give you access to the trolley - be sure to check that out too. The view is amazing and the church is beautiful. A must stop.

A romantic and artistic paradise!. The whole place has such a gorgeous creative feel about it. On watching the film 'Moulin Rouge' I had a really romantic idea of the place and it certainly lived up to it. I only spent half a day there, but could happily live there among all the creative types! If you have time, visit the Sacre Coeur and have a drawing done by one of the many street artists.

typically Paris, (so, Paris). Montmartre is MUST SEE! can't leave the capital city without walking around (and UP) the Hill of Montamrtre for a couple of hoursIf you feel lazy, there is a little "funicular train" going up and down for the price of a Metro fare!Well Montmartre is an exquisite place to visit, but it's a little "overrated"!!! Try to avoid the "tourist traps", would be typical restaurants....and rather choose really typical brasseries down hill! ( along the rue des Abbesses for instance) Whrn on top, of course the Basilica of the Sacred Heart is something you want to visit, but there is a really small church beside the PLACE du Tertre (the famosu painters place) its name is " Saint PIerre de Montmartre church" ans it's really more interesting. There is a funny "twisted pilar" in it and one can't avoid it!!There are sometimes open air concerts in front of the church!Place du Tertre is quite a place. One can get a caricature, or an instant painting by local (or not) painters. Any style, you pick one! Other artisrts will make your profile with paper cuts!!!! in a couple of minutes. (you will decide yourself if it's a tourist trap or not) I'm a parisian myself, and I have benn to Montmartre many times, all seasons, there is always something new to shoot, or see!! and it's fun to be part of the tourists from all over the world! and Don't forget the Salvador DALI museum!

Heart of Paris. To be in Paris and not to visit Montmartre is something impossible to imagine. You will have an unforgettable day even just by walking there ore watching the artists and painters working , visiting Museums ore just having a wonderful mean in one of the coffee shops or restaurants which are many here . When you want to come to Montmartre you have to plan for a day of enjoyment and Wonderful experience.

The Artistic Side of the City..... One of the most beautiful and authentic parts of the City of Paris, Montmartre has lots to offer, from small cafes on every block to small boutiques offerings from a range of souvenirs to fresh food. The cobblestone streets are not easy to handle if you are not properly dressed and you can easily get tired with the hills so take it easy and be prepared. Its also a very popular area to see the occasional street artist or painters with lots of places and galleries around. You can easily find a good restaurant around every corner here and its a great place to wander around. One of my favorites places in Paris, for sure...

So Paris. So Touristy. So Fun. It's fun to walk along the streets of Montmartre and watch the jugglers or artists at work. Every conceivable souvenir is also available and the price is NOT going to get better. Just be careful to stay among the people touring and don't venture too far off the main marche alone.
Cool hood. Decent apartment prices nearish, great nightlife and cafes. Is not that near the center, but it is a great hood to be in generally.

Well Worth the Uphill Walk. The area is fantastic. It is easily accessed from Metro stops. The journey up the hill to Sacre Coeur du Montmartre is half the fun. There are many artists, shops and restaurants. At the top, is the Sacre Coeur, which is very stunning. During our visit, we watched a local performer do incredible stunts with a soccer ball while climbing and suspending himself from a lamppost. Highly recommended. Allow most of a morning or an afternoon.

Vibrant and not to be missed.. Vibrant and not to be missed.A metro stop from our hotel.To be certain, take precautions to avoid the attempts of the pickpockets,Montmartre is the heartbeat of Paris, and we find the area to be "safe" day or night.Lots of tourists, and lots of action.I am certain that my WWI grandfather enjoyed some "benefits of Montmartre," that I shall never.

The best view of Paris. It's quite a steep walk up to Montmartre but well worth the effort. We stopped at a cafe on the way and watched the world go by as we got ready to venture on. The climb to the dome of Sacre-Coeur, 300 steps most inside a stone spiral is exciting and tiring. At the top the 360 degree view of Paris is amazing. Make the effort it is worth it.

A high point in more than one way. Montmarte is an area primarily on a hill that overlooks the whole city of Paris. There are artists and cafes and it smacks of being the Paris of yesteryear. It can be very busy during the day and rightfully so. But as warning - there are pickpockets here in abundance. I caught one. While I lost nothing and he almost lost a hand, do watch out for them. But, don't let them stop you. Most people do not encounter trouble. Be sure and bring your camera and go to the top of the steps or into the church.

Real Paris is here!!. If you want to see Paris from its traditional side you should visit Montmartre! Here you will find traditional cafes and restaurants, you will see real painters all over the streets and you will feel that you travelled back in the past when artists were living there!! The most artistic place on earth is definitely here!! Also Sacre Coeur du Montmartre is very close..From up there you will see Paris all over!!

My favourite. Montmartre is my favourite area in Paris. It is well worth the climb, or you can take the funiculaire, because the view is beautiful. Too bad they didn't place the Eiffel Tower a bit better, or it would have been a perfect view.
If you can, visit it at night, the atmosphere is just great.

A Taste of Paris. On our first night we were fortunate enough to be able to walk from our hotel to Montmartre and what an introduction to this amazing city. Nestled behind Sacre Couer lies this artistic area where you can browse the work of artists and mix and mingle with street painters and more established artists. It was wonderful just to walk around and absorb the atmosphere but unfortunately we did get our daughters portrait done but we didn't make the best choice but we didn't let it bother us and when we return we will select more carefully.

Fabulous walk through Bohemien Paris. We had a walking tour scheduled to see some Picasso history, windmills and churches. Walking around we see amazing cafes, shops, and restaurants. Time to start our tour. But to get there after walking around the area on our own for a couple of hours first, we walked through about 10 blocks of what we found out later was the red light district. VERY red light. Nothing R rated going on there. But it was mid day, and the characters were still asleep, so what we saw were tons of sex shops and strip clubs.We started the tour at the Moulin Rouge. Quite a history of it's own, and an obvious favorite of our tour guide. We walked through a bunch of streets, each with it's own story. We saw the original Moulin Rouge, lots of cafes, and got a real sense of the Bohemian nature of the area and the time of Picasso. At the top of the hill we get to the famous cathedral. Tons of people. Live music. A little bit of a street carnival atmosphere. Very enjoyable and NOT TO BE MISSED!Once at the top, you are on your own to get back. We stopped at a couple of cafes for a little wine. And we continued strolling around when we happen upon a chalkboard with some restaurant specials. Best food we had during our Paris trip was here at a place called Alice Pizza. It's a very nice classy restaurant that doesn't even serve pizza or look like it has EVER served pizza. Wine was fabulous Food was fabulous. Service was fabulous. Which from me, is QUITE and endorsement.

Take a break from the city, become the artist you always wanted to.. Oh, the beautiful life... no wonder many artists feel inspired in Montmartre. it is one of those places you come every time you are in Paris and it is always have some new faces to show you.the atmosphere is a drawing to you, stay and feel the spirit, even thou it is definitely one of the biggest tourists traps ever. go there, have a croissant and sit around, enjoy to smell the clean artistic air.

Beautiful Neighborhood. We enjoyed the unique streets in this district. We will stay here on our next visit. Great views of the city, great shops, some good restaurants. Busy shops with junky stuff near the Cathedral.

My favorite place in all of Paris. The funicular ride to the top is fun. But the artist village around Sacre Couer is old and historic and quaint and quirky. A must experience. On your way you'll see the damous Moulin Rouge, too!

Parfait!. The place is absolutely perfect, nice food, nice stores, beautiful view. The only but is the crowd. If you are luck enough to get there and not find hords of tourists, spend the whole day snooping around, There are nice corners to be visited. However, if you find loads of people, stay for a while and leave as soon as you can, sometimes impossibel to walk around. :(
Nice. Nice to visit in paris. The view is just great. Go to the top! U have to take some stairs, and not sure if there is any elevator available

A great place to visit to enjoy the artists quarter. Sat next to the Sacre-Couer Basilica, on the hill above Paris, the old quaint streets contain some nice shops, some tourist tat but also lots of cafes and restaurants where you can stop and people watch.The main square (Place Du Tertre) is full of artists painting and drawing the tourists. Great to just marvel at their skills.Has a nice atmosphere and definitely worth the trip there

Sacre Coeur magnificent church. A must do in Paris is to visit the Sacre Coeur. If you don't mind climbing narrow stairs the bell tower at the rear is worth it. Once at the top you have magnificent views over Paris.

Inspiring. Under heavy rain was our visit.
That very artistic and romantic distric shows the soul of Paris.
Worth the visit with a lot of free time for a relaxed walk

Heaven for Art Lovers. It is a really great area both at Day and Nigh time. The place is rich with passion and allure of art, beauty and well love :-)
Plus, it not far from Metro but Paris Metro go pretty everywhere, anyway.

Atmospheric. Old, quaint but buzzing. Good restaurants and tourist shops. Great for bartering. Not a place for avoiding crowds. Spent whole day & evening walking round at leisurely pace. Nothing's rushed. Lovely evening meal & reasonably priced. Helpful staff in most places.

Neat area of France. We stayed in Montmartre, it is a neat area of Paris. We had a pretty good hike to the Metro. The streets are clean and it has several street side restaurants, you must eat at Le Basilic... Simply awesome food.
Nice place for daily walk. Very good place for a stroll. The small streets are unique. Here are a cheap souvenirs that you can take as a souvenir.

What a Fun Area of Paris! Climb the Hills, Charming Alleys, and Grand Views of Paris. We adored Montmartre. It's a surprisingly hilly area that floats above Paris. There are magnificent views of the city everywhere you look and the iconic Sacre Coeur Cathedral towers above the area. There are tons of restaurants and things to look at and discover. The one note of caution is that it is very touristy and crowded so be prepared for that. Highly recommended.
LOVE this area. This is one of the best areas of Paris. If you enjoy art and want to experience the local feel this is the spot for you. Highly recommend.

Great views of Paris and wonderful side streets. We travelled by metro and walked up the steps to Sacre Coeur. Magnificent view of the city. It was lovely to sit on the upper steps and just relax for a while. We encountered some very aggressive immigrants who tried to grab our wrists to tie a coloured thread. I had to be even more agressive back and wrench my wrist away from them - not pleasant. The Place du Tetre around the back of the cathedral was the best place to be. Lots of very good artists - many touristy paintings but some very original ones. Plenty of places to eat. Tip - to save money, buy a crepe or sandwich and sit at the side of the road. You will enjoy people watching!

My favourite one. In Montmarte u can feel the soul of bohems life - art, music, well.. Moullin Rouge:) It is a city inside of another city. It is unique with many small shops with streets without any tourists...Love it

Charming to the bone. The whole of Montmartre is a very charming part of town. Narrow streets, small suvenir shops, bakeries and restaurants. We walked up from the metro station Abesses and felt like we came to another world after we just before visited the Champs Elysees. Stair and streets with restaurants all the way. It can be very crowded here. We came on a sunday in july and it was packed, but on wednesday when we came back it was perfect. Still a lot of people, but relaxed and easy to find a table at the restaurants. I always come back here and it never gets boring.
Love it!. Nice region for walking tours. There are a lot of things to see. But in order to avoid climbing the streets, you can take the Montmartre Bus, it works with the Paris Visite ticket.

Super surprise. Fantastic view from the highest point of Paris and all for free.
The basilica is free to enter, and you have all the time to enjoy the surrounding views.
Not far to metro if you wish to use it.

Such a beautiful place. Definitely you have to visit this beautiful place, see the pitcturesque neighborhood, outdoor artists, painters and musicians and of course the church of Sacre-Coeur and the wonderful view of the city from the hill.
Perfect place to admire the French culture. Montmartre is a special place in the heart of Paris. A must seen to everyone who enjoy arts and culture.

Wouldn't take no for an answer.But the place was interesting. We actually got there too earjy, little was open. It was a part of the tour of the bascilica Sacre Coueur. It was quaint and looked interesting, but our timing was off. But not too early for the street artist, be prepared, they are very persistent. While my friend wanted her sketch I did not want to spend 50 Euros. My artist followed me around sketching while I was repeating "no I dont want it." When he finished he pulled the sketch from his pad and demanded to be paid. When I refused, He said I insulted him and he took the sketch wadded it and threw it to the ground. By the way, I didn't think it was very good and certainly wasn't going to pay 50 Euros.My friend was happy with her experience, I didn't want to get seperated from my friend, so I couldn't go too far. It was a funny story.

Absolutely Loved it!. I stayed near galaries lafayette and we walked it to Montmartre which was a 20 min walk early in the morning. Absolutely loved this area, filled with small cafes and souvenir shops, they have a small flea market at times and also artists who can draw you cue caricatures. Sacre Couer which is a catherdral atop the hill is a must go! the view outside is a stunner.

Amazing town! Plan lots of time to see it!. I thought there wasn't much to Montmarte other than Sacre Couer. While the Cathedral is wonderful and definitely worth seeing, the town surrounding it is wonderful! We spent all afternoon in Montmarte and could have spent a lot more if we weren't already so exhausted. One of the local artists in the town square did a charcoal sketch of our kids and it's amazing. I'm having it framed and will be hanging it in my house. Between the 4 of us in my family, we bought several pieces of art from local artists and they were all reasonably priced. We had lunch at one of the cafes - La Boheme - and it was wonderful. My husband had a huge steak and my daughter had an endless pot of mussels. We will definitely go back and plan a longer day in Montmarte during our next trip to Paris!

Mixed experiences. We took the 67 bus from the Latin Quarter (same tickets as metro) and enjoyed the city views from the bus. The church itself was beautiful, and the small streets were quaint, but I had mixed feelings about the whole experience. There were hoards of tourists in a main square, and we encountered a teen gang of scammers/potential pickpockets as our Airbnb host had warned us. (Going up a flight of stairs, a couple teenage girls handed us petitions to sign regarding an organization for the deaf and mute. One column was for amount of donation, which we saw lots of people had filled out! I held my purse in front of me as I signed with the other hand then left when I saw that column. My teen daughter was behind me a bit--and she did the same, but as she tried to leave, she was swarmed by a huge number of quite aggressive people; I called out to her and she was able to push her way through, still clutching her purse. Think about it--you're distracted by holding a petition board with one hand and signing with the other, and at the top of stairs you can't easily get away. The police try to crack down on these activities but are limited because they're done by minors. (Then there are also police/government activities against entire Roma settlements--makes me queasy too.) OK. So then we went to a restaurant on a slightly less crowded street. Our family of four wanted to order and share two meals (my husband was going to leave to take photos then come back only for the company, and the kids don't eat much, plus the meals were expensive). The waiter got all huffy and stormed off. Really?! (If it's a problem for them, they should print a "shared-plate charge" in the menu.) We should have just gotten up and left at that point but were too taken-aback. Instead, a waitress then came and was really nice, bringing an extra plate and offering us water. Other restaurants, we asked for "regular (tap) water" and got it. This time, she brought a liter bottle and opened the top before we could say, "Wait, we thought you meant tap water." The bill showed it was 7 euros; our total bill came to 50 euros, which is still a lot. One meal had included dessert, but it never arrived and we didn't realize until we were outside the restaurant and didn't want to return. The dessert might have been a mistake, but the bottled water after acting all nice--that felt like a revenge scam. Not really better than the fake-petition scammers in my opinion (except the fake-petition scammers' families were probably poorer). This was our only bad experience with any French people or in any French restaurant during our 10 days in France. I wish I remembered its name!! My conclusion: sites mobbed with tourists probably bring out bad sides of everyone.

Walk around and explore. Beautiful place to walk around and sit round for a drink. Loved the vibe of the neighborhood. The artists market is of good interest, dont forget to bargain if you are buying something from the marketplace as the prices are marked on the higher side almost always.

If you want a place to sit and watch, expect the worst French behaviour.... This place is of course very famous and hence the staff at the nearby restaurants behave like kings - we just wanted to sit down for a shared coke, and the staff commented 9 times loudly that we only ordered ONE coke. We left and found another place - still very expensive - but with a staff that was not arrogant and stupid. Montmartre is of course worth a visit but I suggest to bring enough water on your own, since French arrogance cannot get higher than here
Go out of season if you can. Sadly very trippery, which hid the real interest and quaintness of the area. But a must fr visitors to Paris.
Nothing fancy. Small streets with beautiful shops but nothing spectacular. It also very crowed, which also makes things more difficult.

Oh la la. Climb up the steps and pass behind the wonderful Sacre Court Basilica and you are in Montmatre, a village teeming with tourists, plenty of cafes bars, restaurants and shops selling pottery, art and trinkets. It has a fabulous atmosphere and if you're wearing a good pair of shoes explore the little streets around.
stunning area. wandered around here on Christmas day, drinking wine, eating far too many brioche and had a lovely wandering day.... great place to visit

Bohemian paradise. Delightful area to visit with many shops, art vendors set up in the square and wonderful artists and musicians working the streets. Walking in the footsteps of so many great artists alone is worth the visit, but the traditions carry on. Wonderful place to wonder!

Lovely area. We adored Monmartre. We did a guided tour with New Sandemans and then went back on our own to explore more. It was a bit disconcerting to start in the red light district at Blanche metro, but a few steps took you a world away. Monmartre is tremendously pretty, full of history and stories of artists, plus lots of good restaurants. We loved the square full of artists - pretty and fun. We weren't very keen on the Sacre Coeur, but Monmartre has so much else to offer. Don't miss it!
Gorgeous views of Paris (make sure to be there at sunset). This area was wonderful. Sacre Coeur, the views, the shops, the restaurants, the street performers all made this a magical place.
A must for love of monuments. Being here is a an experience in itself . Amidst the history it can evoke so much . Would recommend it to all to keep the appointment with monument .
Memorable visit. Eclectic atmosphere , great cafes and interesting cultural experience. Visit to Sacre Coeur a must whist up here. Often you will hear Nuns singing.

Lots and lots of shops.....bought most of my souvenirs there.. I like the hustle and bustle of Montmartre! Years ago I had my granddaughters portrait done there & I love having that reminder of a GREAT trip to Paris.

The best place to visit when in Paris. On a glorious sunny day we visited this lively and bustling 'artists quarter' of Paris .....it is as another contributor has said "an absolute jewel". Lots of cafes, fast food, gift shops......One of the best visits in Paris.....a great day out

probably my favourite area in Paris. We walked a lot in Montmatre area coming from Pigalle. The area is so cool. Le Sacre Coeur is one of the most beautiful church in the world. The small roads full of shops are very crowded but nice. In some areas there are some immigrants asking for money, trying to sell something or cheating using the shell game

Crowded but talented. The area is massively crowded. I was a bit wary of my belongings but may be it was just me over-worrying. However, the area is loaded with real talented painters. I kept snatching looks to what they paint all the time.

Not enough time in this jewel of a place. Hands down one of my favorites places in France...and only a couple of metro buses away. The cobble stone streets, authentic music and artists on the streets made this visit so worth my while. I wish I would have had an entire day to visit. The cathedral of Sacred Heart was unbelievable and had the most amazing view of Paris. Yes, the climb up was steep but once your up there it is breathtaking.
Touris Trap but still Iconic. Day and evening busy with tourists and panhandlers, and street performers, and artists. Still worth visiting briefly and eating or having a drink further off

You have to go here. Sacre Couere! You just have to come here, not only for the basilica, which you can access via the funicular for those of us less fit, also for the views, watching the artists at work and the labyrinth of streets to discover. There is an atmosphere here that is palpable. Stop and have a drink and people watch and soak in the atmosphere, it is that good, enjoy.

Place to stroll around. Interesting place to visit in the artistic quarter with many people at the top it is very touristic but nice view of Paris. Many artists drawing things mean you can get a nice painting. Don't forget to bargain. It is a nice climb up but you can also take the Twitter train or the vennicular railway.

A saucy side of France. We spent a night in Maison Soquet (25/6/15) and had the chance to explore Montmartre & Pigalle on foot. I was initially apprehensive when our taxi entered the area. It seemed rough, the people somewhat coarse. Lots of motorcycles and mopeds zipping around. (we were more used to the areas closer to the Seine). Still, I'm glad I took the time to stay here. Despite it's reputation for petty crime, there is an honesty to this place, and it's people. It's touristy enough, especially the areas around Moulin Rouge and Sacre Coeur. Indeed, many tourists make the trip to Montmartre just to see Sacre Coeur, and rush off. But, it's really more fun just wandering around the narrow streets here, watching the unpretentious local folk, stopping for coffee in one of the cafes and stepping into the various stores (not all sell sex toys ) It is a former red light area, and when night falls, a vestige of the old area can still be glimpsed. Very safe nevertheless, we were wandering the streets till 11pm and felt no danger whatsoever. Highly recommended.

A must go on your Paris trip. We loved this area of Paris with the Basilica of Sacre Core the surrounding streets and and just sitting back in the local square in of old Montmarte enjoying the food and wine.

The cradle of the Impressionists. Get off the subway at the Abbesses station and gently climb up the hill. Stairs and narrow streets. On the top many restaurants but not very good. I rather propose a drink or crepes. You can admire the crowd of tourists and the local painters making portraits...if you want one better negotiate the price before they start and often they start without your permission so refuse it. Only bad artists do that. All around the world the same problem exists. View from the top of the stairs is outstanding. It's 360• if you climb up to the top of the Sacré Coeur church. A small old vineyard is on the North slope of the hill.

Go early to avoid the crowds and don't eat there!. Montmartre was the most over crowded place I went to in Paris so it was hard to enjoy it. The food was very expensive and not very good. Tourist traps. Go very early to walk around without the crowds and get a feel for the place. I wish I did that because I could tell it would be a quaint place to visit with its cobbled streets. Also there are stairs and cobbled streets everywhere so if you have mobility issues or back issues it can be a problem.

One of the my favorite areas in Paris!. Despite all of the tourist traps, Montmarte still has such nice vibes. There are talented artists, yummy cafes, cute little gardens and tiny stores selling handmade goodies everywhere. Beautiful view of the city, too!

Gorgeous view from the church steps. I love Montmartre! As much as there's a tourist trap vibe in some squares, others are quiet and feel like you're transported back to the time when the streets were over run by starving artists and people dancing at the Moulin de la Galette. Love spending time here. But beware the "bracelet weavers" and street artists -- lots of cons working here.

Montmartre suplex. Stayed in a terrific duplex right next door to the moulin rouge that we booked them the French experience in Australia. What a fab location and a huge duplex with 2 bedrooms and 2 ensuite so and a big living area.Loads of places to eat and across the road from the hop on hop off bus.The Proximity of the Moulin Rouge meant that an evening at the show was not to be missed.Easy walk to three different metro stations so we were able to get everywhere including Versailles easily.

my fav place in paris. made our own way via the metro was easy, this is a gem with street artist everywhere very Bohemian , had a spot of lunch in the sun people watching while listening to very talented buskers played , worth a visit

Loved my little home neighborhood while in Paris.. This was my home neighborhood for my stay in Paris. Enjoyed the quirky mix of everything. Best part was being able to slip down a side street to find a very quiet respite from the busy areas. Deserves to be explored by day and night!

Incredible, must see place!. I visited Montmartre with a free walking tour. I couldn't even imagine how special it was for local people to live in this district with loads of cafes, shops and bakeries. It is definitely worth of walking through tiny medieval streets, sit at the cafe terrace, drink coffee, enjoy calm atmosphere.

Looks like the place to stay for fun. We traveled through this area and decided that it is likely the "fun" place to stay. Looks like a lot of activity with restaurants, bars, and shops. A little dirtier than some areas. But alas, we didn't find any clean places in Paris.

Montmarte. A great way to spend a day on Paris is-get to Montmarte, walk to the Cemetry, this could take a whole day as it is huge and so interesting, then after enjoying lunch in one of the many Restaurants in the area, walk up through the Montmarte suburb, beautiful shops, restaurants, fresh food and seafood shops. Take the fernicular up to Sacre Cour and spend the rest of your day viewing the Church and the amazing area around it. Have your portrait doneby one of the many ? artists, browse the souvenier shops or stop for coffee along th way. Montmarte is an area full of history, entertainment and fun, a wonderful experience

Smell of 'old'Paris!. Romantic atmosphere of Paris with the Basilica of Sacre Core the gardens the view and the small square surrounded by coffee shops and small restaurants in Montmarte.Painters willing to make your portrait and somewhere there you can also find the Salvador Dali's small museum and nice places to buy handmade chocolate treats!

A beautiful, but overpriced tourist area.. There's no denying the charm of Montmartre,but beware: it's a real tourist trap, with people selling generally second rate 'art' to the unwary. Restaurant prices charging ridiculous prices even for a beer. Go, see, photograph, then leave.
Montmartre - the place to live as a tourist.. Loved living in Montmartre. Beautiful location with galleries, cafes, landscapes, the Sacre Coeur and within easy access to the City of Paris by Metro
A place to go. This is definitely a place to visit in Paris. It is so lovely with the Sacred Heart and the Place du Tertre. There are artists everywhere, and the ambiance is nice.

Artists haven. This place still attracts a significant number of talented artists in the tradition of this historic artists haven of old (Salvador Dalí, Amedeo Modigliani, Claude Monet, Piet Mondrian, Pablo Picasso, Camille Pissarro and Vincent van Gogh). There is a good selection of fine restaurants where you can select from traditional French dishes or something trendy while you watch the artists ply their trade. The is a wonderful environment to be in.

Enjoy the atmosphere. A must visit while you're in paris...just go and soak it all in. The artists and the surroundings. Lovely view of the city and the Sacre Coeur is close by. It's a very crowded area, be careful if your belongings. It's also quite a steep walk up so take a bus or cab.

A Paris icon even while a tacky tourist area. I visted Montmarte after an absence of many years. Sacre Couer is still a white Byzantine building visible from most of Paris, but the crowds are intense. Hold on to your valuables. The famous artists square, Place de Tertre is still vey nice and although super touristy, is still,well worth observing. When done visiting, head out to other parts of Paris for lunch.

Like home.. I loved the vintage feel of there. Very homey, quiet and lovely souvenirs. The artists are amazing and their works fascinating. Bright, jumps out at you. The price of food, budget friendly, Make sure to try the gelato at Tutti Sensi!!! and the view from the steps awwwwwwww.. My heart melted when I found it. I think so far.. this is my favourite place in Paris.
Must go!. This area of Paris is fun, beautiful, and very interesting!A definitive must when in Paris. Walk up the side streets to find the most amazing cheese shops and bread shops.

Great atmosphere. There are lots of restaurants, shops, and artists throughout Montmartre. It had a very friendly atmosphere. We enjoyed our time there but hadn't looked into it's history much beforehand. I think that would have made our visit even better!

Charming and Quirky. Montmartre is a delightful hilltop artist village. You will discover cozy bistros and small galleries. There is a wonderful view of the city from Montmartre. Local artist paint the city from this vantage point and display small works of art for sale to visitors. There is also a historic church you will find interesting. It was part of our city tour and we thoroughly enjoyed our time there.

Le Sancerre.... A very special place.. My visits to Montmartre always include breakfast in Le Sancerre & always will do so in the future. Despite some changes over the years in terms of decor this place is one of the few remaining cafes/brasseries to have retained an interesting character and a local feel and not to have been swept up in the increasing embourgeoisement of Montmartre which I have sadly witnessed over many years. I highly recommend the morning for a visit. Excellent breakfast (& cheaper than many that are less good) friendly staff and altogether a wonderful place to hang out. I love the place!
a must see. aaaaaah, we walked miles to get here. and the stairs...... don't do the stairs, rather take the shuttle up the hill....definitely worth the visit!

Had fun. Well, just first of all don't get you expectations 2 high, I visited the place upon peoples review about it and I loved it but wasn't that impressed.The view is amazing we got to see Paris from the top at the morning and it was very nice ( but I already did the same at Eiffel tower so OK why should I care about that again?, but the difference in Montmartre is that you can sit on the stairs and just relax and enjoy the view for a long while- and that's why i advice that you Visit Eiffel tower at night to see the difference- see my review about Eiffel tower if you like)Also you must try the restaurants or cafes there they are amazing! its really worth it! but keep an eye on your personal belongings.I would defently not recommend that you visit the artist there! its not worth it! and the drawing would cost averagely 40 to 80 euros and sometimes more!! so skip it! and the good artists are no less than 80!

Great Artsy Area. If you don't mind walking uphill this area is very 'artsy'. There are artists everywhere available to paint your portrait. The restaurants are nice and there a lots of little shops. It is very much for tourists.
Self tour. I LOVE MONTMARTRE!! The shops, the outdoor cafes, the people, the atmosphere! I love this place! The food is awesome. Bring me back!!

Book a tour!. Montmartre is simply gorgeous. If you're not familiar with the history of the area, book a tour! There are so many beautiful restaurants and cafes to enjoy, as well as areas where artists are selling their wares. I could (and did) spend hours wondering around the streets of Montmartre, a must see when you're visiting Paris
Must do. We loved it there: from the amazing church, to the green grass, the stores and restaurants and the painters. It was really nice.

Interesting. What used to be a significant historical area, of Paris, is now a commercial area for artists, restaurants and souvenir shops, which is why it is such a great place to visit.The restaurants have great character, the waiters dress up in a typical french style with striped shirts and cravats, the artists sell their works or do on the spot portraits of tourists, the area has a lot of atmosphere, I really loved it there.Not to mention you can visit Sacre Coeur at the same time.If you are buying souvenirs, make sure you price them from shop to shop, we did find a big variation in price.
historical place. I know montmarte from the film Amelie. If you are really a history lover, then visit montmarte. Othewise it may not be very interesting. Be aware of pick pockets.

Charming area. Charming area with a gorgeous view of all of Paris. Really enjoyed walking around and looking at all of the artists sketch their portraits. We had to get a portrait of ourselves as well while here!

Can be very crowded with people (ripe for pickpockets) or beggars.. Hilly place that is littered with souvenir shops- if there is something you cant find in 1 shop, you will probably find it in another shop down the road. Quaint cobblestone streets harken back to an earlier time.

Art and Beauty. The way to Montmartre, Sacred Heart Church, Dali Museum, and the sound of music, everything around you speaks of love and beauty, a visit to Paris without visiting Montmartre and everything around then you missed a half of Paris, the Moulin Rouge in the evening awaits you. You will like this neighborhood if you looked into it by your heart. beauty

Worth a visit. Yes it is touristy, but definitely worth a day to visit. There is so much to see and the area is full of shops and cafes. Don't like the tourist feel! Keep moving away to the edges. Bring a picnic and enjoy one of the area parks. You won't regret it.

Nice change of pace. We have seen everything in Paris so this is a nice change. We took the funicular up and walked down. One up we visited the main cathedral which had a service in progress. No admission charge. We then walked around the Town and walked by Renoirs studio and where other famous artists meet. Very nice,- Expect lots of up/down walking!- No public bathrooms so prepare to buy something at a restaurant to use restrooms.

Fantastic place to people watch - but don't forget that you are being watched as well!. It may be packed with tourists from all over the world - just like you - but it is still very Parisian and the basilique de Sacre Coeur makes a fantastic backdrop, while the church steps offer a great view over the city. Late afternoon or early evening is a good time to go if you want to join the throngs and soak up the atmosphere and perhaps enjoy an aperitif in one of the many bars, some of which share space with the many street artists, most of whom are fantastically adept at capturing a genuine likeness, or creating an amusing caricature. It's very easy to get carried away here and pay more than you meant to for a nick-nack, or a charcoal sketch!
Want a variety in one place?. This was a fun area, very different, not to miss. From small shops, strolling, the Ber jet Follies a blast

As always..my favorite arrondissement. Great atmosphere....around the Basilica, the winding streets, the gelato, the restaurants.....the whole area is magical. Really pleasant experience in Montmartre!

Must visit Montmartre if you have time in Paris. We took the local train to Montmartre. The transport system is really easy to understand in Paris. When you arrive you can catch a local bus right where you come up from underground which takes you all over Montmartre for just two euros. Much cheaper than a tour. It goes right to the top and you can get on and off where you like. There is also a little train that goes to the top of the hill but don't kn ow cost of this. Spend a whole day here if you can, so much to see but watch out for pickpockets be alert all the time.
The quintessential image of Bohemian Paris. I loved visiting Montmarte. All Of the cafes, the breathtaking views, and the artists square are just indescribably beautiful.

Plan for fun!. I loved this area. My gosh, so many interesting people, vendors, musicians, shop owners, artists on the street, food, and food, and food and drink, and did I mention food!!!! You need to spend hours walking the streets, taking it all in....have fun!
An adventure in art and time.. Montmartre is still there for you. Lots of odd places and houses for you to discover. And people. Not only Tourists. They mostly hang out around the Sacre Qouer.

Great place to enjoy the local art.. Great area for artists. If you want a professional portrait done or are looking for local art work this is the place. Nice small neighborhood to wander around and just spend some time enjoying the local art.

A definite must!. I loved this area. Strolling through the art market was very fun and I have some amazing art now hanging on my walls. Definitely haggle - we got great deals buying all our art together (3 of us) instead of individually. The whole area is well worth the visit! You won't be disappointed!

a taste of old Paris. one of the oldest sections of Paris a must see walk up the steps or take the cable car its like Paris of old
artists everywhere great shops and plenty of restaurants and bars
Love it. Just amazing place!! I want to go again! When you are there, with all the painters you go back to the history

One of my favorite places in Paris. The Place du Tetre is a bit clichéd, but clichés exist for a reason. There's just no better way to feel like you need a beret on your head, a baguette under your arm then to stroll through the stone streets of Montmarte, up and down staircases, gazing on flower boxes and quaint vistas in every direction. It's one of the few places in Paris that feels like Haussmann didn't get his hands on it. I generally love the "sameness" of Paris' architecture that he created, but that's why Montmarte is a must - the last windmills, the crooked little streets, the hills, the tile roofs. Everyone goes to Sacre Couer and Place du Tetre - do yourself a favor and get lost in the streets beyond.

Wonderful place to walk. We've walked up the steps in the winter (a little slippery!), the spring and the summer. And in any season, walking to the top of the hill at Sacre Coeur is well worth an afternoon's investment. It's a beautiful area, filled with creperie, museums, little restaurants. Plenty of opportunity to people viewing. Loved the Dali museum. And the views?? Spectacular.

Come see the local artists. My wife and I visited Paris with our French friends, this was a must as Fabienne stated, watch local artists paint , using chalk, charcoal water colors etc.... Plus the food is outstanding

Charming!. A beautiful part of Paris with winding roads, limitless cafes and restaurants and a charm! lots of shops and ice cream parlours and a few tackier shops closer to the Sacre Coeur. By far my favourite and prettiest part of paris!

Disappointing. Nice area, but nothing really special, was very disappointed though I don't really know what I expected. A pleasant area to walk but nothing special. Worth a visit if you have plenty of time
Great way to spend a morning. Nothing like wandering about, up to Sacre Couer for a visit and breath in the views. Then strolling around, taking in the artists at work.

Seedy neighborhood whose one claim to faim is Sacre Coer. Honestly your time would be better spent elsewhere in Paris. Yes, Sacre Coer is beautiful. But Montmartre has more than its share of sleezy adult stores alon the main promenade. This is the home of the Moulin Rouge and other such establishments so its a historically seezy area. See the Marais instead.

True Paris. I loved Montmartre so much! Great, Parisian atmosphere on its streets and so much to take in! There were painters, people singing old French songs, charming stairs, beautiful buildings, souvenir shops all over the place. We could have stayed there for hours! Would go back at any time!

Sacre Coeur definitely.... My favourite part of Paris. Beautiful streets, great energy, and an oasis of calm as you climb Montmartre up to Sacre Coeur and fabulous views across Paris, taking in the Eiffel Tower. I alway make a point of visiting when I'm in Paris.

Montmartre - Visiting Sacre Coeur, portraits by artists, enjoying crepes and ice cream. Visiting Montmartre was one of our prime destinations during our vacation in Paris. We climbed the steps all the way to the church, although there is a lift (furnicular) for those who prefer to ride up. We visited the church of Sacre Couer, then afterwards walked down the alley to the courtyard filled with artists. We looked at the different samples of their artwork, then settled on those whose work attracted us, having portraits made for 3 of us with different artists.We ate in the cafe at the corner, La Boheme, that served delicous mussels soup and other comfort food. Walking through the different shops selling souvenirs, paintings, accessories, etc., we stopped to sample some French Crepes and ice cream. It was a very enjoyable 4 hours spent in the place. Afterwards, we took the subway and dropped by to see the Windmill of Moulin Rouge, then transferred to the Trocadero to watch the Eiffel Tower at night, with its' beautiful scintillating lights.

Hidden treasures in the area. Montmartre is beautiful. There is enough written about it. The area has a lot to offer, from food to touristy shopping to photography. Walk around the area and you will discover so much. Salvador Dali's museum is up around the corner, so on return from the cathedral a visit to Dali is an added treat.
Pleasant area. One of our favourite areas to meander through. Some lovely quaint little restaurants, where competition keeps costs reasonable.

A different Paris!. Absolutely beautiful. Make sure you go up to the top of the dome of Sacre Couer. Stairs are easy and well worth. Make sure you walk down through the village to Moulin Rouge. Great little cafe up the road on the right just before Moulin Rouge. Great food and good value for money. Love the atmosphere of the whole area.

Picturesque and historical. It's not just the visit to the cathedral, the trip to Montmartre has a lot more to offer. It's situated on the top of a hill from where you can get a roof top view of Paris. The lanes are full of history and bustling with tourists and activity. You can find local artists drawing free hand sketches and portraits or playing their musical instruments. I don't have a great sense of art but found the work pretty neat. You need to bargain on the price if you want to get your portrait done. You can get variety of food around the cathedral. People enjoy their coffee while enjoying the activity and sun. You can take the funicular on your way up and opt to walk your way down to the metropolitan station. There's a lot to explore in the bye lanes, and if you're interested to explore, budget for at least half a day.

Things DO change. It has been about 20 years since I last visited Sacre Coeur and the Montmarte area. It has always been a tourist area, but I do not remember so many large organized tour groups clogging the narrow streets. It is a picturesque area and worth a visit. Too bad it is cheek to jowl and crammed with cheap souvenir and trinket shops.

Take the walk . You can climb the steps or take the funicular. When you get to the top you'll have a spectacular view of the city and a chance to see a 'modern Byzantine' church that was finished only a century ago. The area itself is rather crowned and anything but pristine, the artists in the square are not nearly as good as their opinions of themselves, and pickpockets are in abundance. That said, it's worth a visit.
Worth the trip one time. If you are in Paris for the first time it is important to see as much as possible. Montmartre is one of those places to see, tons of history.

A pictureque part of Paris.. Montmartre is well worth a walk about, away from the main parts of Sacre Coeur and the Place du Tertre, which are the 2 main tourist focal points.
