Don't just visit these 2 attractions and leave without seeing the area.The streets are narrow and steep but there are some lovely views to be had from in front of the steps of the Sacre Coeur.There are a number of coffee shops and bars away from the main areas above that are much better than the traps at Place du Tertre, where waiters stand outside and desperately try to get you to come in to their restaurant.At the foot of Montmartre, at the Abbesse metro station is the 'mur d'amour', a stunning art work that says "I love you" in hundreds of languages and a great photo opportunity for any couples.

Loved the history, disappointed in trashy tourism. This was intended to be a highlight of my trip. With the distinctive pedigree of this area and the artists it generated, I can't help but be disappointed in the vibe of the place today. Artist's square is loaded with average work, cartoons, and general mediocrity. It was lovely to see Utrillo's la Maison Rose, much the same. I guess my imagination and love of the artistic period of the late 1800's to early 20th century was not as evident visually as I had hoped. Still the history of the place is significant and worth a visit, just to walk in the steps of some of the greatest minds and artists at the turn of the 20th century. Down the stairs and into the area of the Moulin Rouge you can find an area lit with neon, color and energy. If you ever get nostalgic for Times Square in the 70s go here...

Artists everywhere. Great place to look for original art and also visit the beautiful church on the hill. Street vendors are everywhere selling trinkets -- prices here, however, are less than at the Eiffel Tower and they will bargain.

Enjoy the Art in Montmartre. Montmartre is a must when going to Paris. It is a sharp climb (but you use the funicular) and actually we walked it from the Arc visiting the Moulin Rouge and fruit stands along the way. Watch the artists paint and draw, enjoy a lunch and people watch, and visit the basilica. The view is awesome.
Carrefour open till 11:30. Carrefour in front of moulin rouge is open till 11:30..Very handy for tho se wanting too purchase breakfast for next morning

Fantastic view fabulous atmosphere. Don't miss this. Once you have arrived at the Cathedral and enjoyed the view stroll around to the left side and follow the crowd to the most atmospheric restaurant and shopping area.Enjoy.

A must visit if you're in Paris. Just a short metro trip away from Paris, Montmartre is a must-visit. It has a really cool vibe with lots of street action, restaurants, pop past the Moulin Rouge for a photo, visit the Sacre Coeur and definitely visit the Montmartre Cemetery.Take a stroll down little side streets away from all the above touristy attractions and you will find quaint restaurants and an amazing vibe.

For New Yorker it will be the French village.. When you stay in the mid town in Paris, you have too many museum to visit and too many places to go. When you have time, you have to go to Montmartre. Because I spent most of life in New York and I love the Village area, I find the same place in Paris when I visited the neighbor of Basilica of Sacre and I set on the step there looking on the old part of Paris from the top. I walked in Montmartre and purchased most of my memorabilia to my friend and family. I walked the high hill and narrow streets and visited the houses were the best painter in the history spent their poor life on it. There are too many nice restaurant. One of the artists insists to draw my picture which I agreed. I still have it even it does not have anything look like me.

Real Paris is Montmartre. Having lived for a shorter duration in Paris, I came to the conclusion that the Real and Geuine Paris spirit is found at Montmartre town square near the church, the area is great and offers You all the best from the city, You have offcourse Moulin Rouge district, but away from such distractions, this area is The Place to visit, wine and dine, take a strole and enjoy it...

Mooching in Montmartre. Today was our last day in Paris so we decided to spend some time mooching around the shops and bisros of Montmartre. It is a very hilly and atmospheric part of Paris. We stopped for a great lunch and then walked up to the Sacre Coer

Best in the early morning. I simply love this area. It is one of the places the onslaught of tourists can't spoil. It has so much charm and confidence about it. If you can, visit it when the tourists left or have not arrived yet. I like it best in the very early morning.

Montmartre. This is a lovely area for a wander around watching the artists in the square,and just soaking up the atmosphereafter a visit to Sacre Coure.Crepes are yum but once more its a tourist trap for restaurant prices-the 3course menus seem good value but check the drink prices before you go in or stay on water!

"Touristy, but fun". We took the train from the Eiffel Tower to Montmartre and then a bus to the top. We were delighted to see this tiny hilly area lined with shops and restaurants. It is quite touristy , but fun. We enjoyed people watching and the quaintness of the area. We went to a beautiful, peaceful church on top of a large hill and enjoyed seeing it as much as the larger cathedrals. We were able to look down at the city below and it was all very scenic. We stopped at a restaurant and sat outside enjoying the day with some good red wine, who could ask for more! On the way back we stopped for some Gelato, yum and headed for the Funicular for a ride down to the train station. All in all a very lovely afternoon!

Have to go. Anybody spending even 2 days in Paris must visit here. A beautiful hill on the outskirts of the city it's the most charming part of Paris. The walk to the top of the hill and the view of the city from there is amazing. This is the area where so many impressionist artist spent a part of there life. Just walking around here is so nice. The church at the top is lovely and worth a visit and the artists square where you find so many artists painting and displaying their art which one can buy is a absolute must. Here there are some lovely cafes to sit and while away your time. The feeling is you are in a village.Just loved it.

Paris trip. A must. We walk up from the metro near the Moulin Rouge up to Sacre Coeur and whilst it was a steep climb in places it was well worth it. There are some great shops on the way and once you got up to the main square there were lots of cafes as well as artists and the place was really vibrant and fun even in the drizzle.

Relaxed on the top. My main fear was the crowds of tourists, yet we happened on a quiet Thursday and enjoyed the idyl of the place. A bit more touristy than I like it, but still unmissable. Paris as stereotypical as possible.

Lovely part of Paris. We walked from Gare du Nord after getting off the Eurostar (about 15 mins). The Sacre Coeur is a lovely sight on top of the hill with good views over Paris. There are lots of cheap tourist shops on the way for souvenirs but beware the hawkers - just say "non merci" and walk on. Make sure you go to the artists market at the left side of the church and wander around looking at the art - it feels so French!

sketching memories. Choose your artist carefully... they all have different styles - We had watched some videos on Youtube and knew exactly who we were looking for... ( Davy Lim ). The experience was just as we hoped - making a special time even more memorable. We were glad that we got there at about 9:30am - some artists were only just getting there. He was able to sketch both us in about two hours - so be prepared to be flexible with your schedule. The morning light was helpful giving pleasing textural hints for the artist. The square itself can get very busy - coach load after coach load are dropped off. Mr Lim says that visitors need to be careful when choosing their artist as the style and quality does vary greatly - as does the cost - there is some degree of negotiation open to you.

Now this is Paris.. We are so glad we stayed in Montmartre! The area is very hilly to walk around in but quaint, & feels like what I imagined Paris to be with the cobble stone streets & cafes. The area isn't as touristy as others so the feel is more relaxed & uncrowded. It's close enough to all the must see famous sites to walk, or has convenient acces to take the Metro or bus if you prefer.

Amazing view. lovely place to spend some time with family or even with your other half.You could pay few euro to get to the top or using steps.If you decide using steps I would recommended one passing electric cars(lifts)as they not steep stairs and is a lot of easier to get to the top and much more lovely view. beautiful panoramic view of Paris..Only down side is that people try to sell you stuff and even when you saying you don't want they still try and follow you it is a bit annoying.otherwise worth to pay a visit

A must see.. Almost missed this great location during our visit to Paris. Went up to the Sacre Coer as we had an idea it was not far from there. Luckily we walked just a little further on and 'found' this wonderful enclave of talented people. Wanted to buy the whole place.
Magic. This is why I love Paris, because of this neighbourhood! It remainded me of the movie Amelie, and it was so peaceful and full of street art, I really liked it!

Sacre-Coeur, artists, quaint streets. Another must-see while in Paris. The hill top has, of course, the famous Sacre-Coeur church perched there. But the views of Paris are wonderful from there, and near the top is a square full of artists selling their wares, while you can then walk around quaint streets as you make your way down the hill to the bottom.
wonderful way to see Paris. A must see when you visit Paris. Wonderful way to see the city and immerse yourself in the culture. Take a cab up and have a see.

Charming and worth your time!. The Moulin Rouge and the seedy area are only a small aspect of Montmartre. There are so many enchanting areas worth exploring! The Sacré Coeur Cathedral is worth the climb and the view is lovely. It is a fun experience strolling through the areas where Picasso, Van Gogh, Monet, and Dali worked and lived. And there is a small vineyard and charming nooks and stunning homes lining every street.
bohemian area. We enjoyed staying in this area, close to Abscess and some wonderful dining also close to the Carrefour, where we could by some food for dinner to prepare

Photographers Delight. We done a self walking tour of Montmartre. Around every corner you find something to take a photo off. Art work, souvenirs and restaurants are found along the way too. A pure delight to spend a few hours.

TOP of the World. highest point in Paris and worth the effort to subway or cab up. Walking down is better. Interesting community with shops and cafes and a different fell from the sprawling city below. Go to the top and the Church and look out. Be in good shape as even the Metro steps can be challenging.

Beautiful.. Simply beautifull, one of the more pitoresques arrondissements in Paris. From the atmosphere to the buildings everything is awesome. Make sure you stop at the central square and enjoy a nice hot chocolate (if visiting during winter) or get your portrait made by one of the many street artists you will find there.
Incredible city view. Not only is the view worth seeing but the cathedral is charming and the street art scene is where reasonable and good art direct from the artist can be purchased.

Sadly, little street art is left .... The area is fantastic and just a short metro ride from anywhere with a walk up the steps (a lot of steps) to the Cathedral of Sacré-Coeur for a panoramic view of the city. The art area has been relegated to caricatures mostly but some of the shops remain - try a bit harder to find them. There is a funicular if you so desire to avoid the steps but the walk to the Cathedral has sufficient seating along the way and the reward of the view is your prize.

The best way to get a feel of Parisian Life. Absolutely Beautiful.Well worth the Everest style climb up the steps (There is a cable car for the less energetic)The village square is vibrant with Artists selling there wares and willing to sketch you portrait for 60 Euros, The bars are a beautiful way to soak up the atmosphere and listen to a crazy accordion player who hops from bar to bar

Walking Tour. We walked in the streets of Montmartre with a local tour guide. I forgot his name.. Its a free walking tour and you just need to tip the guide at the end of the walk. We got the flyer from the hotel we stayed in and happy that we did because our guide was very knowledgable and shared great insights about Montmartre's past and how that influenced the area's present vibe. Coincidently, my husband and I saw the actual painting of Renoir in Munich's Neue Pinakothek and when we had this walking tour, our guide showed where that painting was done! Knowing where the inspiration was drawn from and seeing the painting is a incredible learning experience. :)

Need to clean up streets !. We have visited the Montmarte several times & have always enjoyed the atmosphere. This time though it seemed to have lost its charm . There were lots of street sellers with tacky souvenirs. The worst thing was the litter everywhere piled up next to overflowing bins & rubbish thrown down on the pavements. I won't be rushing back there or to anywhere in Paris for a while.

The artist corner. I love this area of Paris, it reminds of me of how simple life used to be before it got complicated with technology and many other things. Here in Montemarte, you see artists try to make a living by painting their surroundings and, often, tourists. Walking around here has a different feel to the rest of Paris and I love it! Make sure you come on a good sunny day where you can relax and enjoy the area. Have a cup of coffee while you people watch, I recommend it!

Lazy day in Paris. We'd had a hard week in Paris. And so our last day we decided to visit Monmarte and take it easy. The sun was shining, it was a pleasure to walk in the narrow streets browsing in the shops, lots of choices for a lunch.

Wander the streets and visit Sacre C'ouer. There are few better experiences, or more Parisian ones, than wandering the streets around Montmartre. Scare-Coeur is of course a highlight, but the streets around it and below it are full of really interesting cafes, nooks and crannies. Avoid the tourist traps full of over priced tourist schmalz - and the rip off sketch and silhouette artists who will overcharge for very ordinary imagery. But sitting at an outdoor table in the afternoon as the shadows lengthen and drinking a coffee or a beer is one of the great Parisian experiences.

You have to see it!. Excellent place to walk around in.The architecture is beautiful.The Le Tire Bouchon is one of the best crepe houses I have ever been too. Phenomenal crepes with rich tradition. You have to see it to know what I am talking about.The view from the front of the cathedral where you are overlooking Paris is simply amazing too. On a nice night you will not be disappointed.Much love,Navid & Zeena
It is an amazing place to go for a walk! . You can start around Moulin Rouge and end next to Basilica Sacre Coeur! Great streets with a lot of beauty and history, cafes and markets.

Artist’s enclave with its charming and village like atmosphere. Montmarte is the most romantic neighborhood of Paris and the district earned its name after its 130m high hill. Painters and poets such as Salvador Dalí, Amedeo Modigliani, Claude Monet, Pablo Picasso, Vincent van Gogh used to live here.The area is best known for Sacré Coeur Basilica (Sacred Heart) and Moulin Rouge. Rather than having lots of things to see, it offers a charming area to take a stroll. Staircase streets, quaint windmills, and sweeping views characterize the area. Wander around on the narrow, hilly streets of Montmartre. Fall in love with streets like rue des Abbesses, rue des Trois Freres, and rue des Martyres.Find the windmills on rue Lepic and the famous Moulin Rouge near Blanche metro station.Stop at a patisserie for a freshly baked chocolate croissant, a taste of creamy brie or sharp bleu at one of the many fromageries, a succulent orange you'd swear was fresh from the orchard. Then relax in a 'petit café' to enjoy a café au lait while watching people.Beware of the false portrait 'artists' on Place du Tertre. Some will quote a low price, and after producing something that does not look remotely like you demand a far higher price. It is recommended to watch them first before choosing one. Beware of pickpockets.An officially designated historic district, Montmartre is one of the most colorful neighborhoods in Paris so it's no surprise that this area is a favorite among tourists.Subway: Abbesses (M12) & Anvers (M2)

Really Lovely Area. It was very hot when we visited this area and there were a lot of people, but you must see the view from here it's great. There are some really lovely restaurants off the square that were surprisingly in expensive, a pleasant surprise. A very pretty place.

An artistic and quirky region of Paris. Northern paris is the most quirkiest and artistic, This region offers delights from the sacre coure church to the moulin rouge. Be sure to explore all passages to find individual boutiques and some lovely art work.

Can you say "Nightclub District"!. This area is famous for its cafés, and cabarets. The "Chat Noir" founded in 1881 was very popular with writers and artists. The " Moulin Rouge, founded in 1889, is famous for inventing the "CanCan". The Montmartre district was also featured in many movies: American in Paris( Gene Kelly and Leslie Caron), Amelie, Moulin Rouge, and Ronin. Artists who considered this area home for a while: Picasso, Matisse, Degas, Latreuc, Vincent Van Gogh, etc.

One of most lively and authentic local experience in Paris. Heard and read a lot about this area and I would fully agree that this is a must visit area of Paris. Lots of restaurants, though not as good as and higher priced than saint Germaine area but it's cobbled Narrow streets, hilly terrain and artistic little buildings add a unique character to this place.... Good view of Paris from the top and very local feel in the streets below the hill around Sacre-couer.
Oh La Laa. Amazing place! i was like in a fairytale ^_^ Painters, artists and a lot of interesting people are collecting here, you feel positive and joy.For me it's one of the best places in Paris !

Great neighborhood. I personally love Montmartre. I think it's a really unique neighborhood with a different character from the rest of Paris, I think. The views from the top of the hill by Sacre Coeur are great as is the actual basilica itself. The square with all the artists is really cool but be aware that you will constantly be asked if they can paint/draw/etc you. Lots of cute little restaurants and cafés. The street that the Moulin Rouge is on is always fun to walk down but may not be the place for younger children who like to ask questions as there are tons of sex shops. There are three metro stops on that street though. It's definitely worth walking around during a visit to Paris. I've always been urged to watch out for pickpockets especially in this neighborhood. I've never seen anything or experienced it but it's definitely something to be cautious of nonetheless.

TAKE YOUR TIME AND TAKE IN THE ATMOSPHERE! WONDERFUL!. Montmartre itself is a wonderful place to visit. The artists are scattered around and some are excellent! The caricature drawings are fantastic to watch coming to life and so quickly. There are some fantastic paintings to purchase. If you can, walk to the top with the Basilica is and the view over Paris is amazing. Paris is such a wonderful city, with so many places to visit- do plan ahead. There are shops and stalls around also. Do be mindful of your purse/wallet, as with any place (home and abroad!). Enjoy the atmosphere - it is a truly wonderful place to experience.

lovely for a warm early evening stroll. Delightful location. Loved the evening stroll up the local street, enjoyed roasted chestnuts on the corner......architecture, ambience, crowd.....everything makes for a superb experience.

Too Touristy but still a must visit. I have been here four times now and always feel this needs less tourist traps. You have to visit Sacré Coeur around the corner, which is fabulous, so you will visit here but I found it full of trinket shops, OK restaurants and crowds.Avoid the street artists - I have been caught once and it cost a lot for a portrait of my wife that was unrecognisable.Look for the side streets with views - there are some great ones, find the quiet gardens/vineyards and walk around the basilica and then down the stairs to the various terraces (or take the Fernicular) for a great morning or afternoon.

a nice place to see. it is easy to access to it from Station Abbesses, go towards the funicular to go up there, now if you are an athlete and you do not care about going 220 step staircase, which will save you 3.4 Euros (round trip) and loss weight....reaching up breathless..so, it is a very nice area very crowded so you have to be careful, lots and lots of artists that will approach you to sketch you for 50 Euros +/-, and they are very good in their work. walk around enjoy the scenery over looking the beautiful Paris, then setting in the café sipping coffee (in a reasonable price) and watching people getting drawn by artists.

Artists quarter. One of the most romantic places in Paris where the artists and other easy living people are gathering. Here you can feel the positive and relaxing atmosphere as a real contrast to the other touristy Paris attractions.
Paris at its finest. My wife and I visited the Montmarte on our anniversary and it did not disappoint. We are already looking forward to going back.

A little of old Paris. We were urged by our friends to visit the Basilica de Sacrere on top of the hill at Montmare,and we found the walk up to the basilica very charming for the streets were lined with little shops and there were beautiful houses along the way. It had a village atmosphere and Paris must have been like that in the olden days.In the square there were lots of cafes and artists around it, painting and selling; giving the whole place an atmosphere of what Paris must have been - the ultimate destination for budding artists!  On top of Montmartre we got an overview of the city. It was a bonus for us to experience a farmers' market just next to the basilica. The farmers from the province of Perigon came to display and sell their specialities like jam, fruits, rose oil, escargot, wine, foie gras etc.We had a lovely day at Montmarte.
easy day. stroll around, buy a little art; grab a baguette, cheese, and wine, sit in the park below Sacre Coeur and have lunch.
AWESOME!!. One of the best landscape I've never seen in my life, surrounded by artists and nice cafè and restaurant. Definetely worth it!

So romantic. Paris is such a beautiful city and so much so see. Our first day was the Sacra Coeur Church then at the top of the church (looking at the church )turn left down the wee streets into the Montmartre. This place has lots of restaurants and in the middle of the square you will find lots of painter and artists,an amazing atmosphere, lots of music and just a great French buzz about the place. Food is varied but try the mussels they are great and not too expensive

Not bad for a first timer!. We walked all the way from Moulin Rouge up to Sacre-Coeur. It was raining so we didn't really enjoy it that much. However, I think this is definitely a must visit place if you are in Paris for the first time. I might return here for my next visit if the weather is nicer. Please see my photos and vote for me if you find this review helpful. Thank you!

Quintessentially Parisienne. Whilst I didn't encounter the plethora of artists for which this area is famous; I still thoroughly enjoyed the beautiful streets surrounding the Sacre Coeur. Visiting Paris, is about balancing so many wonderful options of how to spend your time against the time you have available. I believe that a visit to Sacre Coeur is well worth a visit, even if you can only spare a short amount of time, do use it to meander around the nearby streets.

Beautiful view over Paris. It is difficult to say whether it is a good idea or not to visit Montmartre. Sacre Coeur itself a landmark church, but nothing special. Montmartre is overcrowded, some 35 years ago it was very nice to walk around Place duTertre, but not anymore. The little cafes are also full, it is hard to move at all.The Montmartre Museum and the Dali Museum are worth to visit, both are really very nice.

Handicap Visit. Took a Taxi to the restaurant area behind Sacre-Coeur as my wife was in a wheel chair. From there we could brouse the vendors, dine, and even use the back handicap entrance to the church. The incline down to the park below the church was manageable, and we went there later to view the Eiffel Tower. We waited until dark to see her lighted up. Wonderful.

Gently breezing. Have some fine wine at one of food tent, take a look on portraits, antique books, vinyl and take a stroll down to van gogh 's house - By the way there is great hand made perfume shop below the hill

Too "Touristy" for my Taste. I visited Montmartre 15 years ago and loved the 'artsiness' of the area with painters creating on the square, outdoor cafes to watch them work and enjoy the fresh air. This visit left me feeling sad as the climb up from the metro had souvenir shop after souvenir shop and litter all over the ground. The artists also lacked variety choosing instead to do chalk portraits of the tourists. For me, the old charm was missing.

Be careful. Montmarte is a wonderful and exciting place to visit. Lots of rtist in the street doing portraits. Museums like the Dali are there. Nice food places. Even a new Starbucks.Very crowed with people brushing by one another.There are many gypsy's working the crow. They set up 3 card Monte games to draw in the crowd. I had my IPAD pickpocked there. It happened in a second. The police were helpful but there was nothing they could do. If you go there be very careful.

Finest panorama of Paris. The church and the panoramic view of Paris from the top is a treat for the eyes ! Loved the holy prayers on Saturday evening. The view of the eifel tower and the street performers in action made it a very nice place to relax

The famous Monmartre actually is dissapointment. During my entire stay in Paris probably this was the place where I was really disappointed. I liked the church of Sacre-Coeur but the famous place of the painters is gone. There is plenty of little "art" shops, cafes and restaurants but the atmosphere isn't real. Actually I didn't find it charming. Although if you are in Paris you should take a look.

Magical place!. It had been a while since my last visit but the area has not lost any of its magic. We visited a couple of times, the best was the day we left Paris when we went first thing in the morning and had breakfast on the square. Very special, very few people around which provided for enjoyable chats with the artists.

Historic Paris. A trip to Paris can not be complete without visiting Montmartre which was the heart of art and culture in the city. You will come across the house of Van Gogh, Picasso and many others. There's a little cabaret which Picasso used to visit often, and it is just overwhelming to be able to see that history right in front of you. However, having said that, it is an area where a walking tour is highly recommended since most of these historical treasures are hard to come by for a tourist on his own. We did the walking tour with Sandemans and absolutely loved it. Our guide was On no, and he made sure we got the best from the area!

A "Must See" While in Paris!. It was wonderful wandering through the old streets, imagining some of the Impressionists painters walking the same streets 100 years ago! Great little shops and great places to stop for a bite to eat. Seeing the artists in the square painting was a special treat.

A stroll back in time. The home to some of my favorite artists. Enjoy walking the streets, eating in the cafes and watching the artist in the streets. Just watch out for the pick pocketing since it can get crowded with tourists. We found it more peaceful to stroll around the less populated areas.

Amazing place. When i came out of metro the place wasn't as good as i expected. I walked up the small street with the gift shops and i saw that beautiful place i remember from the movie "Amelie". Too many people,too many tourists but just a beautiful and romantic place. I enjoyed every single moment there. I will visit it soon again.

Montmartre - Hill of Martyrs. Montmartre has attracted artists since the 19th century and has become a tourist attraction due to the now famous artists such as Picasso, Dali, and Modigliani, who lived there and produced some of their famous works of art. Today, you'll find portrait artists plying their art to tourists, but it's an interesting area of Paris to explore and think about the famous artists who once live there.
Beautiful district. Great to just walk around in, and take in Paris at your own pace... and the jewel in the crown is the view from the Sacre Coeur church.

Great place to watch other tourists but beware...... This used to be May favourite part of Paris. The views of the city are great from here and it's a wonderful photo opportunity and because of this the crowds are phenomenal. The main square is also crowded and has lots do restaurants and is a great place to stop and have some great food and watch the world go by although all you are looking at it other tourist doing much the same. The main problem here was the numbers of pickpockets and beggars of which Paris seems to have more that any other city I have visited. Keep your wits about you ( and your hand on your bag or wallet) at all times and be especially careful exiting the Metro in this area; there are men waiting at the bottom of the stairs indicating to others at the top who is worth picking.
Arts paradise. The most famous place in all Paris. The symbol of Golden Epoche. Symbol of freedom, youth and eternal love to that place.

Must visit place. Magic, unforgettable place. When you visit Paris, don't skip it. Your priorities should be : Versailles, Louvre, D'Orsey, Eiffel Tower, Latin Quarter, Monmartre, Notre-Damm, Les Invalides, Pantheon, Pere Lachaise cemetery. If you've seen these places, you've seen Paris.
Worthwhile, if only for the view. Spent the day in the area of Montmartre and even if rather grotty and touristy it is worthwhile walking the backstreets. The view of course cannot beat.

A must see area in Paris. You MUST visit Montmartre and the Sacré-Cœur Basilica. This area is different! You feel as if you are roaming around on some movie set! With beautiful Cafes, Artistes sketching, various shops and the hustle bustle of a village ... you really feel a serenity and calm all around. The Basilica in itself is very imposing but with a refreshing and relaxing aura that you can carry for the entire day! This I am talking about the daytime, but its seems to be more famous in the nighttime due to the Moulin Rouge, which we didn't stay to enjoy.

Beautiful Church. Great views. Good food. The Sacre Coeur is grandiose. The views are terrific. Walking around the rear of the church into the artist area is an experience not to be missed and the food ranges from inexpensive to fine dining.
Nice. Well worth a visit here , a very vibrant place much to see and do, keep your bags under raps though, be mindful

very different atmospheres within a small space.. We got off the metro at Anvers, and were immediately struck at the difference in this area with the other tourist areas we had been in. It was not a very clean area, and we actually saw mice outside the restaurants and bakeries while we made our way up to the Sacre Couer. Unauthorised street traders were plentiful, and ladies were harassing tourists for signatures and money. My son and I sat on the wall below the church and observed gangs of 3 or 4 working together picking pockets. These people are easy to spot as they have no bags or cameras with them! At the side steps of the church a street band of 3 men called prestige were performing and had drawn quite a crowd as they were very good. However, we took the side streets to the side of the main streets back down Rue Lebec and came to the main streets full of lovely little shops, where we stopped near the Abbesses metro stop for a café. Proceeding down towards Pigalle to take the metro, we were struck by the contrast and the more liberal atmosphere.

Montmartre District. You MUST Tour the Montmartre District, preferably on a Guided Tour! It is the Nightclub/Entertainment/Music District. If you miss it then you missed the Soul of Paris1Go the Moulin Rouge show after your Tour which is in the heart of the Montmartre District.Moulin Rouge is famous, tourist attraction but worth it!! Give the Maitre De ( The guy who seats you in the Crowd) $10 or so and he will " find " you the best available seat when you arrive- it is worth it! You are already spending a couple hundred bucks so you might as well get a decent seat!
Entertaining . This area is quite entertaining with a lot of artists and musicians, many cafes and restaurants. We enjoyed spending the day there, be aware of pickpocketing in large crowds.
Montmartre. We went trough the park which was really nice. We went on an Sunday during religious services. Nice to see this. To bad it was raining.Fantastic view of Paris from here.

Parisian style Area. This area seems to be the more typical Parisian living. It certainly still caters for the tourist, but it's had a less of an influence here. Worth a visit and a walk around to enjoy the area, not top of my list to do but something I'm certainly glad I did. We visited the Moulin Rouge and then walked to the Sacre Coeur from here. Afterwards we then meandered back into central Paris.

You should be here. It is reall romantic place opening wide and beautiful vision to Paris.Like: atmosphereDislike: there was group of guys (7-8 people) who was trying to conflict with people. I detected that they are local white guys having "business" on that. Our group was for 20 people and we make them to shutup and stay away from us. Probably there are no such are guys there. It was 2001

Cute neighborhood. It is a charming area to walk around and people watch. We went there after visiting the Sacre Couer. There seems to be more tourist shops than I like, but still a fun place to visit. We found a wonderful chocolate store that our children loved.

Foodie must see and cheap souvrnirs. A walk through Montmartre is a must do if you like seeing fresh produce, charcuterie, boulangerie & fromagerie close by lots of reasonably priced bistros & cafes. Lots of cheap souvenir shops if you are in a hurry too. The Place du Tertre is worth a look. Lots of lovely local art but very crowded even on a rainy day. The piece de resistance is of course the beautiful basiluca of Sacre Coeur. (Time your visit there for a church service if you can. There are few things so moving than French nuns singing the adoration. )

Must see in Paris!. This is a day trip not be missed. It is easily reached on the metro, and it is an arty trendy section of Paris. Lots of interesting shops and neat places to eat. The Basilica on the hill has awesome views and shows the suburbia side of Paris that you don't often see.

Typically french. Montmartre is probably the area that makes me think of the best typical French/ Parisian area. If you imagined Paris like a city full of artists, painters, small/old streets and shops, little restaurants... then Montmartre is the closest remaining of that old image of Paris some can have.

Downhill. Have been to Monmartre many times before and always enjoyed the atmosphere. As it was within easy walking distance we went up the hill. Disappointed it has really got far seedier. It is packed dirty and a rip off. Doubt that we will be back. A shame.

Our Best Night in Paris - Montmartre se Magnifique!. We saved a walk through Montmartre for a rainy Friday night on 1 May. Night rain was an answer to our prayers because photos are enhanced by the reflection of lights on the wet pavement. This neighborhood exudes a charm like no other in Paris. From the Anvers Metro Stop we walked uphill and took in the bazaar like atmosphere of Rue De Steinkerque leading to the steps of Sacre Coeur and its great vistas of Paris, especially from the dome of the Sacre Coeur Bacilica, free admittance, dome 6 euros, open to 10:30 pm every day. There’s spectacular iconography over the altar. More bustling nightlife, shops and cafes are along the narrow Rue du Mont Cenis and photogenic Place du Tertre where artists sketch or paint tourist’s portraits. Be sure to look back at the illuminated spires of Sacre Coeur rising dramatically above the narrow street. After an Amorino Gelato break we strolled downhill a block along Rue Norvins to photograph the picturesque intersection in front of the Le Consulat Restaurant. A few blocks further down on Rue Lepic we had a surprisingly fine dinner at Autour du Moulin, then off to photograph the Moulin Rouge with reflections on the rain soaked pavement gracing its feet.
Nice walk. After you are done with visiting the sacre ceour, you can have a walk around Montmartre. It is an old place with nice cafes. Beware of the pickpockets and thieves.

So Parisian.... This is the quintessential Paris, in my opinion. Tons of outdoor cafes, great houses on the streets, beautiful view from the church, and the artists square all make for a great afternoon.

Loved It!. Montmartre is not at the center of Paris and those who come to see the Eiffel Tower, Louvre or Arc de Triomphhe most likely will think about staying closer to those attractions. However, the costs involved in staying so close to those attractions will seriously impact the budget of the traveler in ways that can be avoided.We rented an apartment for several days in Montmartre and were thrilled with the result. Paris's fantastic Metro system whisked us anywhere in Paris we wanted to go and cost next to nothing in doing it. Thus, staying in Montmartre meant we spent far less on lodging or on food than we would have had we stayed in the city center, yet we quickly accessed everything in Paris whenever we wished.And the Montmartre area itself is a great place to be. It is NOT bustling with tourists (well, not as badly as it could be) and it offers the real feel of living in Paris and experiencing true French culture.Were we to return to Paris, we would happily stay here again!

Well worth your time to visit.... Beautiful views of Paris from Montmartre. Any time of day/night is good to go, but sunset is particularly gorgeous. It gets crowded on the steps just at (and below) the cathedral, so make sure to get there slightly early. The "square" area with all the artists is somewhat cliche, crowded and aggravating with people peddling their wares and services, but step away from that and go down to the little park just to the side of the cathedral, or some of the side streets behind and to the side of the cathedral and you'll be remarkably more secluded and able to take it all in. Be sure to also visit Dalida's grave/memorial if you are at all interested in the legendary singer. Of course, the cathedral is stunning and a must-see. I don't use the word "charming" very often, but this little area of Paris is definitely that. Loved it.
Third Time. Been there for the third time, but finally got a amazing weather so, it made this one different. Amazing city, look forward to come back
a fun neighborhood. It's worth going to this neighborhood and walking up to the church. It is very busy with tourists and artists, and we were warned of pickpockets, but it is mostly charming.

Beautiful & charming area with Sacre Cour Cathedral. Quaint, charming, very Parisian! Food, wine, lots of small shops & the Cathedral is beautiful. Lovely view from there. Cog lift from ground level to Cathedral! Really enjoyed this area & took a train/trolley ride from there down to Moulin Rouge & back. Train was very inexpensive & you could hop on & off wherever you liked! Good narrative of the area on the train!

Great sights, shops and life in Paris.. We walked Montmartre using a booked called "Paris History and Mystery" by Oriel and Peter CAINE.Taking our time we walked all through Montmartre and thoroughly enjoyed the half day it took us.Plenty to see and do. Great choice of meals and snacks. A bit of shopping and it led us back to our apartment near the Moulin Rouge. We then spent a few hours in the afternoon at the Montmartre cemetery before back home for the evening.

Great Place of Street Artists. Me and my wife wend to see Sacre-Coer and then we had a round in Montmartre. First we walked and then we took a trackless train ride. Both were fantastic. We saw lot many street with great character. Beautiful Houses with creepers and flowery plants. Then we went to a public plaza. which was full of street singers, painters artists and lot of food around. Few artists offered to make a sketch of my wife but we were in hurry. We bought few postcards from a shop a souvenir to friends in India. It was fun seeing Montmartre.

Lovely part of Paris. Lots of lovely shops and restaurants. Lots to do and see. Easy walk to Sacre Couer and Place du Tertre. It is very hilly so bear this in mind. Metro staion close by at Pigalle or Abbesses.

Interesting part of Paris. Montmarte is located on a 425 feet limestone hill. All else around it is very flat. The highest part of the hill is where you can easily find Sacre-Couer, the basilica of the Sacred Heart. The area around and below the basilica is full of shopping, eating places and local artists and musicians. The Moulin Rouge is nearby. At times it is very full of people--beware of pickpockets!!

Great to amble and take in the views. This is one of my favourite areas of Paris.It's a great place on a sunny afternoon to walk around the streets with its bars and bistros and curio shops. There are great photo opportunities and you can rest your legs from the incline in the little squares and watch the children play by the fountains.Yes it can be quite touristy by the sacre coeur, but it's worth stopping for the views and then escaping to the quieter side streets to take more photos

Great for what it is. Loved it, but depends what you want. For a short break, as a couple, it was great. There's a bit of nightlife, famous for Moulin Rouge. By day it is great to stroll among the souvenir shops, boulangeries, pattisseries, creperies and similar watering holes. Coffees and beers aplenty. Some quirky shops for browsing. Sacre Coeur was impressive, the artists' quarter somewhat disappointing but still worth the visit. And that's about it.

My Favorite Area in Paris. At first we meant to come here for food only as we were very hungry after visiting La Basillique du Sacre Coeur and Musee de Montmartre. Once we settled down in an outdoor restaurant, we realised that we were in the artist village, a very interesting and vibrant area. There were many artists stalls selling their works and also artists doing live skectching. I am so happy that we came here empty handed and with empty stomach, but ended up leaving with beautiful paintings and lots of fun-filled memories. As one may think, this is a very touristy place but to me as a tourist, I love it!

Great village overlooking Paris. As part of a tour group, We rode a small wheeled train up to the village to see the church and village. There are many small shops and nice local restaurants. We had very nice meal outside. Make sure you bring plenty of euro as backup to your credit card as there machines broke down during our Resturant visit, we were glad a friend had extra cash. People are friendly but like everywhere take extra caution with valuables.
Great views and atmosphere. This was great little market with local people and artfefacts, painting etc. Definitely worth the trip!

Excellent . Lovely place to visit while in Paris. Sure, it's mobbed with tourists but at the same time, it's different from the rest of paris. Go to Sacre Cour and sit on the steps, what a view of Paris you will have. Enjoy!

Unparalleled view of Paris. We were able to take a tram to Sacre Coeur - the cathedral is stunning and the view of the city from this area above Paris is fantastic. The area is very touristy, but also a great place to watch artists sketch and sell their pieces. It can be a bit crowded but the history and the atmosphere is worth the visit
The Best souvenir of Paris. Really nice place to visit. In every corner you have good stores to buy souvenirs. It's a little tiring go up to the Sacre Coeur, but worth it.

Neat place with great views of Paris. Way too crowded on a Saturday though.. We took the Metro from our hotel to the station near the funicular and then walked up from there. Sacre Couer is a beautiful cathedral and the views of the city from the front of the cathedral are very good. The artists on Place Tetre are nice but the crowds were so thick you could hardly move. We walked down by Moulin Galette to Moulin Rouge. This is a nice walk with some interesting architecture along the way. Worth a trip if you are in Paris for a few days.
very good. very nice place, artistic, with lovely view, smiling people (tourists), nice for walk, very romantic and of course rude workers.

Nice view of the city, must see!. Really nice view of the city. I suggest taking the stairs instead of the shuttle, so you can appreciate the view ever more when you arrive on top! Lay down on the grass, have a drink, walk the neighborhood, etc.

Great but cautious visit!. Its a stunning view from the top but its spoilt by men selling cheap rubbish & hassling you. On our way up there were 6 black men 3 each side trying to get you to have some string which i expect they wanted money for, they are too touchy & pushy but we just walked on and ignored them.Like other comments there was a lot of rubbish where people are sitting on the grass drinking & chilling out. Also there are men selling beer for €3 a bottle but you can haggle.Would i visit again...... No

Like a dream sequence. I picked up Montmartre simply because I wanted to go to the Dali Museum. What I did not realize is that it would transport me to a place that you see only in movies! A bustling street with various artists thronging the place. Small shops with colorful items, outdoor cafes, pizza places, and a high energy, happy vibe all around. Please check more pictures to understand what I mean. My sister got her caricature done from a 'real' Parisian artist and I tried out the Silhouette. Both turned out fantastic. One tip: Even though the artists charge 20 euros for any such sitting, we asked if they would do it for 10, and both of them agreed! I think basically they do it for the love of the art - not so much as a business. There was an artist selling the cylindrical tube in which we carried the rolled art work (3 euros). You get them for 2 in the nearby shops but they are not half as pretty. Or artistic. Our artist/seller even painted my sister's name on the tube. The information center is right around the corner and you will get a small map with the major tourist spots. Do check out the Dali museum, the Windmills of Montmartre, the vineyards, Le Lapin Agile - all in and around the area. Even the walk itself in the cobbled streets is an experience. Must, must visit.

Sandemans Montmartre walking tour. Esteban was a wonderful guide, with a great range Of knowledge of Parisian history and culture. He started at 6pm at La Moulin Rouge and we steadily walked around the cobbled streets of Montmartre hearing the sad tales of the talented artists who lived their during the impressionist era, and of others since then. The tour culminated at Sacre Couer Cathedral where you have the option to participate in a self guided tour within. A wonderful view of Paris is available from here. This tour should not be missed as tells you a different side of the culture and history compared to the glamour of central Paris.

Disappointing Cathedral but great view. Could not get up to the town due to the artists lining the street wanting your business. Cannot stand this. Montmarte itself was disappointing inside and a little grubby an the exterior. The views of Paris from there were however spectacular. Again the beggars as we came out of the Cathedral were a little confronting as they were old women. We did not experience the scammers here. I woudl recommend the Funicular ride up the hill.

The bohemian Paris that should be on the top 10 and is not.. Montmartre should be right up the top ten of Paris but somehow they have let it slip down the scale. The painters square is a must to visit just looking at the guys working and exhibiting great work is worth the trip. Could one afford one, maybe you're facing the next Monet, Picasso, Van Gogh. There is seriously good art in this little square. Then the cafes and bars, slightly over priced and cramped with people may add some to the bohemian factor. The let down are the pick pocketers and the conmen that almost force you into buying things you did not request or wanted. They stopped you, so eager to get money out of you, that it is invasive and rude behaviour. Be firm when you say NO, once you pass them you may enjoy your time puddling around the square. Hopefully some parisians will read this and understand that if you let people freely move around and approach you they will be more likely to strike a deal.

Loved this area because of the art history. This would be my area of choice to live in if I lived in Paris. We took a tour and loved the history and stories about the red light district, Van Gogh, Picasso and Modigliani, to just name a few. Really pretty area as you go up the hill. I would consider staying here in this area the next time I visit Paris. Also, looks as if there are also lots of restaurants (the one from Amelie is here) and things to see and do, like the locals.

Breathtaking. This is definitely my favorite part of Paris. It's such a cute little area with beautiful streets, tons of cute shops, outdoor markets and great food. When you're here you simply must take the stairs all the way to the top and look out at the city of Paris from the steps out front the Sacree Coeur. You'll fall in love and it won't be a moment you'll ever forget. The park beneath the church is gorgeous and great for sitting around taking pictures. After that just wander around and visit all of the great little custom shops that are great for jams, artisanal goods and souvenirs of course. Be careful of the somewhat aggressive group of men in the park that offer you "free" bracelets. They can be rather touchy. Other than that, the memory of Montmarte is one I'll hold close to my heart forever!

Beautiful basilica over looking the city. Had the Paris pass which gave us access to the Petite train that departs right in front of the Molin Rogue and takes you up to the top with ease, going down was bumpy ride but well worth the visit to the some what crowded and touristy artist colony.

Our New Backyard - Love This Area!. Montmartre, famous for the Sacre Coeur, home to artists such as Dali, Van Gogh and Degas, this place of Paris history is also our home for the next three months.Being unaquainted with the Parisian arrondissements, the idea of the Artists area, set a little from the busy centre of Paris was appealing, I couldn’t imagine being anywhere else. What ever you want, its around the corner, and if you can’t find it you probably don’t need it.Our discovery begins first with the famous white monument standing proudly as a bastion of French religious and political history - although a famous and auspicious temple inside, the real monument is the view from the steps looking out at the parisian expanse Beer is for sale on the steps of a church with a serenade by local musicians and a mixture of cultures, colours and creed, this place is truly one for worship. The local streets are lined with traditional parisian fare. Boulangeries produce the best bread we’ve ever eaten and the smell of fresh chickens cooking fills the air. We indulge in traditional parisian pastimes enjoying a coffee and croissant watching the passers by. The fish monger makes no apologies for selling out of todays catch, and the Rue Du Abessess bustles with both locals and tourists alike. Our favourite meal has been from a little known Bistrot Poulbot, nestled in a side street far from the rabble of the busy sights. An entirely french menu tests our wit. For the full details of our meal you can visit our trip advisor review!! But with starters such as traditional ouef cocotte (egg in a jar) and ouef de pain we were excited to see the modern variations o these classics and were not disappointed!And while this indulgence might lend one to think about the waist line, and consider the need for restraint, the hills and steps of Montmartre ensure there’s always an appetite and happy bums all round.

Beautiful day spent walking around . After walking through the Pigalle area, we went to montmartre and walked up the hill to Sacre Coeur. (lots of stairs!) There is a ride that takes you up though. It's a beautiful view of Paris from the hill. I enjoyed the outside more than going in but maybe that's just me. We walked around the area for a little more while, saw a long list of artists drawing people, a bit expensive but nice. Lastly, we visited a wall that's got the words 'I love you' written on it in many languages. Nice spot for a photo. Overall, I loved being here.

Lovely away from the crowded areas. Walking up via the side of the Sacré Cœur (rather than the front) allows you to avoid a lot of the stairs. There's a great view across Paris from the front of the Sacre Coeur which is really worth seeing.The main crowds are immediately around the basilica and the Place du Tertre, it's only a short walk behind or to the side of the basilica to find more peaceful areas. Interesting to see some other windmills closer to the top, also the lovely vineyard opposite Lapin Agile.We didn't have any problems with "string people" when we visited, which was midmorning on a Monday.

Montmartre, try not to skip this place. Taking a metro to Montmarte was easy, but I did not know that we have to climb up so many stairs to go out from the metro. Take the lift if you go with friends (it's a bit scary if you are alone). I climbed up the stairs and had to catch my breath several times.When we were out, we looked for a cafe to have breakfast. Then we took a walk to the church and to the place where the painters gathered. I always love seeing artists at work and I enjoyed getting a small painting from the artist himself.Montmarte is still a must visit when I'm in Paris.

Cobblestone streets and quaint buildings. If I had to choose my favorite spot in Paris, it would be Montmartre in the evening. This is where a lot of the famous artists like Dali and Van Gogh spent at least a few of their years painting. It's easy to see where the inspiration came from.Although many of the buildings have been turned into souvenir shops, the cobblestone streets, outdoor eating in the square, ample supply of portrait artists, and fantastic views make this spot one that I wished I could stay far longer. Set high on a butte adjacent to Sacre Coeur, it's a place you must must must go.

Lovely setting, too busy, stroll around in quiet streets to feel Montmartre. Very lovely square, however far too busy to really get the feeling of the coziness of Montmartre. A couple of streets are quiet and make a nice stroll around Montmartre
Nice visit!. We had fun walking around in a beautiful sunny day!lots of tourists!!! be aware of the pickpockets!!!! Plenty of them!!worth the visit on the SAcre coeur catedral

Bohemian vibe!. We stayed here during our visit to Paris. It was a good choice for us, since we travveled with a very small budjet. Definetly recomend the following: the Montmarte hill and it's breath taking views and church, the early morning markets!

Fun area to explore and dine. Had fun roaming the hill top area of Montmartre. Lots to see and do here with plenty of artisan shops, restaurants, cafes, and historical sights. Loved walking thru the windy cobble stoned roads to see one postcard view after another. Highly recommend this area as a diversion from the more central sights.

Fun Trek. Montmarte is a must see if you are in Paris. There is quite a walk up a long flight of stairs but once you get to the top, you find a little artists' village. There are lots of shop and restaurants. Mostly, there are artists painting, sketching, drawing, and selling their works. Charming! Beautiful artwork.  Beware the con artists, though. There are lots of groups of pickpockets who work together to steal from tourists. There are also a lot of pushy strolling artists who are happy to stop you in your tracks and start sketching your portrait. This sounds fun but at the end of the sketch, they roll up your portrait and demand $20-30. You did not ask to be sketched and were not particularly interested in buying this quick scribble. These "artists" can often be rude if you refuse to purchase. We were called &#*! Americans when we did not purchase.Do not let these warnings scare you off. You must see Montmarte. Just be wise and enjoy yourself.

Montmartre Evening Tour. We participated in Sandeman's Montmartre 2.5-hour evening tour on the day of our arrival in Paris from California. Roberta was our independent tour guide. She conveyed her deep passion and love for art and history in a compelling, evocative and often-times humorous narrative as we made our way through the streets and back alleys of Montmartre. It was a great way to start our vacation.

Worth visiting. Lots of shopping and food spots located near the Sacre Coeur. We took the little train through the city, up the hill, and along very narrow streets. It was super crowed but very active and enjoyable. The view from the top of the hill was awesome.

Must visit!. Thanks to "Airbnb" we were able to enjoy some days in the heart of Montmartre with the feeling of living here. Not only is it located perfectly to all sights you have to visit in Paris but itself has so much to offer. Romantic restaurants, Sacre Coeur, Moulin Rouge, etc .. This place is perfect!!

The view .... Is pretty much all I have to recommend- the neighborhood is otherwise a little seedy- profusely smells like urine and can be a little dangerous at night especially for the lone female traveller.

The best area of Paris. In my opinion, this is the best area of Paris. It is very relaxing, artistic and friendly. You have to visit one of the best churches- Sacre Coeur and enjoy in a beautiful and free view over the city. Than, you can walk down the narrow streets and see (or buy) paintings on main square. Usually, you can hear some musicians playing Parisian songs. And, at the end, sit in a restaurant and enjoy in their cheeses and wine.

Beautiful cobbled square full of artists painting and cafés. I loved this cobbled street/square area with all the artists painting and the cafes. Lots of narrow streets to explore or just sit and watch the world go buy in one of the cafés. The artists were also offering to paint or draw your portrait and quite a few people were having this done. It did get busy so perhaps go early in the morning as we did and combine it with a visit to the Sacre Coeur. I did see a small train/car going round if walking is a problem. We were dropped off by the coach at the bottom and had to walk up LOTS of steps to the Sacre Coeur and then round the back to the artists square.
French ambiance. My favourite part of Paris. So far. It has a very nice atmosphere with nice shops and plenty of cafes and restaurants.

So Quaint, and beautiful. We decided to head up to Montmartre on a whim, and we're glad we did. We were able to ride the furnicular, see the Basillica, and walk around Montmartre & back down to Moulin Rouge. We bought some art in this little square when dozens of artists were at their easels painting, drawing, and creating. It was beautiful.
Like in French movies. Loved this area for the gorgeous city view and the atmosphere - so truly French! Musicians and painters everywhere. Must visit in any weather.

A Bit Scary Now!. We rented a great apartment on Rue Livingstone for 5 days via the VRBO.com site. Had I been a woman alone I would have gone to another area to a hotel and gone into credit card debt! Vagrants on the streets, trash, and worse in the evenings when the shops closed. When all you see and hear are non-French speaking people who are from other parts of the world, you aren't going to have a true French immersion experience. Next time we will stay in The Marais!

Take a walk around. Montmartre used to be a country village producing flour, but was incorporated into the capital in 1860. It is charming to walk around and in the past it attracted some of the tops artists like Manet, Degas, Van Gogh and the like.

Tres bien!. This was by far my favorite neighborhood in Paris. The view of and from Sacre Coeur is spectacular. We enjoyed the outdoor markets, and I loved seeing the artists n the plaza displaying their art work. But beware - it is very hilly and there are a lot of stairs. You can skip some of them by taking the Funiculaire, which saved a few steps, but not all.

A Village Ambiance. This is one of the most charming areas of Paris, once you get away from Pigalle and the crowds at major tourist sites, such as Sacre Coeur and Place du Terte. Narrow, cobblestone streets bring visitors back to an earlier era. It is easy to imagine former residents, such as Picasso and van Gogh walking here. Some buildings bear plaques, describing famous people who worked or lived there. Little shops geared toward residents and small cafes and restaurants beckon as does Clos Montmartre Vineyard, which seems so out-of-place in a major city. This vineyard still produces a few hundred bottles of wine yearly. I recommend looking through self-guided walking tour guides at a bookstore to plan an itinerary.Sacre Coeur is, of course, a "must see" in Montmartre. Approaching this beautiful church from the rear is better than ascending the steps. Fewer people come this way and I've never encountered touts here. But they sometimes gather at the bottom of the steps, try to tie "friendship" strings around visitors' wrists and, if successful, demand payment. I just ignore them and they go on to someone else. The view of Paris from the top is simply stunning.Place du Terte, a reminder of famous artists who lived in Montmartre, is near Sacre Coeur and also draws huge crowds. Unlike the church, however, I do not think this square is a worthwhile stop. The artists with their easels are there to attract tourists, and many who sit for a portrait, leave disappointed with the result. Whatever you decide to do in Montmartre, consider taking the Montmartrobus. Its route goes from Pigalle to near Sacre Coeur and back, making ascending and descending those hills a lot easier.

Possibly the best place in Paris. I'm a frequent traveller to Paris and I always stay in Montmatre as its got a lovely "village" atmosphere.If you manage to get a hotel in the locality you will have loads of amazing restaurants on your doorstep. I've stayed in Montmatre for up to 10 nights in a row and been able to eat in a different restaurant and had an amazing meal every night. The prices are cheaper than close to the main tourist sites also so if you're looking for good french food without breaking the bank this is the place to come!

Not to be missed!!!. Montmartre is a wonderful, atmospheric place and not just in the evening. Even during the day, you are swept away with impressions of the past. I just absolutely LOVE the place!!!

Delightful place to walk around - Helpful tour. Take your time to visit Montmartre. Get off the subway at Abbesses station. Take Rue des Abbesses for three or four blocks until you reach a sort of detour. Take Rue Lepic. Go straight until you reach a place calledl Moulin de la Gallete. It's an excellent place to grab something to eat. Go north on Rue Girardon until Rue Norvins. Take a right turn an walk at least 20 minutes in order to reach Sacré-Couer. At the end, stop and discover Place du Tetre.Hope you like it

Go here to be robbed and conned. Montmatre area could be so spectacular and special, but is totally ruined by hundreds of little booths and merchants selling piles of junk, "art", poorly made food etc. It's crawling with pickpockets and con artists who try to rob you while smiling at you. Do not go here. It's absolutely dreadfull and could end up ruining your day or your vacation if you get robbed.

Stunning view of the city. A "must do" when visiting Paris. Stunning views of the city from Sacre Coeur The 18 arr. is full of local artists in the area of Place du Tertre. Loved every minute. Take the time to walk about and enjoy the culture, surroundings and everything Parisian.No incidents during our visit to Montmartre but we were forewarned by our guide of scammers and pickpockets.

Never boring in Montmartre. I chose to stay in Montmartre, not just visit the place. I loved it. It's one place where you can feel like a local. Bohemian to say the least. Walk out your door and no need to travel anywhere. It's all on your doorstep. We did the tourist thing in the mornings and returned to. Montmartre just after lunch on any given day. Walk the streets and you will always find something interesting. Cafés are endless and food markets are everywhere. Such a great neighbourhood with more of a Parisian feel than a tourist hang out. Loved it

Best way to stroll in Paris in night. The narrow artisan street will give you a rich culture of Paris along with small cafes as the one in the movie Amilee. The moulin rouge to Monmartre is a great walk with many small and beautiful cafes. To the top is is a spectacular view of the city in lights. If possible take a guided tour to this area and end up with dinner or a show at moulin rouge.

Montmartre mon amour!!. So special place!!!it'so intense..I went to Paris twice and both of the time I HAD to come over Montmartre with all its artists and culture and magic atmosphere you can breath walking around!!I love this place!!!

Thugs at Sacre Coeur Paris France. After entering the lowest level approach to the Sacre Coeur on April 16th 2015, my nephew was verbally barraged and then was grabbed around his right wrist and shoulder. I was with him and shouted repeatedly to stop, stop, stop and no, no no. This was about 9:30 in the morning and the crowds were light. No one came to help and after an eternity and lots of Engligh profanity, he released his grip. The thug kept shouting, "I will get you when you come back this way." My nephew had no visible values, though I had a nice camera and a backpack for a coat. The thug had at least 3 friends who were checking out tourists working with him.Another tourist approached us and said they had done that to him too.We found 3 police officers in khaki with assault rifles 2 levels up by the front door of the cathedral and reported the incident. They didn't seem comfortable with English but did move down to the same level as the thugs. He and his 3 friends continued to approach other tourists but not to be have as aggressively. Not a fun incident to experience. Still wondering why he was targeted. Maybe to tie him up so another could rob me?

very cool place to walk around. many good eateries and sidewalk cafes. a very trendy area and lots of strolling musicians to give it more atmosphere. just a short stroll from the Moulin Rouge area. We went there two different nights because we enjoyed it so much

We simply like it!. A place to go! Either you take the stairs or use the funicular (at the left of the park at the bottom - cost a metro ticket). The view is amazing and the atmosphere very relaxing. Then we walk around and you have a lot of small different place to eat. Lovely place.

Delightful place to visit. We did the Sandeman Montmartre walk and it was one my favorite activities. Ask for Inga, she is fabulous. They take you past the Moulin rouge and the crowded Parisian streets and walk you past where Vincent Van Gogh lived and where Picasso paid for his meal with a painting. You then walk up the hill to Sacre Coeur and you have the most fabulous view of Paris. I think what makes a place live is the stories, here Picasso stood, this is the famous blue door of Van Gogh, this is the place where the impressionist had their dinner. I love the history and the beauty. Lots of crowds, stuff to buy and lots of places to eat. It is probably worth reserving a table for when your tour finishes because the best places to eat were totally full when we were there. Go to Montmartre and take a walking tour so you really appreciate the history that makes this area what it is. Good teen friendly activity

nice worth visiting. well this place is alsoworld known as montmarte or sacre coeur for a good visit n stroll in summer can spend nice ly two to three hours can take out your sketches with good talented artisit good view of the effil tower and the montparnesse building woth going the visit of the church is free and once i nthe church you will see up and whereever u go i nthe church just see up and the lord jesus is looking and guiding yo uas always
Montmartre. Great area near Sacre-Coeur. It really feels like a true neighborhood as most of Paris does. It's filled with artists and other creative people. The vibe is active. Plenty to see.

Sacre coeur. It's one of the best views of Paris. The basilique its fantastic and for the ones that are catholics it makes the heart sweet. It´s very importante to go from the stairs by the sides of the mount, not the principle stairs or sides of it, so we don´t find the pickpockets and men trying to make some bracelets in your fingers by force and then charge you. NEVER EVER GO AT NIGHT.
Must visit Place @ Paris. Very good place on the hill . You can have fantastic view of paris from here. Enjoyed climbing the hill . Very good garden.

Monmartre is a delightful part of Paris. Monmartre is equal parts famous and infamous, and with good reason. The home of artists and bohemians in the 19th and early 20th century, The vestiges of seedy nightclubs and cabarets are still present in along the walk from Blanch to Pigalle Metro stops. However, the area is also home to Sacre-Cour and if you wander the streets you can find signs of the bygone era when this hill was a rural agrarian setting: two of the over 40 windmills that used to operate on the hill are still standing.The Pigalle and the area immediately around Sacre-Couer were quite busy with tourists, but once you got a couple of blocks away things were much quieter. I particularly liked the area around the Vineyard and Au Lapin Agile (The Agile Rabbit).

Amazing place!. This is one of my favourite places in Paris.Going up by climbing those stairs is like being the lead in a French movie, it's a classic.Once on top you arrive right in front of the Basilica of the Sacred Heart(Basilique du Sacré-Cœur). It's located at the summit of Le Butte Montmartre, which is the highest point of the city. Admission to the basilica is free and donations are accepted for the upkeep of this beautiful building. Only thing is no photo's allowed inside .. really bummer since it is beautiful inside.Keep walking and meet the cutest streets full of art and lovely restaurants. We spent about 30 minutes inside the basilica and then another 2 hours walking around the neighborhood at the bottom of the hill. Deffinitely recommend to visit!

Best View of Paris!. Up the only hill of Paris,one can find MontMatre!The church of SacrCore is standing there,as a protector of this splendid view!You can go up using the teleferique with a fare of under 2 Euros,or you can just go up the stairs.There are not so many stairs,but the climb is a bit tireding,so you can use the teleferique.Alot of young people just hung out on the stairs of thiw beatiful church,drinking wine and talking admiring the view.On top one can find small streets very colourful,where as we were told all artists of Paris used to live.The singer Dalida had her house there,and there is also her statue in a small street.Nice little tavernas,cafes,and tourist shops surrounds the premises.We went there at night,and we didnt feel at all insecure.They said to us that is a bit dangerous place,but as we found out it is far from that.It is must point when in Paris!If you have time and the money you can have your portrait done by the local artists near the small square!
Better with a guide!!!. I been there with Connor, he's a guide from SANDEMANs. My tour was very interesting and it could not be better!

Montmartre, - Colourful, cultural and artistic. Missing our scheduled volunteer guide around the area, we had to find our own way around Montmarte using the maps provided by the tourist office. We visited the Basilique de Sacre Coeur at twilight and during the day; both times were busy with tourists and people selling tacky Eiffel Tower souvenirs but we didn't allow this to spoil our visit. The view from the steps of the cathedral over the city of Paris is absolutely breathtaking and not to be missed. I recommend a visit to the Musee de Montmartre which is housed in the oldest building in the commune where Auguste Renoir and other famous artists found their home. The Museum has a number of unique paintings, drawings and posters. During our walk, we found the two remaining windmills of the area (Galette and Radet) on our way to The Musee Montmartre which is situated not far from the Place du Tertre and the infamous Lapin Agile cabaret (opposite the Vineyard of Montmartre). We didn't have time to visit the Dahli Museum but saw some evidence of his work in the locality like a man appearing to walk through a wall. At nightfall, we took the Metro to Blanches in order to photograph an illuminated Moulin Rouge then sat for a while in the boulevard absorbing the sights and sounds of this historically seedy environment while all the time feeling quite safe. There are lots of good, value for money restaurants to choose from, but wouldn't recommend those situated immediately around or in the centre of the Place du Tertre; we were ripped off big time there, we each asked for a beer and were presented with large glasses that cost 17 euro's each, a sum we didn't know until the bill arrived and the beer already consumed!! So, make sure you are precise when you order and ask questions about cost if it is not obvious.

Can't quite decide.... ...whether to go there or not! If you're in Paris, it would be a shame to not go and if I don't visit another church in Europe, I'll be a happy camper, but Montmartre and Sacre-Coeur are tourist traps of monumental proportions! The walk to the funicular is dirty and full of cheap shops, the views from the top are not all that great and there is garbage everywhere. It seems to be a hang-out for young people. I hate to say it, but the highlight was a busker who did amazing things with a basketball. We were mesmerized by this performer and that was the extent of our enjoyment of the visit there (but for that alone, it was worth it). By the way, I hope it's okay to extend this opinion. You don't have to put money in a busker's hat if it doesn't interest you, but if you stop to watch and enjoy a performer, I think you ought to throw something into the pot! A lot of buskers make traveling interesting and fun and this is their living. So don't partake if you don't have any interest, but if you do, pay your way!

Beautiful church, many steps to climb. Sacre Coeur is a beautiful basilica built on top of the hill of Montmartre. Many steps to climb but a beautiful view of Paris awaits you on top beside of the many good restaurants and relatively cheap souvenirs to get from there.

Dangerous. Stay away.. The stairs are crammed with rowdy people drinking but the worst part was the several groups of obvious scammers and pickpockets. We were attacked in broad daylight on the way down the stairs even though we had been warned and were being cautious. There was no security personnel anywhere to be seen. We made a big scene and got away but it ruined our day and our impression of Paris. Would not recommend this location to anyone.

Avoid Montmartre at Easter. Montmartre used to be really charming, but this Easter when we visited Paris with three youngsters that we wanted to show all the lovely places in Paris we got very disappointed. OK, it used to be touristy even 10 or 20 years ago, but this was ridiculous. We felt like we were trapped in a school of herring and immediately started to look for an escape route. Maybe it is more like it used to be other times of the year. It hurts to give this unique area such a low grade, but that is how we experienced it.

great, great part of Paris. this very arty place is definitely worth a visit. Again - you are in Paris but it has a totally different, sort of a village, feel to it. Lots to see and do. Amazing view of the hole Paris too.

The roof of Paris. From the stairs of Sacré Coeur, you have a view of Paris which cannot be compared. The sacré Coeur itself is pretty ugly but the neighbourhood gives a glimpse of the popular Paris tha once was.
Worth the climb. Try to time your visit here for a sunset experience. The view of the city is worth your time and effort. Be careful of the salesmen and watch your wallet.

Great time. Visited in April and had dinner and drinks and then went on a walkabout. Great atmosphere all around the area and good times spend on the steps of the church and stunning views over Paris. Highly recommended way to spend an evening

must go stop off in the city of light. This wonderful part of Paris is awash with numerous pubs, bar's and restaurant's, fantastic architecture, even a vineyard, it's a real tourist hot spot. You have to see SACRE COEUR, one of the most beautiful churches in the world, if your brave take the steps up,for the less energetic the bus or funicular whisks you up the hill in no time,were the views of Paris are breathtaking, as you will notice by the amount of tourists up here.Go into the square near the church full of pub's, bar's and restaurant's, absolutely amazing anytime but at night magical and most of these establishment's not as expensive as you may think.The usual caution's apply,be aware of pickpockets, they operate up here,were there are lots of tourists, pickpockets follow, same in any country anywere in the world, so keep aneye on your belongings. This is truely an area of Paris that you must visit and well worth a whole day in this great part of town.
Artsy place. You need to follow the directions to the Abbey. There's two sets of stairs that you'll need to go up. then there is a plaza were there are artists that will draw you.
Very artistic. I was lucky that i took the train then i walked to where the painters are. such a nice walk. there are nice shops on that road. very magical, french, .. really moved me.

A Monestary and quaint village.
