We took the mini train tour up to the Monestary and were amazed by the place.The architecture of the church is stunning and the number of people in and around the church was surprising. As everywhere else there are tourist there are pickpockets so be careful.Stop in the courtyard and have something to eat while the local street artist sketches your likeness for a fee of course.

Great atmosphere . A unique little place to walk around. Lots and lots of artists painting in the square so a great opprtinity to get a portrait done.There are also lots of bars and restaurants to choose from. A lot offer set menus at a good price. However the restaurant we chose stung us on the drinks prices so watch out for this.

Magical Environment Overlooking Paris. Have been here many times since my college days. It's a magical artist community. Great for people-watching, eating crepes, walking stairs and experiencing a romantic evening. Best seen at night!

My Favourite!!!. Sacré-Cœur is one of the beautiful churches. White marble architecture makes it look marvellous. I went with my husband and we walked up the steep hill. The entire walk was through narrow lanes, with coffee shops and eateries on the way. Though its a long walk. Once, we reached up, we saw that to reach the church, either we take cable car, or a Montmartro-bus, or walk up the stairs, or walk the hill from back of Montmartre. We took the back way and loved it. There comes a square(just behind the church) where there were numerous painter on the way. Some were painting some building, some were asking people to draw for their sketch. The place looks so different, full of artists. It gives a feel of real, dreamy Paris. Good to see. From top we could spot entire Paris. Though lastly, we came back from the stairs. Must visit.

Favorite part of Paris. This is a steep hill that rises out of the generally flat Paris landscape, and has a famous church at the summit, the Sacre Coeur. You can reach the summit by a famous set of steps, but apparently you can also catch a funicular railway that connects to the Metro. In the square next to the church artists paint portraits or caricatures of tourists, the standard of some being very good. The area is thronged with tourists and it can be very difficult to get served in a restaurant, even when its not overly busy.Downhill where there are less tourists is better. You can find the Moulin de la Galette which is associated with the famous Renoir painting. Further downhill are quite a lot of good restaurants and bars around the rue des Abbesses and if you keep going to near Blanche Metro station you can find the famous Moulin Rouge. Montmartre was the hang out for artists like Van Gogh, Renoir, and Toulouse-Lautrec and despite the frantic tourist activity some echoes of the old bohemian life remain.

Everything I was Hoping Paris Would Be. . .. My 20 year old daughter and I stayed in an apartment in Montmartre during our first visit to Paris. Like many who travel, sometimes my expectations of what a destination will be like are never met. But Montmartre was exactly what I hoped Paris would be -- full of narrow, cobblestone streets, small neighborhood bars, shops and plenty of eccentrics. Downstairs from our apartment was a tiny shop that repaired lutes. And across the street was a preschool housed in an old abattoir. Even the children had their scarves wrapped as carefully as their handsome daddies. And the first night we walked home from the metro, a woman in a red dress leaned out her window smoking a cigarette. This is what we came to Paris for and we were well-rewarded by staying in Montmartre.

Breathtaking views. Breathtaking views of the city, wonderful architecture and lots of local shops that are close to church. No Photography is allowed inside the church. Wonderful stop, doesn't take very long to walk through and marvel in the church.

Incredible athomosphere. I just loved walking around that area, so nice, so colourful, such pleasure. Full with little shops, art galleries and cute cafes, and the view from the stairs in front of the cathedral is inspiring.

Wonderful Half Day or more. My wife and I spent the good part of half a day exploring this wonderful area of Paris. There are pleny of cafes, restaurants, shops, artisans, churches, etc. to visit here. Sacre Coeur is a must as with many of the other churches in the area. Any of the Metro stops in the area are close enough that you can easily walk to all sights.

Early birds get greatest rewards - and best coffee to date in Paris!. We rode here (on Velibs, our favourite Paris transport) at dawn - to miss the crowds and to see Paris awakening from the top of Montmartre. Rewarded on both counts as the hordes descended just as we were leaving. A beautiful church, amazing views in all directions, and a great experience wandering down the cobbled laneways of Montmartre afterwards. One massive surprise was having our best coffee so far in Paris at a little corner place called (not so imaginatively) Cafe Montmartre. In such a touristy area, this was very unexpected but the young fellow setting up chairs very happily stopped what he was doing to make us coffees and my 'noisette' and my partners cafe creme were both sensational. The older owner then came in and chatted away about local attractions and showed just how wonderful the French can be with tourists with only basic French to converse.

Avoid times when Heineken have a sale on. Unfortunately our experience of this location was spoilt by hoards of street sellers (who could speak neither French nor English) thrusting bottles of heineken in your face demanding that you purchase from them or pickpockets attempting to draw your attention whilst their accomplice helps themselves to the contents on your open pocket. We recommend an early morning visit, (we visited at sunrise the following day) and this was far more enjoyable and indeed beautiful. Being able to appreciate both the architecture and scenery without feeling threatened.

A beautiful afternoon. We drove through Montmartre on the way to Sacre-Coeur one day and decided to go back for av is it another time to walk Amon the shops and artists. It wast a truly memorable visit.

Artists galore. Some say this is the best route to Sacre Couer. I suppose, but we took the hard way - straight up the hill. Montmarte is known for artistry, and there certainly are many there. Selling already painted works as well as offering to paint or draw your picture as you wait. I'm into watching and taking pics of the happenings going on, but really, I didn't see any future masters' works on offer. Lots of people and I assume therefore pickpockets. There are sidewalk cafes. Don't let my less than stunning review discourage you from going for it is a strong part of Paris.
It was OK...... Picturesque part of Paris...but very overcrowded. Need to keep your wits about you if you are going to escape with all of your belongings intact! Nice view though!

Best way to get to the Sacre Couer. Lovely neighborhood that is quite Paris-esque. Make your way up to the Sacre Couer by walking through Montmartre. I suggest heading to the Moulin Rouge to see the sight and take a pic or two. Head north on Rue Lepic and turn right on the Rue de Abbesses. Quaint street that really feels Parisian (possibly go back there for dinner as there are many brasseries/restaurants. Make your way by keep heading north thru the Place de Abbesses (if you hit stairs, you're doing it right). Find yourself at the Sacre Couer with and a much better way to avoid the touristy stores and forceful men selling souvenirs at the stairs leading up to the Sacre Couer.

Well worth the visit . This place is well worth the visit. Loads of places to eat nearby and the views from the top of Montmartre are amazing. You can practically see the whole of the city from the top of the building. Be careful of pickpockets though. You will get a lot around here unfortunately.

Tourists beware! Unsafe area!. I haven't been afraid in many ares that I've traveled, but here, I certainly was. We went to visit Sacre Coure, which was beautiful, but I'd never go back. Upon leaving the metro, we stopped at a bank machine where there where sketchy looking people everywhere. We had several people come up to us and ask for money. We walked up the back way of the Sacred Heart, there were even more sketchy people who looked like they might rob us in daylight at any moment. I was genuinely afraid. Then when we got to the church we had a nice visit. It's beautiful and the grounds and views are spectacular. Yet when we left, we were accosted by the men outside trying to sell you the sting bracelets. One came at me and grabbed me and one followed my fiancé and kept yelling at us. They even started to circle us when we jut took off very quickly. They will not leave you alone. I never once saw a police officer and don't know how they allow them to stand there and accost people. There were several local cops in the nicer areas of town, but not here where they are needed. Next, when we got on the metro to leave, we saw a man and his wife get attacked! A man was following them and wouldn't leave them alone, then pushed them down the stairs and went after them! Even with throngs of people around! Bottom line, unless you're in a large group with several big men, DO NOT go anywhere in this area. It's definitely the ghetto.

My Favorite part of Paris. I absolutely LOVE this area of Paris. It was very crowded on the Sunday we visited and there was a festival atmosphere. The narrow streets are lined with shops of all kinds (lots of ticky-tacky) . Artists wander the square wanting to draw your portrait, but are not annoying. It was a delightful place to eat lunch, and there are lots of options.

love love love!. by far my favourite place in the whole city! <3 i just felt so at ease there! the atmosphere is relaxing, laid-back and very Amelie-like ;) plus, all the street art around there is magnificent! just enjoy some cafe-au-lait at one of the oldest bistros and tavernes of Montmartre and fall in love with it like i did :)

Nice little town!. We went there quite early in the morning, not a lot of shops open other than some cafe that serves breakfast. However, it is a very nice walk along all the streets, let yourself walk without a map and discover interesting buildings in every corner! Most of the shops & the artists start at 10am, so I would recommend a visit after 10 or 10.30am.Nice place to walk, very well resemblance of Parisian town!

Always a Pleasure to Visit.. This area is one of our favourites each time we visit Paris and we generally go in late afternoon and combine the trip with an early dinner. The small streets wind back and forth and you can still see grape vines on some plots left over from hundreds of years ago.It is hilly and some areas with cobblestones difficult upon which to walk. The funicular leading to Sacre-Coeur enables a spectacular view over some areas of Paris.The street sellers are very good natured but perhaps not so are some of the pushy tourists, beggars and touts. I suppose this all part of the experience. We have purchased quite a few items over the years (not trinkets) including on our recent visit, and these remind us of the vibrancy of Montmartre.
Quaint. Love the atmosphere and walking about . Artists are pleasant and tend not to hassle. Lovely little cafes around the square.

Proper Paris. this is proper Paris, but go in February when there are no loud mouthed Americans, pushy Japanese or aggressive Germans to spoil it.
Go late afternoon views over Paris sensational and Place du terte quiet, avoid like the plague between April and October.
Beware of dodgy blokes at bottom of funicular and the steps.

Street art. If you are lover of street art, this is a place of the town where to go. It is located on the hill so the view is excellent.It is very lively with a lot of small restaurants with acceptable price

Art region of paris - near to sacre Coeur . Lovely area of paris right next to the famous church basilica! Plenty of little streets with bars and bakeries too ! Be warned this area is quite hilly ! Enjoy
Overrated . Too much talk abou nothing overcrowded and dirty. The visitors don't respect the area. Maybe is better to visit it in spring or summer
Nice area but touristy. Not sure you can have one without the other after the "word" gets out. Climb the hills in this area and stop for coffee, a meal, or ice cream. Nice area.

Too commercialized. Montmartre and the Sacre Coeur were my most favorite places to be in Paris.I spend many many times in that place, solo or with my wife.However the last few times I lost it with Montmartre, The artist had no longer space to exhibit properly their works or paint their patrons. An all enclosed cafee had taken over the square and all space, sights had gone. Basically that is happening all over Paris, its all about COMMERCE with no place anymore for memories

Old Paris. This is what I'd always imagined Paris to look and feel like. There was a great view of Paris (although it was pretty foggy the day went!). The church was worth a visit and so was the square where the artists were painting - lots of people wanting to sell their wares; some of them were very talented. Take the time to enjoy a coffee in one of the many cafés.

Amazing View of Paris. Very enjoyable place to walk and to check the view. Nice little restaurants around, walking distance from Moulin Rouge so you can do both in one visit.Enjoyable to visit during the day and at night, but not to late cause you wont find to many places open or many people around.
Nice environment. We went at night, and it was lively with a fun atmosphere. Similar to a lot of those outdoor, night life areas.

Worth the walk up the hill!. The hill to the top can seem endless, but with two beautiful churches at the top and a view of all of Paris it's worth the effort. Montmartre is bigger than just the arty bit at the top, and if you come up from Rue Caulaincourt upwards the neighbourhood is very smart with several patisserie and chocolate shops. Ideal for breakfast snacks. The artists area is actually very tiny, and off season in February was not busy at all. The artists square where they have set up their work for sale is an interesting place. It is very nice to sit at one of the many cafes on the square and people watch. Of course there is the Sacre Ceour to look at, but there is much more to Montmartre than just one church. If you take your time exploring off the beaten track, and are prepared to walk then Monmartre is a lovely neighbourhood to check out.

Go on a sunny day. Go on a sunny day. The atmosphere is wonderful. After 9 o'clock at night the place clears up and only the odd artist is left.Highly recommended, don't leave Paris without a visit to Montmartre.If you decide to have your portrait drawn, go around and chose the artist whose work you prefer. Don't chose the first available one. Preferably one who is actually sketching rather than displaying previous portraits made from photographs.

Beautiful area. Not a difficult walk up. We arrived by the Metro then walked up. It wasn't a difficult walk. Once we got there, charming shops, lots of places to eat. Huge number of artists offering to paint your picture. We weren't particularly hassled by any of them or street vendors either. Great views of Paris from Sacre Couer. Well worth the trip.
My Most Favorite Place in the World. Art, talent, shops, restaurants, entertainment, Montmartre is a beautiful part of Paris ♡♡ Will return one day and make it my home.

Take Care. We had spent a nice day in La defense and thought that we would visit Montmartre et Sacré Coeur about 16.00 hours. Le Metro was fun as always watching folk sneak through the barriiers without paying and then meeting the Police.   We walked from Abesses Metro station to base of Sacre Coeur without problems - an interesting walk with lots of little shops to look in as well as the ubiquitous tourist junk shops.  We believed that the walk up to Basilique du Sacre Coeur would be heavy going but it did not look too bad so we took the walk rather than the little funiculaire which had a massive crowd gathered outside "queueing" (although this would be good for wheelchair users).  As we walked up the hillside, we were approached by about 5 men trying to give us bits of string, blocking our path, and then trying to take the rings off my partner's fingers - we rapidly departed up the hill.  There were many harmless folk selling bottles of water & beer who were not a particular problem, & several performing artists along the way who were also not a problem - we enjoyed watching them for a short time.  Sacre Coeur was interesting Despite the signs, some folk insisted on talking loudly and on taking photos, even with flash; but one was hurried along so we did not get to really study the building.  On the way down (other side) we were again approached by more men intent on giving us bits of string, whom we avoided more effectively.  At the bottom of the hill, we spent an interesting 20 minutes talking to the guys from the Compagnies Républicaines de Sécurité Police; they felt that they could do little about these men. We would not visit again; it is too risky to be able to enjoy it;  If you do go, take care, do not wear jewellery, do not carry expensive cameras and do not carry lots of money or credit cards.  But the chat with the CRS Police at the foot of Montmartre was very interesting for someone trying to improve his French language skills  If you do wish to visit, one can buy CS gas at amazon.fr http://www.amazon.fr/CS-Save-Gaz-5005-15-Dame/dp/B003LXLTWQ/ref=sr_1_9?ie=UTF8&qid=1425935840&sr=8-9&keywords=CS+gas

Don't miss this neighborhood!. We were iffy about this area, but I'm so glad we made it! We did the walking tour recommended in Fodor's, which took us down some beautiful streets. Good little shops, great lunch spots, and the views are splendid.

This is a charming neighborhood... see review for visit guidelines. I've been here twice. The far more pleasant way is to arrive at the more northern metro station, and walk down hill to see Sacre Coeur. Don't walk up from the Anvers metro. You'll be swarmed by street hawkers selling tourist junk. Arrive via Lamark-Caulaincourt. Walk south, past Place Dalia,the little vineyard, the Maison Rose, and to Place du Tertre, and the church. Make your way towards the Abesess metro. The streets you want to avoid are near the funicular, and Anvers metro. Do a search of Montmartre walks, and you'll get the highlights. The Dali museum is less Dali, and more other artists in the Dali style. The cobblestone streets and old buildings are the very quintessential bohemian atmosphere tourists hope for. Don't let the touristy stuff spoil your visit.

Nice break from Parisian madness. This was an afternoon of total respite.Lovely bright day with blue skies meant we spent our time walking the streets of Montmartre. Stopping off occasionally for a beer. Ok maybe I stopped a few too many times!It's delightful. As a place to visit if you have the time I cannot recommend it enough.

A different Paris experience. We went on a walking tour in this area of Paris and you experience a different side to Paris- away from the heart of the beautiful, romantic city, Montmarte offers a bit of an edge.Walking around, you see where Picasso, Van Gogh and other famous artists lived, drank and picked up their ladies of the night.At the top of the hill, there is a magnificent church you must visit- everything inside is mosaic and is worth a 15-30 minute stop to take in the art work. The views over Paris are amazing from the church steps too!This part of Paris is home to the love wall, a beautiful vineyard and Moulin Rouge which is worth a photo but be careful not to stray down any streets away from the main squares or roads as we did bump into a prostitute or too. This is the area of Paris where you will see many sex shops too. Don't let it put you off though as there are some amazing bits to see and it's much less casual in the day time.

Fabled District Lives Up to Its Reputation.. Although the best way to see everything and enjoy the architecture, is to walk up the 'hill,' be forewarned - it's steep, tall, and a bit of a work-out. If you're not into that kind of exertion, take a cab to the steps at the foot of the Sacre Coeur, and walk up to the cathedral from there. This white church is glorious - and absolutely ethereal and magical in the early morning light. From there you are only a short walk to the markets, restaurants, shops, and outside artists of Montmartre. This is (yet another!) spot in Paris to be sure to eat in an outdoor cafe and watch the citizens and tourists stroll past - the perfect place to people-and-fashion watch. Many will have other favorite spots, but I believe the best crêpes in Paris are to be found in Montmartre. This is also the spot to have your portrait drawn or painted al fresco. If a full portrait is a bit too pricey for your budget, have your silhouette cut. Each of the artists we've selected to do this seem to have an unerring eye for capturing the subject, and the pleasant experience becomes a treasured souvenir of your trip. Be sure to take the time to visit the various art galleries and antique shops that abound. It is easy to spend an entire day at the Montmartre, so manage your schedule so you leave enough time to do this 18th district historical area its due.

Enjoyable afternoon. After a visit to Sacré-Cœur we strolled down the road, honestly just following the masses of people. We knew we wanted to go to Montmartre, but as a stroller I didn't mind if we got there in the most direct path or just found it. We knew we were headed in the right direction when we started to see people holding sketch books and art supplies. There are numerous shops and restaurants in the area but the gem for us was the square where all the artists are working away and selling their creations. We strolled and looked for just the right articles to take home. There are all manner of artists here. They are doing realistic portraits or caricatures or sketches. There are others doing scenery of the area or landscapes. Some are realistic, some are "artistic interpretations". We found all the artists friendly and welcoming. After the art purchases we just walked around the neighborhood full of all manner of shops. I found a great little second hand shop on the way to a wonderful lunch. This is a charming neighborhood that is worth the trip up on the Metro where we came from the Eiffel Tower area and got off in Moulin Rouge area. Be warned the trains up to this area are quite crowded and you will have to essentially push your way on and off, but nobody seems to mind.

Go at night. What a beautiful building. Take a walk up there but go at night, you see beautiful views of the whole of Paris by night! Beautiful. Be warned though the trek up there is steep, but it's worth it. Then take a stroll around the city.

Nice neighborhood. Really nice place. We headed to Sacre Coeur and back to Moulin Rouge and enjoyed every step of the way. It is a long walk up the stairs to get to Sacre Coeur but you can see a lot of people, nice places like restaurants and a little market place where is full of artists that paint, maybe have your portrait or caricature made there.

Appreciating a good walk in Montmartre. I consider this neighbourhood in Paris an area really for walking. It is up there in a mountain in the 18th city district (arrondissement) and where the Sacre Coeur church is located, dominating the view.But once there, looking from the top to down, the view of Paris is amazingly beautiful. Just to get there is already nice if you take the little ferry cable to go up, while enjoying the view.The narrow streets have the old charm from the time artists like Picasso, Van Gogh, Pissaro and others were living and working there, probably yet exchanging their paintings for drinks and food in nearby restaurants.The "Lapin Agile" is one famous restaurant for having gather many of these artists and intellectuals until late at night for passionate discussions. There are quite a lot of tourists in the area, but that is true for the whole Paris. There are many street artists drawing outdoors and touristic traps in a format of little shops and restaurants, so be ware if you decide to buy or eat in that area. If walking just outside the main area around the Sacre Coer,you might already found a bit more of authenticity. It's still possible to find some quite and interesting streets to just wonder around or a little simple bistro or patisserie.
Bursting with Energy!. This area was so full of life and energy. It felt a little bit like Greenwich Village, NYC! Loved it!
4 days in Paris. 4 days in Paris is worth spending holidays, my favourite place is Sacre-Coeur in Montmatre, the view when you are up is so lovely.

The cutest church to see. This church venue is very beautiful to see. If you visit the place before sunrise, you can see a very good view of the rising sun. The church is very old and lovely. The path to the church is also surrounded by old and beautiful buildings.

Feel the spirit of bohemian Paris here. Montmartre is definitely one of my favorite neighborhoods in all of Paris. When walking through its streets you still can feel the spirit of bohemian Paris. I would highly recommend using Rick Steves' Montmartre tour as this will help you see the area and imagine how it was during La Belle Epoque and early 20th century. Since Montmartre is on a hill, you will see some of the best views of Paris from here.

A charming day to spend in Paris. Montmartre has had a reputation for bohemian life. For over 100 years people have flocked to this interesting area in the north of Paris to enjoy a day in the midst of famous and not-so-famous artists who will give you a treasure to take back home, painted and signed in the Place du Tertre. You can stroll by and see them at work, and then choose the one that you believe is doing the best job. Negotiate the price. They are expecting you to do so. And then sit in one of the surrounding cafes to enjoy a warm cup of coffee in the winter or a cool drink in the summer days while the show goes on around you. A top area to see Parisian life at its best.

The best way to get to Montmartre from Hotel de Ville/the Seinethe Louvre. The big disadvantage to Montmartre is all the climbing, just to get to the best bits like Sacre Coeur and La Place du Tertre. If you can find your way to the base of Monmartre, near Pigalle, then you can take the Funiculaire (the ski-lift type tram that takes you to the lower bit of Sacre Coeur). But if you are staying near the Seine, around the Rue de Rivoli, Hotel de Ville or the Louvre, for example, then instead get on the 67 bus and take it to its terminus at Pigalle. Then switch over to the Montmartrebus, a smaller bus which takes you up all the narrow winding roads to the Place itself, or any other place of your interest along the route. See pretty well all of Montmartre without all the climbing. Save your legs for walking around the interior of Sacre Coeur and all the shops/restaurants encircling the Place de Tertre.

nice touristic area. lots of restaurants and artist that will offer to draw you a portrait. make sure to go for the artists with Identifying card from the municipality as those re better in general from other not professional. if you decided to have a portrait you should bargain but be careful some good artist may have a benchmark price. you need 3 hours especially if you went for a portrait.

Go Off The Beaten Path. Montmartre is possibly best known for Sacré-Coeur or the Moulin Rouge, and the little art square beside Sacré-Coeur. I discovered some areas beyond the the tourist areas you will find part of the "Real Paris" that locals live and hang-out. To be discovered are some wonderful streets with great architecture, shops, cafes, boulangeries, etc... It is chance to meet the locals and find some gems!

The different part of Paris. Montmarte is the different part of Paris, it is good chance to buy pieces of art or handicrafts. At the market place you should really be aware of artist that really want to sell you for example quick made profile picture. Montmarte is so peaceful and attractive place that you have to prepare to spend there hours. If you are tired to walk, you can always have a break in tens of cafes and restaurants. located in the Montmarte.

QUAINT AND CHARMING. Great place to see and feel the local atmosphere and people of Paris. Go into the local bakeries and shops to smell and feel what a real Parisian's dailynlife consists of. Don't miss this area well worth spending 1/2 a day there.

Montmartre MADE my Paris trip. When we arrived at our hotel in Paris I was excited because we were staying on the Champs Elysses thinking that we would be "in the hub" of all things Parisian. We had a beautiful view of the Eiffel Tower from our "french balcony" so we were able to see it light up at night, which was fantastic. But, as we walked and toured the avenue, we were disappointed because it felt so much like 5th Avenue shopping in New York City, and we didn't come all this way to experience NYC. (Don't get me wrong, I love NYC and the round the clock action, but I was looking for what I thought was "Paris".) We took a tour with a driver in a car made for 2 in the back seat where there is a window in the roof of the car. It was from that driver that we were reminded of what my aunt had told us before we left...don't miss Montmartre!AND, you have to visit Montmartre if you want to experience such a unique, quaint "village" that wraps you up in all things Parisian. From walking the cobblestone path up to the square of Montmartre, your visit begins as you are offered to have a sketch drawn by a local artist (though they range from highly skilled to apprentice-level in skill). Don't miss the opportunity. It's MUCH different than Americanized caracitures (sp) offered at theme parks. The one thing I missed doing was taking a picture of "my artist" with me holding his portrait of me. I haven't hung it, because it seems self-serving, but the drawing brings a flood of memories of Montmartre back, even thinking about it. We continued our walk with portraits in tow, and reached the square of Montmartre where you see artisans using about as many sources of medium to offer for sale. Though, they don't stop creating to "pull you in", they don't have to, their work speaks for itself. There are all types of cuisine that you can chose from small shops. We chose to have "french" onion soup, and nothing will ever be as comparable to the taste of the soup we devoured sitting at (I believe, St. Margaret's) an outside table enjoying the beauty of what this district has to offer. There is so much more to the experience, I can't possibly convey in words the culture, beauty, and adventure this visit added to our Paris experience. In fact, I sometimes forget to say I went to Paris, I usually say we went to Montmartre and would highly recommend it to everyone, unless you are in the city to buy high-end fashion comparable in buildings/concrete of New York City. DON'T miss it!

Incredible Artist section of Paris. This is one of my favorite neighborhoods in Paris. Full of artists past and present with an incredible rich history. Loved the artists square and the cafes were awesome. Shopping was wonderful. Hope to go back again someday. Truly magical.

Quintessentially Parisian?. I'd never heard about this place until I booked an apartment right in the middle of this place and then landed up there. I was charmed because it was my first experience of Paris and everthing I saw fitted my stereotypes of what Paris is supposed to be: cafes, streetside artists, piano bars...among others. Yes, yes...there is even a Starbucks there, plumb in the middle.What I wasn't prepared for was however this place is so incredibly touristy - we're pouring out of the woodwork! Then the shops, the unending shops selling the same damn things. The cafes selling overpriced stuff. Mediocre artists parading as portrait painters, paperless refugees sellingg you laser pointers or keyrings of the Eiffel Tower...But all said and done, the place is as central as central in Paris can be. The nearest is a scramble down a steep stairway or via the Funiculair (which is always fun with kids) and then...you're linked with the rest of Paris via their incredibly efficient Metro system. Staying at Montmartre makes sense if you're going to throw yourself around all directions of Paris. The views of the city are nothing exciting unless you're on top of the stairs at the Sacre Coeur and then that cancels all my other generalisations about the views from out here. I'd urge you to walk around the neighbourhood - that's a great way to check the lay of the land and learn more about the place. Pickpocketing being a fine career option for many of the city's more recent immigrants, be advised to hang onto your stuff dearly. Not just in Montmartre, but in all of Paris.

A tiny slice of life. I never miss a chance to visit Montmarte. I love to go up the hill on the funicular and walk around and see the artists painting on the square, go to the overfilled gift shops and find a place to eat and drink. It might not be the best food but the atmosphere is perfect for watching people. If you get out of the square arae on top and start to wander the streets you can begin to imagine what it used to be like. I's the old Paris when the streets didn't all come to the point of a star.

Montmarte is so charming. We stayed in a hotel in this area and were able to walk there. It is so charming. Little shops, artists sitting on the sidewalk painting, land best of all was the Basilica of the Sacre Coeur.when you stand on the steps you can see all of Paris.

Disappointing. Perhaps it was because it was winter, but there was nearly nothing to see other than artists selling their work and sketchers offering to do your caricature in 10 minutes. The neighborhood is nice, but you might ask yourself if it was worth the trip. There were a number of shops selling art, but it seems more oriented towards tourists than art collectors. The 'advertised' bohemian feel struck me as more for the tourists than genuine. Still, we stumbled on a restaurant where we ate the best meal we had during our week in Paris. Try the Le Coq Rico. As the name implies it is about chicken, but not completely.

The best area in Paris. Montmartre is quite possible the estereotypical picture of Paris, away from downtown and the river Sena sides. Coffes, small restaurants, lovely-faced houses and a shocking view point. So much better than the Eiffel Tower and L'Arc du Triomphe.

Disappointing. we headed here early on Sun morning but already the crowds were out. Couldn't get up some steps due to large numbers of people congregating. Seemed there were no tourist staff or police to patrol the area
Constantly harrassed by people wanting to paint our pictures.
Tacky shops selling same stuff you see all over.
overpriced coffees and food.

Must see. Not knowing anything about Paris, we booked any hotel that came up. The 1st one was the choice and it happened to be at the base of the Montmartre. Again, not knowing , we just went out for an afternoon stroll and happened upon it. Marvelous place, plenty to see with beautiful architecture and a nice bohemian atmosphere. Street entertainers were....well....entertaining and the shops and cafes were not too expensive. I would recommend a visit to anybody.

Mont Marvellous. An easy metro journey and short walk takes you to a marvelous vista of Paris. The cobbled streets, quaint houses, cafes and restaurants is a big draw card. There also lots of creativity in art and pottery shops.

A must!. I hate crowds,and don't get me wrong Montmatre is a very busy place, however I loved visiting. I loved the variety of art and bohemian feel. Was a lovely place to walk to on a sunday morning with a visit to sacre coeur!

Pleasant stroll. Lots to see, some beautiful architecture, relaxed atmosphere, a bit hilly if your not a walker but there is a little white bus thingy that you can get from near the metro that takes you to the Sacre Coeur which is a stunning building and heaped in history.Lots of touristy shops and gazillions of "artists" ready to do you a quick portrait, restaurants pretty standard but plenty to chose from, hot dogs seemed popular for many but a good way to pass a few hours,try some of the back streets to get a feeling of the old town.

More Ahmed than Amelie. If you're going to Montmartre hoping to find the magical bohemian district portrayed in the film "Amelie", then you are going to be disappointed. While the place does have some beautiful architecture (and of course there is the Sacre Coeur), it often feels more like you are walking around a Moroccan city than the quintessential France. This is not to say it's not interesting, it's just not particularly French/Parisian. That said, an interesting time can be had here, just keep your wits about you as it still is a red-light district.

You can still imagine the artists and the absinthe. My favorite part of Montmarte is the Musee Montmarte, a special little gem of a museum that features the art of the late 19th and early 20th Century, when Montmarte was a bawdy playground to the artists and writers of the day. Just ignore the numerous tourists and tacky souvenir shops, and wander the streets...you will get it!!! Even the street artists that stop to sketch you and sell you your picture are charming, and not too bad at their craft. Have a peek at the Moulin Rouge, Sacre Coeur, and if you are up to it, climb the stone steps, don't take the lift!

Historic neighbourhood. The Basilica of the Sacred Heart, the Moulin Rouge, very narrow street full of historic buildings and streets that go up in the hill. This place reminds of the old Paris before Napoleon. Very charming.

Lots of crowds but keep walking and it gets much better. I visited the historic Montmartre to do Rick Steves' walking tour. An excellent way to spend the afternoon as I love history and there are several iconic sights along the way. Don't let the crowds at the top of the hill scare you off.
It was very crowded and expensive this time. I went there three times, like 5 years ago, two years ago and now. Now it wasn't that good.. many people and very expensive art.

Disappointing.. We visited Monmatre in early January and were somewhat disappointed. The approach to the Monmatre area was rather dismal and the market area below Sacre coeur crowded, and messy. Many of the restaurants in the Monmatre area were closed and so the "atmosphere" we anticipated was sadly lacking. Undoubtedly it must be better in Spring or Summer?
Great parisian evening. Loved the whole bohemian feeling of the place. Many good restaurants and few good shops to browse. Would love to visit again

Historical site but very crowd. Arrive early to see and photograph the site around the church without a lot lot of people. The visit inside the church you will spend at least 1 hour (may).
There is a artcraft shops around the church.

Love this section of Paris! . If you are looking for artist section of Paris, you found it here!! Also home to some incredible art work, brasseries, restaurants, artist square, shops, a windmill, and a vineyard. So grateful to have experienced Montmarte. Love it here. Strict closing policy for shops at 645pm. Home to some famous artists, I believe Renoir. Definitely go here!

A creative person's heaven...... What a magnificent, artsy village.....you walk cobblestone streets filled with artists selling their creative pieces....and most artists are performing their trades as you walk up to them. I bought a lovely watercolor of the Eiffel Tower which after meeting the artist, she signed it for me. We ate crepes in a very unsual liittle cafe...and the shops are filled with such unusual treasures. While in this part of France, a trip to Montmartre is a must see!
a great view. It is worth catching the train up to the top, to stand and watch the sun go down over Paris. You get a much better view here than the Eiffel Tower.

Wonderful. Beautyful church and great view of Paris. Excellent walk around in the little streets. Careful of the very expensive portrait makers that bother you often. The funiculaire is not worth it unless you have mobility problems.

Lovely area of Paris with amazing views. You can see over the entire city from here, and it is gorgeous. Warning, not for the faint of heart, lots of walking, stairs, etc. Even just to get out of the subway is quite a hike. Great little shops and restaurants, cafes, etc. here--it is a great area to spend a few hours.

Very Bohemian. We loved it! What a delightful neighbourhood, with its winding climbing streets and the square with all the street artists. Plenty of lovely cafes and patisseries and all types of gourmet food shops. Plus of course, all the tourist shops full of souvenirs! Lovely place...a must visit if you are in Paris.

Stunning view; see it in the morning.. Montmartre was gorgeous. And it was especially gorgeous early in the morning. Go there right when it opens, before all the buses roll up with throngs of people. It will be quiet both inside and outside the church, making for a lovely time to gaze out upon Paris and do some thinking.Afterwards, visit the local coffee shops and wander through the boutiques in the area. Lots of stores have been open and owned by the same folks for years. You'll be done and on to the next adventure by noon.

very touristic. the area is interesting. But many street, in particular Place du Tertre, is extremely touristic.
It is still interesting to visit, though.

Wonderful Place. This is where I stayed when I travelled to Paris. When I booked the hotel online I knew nothing about it, only to realize it is a place with rich history background and culture. Take a stroll around this hilly area without looking at your map, have a little adventure and you will be very cheerful when you come across famous places like the moulin rouge. I will choose this place to lodge and take another walk again on my next visit!
naaah.... wasn't as lovely as we expected except Sacre Coeurthe nieghbourhood looked vast and dirty when compared to other Paris sites
The village within the city. Undoubtedly my favourite area of Paris to stay...an intimate village feel in the edge of the city..and amazing views.
Don't bother.. I seldom write negative reviews but over the years Montmarte has lost all it's former charm. There are so many better places to spend your time.

Simply amazing. I walked 300 stairs to get to Montmartre. The streets are beautiful and the Basilic is an architectural masterpiece. I recommend to visit the crypt as well. The view from the Basilic`s courtyard is spectacular especially on a clear day.

While away a sunny winter's afternoon.... If you enjoy exploring back streets, this is a good choice. Down the base of the hill there are loads of inexpensive bargain bin type shops - socks, undies, bargain clothes and an eclectic mix of cultures - barely a tourist to be seen. Up the hill to the Funicular base are the souvenir shops. The park next door to the Funicular station is a pleasant spot for a sit in the sun. Up the hill (bit of a slog on foot - definitely go the Funicular) is interesting indeed - visit Sacre Coeur (shhhh), the awesome Dali Museum (resist the urge to buy strange art), watch the artists in the square (perhaps a caricature for the folks at home?), find a cafe and enjoy a glass of wine and a slice of quiche. More fun in winter than in the summer crowds that is for sure. Stroll out the other end of Montmartre and wend your way past the cemetery and down to the Moulin Rouge. Very easy spot to while away a few hours,

Beautiful city. Visited this area as a family had a lovely day and the weather was hot and sunny.Took the cable car upto sacre coeur the views were amazing. Had a fab lunch in a traditional french cafe before taking a walk to moulin rouge. Dont let your husband be alone in pigale - he will be invited to a live show as mine was!
Lovely old area. Just loved this area, so romantic and sweet. Old houses and lots of artists.Some cafe around and tourist shops.

Great place, especially if you enjoy art and scenery.. The hotel we stayed in was lovely, the streets of monmarte are quite pretty and it is a lovely place to walk around and explore. The walk up to the Sacre couer is not that bad and definitely not worth the stair lift ( if you are fit and able enough to climb stairs).The artists are amazing in the main square, also a must is the Macaron shop so delicious.

Best Neighborhood in Paris. I'm biased since I used to live in Montmartre, but I continue to love it. It has the feel of a quaint village town in the heart of Paris. Worth a stroll by the main square where artists still congregate to sell their artwork. Great little restaurants (though experience ) and shops.
Amazing place!. I´ve never seen such a nice place as Montmartre- these amazing small aisles, wonderful restaurants and coffees - I love it there!

Favourite area of Paris. Friendly bohemian neighbourhood with lots to see and do. Great choice of restaurants and many lovely little shops to explore. Visit at any time of the year, Sacre Coeur area at Christmas is beautiful with lovely markets and views over the whole of Paris. Summer is wonderful too with lovely parks to visit and Place du Tertre where you can watch the artists at work. Never tire of Montmartre!

Très joli. In this neighboorhood you can see Le Moulin Rouge and the church Sacre Coeur. Additionally you have an amazing panoramic view of Paris as nowhere else. There is a lot of stairs but if somebody don't want or can not, there is a lift, which is payd but it costs something like a bus ticket. The access to Montmartre is easy by the Metro. Must see the painters in Place de Tertre. You need at least an afternoon to see the essence of the place.
Really pretty. Definitely my favourite area of France. Like a little village a step away from the bustle of the city.

This should not be your first destination. Lots of artists in square who do very nice work . However many will approach you to do a caricature of your likeness and not one even came close. Don't waste your money. There are lots of souvenir shops and places to eat. Nice for quick visit. If you have the ,metro pass you can take the funiculaire to the top.

Picturesque area to walk. It is very nice to walk around to see the artists in the square sketching and drawing people, and admiring the art that they sell. It is very typical of Paris and with the Christmas Lights was very beautiful too. The Souvenir shops are a bit too much...pity...Still you can find little cafes serving local fare at reasonable prices away from the square. The area is very nice to walk around and enjoy the views of the City. Keep going to the Basilica du Sacre-Coeur to enjoy beautiful architecture.

shopping !. The place is beautiful , just adjacent to basilica. There are loads of souvenier shops, cafes, a lot of artists draw caricatures. Its a very festive atmosphere. I don't know if its like this everyday but it was just a great day visiting this place.

Lovely!. The Montmartre area and its surrounding neighbourhoods is a very active place to visit. Home t the famous Sacre-Coeur church, the streets are full of artists (make sure to get a drawing - or a caricature of yourself while you are here). Wonderful views over Paris make the trip to Montmartre well worth it. Recommended!

Not the beauty it once was. It is unfortunate that such a bewitching place as this, has lost the unique charm it once possessed. The ill-kept, dodgy streets and the sketchy people hanging around it have turned this once picturesque jem into the old runned down ruin it now unfortunately is. I remember this place in it's prime, when montmarte was a must-see destination for all travelers visiting Paris. In my eyes, it emulated the image I had in my head of a typical, authentic Parisian town we all have heard off or read in the movies and novels. You could loose yourself for hours, soaking up the atmosphere of the cobble stoned streets and narrow lanes accompanied by quaint boutiques and shops of all sorts. The place seemed to almost have an enchanting character of it's own. Little pastry shops and interesting cafés lined the streets leading up to the main attraction. The view at the top of the hill was and still is breathtaking, thankfully one redeeming quality that has remained unspoiled.Though some of such cafés and shops still stand, the essence of it all has been ruined. The artists quarter is now a relatively baren, deserted, and uninspiring location, far from the thriving centre it once was. To sum up, Montmartre is not like how I'd remembered it to be. It has failed to retain so many of its distinct characteristics I’d fallen in love with in the past. If pick pocketing, dodgy characters, graffiti, run down metro stations, and a general thought of 'I hope this man doesn't steal my purse' is not enough to put any traveller off, I don't know what would. Stay as far away as you can. Au revoir Montmartre, I am never coming back.

Montmarte Shopping Surprise. We went to Montmarte to see the Basilica Sacre-Coeur and found many other gems there once we arrived. The shops were filled with beautiful textiles. We bought fabric to bring home to make into a dress and a suit jacket. We also visited the Church of St. Pierre, We ate at a cafe near the square and then walked the streets. We found the best surprise when we came across the Montmartre Museum and Clos Montmartre Vinyard. We spent time in the museum and in the beautiful gardens.
Not to be missed. A city not to be missed when in Paris, a true gem. Do visit the cathedral, what a beauty!! Nice place to shop and dine.
Lovely Area. Wonderful area, but it is overpriced. A lot of artists in the street and the amazing basilique du sacre coeur.

Serendipity!. Montmartre is one of the best places to visit when in Paris. Start from the top hill at the Sacred Heart Basilica where the view is magnificent. Then take the cable car or use the stairs to go downhill. The small streets there are beautiful and have nice small shops that you might find interesting.
Semi interesting area. Semi interesting area - great for a stroll - good cafes -but a little overrated - ethos. Guide book might bring out the hidden gms here

DO NOT GO HERE, FOR YOUR OWN GOOD.. We were in this area catching up with friends, which it had a very unsafe vibe and felt very dingy. We were told about the cathedral by friends since we were in the area we unknowingly walked there and got to a flight of stairs. I had a bad feeling about it before we approached as there was atleast 10 african men scattered arouns the area. This was at night and not many people were around. Against my instinct we approached the stairs to be hastled about showing a trick with string. I insisted no atleast 5 times and he went ahead and grabbed my hand and started tieing a bracelet. I felt uneasy but didnt know what to do. I was watching over to my partner to make sure she was ok and not being hasstled. They had got her to I questioned what he was doing and he just kept saying hakuna matata and making small talk at the end I knew he was going to want money im not stupid but giving the situation and how many of them with scarce amounts of people and way to many of them I knew I wasn't getting away easy. At the end when he asked for something 'some paper'. Another one came over and started hastling me saying 'give me 50 I give you change' I resisted and tried to get of easy for what felt like several minutes until I knew I wasnt going to get me and my partner away safely until I gave in. They ended up getting 40euro off me for both of us us. Which at the end of the day I was just glad we both got away safely and nothing else stolen. But I was furious afterward at the situation we'd walked into so close to 'must see' attraction. We see them everywhere with varies scams and im always alert and avoid them but this was secluded and no escape and no security or police in site despite this being such a common place for crime. An absolute disgrace that nothing is done about this. It definetely ruined my night and has painted a very ugly picture of that area for me and im hoping not paris as a whole. DO NOT GO HERE, FOR YOUR OWN GOOD.

That unique pretty atmosphere !. So much narrow streets with an ancient style make Montmartre the best place to spend an evening in Paris.Moreover, it is nice for sightseeing and you can also visit the Sacre Coeur Basilica, one of the most important landmarks ! Definetely a must-visit in the city.
A place full of Art. Beautiful place, many artists. There is a train tour,which costs you €6. worth to try. But the face to face painting asked for me € 70. Too expensive.

You have to visit Montmartre. So much to see as you wander around the hills of Montmartre. Great food stands, places to eat and/or have a drink, and charming houses and squares. Crowded, yes. But go in the later part of the day and it isn't so bad.
Love this place!!!. I just love this place, is kind of cool, the view is amazing. Also you can have some food, or walking around the square and watching the artist, really so nice place!!!

Yes, it is crowded but go for the view. Artsy cute town perched high above the city. Sacre Coeur is there along with cute boutiques and restaurants. Many things to see:Artists in the town center, the oldest Cabernet Au Lapin Agile, and the only vineyard in Paris.

Climb up the many steps and the view is well worth it. This is a church at the very top of the hill. Once up there, the view of Paris is well worth the walk up. There is a huge queue into the church and we didn't bother. Venture down to the streets nearby and it is interesting to see how the Parisian operates each day. When the sun is out, people would sit on the steps and soak in the sun.

walking is the only way to appreciate this delightful essential Parisian enclave. Short and sweet... this little cobblestoned alleys will make you feel like being teleported back to the days that housed and fed artists like Picasso and the break-away group of writers and philosophers. Cafes and Eateries jostle for your attention around the village square. Place du Tertre, hemmed in by low houses from the 18th century. You can read up till you know everything, but one nocturnal visit will educate you faster than Rita, in the mysteries and delights that is Montmatre . Walk your trots off.

Th perfect face of Paris. It is exactly what you want and need to see when you visit Paris. It is simply perfect and cannot be criticized. You will find all types of artists, from painters to musicians. The view is breathtaking.

Highest point of Paris is a must see. It's really crowded all the time here but so worth it for the photos and ambiance. Definitely try to the creperie and also the sausage sandwich they sell on the street is heaven. Caricature drawings is a must to take back with you as a memoir and of course the view, heavenly truly

Cultural quarter of wonderful city. Strolling around the winding streets of Montmartre takes you back to a bygone era. It just oozes class and culture, with fantastic street artists, lovely art & craft and souvenir shops and some romantic and cosy cafes and restaurants. Fortunately our hotel was located at the base of this lovely area and so we were able to stroll through the area many times. Like many popular areas in many cities, it is plagued by pick-pockets, street performers trying to extract money from you and other less than savoury characters. However, forewarned is forearmed! Just say no.
Good place to buy souvenirs and more!. It is good place to buy stuff like souvenirs but please beware of gypsy, burglar and pick pocket gang.

Found ourselves in a crowd. I can only speak to our one experience at Montmartre which was on New Years Day at sunset. This was a very warm day for Paris in the winter and the foot traffic from the metro station all the way up the mountain was very tight. The restaurants were full. I suggest visiting on a non holiday as Parisians were all there! The view isn't perfect of the city unless you get up to the church.

Parisian culture and street artists. Along with your visit to Sacre Coeur, which is a must I highly recommend exploring the streets and shops around the cathedral. In addition to the many small shops that display the best of Parisian food there are many street artists around just waiting to draw paint or sketch you. I of course obliged and it is definitely something I would recommend however you must carefully choose the artist which you prefer. My advice is to hang around for a bit and see how they sketch others, before choosing yourself the normal price is around 20 euros.

Real Paris?. Our first trip to the city of lights could not have been better, mostly due to our decision to make Montmartre our home base. It's Low key, a bit sketchy, and hip (think Greenwich village) replete with colorful neighborhoods with endless little cafes and "off the mainstream restaurants" that were a welcome break from touristy establishments. We stayed at the foot of Sacre Coeur basilica hill- the only hill In Paris. The basilica is a tourist attraction as is the little neighborhood on the top of the hill but a must do if you're in the neighborhood. A great area to wander and get lost in (just use some common safety sense).

Fascinating area, but watch where you step. Great places to eat, less crazy than the Champs-Elysees, but be careful where you step... there was a near waterfall running down the stairs up and it hadn't rained. On the plus side, though, lots of breezy male washrooms I guess!

How I imagined paris.. A beautiful part of Paris just how I always imagined it to look.
If you are around the church or the restaurants yes you have the touts etc but walk two minutes away you feel like you have gone back 100 years to the Paris of old.

Best View of Paris. Montmartre is a must see place in Paris. There you find the beautiful white-domed Basilica of the Sacré Cœur and the Saint Pierre de Montmartre church. It has also nice entertainment at all hours of the day. Most importantly you will find the "ateliers" of many great artists of the 19th century. My girl friend and I went there many times, October 2014 was the latest. It has not changed a bit. We highly recommend to go from Pigalle, walk the stairs and plan on staying there for al least 4 hours, you will love it...

Fun place to visit if careful. Watch your bags and wallets!! Montmartre offers exquisite viewpoint on Paris. Very beautiful church and nice area to walk.However, pickpockets are seems to be a real problem there. Also don't buy things from shady street vendors.In addition restaurants are way overpriced and serve generic tasteless food. Excellent place to go and take few pictures, but can't recommend eating there. And watch your belongings!

New Years Day at Montmartre. normally I don't like crowds but this was an exciting experience..brilliant sunshine ..sitting outside restaurants..hot mulled wine..roast chestnuts..music..dozens of artists & hundreds of paintings...fascinating museum..and spectacular views..unforgettable

Historic quarter. Even though it was a cold and damp day the area was a packed as ever. Lots of small shops and boutiques as you would expect plus all the souvenir shops. Such a pity that other than a few all goods were made in China as far as we could make out. Despite the weather the traditional artists were present should you want a sketch or profile of yourself as a souvenir. Lots of bistros and coffee shops to choose from but we didn't eat there being advised that most were tourist orientated. If you do visit Montmartre then you must make time for the Sacre Coeur which is in the same area. Is it a must see? Yes, because of being such a famous area and its proximity to the Basilica

Lovely with a bit of sunshine. My partner and I went into a day at Montmartre expecting a lot and were disappointed early on,Luckily this would change as we moved along.Upon leaving Anvers metro station and gazing up the hill to Sacre Coeur you could see more people that footpath.We had been warned that it was a busy destination but didn't expect quite so much.Disheartened we moved on down a few side streets and ended up baling through some gorgeous cobblestone streets with a hundredth the ammount of people.While a coffee was still at tourist prices, the architecture, the shopping and the general pace of the area was more than inviting enough to justify more than a few coffee breaks in the many patisseries and cafes spread throughout the west side of the Montmartre district,By the time we made our way up to Sacre Coeur we were far more Warrener with the area we had heard so much about and the view from upon the hill was spectacular. Especially with the sun shining gloriously from eart afternoon onwards.Well worth the trip, crowds or not, you can still find some peace in a beautiful area without venturing far.And in reality we are here as tourists and the Montmartre district was crowded for a good reason.

Great place. Montmartre shows the real soul of Paris.There you can find typical shops full of delicious French food; you can't miss the cheese, especially if you love the goat one! Montmartre is a mandatory place to visit if you want to understand the soul of Paris.
little town in a big city. Loved this place. Take a step out of Paris and still stay in Paris. Beautiful buildings and just totally French!!!

Must see district in Paris. Montmartre is an official historic district in Paris. It is in the 18th arrondissements and is on the Right Bank of the Seine. It is located about two or three miles north of Central Paris and the Seine River. The area gets its name from the 130 meter hill in the center of the neighborhood. I thought this area is very interesting and think it is a must see district in Paris. Historically many famous artists (including Degas, Toulouse-Lautrec, Renoir, and Pablo Picasso) lived in this neighborhood as it used to be outside the Paris city limits and the rents were low (it is now a trendy and expensive area to live).I stayed here with my wife for a week in late October and really enjoyed this lively and interesting neighborhood. Since Montmartre is a hill, expect to do a lot of walking and climbing up and down the hill if you stay or visit this area. A funicular railway carries tourists and locals from the bottom of the hill up most of the way to Sacré-Coeur (if you do not want to walk up the stairs). You need a metro ticket to get on it. While buying our metro ticket to go down the hill we were “helped” by a couple of scammers that tried to sell us tickets (that would most likely not be valid). We watched these people for a while as they tried to “help” almost every tourist that walked up to the metro ticket machine. There is also a small tourist train (Le Petit Train) that runs around the neighborhood that you can buy a ticket and get driven around to the major sights (you get headphones and can hear about the neighborhood in English).There are many different “parts” of this neighborhood but Montmartre's most recognizable landmark is the Basilica du Sacré-Coeur (you can even see it from many other parts of Paris). This area used to have many windmills but most are gone and the few remaining ones do not work (they are for show only). I enjoyed looking at these old windmills. There is also very touristy part of Montemartre but that is just a small part of this neighborhood. I recommend that you go on your own walking tour (download a tour map) or go on a guided walking tour. This is a great way to see most areas of the interesting areas of Montmartre (not just the t-shirt area below Sacré-Coeur). While I enjoyed this area my one complaint were the bracelet scammers near Sacré-Coeur that tied a string around your wrist and then asked for money and got aggressive if you do not pay them. I really enjoyed staying in this neighborhood and think it is a must see district when you are visiting Paris.
Nice for strolls!. A great area with touristic shops and lots of people and of cource, the beautiful church! Bought some souvenirs there for a nice prize!
Quaint Beauty. Viewing the local artists at work and having a great lunch at the corner bistro satifies the soul. Even in the misty day the view of Paris is beautiful

Loads to do even on a damp day. I was thinking of reviewing each of these individually, but that doesn't do justice to the whole Montmartre experience, Sacre Cour, and the views over Paris from its steps and Dome, Place du Tetre and the musee Montmartre, get there early and watch it fill up with painters and people. Coffee and lunch on any of the terraces around the square.

Nice artistic feel. Really easy to find! Take Metro to Anvers, step out of the metro and its just on the right. Walk all the way up and there is it! Remember to go behind the church from the left and the street is just there. Nice street with lots of souvenirs and paintings to buy. Lots of artist trying to get a sketch of you. They will try to get 50-60 euros from you, I paid 30 euros but heard its only 10~20 euros. However, the friends all says that the sketch doesn't look like me... sigh.

So lovely, so cute!. It's such a nice place to visit, preferably in the end of the afternoon. First take a hot chocolat, then just walk around. The ambiance, lovely shops, many artists. The typical Paris' atmosphere! A place to love
Montmartre in the rain. Even on a clouded drizzly day we were happy to visit the small streets of Montmartre. The painters, the tiny shops, the sacré coeur and the view are nice to see.

Beautiful and romantic !. I think this is my best place to visit once in Paris :) stunningly beautiful, romantic and breahtaking. Lovely alleys and architecture. Perfect for photos Shoots. PS. there are many artists (people dancing, singing, performing) make sure to stop by and watch:)

Loved it. This is great area and I really enjoyed wandering around the streets. We were staying locally and I found that some roads were thronged with tourists, yet others I was the only one. Which was great! Loved dipping in and out of all the amazing cheese shops, bakeries etc. There is loads to see and do in this area just walking around (including an amazing old cinema) and a wonderful street market with fish, veg and spices (I think it was on a Saturday?) under the subway line

Fabulous! as always. Sacre Coeur is lovely. The view from up there is lovely. Many of the artists selling their work in the streets, some say they seem to be selling art works done mass production, I felt much more a true sense of lovely ambiance. You won't find many budding Picasso's, but you'll find souvenirs of your trip.
The other famous church in Paris. Love this area and the placeYou can chill visit the churchGet yourself a portrait by the artistsYou get to experience the Typical Paris life style

Tourist Trap To Be Avoided. Overall, the area is a disgusting tourist trap that emphasizes the very worst aspects of humanity. As many others have said, the tourist industry (and the very worst part of the tourist industry) completely and utterly dominates this neighborhood of Paris. While it is a good jumping off point for some nearby nicer neighborhoods of northern Paris, the area immediately off the metro stop to the church itself is an utter hive and scum and villainy. If you only have a few days in Paris, don't waste one of them visiting Montmartre. If you have longer, it is worth a brief stop but nothing more.

A must go to place to relax and enjoy Paris. Mont Marte is a favourite spot around the globe. The cathedral is stunnning especially at night and there are many great photo spots. In the cathedral I like to go to the vaults below on a sunny day and the shadows and sunlight makes for tremendous contrast against the graves.To climb to the turrets in the cathedral is tiring but really well worth it as it is one of the vantage points.The old terraces below are a hive of activity, just beware the peddlers of junk and the pickpockets.So many bistro's and pubs to relax in and the food is good priced. All restaurants are fun.I spend 2-3 hours every trip in Paris and discover more each visit.

I wish I could have been there 100 years ago. Unfortunately, the tourist industry has taken over what must have been a charming area. Sacre Coeur is lovely. The view from up there is lovely. But so many things are tacky and designed to separate tourists from their money. Many of the "artists" selling their work in the streets seem to be selling art works done in factories, by mass production. You won't find any budding Picassos, but you'll find plenty of souvenirs with Montmartre or Moulin Rouge printed on them. If that's what you want to take home, then by all means go!
A must. When visiting Paris, you must take time to wander around Montmartre, poke into the shops, visit the artists and just enjoy everything Parisian!

Incredibly unique artistic place. You should visit Montmartre just to feel that espesial ambiance... You will really enjoy steep and cobbled streets of one of the most historic and interesting neighborhoods in Paris!! Don't forget about map not miss any sightseeings! The Basilica Sacre-Coeur, the Elysees Montmartre Theatre, famous Moulin Rouge, the Montmartre Museum - it's all Montmartre! The best onion soup we tried on Montmartre ) You can come into any cafe or bars and you will not be dissapointed.And galleries, artists...wonderful works!

Beautiful in the crisp cold winter! . We loved this area of Paris. We sat at the square for a long time just taking in the scenes around us before wandering around the streets. Love all the artist links and small cafés welcoming you in. You can't visit Paris without going for a nosey at the Moulin Rouge - just fantastic!
Lovely neighbourhood . Nice place to walk, few galleries. Moulin rouge and adult shops. A lot of beggars kind of ruin it... Not too busy even on a Saturday night

First visit to Paris. I took the yellow L'Open Tour Bus to Montmartre. I walked up the narrow streets from the bus stop to the Basilica at the top of the hill. There are many souvenier shops in the area, which are reasonably priced.
Fantastic View. Took the train and stayed for a few hours. Lots of nice little shops, street vendors, and great view of the city.

My Paris. This was the only place in Paris that I wasn't disappointed by. As soon as you walk out of the train station, you see a carousel, paved streets and a corner cafe, with an accordion busking next to it. It was beautiful, I found this gorgeous little antique perfume shop, and a lovely crèperie- truly epitomises Paris. The view from the top is amazing

Just wonderful. Beautiful, stunning, superb. Montmartre is my favourite place, from walking up the steps to the Sacré coeur, to the breathtaking view across Paris, to the cobbled streets and tiny squares - just wonderful.

Lost an iPhone. My husband and I walked from bus stop into this area to see church. Chuch and area up to it were beautiful. Beggars and venders were a huge turnoff to me. Painters were aggressive about doing a sketch - "5 minutes". Right. We had lunch were our hotel recommended. It was very good but expensive. My husband thinks left his cell phone on the table. I don't think so. I think he was pick pocketed by a woman we talked to.We called restaurant and had hotel call. We turned it off as soon as we got back to hotel. Don't know the value of iphone that has been turned off so I could be wrong. I wouldn't say avoid the area like in another review. It is worth seeing but be very careful.

For Art Lovers. To walk the streets Picasso and his contemporaries walked - to sit and absorb its bohemian atmosphere was worth the visit. At the entrance - prior to boarding the tram - it may get crowded, but once up there it is fine. I had been warned about pick pockets but I did not experience anything negative. Walking the streets behind the church and visiting the shops and galleries is recommended. Especially if you love the arts.

Not to be missed. Tucked away in one corner of the city of Paris is the neighborhood of Montmartre – a hill in the north of Paris, long known for being the creative hub of artists, and in more recent memory, made popular by movies such as Amélie and Moulin Rouge. Despite the urbanization, Montmartre managed to retain some of its distinct characteristics such as the old buildings, steep and narrow cobbled streets, and the rustic windmills.The best way to explore the village is on foot. You could either book a walking tour, or grab a map and start at the base of the village and make your way up the famous Basilica du Sacré-Coeur. Anvers is the nearest metro station that gives you access right to the base of the village. You will immediately notice the difference in the character of Montmartre and central Paris. The walk uphill is steep, but reaching the base of the Basilica on foot is quite manageable if you are young and fit. Alternatively, you can even take a mini train ride that goes around the neighborhood and up the Basilica. When you reach the base of the Basilica, the sheer beauty of the white-domed church will take your breath away. Sitting at the highest point in Paris, it offers breathtaking views of the city and in my opinion, is one of the most beautiful churches I have seen. The steep stairs greet you to take you up the church. You can also opt for a funicular ride up.From here, we took the mini train that takes you around the neighborhood and an audio guide introduces you to the hill-topped district. At just 6 euros per adult and 4 euros for child, the ticket is reasonably priced and the ride itself is very picturesque.Many cabarets, most notably the Moulin Rouge, and erotic shows continue to attract visitors to the area. The Place du Tertre, where a once penniless Picasso lived, is also a reminder of the time when Montmartre was a mecca of artists, as even today every morning artists set up their shops ready to paint the tourists who flock the area in large numbers.
Very pretty. See the famous artists, and walk along the beautiful cobbled streets. Lovely cafe's and so high up you can see the whole city

Enchanted district!. From far, this is my favourite part of Paris. Despite that well-known "arrogance parisiéne", here you will find curious people, mostly tourists, but above all, that spirit of old Paris.  As I live in Barcelona, I see so many common vibes which could make Montmartre brother with Raval (Bcn).  It is the first plave to visit if you love walking. And these streets have something mystical. The smell brings you back in time. And as a reward, you find on the top of the hill the Sacre Coeur! It is. for sure, a place to get lost and find yourself again. :)

It's all very "French". The area of Montmartre is what tourists naturally think of as being "typically French". And that is exactly what the painters, touts, "antique" shops and restaurants of Montmartre want you to think!! In fact, the truly "French" part of Montmartre is only seen as you walk slowly down the narrow streets towards Place de Clichy (of Moulin Rouge fame). There it is like a village in the middle of a city (but not at all commercial).The touristic market place is solid with painters, who have probably painted exactly the same thing 1,000 times, and touts who will cut out silhouettes of your head for a princely sum (they start cutting without asking, so learn to say "Non" before going there!). The restaurants, where you will be treated with Gallic shrugs and Parisian pouts to make you feel you are "really in France" are good at overcharging for very average fare, so stick to light snacks unless you have a large bank balance you want to get rid of. Oh - and keep a tight hold on your valuables since the area is well known for pickpockets.Apart from that, it's brilliant!!

Lovely Monmartre... I just love Monmartre.. A beautiful charming little city just behind Sacre Cour.. I love the Cobbled Streets, amazing little Cafes , Restaurants and so many talented artists who just paint you and you can take it as a souvenir. Make sure you plan your day accordingly, cover Sacre Cour and enjoy the sight of Paris and then visit Monmartre..Just take a walk around the place and enjoy the local aroma.. Must visit if you are in Paris.

Ahhh Beautiful Montmartre!. What a stunning little part of Paris. We went to visit the Sacre Couer, and did a little exploring of Montmartre. There are beautiful little restaurants, bakeries, curio shops, artists, chocolate shops, you name it in Montmartre! Its a beautiful place to visit and stay in Paris. I would recommend visiting when in Paris. Get ready for lots of walking up hills and stairs though so wear comfy and walkable shoes. We took an unforgettable walk from Montmartre to the Eiffel Tower and loved every second of it

Hand painted original artwork and a panoramic views, this is the place for you. Just be wary of the pickpockets.. Montmartre was the one place a colleague of mine told me I had to go on my visit to Paris. He informed me that it is up a big hill that you can climb (stairs of course). The only annoying part are the pick pockets, some of which very brazenly make physical contact with you pretending to give you something. Just make sure you keep your money in a zipped pocket or your hands in your pockets.Once at the top there is the Sacred Heart Basilica of Montmartre Sacre-Coeur (reviewed separately). Up there is a beautiful view of the city.Behind the cathedral is I suppose what could be called a really touristy area, full of restaurants and shops. However, in the middle of that is the real gem of the area: the artist’s area.These are not the cheap prints that you find along the River Seine but serious works of art, often hand painted right in front of you. We purchased two incredible works directly from the artist who was painting another as we purchased it. The art is not cheap, but the quality it worth it.It is unfortunate that the area is touristy and the pickpockets try to take advantage, but outside of that, the area is a must visit for the view and the artists.

be sure not to miss.... be sure not to miss..  If you are coming on foot from the center ready for a good walk, climb really hard, you better go some transport ... nice little restaurants .. ideal for ignorant tourists, street artists selling souvenirs ... all kinds of stuff

Cobbled arty parisian. Beautiful area of Paris old and authentic, scammers in abundance at foot of sacre couer, very intimidating with groups of men prowling to make money,their were gendarmes circulating which helps but please outlaw these scammers it spoils the whole ambience

Interesting Parisian Attraction - A Bit Crowded. A very eclectic mix of artists, although it felt quite touristy. Given it's history, you should probably visit the area anyway. It's a great spot to people watch if you can get out of the main flow of the crowd. We were there in September 2013. Weather was great with nice views. We enjoyed walking both up and back down the hilly streets to get there, but public transportation can get you there if you prefer.
