If you walk, you will pass and visit beautiful Montmartre Cemetery with many historic grave sites.We enjoyed a nice snack on a small patio with limited seating but in general, I didn't see much outdoor cafe type seating there.
Great cafes. Very nice walking, cafés are awesome, nice area to stay, lovely sights to see, iwatch out for scammers

A must do!. For me this is a must do EVERY time I come to Paris. I just love the eclectic collection of people (including pick pockets and con men) and art. It is especially nice if the weather is decent and all of the artist are out. I now have artist I buy from regularly here. To me it give you a true sense of old Paris of Toulouse Lautrec's time. Hold on to our Euros!

Relax, entertaining, beautiful place to be!!. This place is so awesome!! It is a good place to hang out and chill. We planned to watch Moulin Rouge and found out there were no tickets. Then we went out and hop on the little touring train. The train has music and songs, it is quite a pleasant ride. The little train can take you to the top of the hill. The little train has a couple of stops, and people can hop in and hop out. One of the stop is the Catherdral, do not miss the sunset view, overlooking the city, it is spectacular!! And on the mountain top stop, there are many restaurants, shops, musicians, artists. It is an awesome place to be! very alive and great!!

Amazing view of the city. Went to Montmarte this November. If u have the Paris transport ticket u can get a free ride upto the top by cable car, as there is quite a bit to walk. The view of paris from here is really nice. U can spend some time here even sitting around. There are several souvenir shops enroute. Nice way to spend some time late noon early evening.

Montmatre is awesome. A friend and I stayed in an Airbnb apartment in this area. We loved it. There was a little cafe called Hope Cafe just by us which was amazing as it had gluten free and vegetarian options - hard to find in Paris. It was a beautiful and safe feeling area. At the top of the hill is the Sacre-Coeur which is amazing and the area where all the artists do portraits. I had one done by a cool guy that does his in a comical way with big marker pens. Montmatre is so pretty, cobbles, old buildings, trees, cafes. Would stay here again for sure.

Our favorite part of Paris. Montmartre ended up being the higlight of our trip. Yes, it's commerciallized,a dn yesm it's touristy, but it's also where so many famous artists hung out. You can stand at the spot Renoir stood when he painted La Moulin de la Galette, imbibe at the club where Eidth Piaf was discovered or where Picasso downed more than a few, seer the real, one and only Moulin Rouge. Once away from the crowded square with its artists real and phony, you get real sense of what the place was like when it housed so many famous people. Our next trip to Patis will be centered there.

Wonderful neighborhood in Paris. I loved Montmarte... went here on a 2 hour walking tour and found it to be really beautiful and interesting. The cobbled streets are really pretty and there loads and loads of cafes and shops to keep you interested. The Sacre Coeur is stunning and the view of Paris from the top is really really cool! Make sure you wear good walking shoes .. the streets are steep and narrow . The Place du Tertre is a small square filled with artists who paint their own or offer to paint yours. I didn't buy any but i liked the vibe of the place.

Not that exciting....... Ok....if you've spent anytime in Le Marais, you won't neccesarily find Montmarte anything special. Apart from Sacre Couer I was a bit disappointed. My visit didn't live up to the hype...... The live art scene was one crowded square of bored looking artists hawking their wares. Some touted for business whilst others engaged in trying to replicate Mona Lisa's eyes on the faces of those tourists patient enough to sit still for ten minutes.....maybe I just didn't get it. Yes, I walked the back streets, ......yes, I visited the shops and galleries....and yes, I explored the grounds of Sacre Couer. Nope.......it wasn't working so I walked down the hill and patiently waited to be seated at Moulin Rouge. The show started and all was again well in the world.

Best atmosphere in Paris. The sights from Montmartre are beautiful, especially at night. The Sacre Coure is breathtaking. When I was there a wedding was going on outside on a warm summer evening and all the tourist got involved and we danced the night away. A must visit when in Paris.

Charming. The upper streets are the nicest, and there are some very nice gift shops. We went into an amazing chocolate shop which had scale models of attractions in Paris and I bought some delicious macaroons.

Such a lovely place. It's such a lovely place. I imagine Paris to have been this way before, cobblestone streets, nice little cafés and restaurants, artists everywhere... It's probably a bit cliché now but I still enjoy going there and wandering around the neighborhood, eating a nice warm crepe, looking at artists painting the old Paris or drawing people's portraits.Be careful though, for some people, drawing your portrait is a real business and they will harass tourists until they either leave or give in. Their prices are very high. For the same amount of money, or less, i'd rather go and see a true artist, on the square.

Art & Architectural Buff with a desire for true Parisian experience. I LOVE MONTMATRE! Pro's - trying to preserve as much as the authentic Paris as possible. Lots of fun cobblestone streets to wander and get lost in - it is what one thinks Paris should be like. Many famous artists (painters, singers) once lived in Montmatre and if you know where to look or let yourself get lost and take your time you will find many hidden gems. Lots of authentic markets for fresh meats, flowers, cheeses, one woman was on the corner with a baby goat handling out samples - it's charming! Take a tour with a local that knows the history and can share sites and history no tour bus will give you nor would you know on your own...just not in tour guide books. Con's - as you arrive on the metro you will probably come out around Moulin Rouge, do not let this avenue of bars, clubs, sex shops deter you. This is the only negative for some. Head up the hill and you will experience something like no other part in Paris. Make it to the top and walk through Sacre Couer, Amazing.

What a great place to experience. We enjoyed Montmartre as members of a 2 hour night tour of the area. Apart from the cold we thoroughly enjoyed the experience. From the red light district, to the artists stories, to the Sacre Couer, to the music on the hill, then the restaurants, there was nothing to not enjoy. We will be back there again we enjoyed it so much. Next time we will try it in daylight to see if there is a difference
Wonderful and cute neighborhood . Great place to walk around narrow streets lined with art and curiosity shops. Have your caricature drawn in the town square, and walk through the Sacre Couer.
Wonderful artist section of the city. Many artists here, many opportunities to purchase your own painting. Also features lovely views of the city.
Sunny days. Montmartre is a great place to go on sunny days. After admiring the interior of Sacre Coeur, make your way down to the grassy area, take out a book, enjoy the view and just relax.

Cute Neighborhood. We stayed in the Montmartre area during our honeymoon and loved it. There were lots of little shops and restaurants and of course beautiful apartment buildings. Lots of the streets were cobblestone and climbing the hill after a rain was a little challenging. The Red Light area on the Boulevard de Clichy at the base of the hill was, um, interesting, but other than that the rest of the neighborhood was cute.

Lovely neighborhood but also a tourist trap. The Basilica's tower tour make this place worth visiting for a tourist, and harp player on the steps of the Basilica, the winding old streets, artists bazaar, and cute neighborhoods add to its appeal. We found most of the shops & restaurants to be a little too touristy with mediocre product & food. Yelp/Trip Advisor can help make it more pleasant. Artists will also approach wanting to sell you a caricature or drawing just good enough for your junk drawer at home.Wander too far down the hill, and you'll find yourself in the trashy Adult district where the Moulin Rouge resides. This is not a place you want to be if you are a family.

A top day on the top of Paris. Up the hill, you can't miss it. Grab a seat outside the restaurant that sells cold beer, and watch the amazing parade of humanity. From one to a hundred they all come to be a Parisian, even if it's just for an hour. Try to fit in an hour on the steps under the church where world class busking is on offer... Amazing!
Went twice!. We liked Montmartre so much we went twice on our trip. The cemetery was incredible and the basilica was beautiful. We found cute little gifts to bring home.

Art atmosphere. Nice place to see artistic people and painters. Everyone is suggesting to do draw your portrait. A variety of nice cafes with tasty coffee, where you can sit and see how painters drawing their pictures.
Nice Basillica and a few cafes. Quite a contrast from the rest of Paris, this area is worth a visit for impressive photos of the Basillica and to wander around.

Do yourself a favour - spend a day, just wander & get lost. Monmartre is many things. It is the cool bohemian arts centre, the touristy bit, the history, the community. Do the touristy thing & get a caricature or silhouette or something (I got a silhouette which was pretty good & not too expensive) - it's a fun experience & a nice souvenir, but also wander through the back streets & little lanes & experience the community as well. Stop in a little cafe for coffee, have lunch somewhere, check out the old vineyard, experience the street music, & appreciate the artists . One of my favourite things to do anywhere is to just go wandering in cities and neighbourhoods to get a feel of the place, and in this regard, I think Montmatre is one of the best places for a 'walking tour' anywhere. Don't even bother with a map, just get lost for a few hours & enjoy. It has such a wonderful 'vibe'. Be aware that it is pretty hilly with some steep steps in places, so probably not recommended for those with mobility issues. Fantastic day out!

Montmartre. I stay in Montmartre for my few days in Paris... But I didnt get to see the magic behind it. Guess when i get to comeback I'll get to enjoy the nightlife a little bit more.Sure a nice place to stay... Very convenient... Thanks for recieving me!!! C:

Nice.. My wife and I visited Montmarte - especially in view of her being an artist and having her own gallery in Mcgregor. We were not disappointed but the people offering to draw your picture on the streets were really no better than hawkers selling their wares! I am not being nasty - it is all so contrived! We took the metro to Anders and walked up between all the traders until the funicular up 5 the Sacre Coeur. After that we meandered back down -stopping for some delicious onion soup at a small cafe called cafe montmarte. Could not find it on trip advisor. We were lucky it was a beautiful sunny day.

Excellent. Spend a day. A beautiful Parisian neighborhood. Be prepared to walk, go up and down a lot. Would recommend you get the highest metro station and than go down the . A lot of stuff to see and houses, cafes, restaurants. A bit expensive tho, but normal to other paris region prices.

One of my favorite days in Paris. I absolutely loved our day in Montmartre. We left early and walked from our hotel on the Rue de Rivoli, despite people telling us it was too far to walk. It was a very pleasant walk and we began by going to the Sacre-Coeur. The place is very hilly with lots of steps so you don't want to make too many wrong turns, so my smart phone GPS came in very handy, as it wasn't the easiest of places to navigate. Then we went for a walk around Montmartre and watched street performers perform French music and dancing which was very enjoyable and added lots of ambiance to the place. We went for a wonder around the artists and purchased a little painting each from one of the artists. Beware there are some scammers, so we watched carefully and saw this artist put paint to canvas, and we love them as a little souvenier of this wonderful day. After this we went and had lunch at the Moulin de la Galette which was lovely, full of character and very nice food. Then we walked back to our hotel via the Moulin Rouge to see it in the day light. An extremely enjoyable day with lots of character and charm.

Montmartre a wonderful place. Montmartre is a unique place , with a whole different vibe of the Paris down the hill. Its arty and its cute . I like to eat a big bowl of Moules Frites in one of the cafes overlooking where the artists paint on the square , and just soak up the atmosphere there. Hundreds of years back it was a separate village with its own vineyard even , a little of which survives today. If you happen to be there for the once a year guilds parade you will see a spectacular sight as the local craftsmen, businesses and workers all march through Montmartre in their respective costumes with their banners. Montmartre from the outlook near scare Coeur, overseas some of the most spectacular views of Paris . Walking back down the steps and hill is easier than walking up there .

Artist's village. I loved walking through Montmarte - seeing all of the artist's out painting, sketching, etc. was really cool. A bit dirty (even for Paris) but it was beautiful and there were some fun shops and restaurants. Read up on the scams before you go - especially near Sacre Couer - it's not unsafe, you're just likely to get hustled if you're not aware of what to avoid (e.g. don't accept a free red rose, let anyone tie a piece of string on you and/or sign a petition).

Beautiful place. Great view on top of the hill. There are many peddlers selling stuff like souvenirs n toys and even a live band . Behind it you can find many eateries n restaurants n many artists painting at the square.

Don't miss this when in Paris. I think the best area to visit is Montmartre due to its uniqueness, charm, and historical significance. If you want to see where the modern artists lived and worked, such as Dali's museum, this is the place. The Sacre Coeur church is magnificent and there are many great cafes/restaurants. Artists encircle the square. It is very charming and different, so make an effort to go there.

One of my favorite place in Paris. You cannot visit Paris without going to Montmartre. Is a very nice and typical laid back French atmosphere. Located in a hill having the Sacre Coeur and Place du Tertre like the main landmarks you can relax couple of hours during your active vacation in Paris. Plenty of restaurants and cafes, different type of shops, interesting small fashion boutiques fulfill the enchanting atmosphere. During the day can be pretty busy with crowds of tourists coming to visit the area, therefore the best way to visit the place is late afternoon and early evening.

Excellent, Brilliant. A must visit in the evening to spend time and relax. You never really realise the place till you actually reach. Its surprisingly at a lot of height and has an amazing feel to the whole place. One will eventually end up spending close to an hour just seeing around and enjoying the breeze. Good eating places adjoining to finish off the day.

Worth staying in Montmartre and exploring. We have been to Paris before and been to the usual tourist attractions, but only seen Montmartre in the distance. We decided on this visit to stay a couple of nights at a hotel just off the main areas of the area. We found that a map and walking were the best way of exploring, though the area is hilly. The coffee and beer/wine breaks were appreciated.There are two sides to Montmartre. In the day, there is the Sacre-Couer and other tourist sites to visit and enjoy. In the evening we walked to the Rue Lepic and Rue des Abesses area where there are local shops selling meat, fish etc and a number of excellent restaurants including many in the smaller back streets. Worth hunting around. We enjoyed staying in Montmartre for a couple if days and would recommend it.

Lovely heart of Paris. Montmartre is a lovely enjoyable area of Paris with narrow streets and many shops selling souvenirs of Paris as well as many restaurants many of which can be described as budget restaurants. There are many such shops and restaurants on Rue Rochechouart, and when leaving the avenue to take the small streets the go towards the hill on the top of which the famous Sacré Coeur is located. Still, on the small streets, more shops and restaurants are found. One should be beware of the pickpockets. Montmartre is still better than the adjacent area called Pigalle. After I came across a pickpocket at Nation station when taking the RER, I learnt to put on a zipped coat not to leave any pocket accessible.
Romantic place not only for couples. It's my favourite disctrict in Paris. Such an amazing, sometimes calm place. Beautiful architecture. I can just walk there and enjoy it. Recommend to everyone!

Stunning church on top of the city. Montmartre is on the top of a very steep hill in the artists' quarter of Paris. Once you get to the top of the hill, you are rewarded with a magnificent view of the city and yet another stunning architectural masterpiece of Christian design. Watch for thieves and peddlers but enjoy the free self guided tour through the church.

Just the atmosphere makes you want to stay!. Small jovial coffee shops and restaurants just make part of the scenery, there is a very distinct laid back friendly vibe all around here that's quite hard to describe in words but so easy to become enchanted by.

Quite a rough area. We got off the metro at the Chateau Rouge stop and immediately realised it was a less than savoury part of Paris when we saw three drug addicts smoking crack in the metro station!! Climbing the stairs to street level, we were touched and grabbed at by men trying to sell us food etc and there were a lot of beggars, homeless people etc. There was a really dangerous feel to the place and we were very intimidated. However after a five minute walk we came out into a much safer area and approached the steps up to the Sacre Coeur Basilica, which made it worth the journey!

Stop in Time. Hello Travellers, I think Paris is so fascinating because it feels you have stopped in time.You have all kind of áreas this one is all about artists you have art painting its a pitoresque place right up the Sacre Coeur that is a beau too.Go there take a walk, drink a coffee and watch the people.A little bit more down you have Pigalle and the Famous Moulin Rouge.Unmissable!!!!

Amazing area of Paris. We had a whirlwind trip to Paris and really recommend Montmartre - we ate excellent boeuf bourgignonne then wandered and saw the Eiffel Tower lit up in the distance with a sliver of a moon in the background, a beautiful square with really talented artists sketching away and finally the lovely Sacre coeur on a Sunday evening complete with a singing nun and candles galoreLeft feeling replete in every way !

Lovely. Great place. It's obligatory to visit. One of my favorite. You can freely buy some cofee or wine, take a seat on a hill and watch over the Paris, look the street shows. Want to go there again =)

My favorite part of Paris. I loved walking around where Monet, Renoir, Van Gogh, and Picasso used to roam. You must climb the steps to The Basilica of the Sacre Coeur (I lost track by 200+ steps), and get a grand view of the city. The funicular wasn't operating at the time of our visit, but it was good to walk off all the crepes and other good food we had consumed.

ONE OF THE BEST PLACES IN PARIS. On the top of a hill, you can enjoy a great view of Paris. You can use your metro ticket to use the telephrique or climb the stairs. The Church (though new architecture) is very nice to visit. Shops and restaurants are below the hill and the prices there are the best for souvenirs. Worth visiting also at night.

A great place to get a view of the city.. Lots of steps to climb, but the view is great. I also found the church to be impressive ... and when we went inside there was a choir of nuns singing ... so we had to sit down and listen.

My favorite neighborhood in Paris. Montmatre reminds me of the village in NYC except it is hilly and much older in years. As in any urban area, be careful of street vendors (a lot near Sacre Couer). Just a fun place to walk around, explore, and have fun.

Montmartre. This is one of Paris's must see attractions. It's really beautiful at Montmartre, but beware of the scammers that hang around there. I only stayed for a short time because I was continually being harassed by people trying to scam money from me. There was a group of gypsy girls posing as deaf girls asking for donations and trying to pickpocket. There was a group of African men who insisted on tying a string around my finger because they allege it's tradition. I had to threaten to call the police to get away from them. I had a friend who let them put the string on his finger then he had to give them money to get it off. On a positive note, the view near the Cathedral is great and it really is a nice place just to walk around the streets.

Gone to the dogs a bit. Once you get past the pushy African gentlemen at the bottom of the steps to Sacre Coeur, and all the 'artists' and hawkers at the top of the steps, it's actually quite a nice area. The cafes and markets are nice during the day, but at night it shuts down and gives way to the seedier side of the area.Luckily I knew enough French to dissuade the gentleman at the bottom of the stairs from pursuing his bracelet scam. Keep your wits about you, and avoid travelling here on your own at night.

A ''tourist trap'' that is well worth a visit!. This is one of Paris' major tourist clichés; Artist's Quarter at the top of Montmartre is always well stocked with (too much) tourists, but still, one can take help but love this place! Plenty of restaurants, outdoor cafes and coffee shops but also 'artists' that make a painting of you' for no money at all "... The quality is diverse but still not exactly poor. The most fun is to just sit at a pavement café and watch all the people walking by! I have been here for several seasons and, as with the rest of Paris, the spring and fall are absolutely the most beautiful. Do not miss a peek into the beautiful Sacre Coeur, and take the most magnificent panoramic picture all over town!
Must visit place. Wery nice and beautiful part of Paris. You must visit this place. Many painters and mini cafe at this place
Good place to visit. a must visit place for photographer. Easy to access by Paris metro. Many good restaurant and street activities

Absolutely beautiful. Just like any other part of Paris, Montmartre is beautiful.Known for it's mills that u'll find around the corners, packed with some amazing restaurants and great art.I love the charming narrow streets and the steps!

Splendid area of Paris. My family had an apartment for 7 nights off Rue Ordener. Short walk to Sacre Coeur Basilica, Jules Joffin metro station. Plenty of bakeries and supermarkets close by. Sitting on the steps in front of the Basilica sipping beers listening to buskers was relaxing. Market on the weekend was busy. Restaurants are great. Overall top spot.

Charming, must-see. Reviews I read about Montmartre were somewhat negative--that it is touristy with over-priced shops and restaurants. I just loved it, though. I loved the narrow charming streets, the artists displaying their pieces, the I Love You Wall. It's a happenin' place. There was a young Parisian violinist and a cellist playing on the side steps of Sacre Coeur. Their heavenly music made my day. Hearing that music and seeing those young women play, colored everything I experienced up in Montmartre. We enjoyed touring a small museum featuring Utrillo and giving a history of Montmartre. We had a wonderful lunch outside. The food was really good but even better, we were served by an older woman and man who were VERY kind. I bought a bright little oil painting. The artist packed it carefully for travel. Whenever I look at it, I will remember that beautiful day up in Montmartre.
So Paris!. I loved this place. It was everything I pictured Paisian artist would be. It was a fun place to see. We ate our lunch and watched the artists paint!

Absolutely delightful. How I wish we had stayed in this area! We visited for just one day, to see Sacre Coeur , and the only downside is the steps to the metro (there is a lift as well!). When we arrived, I was desperate for the loo, and although we later discovered there were plenty, on arrival we couldn't find one, so I popped into a local cafe and asked if I could use theirs. They were so accommodating and friendly, and I was extremely grateful! We used the funicular to access Sacre Coeur, which was absolutely gorgeous, so peaceful and beautiful, with spectacular views across Paris. Chris and I both felt completely relaxed on the grass, watching all the visitors enjoying the atmosphere which is so different to downtown Paris.
Pretty. Very touristy/crowded area, but nice to walk around regardless! Be sure to check out Sacre Coeur basilica!

Crowded, but Fun. Be sure to visit the Sacre Coeur basilica, and wander around la Place Du Tertre, lots of time for people watching, check out the artists there, very touristy but fun. Watch out for pick pockets, and pick up a souvenir or two.

Very pretty.. Montmartre is a really nice place to walk around in good weather. Lots of places to eat; lots of little shops to duck into here and there. Some touristy and lame (Diwali for example) and some rather nice. It's just a pretty place. There's even plenty to see on the way there and back. Definitely one of my favorite areas.

such a shame. Monmartre should be wonderful, a part of old Paris. Unfortunately tourism has destroyed the charm of this area. The shops cater for the throngs of tourist that invade the area, the "artists" want to draw your likeness and take your money. Too many people, too many shops selling ubiquitous eiffel tower souvenirs. Try to leave the top of the hill, wander down the streets to the bottom, the cafes there are a little more authentic, certainly less crowded and touristy. But, the view from the Monmartre is wonderful, the Sacre Cour is beautiful, but beware the scammers. Despite all this make the effort to go there, walk down the stairs in front of Sacre Cour and see the merry go round. Take great photos of the windmills, the grape vines, and of course the beautiful stairs. Remember, you are in Paris, love the city, in all its imperfect beauty.
Lovely. Hiking to it certainly gets the heart pumping but when you get there it's a beautiful place, very bohemian. A very family friendly atmosphere.

Overrated. A tourist destination full of tourist cheap Paris gifts. Sure you get to see Paris from above, but you obtain a better experience from the Effiel Tower. The artists simply scout the tourists for portraits. But nothing special.The cathedral is is just like every other spectacular European cathedral. Easy to get to by bus (number 95) just down from the Musee d'Orsay.

A Interesting place to visit. Montmatre is an interesting location. Located at the top of a hillside, the most significant site is the Basilica, overlooking Paris. The Basilica's interior is very pretty and very well maintained. In front of the Basilica is the best place to view Paris.Around the corner from the Basilica is the town square, with all types of souvenir shop, ice cream shop, sidewalk cafes and most of all a lot of artist walking around with a pad ready to draw your portrait. The city square has art exhibits around all 4 sides along with artists in the process of drawing at portrait. It is interesting the see the different styles and kinds of art work all in on small area.It is a very busy location but something you should do if you have the time.

Don't miss this. Hilly and charming. We went during the wine festival. Lots of stands wine and food. Take the funicular to sacre couer for views of Paris. Walking here is a challenge. bought a little painting as souvenir

Great ambience to this part of paris!. The views from the basilica are panoramic across paris... But the best surprise for me was the FABRIC shops (near the base of the steps below the basilica) leave your man at the cafe where he can enjoy beer and good pizza while you wander through the most amazing textile, fabric and haberdashery superstores!,, you will need two visits to just scratch the surface of what is available ! Buy an extra piece of hand luggage from the tourist street, to take your goodies home!! The artists square is also interesting..

One place you can't miss in Paris. This place has an old world charm to it that you simply cannot miss. I have been to Paris before and due to lack of time could not visit this place. And after being here I realised what I missed.This place is gorgeously beautiful. We went during the wine festival in October 2014. The place was bustling. We had a fantastically sunny day. There are artists all over sketching and showcasing their art. The cathedral is beautiful and you have the most stunning view of the entire city of Paris from the top. There are numerous cafes serving great food and fresh salads. The perfect way to enjoy is to sit outside in a Cafe, soaking the sun, a bottle of wine, good food made with local produce, as you take in the surroundings and art. This is an adorable village area of Paris which is absolutely breathtaking.You simply cannot miss this!
Amazing. We were in the montmartre at the wine festival and had a blest. Very nice people and a fine wine and cheese Enjoy every minute at this lovely quarter

A taste of the country. Walking through and around Montmartre is definitely one of the highlights of my trip. There are beautiful buildings and cobblestones and vineyards and fountains everywhere. Very relaxing and nice.
Montmartre. Charming village atmosphere. Full of artists and shops and generally buzzing. Delightful walk to reach the Sacre Coeur and cafes.

fantastic. this is the best part of Paris its what you imagine Paris to be, little cafes , nice little shops , music playing ,artists painting, a great atmosphere, welcoming to tourists, unlike the rest of Paris.

Good view point for Paris City. LIke any other city center point in europe. Small, quite & charming. You can admire the less than impressive paris skyline among the throngs of tourists and might be lucky to get a good photograph. You can enjoy the evening sitting at the steps sipping a beer bought from the vendors roaming around. Some street performance is always on at the view point and provides a great way to kill time in the district

Must see once.. I arrived to sacre coeur on a Sunday. Mistake, there was a festival which was nice,but very very crowded, difficult to walk. I was able to see the view and part of the church, then we went down some stairs to the side of the church and found a wonderful spot for lunch, a nice outdoor cafe with very good food and service. We could not walk down the stairs in front of the church due to crowds. Walking around after lunch was fun. Lots of quaint shops....

So much to see and do !. Of course there is the Sacre Couer but Montmartre has so much more to offer. We did a street walking tour which I found on the internet and I am so glad we did. You arrive away from tourist central and meander your way down back streets and get a real feel for the true Montmartre. You come in the back of the Sacre Couer and avoid the pickpocket problem. You can ride the funicular railway up to the Sacre Couer if you come in from below or take the stairs. The walk took us to see Place Constantin Pecquer, Place Dalida, Maison Rose, Le Clos Montmartre, Au Lapin Agile, Sacre Couer, Eglise Saint Pierre de Montmartre, Place de Tetre, Dali Museum, Passe Muraille, Moulin de la Galette, the I Love You wall and Abysses Station where we caught the Metro back to Paris central. Do explore this part of Paris because you will be missing out if you don't.

Wine festival in Montmarte 11.10.14. Nice place to see Paris from this highest place, amazing view. Lots of restaurants near the church. For old people I will recommend to arrive with taxi and not with the metro, as there are lots of stairs up to the top from Abbesses metro station. Very nice and romantic place. Watch out from thieves pockets.

Awesome Place....you have to see it. We saw this Church at night...the inside was closed. There still was a lot to see on the outside. Best of all you can see all of Paris. It is a definite stop on your tour list. You could also see the Eiffle tower from here. It is a long hike up the stairs or you can take the train up. I say hike the stairs! There were a lot of people out there when we went. They had beer bottles and can everywhere. It was sad that people would do such a thing to the church.

must visit. a must visit when in Paris! So beautiful with spectacular views! Bought a couple of hand painted views of Paris here and really wish I had bought a larger one. such an artsy place.be aware of beggars!

Oasis in Paris. We were pleased to see that there was a funicular to the top here, Metro tickets worked on it. The first area that you enter around the square is a little tacky and we were hassled by several artists wanting to do paper cutout portraits or cartoons of us. We headed off down a sidestreet and escaped the worst of the tourist trap part. We found a quiet area next to the Dali exhibition and sat and had our picnic. The history of the place permeates everywhere. We found the vineyard on the hillside and L'agile Lapin. Look up and still you see the glass roof lights on current day flats that are still used as artists' studios. Loved it.

A hidden gem in Paris!. We took the funicular up to visit the Basilica du Sacre Coeur de Montmartre in Paris & stumbled across this beautiful, quaint neighborhood filled with lots of local artists displaying their artwork! This place is a great place to enjoy outdoor cafes& shops! LOVED THIS PLACE!!!

A favorite neighborhood. Loved the sites and everything about this beautiful area. Several artist sites and loads of history surrounding artists lives and inspiration. Very picturesque and quaint neighborhoods.

Arty and yet slightly unsavoury. The area is great in certain streets but in others I felt unsafe for the first time since an unexpected area of Naples! the Basilica and the markets are great! The artist area is intriguing and has a lot of history! Some of the restaurants and cafes are fabulous and serve decent portions! Well worth a trip! Though I'd be doing a lot of homework before I stayed in this suburb again!
Enchanting. Went early morning to avoid crowd & it pays off to see this enchanting monument in tranquil atmosphere. Awesome from outside, calming inside & great view of the city from balcony !
Great Area. After visiting the Sacre Coeur Basilica we walked around the area exploring the cobbled streets and stopping for coffee at a sidewalk cafe.
Our favourite location. This was our favourite area in Paris for spending our evenings. Based on the advice of our tourguides, we tied a few restaurants/cafes which were all excellent.

What a dump!. We were recommended to stay in Monmartre by friends, but we wish we had not followed their advice.Monmartre is run down, polluted and not the romantic getaway we expected. I would not recommend staying in this area, unless you want to feel uneasy every time you leave or return to your apartment. It may once have been a beautiful area, but now it is full of trash, dog poo, smells of urine and plenty of crummy takeaway shops.Monmartre was easily our least favourite area of Paris.

Fun area and BEAUTIFUL views. We arrived via the metro and hiked the hill to Sacre Coeur - spectacular! The church, the hill, the setting, the harp-player on the steps - it was all amazing! We walked through the neighborhoods, bought some lower-priced souvenirs, tried the French hot chocolate - melted chocolate with crème freche on the side, wandered through the sexed-up Moulin Rouge area and wandered on to the Marais for a multicultural, multi-ethnic array of shops and afternoon treats - coffee, wine, small plates. It was a fun immersion in local and diverse culture.

Now it feels like Paris!. Wonderful walk up the hill to Montmartre, charming streets bustling with shoppers, quaint restaurants, row upon row of artists painting and selling their wares, and the incredible Church of the Sacred Heart. Wonderful day in Montmartre.
Caveat Emptor. A quaint arty hillside location dominated by the Sacre Coeur but unfortunately tainted by hoards off tourists, litter, touts and the high risk of being pickpocketed, Tread carefully!

My favor!. One of my favor places in Paris.The magic atmosphere that Montmartre is providing with the street artist’s (painters/musicians) and the small back streets is something that you need to feel. Sit in small restaurant, enjoy a glass of wine and let yourself to relax watching this nice area with the people passing by. Also you can enjoy a very nice walk from square within the back romantic streets and visit the small beautiful souvenir shops. Recommended 100% to visit specific area especially early afternoon and stay their till evening.Only disadvantage is that you need to be very careful with your belongings as in specific area there are some strange people.

Great. Fantastic atmosphere. We had 3 hours here as part of our tour. The Cathedral is obviously a place to visit but go for a walk along some of the streets as well and see the windmills, the vineyard, the cobble streets, the artists square, the cafes etc. Lots of souvenir places and lots of artists willing to tell you how good looking you are :-) The whole place has an atmosphere like a fair...highly recommended.

Sacre Coeur. This church is simply magnificent, and on a sunny day it stands out like a beacon above the city of Paris. We found getting there easy thanks to the excellent subway system (by the way, we recommend buying a caret, or 'book' of 10 tickets versus the pass). The walk up the many steps to the church is not for the faint of heart, although there is a funicular available. We opted to do the 6 euro climb up to the very top of the dome, and were rewarded with splendid views of Paris. The artists' district surrounding Sacre Coeur elicits memories of Toulouse Lautrec, Picasso and other artists who called this area home. Not too far from the Moulin Rouge.

Real France...but a lot of tourists. We thought Montmartre was lovely, albeit full of tourists. It is some way north of the centre of Paris on a steep hill with stunning views of Paris. The gem is the church of Sacre Coeur but the whole area is lively and interesting.We spent a happy afternoon strolling round seeing the sights including the museum, the vineyard and the cemetery. All were interesting in their own way...and the restaurants and cafes were inviting..Next door to Sacre Coeur is the church Saint-Pierre de Montmartre which is worth a visit.But a word of warning. The hills are steep and there are many flights of stairs to negotiate.

Lovely area for a stroll. My husband and I walked from the Moulin Rouge, through the Montmartre area on our way to the Sacre-Coeur. We really enjoyed the walk. So much so that we stopped at a cafe to have a drink, people watch and just take in the atmosphere.

What an atmosphere. Super atmosphere with painters, singers, and musicians. I would recommend sitting out for lunch and just watching the world go by. We sat in one of the restaurants of the square and listened to the local lady singing in French. It was just a bliss!

Nice Place to view Artists!. This area is a nice place to have your portrait done by people who do this all of the time. There are a lot of tourists around if you don't mind crowds. The area covers about 2 - 3 city blocks with many places to eat around the the square.

Do it the Parisian way. It was my second visit here and this time I decided to soak in the afternoon sun on grass in front of sacre coure. I stopped at mono prix and bought a salad and small bottle of wine and picnicked like a true Parisian! What a lovely experience and far better than sitting in a fancy restaurant with other tourists paying a fortune to get the front table when you can sit on the grass and get the beautiful view of paris! If you are wanting to enjoy a good meal though there is a lovely Italian restaurant called il duca on 26 rue Yvonne le tac. Well worth it but ensure to book! Oh and don't allow the guys selling stuff to get to you remember it's your holiday and once you say no they will go away. Best to just not speak to them and they get the message! Enjoy!

Beautiful. My boyfriend and I went to Paris for the first time and got an apartment there. If you're looking for a non-touristy, Persian area, Montmartre is the place to be. I loved it, and found it to be much better than being surrounded by tourists because I got to experience a more Persian lifestyle.

Hidden treasure. I found this on trip advisor and when our hop on off tour stopped here I was pleased. We stayed about two hours but I could have stayed all day. So many souvenir shops, cheap clothing but lots of junk in boxes, lunch places, beautiful sights, a delicious macaroon shop and the guy was great and I wish I had returned and bought macaroons. It's a little hilly and quite a few steps so wheelchair people would definitely struggle. Allow hours to take your time. The church at the top of the hill is worth going inside.

One of our favorite areas. Loved this quaint area! On the tip of the host of our B&B, we took the line 4 towards Clignancourt & got off at "Barbes Rochechouart" and switched to Line 2 and got off at "Blanche". Once we got off the subway, the Moulin Rouge was right in front of us. We headed up Lepic Street and split a delicious cookie at les petits Mitrous before heading to dinner at Al Caratello (yum). After dinner, we continued our way to Sacre Coeur. It was beautiful to see the city all lit up at night on top of the hill! We then went back to see it again during the day. Lots of gift shops and cafes. I purchased paintings of Paris at very reasonable prices.

A real tourist trap!. We have been to Montmartre perhaps half a dozern times in the past and have always enjoyed it. Perhaps this time we picked a bad day. The place was heaving and it was not a pleasure fighting your way around the painters' square. There were all sorts of "entertainers" intent on relieving tourists of their hard-earned cash - including a man who had a parrot which he placed on peoples' shoulders for the inevitable photo...at a price. The area in front of the Sacre Cour was so crowded we didn't feel inclined to visit this time around. Also lots of "traders" trying to sell water, beer, cheap trinkets etc. In short, the horrors of mass tourism were brought home to me. Next time we'll visit early morning before the hordes descend on it!

I like this neighborhood.... I didn't experience any routing like some other reviewers did. We walked from the main square where there were artists displaying their works to Moulin Rouge area. Overall, it was an enjoyable walk around this cosy neighborhood.

Montmartre - beautiful. You could catch the metro (best stop is Abbesses), or take an easy paced walk from the city (40-60 minutes) through a couple small Parisian city vineyards and passed beautiful French terrace houses. Definitely worth a visit, with plenty eateries around the area. Any of them are great. The clothing boutiques are fab too. Including a GREAT little vintage shop - although crammed it's tidy and has some of the best hats and coats at super prices (EUR 5-40).

'Amélie' and other hidden areas. Montmartre is so much more than just the Sacre Coeur and Place du Tertre. Favoured by the 19th C Impressionists, it is still home to artists, singers and poets and is often used as a location for films. This is as authentic as Paris gets, especially in the hidden back streets away from tourists. Behind the Sacre Coeur there is a small vineyard and the quaint bar 'Au Lapin Agile'. Nearby is St Vincent cemetery and a square named after French singer Dalida. Her mansion is close by. The restaurant Moulin de la Galette is worth seeking out. It was painted by Van Gogh, Picasso and Renoir. Fans of the film 'Amélie' can find the grocers shop at 56 Rue 3 Frères. The café where Amelie works is Café des 2 Moulins on Rue Lepic, close to the Moulin Rouge.

A beautiful spot in Paris.... Montmartre is one of the liveliest places in the city of Paris. It's packed with fascinated tourists and cheerful young people. The crest is quite steep, but you can take the funiculary if you are not really fond of climbing stairs. I advise you to take your time examining Sacre Coeur, which is one of the most wonderful buildings in Paris. After that, have your portrait drawn by a street artist: it's definitely worth your money.

Online self-guided walking tour with photos was outstanding!. Must try www.paris48.com/montmartre-walk.HTML for your best sights with the least hassle, hawkers, and very few tourists! You begin not at the funiculaire but at a different Metro stop, and come through the back way and even to the back side of Sacred Cour. While this tour recommends against lunch in the Place du Tertre, we prefer it. Otherwise, an outstanding way of doing this section of Paris. I have done several tours here and this was terrific! We were very safe and comfortable along the way and while there were some steps, most of the tour was gentle in that regard.

Montmarte. Not sure I can recommend this area. I even saw a hotel I considered staying in. Let me tell you it had a series of red lights in front which given the area was fitting-though the hotel was nothing like that. It's just a bit iffy at night. However some people like that. I would liken it to a downtown area of NYC.

One of my favourite places!. We spent a couple of days in and around this area - it's one of my favourite places.Had two evening meals - two different restaurants. Both set menus which cost €15 and €19. The best French onion soup I've ever tasted!In the Sacre Coeur itself we sat and listened to the nuns singing Evening song... Truly beautiful!The only slight downside is the price of the drinks, but you are in one of the most beautiful places in the world!We had NO problem with the touts - we just politely said "no thanks" and they accepted that!Enjoy!

Enjoyed our visit but spoilt by touts.. Four of visited Montmartre on recommendation by a fellow traveller that it shouldn't be missed. We did enjoy the visit but feel that it is spoilt by the touting, the scammers and overdone with artists many of whom are pretty average. The cobbles street are nice but spoilt by so many cheap quality tourist gift shops. Made in China gifts are not what I went to Paris or Montmartre for. The best part of the visit was to the Love Wall . Don't bother with Moulin Rouge , it is an expensive tourist trap. Better quality dancers n Australia.

Very quaint district spoilt by touts. It is a very lovely place with old style cobbled streets and cafes, small shops, etc.... There is a small square where artists show off their works and even pretend to paint a bit. I last visited almost 30 years ago and this small square was packed with artists genuinely painting and less interested in tourists and vistors than on their works. Now its a totally commercial operation with bars extending their space into the square and limiting artists to only the fringes.I bought a couple of original pieces (the copies are done by art students) in one of the galleries (not on the square) and had a drink in one of the brasseries facing the square. The drink was of course priced according to the surroundings (ie. 50% higher than further down the slope).I could probably live with all this and accept it as part of the evolution of Montmarte. What I did not enjoy however were the quacks masquerading as portrait painters and hassling everyone on the street to have their portrait drawn. I especially did not like it when they kept on bothering me when I was enjoying my drink and watching people walk by...yet telling one of them to get lost doesn't automatically communicate itself to the rest of his tribe who keep on coming by hoping some poor desperate tourist will part with some of his hard earned cash to have his portrait drawn by a third rate (at best) artist. Montmartre is a must see for all visitors to Paris but accept the annoying touts as part of the experience.
Experience it!. Little cobbled starts filled with pretty little shops... Meet people displaying their artisan skills... Do try the macaroons, they are mouth watering :)

Loved this Beautiful , quaint neighborhood. From cobbled streets to a throng of road side cafes, everything about this neighborhood is welcoming and enchanting. Spent the better half of an evening strolling around the beautiful lanes, walking in and around little cafes. We also made it a point to stop at the cafe that was a parto f the film "Amelie".Moulin Rouge is a short walk away.

Hill in the north of Paris. Montmartre is mainly known for the white domed Basilica of the Sacré Cœur on its summit and as a nightlife area. Its nice location where you can walk up the hill taking in the area where once many artists lived, see the remaining windmills and get to the Sacré Cœur. Before then you pass the Moulin Rouge area which can be more racy at night.

Love, Love, Love it here. Great place to visit during the summer!. I can't tell you how many people miss out on visiting Montmartre, or put it in their itinerary to substitute another sight when the other sight is unavailable only to be surprised to find that this place became the highlight of their trip.This is PARIS! If you visit during the summer, you will see people relaxing on lawn, smell the freshly baked baguette, and buy wine on the cheap at local market. Just walk up and down any street here and there is an instant post card view. writing about this place makes me want to go back so badly. The atmosphere and overall vibe here was just mesmerizing.Grab a Jamon and Fromage (Ham & Cheese) crepe and enjoy the picturesque streets of Montmartre.

Next time I will rent an apartement here. You want to simply enjoy your vacation? in Paris?..pick this place!!! Atmosphere, enjoying life, live the moment fully...why live close to the Eiffel tour or live close to latin quarter..when you have a nice little hill as Montmartre. Artist, painters, museum, lovely brasserie, feel in love again, be in love or love yourself. I cant wait to go back to Paris to see more, but I will travel for an entire week, so I can feel, smell and taste Montemartre every day.
What a view.. Great place to visit and enjoy a lovely lunch among the many artists working as you eat. The view from Montmartre over Paris is fantastic.

This is a really Fun Place. This is what you think of when you think of Paris the music the people the artists the restaurants. Loved it. The Salvador Dali Museum here is a must see but the street food and art are what is really fun
I want to move here. Just a great place, cheaper than Paris, and a different air about it, could be hard on non walkers due to hill, but there are ways round that, you must go.

Charming place as a base for a Paris visit. Main Street is jam packed with restaurants and bistros, Parisian as well as other cuisines too. Gourmet shops selling cheese, pastries, seafood, chocolates, small goods are an attraction in itself. Montmartre cemetery is mins away and quite pleasant to walk around, filled with very beautiful sculptures and momentos for the loved ones passed away. Seeing this reminds me to be nice to those around you while people are still alive.

Artsy Paris. I was fortunate enough to have lived in this neighborhood some years ago. This visit was nostalgic. You are immediately subdued by its artistic charm and bohemian atmosphere. I revisited my former routine of getting some coffee and a pain au chocolat (chocolate croissant) from a neighborhood bakery, sat on the steps leading to the Sacre Couer and soaked in the divine view of Paris.

Very touristy - but sometimes like in Montmarte , it's great. Walked there on saturday. Was amazed by the charm of the place. There was tons of tourist. Sometimes thats nice. Great view of paris is seen.

Whimsical and adorable.. I spent a lot of time in Paris in the spring of 2010, and Montmartre is by far my most favourite place in the city, where highlights include Sacre Coeur (gorgeous!), the Montmartre Cemetery (might seem like an odd place to visist, but one really should - it's quite beautiful) and Moulin Rouge (classic!). For a tourist it really is a great place to visit, easy to get to with the Metro. Restaurants in the area are not that overpriced, and while strolling the amazing, genuinely French streets you can still find souvenir shops to get whatever you need at. A MUST when in Paris.

Calm and relaxing atmosphere.. This place in my humble opinion it's not to be missed, it would almost seem to not even be in Paris but rather in an ancient village. Located behind the famous basilica of Notre-Dame, easily reachable thanks to the hyper efficient subway located right at the foot of the hill in front of the cathedral. Montmartre is an idyllic place, numerous restaurants and craft shops, the ideal place to be able to grant a self-portrait or a caricature made by one of the many artists who flock to the main square behind the basilica. It exudes an air more relaxing than the frenetic city. In a nutshell Montmartre is one of the top attractions in Paris.

Montmartre still a fascinating area of Paris. Whether you take the funicular or walk up to Sacre Coeur this is a very interesting part of Paris. Small cobbled streets hugging the mount that Sacre Coeur sits upon. The top part is tourist heaven - and shops accommodate but there is good value in the restaurants and I didn;t find prices tourist trap like London. An interessting area of just wander around and the views are very good from the top. Only dislike were, during the evening were one or two artists who did not go away when you said you didn;t want them to draw your portrait - but most were fine. Some good art work still to be seen. It's not all imitation made in China, which was rather nice to see.

Great space. I love Montmartre! Romantic atmosphere with pretty shops and buildings, with street bands playing music on the top of Montmartre. From the top, u can have a nice view over France. However, the price is rather high here for everything!
Paris essaince. because of the famous paintings, we visited Montmarte with high expectations. It is a nice area to walk around, filled with small shops, small bars, small roads, very Parisian style.

Don't bother to see anything in this area other than Sacre Coure.. The church is beautiful & the funicular ride was interesting. However, the rest of the area is nothing but a tourist trap. Beware of pickpockets in the crowded streets.

Wouldn't stay in any other area! . I love Paris and try to visit at least once a year but Montmarte has a special place in my heart and I always look for a nice hotel in the area (usually Du Moulin). Walking around in Montmarte is wonderful and you wouldn't find a finer place to taste the true Parisian spirit.

We spent a morning walking all over Montmartre. We had a lovely time walking and walking and walking this historic neighborhood of Paris. At the very end just West of the Abbesses Metro Station we found the most wonderful patisserie to end our walk. This is just a wonderful place. It is magical as is all of Paris to us. Felt we were following in the footsteps of all of the famous people that have lived here.

Pretty view & best place to buy souveniers. Here you will have an amazing view over Paris, it is very close to Moulin Rouge, the Salvador Dali museum, Starbucks, restaurants.The streets are very narrow and very parisian. A lot of artists are drawing or singing at the corners of the streets.Also, this is the best place to buy souvenirs, because you will find the same things you see in other places, but here are much cheaper!

Best in the Evening. I visited Paris many years ago. Montmartre had such deep impression on me. Whenever I saw paintings or pictures of Bohemian paris, accordium started played in my head and they reminded me of Montmartre. I always wanted to go back. So I went back recently. We arrived when it was still bright. It was overwhelmingly crowded and slammed with tourists. I was somewhat disappointed. We went to have dinner first. After we came out again, it was dark and lights were up. Music was playing and singers were singing. The crowds were blurred by the dark. Suddenly I found my lovely Montmartre back.

My favourite part of Paris. The Montmartre area of Paris is to the north of the City and has a funicular railway to take you to the top of the hill that gives you a great view of the City of Paris on a clear day. You can also visit the white dome of Basilica of the Sacré Cœur and its surrounding streets that are both beautiful and charming. We chose to get the metro to Château Rouge (not the station recommended for Montmartre) as it did not require us to change from Gare de Lyon where we were staying. After a 20 minute walk we found our self at the top of the hill without realising we had climbed it! The station was relatively quiet compared to the others around the area and may be worth using it as an alternative.The area is also famous for the Moulin Rouge show; whilst we didn't attend the show we did wander down to see it. Not a must see if you are not seeing the show, mildly disappointing. But all in all this area was my favourite part of Paris and felt distinctly Parisian (or what I imagine it to be).

a good neighborhood. If you go to Montmartrre, only important thing to do is to walk this neighborhood, the alleys with little restaurants, a vineyard, and a beatiful church. Moulin Rouge and sex shops, nonsense

Very over crowded tourist trap. While this is a beautiful area, it was overloaded with tourists and lost the charm that it use to have. I would recommend a short visit after a visit to the Sacre-coeur.

beautiful at night. taking the cable car up to Montmartre reminded me loosely of my time taking a similar cable car up to Manakamana near Kathmandu, Nepal which also had a religious temple at the top; the Hindu Goddess Bhagwati to be exact. i went during the evening and watched the sun set and the night crawlers come out with beer for sale as well as this signature toy that would light up and be slingshotted high into the air only to come right back down to its owner.

What fun!. We walked around Montmartre after vising Sacré-Cœur Basilica. We enjoyed a little shopping, lots of people watching and a great lunch. We caught the metro out from the city and enjoyed the sites and sounds. TIP: make sure you leave enough time before or after visiting Sacré-Cœur to enjoy this faboulous part of Paris. You wont regret it!

A great neighborhood .... We walked from the Louvre to Montmartre ... A great experience ... It's a very artistic fun happening place ! Walk towards the Sacre Coeur and be enthralled by the wonder of the Basillica !Just stand and stare till your senses are in overload mode ... Take your time and walk and just enjoy the sights.. The place.. The people ... The cafés .... The sidewalk stores ... The sounds and smells of Montmartre !!! An experience you will not want to miss !!!

AMAZING!!. Monmartre is that place where you can loose yourself for hours or even an entire day. The walk from the station up to the Basillica is awesome. You see so many artistes and food joints and you want to try everything (bad idea since it is really expensive and you have scamsters at every corner). This place seems so different from rest of the city. The best part about Monmartre is that you can enjoy irrespective of whether you are alone or with a group of friends. The place is crowded so dont take small kids along.Really nice place, a must visit if you want to enjoy a very different side of Paris.
lovely view. We lit candles in the cathedral, and walked around the neighborhood, down to the artists' square, then had Nutella crepes.

Bohemian Paris. I walked around Montmartre a young solo female traveller and didn't get harrassed by any people or schemes once. I felt perfectly safe and enjoyed aimlesssly wandering the cobbled laneways letting the place reveal itself slowly.Sacre Coeur is the centrepiece (atop the dome is a rewarding view), but find Espace Dali for a museum of his works, listen to the buskers, follow lanes of unusual street art to famous artists homes and studios. Imagine Degas, Renoir and Monet in the historical cafes, see where Van Gogh was inspired.Find Cafe des 2 Moulins where Amelie was filmed (stil a real working cafe)a

Get there early - that's the secret !. Had very mixed feelings about visiting today but the jet lag had us up very early , the day was a stunner so we took the chance .we were staying in St Germaine is the 95 Bus was a fantastic way to cross the city as it came to life on Monday morning . From the stoop its a lovely walk up the hill through the quiet streets .At 8 am the church is practically deserted ,very peaceful ,no con men ,no sleaze etc mentioned by previous reviewers .Thoroughly enjoyed it .

Not what it used to be. Montmartre has become a serious tourist trap. Overcrowded with busloads of tourists, it is busy and fully stuffed. The restaurants are overpriced. The square is a press of people with touts and too many 'artists' plying their trade. This overcrowding has meant the area's charm has been lost to some extent, turning it into just another generic, hectic tourist zone. The Sacre Couer remains breathtaking but with so many people everywhere it makes it a little difficult to enjoy in peace and calm. Try to get off the main drag (which will be difficult) if you want to find a bit of the earlier Montmartre. I'm not sure I'll be going back in too much of a hurry. If I do I will steer clear of the tourist traps -- not easy in Montmartre.
Amazing views. Well worth the trip. Cable car up to the Cathedral is included on your metro ticket. Fantastic to have a walk around and see all the artist drawing and painting the tourist.
Very crowded. It's been a long time since I was here and it has changed as all things do when there is a lot of tourist. It was still worth the hike. The views from here are the best. A must see.

Get lost in an amazing neighborhood. We went to Montmartre on a whim, and ended up spending almost the whole day here. We started by diving right in and climbing the stairs to Sacre Coeur, and spend the rest of the morning wandering the curving streets, going in shops, bakeries, galleries and anything else that looked interesting. And, trust me, there was something interesting around every corner.The climb to Sacre Coeur is not for the weak (there is a cable car), but it is amazing to take the steps that simply lead up from one of the streets and climb your way above the city. It is an amazing perspective and adds a special touch to your visit.
A good old world experience. Nice street vendors, with a lot of good variety souvenirs! Good food and a nice vibe, overall a good experience.

Great french atmosphere!. This is a must area to visit in Paris, especially after sunset! There are many steps to get to the top of the hill but there is also a cable car. The ticket for the cable car is the same as the one for the Metro. The view from the hill is amazing! There are also street performers, many artists that sell their creations, painters that make portraits and caricatures and great local restaurants that have been there forever. This neighbourhood truly is a lively one!
Great place!. Lots of history, wonderful little streets, love the cute old Saint Pirerre church, a must-see in Paris, daytime and nighttime but too many people!

Paris trip isn't complete without Montmartre. By far, my most favorite place to visit in Paris. There is artful and antique neighborhood full of restaurants and shops leading you up to Sacré-Cœur Basilica. This beautiful cathedral sits on the top of Montmartre. The view of Paris is breathe taking from the steps of this cathedral. Before you walk back down, take a break on the steps and watch free entertaining street shows. I personally recommend the day view over night view. Best time to come is before the sunset and so you can leave with the sun.

Highest point in Paris. Montmartre is possibly the highest point in Paris. It gives great views of Paris. The Basilica of Sacre Coeur is an interesting church to visit. The street side shops and resturants gives an old downtown feeling. Worth visiting to have a good time for an evening.

Quaint quarter. I love, love, love Montmartre and in case you are wondering why that doesn't warrant 5 stars, it is probably only because so many other people love it, that it is always crowded with tourists. That in return draws a lot of crooks so be prepared and beware of pick pockets as well as those people that are trying to get a signature from you and then ask you very aggressively for money. Having said all of this, the view over the city of Paris is magnificent and Sacré Cœr is a beautiful church that makes the perfect backdrop for pictures. There are also gardens around Sacré Coer with a waterfall fountain that does not seem to be very well known, but it is peaceful and beautiful there so check it out. Fun is also the furnicula, even if the ride is very short. Otherwise be prepared for lots of stairs and elevations in this quarter.
If you like life pay a visit.. Was there at night and went back during the day for more. So many streets to visit and things to see. You can experience life to the fullest in Montmartre. Go visit.

Worth a visit. After reading some other reviews, we weren't too sure what to expect, but decided to go anyway, and loved it. Sure, there were tacky souvenir shops, and hawkers, but we weren't harassed by any of them. As for pickpockets, they are anywhere tourists go, so you just have to be aware and be careful, so we didn't have any trouble. As for the unlicensed street performers - seeing the taken away by police is all part of the experience. Spent a morning wandering about, watching the artists at work, drinking coffee, and exploring. It was raining the day we went, so the view wasn't as spectacular as it might have been, but still worth it. We enjoyed seeing a part Paris that was so different to what we'd already seen, and would definitely go again and spend a few more hours exploring the quaint cobbled streets.

Great atmosphere. Since Montmartre was close to our hotel it was my first experience of Paris. I loved the winding road with many shops and restaurants on the way up the hill. The vendors and street performers were wonderful and not pushy like you see in other areas. The view was beautiful but the area around the Sacra-Coeur steps is very crowded (and the vendors get pushier at the top of the hill!)

Full of color and interest. This area calls for exploration! We would have liked to spend an afternoon checking it out but didn't have enough time. If you have time, it was surprisingly fun to have a portrait drawn. We found the people in the street were MUCH less costly and did a wonderful job -- best to watch them do others and pick the one you like most.

The bird's eye view. Montmartre is the place to be when you visit Paris. You get the view of whole of Paris. Must visit the area near Sacré-Cœur, which offers lot for restaurants and you can get a Sketch made by one of the Artists (remember to bargain).

wish I had spent more time there!. I don´t like crowds, despite that, I loved Montmatre. I don´t plan to come to Paris again but if I do that will definitely be the place I won´t miss. Narrow, winding streets where you get lost easily but... that´s what gives you all the flavor. the only place in Paris where you can still appreciate sights the impressionists and other more modern artists saw. That´s where you can still find the charm of Paris we all heard of.

Charm of Paris will not be completed without visiting Montmartre. I enjoyed soooooo much this lovely area of Paris . Who wouldn't????It is a hill , where you find on the top the Basilica of the Sacre-Coeur , one of the famous landmarks of Parisyou can go up the hill Monmartre using the stairs (if you are in a good health & fitness) , and if you don't use the finucular it's awesome experienceenjoy Place de tertre , which is a famous square in Monmartre area , where you find street artist & painters , making a handy quick portrait for you in less than 15 minutes , it will be a nice souvenir from ParisIn Montmartre , go to see where Picasso and Van Gogh has lived and enjoy the french nightlife It is a lovely crowded hot spot of Paris , I recommend everyone to visit it

My favouritest place in Paris.. I went there twice,just could not resist it. The cobbled streets, the singers,the performers,the artists, the cafes, the quaint shops, the Basilica Sacré-Cœur, the view of the city it was simply fascinating. I felt a strange connection with that place. There is so much art and music around, it therapeutic.Not to miss the amazing street food :)

Interesting place. I find this place interesting and I bet that art lovers would love staying here. Food is quite expensive but worth a penny due to many art works to see. Place de Turtre is a place must see.

Sandemans Free Walking Tour. We joined the Montmartre Sandemans free walking tour by meeting the guide in front of Starbucks at the Blanche metro station on line 2, at 2pm. Metro Station Blanche is just across the street from the Moulin Rouge.We spotted our guide as she was in a typical red neweurope t-shirt.Montmartre typifies all things quintessentially Parisan, from terraced cafes to romping bars and clubs, drunken can-can dancers to budding street artists and performers, bourgeois-bohemian apartments to tiny cobblestone streets.On the tour of Montmartre, we discovered what made Vincent Van Gogh, Toulouse Lautrec, Claude Monet, Pablo Picassom and Salcador Dali want to call this eclectic district home.On this 2 hour tour, we went to Sacre Coeur, the highest point on land in Paris; Pigalle, Paris legendary red light district; the incredible story of Paris first bishop, the headless Saint Denis,;Paris's last surviving windmills; Cafe des Deux Moulins from the movie Amelie; La Place Dalide; Moulin Rouge; French can-can dancers; Montmartre vineyard; Lapin Agile- cabaret bar where Picasso traded paintings for food; the famous Artists' Square; Van Gogh's house.We only had to pay a fee of 10 euro and after the tour we were treated to a glass of wine.

Best place to be in paris. It was the most beautiful place in Paris. My trip to paris was just for 3 days and in those three days I managed to visit quite a lot of places and one of my favourite place is Montmarte. Amazing view plus an artistic square. Truly an amazing place.
Artists District. Took a very cool trip by car up to the Basilica atop Monmartre. Saw where Picasso had a workshop and where Van Gogh lived.

Very interesting - have always wanted to see the artists - seedy on the way up there!. Yes, it's a bit seedy - but it was definitely worth the trip. The artists are there, paintings are for sale, some are painting portraits of people, it's fun to watch but you can't take pictures of them or their work. There is one street near the Moulin Rouge that is trashy and stinky - lots of vendors selling things and people gambling on the shell games. The souvenirs are cheaper here. Many of the stores have some goods out on the sidewalk so it helps to compare prices a bit.

This may be the best of Paris. Everybody loves this place! So much history!Famous artists lived here and you can walk through the square and see current artists at work.Honestly some of the portraits they painted of people were the best I have seen.The artwork is more pricy than I thought. The roads are narrow and cobblestone. You get such a feeling foe old Paris.You get to see the café where Picasso met his artist friends or just view his house.You can see Sacre Cours / Montmartre from anywhere in Paris.That's because it's reminding you to put this on your list of places to visit.I will be back!
Beautiful quarter of Paris - Must see!. This is a great area of Paris with boutique shops, lovely little cobbled streets and wonderful selection of cafe's and restaurants.

Sweeping view of Paris. From Sacre Coeur you have this great view of the city below, yes there is a commerical feel to it, but you can still walk around and find some hidden gems. There is a park where the artist from past and present paint. You can talk with the artist and buy one of their works (yes it's tourist price!) but still a good souvenier of Paris. I found a little hole in the wall shop that sold original paintings down the road from the park with all the artist.

Circus!!. No trip to Paris is complete without the trip up to this area, we took the funicular which is included in the metro pass tickets, but as soon as reaching the Sacre Coeur plaza it's just one big joke there after. There are unlicensed souvenir sellers everywhere with the police arriving chasing them every 5 minutes, rubbish everywhere and numerous overpriced shops and restaurants. If I came back to Paris probably wouldn't bother coming here and definitely wouldn't spend £50 on 2 crepes and some chips!

Love this place. Took a free walking tour.. Magnificent! Love the food, art and music culture and serenity of this area. Get here, walk around and take it in. Walking up the hill is half the fun..I felt less guilty stuffing in the cheese and bread purchased in the way up be caused I put in the hard yards! Worthy of a good walk around!

Mixed feeling because it's so commercial. It's a place with history and I keep going back.... It used to be more artists and less shops- the balance & atmospere are getting screwed up. Still, my daughter had a caricature done. Now , that was REALLY good. You just need to look around well and compare. Seeing the artists work gives the best way to judge their style and capacities. I had artistically unsatisfying (grin) experience with thewandering artists - the ones who walk around and make a quick picture on which mother wouldn't recognize you.

Stay away- dangerous. If you want a good chance of being mugged, being stared down by rough looking people, or around a part of town where protests happen then this is the place for you! Seriously, it's not the most romantic or friendliest-looking place. Go else where. You will regret coming here and will just want to leave ASAP

Hideous Tourist Trap - Don't Go!!. After enjoying the ride up on the little train and seeing l'espace Dali all I wanted to do was get out. This place is hideous! Full of junk, gypsies, steps to Sacre Coeur stink of wee, people approaching us constantly asking to do a portrait of the children, the most bizarre 'second hand clothes shops' with boxes of old bras and rags on offer. We were approached by the Roma petition hunters. All I wanted to do was get the hell out of there. Had caught the little train up which was quite nice - should have got back on after the Dali exhibition and high-tailed it out of there!! Nothing really bad happened to us but I'm sure it could have. I would not take children there in future but, then again, I will never go there again!!

Worth a Visit to just walk around and eat.. This is the highest place in Paris and location of Sacre Coeur. The church has continuous prayer, so no talking or pictures, etc. at any time inside. Great view of Paris from the steps. We had lunch at a little place thatg I cannot remember the name of - a pity because it was wonderful. My impression is that there are many such little places there.

Great place to walk and shop. This is a great area to walk around to window shop and enjoy the sights. There is a fantastic overview of the city from in front of Sacre Coeur. There are little streets lines with interesting shops, accentuated by hills and some steep climbs. We spent about half a day walking around and could have done more. Although busy with tourists, it has an entirely different feel than the rest of the city. We took the metro and it worked out great. There is a market square with tons of artists who will draw your picture. Just a great area to relax and take in a different element of Paris.

Love this place!. We stayed here for a few days and the square proved to be one of my favourite places. Quite touristy but it is very cool to see the artists in action and the hustle and bustle proves to be a good atmosphere. We walked around and then sat in a restaurant with crepes and a glass of wine just people watching. Good fun!

Montmartre. Stayed in a great place through Airbnb right up in the outskirts of Montmartre. Walked up to the cathederal and around all the neighborhoods. Felt safe walking at night and many pubs/restaurants to choose from. Would definitely stay in this part of Paris again.

A gathering place at sunset..... Went there in 2013. Montmatre seems to be one of the places to go at sunset to see Paris light up after dark. Great views, very crowded. Seems to attract tourists, locals and opportunists. Some great restaurants in the area. Watch your wallet/pocketbooks, as there a a lot of street people/scammers in the area looking for a "mark", but overall generally safe. Do not stay too late or you may not be able to get a cab (or have to fight for one - long lines) and it is a long walk back to the nearest neighborhood. That said, it a must visit area for the views, history and food!
Good. Montmartre is really worth a visit, although it is full of the tacky souvenir shops the restaurant's are ok and the church is a must.

I love this place. Montmartre is now a suburb of Paris but it was once a county town, as a result it has a different feel to old Paris.The Montmartre is two types of places, the flashy tourist area, with Moulin a Rouge and also the streets that have yards, and parks. Most unusual for Paris.Montmartre also is the highest point of a Paris and there is a sweeping view of the city and you catch glimpses of the tower.So go for a stroll, take a walking tour,beat in the many restaurants and enjoy the vibrancy that in Montmarte.Metro has 3 stops in this suburb, all have something to offer when you come up to street level.Enjoy

will make you feel happy. A must see by all means. You must go walk in the narrow streets, buy from the souvenir shops, sit on a café and listen to French songs. The streets in montmartre are full of artists, you can have your picture drawn or a sketch of your face maybe a silhouette. .. It is also very crowded, but in a nice way because everyone is here to enjoy. So the general mood is very nice

Crazy, crowded, touristy but you have to go!!!. Some people will absolutely hate Montmarte and others will want to return again and again. I've been several times and just find it totally invigorating most of the time. I love sitting at a sidewalk cafe, sipping a coffee and just watching the world walk by.
