Don't let anyone scare you away because of the pickpockets and scam artists. Hold your valuables close and be smart and you will be just fine. I was up for the annual wine festival last October. The parade is a must-see - hard to describe - you just have to see it. However, going up to the square during the wine festival is a daunting thing. My daughter and I managed to wade through the solid pack of bodies to get one wee taste of champagne but after that it was simply impossible to get a single drop of wine. There were so many people that you could barely raise your arms to lift your glass to your mouth. Soooo - come to Montmarte anytime but during the wine festival and be sure and wander the hilly, curvy streets away from the main square. Daytime is lovely and if you are up there at night it will feel just a bit seedy but still quite a delight - the night-time view of Sacre Couer is not to be missed. And don't miss the views of Paris from beneath Sacre Coeur!

Hard to rate, but a must. I travelled here solo , after my family had left for the UK that morning. I had a night up my sleeve before flying out and it's one place you should not miss! I stayed in a hotel very close and visited around 8 pm . it was full of tourists and not a great experience ( France in summer ) and after having a pleasant walk to moulin rogue ( plus a few drinks ) I walked back around 11 pm to my hotel and it had taken a dark corner and quite a few homeless drunks that urinate on the stairs. Stay away late at night.However , at 8.30 - 9.30 am I had a run around the area and it was a true awaking. Very FEW tourist , mainly Asians . I would recommend to do this as you will have the place to yourself. Then make your way to more touristy sites that open up at 10 am. Note - you will miss the restaurants and artist doing sketches. Personally I found this something I could miss and restaurants were outrageousness priced. I paid 7.5 euro for a bt beer. Some restaurants are open though for a coffee etc.Tip - walk down the hill ( 500 meters ) towards moulin rouge and have dinner at one of the many outside / inside restaurants that were reasonably priced and better if going for lunch or dinner.  Watch out for the black African groups of men. Just turn around and go one of the many other entrances. They hang in groups of 5 plus. Otherwise walk straight through them and do not make eye contact. They tend to operate at the bottom of the main stairs.Lastly , they have a escalator , but it's a very pleasant climb up the stairs and a good way to work of the French cuisine!

Lovely place....but.... Simply lovely area. The best way to explore Montmartre is by walking around and getting lost in the streets. You will find shops selling souvenir and gifts. Lovely bakery also lie along the streets. While you are here, consider getting your portraits draw by the artists. Will definitely visit this area every time I am in Paris. But this neighbourhood is definitely the safest. Be careful of your belonging as pickpockets hangs around this area often. Just do your due diligent, and you will be fine!

Amazing Atmosphere. We had a friend who took us to montmarte and what a gem it is.. the place is so old school and unhurried. We really enjoyed our time just roaming around city square, checking out small shops and the artists lined up on the streets. I feel you have missed the real paris if you dont visit motmarte.

Visit to montmatre. I recently travelled with my 3 teenage children for a summer city break . We found the trains and metro overcrowded and stuffy .Once we reached Montmatre we felt much safer and comfortable using the local buses to visit the attractions . The Sacre Couer was a 5 minuite climb from our apartment so we were very lucky . However the stairs leading up to the Sacre couer smelt of urine and this spoilt the walk . The crowds were more bearable if you visit later in the day however you can't avoid them in the square where all the artists are at work , it didn't spoil it for us , you just have to accept it . I have some great photos looking down onto the Parisienne streets . We had lots of cafés and restaurants and shops on our doorstep and found montmatre quite a pleasant safe place . But we didn't go out at night!!!

Memorable!. Montmartre is one place I have promised myself to visit every time I am in Paris. We visited this place on a sunny September afternoon, it was not really crowded and we loved our time there. Take your time to walk up (don't take the cable car unless u must!) and amble around all the alleys, savor the atmosphere and there are some really good eateries around. A lot of artists, painting, sketching and playing instruments its a pretty beautiful sight. We weren't really heckled by any souvenir seller but maybe we were just lucky..The famous Sacre Coeur is atop the hill and its magnificent and if its a clear day you'll have a lovely view of Paris! Give yourself at least 3 hours to enjoy and soak in Montmartre...
fun area. a lot of things to do and places to eat, but it becomes a bit seedy and maybe not the safest bit of paris late at night

Uncomfortable. The Sacre Coeur is magnificent and worth seeing, as is the view. However, the area is absolutely crowded and didn't feel as safe as other parts of Paris. As has already been said on these reviews, the souvenir sellers (of which there are lots!) seem to be much more pushy here and slightly more aggressive which spoilt the experience. Didn't like the area around the Moulin Rouge which was full of sex shops. All in all, I'm glad I visited to see the Sacre Coeur but won't go back to Monmartre.

Arrive Hungry!. Really enjoyed walking the streets in Montmartre. I started by walking up to Sacre Couer and then you can veer to the left at the top of the stairs up to the basilica and start meandering down through Montmartre. This can take you past the Dali museum, which is worth the fee if you like surrealism or Dali, and then through all the many streets with shops and restaurants. I had dinner at La Sancerre, but there are many wonderful little cafes to choose from (as in all of Paris!) At the bottom of the hill you'll encounter the red light district and the Moulin Rouge, which is worth a photo or two as well.

Great View of the Paris City. To reach the cathedral, you could walk up the hill or take cable car. But i would recommended you to walk since you could see different view of paris during your walking. Like other tourist attraction, there are people who try to tie some kind of thread on your hand and ask for money, so be prepare for it. the less about this place was gorgeous.
Great neighborhood. Montmartre is a great place to visit. We traveled for hours through the neighborhood, discovering amazing food and buildings. Totally worth it.

Thrift store heaven. We went for the excellent view of Paris and to see the beautiful building. It was hard working getting up all the steps, but it was worth it. You can take a lift or a mini train up if you do not want to tackle the stairs. It was busy, but not crowded. There was a group of thugs working the crowd of people leaving with the friendship bracelet scam. I was an easy target because I foolishly wore high heels that day and could not easily walk away from them quickly. They quickly had me surrounded before they realized the 6'5" giant among them was my husband that arrived a minute later. They ran when he appeared. I loved the three thrift stores we found on the short three block walk from the subway to Montmartre. Yes, they are crowded, poorly designed, and dirty.....but worth the hassle. I got silk scarves for 1 Euro and a pair of leather boots for 5 Euro.

Worth going to!. This area has a very different vibe compared to the rest of Paris. Yes you have to hang tight to your bags given how many people there are here but I was never approached by scammers nor people who tried to rob me etc. There is a mini train that drives around and departs every 30 minutes. I hate walking and if you do too I suggest you take that so you can see the area while driving around. It will take you to the highest point of the city where you can see paris. Interesting place with a lot of tourists, sex shops and the Moulin Rouge which did not look half as classy as I thought it would have.

Musée De Montmarte and Jardins Renoir. Visiting Paris you will most certainly decide to visit the sugary white Basilica Sacré-Coeur too, and now being there high up I recommend you not to miss the lovely Montmartre Museum with its charming Renoir Gardens only a few minutes’ walk away from the basilica.Musée De Montmartre and Jardins Renoir highlight important aspects of Parisienne history as does Montmartre itself. We visited the Basilica Sacré-Coeur on July 12, 2014. It is truly monumental, majestically situated as it is on top of Hill Montmarte (Butte Montmartre) with a most lovely view over central Paris downhill to the Eiffel Tower, Pantheon and Notre Dame. It was built as a symbol of atonement after the French Second Empire's defeat at Sedan on September 2, 1870 by Prussia in the French – Prussian War 1870 – 1871 and the ensuing Paris revolution famously known as the Commune, which was bloodily quelled by the Third Republic, the political heir to Napoleon III's Second Empire. Construction started in 1875 and was finished in spring 1914, but the basilica was not consecrated until 1919 due to a new war between among others France and Germany, the Great War (August 1914 – November 1918). Butte Montmartre is a hub in French political history, both in the defence of Paris against the Prussians by the new Third Republic - it was from here that its defence minister Leon Gambetta fled the city in a world famous and spectacular way on October 7, 1870 by a hot air balloon - and when the new republic failed to do so the Paris Commune took over with such noted defenders as the famous ”Red Virgin”, Louise Michel . This is also documented in the Musée De Montmartre. But today Montmartre is probably much more famous as a hub in French and European art and entertainment history, also documented in the museum. It all started when Paris artists moved from Left Bank's Latin Quarter, from Montparnasse to Montmartre because of the enormous reconstruction of Paris during the reign of Napoleon III (1848 – 1870) with the construction of the new broad boullevards and very expensive new houses. In the words of Alistair Horne (Seven Ages of Paris. Portrait Of A City, 2002), which I allow me the privilege to borrow, the narrow irregular streets and low houses of what until recently had been a detached village, with windmills, vineyards and gardens in almost every way suited the artists better. An earlier generation led by Berlioz and Heine was followed by Pissarro, Cézanne, Monet, Renoir and Toulouse-Lautrec and later by Van Gogh, Picasso, Braque, Matisse and Duffy with the centenary year 1900 as a watershed. Together with the artists the famous cabarets, such as the Moulin Rouge, the Moulin de la Galette (eternalized by Renoir’s and Van Gogh’s atmospheric paintings) and the Lapin Agile were vital energy spots of the Belle Epogue and beyond.You may get a glimpse of the environment of that time, if you go out into the gardens on the back side of the museum. It’s almost a time machine out there! It is so calm here. On your left side you see a wine yard, a left over from the Belles Epogue, still producing about 1.000 bottles of wine today, looking down the hill wrapped in grapes you will see the gable of a little house with ”Lapin Agile” painted on it. This is the famous cabaret - and it is still going strong!Entering into the second garden you may enjoy a real pearl, and I would not hesitate to say: the real Jardin Renoir. It is a place built for relaxation and contemplation. Its calmness and design reminded me of Renoir’s garden and house in Cagnes-sur-Mer at the Côte d'Azur between Nice and Cannes.Henning Ballerup

Great place to hangout. Went on a cold, rainy, windy February night...and it was packed. Loads of people drinking and chatting and selling things and sight seeing.A very lively energetic place worth a visit any time of day any time of year.

Beautiful view of Paris!. Take metro to Abbesses or Anvers (better, just 5 mins to bottom of "hill"). Then either walk up the steps or take a funicular. One normal metro ticket (€1.7) takes you one way up on the funicular. If you purchase 10 metro tickets at one time, there is a discount. The beautiful Sacre Coeur basilica will be the first thing that welcomes you at the top of the hill. If you look back, the view of Paris is behind you! Very nice! The view of the Eiffel tower is also possible but you have to walk 5 mins away from the Sacre Coeur. The first time I was here, it was raining. So we took the tram (ard €10 if not wrong) which tours around Montmartre. Not bad.Montmarte used to be a quaint village where artists liked to live in. Now it's a very tourisy place. There are still artists selling their artworks and some will approach you to have your portrait sketched. Good to spent a few hours here, visiting the basilica, absorbing the view of Paris and have a nice lunch! Beware of pickpockets and pushy peddlers.

Stay away. Amazing view from the hill and the Sacre Coeur itself cannot justify the horror of this place. From the moment you step out of the metro you are harassed and watched by groups of dodgy characters. The whole neighbourhood is badly overcrowded and feels very unsafe with all kinds of scams going on everywhere you look. After spending some time in Paris already we were shocked to feel so uncomfortable in this otherwise pleasant city. In comparison to other areas we've been to it was like a different planet. I would stay away.

Take an Xanax before.... I never write reviews but I had to after going to Montmartre. I'm not sure who to feel sorry for here? The locals, the gypsies, the tourist? I mean whatever Montmartre was before, it is no longer. You will walk up to the basilica and see a sea of people. Literally thousands. Walking the stairs are hundreds of tourist - camera in hand. Thrown in are the guys who throw a bracelet on you and then demand to be paid. They rush at you and god help you if you make eye contact. Personally, I would never go here at night. If it's scary in broad daylight I wouldn't take my chances at dusk. Then you have everyone taking photos. There must be a thousand cameras and iPhones out just snapping away. Selfies are king here. Whatever you want to call it.... it is the furthest thing from peaceful.Moving deeper and higher into Montmartre you will find little cafés & restaurants. They were all filled and people seemingly happy. Perhaps the food is delicious and cocktails too? Give it a try - I did not as prices were a bit expensive. I would suggest drinking loads of wine - you'll need to. When you are there gypsies come at you like your made of gold and throw papers at you demanding you to sign. It's so their comrade can snatch your wallet or make you pay after signing. It's just sad. And couldn't be more annoying. You spend half your time protecting your belongings and saying "no"then looking about the area. I could not imagine living here. I feel so sad for the Parisians here. The tourist comes (me included) and so does all the crime and kitschy trash shops. Perhaps in a few years the bad will turn everyone away (tourist, gypsies, thieves) and it'll start to be like it's old self again...less is sometimes more.

beautiful scene from above. I & my wife got here in the morning on Sunday.The mood and the weather were good enough.After steps, the scene above Paris is still memorable.I got annoyed by the hawkers who forced me to purchase his goods which I didn't care of. One of them greeted me in Chinese, Japanese and even in Korean and then held me to tie my wrist with one of his goods. It took longer to escape from him than any others. In many Parisian attracts, they do the same.I suggest you to ignore them by being one of guided-tour group for a moment and move with them. The hawkers usually try solo or couple, I think. Except this, I satisfied with Montmartre. Hope you enjoy yourself.

The souvenir sellers spoilt it. I have been here before & the first time was better. This time I really noticed the larger number of souvenir sellers which sort of cheapened this icon. Some didnt give you a very secure feeling either and my wife didnt feel safe at night.I realise people have to make a living however, I think we (or at least the French) need to ensure some more respect is given to some places.It is still well worth the visit as well as taking the funicular (lift) up the hill. The steps are pretty steep otherwise.Take the time to wander around. The view of the Eiffel Tower (if you are looking for it) is to the right hand side (facing the city) up the road and in between some buildings. A great view of the rest of the city though from the front.The first time I was here it was an artists haven at night although unsure now.

Tour during the day. We loved Montmartre but we wouldn't visit this area at night. During the day you can avoid all the sex shops (unless you want to go in) just to experience the neighborhood. We still got asked 4 times to come in and watch sex shows. Once you move away from the run down stores and move up towards the basilica, it is much better and the little artist shops at the top are fantastic. Worth the visit but go during the day.
Overrated, overrun. Montmartre, so romantically depicted in "Amélie", is so overrun with tourists that you barely see your surroundings. It's a shame.

A Very Frightening Night. My night at Montmartre was hands-down my least favorite night in Paris. The first problem was just that: We went at night. The atmosphere was creepy, and there were scammers everywhere trying to sell us flowers or give us hard alcohol. Even though we ignored them, they wouldn't leave us alone. By the time we got there, the shops were closed and all that remained were drunk people. The view from the church was ruined by these people harassing us. When we finally decided to leave, we headed down the stairs... Which were covered in urine. To make matters worse, our tour director was very unfamiliar with the area, and led us through the neighborhood (where we saw people running and heard plenty of car alarms going off) to a nearby metro station. The metro station was also eerie, and run-down. I felt very unsafe, even in a large group of people. If you decide to visit Montmartre, please do not do so at night.

Lovely area with a great artist market and quaint shops. We visited Montmartre with a group of teenagers. It was a super place to go with them, views of the city, shops, food and lots of photo opportunities. Students (and staff) thoroughly enjoyed it, despite the 300 steps!

Great views and Basilica!. This is worthwhile a visit! The funicular ride up and down the small hill was good fun. There are nice views of Paris. We went to the Basilica during Vespers and enjoyed the choir and organ music. On the way back, we stopped at a small freshly baked cookie shop (in the lane that is directly opposite the metro entrance). Well worth the visit!
Beautiful views and atmosphere. Very pleasant atmosphere with some of the best views in Paris.Is one of the artist quarters with plenty of coffee shops and street food.

Historic & Fun. I was worried this area would be too touristy, but we got to the area before all the big tour buses (around 9am) and really enjoyed visiting Sacre Coeur, and the nearby plaza full of artists. We bought a small painting, and also visited some nice (not junky) shops where items were reasonable and high quality (purses, etc..). Very pretty area, and fun to hike up the hill (and there's a funicular too).

Great place for wandering, people watching & cafes. Montmatre is a hill in the north of Paris & also the name of the surrounding area. From the top, where the white domed Basilique du Sacré-Coeur is located, you will get some of the best city views and photo-ops. Many famous artists, to include Dali, Monet, Picasso, Van Gogh, & Mondrian, had studios or worked in this area. Montmatre was quite crowded with tourists, even though we headed out in the morning. We snapped photos, saw the Basilica, wandered the cobblestone streets, and ended up at Place du Tertre, where years ago the legends of art used to roam. It’s now filled with watercolors & sketch artists… many quite good. The day was already hot (around 85 degrees) and I didn’t want to be “sketched” so we stopped in at a cute café for a glass of wine. Our choice was La Cremaillere where we people watched for about half an hour before we met grabbed a cab back to the hotel.

Where you can see old Paris. This is the best neighborhood in Paris showing and describing the last decades, There is a lot of sight seeing starting by Sacre Coeur Cathedral then going down to the Place de Tertre where all the artists showing their arts. going down again to see the Moulin Rouge theater in Pigale quarter where the night life has it is unique reputation.
Enjoyable day. We had a lovely morning looking at the church, the markets and cafés . Great views of Paris. A very pretty area.

Great place to eat outside. We toured the church first, and went to Montmartre to eat. The food was good, but the atmosphere of the entire place was spectacular. Artists sell their paintings on the street and some will do your portrait. My daughter had her portrait done, and I am so glad we did.

Lovely way to spend an evening!. After a day of touring Paris, it was relaxing to stroll around Montmartre. There are plenty of cafes and food vendors along with interesting shops to browse. We walked around, ate crepes and watched the artists at work. The streets are narrow and the architecture is interesting. It didn't have a crowded, touristy feel--I felt like I was mingling with the locals.

A feeling of old Paris. The journey is worth at least the views of the city. The streets are busy but have the old Parisienne feel to them and you can imagine the artists who used to work here. Wander around and take in the atmosphere

Lots of steps but worth it. This is a lovely spot once you cope with all the steps! You can go up the easy way though. The Sacred Heart church is beautiful inside. Take some time to sit and absorb the atmosphere.The surrounding streets are filled with artists and numerous restaurants. Great to sit and have a drink and watch the world go by. Well worth a few hours visit.

pleasant atmosphere. Nice place to relax and to have a walk along the twisted, narrow streets. It reminded me of my home town. Houses are very nice, lots of flowers, small gardens and family restaurants just across the busy square which leads to Sacre Coeur but it pays off when you see the view and listen to a song played on the harp.

Very Careful at this Site.. Take the Funicular lift, to the left, looking up from the main road running perpendicular to Montmartre, to avoid 'Bad People' hanging out on the bottom set of steps. There is NO Police presence anywhere in Paris, especially here. Under the guise of tying colored strings around your finger for the Basilica (still don't know why) they, 3 well positioned men on each (left & right stairs) will physically block your way, grab your hand, while others on the sideline come out to help frisk. My son and I beat a hasty retreat, then re-entered the other side with a large family with children. The attackers would have been arrested in the US for what they did but they act with impunity.The Basilica itself is beautiful, no pictures inside. Climbing the stairs deserves a badge (for many reasons). Beautiful view of the city. The streets just below the Basilica are filled with souvenir shops and men playing some kind of shell game, not too scary.
Cool to see. This area was cool to see, but I did not purchase any art. It was, for me, a place to browse and people watch. I did not stay in the area long, but I'm glad I made the stop.

so relax... wow wow .. very nice to see the other side is very different from the glitter of the city of paris .. This area is very calm, cool, very nice for the family to relax. if it still has plenty of time to enjoy the city of paris, preferably to monmartre to relax.

So much to see. We visited this area because we wanted to see Sacre Coeur. After we saw the Cathedral we walked around Montmartre. We loved all the little streets with all the restaurants and cafes but we really liked the Square with all the artists and artisans.
So Much to Do!. This area has a lot to see and do. You can visit the oldest church in France, see where famous artists lived while working, and see walk through the artists' square.
Climbing for art. Great neighborhood to wander. Good food, small shops and ambiance. No wonder so many great artists got inspiration here.

Far less artists, loads more restaurants. I must admit, it lost a bit of the nostalgia by replacing the artists with some restaurants/cafés, but still worth a visit for sure! This place is buzzing and one can feel it in the air! Most artist doing portrait studies and caricature with a few still indulging in oil paint, pastels, charcoal etc. A true delight to watch. Highly recommended!

Bustling with life. We had a lot of fun wandering around the area with our kids. So much going on! We enjoyed the hills and the atmosphere with roving musicians.We had portraits made of the kids which were beautiful and a neat experience. Note that there are some artists walking around with clipboards who will try to make a portrait.  There is also a square with a bunch of seated painters who take longer-these are higher quality and a better experience.

Cute Little Village. First time to this area of Paris. If you can, so the stairs...its makes you a better person. If you can't there is a two minute tram ride up the hill, which will cost you a metro ticket. Great little shops, restaurants, and the church. Just watch out for the piles of guys selling beer, water, and trinkets. You can also get your portrait sketched y one of the local artists.

Paris!. So glad we stayed in this neighborhood and got to spend a good amount of time walking around. Lots of great places to stop and have a glass of wine and a bite to eat. Sacre Coure is impressive and the views spectacular. Walking around the square with the artists painting is my idea of what everyone should think of as Paris. Must see.
Old Paris. Nice to see Paris in a different light! Great place to bidi lots going on there be aware of pickpockets lurking around! Lots of nice architecture to see

5 stars if not for all the trinket shops. Beautiful tree lined streets and a public square found on Paris' highest elevation. The square finds many painters selling their works. No one approaches you so there is no pressure to buy anything. My wife bought a beautiful water color of the Eiffel Tower. Be prepared for a little hike as this is the highest point in all Paris
Montmartre: Da Bomb. Find a little bistro or bar - and drink up a bottle of wine with someone who you love. Then have a stroll up to Sacre Coeur. Heaven.

Last Surviving Vineyard in Paris. If you go here, I would highly suggest using Rick Steve's walking tour. I actually did not go into Sacre Coeur, but took a moment to scan the Paris horizon, take pictures, and eat my breakfast on a bench halfway up the stairs to the cathedral. I did, however, go into Saint Pierre de Montemartre. I believe it has four purple-ish columns dating back to Roman times inside? At first I though they were the two huge columns flanking the entryway, but look a little farther back from those columns, and you will see the nondescript, ancient columns you're looking for. Kind of cool to go to touch something from that far back! His tour takes you to a square which is surronded by cafes, and full of artist's painting pictures. If you want your caricature done, a portrait, or to purchase one of their gorgeous works, you can. I picked up a painting from a local artist, and I treasure every day I look at it! It's a picture of the square I bought it in, and these artists can even take credit cards. Nice souvenir, huh? Rick Steve's tour also takes you by the last standing vineyard in an area that used to be covered with them once upon a time. You will also see the cafe La Vie en Rose was debuted in, and the studio where Picasso began his painting in Paris. On the square by his studio, I was serenaded by an accordionist while children played nearby. Cafe de Deux Moulins from the movie, "Amelie" has changed name, and was a letdown from the outside, so we didn't even go in. If you want to see the Moulin Rouge, it won't be as spectacular as I'm sure it is at night when the lights are lit, but I got a picture anyway. There are also other neat windmills to see on his tour (as you can tell, I'm a windmill fan). Afterwards, we took the Metro to the Marais District to have lunch at the Dormouse in the Teapot. They have a mile-high lemon meringue pie.

Must see precinct of Paris. Am Absoluetly brilliant place. Make sure you get down at abssinthe metro station and walk from there (not pigalle). After you have seen the sacre coeur, do keep time to walk around and eat something at place du tertre . Brilliant vide to the place !!

Favorite neighborhood of Paris. If you want to see what we all imagine Paris to be, make your way to this neighborhood! It is not very difficult with the metro and the funicular! Great souvenir shopping at decent prices and beautiful street artists and restaurants.

LOVE! Perfect place to wander, eat, drink, and get lost!. Montmartre is a great neighborhood. I got a great recommendation to take the train to Moulin Rouge and then walk the longer way through Montmartre to the Sacre Coeur. It was a perfect walk. We took it slow and stopped a few times to get a drink and split a small bite. I definitely would have spent more time in Montmartre if I had a longer trip. I highly recommend you dedicate one afternoon to this neighborhood. Take the train to Moulin Rogue, take a leisurely walk up to Scare Couer and then walk down the other side. You get a great feel for the neighborhood!

This really is Paris. With it's twisting side streets full of hidden gems like the tiniest vineyard in France, the magnificent views and the lovely restaurants, this is a place not to be missed. It is wonderful to explore on foot, or sit at a cafe people watching. If you want to see and hear a bit about the area, the little tour train is a bit of fun.

One of the iconic places in the world. Famous for its artist square and the artistic life, an iconic place where Western art was changed by a group of extraordinary freethinking individuals. It is a bit like a pilgrimage just to be there and to feel the art in the atmosphere.

The best district in Paris. Monmartre is one of the best or even the best part of Paris. Here you can feel real Paris, meet lots of interesting people, meet local art. Have walk in this district - without a destination, just walk a bit. The area near the basilica is very nice.

My kind of place!. I have been there sooooo many times and bought my first 3 paintings there in 1966 when I was still young. My grandchildren own them now. Typical Parisian kids paintings. I even had a photograph taken with the artist then in black and white. I advise everyone to visit Place du Tertre. It is situated just behind Sacre Cœur Cathédrale.You will enjoy all aspects of the area especially seeing all the artists at work. I am an artist myself and therefore can spend hours there just looking and asking questions.Espace Dali, that is, if you like Salvador, has a permanent exposition there as well. You will certainly enjoy this vibrant interesting place. Highly recommended.

Change is not always good. Montmartre has changed quite a bit over the years and except for visiting the Basilica, I don't think it is worth the effort. It was an unique neighborhood with some great street artists. We were here 15 years ago and could not wait to get back here to find something special, instead we found characture artists and paintings of the Eiffel Tower. The last time we were here, we found a beautiful painting by an unknown artist. We stopped at a little pub for a beer and water and got charged 7€ for the water. I still think it is worth walking up to the church, as the Basilica is incredible and the views from up here are beautiful, but skip the shopping and eating up here. There are a lot of scam artists (African men trying to put bracelets on your wrist, or teenagers trying to get you to sign a fake petition, or a person asking if you lost a gold ring) around here, but they are easy to avoid. Don't make eye contact and when they ask you if you speak English, just say NO!
Must go place. Montmartre it ´ s one of the most beautiful places in Paris. The architecture is lovely and the hidden little streets will make you feel like back in time. You will love it!

Quintessential Paris!. We rented an apartment for just over a week in Montmartre, and it's now our favorite area in Paris! We loved the hilly terrain and many trees, the beautiful turn-of-the-century architecture, great restaurants and friendly locals. We truly felt like we were Parisians and not just tourists. With so many Metro stations in the area, we just hopped on to go visit attractions in other arrondissements but always loved coming back "home" to Montmartre!

Great view. The steps of Montmarte give you a great view of Paris. The only thing I'd recommend is not making eye contact with the people trying to sell things. There is also a well know scam when a man tries to trap your wrist in string and make you pay for the bracelet, claiming it's "for the church". Just don't give them any attention and you'll be fine. Knowing a little French helps here too because they're trying to pray on clueless tourists.Montmartre itself is great because there are a lot of interesting street performers. Be careful with the restaurants in this area because they can also be a tourist trap.

If these cobblestone streets could talk........... I lived in Paris for a time back in the 1970's and went back again some years later, only to find that this city still owns my heart! Paris, especially Montmartre, is one of the most wonderful parts of Paris. The day time offers wonderful shops and small boutique style restaurants, while in the square, the artists are painting until the wee hours of the morning. Once the sun goes down, the whole mood changes as the cafe's start with their music and singing and there is excitement all around the square that is Montmartre. The back side of Monmartre houses such wonderul places as Moulin Rouge and other nightclubs that make this place the best place for artists to gather, while on the other side of the mountain (because Monmartre is on a small mountain in the city itself), lies Sacre Couer Cathedral which is a sight to behold in the morning sunlight. It is awash with white and can be seen from anywhere in the city where one can capture a view. The flower peddlers have their carts and wagons all around while the smells of fresh baked bread and freshly brewed espressos fill your head with overwhelming delight.If you visit Paris and go nowhere else, make sure to see Montmartre as it is every dream you ever had of Paris!

Hilly hipster hangout. So different from Paris as it's set on a hillside. The streets are winding and hilly, which is a stark contrast to flat Paris. There is a lively buzz, bordering on crowded during the days. But the ambiance in the evening is much more relaxed. Plenty of cafés situated by staircases that offer nice views of the city. Be prepared to climb when you visit!

A good hike up the hill. And nice views with a wonderful free cathedral to view at the top. Lots of places to buy art or have your portrait done, by a local sketch artist. If you a shopping for higher quality art work this is not your place. The canvas pieces here are drivin by and for the tourist/souvenir market . All in all worth the walk up the hill or you can take the lift.

One of my favorite areas. It is a little bit of a hike (even from the Metro), but I really enjoyed this area. Quirky shops, great views of the city, interesting streets with steep steps, etc. Buy some wine while in the area!

Interesting view that's about it. The area between the Metro and the start of the hill is something of a tourist trap. While you can catch a lift up to the top of the hill don't be slack just walk and you will save some money, burn some calories and ensure you don't have to stand around waiting in line.You can visit Basilica of the Sacré Cœur and donate for some overpriced candles and there is also some Catacombs you can visit around the back of the Basilica. There are plenty of markets in the area if you are looking for something to purchase to remember your trip. If you are hungry and thirsty there are plenty of places to sit down and relax but you might want to check the prices firstWhile the view over Paris is ok but I expected something more so was a little disappointed... but upside the place can be done for free....

Fun area. Lots to see here, taking the Montmartre train a must! Fun to watch the artists at work, have coffee in a cafe, see Sacred Coeur, ride the Funicular and shop for souvenirs and bargains in the lower streets.

My favorite place in Paris. I was I Paris July 2013 this was my favorite place on Paris. The view was great! I usually don't like crowds but I did not mind this one, young and old, locals and tourists, a lot of artists. Just a super hangout spot.

A Side Trip. This was interesting. We got off the Metro at the Pigalle, and started our walk.First off, if you're a prude or have young children with you, this may not be your area. The shops selling sexually oriented equipment are pretty much out in the open. It would be hard explaining to the kids why that man in the window is in black leather and tied up.We were there to see the Basilique du Sarce-Coeur church, which is famous for it's steps. (What in France ISN'T FAMOUS for it's steps?) It was interesting walking through the neighborhoods. As we walked, I found if I looked to the left or right, I was looking into someones living / dining room, so I stopped looking left and right.The area is hilly. Very hilly. If you aren't in reasonably fit shape, the hills won't notice but you will.We were forewarned about pick pockets, so we used alternate hard to pick travel wallets, and didn't have any problems.It's a nice area, with a great view of Paris.

The place for live shows. When you arrive there you will see a lot of streets, a lot of caffes, and a whole bunch of people walking about. Take notice that the places that hold adult fun do not condone of taking pictures, so you might loose your sd card if you snap the wrong pic. Otherwise a pleasant place, where you can feel some of the old spirit of Paris. A bit commercialized, but still a sight to see. Walking around you can come upon a lot of street acts, and really top notch once, since the competition is big. If you are keen on throwing some money away, you can buy some art from the local artists. Really a must see and an integral part of visiting Paris. Totally sweet.

Great spot in Paris. Just a nice trip away from the city - but still in the city. Walk up the hill and enjoy the little shops and amazing coffee. The last square before you are at the view point has painters selling their artwork followed by a beautiful view of Paris. The stair case on the way down too is very romantic in the evening.

Sunset @ Montmartre - the best free thing in Paris. This is my 4th trip to Paris, and this, is my most favorite part of the city. Montmartre is lively, unruly and just full of good vibes.The millions of tourist kill the experience but only if you go at the wrong time. I took my friend up there on a Sunday evening at around 8 which gives you an hour or two till sunset. By 9/9:30 people are barely climbing up to the Sacre Coeur anymore. Grab a seat on the stairs or if you like your space, find a spot on the grass and watch the sun set over Paris while you're serenaded by street musicians or entertained by random/weird dancers - you don't have much of a choice but to watch them however, its thoroughly enjoyable! The eateries are usually a little too pricey up there, so come back down to grab a bite - there's a ton of cool places of all cuisines to choose from.Also, if you can't walk up there, there is a funicular that will get you up right to the front of the Sacre Coeur!

Loved Montmartre. Really a wonderful day trip. I thought that it might have been too far to walk from out hotel (near the Eiffel Tower), but it was a wonderful walk. After reading the descriptions, I thought that the walk up to Montmartre might have been exhausting, but no, it was beautiful. We walked through the cemetery and then up through the little artists village. When we left, we walked down from the church. I highly recommend the day trip. However, I was using the city guide from Trip Advisor and got confused after stop one ( the cemetery). We ended up having to ask for directions. I'm sure it would have been easier with wifi or a small detailed map to help with directions.

Touristic or not. It depends of what you like. The "heart" of Montmartre is very very touristic. The surrounding area is not. You can choose whatever you like but if you stick to the first choice be aware of overpriced products and do not say afterwards that nobody was there to warn you.

Must see.... I love the ambiance of the Montmartre region of Paris. The artists, the food, the Basilica, the views...everything. It is wonderful to watch the artists painting and I bought two paintings while there this year. These are licensed artists, in contrast to the works you find in other parts of Paris. Go early and avoid the crowds.

Superb a Paris favourite. Loved Monmatre wasnt sure what to expect went up the hill on the lift then short walk to square absolutely great atmosphere lots of artists beautiful buildings lots of lovely cafes and restaurants worth sitting to people watch really enjoyed brief time would like to explore more in future

Love Montmartre. This is a hectic and crazy place to visit, but so much fun! There are a lot of tourists!!! This a great place for a walk, people watching heaven and wonderful places to eat. While in Montmartre, visit the Basilica, hike up the hill for beautiful views, visit "le mur des je t'aime", Moulin Rouge and so much more.
Montmartre. I liked everything about Montmartre. You need to experience it. The streets, buildings, atmosphere ... it is Paris!Be prepared for lots of tourists, though.

Very, very popular. There's no denying that Montmartre is extremely beautiful. On a Saturday in July, though, it is extraordinarily crowded and a bit uncomfortable. Don't go if you are disabled - the streets are cobbled and very steep.

Worth walking up to. Situated on a hill overlooking the city, this area of town has a pretty church, lots of street vendors and artists, and plenty of places to eat. If you wander away from the tourists, you find the quaint neighborhoods and the places where the Parisians eat. Negative: Beware the scammers. They come up to you and try to get you to hold something or to put something on your wrist and then they get agressive about trying to make you pay them. Alternatively, they walk up to you with a "petition" to read and then try to force you to give them money. Just a hand held up like "stop" and otherwise ignoring them does the trick. As soon as you look them in the eye or talk to them, they engage you like you are prey.

Always busy and always fun!. I love going to Montmartre on each visit to Paris. This time I took a bus and arrived on the back side of the town which I loved. We avoided all those crazy people trying to sell you bracelets by the funicular, and also avoided the crowds in front of the Sacre Couer on the way up.

Favourite Laid Back Place. On a hill, but easily accessible via the Metro (get off at either Pigalle or Anvers depending on whether you want to walk east or west) and just wander. The main streets are pretty crowded with tourists at lunch time, so either go for an early or late lunch, enjoy beautiful and quite authentic french onion soup at a road side brasserie, or wonderful gallette's in the back streets. The little shops are full of interesting things. Visit Sacre Coeur (breathtaking views over Paris) and then down towards the Moulin - red light district..there's something for everyone.

teeming with tourists. Fun to watch the artists painting likenesses and caricatures of tourists. Sacre Coeur is beautiful, and you can see most of Paris from the hill. But the walk from the metro to the hill was scary, and the neighborhood dicey.
Great tourist attraction . What a great place...as a tourist your amazed by the laid back cafés. Such a great atmosphere. The market / stalls were fantastic. Well worth a visit

Touristy. I probably went to this area at the wrong time. To give it a better chance, early morning would have meant less tourist roaming about. Regardless, it was just ok for me.There is a square in the neighborhoods west of Sacre Couer where there were a lot of artists squeezed together drawing tourists' faces. I love art, so it was neat seeing this. Around the area the architecture and store fronts are really neat, but all the stores are souvenir shops and tourist restaurants.We did manage to move outside of the tourist area to a more "local-seeming" street where we stopped for a glass of wine. Some streets were better than others.At the bottom of the hill is the sex street running east and west....south of Sacre Couer and Montmarte....where Moulin Rouge is located. That was an interesting street, but we went during the day. I wonder what it's like at night.Of course I'm glad we wandered around the area. It was pretty neat. But the stores were overwehlming souvenir focused, so that gets old.
Oh, Paris. No trip, even repeat trip, is complete without visitng Montmarte and Sacre Coeur. The steep walk up is worth it.

This is THE place for all art lovers to visit. Aside from the Sacred Heart Basilica, the next best part of this area of Paris is the incredible art you can see. From small stores that specialize in inexpensive art souvenirs up to near masterpieces to the many local artists who will gladly do a portrait for you while you sit and pose, this is a beautiful and quaint part of the city to visit. My favorite time here: the evening when it is a little less crowded and hectic and the views of Paris from the top of the steps are wonderful.

Well Worth the Time. If you like beautiful churches, Sacra Coeur is a must see. Forget about all the skanky traders who occupy the shops and the paths nearby, just go to the church and you will not regret it.

evening at Montmartre. People sitting at the foot of Sacre Coeur, eating in small restaurants, being drawn by local painters. this is Montmartre in the evening. A special atmosphere. See for yourself. You can get to Montmartre on foot, climbing many stairs, or take the Montmartre bus from Pigalle or by a funicular (about 30 second ride). ENJOY!

hidden town in paris. We stumbled upon this quaint little town when looking at the sacred heart church. It is quite a difference from the City. We were dropped off at the Moulin Rouge and that street is filled with sex shops and trashy stores, but if you make your way and go up hill to the left you will find a staircase of about two hundred steps. Once you climb them, the world changes. The streets are cobblestone and the sacred heart church is amazing, plus there is a breath taking view of Paris, great for watching the sunset. Walking past the church, the streets are lined with artists painting. There are also a multitude of stores and cafes. I loved my day there and highly recommend it

Wonderful neighbourhood. A wonderful neighbourhood with so many things to see and do, from the famous Moulin Rouge to the equally famous Sacre Couer. The Dali museum was excellent, tucked away down a little street near Place du Tertre. The flea market was a pleasant place to wander and window-shop, and there are so many cafes, shops and restaurants in the area. Just watch out for the girls with clipboards - they may be asking for help, but they're just trying to distract your attention so they can steal from you!

It is so worth it!!. Definitely a must when in Paris. Nice paintings for sale(the souvenirs here are also cheaper), there are 2 cathedrals to visit, a nice view of Paris from the top, there is even a small vineyard in it.

Nicevway to reach Sacre coeur!. Our climbing started at The Moulin Rouge making a long stop at the cafe featured in Amelie. It was very nice and pleasing and I wish I had taken some photos. We came down through the stairs.

So worth the hike!. We arrived at first just to get a photo in front of the Moulin Rouge, but seriously - take another couple of hours and go for a walk to the top of the hill to see the Sacre' Coeur Montmartre cathedral at the top. It's a tough walk up heaps of stairs and its fairly steep- but there are so many little laneways, shops, art work, little markets along the way that you won't regret it. Take your time and enjoy the walk. If you aren't able to manage the hike - there is a cable car. My husband and I are by no means fit, but were still able to do it and loved it!You know how you have a picture in your head of what something would be like? This is, to me - what Paris is! Lovely.

A must see destination!. This is a very Parisian experience, and one certainly not to be missed. A cable care is available to take you to the top if you are unable to walk the steps which are numerous. I wish we had more time to spend here on my group trip, and that I had more money and space to bring back artwork from here. One word of caution is to beware of pick pockets at the bottom of the steps, and people trying to "tie a string" around your arm. This is a touristy area, and unfortunately, that comes with the territory.With that in mind, t was very fun to walk through this district. There are actually grape vineyards as well that produce a very small amount of wine each year. Also not to be missed here is the Sacré-Cœur Basilica. I was there on a Sunday morning, and they still welcomed visitors during the morning mass. It's definitely not to be missed.

Wow what a view. It is well worth the climb up the many stairs the view is quite spectacular which makes up for the gauntlet of African peddlers that you have to run through to get to the top. Lots of street entertainers aSo peddling their ways.
Lovely. Actually it is really joyful hanging around in the small streets of montmarte.Nice small cafes and shops in the area

Loved the experience. I know many people say this is a tourist trap and dirty, but I thoroughly enjoyed my visit there. Even more than a stop at the Sacre Coeur, I enjoyed the area of restaurants and street artists (the artists "audition" and a limited number are licensed to display their art work there so the quality is good overall) and actually purchased some wonderful water colors from one of the artists for a very reasonable price. We also had a very good meal at one of the restaurants that had extensive outdoor seating and the atmosphere was both interesting and vibrant. Yes, there are tons of tourists and there are definitely tourist trap shops and restaurants, but you can find a bargain if you have the time and tenacity. What among the supposed "must sees" in Paris isn't crammed with tourists, somewhat dirty and prone to be outrageously expensive during prime season?! Time of year can be everything. Additionally, if you choose to take the steps, the walk can be daunting but the view lovely.

This is how you do Montmarte!. We had no intention of visiting this neighborhood, but our guide at Hush Hush Tours suggested that we might like it. Meeting us right outside of the famous Moulin Rouge he navigated the cobblestone streets showing us the local flavor of Montmarte. Winding our way around, we saw the café Van Gogh frequented, the apartment Picasso lived in, and many other gems our guide told us all about. We saw the man in the wall, the priest without a head, and touched (SHHH!!) an authentic ancient Roman column! The tour went up and up to reveal a beautiful view of the city, and the monumental Sacre Coeur. After shooing away the street bullies, he escorted us down all of the steps and pointed us in the direction of an award winning bakery. This is how we do Montmarte!! Thank you Philippe!
My favourite spot to visit . This place is full of little shops where you get value for your money. Can be overcrowded but it seems to fit the ambience. You will not be disappointed.

Tired.... I had not been back to Montmartre since I lived in Paris in the late 90s, wow... Needs a good clean, felt cheap and lost it's village feel. `it is clearly a tourist trap, but somehow it never felt quite so cheap...

Stroll a bit. Most of the tourists hang around the Sacre Coeur and Place du Tertre but there is more to Montmartre than that. Stroll over the back to the Clos Montmartre, the last remaining vineyard in the city of Paris. Over the road see the Au Lapin Agile famous since impressionist days and nearby the Montmartre museum. If you take a walking tour you will come away with much better insights into this very different area of Paris. Also highly recommended is doing a Google search for Paris scams. Learn about the ring scam, the string on the finger scam and the "sign my petition" scam before you venture into highly touristed areas, not just Montmartre.

Unique, but crowded and inconvenient. We took the funicular up and visited SacreCouer (worth the visit). Then we wanderec around the artist's area. It was crowded. Food was touristy and expensive. The better area was at the BOTTOM of the funicular and not at the top. If you miss out on this, don't worry.

My favorite area!. I wish my hotel had been in Montmartre!!!! When you think of the Paris of artists and music and of the heydey of Paris this is where it happened. This is the Paris of adorable cafes, shops and lovely little hotels. It's very hilly and atmospheric. Take some time to stroll around adn shop and spot the views between the tight alleys. When I go back to Paris i will be staying in this area!

GREAT views, nice cathedral. This cathedral is very different from most of the cathedrals in Paris (and europe for that matter). Not completely unique, but very nicely done. It takes some time to walk up to this great structure if you are coming from other districts in Paris, so be prepared to walk, but the trek is MORE than worth is and if its a nice day, you will hardly notice it. The neighborhood surrounding it contains less curated shops and showcases a bit more of what makes Paris great: many different cultures and cuisines from various nations!

Montmartre. Church was beautiful but they wouldn't let my 20 yr old daughter in because she was wearing shorts. ;-( Major disappointment. They let others in wearing shorts but said hers where too short....they weren't. She's a modest girl anyway so I was bit upset. So be warned...dress accordingly. The area itself was lovely. Meander the quaint little streets & stop outside for lunch to people watch. It's a beautiful view of the city from up here!

Montmartre meander. One of the high lights of Paris. Steeped in both history and beauty it is well worth the effort to get away from the crowds about Sacre Coeu into the back streets. Lots of great spots to set or just have a drink and watch the world go past.

You just need to move off the beaten path. Montmartre is my favourite neighborhood in Paris. I've stayed here a dozen times and discovered that it is so much more interesting than it might first appear. Bear in mind that I'm talking about the real Montmartre, the area beyond Abbesses. Just wander around and you'll find amazing views, people, and places. Take your time and wander at will. I hope you love it as much as I do!

Wonderful walk. The area around The Sacre Coeur is well worth a visit. Despite the number of tourists around the church, if you can get off the beaten track walk around the cobbled streets and see the artists at work, it's lovely. Feels more like the old Paris before the tourists.

Quint-essential Paris. Wondering the streets of Montmartre takes you back in time as you snake through the winding narrow streets. Must eat or have a drink in one of the many sidewalk cafes that make Paris, Paris

Favorite Part of My Trip!. If you read reviews about the sleaziness and Moulin Rouge stuff, I believe you're at the wrong place. Be sure to find the right part of Montmartre!! The street Montmartre is dirty and packed fully of people and cafes and shops. We got on a tour bus at Hard Rock Cafe and rode it to the Basilica. This is where you will find what you're looking for (or what we were hoping to find!). If you're at the Basilica facing the Basilica, go left and keep walking! My husband and I just happened upon it - at least the part where the artists were in the square and the oldest cafe in Montmartre. It's great to be able to pick up a little original for an affordable price.

Great Way to See Montmartre. Discovered a 'free walking' tour (with tip) from students and residents who give a different twist to the usual guided arranged tours. These tours meet in different areas at specified times every day. The guide was super and introduced us to styles of people, history, delectable tidbits of information, vineyards, and bee hives as he led us to a small park where people gather on the side of Sacre Couer. It gave us a totally different perspective, away from the tourists and amidst the residents.On our way down to the metro we discovered a great little restaurant called Pepone Café on 10, Rue Lepic.
Beautiful area. Great restaurants, many shops and a wonderful part of Paris. We took a walking tour of the area and loved the outdoor restaurants.

Everything I have ever dreamed about!. This place is absolutely gorgeous! I went at night, when there were less tourists and the streets were lit up beautifully. This place is the place of my dreams, and I cannot wait to return here one day!
Chilled afternoon. Great for a look around the shops, grab a meal in one of the many cafés. We sat on the hill at Sacré Cœur watching the sunset while a busker played to the crowds. Worth a visit!
Must go!. Nice place, amazing landscape and you get to see the beautiful Sacre Couer Basilica. Definitely worth a shot! Plus, it's free (unless you decide to get the funicular to go up)!

Nice stroll, cafés, shops, beautiful church at the top. A great historical site where one can enjoy strolling through cafés and shops. However, the area has been infiltrated with souvenir shops and many young people drinking, dancing right outside the church. It didn't feel historical anymore. There were many persistent peddlers, bit annoying. Sad!

Montmartre. Firstly visited Sacre Coeur Basilca which was nice with great views over Paris, then wandered off around corner to where the market area was. Lots of artists sitting sketching people, of which me and my new fiancée took advantage of. The artist was a very friendly man as well. Many little cafes and restaurants and souvenir shops as well. We liked it and if you have some time spare on your trip, it's worth a look around.

Uphill and Downhill. Montmartre must surely be one of the most iconic areas of Paris.If you don't fancy walking up the famous hill, there's a small funicular railway that you can take. Once you reach the top, you can visit the beautiful Sacré-Cœur Basilica and marvel at its architecture and ornate interior. Outside the church, there's a spectacular view of the city and it's a nice place to watch the sunset.Parts of Montmartre still have an almost rustic, village-like atmosphere: look out for the little vineyard and the Moulin de la Galette. For authentic French cabaret, visit the Lapin Agile. One particularly pictureseque area is the Place Emile Goudeau, a charming tree-lined square where you can find a recreation of the famous Bateau Lavoir, residence of so many famous early C20th artists, including Picasso. Indeed, the theme of art pervades Montmartre, with a large number of artists in the area who will paint or sketch portraits of tourists. Meanwhile, lovers of modern art will enjoy the Dali museum on rue Poulbot.Montmartre is also famous for its nightlife, typified by the world famous Moulin Rouge. There's a wealth of places to eat, including well known restaurants like Le Consulat.But there's another side to Montmartre which is not quite so romantic. It's so heavily frequented by visitors that some tourist traps and scams have inevitably sprung up. Be especially vigilant on your way to and from the Sacré-Cœur: the steep, winding paths leading to the church are the haunt of the notorious "bracelet guys" who aim to get money from you by manoeuvering string bracelets on to your wrist whether you want them or not. There are many cheap and sometmes tacky souvenir shops around and, of course, there's the red light district of Pigalle, with its seedy shops and theatres. Don't get suckered into bars or clubs with promises of free drinks or dances.So keep your wits about you when visiting Montmartre, but also keep an open mind and you'll find many intriguing places to explore in this legendary district.

Not sure it is worth a special trip.... Not sure is worth a special trip...though the Church is nice. The Moulin Rouge isn't much to look at, and the strip is pretty seedy. How all the sex shops compete with each other is beyond me. There is a Museum of Erotica if you are in to that (didn't go in so can't review). If you have the time, go, so you can say you did, and form your own opinion.

A little sleazy. I had heard how lovely and quaint this area was. As we exited the metro we noticed how much dirtier the area was than other places we had been and were immediately "greeted" by peddlers. Sacre Couer was definitely worth seeing but peddlers and scammers were in abundance. We took a less traveled route back down which was nice for the most part if you don't count the obvious prostitute we saw along the way. At the bottom of the hill on the main street, sex shops and magazine stands with topless photos abound (not great when you have your 12 year old son with you). The whole area (minus Sacre Couer) just felt a little sleazy.

Eclectic. Monmatre was one of my favorite places in Paris. it is so lively and artistic. I had my portrait done by a local artist. It was just an energetic, lively place. But, the funnicular does'nt alway work. Be prepared for some major stairs. There is also a bus or you can cab up.

Funicular up, Walk down.. You will want to take the little funicular up - it is so quaint. It was pouring rain the day we were here, but the little shops were still all open which was fun. On the way downhill, you can stop many places to take pictures, or shop, eat, get an ice cream. It is about 1/2 hour on the Metro from Notre Dame cathedral, but that includes the time spent changing trains once. Buy an extra Metro ticket if you want to take the funicular.

Died and gone to Paris. Went on the Metro on the advice of two friends. They did not do me wrong. Came out of the Metro and BAM..The Moulon Rouge right across the street. Iconic and fun to see. I saw the hills around me and decide that yes, I would meander the steep incline with shops, cafes and restaurants of all sorts, with all sorts of people. Made my way up to the top to have lunch and look over the vista that is Paris. Spectacular view. I had a gorgeous lunch with the obligatory cheese and wine and lounged for a while people watching. Absolutely could live here. Did some shopping in the little boutiques for my family and had a wonderful day. The weather was spectacular, so I lucked out there. I certainly do love Paris in the Springtime!

Iconic neighborhood. Great place to visit. Very iconic and as you can imagine.. crowed. Be also aware of the tourist traps, mainly the painters, who will try to trick you on doing a portrait and then charge for it. Beautiful place regardless.
Walk around. Walk around and let Paris sink in. Sit around in cafes and watch people pass by. Lots of bars and pubs around.

Egads, the Summer Sunday tourists. The Place du Tertre was not good twenty years ago. Now it is terrible. Restaurant tents cover most of the square. The Sunday mob scene here and on the steps of Sacre Coer made one wonder why we made the journey. Maybe other evenings would be better. What was once charming has been overrun by mobs seeking an authentic Paris experience. The authenticity is the throngs of tourists. Try early AM. or the winter months.

Lots of tourist traps.. While the Sacré-Coeur is worth the visit, either for the basilica itself or just for the view, the top of Montmartre is now just one large tourist trap, especially around the Place du Tertre. If you really want to check Montmartre off your bucket list, just power through the Sacré-Coeur and Place du Tertre and make a beeline for the must nicer lower parts of Montmartre, especially in the west.

A favorite neighborhood (with great baguettes!). During a vacation in Paris, we visited several neighborhoods. On a free day, we decided to head back to Montmartre because we liked it so much the first time! Don't just visit the area around Sacre Coeur (though you should visit--the church is beautiful and there are wonderful views of Paris from the steps out front)--make sure to head down the hill and explore some of the shops and cafes away from the tourist-focused area. There are nice cafes near the Abbesses Metro. If you like a true French baguette, Montmartre is the place to find one! A few bakeries in the area have won the award for Paris' best baguette (the winner supplies baguettes to the French president). Cocquelicot, Le Crenier a Pain Abbesses and Boulangerie Alexine are all good options.Paris Walks is a group that leads English-speaking tours around Paris; they meet at a Metro stop. We took the Montmartre tour, and it was excellent; it really gave us a feel for the architecture of the neighborhood and the history (full of artists).

Great place to visit. Take your time to look around Montmartre once you have been to the Sacre Coeur. There are some fantastic shops and stalls and you can have a caricature done whilst you are there.

Do not miss!. Nevermind the sex shops around Moulin Rouge, go to Sacre Coeur and Montmartre, get your portrait done or just observe artists doing their thing... or listen to street bands or other musicians... then check out the church and climb to the top, the view is worth it!

A quiet spot. It was raining cats and dogs, we were hungry and we stepped into Le Relai de la Butte for late lunch. Wonderful food, a fine Bordeaux wine and we forgot about the rain for an hour as we sat in our alcove by the window. You fall in love with your mate all over again. Priceless

The most beautiful part of Paris. I have enjoyed this beautiful artistic part of Paris very much. You can buy here souvenirs for a good price and have a cup of coffee at one of lots of restaurants in narrow streets. If you are tired of a day-long walking in the town of Paris, just sit and relax on the hill under the Sacre Croer church a have a nice view to the city.

Beautiful, we loved it!!!. We loved this area, make sure you have enough time, as there are so much to see & experience. Wear comfortable walking shoes and be prepared walk up some steep hills & stairs, but believe me it is worth it.Here you'll find lovely restaurants, shops and amazing arts & crafts. The vibe at night is fantastic. This to me fitted the romatic picture I always had in my head of Paris, perfectly.

Still a good place to go and watch the world. Despite being a tourist hub Montmartre is still a great place to browse through the shops and watch artists sketching tourists. The restaurants are of reasonable quality and the neighbourhood is pleasant to stroll around.

So much too do so little time!. Montmartre is so much fun! Be sure to wear good walking shoes! It's very hilly and there is LOTS of ground to cover. You will be amazed at how many people are at Sacre Coeur. Along with lots of street entertainers, artists, tons of tourist shops, and tons of things to see. Be sure to take pix of cool French graffiti and the musicians. Buy a crepe made in front of you with Nutella and cognac or stop into one of the amazing ice creams shops for the most incredible and decadent gelato that you have ever seen!

A Village within the City of Lights. No visit to Paris would be complete without a trip to Montmartre. It is a bit edgier than the usual tourist areas in the city, but it's so full of history and culture. We did the walking tour in the Rick Steve's Tour guide that starts at the metro stop, goes up to the Sacre Cour Basilica and the old village with its Vinyards and cabarets and finally to the homes of Picasso, Van Gough and other artists who lived here. All worth seeing, just watch out that this is a major area for street scams that seem to be better controlled in other areas of Paris. Finish the tour at a street cafe to have a beer and people watch.

Loved It!. We loved the neighborhood behind the church. At first my husband did want to go, as he is tired of churches, but in the end it was his favorite place. We eat in the square, viewed all the artists working, bought some original art, found a great bar with a bass player outside, listened to the music and end up at the Dale Experience. Great place!

A Beautiful Church in an Artsy Neighbourhood. The Montmartre is a very interesting area with a large outdoor square with lots of portrait and art stalls. It borders the Sacre Coeur church which has a commanding view of Paris. We had our children's portraits drawn there several years ago. The cafes are generally good and not too expensive given the number of visitors. It can be quite hectic after lunch on a good day. The evenings are enchanting and very festive. It is a key part of any Paris trip.
Must see area!. Fantastic place. A must see area for anyone visiting Paris. Try having lunch at one of the authentic restaurants by the side of the road before the square! Great in summer!!!

Very chic hot spots!. Montmartre is so awesome! It's a very bohemian area of Paris, lots of street vendors, cheap and cool souvenirs, the picturesque steps to Sacre Coeur, and of course, Sacre Coeur. I really love the free spiritedness of this area! Beware however, there are many very aggressive street vendors who try to trick you into spending. I had a few guys put bracelets right on me in about 2 seconds and then want 20 euro for string bracelets! My husband had to intervene for them to leave me alone! Aside from that, Montmarte is amazing!

Unique Side of Paris. Walking around this area to see the Moulin Rouge, then walk up the hill, seeing unusual small area. Very different compare to central paris. cosy and comfortable area to chill and enjoying the lunch. A lot of street artist, painter and small souvenirs shops. Walked a bit more you can see the Sacré Coeur

Unusual, cosy and full of hidden gems. Montmartre is a neighbourhood in northern Paris, mostly known for its iconic church Sacré Coeur. Don't just stop there and by the corny souvenir stands, though. Take your time to explore the narrow streets full of handicraft shops, young emerging designers and creators, vintage shops and cabinets of curiosities. Look for La Boutique des Anges, Tombées du Camion and Chinemachine, just to name a few. You can also find inexpensive snackbars where you can try the typical parisian crêpes and pastries. If visiting in the evening, pick one of the cosy corner bars around the Sacré Coeur and enjoy the view and the nightlife. Only one word of warning; Montmartre is a very, very touristic spot and loads of thieves hang around, trying to talk to you, to sell you stuff or get you to engage in illegal bet-games. Suspect anyone that approaches you, even if it looks as if they belong to a legit tourism company.

Different side of Paris. One of the best places we've been in Paris. A lot of culture and art. Found the cheapest souvenir-eiffel tower keychain at Euro5 for 13 pieces, tasted the best french onion soup and bought a souvenir painting from the charming old man painter at the street.We loved the laid back feeling in this area. We climbed up to Sacre Coeur via a mini train. In this way, we got the chance to see the old streets and charming little shops of this place.We are a fan of the movie Amelie and it was so overwhelming to see the locations of the movie in Montmartre.When we go back to Paris, we would love to get an accommodation in this area.

More crowded and a tourist trap than when first visited 30 years ago. While it is probably a must-do for any first time trip to Paris, you will find Montmartre to be incredibly crowded (which out for pickpockets as this is the worst place in the city) and lacking much other than the Sacre Coeur. The street artists that I recall from my first trip to Paris 30 years ago was replaced by more commercial artists. Yes, there are still some actual artists doing live drawings, but most are not actually selling their own wares.

Nice. we arrived by the metro my first impression was not the best. The surroundings once off the metro were not the best. Once on our way up to the Cathedral you can savour a different atmosphere. There is a lift up to the cathedral and that part of the city as well... as it is high. There is a considerable amount of stairs to climb. There are artisan, artist and musicians along the streets. Lovely day!!

THE CHARM THAT IS UNIQUE. Visiting France and Paris was an opportunity - a dreamy one and yet visiting Montmartre was an experience so French ... so sophisticated and yet so wanderable! The cluster of artists ... sketch or silhouette or a cartoon for a smile and friendly chat with the artist creator ... trottoir restaurants - in an infinite row ... handicrafts and souvenirs as also objets d'art all around ... give a romantic cuddle.One must visit this at least in life time tto shed 30 years 70+ as in my case!

A fabulous introduction to Paris. This is our first time to Paris and we are staying in the area, a short walk to the top of the hill, through picturesque street lined with cafés too the fabulous area.I'm here to taste test the crime brûlée of Paris and I was not disappointed. The people watching is fabulous on the sidewalk cafe seats.... highly recommend visiting this area.
A sacred heart of paris. i love this part of paris the most.... the bar and restaurant crawl right upto the church. It's a cosy nook, full of activity and charm. Next time, I'm going to stay here.

Friendly and diverse.. What a great place. So glad we booked an apartment here. The metro ride into town is easy and yet the local area is friendly and diverse. Everyone we have come across had been helpful and welcoming.

Simply French. Only spent a few hours here and adored it, plenty to do and see for everyone. The Sacre Coeur was everything I expected and more, it was beautiful. You can either take the steps or the funicular up, the Moulin Rouge is nearby also and Montmartre cemetery is worth a visit. Keep an eye on your belongings as always there's pickpockets everywhere!! Bon voyage

Great Neighborhood Bustling With Culture!. This is a great little area of Paris that is very quaint and has tons of artists painting in front of you and also cute little cafes.This areas of town is home to Le Mur des Je t'aime and the Sacré Cœur, both of which are very beautiful.Tip: If you are going to visit this area of town, come around 7 or 8 in the morning, as the crowds of tourists may spoil your views and you can thoroughly enjoy the area. However, if you are interested in engaging with the crowds or doing any "people watching," then any time from 10 am to the late evening is appropriate for this, as there will be tons of tourists here then.

A special feature of Paris. Set just behind the great white Church (Sacre C'our) {I think that's how it is spelt] the Monmarte was a wonderful experience. Lots of live artisits at work and also work on display.. Mixed with places to eat and experience artists at work - working from life models (you and me) it was a memorable visit...Would highly recommed a visit ... and if you are up to it there are about 1,000 steps to the top... but you can get transport.. find a good artis and get a portrait done.. a great momento!Kids would love it too... You will need about 2-3 hours to enjjoy the place... and if you like Art... this is a must see place!!

Great views. Once again the huge volume of tourists spoilt the visit and being jostled and pushed around is not my idea of seeing such a wonderful place. The best part was the great view for the top and the escalator or inclanator.

My favorite neighborhood in Paris. Montmartre is where you will find the best creeps, the stunning sacre coure basilica, street art and an all-around feeling of being in Paris. Still quite touristy, but not as much as the Eiffel Tower area. Be sure to pay this beautiful neighborhood a visit-- and bring your appetite.

Too Crowded...Too Touristy. My wife had last been here almost forty years ago and had remembrances of a quaint neighborhood with wonderful artists painting the same scenes as her favorite impressionists. Today this area is overcrowded with tourists and local artists hawking their mediocre paintings. Spectacular views of Paris from top of the hill, but your share them in an overcrowded venue. If you go I would suggest early on a weekday morning before others have had a chance to get there...maybe then it would be a quaint and quiet Paris neighborhood.

Nice area to spend wandering the romantic streets of Paris. The Montmartre area is lovely to spend the day walking around and getting a glimpse of the older, more classic streets that most people associate Paris with. Here you will find sidewalk restaurants, artists waiting to sketch you, some souvenir/tourist shops and winding streets with boulangeries and patisseries. My boyfriend and I did a sketch and while they are not cheap (around 100E for two depending on the artist) they do make a nice souvenir or your time in Paris. A good area to base yourself if you also wanted to visit the Sacre Coeur Basilica and take in the views of Paris.

What a Charming Neighbourhood. Our family absolutely loved Montmarte. We stayed in an apartment with a view of the Basilica. What a beautiful part of Paris, lovely cobblestone sidestreets with fantastic shops. This is a must see if visiting Paris. I will never forget their cafes and restaurants, so many choices. A wonderful place to just walk the streets and take in the breathtaking views. Lots of artists in the area.

Bohemian charm. Love this neighbourhood. Started the afternoon at the Café des Deux Moulins (or Amélie's Café), continued up the little streets to the Sacré Coeur, and then slowly down again through the little quirky streets, stumbling upon funny shops and cool bars, and just enjoying.

The old bohemian paris. A beautiful part of paris situated on a hill where all of the greatest artist such as Picasso, Modigliani lived, had there wines and partied =P now its a cute little tourist attraction, crowded with street painters/artist, old cafes and restaurant =) if i gotta complain i must say its overcrowded with tourist, but then again I'm a tourist too ;) its definitely worth a watch.
