Perfect spot for relaxed view. I love to sit on the stairs and watch/listen to the pulse of Paris. Be aware of the beer sellers and those who may look suspicious. Also nice by night while the Eiffel Tower is enlighten.

Beautiful, relaxed, walking and lots of delicious things to munch on. It is worth making the trip on the underground, and then the walk, to find some time in Monmarte. I loved the food, the coffee and soaked up the atmosphere as I listened to local music in the street. Totally a must see (and another chance to try insane cheeses that seem to walk all by themselves).

One of the most charming neighbourhoods in Paris. We love Montmartre. It is a must see when you visit Paris. It's a wonderful place to just wander the streets without any destination. Sacre Couer is obviously a must see, but there is so much more to Montmartre than that iconic site. If you have time do the walking tour offered by Paris Walks. It is an excellent way to see Montmartre and learn about its history.
Lovely atmosphere!. Lovely atmosphere, lovely shops. A must see! The Sacre Coeur cathedral is not bad but we enjoyed more our walk and the view!
09h00 to 13h30 plus. Magical cobblestone sidewalks lovely little shops on rout and then the climb/ loads of stairs only saw the elevator upon return. Beautiful scenic views. Highly recommended
Montmartre. Food, drink, music and shopping, what else is there? We there with a group of high school students. The girls were fascinated with the young French military keeping watch on everything.
Beautiful. Full of history, beautiful buildings and charming cafés. Make sure you wear comfortable shoes and take the walking tour.

Great Neighborhood. Love this area of Paris! One of the original parts of Paris and one of the oldest it's oozing with charm. But it may not be the kind of area all tourists would be comfortable in. The population is mainly blue collar and made up of immigrants. The streets are filled with the debris of daily living and the cafés are loaded with locals enjoying the joie de vive of Parisian life. Noisy nights and narrow streets make up much of the charm of the neighborhood but to many tourists it may seem threatening. Good food at reasonable prices abound but you would be hard pressed to find any of the establishments listed in fine dining guides or rated as 5 stars. You are a walk to Sacre Couer or Pigalle with its famous Moulin Rouge. I would pick this area of Paris rather than the more sterile sections of tourist traps located in the downtown area. But be forewarned it is not for everyone.

Shrouded in History. Do your self a favour and join a walking tour to really understand the significance of this area in the history of Paris and Art. Stroll through the narrow streets and understand why this place is so different to the rest of Paris.

PERFECTION. please. People travelling Paris, people reading this possible useless review, take a night out of your trip and GO TO MONTEMARTRE! Buy a rose for your fiancé, buy a rose for your wife, get your portraits drawn or painted, have a beautiful dinner. everyone working on this hill top deserves time and money. The restaurants have never been disappointing, the food has always been grand. the church is lovely . such a romantic hilltop. I beg you all to visit here and guarantee you will all enjoy it!!!

What a cool, artistique and bohemian atmosphere. Therefore, I'll continue with my exploration of, now already, the eighteenth arrondissement, a part of the Right bank of the River Seine. After the visiting of the white - domed Basilique of Sacred Heart, I had started to descend by feet to feel the touch of the old cobblestones, firmly and solidly put in the twisting steeped streets. They are (the streets) more or less small by width or length, but they include in itselves a lot of happenings. Let's begin from the plenty of nightclubs, in which govern so lively ambience. Then, here, there is a little further from the Basilique, another older church, called Saint Pierre de Montmartre for which say, that is a site of the foundation of the Jesuit order of the priests. And definitely that is an area, mostly renown for the numerous painters who lived and worked here, like Salvador Dali ( the Espace Dali is in the Rue Poulbot), Amadeo Modigliani, Claude Monet, Piet Mondrian, Pablo Picasso, Vincent Van Gogh and many others. You ought to drop by the charming cafes in these ravishing streets and try the french coffee with croissants (crescent-shaped pastry roll).Here on the hill, in the 1814 during the Battle of Paris, the Russians- Cossacks first used the term of the "Bistro" ( in the russe, it means quickly) when they wanted to be served, and so it remained as the name of the cozy little restaurants in Paris. Very popular either before or now is the tour of the Le Chat Noir(the Black Cat) Cabaret, that is announced by the artistic advertisements hanging on the walls of the houses. Also I liked the very inclined stairs in the Rue Foyatier.That was beautiful adventure on the entrancing streets of the Hill Montmartre.

Great view!. The Sacre Coeur cathedral is not bad as far as churches go but I was more interested in the view. During the day you get a look over Paris which is just as good as from the top of the Eiffel Tower. At night the cathedral steps are a hangout for locals and I recommend having a few drinks with them while gazing upon the lights below. From there it is a short walk down the hill past little cafes, bars, alleys, and painters, into the red-light district where you can take in a show at the famous Moulin Rouge.

Lovely place . It's on the high end of Paris . As you can see the whole paris from the location .. All the painters are there if your interested in painting and also you need try their cafés as located in a very nice streets

Beautiful view and good bakeries. Visited the Sacre Coeure church (before entering, there are men who would like you to donate, but it is not obligation), walked along the streets. Just for fun used the funicular to go up on the hill. Near the church there are many annoying salesmen.

We were worried.... We were worried about Montmartre the last two visits but the neighborhood has really turned around. It's about three times more crowded now, but there are new little shops, the streets are cleaned up, the shop owners are friendlier, the cafes are busier and the entire nature of this neighborhood is more like what it was our first couple of visits. We were really encouraged. We hang out in Montmartre & les Halles now instead of Île de la Cité because of the pissy shop owners in Île de la Cité. Montmartre is so fun that you'd be hard-pressed to not have a good time here or find something interesting. Even Pigalle looked a lot nicer. Normal people all over now, not just the seedy street looking people. There's still color & a bit of adventure but its not nearly as nasty as our last trip.

Magical place. Montmartre is one of the loveliest parts of Paris and although touristy still retains it's Parisienne charm. You can take the Metro to Abbesses and then walk, or take the Funicular up to Sacre Coeur. Note that there are a lot of very steep stairs up from the Metro station so take the lift if you need to preserve your energy for the walk up to Sacre Coeur. The view from the top is spectacular, however the area around there can be spoilt by the tourists and street vendors selling trashy souvenirs. There are loads of places to eat in Abbesses catering for all preferences and pricing.read less

This is where the real shopping is. Walking around the Champs Elysses and other parts of Paris, you wonder how the heck can anyone afford to buy anything in this city. Until you come to the Montmarte. Not only are the clothes stylist, but very affordable. This is a great place to walk around after visiting Sacre Coeur. There are lots of little shops to buy gifts and souvenirs, and plenty of terrific places to eat. Anyone who travels to Paris knows how much the city can take a toll on your wallet, so it's great to find a neighborhood that's a little softer on the blow to your bank account. Still an enjoyable places to visit do some shopping.

J'aime Montmatre. This has been one of my favorite places the two times that I have been in Paris. It is nice for strolling, getting a portrait of yourself, city view, shopping for souvenirs, eating snacks (ice cream), and the best thing is that you can enjoy it during the day time or night time. I went with a friend and my sister, and we visited it in October 2011, but trip advisor did not give this option.

Stay here. If you have the chance to stay in Mondmartre - DO IT. It is the real deal if you're looking to have a true french experience. Easy access to the subway, near major attractions and blended with different cultures and food. Once you get here you will never forget that feeling of wandering the streets of Paris via montmartre.

fantastic. great views of Paris from the Sacre Coeur & I loved the area around the corner where all the artists paint & sell their paintings, bought a very nice canvas of the Eiffel towertake the road from opposite the Moulin rouge for a tour around Montmartre

Relaxing, beautiful atmosphere. The highlight of my time in Paris. Better experience than the Eiffel Tower or the louvre. Eat dinner at the piano bar, get a caricature done by one of the many artists, have fun avoiding the pickpockets and trinket dealers. Enjoy being out of the mess of downtown.

Get a Local Tour Guide. You really need a local tour guide to show you all the little interesting places in Montmartre. The moulins (windmills), home of Renoir, quaint vineyard, parks, legend of Saint Vincent and of course the Bascillica of the Sacred Heart. Otherwise, you could be overwhelmed by the many cafes, souvenir shops and caricature artists. If you are looking for original artwork, you will find few. As with all attractions in Paris vicinity, go early in the day. Oh, and take the little train to the top. It is not a place for children, as the cabarets and sex shops are at the bottom of the hill.

Great food, great view. We got to Montmarte via our hop on hop off bus (great way to travel around Paris). It was very crowded but we got to the top to Sacre Couer by the funicular. The first thing we did was find a crepe place that our friend had been to before. Myhusband and friend ordered ham, cheese and tomato creeps while I ordered Nutella and bananas. OMG! So delicious. We walked up the steps and around loving the great vistas. It was cloudy and then started to drizzle. We ducked into a pastry/chocolate store and bought so many delicious goodies that we had no room for dinner. It was a great deal of fun. Many calories plus great views of the city!

As if in the cinema.... but oh those hills and cobblestones! So picturesque, with narrow streets, shops, wonderful little bistros and ice cream vendors. But the ups and downs are not for the faint hearted, nor for the high heel wearing. TIP: If you get out at the Lamarck metro take the extremely large elevator to the top...or else be prepared to march up five flights.
Dense with people drinking beer. We felt unpleasant and unsafe. Loaded with people drinking beer, dense. The view WA blocked by trees. Not sure if i would come again.

A peintures village in Paris. When you visit this authentic area of Paris, you can feel yourself in another age, the golden age of peintures... This is a fantastic place similar to Spain Steps in Roma...The church is also interesting and it has a huge bell!

Artists up close and personal. Wander among the artists creating and selling their works. Talk to them and learn about what they do, then do what we did. Take home an original, one-of-a-kind piece of art that you can treasure forever as a memory of Paris.

Worth visiting. It's different Paris. Place where live artists. And it's easy to notice it, because you can see them everywhere while you are there. Very beautiful basilique, nice view. But you should be extra careful with your stuff, afroamericans here can grab your hand, try to force you to but smth.by puting it in your hands.Lots os cafes and restaurants.Very easy to get there by metro. Station Chateau Rouge

Perfect on a sunny day. First we went here on a cloudy, rather cold day. The Sacre Coeur looked grey and Montmartre was basically dull and a real disappointment. Then we returned on a warm, sunny day and it was really great. Spent some time lying in the grass in front of the Sacre Coeur sun bathing and overlooking Paris. Plenty of nice restaurants and tourist-areas. Try to escape the most crowded areas if you want to go for a stroll and just enjoy the view and the winding streets. Nice.
Step back in time. Fantastic artist's market with plenty to see and buy according to everyone's budget. Beware local cafes are expensive.

A must to visit, but not to stay in. Montmartre is a must to visit for the simple fact of Sacre Coeur being in the area. Just around the corner from the Basilica there is the artists' square in Place du Tetre, where local artists sell there paintings and also do a sketch of you for an agreed price. There are quite a few cafe/bistros in the square, and it reminds me of the tv series 'Allo Allo'. The best way of guiding anyone to this square is if you are outside Sacre Coeur, and looking directly at it, then the square is to the right uphill then bends to the left. Walking will take no longer than 5 minutes. Word of warning, I would not recommend staying overnight in Monmartre because a lot of it is quite rough with seedy x-rated shops

Best Place in Paris. If there's a place to visit in Paris def this is the one that will inspire more. The small restaurants, the music. the artist or wanna be artists and the Onion soup make Montmartre my favorite place in Paris. Lovely bars at night with excellent cognac and good ambience. Missing it a lot

Montmartre, arty vibes everywhere!. Next station… Montmartre! Sunday sunny morning and we couldn’t have found a better place for our coffee and lunch. To be honest, the hill was quite crowed, something that gave a negative impression at first but finally we enjoyed it, as it wasn’t a problem for finding a table at a cool restaurant. The atmosphere was really amazing! A street violinist accompanied our relaxing walk by the sound of Edith Piaf’s melodies and painters who tried to convince you to make your portrait. Street exhibitions, too. You feel it though stereotypical; it’s the hill of the artists. Don’t miss it!
Great place. One of best parts of Paris and our trip. Love it a lot, what a character and atmosphere. One of only few places in Paris I would be back

Amazing view, stunning cathedral, good place for food. I would say that for me, personally, this is the most beautiful spot in Paris. The Eiffel Tower is OK, but it cannot match the charm of Montmartre. Sacré-Coeur is the most beautiful cathedral in Paris, in my opinion. It shines like a jewel high above the streets of Paris with its stunning white towers, looking light and pristine as a feather, compared to Notre Damme.The whole neighbourhood is very lively with the charming narrow streets and the atmosphere of the street artists and the cafes and pubs around.

Where's the toilet?. Went to this place, it supposed to be amazing view but rubbish bin are so full and stink of urine everywhereVery crowdedA lot of tourist and local came to this place to see the sunset but the area has not toilet, you have to go back down the steps for the toilet, the sign not even said clear where the toilet is Too bad, beautiful place but not having a good maintenance

Don’t even think of visiting on Sunday!. Maybe we picked the wrong day, maybe there are too many nouveau riches in the world, but the crowds are maddening. And hustlers of different races and origins are waiting for you. We climb the steps to the top but the square in the middle where painters peddle their wares is so crowded, you cannot see anything or even move around. I have much better memories of this place than present state of affairs. Restaurants promptly displays signs indicating bathrooms are for customers only. We don’t even consider getting inside Sacre Coeur, the line is so long. We have a brief visit in the Musee de Montmartre (see separate review), I take pictures of the Lapin Agile, an ancient cabaret, and Moulin de la Galette, once a popular dancing hall and subject of Renoir's painting. Then off we go to other adventures. We take a bus to get closer to the center and have a long walk on Champs Elysees until we reach Napoleon’s Arc de Triomphe. He started it, but did not leave to see it completed.
Intimidating Atmosphere.... If you want to be surrounded by teenagers off their heads on drugs, with the strong whiff of urine in the air- this is the place for you.

So much charachter. Walking around Montmartre takes you back in time. We were there on a cold but sunny day and enjoyed the whole experience. The Dali Museum was a hidden gem and we thoroughly enjoyed Musee Montmartre, both the building and works of Toulouse Lautrec. St Pierre de Montmartre is just set up as a selling place for tourists with mass produced pieces of artwork. We hurried through this square as it was very crowded.

Nice place to visit, just be extra aware of people around you. You may read in travel guides and websites that this area is “bad”, and yes, the area around the church is one of the worst with regards to scammers and pickpockets. For some reason, they seem to be more aggressive, so we had to be extra firm with and a little quicker with our steps. However, having said that, don’t let that put you off visiting this neighbourhood. Just be a little extra aware of your surroundings. It is a beautiful area with narrow, winding, cobblestone streets. You can see the church atop the hill from central Paris, but it is an amazing sight up close. The red light district at the bottom of the hill is interesting. We went there first thing in the morning and the place was packed with tourists so despite a lot of seedy people hanging around, we felt totally safe. I’m not sure that I would feel the same way at night though.

Beautiful and dangerous. I was here in Deecember 2011Like any place in Paris, the tricksters, pickpockets, gypsies whatever - they are everywhere! Just don't let anyone approach you, best just walk away arrogantly. The Basillica itself is superb! Go twice - one in the day, one in the early evening. A contrast of view. It's placed on a hill, just several minutes get up there. Go up there, have a stunning view of Paris itself, and don't forget to visit the church itself in the day. There are a few stalls up there you can visit to buy cheese, knick knacks, whatever .. It's worth it!

Quintessential. Spent a bit of time walking around Montmartre last week. The narrow streets, artsy feel, and hilltop views make this a great place to visit. If you've got the time and are in this part of the city, do yourself a favor and check out this neat place. We also had a fantastic dinner experience here, unfortunately, I can't recall the name of the restaurant :(
Lovely streets to walk. It is just close to the Sacre Coeur, you must have this walk after visiting it, you can uy good souvenirs with reasonable prices and enjoy the walk there

Last visit 40 years ago. I last visited Paris 40 years or so ago and was determined to show my Wife who had never been to this wonderful city some of the sights. Memories of the Sacre'-Coeur and artists square had always stuck in my mind and I guess it's still the same as it was. We never bothered to find out.Sadly Montmartre is not as it was and after passing the Moulin Rouge we decided to give the area a miss. Boulevard de Clichy has changed, full of sex shops etc, not a place to be with the family.

Trolley bus ride full of memories. This place may have got a bit tacky over the years but it is still romantic and full of character. Artists sometimes will become too enthusiastic but if you buy them a coffee and have a chat they are really interesting with there own story to tellPretty special stood on top of the hill in the rain looking across the city.Always go in search of my 30 year old memories on the trolley bus.

A good place to see the heart of Paris. A lovely place to chill and wonder around. Do NOT take children to this area as the street with Moulin Rouge as too many inappropriate images in the red light area.

The Artists Quarter. The centre of the square is full of restaurants around which the artists are seated either doing caricatures or pencilled pictures of visitors or painting and selling their wares. Well worth the visit.
Couquelicot des Abbesses. Absolutely the best pastries in this part of the city. Has won the Paris competition for best croissant in the city for 3 years. You MUST stop for a pastry.

take the walking tour !!!. we took montmartre walking tour and it was the best off beaten path. starting point is near mulan rouge to amelie's cafe, van gogh apartment and a lot more. it's free but please give him tips because he is so resourceful :)

Horrified by the change in my once favourite area. My biggest shock was seeing the Place du Tertre full of covered restaurant tables fenced and the artists occupying a metre on the outside. I've since read this is the case April to Nov. So artists have full use of the square Nov - April, the coldest months of the year when it is very difficult to draw outdoors! What a shame it has lost it's charm and given over to commercialism where people think nothing of paying high prices for food & drink but would try and knock down the cost of a portrait from an artist, which I heard them doing. Another shock is the sight you see on leaving Anvers Metro station, a tatty shop with piles of clothes spilling onto the street and a bin piled high with rubbish. You have to have your wits about you walking up the hill. The wristband trick was tried on my husband, I'd read about it and promptly pulled him away, they didn't like that. We stayed until dark for photographs then walked down the side steps where a gang of the wristband bandits were waiting like a pack of wild animals. They were persistent and I had to be firm, once we'd shaken those ones off another came running after us, a firm NO and a hand in the face did the trick.The Police really need to do something about these bandits, soon!The once characterful shops in the village are full of cheap tat, there are too many restaurants, the artists presence is minimal, instead of feeling charming as it used to it feels dangerous as you cannot escape being hassled by Eiffel Tower souvenir sellers and wristbandgangs.We WILL NEVER return. Au revoir the Montmartre I remember.

Love it. What a great place. So alive and full of character. We only got harrased once by the resident peddlers. They were trying it on everyone then the cops arrived and they absolutely bolted. Quite amusing really. The street train is fun and the view up the hill is breathtaking. Great place to spend an afternoon.

Busy and colourful. Quite busy when we went in afternoon, We enjoyed a walk around the main quaint streets and saw many artists in the middle of their work. Very nice atmosphere, not to be missed.
We then walked up to the Sacre Coeur. An enjoyable afternoon.

Enjoy an afternoon with the Artists. When visiting Montmartre we arrived in the afternoon, with a lot of people. Had some "Frenchj Onion Soup" at a restaurant acroos from Saccre de Coeur church, and then rode the funicular that took us up there.Behind the church is the Artist Square or Plaza, don't miss it, because this is the best place in town other than the church and the views that it offers which are spectacular. We sat in a cafe for some capuccino while this artist painted us.... even though was not the best picture of me. But I had a great time feeling like La Mona LIsa...

Make the effort. Located at the top of Paris' tallest point this location is very quaint and nice to walk around on a sunny day. The square was full of artists with their crafts and the restaurants were bustling.

Village atmosphere with amazing views over Paris. Visited on a sunny April evening. You feel like you are a million miles from Paris yet you have an amazing view across the whole city. Walk a few metres up the road and you have traditional bustling squares (Place du Tertre) and busy streets (Rue Norvin) full of street artists and entertainment. I loved watching the street artists below the Sacre Coeur (see photo!). However, it is very busy and you definitely pay more for food/drink because it is a tourist location.

My Favourite Attraction In Paris. I have always visit this attraction first every time I have made a trip to Paris.Yes it is very crowded at times best to avoid weekends and visit as soon as it opens otherwise you cannot enjoy the area and all the artists around.

Nice walking tour until crowds. We started at Blanche station and walked up. It is such a beautiful neighbourhood until you get to the Disneyland of sacre cour. That said, I've been there with less crowds. I think you just expect the worse and appreciate it for the beautiful place it is.

What a view, and what a church.. Well worth the climb up the steep streets and final sets of steps. The church is up there with the best in Paris, and the views from the front are breathtaking over a large portion of Paris.

Very Nice Place to Relax & Smile. Just behind Sacre Coeur cathedral, there is his amazing place. Fill with lots of artists & painters very gifted. All around cafés that will help have a nice drink while enjoying your time. I would really recommend having a drink & a portrait after your visit to Sacre Coeur ;)

Good views. Montmartre is incredibly touristy, especially the streets that lead up to the Sacre Coeur, but it is a lovely part of Paris to visit. The views from outside the Sacre Coeur across the city are wonderful. It was fun to take a trip up the funicular and wander around the street. There are plenty of artists wanting to draw a portrait, if you are willing to sit for one. When we visited there was a heavy police presence so the many street sellers that others mention were scarce on our visit to the area which made it an incredibly pleasant experience. We enjoyed the carousel ride too.

Good exercise and nice view. I took the metro to Abessess ahd walked up Montmartre. After my stairmaster experience going up the hill I landed at the famous artist area where there are 10s of artists ready to sketch/paint your portrait. The area is surrounded by cafe and is ideal for an hour of people watching. I then walked to Sacre Coeur both to see the Cathedral and get the panoramic view of Paris. Unfortunately though it was a sunny day, there was a bit of smog/fog.

Great aerial view of the city. Get a cable car to the highest point of the city, watch the sun go down. See the Sacre-Coeur, walk around the small streets. Be aware of people trying to sell you things. A lot of young people were drinking up here, there were even boxes of beer casually being sold.

Unmissable!. A must for any trip to Paris! Setting of the film Amelie, but also many many sites in its own right. Artists in the square, touristy shops, countless, well-priced cafés. The train tour is well worth the couple of Euro charge.

Great view over Paris. Nice place to sit down and enjoy take away brekfast or lunch or drinks in the evening. The park itself, in front of stairs, is closed in the evenings. Nice restaurants behind the church.

Try the walking tour. If you get a chance, hook up with a "Paris Walks" tour to visit this area of Paris. It is a terrific way to get a full appreciation for the neighbourhoods. Best baguettes in Paris are here! Lovely views from Sacre Coeur and other high points in Montmartre.

Montmatre. OK - the church (sacre coeur) is worth a visit, but the area surrounding it has long since lost it's bohemian charm for the arty farty. It's decidedly grotty and rather dodgy - avoid at night unless you want to be mugged. The view from the top of the hill is OK too - you get a vista of the side of Paris nobody really wants to see -ie no famous landmarks. Crossed it off my list, but if I'm being honest, I wish I hadn't made the effort.

A bit dirty and seedy for my liking. I hadn't visited Montmartre for over ten years - I remembered it then as very bohemian and arty and individual. This time I have to say I was disappointed. The area has become rather tacky and too touristy. It looked like it was in need of a good clean up and re-vamp. Of course, the Sacre Coeur was as magnificent as ever and the views are wonderful. We had been forewarned about the pick pocketing teams that frequent the area, and sure enough we were approached more than once. I didn't like being pestered by artists wanting to paint a portrait/ sell me a painting. I realise they have to make a living, but being constantly bothered is a turn-off for me. I'd like to see a better police presence and hopefully see an end to the pick pockets that don't encourage people to visit an area.

Must see. We ended up with the walking tour, which I highly recommend. We walked from the moulin rouge through the alleys toward sacre Coeur. We passed by Dalida's statue and house. But the view from the top of the hill was incredible.

nice walk up, amazing views, great art+cafes. This is my second favorite place in the city. Walking up to the top is a good cardio workout (or you can take the cable car). Along the way, there are nice cafes, cute shops, usually on weekends an art fair, etc. Lots to see and enjoy on the walk up. The cathedral itself is gorgeous from all angles. Sitting on the steps just below the cathedral is a nice place to relax with a bottle of wine and enjoy views of the city.

Favourite Spot in Paris. Beautiful view to see Paris from the steps in front of Sacre Coeur. People just sit and sing along, really amazing atmosphere while we were there. Place du Tertre was fantastic, many cafe and restaurants, many artists with their paintings. Dinner was fantastic. Great place to hang out and spend many hours... The place is hilly with lots of stairs, be ready ...

Beautiful. What a historical placeMy son and I went to see the Church on the hill beautiful.But the streets in cobble stone the bakery that sold incredible Lemon tarts and Fresh bread the small delicatessent which sold French sticks and twixs bars lol. And the STAIRS my goodness be fit up up up up up up up up up up up oh boy... Turn to the right oh look a cable cart have to laugh, I've never seen soo many stairs but in Paris. ( that's why they are skinny). We where there in febuary and it was really nice, I took lovely picture and tried the cafe down the hill from the Church across the street on the corner where they sell huge fresh salad and cheese and meat rolls very affordable opposite the carrousel and souvenirs cart.We went down a few street watching the popular guess where it is under the cup game very very serious and the yummy toffee and biscuit shop with the occasional street man with there adorable dogs such a lovly place to visit PS take light back pack don't cart a little cabin suitcase on wheels not a good idea ....up stairs and through sand ... Don't ask... for a short trip in Paris you need at least 5 full days min

True Paris!. What an amazing place! You have to come here to see the real side of Paris! This is what I remember the most about Paris. Artists roaming the streets, cobbled paths, lovely cafés, souvenirs, great photo opportunities and amazing restaurants! Go go go!

Unforgettable. One of the best views of the whole city with amazing vibe right from the stairs in front of the church all through the district with nice cafés , restaurants, and 18 century fashioned painters that can draw your face better than god! Down to invisible man and get to moulin rouge!
Fantastic vibe. The vibe of the area is brilliant, but certain areas are best avoided at night and some dodgy folk crawl out of their holes.

One of my fav places in Paris but beware of the disc shuffling scam!. We went here in the morning. Visited the Sacre Couer first. It was so beautiful and peaceful. You're not allowed to take pictures in the church. There was a choir singing beautiful hymns which just made the experience even more enjoyable. There are quite a lot of stairs to walk up to the church but it's okay. The view from the top is stunning. We then headed to explore the streets of Montmartre. What a vibe! So colourful and buzzing. Artists all over the place painting a quick portrait. Lotsa restaurants to choose from. Plenty of souvenir shops. We shopped here for souvenirs to take back home. Look out for these export surplus shops on the main streets. It's messy but the clothes are really cheap. And if you're lucky you could get some really nice stuff.Please please beware of the scamsters!! DO NOT entertain these chaps who have these small black discs that they shuffle around on a table. They have one disc which is black on one side and white on the other. They will take money from you...and mind you they bet in denominations of 50 and 100 euros. Shuffle the discs around and then ask you to pick the black n white disc. Almost always it is the wrong one! They are a group who do it and include women too just to make it look 'authentic'. Same scam happens outside the Eiffel Tower. That's where my mum lost 50euros! Phew. A good lesson learnt.

One of the best views of Paris. Montmartre is a fantastic artist quarter by Sacre Cœur church, overlooking Paris. The church is magnificent, view is unbelievable and pick pockets rampart! The artist quarter is great to wander around and indulge in a pencil drawing or painting of your self, family and friends. There are some lovely restaurants and souvenir shops to while away the time. Great taxi ride up and walk down!

Still atmospheric .... Now accessible by a funicular railway, the fee for which is covered by your Visitor Travel Pass if you have purchased one.I guess this IS now a tourist trap, but there is still a variety of art on display and being sold - whether you think it has any validity, is a matter of taste I suppose. It is a shame that the eateries have taken over such a huge proportion of the square, but having said that, I very much enjoyed sitting out in unseasonably sunny, warm weather, eating oysters and drinking dry white wine.For me, this is still somewhere that is atmospheric and still has a charm, even with the crowds.
Nice Views. Very nice views of Paris from SacreCour... nice area to walk around, explore some local food. The place is a bit touristy and the hawkers are a nuisance. Be careful of your belongings.

Jaded community of once great artists square. Though i enjoyed the view and seeing all the different styles of art i feel that this area is no longer a place for artists to share and make new and interesting things, but has turned into a tourist churning kind of place. As i walked around i was bothered by some makers trying to sell something as they made it. What bothered me the most as that though the artists are talented many of them purposely make the subjects look much nicer than they are whether it be younger, straighter teeth, what have you.

I agree with Frisky Traveller. My boyfriend and I visited Paris two Christmas's ago - my fifth trip and his first. Of course he wanted to see Montmartre. The best part was the ride up and the views. Very cheesy, cheap stores, hawkers of all types - not French. Mostly average food and very crowded. Sacre Coeur is still beautiful and the gorgeous view, especially at sunset, made the rest a little better. Will NOT be returning. Very sad.

speechless at the awfulness of a once beautiful place.. i am unable to find anything nice to say about this (obviously once) picturesque and quaint area of paris. we took the metro to anvers, and on exiting the station, were absolutely horrified about the unfolding scene. a 'clothes shop" that looked as though it were a recycling station, not to mention a collective of characters who would make you put your handbag under your coat, however we continued our ascent up the hill to visit Sacre Coeur. I had read up on the opportunistic scammers and frequency of pick pockets, but was unprepared for how bad this area really was. at the entrance to the gardens were two french policemen, (a presence to assure safety you would think?) er no..... a gang of young men, lining the steps with their bracelet scam, approached me and my other half, one grabbed his wrist and another his hand (probably "casing" him to see if he had a watch worth nicking(??) he had to physically knock them away before we made a sharp exit past them up the steps. had a quick look round the basillica and the streets surrounding, but could not get out of the area quickly enough. i am speechless that the french police and local goverment cannot see just how damaging this kind of episode is for an area that seems already to be going to the dogs.two days later we are home, but he has a nice big bruise on his wrist as a souvenier. (he's 6"2 and a big strapping bloke, bit that didn't seem to deter them.btw... our fouth visit to beautful paris, but our first and last to the very sad Montmatre.

Quaint village on the outskirts of Paris. I enjoyed the day trip to Montmartre and walking around the cobblestone streets. The shops vary to tourist made in China stuff to beautiful Parisian soaps and scarves and perfumes. Of course you have to see the Sacre Coeur at the top of hill. Long walk to the top but amazing views of paris.
Artists Heaven. Great atmospheric area to walk around in Paris. Seeing all the artists display their work is lovely. Lots of nice little cafés and shops

Charming. With it's narrow streets, full of artist, caffes, restaurants, Montmartre is very charming.. on the top.. But on the bottom you will see a lot of poor people and beggars so it's not really nice. It is a poor part of the city and I didn't like it much..

lovely quaint. this is a lovely lovely little town... you cannot avoid the tourist traps but getting lost in this place is worth it as there a little artistic shops selling really pretty things... there might be tourist traps all over but its still worth a visit...

The Paris I Dreamed Of. Montmartre is everything you think of when being in Paris. It is quaint, artistic, bohemian, lovely, quiet. I could live here! I can picture the artists of the day sitting at the quiet cafés and bistros. Sacre Coeur is lovely but very crowded with tourists. Walk around the Medieval streets and get away from the tourists! It is a lovely area that you will fall on love with!

Nice part of town, too many tourists. Even though Montmartre is a very nice and colorful part of Paris, I am tempted to say: Stay away. There are simply too many tourists! Montmartre consists of lots of cafes and galleries. At the square artists are lined up to display their masterpieces, but this is also ruined by the tourist poison in regards of the typical people portrais or caricatures, in stead of real art.One of the more interesting sights in Montmartre is the church of Sacre Coeur. Beautiful view over the city.

There's just something about this neighbourghood. It's something magical, romantic, bohemian, artistic, historical, so many things. It is and always will be my favorite neighbourghood. It has everything: stores, restaurants, you name it. It's worth walking around.But there's one thing anyone must be careful with: pick-pockets, scammers and beggars! The first time I visited Paris was some years ago and it wasn't as bad as it is now. No matter where you go in Paris, ALWAYS be beware of them!

Beautiful views at night. We boarded a train outside moulin rouge to take us up to the top. Once we were there we saw the artists but many had already left. We went to see the scare coure church there were lots of teenagers sitting on the steps looking at the view of Paris and the Eiffel Tower in the valley. There were also entertainers outside the church. The view is spectacular at night. There are also several restaurants and shops as well.

Great part of the Ctiy. It doesn't feel like you are in a big city. This part has been preserved like it was years ago. There are artists, cafes, and great streets to walk and see the sights. Don't miss this part of the city it is one of my favorite parts. A great place to see the sun set!

Romantic. Really beautiful building, people were sitting enjoying the music played by a performer while looking across the city of Paris, casual but very very romantic.
French movie in real life.

True Paris. We fell in love with this area. It was fun and easy to get there on the Metro but make sure as soon as you leave the Metro car that you take the elevator and not the stairs! Once in Montmartre you will love walking the streets with all the shops and cafes. Lots of restaurants and we ate at one on the square at the top of the hill close to Sacre Coeur.

Beware of pick pockets and scammers and beggars. Just back from this attraction on the way up the steps towards the cathedral the latest scam is to be approached by young women who are pretending to be deaf . Once they engage you they get you to sign some kind of sponsor form. After you sign this they pester you for money. Don't even speak to them this is a scam. This was also being tried at CDG airport. Police are around but don't appear to be interested. Next there are pickpockets everywhere easily spotted if you look. The other major scam Are by groups of men approaching members of public on mass surrounding them and almost forcing you to buy some kind of bracelet . Be careful they are very intimidating and aggressive if you refuse to buy from them. This was reported to the police at the time but again the police don't seem to be bothered. They said there were plain clothes officers in the area. If there were they weren't doing a lot. Also beggars at the entrance and exit of the attraction. All this spoils what is a great building and lovely area. The French police need to gets grip!

this is the Paris I dreamed of!. Even though this area of the city has A LOT of stairs, I found it completely magical. Sure, there's a ton of touristy shops, and general pests selling stuff you don't want, but that's only a small slice of the neighbor hood. If you ever go, lose yourself in all the little, winding streets. Find yourself caught up in spectacular views of the city. The neighborhood is absolutely quaint with shops, restaurants, quintessential French architecture. You can really feel the history of the area through the vibe of the neighborhood. Fabulous!!

The romantic corner of Paris is on the top!. I have to gush and say something about Montmarte after having been there a few times on different trips. Apart from the tourist crowd (which you can avoid by not going to where guide books recommend in the area) and vendors selling wrist bands or souvenirs of all sorts, there is something magical about Montmarte away from the usual crowds in Paris. Amble along the windy roads, uphill and downhill (beware the 'landmines' left by dogs!), and you find that this part of Paris is a different place altogether. It has such character and a soul that, to me, is the essence of Paris. From the charming little vineyard just across the Lapin Agile (where Picasso was supposed to have hung out during his formative years as a fledgling artist) to the impressive Sacre Coeur, Montmarte has much to offer. It is so easy to lose yourself in this corner of Paris. If anyone tells you that Paris is a romantic city, it's because they have been on top ;)

No to be missed!. You can't come to paris without passing by Montmartre... Won't add more you should live the experience! Well I have to write 100 characters so would say tour the area and the church then enjoy a break in one of the restaurants...

Wish I could go here every day. My favourite spot of Paris. The stairway to the Basilica is full of life and animation - street artists, food stalls, small gift shops, and the most beautiful views of Paris.A few meters from the church, the Place du Tertre is a gathering of great painters, which draw great sights of Paris. I was disappointed not to have bought one, but then again the paitings are very expensive... Maybe next time, when I'm richer!I spent 4 hours just walking by and enjoying this neighbourhood. Loved every bit.
No need to review - spectacular place. The view of Paris is amazing, the architecture superb. We enjoyed walking among the artists who were vying for our trade.

Magical. Place is magical, the people, the spirit, shops, the view, everything! Absolutely wonderful, it makes you want to stay there forever. I had the best time ever in front of the church, some guy was singing and playing the guitar and he made people sign with him, the sun was shining and behind him was Paris, standing so beautifully and proudly. It all made me so happy to be there and alive.

Wonderful to see so many artists. Montmartre has an amazing bohemian atmosphere & you could spend hours looking around at some very talented artists. Tends to be rather a tourist trap. As with any big city be careful with security re your bag.

Lovely neighbourhood. This neighbourhood is famous for the place du tertre and the sacre coeur but has so much more to offer. The very centre is populated by touristy shops and restaurants. but if you take to the little streets you enter a different world. lovely old houses, a museum, a vinery, cabarets places, cemetaries, and a very old, cosy atmosphere, please allow yourself time to explore it and you will be amazed

Lovely but too many tourists. Too many tourists unfortunately! But there is a nice quiet garden at the back of the Sacre-Coer where you can relax (this was in March on a lovely sunny day) I also loved the quiet of the cimitiere, I got a bit lost trying to find it but that was part of the fun

nice admosphere. The admosphere in Monmartre is really good, I went on a walking tour with new paris tours (Sandemans), this is a good way to visit the city since the guide tells a lot of nice stories while you walk around. Afterwards you can stroll around some more on your own if you like to.

Where locals live life and kiss the waiters hello, and there are few tourists..... There are 2 parts to Montmartre. And the 98% part is amazingCobblestone streets, almost no tourists, no grand flashy boulevards, no "gift shops", authentic restaurants where locals greet each other the waiters; and you can sit in a café for hours and people watch. And go to restaurants where you are the only American.This is the Montmartre I stayed in over a long weekend and fell in love with.Then we saw the 2%- in front of the sacre coer steps with the annoying aggressive peddlers, the sex shops further down the hill - this is not true MM, and if this is all you see, you are missing a great experience.Walk up Lepic and have a coffee on Rue Abbesses. Then walk up Lepic to the West, go up to coulaincourt towards Lamark on the North side of Montmarte. Discover hidden alleys and pedestrian streets, and local restaurants....

Square is Filled With Artists Painting Pictures for Sale. You can buy a picture hand painted by a local artist while you are here. Some of them even take credit cards. I buy mine unframed and then get it framed back home. If someone is taking care of your house or pet while you are here, it is a wonderful way to say thank you. A local painting is a lasting souvenir of your visit to France. There are also places to eat and do more shopping. The Sacre Couer is nearby, so make sure to do that also at the same time.
Good view. I love this neighborhood! It's full of artists, cafes, and souvenir shops (arguably the cheapest and best quality in Paris) and it gives a fantastic view of the rest of the city.

AMAZING VIEWS. This was one of my personal favourites from a first visit to paris and thought with it being my partners first time it was important that she went and seen it. Easy little metro ride and then the lovely stair climb to an amazing set of views. Not religous in the least but we went into the church and its incredible scale and design is worth a look but the views are the highlight!

artists everywhere. Here you find artists who can draw a picture of you .. classic or comic ... but you have to negotiate for the price .. souvenir shops are everywhere, but take care of your purse, it is crowded.

Nice area and rewarding view from top of mount. Easily accessible via the metro, Montmartre is the artists district of Paris - home to narrow and windy streets, boutique stores and a great view from the top of the hill near Basilique du Sacre Coeur. Take your time to wander around the area and be rewarded with great coffee, pain au chocolate and breathtaking views over Paris.
imposant. people say you have the best view when on the eiffel tower but I disagree. Montmartre is the place. Don't miss the little square with painters on the way down to moulin rouge.

When in Paris.... If you've been in Paris longer than a few hours you should know to have your wits about you and to take caution anywhere you go - don't let negative reviews stop you from visiting Montmarte. We read reviews and almost didn't go as we were scared we may be accosted by people selling wristbands and souvenirs. Then we thought, it can't be any worse than what we've already seen at the Eiffel Tower and Champs Elysees, so we went anyway - and we are so glad we did! I can't compare it to what it used to be as other reviewers have, and no, it's not romantic, it's actually pretty grimey; but if you go with an open mind and just enjoy the Parisian vibe, artists, cafes, churches and views for what they are, you'll enjoy it. We walked the cobblestone paths, bought some art from a man painting in artists' square and enjoyed people watching from one of the cafes. Visit for a lovely afternoon.... just hang on to your rucksacks.

Be careful!. If you do decide to visit Montmartre then take great care of your belongings. My wife's rucksack was stolen from beside her feet while we looked at a map. Spending 3 hours in a police station was not soemething we had planned for the evening and obviously the experience ruined our day if not our entire stay in Paris. The area around Montmarte is very rundown and even without the theft I don't think I would recommend a visit unless you have exhausted all alternatives.

Love it. WE travelled here on the metro getting off at Anvers. From there you just walk up the hill to Sacre Cour to be rewarded with a fabulous view. Pick a nice day if you can an spend time at the top in a cafe watching the many artists doing the tourists portraits. A lovely way to spend an afternoon.There is a cable car type contraption to get you most of the way up, or if you can manage it the steep walk is a great way to burn off the chocolate crepes!

Worst area of Paris. Paris is a nice place to visit however Montmartre has gone straight downhill the last few years. I strongly recommend tourists to go elsewhere, especially if you are visiting with children. It is not a safe area. Children are not left alone. This used to be one of the best areas to visit in Paris, now its just a scary rundown neighbourhood. Nothing romantic left.

Worth exploring. A village hidden in Paris, we got a cab to the sacre coeur and explored around, the place de tertre has some sweet little shops and an amazing art nouveau cafe, the music is authentic and walking in is like stepping back in time to the early 1900s. A charming area full of artistic history .

Just love it!. Having been to Monmartre many years ago I had fond memories and again it did not disappoint! Beautiful french architecture lines the square where many artists sit and show their work. My daughter had her portrait done and it is so good, so like her! I couldn't help but fall in love (again) with the atmosphere of this arty, bohemian part of Paris. Despite it being February and very cold, yet sunny, Montmartre is so pretty and vibrant - well worth a visit. We had brunch at Chez la Mere Catherine which was lovely. Omlettes and salad with coffee sitting by the window watching the artisans at work.
Nice part of Paris. Montmarte during the day is lovely but keep your wits about you.However during the night all the sex clubs give it a very sleazy feel.

Don't miss Montmartre!. I was expecting something different, something bigger and with more glamour. Totally wrong. Small streets, crowded with tourists looking for the best scenario for the next picture. You can feel the ambience in the streets, full of artists of all kinds, mostly paint artists. I love the cafes, but careful with the touristy ones, that may overcharge the most distracted people.A place that shouldn't be missed by any tourist in paris

Quaint shops and an artists paradise. Apart from the fact that Sacre Coeur is here. It is well worth wandering around the shopping areas watching the artists at work, getting a sketch done of yourself and then walking down the road to Moulin Rouge

A Great Place to Explore. One of the best ways to enjoy Montmartre (Reach it from one of the nearby Metro stations such as Anvers) is to climb the steps to The Sacre Coeur, look back over the panoramic view of the City, and then having turned back to face the basilica walk down the steps to the left which leads to the higher part of the area. You can then gradually work your way down to the lower levels taking whichever byway you choose on the way. Any direction you take will lead you to interesting places and there are many good cafes and restaurants to linger on the way.. Do not forget the excellent Museum de Montmartre which is well signposted. On a sunny day there is no better place (Try to avoid weekends when it is too crowded). The aura of the great artists and characters that frequented the lanes is long gone but there are many interesting characters and some of the portrait artist who offer to draw for you are very good indeed.

Lovely area. Try and get out by the metro at Abbesses station as it has one of very few remaining original Metro entrances - itself a nice photo stop. The funicular up to the top of the hill only takes 5 minutes if that and you can use a metro ticket/carnet to go on it. We walked back down the adjacent steps from Sacre Coeur where of course there are wonderful views over the city.Back down near the metro are lots of nice, if pricey, shops and restuarants including a very upmarket bakery that we found.All in all, a lovely part of the city.

Lovely area but be careful. Good shops and restaurants as well as a lively atmosphere. The Montmartre are is definitely one to visit however you have to be mindful. There are many men preying on naive tourists to buy overpriced tat. I was circled by many of them who wouldn't let me go - as a woman this was pretty unnerving especially as other people just stood and watched.

Vibrant and busy. Several ways to reach the top of this stunning hill/mountain. Funnicular, tourist rail/ bus or WALK. yes that's the best but it is quite a climb over cobbled streets. The view from the top is truly amazing. There are plenty of spots to rest on the way up and lots of interesting little parks and galleries on the way. When you turn the corner to be greeted by the artists square it makes the climb well worth it ( plus you'll deserve a sweet treat or vin)Yes, there are artists. Your eyes will tell you who is good and who is...well not so. Many restaurants available but service isn't the best as it is a tourist hot spot so they don't rely on return customers. Watch out for pickpockets. Don't let that put you off, just be aware and careful. The guys playing their Carribean type tunes on the side of Sacre Couer are entertaining, but if you walk the block and come back, it's a fair chance they'll be playing the same song. If you want a good meal in Montmartre then I suggest you head downhill...somewhere between the top and Moulin Rouge so you are out of touristville. Any where around the metro Abysse (spelling?) is a good area

Worth a trip but need to mindful. Montmartre is one of our favorite place in paris, climbing up the Dome Et Cryte is an awesome experience 300 steps, we have purchase quite a number of original art works reasonable however two bad things we have experience during our visit, 1) This aggressive black guys trying to sell some tacky stuffs holding my husband hand refusing to let him go, my husband have to warn him few times not touch him before he release his hand with abusive remark 2) an artistic approach us if we wanted a self portrait, I check with him on the pricing before engaging him 30€ for a sketch and €50 for a couple however after he finish the sketch quite fast he change his price saying that it suppose to be 50€ for one and 100€ for a couple. Cos we are not student. We refuse to pay him 100€ as this is not what we hv agreed we have given 60€ instead. He quickly accept it and went off. We decided not to frame his work.Despite the two bad experiences I give a four star Cos we really love Montmartre the arts the romance and the history we will come back again ...

The best place to be. For me the Montmartre is the most romantic place of Paris. I love to sit on the strairs in front of Sacre Couer and listen to the street musicians. Than have a glas of french wine in one of the small bistro with local artists and walk through the romantic streets of this magical historical place.

Artists corner. We stopped here to watch the artists at work & ended up having our picture done. Our artist was amazing it really made our day the result was simply stunning. Good fun & a lifelong momento to boot.

Look past the crowds & see the beauty of Montmartre. We has a wonderful day following a walking tour of Montmartre, visiting all those delightful spots you would normally miss. Montmartre has such character and can be viewed without fighting the crowds, hawkers & pickpockets. We followed the walking tour on http://www.paris48.com/montmartre-walk.html which was wonderful and I highly recommend. Our highlight was the Dali Museum, which is just wonderful.

Smooth and wonderful alleys of Montmartre. Ah! Montmartre. Perhaps the most charming endroit of Paris. About a century ago Montmartre was the artistic throbbing vein of Paris - although the golden years are gone, the charm remains and one could easily see why this was the preferred place for artists. Small and narrow alleys up the hill, crêperies and cafés everywhere. Charming little houses, flowers on the windows.Take a romantic stroll, visit "le mur de je t'aime" (the wall of I love you), and please if you've read "The Walker Through Walls" from Marcel Aymé, stop for a second at Rue Norvins to check out the statue Jean Marais (a French actor) made in tribute to this character. Rue Norvins will take you straight to Place du Tertre, where painters and musicians are to make your evenings much more delightful and happy. =-)Go to Montmartre, take your time. Don't be too eager to see everything. Just sit back and enjoy what is the most romantic and parisian neighbourhood of Paris.

Ideal Base!. When we decided to go to Paris, on a recommendation, we stayed in Montmartre. It was the highlight of our stay. There's a certain feel to Monmartre, a village within a great city. There's a bohemian ambiance that pervades the cobbled streets and winding hills and stairways. The many artists that have resided here have left there mark, make sure you visit the famous wind mill or Moulin de la Galette. This is where Renoir painted his famous painting "Le Bal du Moulin de la Galette" You also sit above Paris here especially when you visit the fabulous Sacre-Coeur, the love it or loath it Basilica that rises above Montmartre.

Definitely worth going to for the views.. If anything, the views are well worth it. Also enjoyed the local artisans as well as having our own portraits done by the artists that walk around offering to sketch you.Outside of the Montmarte is a residential area full of outdoor food markets which was great to look around.

Never disappoints!. I visited this place 15 years ago and this year again after all those years and the place did not lose its charm. I was smitten by it then as I was now. It breathes history and art. Let's not forget food, as there are many possibilities in this way too. We saw many painters, musicians playing, souvenir shops and beautiful houses everywhere. It is a very different face of Paris when compared to what you can find in the other parts of the city. At Place des Abessess, you can find one of the two complete remaining art nouveau metro stations, Wall of "I love you" many beautiful churches, statue of Marcel Ayme (The Man Who Walked through Walls) made by Jean Marais and so much more... Even if you have only 3 days in Paris, definitely do not miss Montmartre! We returned again the following day, that itself proves the magic of this place!

Amazing neighborhood even in the rain. I wish I had better weather to walk around and spend some more time in Montmarte... the painters square, the streets filled with bars and shops all in all great Parisian atmosphere !

The many faces of Paris. The first stop in Paris, should be in Montmartre. Specially in the afternoons. Great cozy bars and restaurants, amazing tiny indipendent shops and Amelie Poulain (the movie) shooting places.

full of history. We took a guided walk to discover Montmarte, and it was a worth while experience to discover the history of this beautiful "village". We also returned to Montmarte on a 2nd occasion on our own as we were hoping to purchase a painting from one of the artists. Unfortunately on both our trips there were no artists in the square ( the weather was not great on both these days). The views from the hill are beautiful and the streets are a treasure trove of history. There are lots of wonderful photo opportunities. Worth a trip, but do be aware of pick pockets and the "bracelet" men. We were approached but as just kept our hands n our pockets and walked past them.

Stunning view during dusk.. The view of this place is absolutely stunning during dusk. Just get yourself a few sandwiches, sit on the front lawn of Montmarte and just enjoy the spectacular view of Paris at dusk. Probably the best place to go to if you want a nice and quiet last evening in Paris. You can go there with friends, family or your significant other, you will have a good time.Once it starts getting dark, do the walk from Montmarte to Moulin Rouge. You will see the local market, beautiful restaurants, souvenir stores and wonderful street performers.Really good place to go to for a uniquely Paris outing

If you enjoy being the victim of crime, this is the place for you.. I read the tour books about the various gangs that work the crowds at Montmartre but I never expected it to be so bad. You approach the church at the top of the hill and you are surrounded by gypsies trying to get you to sign a petition. What they are really trying to do is distract you so you can be the victim of pickpocketing. Then when you leave the church you are surrounded by young men trying to "sell" you friendship bracelets. They are very threatening and persistent. It is not worth a visit to the church when you have to go past these thieves. The town itself is mostly a lot of souvenir shops with junk at high prices. We even wandered onto the side streets as recommended by the tour books and still saw nothing worth the trip.

Watch the artists in the square. It's a hike up many steps to get to the top near Sacre-Couer. Here there are many artists. There are also so many tourist souvenir shops it loses some authenticity. Plenty of cafes to choose from.

Another lovely, interesting part of Paris!. Do not miss this most interesting section of Paris with its art section where artists are actually painting, selling art, discussing their works, etc. You're at a very high point and have outstanding views into "downtown" Paris--go to the very top of Montmartre and visit the Sacre-coeur church. In back, to the right of the art square is a wonderful gallery of Dali's works--some for sale and some to just love looking at. As with most places in Paris, there's art, history, churches, captivating people, and an ambience that's tops and, of course, very easily accessible from anywhere in Paris using the incomparable Metro!
Don't miss Montmartre. Visited here over twenty years ago. Loved the street artists and cafes at that time. Sipped wine in a funky piano bar/bistro and watched the world go by.

So what if its busy.... This is a lovely part of Paris. Of course it's busy - it's beautiful, so its going to be - especially when the sun is shining. Real bohemian atmosphere about the place. It was a lovely day in December when we visited. Could spend a lot of time here. We thought about staying here but I think it would be too busy for that. The main square where the artists were was heaving, but we put this down to the glorious weather as Montmartre in the rain is probably not so good.

Amazing bohemian Paris. If you like the village style of site seeing attraction , you will like Montmartre. It is a village in a big city. It has its Bohemian cachet with all its artists mostly painters. Don't miss the panoramic view of Paris from Sacré-coeur church stairs terrace. If you are good enough you can locate your hotel from this terrace.

True Parisen style !. Hi, both my wife and I visited and stayed in this area of paris. The area boasts some of the best restaurants in Paris. The area is very well kept and is well worth a visit. Metro stations are a stones throw away.

Excellent place,Go to here even you have just one night in paris. Very interesting place,every cafe have its history, many famous writers,artists had visited cafe and restaurants on the hill.I spent a full evening here and I wish to come back again and again.

Don't only stay at the front. Worth to take a stroll around the garden area, specifically the path beside Rue Maurice Utrillo. The view of the city from there is one of the truly Paris we think, no Effel, no Seine, just like the ones in 'Amelie'.If possible, join a Saturday night service of Sacré-Cœur. We're impressed by the angle-like singing.Walk around Sacré-Cœur, see some differences.Be ware of pock lifters. We definitely saw some.

Great walk around. Enjoyed this area. A bit touristy especially at the top. We went to the Montmarte Art Museum which was small, but worthwhile. I'd spend less time at the top of the mount, and more at the bottom in the neighborhood.

metro at Abbesse. A day pass on the Paris Metro is 6.50 Euros. On and off where ever and when ever you want during operating hours. I took it from the Seven district near the Eiffel to Montmarte. When you get up to the street level turn to your left, and walk straight up the hill to the Basilica. Lots of shops and eateries. Lots of tourists, of course. Couldn't be easier. If there are too many stairs for you go to the right of the carousel and there is a funicular to the top. I think it was 3.00 Euro for one round trip up and down. The Metro runs every two minutes. Easiest way to get around Paris. A lot cleaner and more efficient that US subways.

a very interesting place. It is very nice walking the streets of Montmarte, to sit for a coffee below the Basilica.I belive it is the best place for souveniers, much cheaper than in other place.Don't forget to have a look at the "Small Chocolate Museum" (a very nice, small shop) and take a few Macrons from there :)If you walk up to the churche please take care for the African guys!

An intriguing and charming place. Sadly we only spend two nights here but from what we discovered on that short stay will likely be back to discover more. The streets are busy and full of shops and cafes. People live here and get on with their lives, surrounded by tourists. The fact so many people live and work here made me feel safe. As in any city I think you need to take precautions, but not once did we feel threatened. There was a mixture of newer "high street" type stores and unusual artesian type stores selling some really unusual things. If only our weight allowance had been higher on the plane!

Colourful, different, bohemic. Is is really a pleasure walking the streets of Montmarte. Visit the places the great artists lived, walk up the great white Basilica, enjoy the lively markets, full of artists and get lost in its colourful streets. Visit the only remaining vineyard in Paris and see the Moulin rouge cabaret.

New Years Eve 2012 celebration. My husband and I climbed the slippery steps of Montmatre on 31 December 2012 to ring in 2013 with hundreds of other revellers! What an amazing and spiritual experience! A church service had just ended and the religious sentiment was palpable. It was raining and freezing cold yet the experience was the best we have ever had to ring in the new year!!!! We shared a divine pizza at a small restaurant at the bottom of the steps (sorry we cannot remember the name, but what a lovely gentleman that owns this establishment).

Dodgy, dangerous and stressful - DO NOT GO. Got hustled by some sweet talking African guys, I've heard you get harassed if you don't comply, but please don't let them get you. Don't walk through the park area below the Basilica, you'll get stuck, even early in the afternoon. There is far too much hustling and pickpocketing around for this to be a worthwhile trip. The view is mediocre at best, and the restaurants are over priced. Find a nice place somewhere in the real Paris, Montmartre is no good. The only redeeming thing is the Dali exhibit, it's fantastic and worth looking for. Whatever you do to go there, though, come from the back and not from the Basilica. Avoid that place at all cost. As with everyone else, this is the only place in Paris I felt unsafe. You won't miss it.

Beautiful. Having read a few differing reviews of this area, I was reluctant to visit. I presumed I'd be pickpocketed, robbed blind, harassed and bored silly. None proved to be true for us!We visited in the evening and it was truly magical atmosphere, the painters and cafes and the beautiful church. The tourist souvenir shops can be missed as they are full of expensive tat.Overall brilliant evening!

Plenty of artists for a memorable experience & unique souvenir. Some very talented portrait and caricature artists. A little more pricey than i expected though. The best price we were given was 90 Euros for a couples portrait so we had a couples Caricature done for 30 euros (bartered down from 40) Very happy with it too.

Over-rated and risky. Beware clipboard schemes and street merchants as they're a diversion while someone picks your pockets. Do not bring anything of value here. Moreover, there are plenty of other safer/cleaner/nicer places to see in Paris but this was sadly a waste of time. It's now very much a tourist trap and I'd recommend passing.

Interesting~. Wonderful place to look around, but better on a warmer day. I wish I had my portrait drawn by one of the artists too, they're all really good!Bad thing is that all the touristy shops are SO expensive. This is probably the most expensive touristy place to visit in Paris.

Worth the trip!. This was memorable. Not only were the views great but the people were so pleasant and hospitable. There were plenty of artists working and while I was there plenty of Christmas vendors all around. It felt as if this part of Paris was having a special small town celebration and everyone was invited.

Simply Wonderful!. This is a beautiful slice of Paris, and is among my fondest memories of The city of Light. Situated on a hill north of Paris, this area is known for its street artists and the Bascillica of the Sacre Couer.We walked from Moulin Rouge to Montmartre at dusk. I must admit that I felt a bit uneasy about the neighborhood between Moulin Rouge and the stairs at Rue Gabrielle. Nothing happened to us, but not a walk I'd want to make at night. Those streets are dark, narrow and the graffiti hints that this is not a place for tourists to wander at night.The stairs from Rue Gabrielle to Place du Tertre will test your cardiac fitness, but its part of the Montmartre experience because when you take that final step its like walking into another world. In Montmartre time seems to pass at a slow, leisurely pace. People are strolling the streets looking at the numerous gift shops or engaging in casual conversation at one of the many bistros.We walked over to Sacre Coeur and did a quick tour of the Bascillica. We lingered on the steps for pictures as dusk turned to dark. The lights of Paris are amazing when viewed from the steps of the Bascillica ... a view that everyone should strive to experience.Later, we dined at one of the local bistros and bought a few pieces of art. The artwork is formula stuff, not investment-grade. However, the colors are vivid and the scenes are recognizable. Looks great in our familyroom with pieces we've collected on our travels.Many reviews have commented about beggars and pushy souvenir sellers. Those sorts are certainly in/around Montmartre. However, the presence of these elements should not deter your visit to the area. Montmartre has far less of this element than the main tourist sites of Paris (Eiffel Tower, Lovre, etc). We took a taxi from Montmartre back to our hotel (about 4 blocks south of the Eiffel Tower). The fare was a very reasonable 12 Euros. I am so glad we found our way to Montmartre ... and would highly recommend this as a must-see destination to those visiting Paris.

Big Church on a hill -. Went on a cold day - dirty area with huge number of tourists. The church was pretty. There is a wc at the top of the funicular at the gift shop. dirty neighborhood. Interested to see if it would be better in the spring

What a shame. I have to echo some previous reviews and say "what happened to this place"? It has been 15 years since my last visit and to say I was disappointed is an understatement. City officials need to step up their game. This part of Paris should be a gem but instead it's a dump. Garbage is overflowing and the streets are filthy. The quaint shops with tapestries and fabrics from around the world have been replaced with cheap flea market shops. The quiet streets have been overrun by scammers and beggars. I'm not sure what the fix is but I won't be back to that part of Paris. Someone needs to step up and reclaim montmartre!

Wonderful. Montmartre, like Le Marais, is a very special, preserved part of Paris. A walk from the bottom of the stairs to the Sacre Coeur and then around to the artists square is well worth it. Lots of lovely cafes and eateries line the streets along the way. Bring some extra money and get a portrait done or buy some original Parisian artwork in the artists square. Something to note though is that the bottom of the stairs to the Sacre Coeur are crowded with guys who will try to aggressively sell you tacky souvenirs or worse, try to put a bracelet on your wrist or give you a rose and then demand money for it. Despite saying "no thank you" a number of times, at one point I had my wrist grabbed by one guy demanding that I give him a minute. My partner was also harassed. Keep this in mind and make sure you bring a handbag that zips/closes properly rather than something that valuables can easily fished out of.

The Jewel of Paris. Situated in the 18th arrondissement, Montmartre gives you the spectacular views of Paris. Once used by King Henry the IV during the French Wars of Religion, this lone hill holds a rich and colorful history. Interestingly, Montmartre was used for war and religion and for religious wars. I recommend walking up the hill. Take your time enjoying the gorgeous architecture of the Basilica Sacré Cœur. Which is one of the most unique in all of Europe. There are a few cozy cafes atop and of course a few souvenir shops which proudly carry French made gifts. In the square you will be able to get a snapshot of the real Paris as you will see hundreds of Artists painting scenes of Paris. You must spend a day here.

do not visit montmarte to late. really wonderfull part of Paris, but we made mistake with wisiting it for first time around 23h.there was almost nothing opened...other day we came around 18h and it was full with people, all restaurant and cafes were working...anyway visit the church, and take a lot of photos of paris from a place in front of church.we played also a game - who will first find eiffels tower... it is easy, but you do not see it in first few seconds...you must visit square at top of montmarte were lot of painters making portraits of guests... i am not fun of making portrait- but it is really colourful and lovely place...

Highly recommended. Wonderful artistic area, and well worth the visit. Since Montmarte is located at the top of a hill (and it could be quite a tiring walk), I do recommend riding the funicular up (and down!). You will find several charming cafes surrounding the square where all of the artists are set up.

An interesting travel from the mountaintop to the valley!. Sacre Couer on top of Montmartre may well be one of the most beautiful sights in Paris. The "funicular" was our friend as riding up the mountain was much preferred to walking up! This trip had a new option -- taking the Montmartre Train down the mountain to Pigalle. It was very different scenery, as this is the home of the blatant sex trade that has flourished in the area for ages. The streets are lined with sexually oriented businesses. Pigalle is also home to the Moulin Rouge. To see the show at the Moulin Rouge and to dine there is expensive. Still, it is the part of risqué Paris that draws many visitors!

Exciting beautiful area. Just a great little area atop the Montmantre hill gives a great view of Paris . The hill is crowned by the Cathederal of Sacre Cour. which is a wonderful experience just in itself.It is surrounded by lots of little shops, Bistros and the little square filled with local artist and their works. It was a memorable afternoon. I imagine it was somewhat like the Paris of an earlier time which so attracted the American expats. The streets are rough cobblestone, and steep so wear comfortable shoes , and if not in good physical shape, hire a cab. A nice hotel, the Mercure Montmatre, is nearby and I suggest it as it is also near restaurants, the underground, Molon Rouge, etc. We were not plagued with beggars and aggressive peddlers as with most other parts of Paris. Enjoy!

Where the Bohemians Roamed. I love this area and took my own walking tour (with the help of a travel guide). I walked down streets, little alleys, saw a vineyard, welcoming cafes and delighted in the drizzling rain on the cobblestone streets. I was transported back in time. There were a lot of people but on some streets there wasn't anyone. I have the luxury of taking my time since I will be living in Paris for a few months. But even if you're on a schedule you'll be charmed by this area and you'll long rememberit after you return home.

Beware the aggressive beggars. Wonderful building with spectacular views. However it is overrun with fellow tourists and there are LOADS of aggressive African migrants who come up to ever tourist and try to tie a bit of string around their finger before demanding money from you. I went there a few days ago again and I was prepared to be harassed. I told the first person "No" but he grabbed my arm. I raised my voice and told him to let go of me. He then became very aggressive and asked me if I wanted to fight with him. I carried on walking and ignored his shouting at me.
