I really do not understand why the police in Paris do not crack down on this behaviour which seems to be getting more common across this beautiful city. It really upsets tourists. From my experiences of visiting the cits over the last decade or so, it is really going down hill, with more and more instances of agressive begging, homeless people lying in the street, rude teenagers, poor service everywhere etc etc..... A real shame

If you missed it, you missed Paris visit. One of the most wonderful place to visit in ParisThe artists with their tableaux, terretoire coffee, restaurants and the nice streets. All in one place few step from sacre coeurMake its visit essential for any one visiting Paris

Not what it used to be.. It's hard not to sound like an old fuddy duudy, but visited Montmartre and Sacre Cour today and was quite stunned at how touristy and commercial it had become. There were groups of Africans on all approaches from Montmartre trying to place woven bracelets on your arm or sell you any kind of novelty. There were beggars, buskers (not very good) and any number of groups with their hand out for money. There was even a Christmas market around the church playing music on loudspeakers and a fake train that takes tourists up the road to the church. The place has absolutely no character whatsoever and has just become an extremely tacky tourist spot. There is no question that the church is beautiful, but with so many beautiful churches in Paris, it's simply not worth the journey. The best thing the Catholic church could do is act like Jesus and cast the money changers from the temple. It is a beautiful place, ut one that makes you sad when you see what effect tourism has on the local environment. This should be a place of peace and reflection and quiet enjoyment. I felt sad being there.
Just beatiful. Very nice historical part of the city. Romantic too. I had a nice morning walk here , when it was not very crowded so i could chech several details.

Worth a visit...just be careful. Lovely little village in Paris, worth the trip for the Sacre Coeur and the little lanes that you can wonder through. Just be careful of the pick pockets and scammers that are everywhere hounding you to buy their products/let them draw a picture of you.Nice little shops up there also, lots of places that sell lovely pictures and prints at a very good cost which are great to take home and frame.Also worth the visit to see the Le Consulat cafe which is famous, and also the creperie which is next to it. Apparantly this is the oldest creperie in Paris and is lovely! 4 euros for a plain sugar crepe however...pricey! But a must do :)

Nice, must do, but carefull on pickpockets!. Montmartre is definitely worth a visit (Sacre Coeur,surroundings, Paris view), but be extremely careful as there are many pickpocket thief's. As I was aware, and having been eating in a restaurant having a window/eagle eye view on them, I can definitely say: Look out, as while eating with great view on the tourist trap street, we identified at least 15-20 people collaborating on these criminal schemes. The game of choosing between 3 items...There are people "scouting" to see if police is nearby as well as some, sympathetic looking guys talking as they were tourist as well. Even some woman will play the games as if they were tourist (we saw 3 working on that). They are not. It's a scheme to get tourist to pay cash to play the game/scheme while pockets are emptied. Be aware of this. French police should be more active in fighting these but after seeing 5-6 different "playing tables" in one street at the same time, I guess it's not on their priority list.

Montmartre. It is without a question the most desirable place in Paris to just walk with your love one. It's safe, it has a mystique in the air at night, you have nice building and the sacrécoeur top-seeing you. not that big, it was a breath of fresh air to wander through the streets and the place du tertre, with all the painters, the bistros and the couples in a love mood. It was the only place in Paris where we actually felt we were in Paris.If you're in Paris you just can't miss this one...specially at night

Lovely but be careful. I am a solo traveler. I went to Montmartre and I did enjoy it so much. I would have rated it 5* if I hadnt experienced being misbehaved by 2 black men. They insisted on wearing the red bracelet into my hands. You better watch out and pay no attention to them.

Do go, but go prepared. Montmartre is a lovely neighborhood with great restaurants and lovely lanes to wander through. Just watching the artists at work makes the trip worthwhile. Also, Sacre Coeur, and the views over Paris are great experiences. Just be prepared for the pickpockets and scammers. Mostly they are concentrated on the streets leading up from the two Metro stations that serve the area, and on the steps of Sacre Coeur, but you can't let your guard down anywhere. We saw lots of people running the clipboard scam in the streets on top of the hill. Wear your moneybelt.

Like the athmosphere. The top of the Montmartre Quarter sure is very touristy, but if you don't mind you'll enjoy yourself. You can find small rues with artists and Cafés... I visited in December when they have a Christmas Market which was also very nice.If you visit in the evening the Basilique Sacré Coeur is well lighted which makes for a nice picture. Moreover you can get insight or on top of it...

Best avoided on the weekend. Making your way up the hill from the train station the road is back to back with people trying to fleece tourists of their money by using their girlfriends to make false bets. Then you hit the bottom of the steps and are accosted by guys trying to tie friendship bracelets around your wrists with other more shady characters on the sidelines doing their own "business". Positive note once you get away from the Sacre Coeur there are some wonderful shops, galleries and cafes. Such a shame that the actual approach to the church is the area best avoided.

Charming and quaint , worth spending a day here. I fell in love with this quaint place which has the charm of a small village , reminded me a little of parts of San Francisco . The cafés are quaint so are the little shops selling souvenirs . The artists too add charm to the place . A must visit . Wish we could have spent more time there

Sandeman Montmartre Tour with Onno. The tour with Onno was very good! I loved the stories and to see the place where Picasso used to eat and draw pictures for the waitress to eat for free. I just think that the tour could be earlier than 18h. It was already dark and vbery cold. This tour is worth it the price! Thanks Onno for a great tour!

Touristy but fascinating. Montmartre has traditionally been an artistic and bohemian neighborhood in Paris. Although the streets are filled with many tourists, there are good reasons: Sacre Coeur cathedral, colourful boutiques, watercolor artists and street musicians. The view of Paris from the steps of Sacre Coeur is fantastic.
Paris paris . Great little area ! Heaps of shops and places to eat real and not to expensive French meals. I was there in Dec so they also had a cute chrismas market going.

Zigzag in lanes on hill, get a touch of artistic Paris!. I deeply believe this is the best part of Paris. But ignore Moulin Rouge, go to the hill directly either from Pigale or Blanche. Then you can just forget the route and wander among this hillside area, but always set Sacré Cœur as a landmark and walk toward/around it. Arrange at least half a day and explore every lane and every corner, then you will spontaneously reach Lapin Agile, Place du Tertre, Espace Dalí, Renoir's garden, etc. It seems around every corner of Montmartre hill lanes there is a hidden gem waiting for your arrival. Never forget to have a coffee and a meal in a bohemian cafe. I strongly recommend Relais de la Butte at Rue des Trois Freres, opposite to Bateau-Lavoir. Wonderful restaurant in a very Montmartre atmosphere.

Forget the grunge of moulin rouge.. Walk that hill!. The main street where you arrive from the train is just awful - very tired; commercial & a Starbucks to rub it in. Grab a bottle of water from the monoprix and wander up the hill. Lovely shops;great cafe scene. Look out for the street art tucked away high on the walls. A refreshing trip away from the Centre of paris. Good views from the church. Watch your bags around the church itself; but don't let this stop you making the trip. Combine this with a walking tour - definitely worth it.

If you want to "feel Paris" visit !. We walked around here after visiting Sacre Cour. And watched some of the artists. And then sat at a cafe and had some lunch while people watching ! So very quaint and neat!! I definitely felt caught up in the atmosphere and wanted to pinch myself to make sure I wasn't in a dream! Then we got a gelato and strolled around and bought some souvenirs! Loved it so much!'

Great artists village and quaint shops, my favorite neighborhood in all of Paris!. The cobblestone streets, the artist's square where artists sell their paintings and will actually sketch your portrait on the square, the quaint little shops and streets all make this a worthwhile place to spend a day. I loved the atmosphere of this neighborhood. Go see Sacre Coeur while you are there as well. Lots of quaint restaurants as well. Had a great salad at the Cafe Chappe while we were there. A wonderful neighborhood not to be missed!

Tschotschkes, shmontzes and not much else.. Sorry to say, but Montmarte is your basic tourist trap. Of course, the cheap souvenir shopping was very good, but other than that it was crowded, and for the first time in paris I felt uncomfortable regarding security, pickpockets and the like. Seeing an obvious three card monte type game for what seemed to be real money made me more wary than usual. The views of the city were nothing to write home about. We have been through countless cathedrals in Europe, so there was no great allure in this regard, either. If you want your portrait sketched, there are many artists willing to do so, for a price of course and no complaint there. The highlight was the Metro station, one of the best of its kind and style. Do go, to say you've been, and I hope you enjoy it more than I did.
Artists. Take time to chat with the artists, have a coffee and just relax, not a great deal to do but pure Paris.

Inspiring. Montmarte was part of a day trip whilst staying in Paris and it didn't fail to surprise and to please. The square was busy with artists and entertainers and the atmosphere was electric. Well worthy of a second visit and next time we will spend longer there.

Quaint Montmartre. Before our trip to Paris, my travel mates and I arranged for a walking tour of Montmartre with a local guide. He was born/raised/lives in Montmarte and was a former Mayor! Jean Louis was the best, providing his personal stories of Montmarte's history. We had to bundle up and carry umbrellas, but the rain did not dampen our love of this spectacular place. All six of us ranked our walking tour of Montmartre as the highlight of our Parisian vacation!!

Beautifully historic.. If there is one thing to know about me, its that I am a huge history and architecture fan. Naturally a historical neighborhood with amazing Parisian architecture was too good to pass up. I stumbled upon Montmartre after taking a walking tour of the Champs-Elysee. I raced over on the metro to make it to a second walking tour of Montmartre. Immediately upon arriving I fell in love. As a native New Yorker I could never leave New York City, but if I did I know it would be for a place like Montmartre or Rome. A place with an insane amount of history. This had nothing to do with the movie 'Amelie', I slept through much of that movie, this had more to do with the cafe's where Picasso had eaten, where Van Gogh had lived, and the bars where artists had drunk absinthe and the early 20th century art culture that still permeates through the air. It was a beautiful experience and a beautiful part of Paris; do stay away from the Senegalese hustlers at the end of the park however. They are really eager to confuse and hustle unsuspecting tourists

Beautiful sight of Paris. This is north of Paris and only a short drive that took about 15 mins. There are 3 main sights to see - the sight of Paris, sacred heart church and the streets with shops and various paintings. In my opinion, you can give the last one a miss as the artist charged Euro20 for a simple sketch of my daughters. The first 2 sights are definitely worth the visit to Montmarte!

The best city view of Paris.. Arrived by Metro on a Wed mid morning. There were lots of students hanging out on the streets. There are Sympa discount clothing stores on route, men gambling or crap shooting, tourist traps, but an exceptional Biscuit /Cookie store whose name I have forgotten. Once you get past the crowds climb the hill to Sacra Couer Church where people sit just to enjoy the rooftop city view of Paris. You will find charming streets of painters who will paint/draw you or are selling their works . There were several Very good Crepe stands and Bistros to sit and sip wine and just people watch. The Monmartre Museum has a lovely garden overlooking hillside vineyards and the museum has many Talouse Lautrec paintings and which will educate you about Le Chat Noir and other historical cabarets in Montmartre. If you like to sew or design, a short walk nearby are streets with many high quality fabric shops so walk around the area.

Skip this "Must See". I spent a month in Paris and this was the only time I felt uncomfortable and even intimidated. The view isn't so special as to warrant the discomfort. Skip it. You won't be sorry.

Great views, cute streets,. Lively, square with artists working and selling, great view from sacred heart church, good crepes along the small streets to load up on carbo/sugar. Fantastic views of Paris. Love wall (wall with I love you written in many languages)

Intimate Paris. We would say that to visit Paris and miss Montmarte would be to miss an essential part of France. We found going to Montmarte a much more village like atmosphere, albeit a very crowded area, especially the closer you get to lunch time. There was a more palpable intimacy with shop owners and the whole area that we did not find in the central tourist areas. The art work around the central Place du Terte was very good quality and we came away with several small paintings from a local dealer. We enjoyed the ambiance of the cafes as well. The views of Paris from Sacre Cour's steps was breathtaking.

highlight of Paris. Montmartre is a must visit, you will find this unique area so romantic yet lively. We visited montmartre almost before sunset on end of October, and we really loved it. There are many cute souvenir shops which sell posters, purse, etc.. we bought some cute souvenirs and really want to be back again someday.

Spend a day here!. There is so much to see in Montmartre. Walk through it's narrow streets, check out the artists' work in the square, climb the stairs to Sacre Coeur, delight in the wonderful view of Paris, eat at one of it's charming cafes, check out the very famous Moulin Rouge. Great neighborhood to see bohemian Paris.
Wellwirth the trip. We made the trip from the left bank up there and so glad we did. This was the Paris I saw in my dreams. We had a wonderful walking the streets seeing the artists and the churches

Delightful!. What a lovely neighborhood. Although there are SO MANY stairs to climb it is part of the experience and charm of the visit. There are however ways to avoid them. When we arrived there was a weekend wine festival which made the experience even better. The shops are so quaint and you can browse slowly as there is no rush to leave! Wonderful chocolate and sandwich shops too.

MONTMARTRE PARIS. Montmartre has changed very little in appearance from 1980s (my first visit), 1990s (my second visit) and 2013 (my third visit), apart from the invasion of tourists. Most people come to see the Basilica de Sacre Coeur and the Moulin Rouge, but there is a lot more to Montmartre than our eye can see - it's the history of the area. You can take the miniature train up and down the hill and narrow alleyways where the coach or bus would struggle to get through and you will get the gist of the place and the local people who live here. Or walk around the Boulevard de Clichy as you come out of metro Blanche or Anvers and look at the bars, cafes, bistros, brassaries, restaurants, lots of unusual boutiques and shops built at the beginning of the last century or earlier. See how many original dance halls, cabarets and theatres of the naughties you can spot apart from Moulin Rouge. Go into the shops like Darty, Sympa and Tatti in rue de Steinkerque where the prices are slashed to less than half their original. Walk up the hill towards the Basilica and turn right into rue de Tertre - you have entered a true boho territory of the artists, writers and musicians of the 19th and 20th century who lived and worked here; now it belongs to 21st century artists, writers and musicians who live, work or roam the streets struggling to make ends meet as their mentors/idols once did. There are more bistros and cafes here, one called Les Deux Moulin in rue Lepic - the 2 windmills of which one still survives today, as well as several museums dedicated to them. Spare one more day to visit Montmartre cemetary where some of the great artists, musicians and writers are laid to rest.

Thank you trip advisor!. We read the reviews of how to avoid the many stairs and street vendors. Boy it worked like a charm. The recommendation was to take the subway and get off at the Lamarck station. Perfect walk and very little climbing. I would recommend that everyone visit this lovely spot when visiting Paris!

Charming neighbourhood. Walking up the many steps towards Montmartre really gave me goosebumps; I couldn't believe I was in Paris! This whole neighbourhood symbolised classic Paris to me, so I'm very glad we went. If you're looking for a quiet, authentic experience this is not it. This place is very busy, constantly being haggled to buy things and being ripped off in the outdoor dining. But the buildings were gorgeous, the artists, and the shops selling art, all made it lovely.

Gem. You can take a train or the lift... or both like we did. The town is quaint but full of people. Lots of people go here so bea careful since so do pick pockets and gypsies. A few guys were selling beer to anyone and the police got them (felt better). Some guy stands outside the lift trying to sell you tickets but dont pay any attention to him as they are fake or already used. We watched him for a good 20 min take advantage of people, when the police came for the other guys he split too. You can also take the stairs too if you know how to get to them. We found some good places to eat at per Tripadvisor but some of them didn't have any English so you decide. this was nice but if your limited on time its not the first thing I would do.

Get here early!!. Just me and my 14 yr old daughter visited for and I was bit nervous after I'd heard about it ebing a bit seedy but needn't have worried..it was lovely. After taking the Metro to Anvers station (avoided Pigalle as it's probably a bit unsuitable for young ladies) we walked up through the streets towards the steps beneath the Sacre Coeur..what an amazing place.The streets were lined with souvenir and trinket shops but we pressed on, keen to get to the heart of the place and took the Furnicular Railway up to the top (if you buy a rover Metro ticket it is valid on here too which was really good value). Once at the top, we stopped at the Irish Pub on the left and had a Magners...and a coke...reasonable for Paris at 13 Euros for us both.The place was buzzing and full of all walks of life, young and old, plus some living statues..one of which was hilarious....he wasn't even attempting to keep still..was very jolly and couldn't resist waving at everyone ..and doffing his halo..think he was supposed to be an overweight, middle aged angel...think Chubby Brown covered in silver paint..lol.Then we went round the Sacre Coeur which was free and absolutely breathtaking..beautiful artwork and interesting insight to the Catholic faith...small side chapels for the various saints to pray to and even the confessional booths..most fascinating.Then we meandered through the streets to the main square where all the artists...nonw, unless you want to have your picture sketched...this is the best piece of advice i can give - take a piece of rolled up paper with you when you go and wave it at anyone asking you if you want a portrait doing..Or..what happened to us, might happen to you..We were approached in the street by two men in their early 60s who started drawing us right there and then without asking or even getting our approval...of course they were utterly charming and di wonderful drawing of both of us...so we couldn't say no and ended up paying out a fortune - eek...daren't even tell you how much..it was 40 euros each. Again, that oft heard phrase on our day in Paris was used again...well it IS Paris and we don't do this often. I was secretly furious but my daughter (who obviously wasn't the one paying) thought it was marvellous and loves her picture, but the only good bit in my view was, we were able to wave our rolled up pictures when we were approached umpteen other times.Really lovely atmosphere in the main square...after an hour or so we went back down the Furnicular - by which time was about 11.30am and the queue was ENORMOUS to get on the Furnicular, so we patted ourselves on the back and went off walking towards Abbesses Metro station where another cheeky beer was consumed before getting on the train.Wonderful experience....just be wary of being accosted into buying something you really didn't intend to!!

Just find a seat and watch the world go by. Whilst it can be very busy it is a must to visit. Find yourself a seat in a bar or cafe and watch the world pass you buy. There is always some thing that will catch your eye and make you smile.

Go there for the sunset. Very nice atmosphere... there are street performers, and crowds just sitting on the steps in front of the basilica chilling out. Panoramic view of Paris. You can see the Eiffel Tower with the sun setting in the background. Very romantic!There were many tourists so beware of pickpockets. The sunset there is great! You need to climb quite a fair number of steps up if you do not want to pay for the tram up.

Don't miss it.. In my opinion, one of the best views of the city can be had from in front of the Sacre Coeur basilica. Take time to wander round the back streets to look in the many small shops.In the Place de Tertre you will find cafes and the artists waiting to draw your portrait. Don't dismiss having your picture drawn. One of them approached our teenaged daughter and tried to convince us her eyes made him want to 'do' her. When the price list came out, adults were 60-80 euro, but he did students for 35. He did a cracking job in pastel in about 20 minutes and a much better momento than a photo stored on a computer.This whole area is very busy, but that's all part of the experience. Allow half a day, take your time and enjoy.

fantastic view. I walked fast up the hill and skipped all the tourist gathering on these beautiful streets.I went directly to the observation at the top of this church.After seeing the main attractions of the city, it was great to see it from this high.It was a bit spooky climbing the stairs. It's a narrow and constant spiral, you don't know how much you climbed and how much is left... but it worth it!

Wine Festival!. Was there during a wine festival, it was such a great experience! Wine tasting and buying 3 Euros glass of wine was a lot of fun! So many people gathered around after at the Sacre-Coeur Basilica to relax and sing a long with a man who was playing guitar. Overall great afternoon, bought some delicious Nougat to go with all the wine :) A must-see if you are in Paris!

Marvelous Montmarte. Our second visit to Montmarte/Sacre Cour.A magical experience the first time and no less magical this time.The view of the city is spectacular and the Sacre Cour is something you have to see.And you get to take a funicular to the top. You can walk too if you prefer to save the money.

Beautiful area, with interesting shops.. A beautiful place to discover and walk around, so much too see.I wish we could have spent more time here.There are loads of shops selling individual things. The olive oil shop 'O&Co' is fantastic and I wish we brought more. May have to take a trip back to Paris to get some more!Take a walk round and you'll fall in love like the rest of us.But beware, house prices are in the millions :P

Awesome. Our middle stop during an afternoon in Paris. We walked up the local streets instead of the steps to this landmark. We then sat the steps and had our picnic lunch of baguette sandwiches and wine. Can't get any better than that!

Visit from Australia once again.. Discover Montmartre. One of our favourite place in Paris. Allow a day out of your itinerary to enjoy this wonderful place. Once you walk up that hill, with touristy shops each side of you, the atmosphere changes. Yes, it is crowded at times, but doesn't that show what a great place this is. The Sacre Coeur church on the hill is perhaps one of the most beautiful churches in the world. It may not have all the glitz of other European churches, but you feel the warmth once inside. You can get a funicular to the top of the hill, or walk up the many steeps if fit & able. The view over Paris ,shows the extent of this great city. Moving away from all this ,you just want to explore more. Don't miss Place du Tertre, the public square famous world wide for its art & cafes. Sit down & have a wine & take in the passing parade, all just waning to enjoy their surroundings. Perhaps before visiting Montmartre, read about it & be your own judge. But I am sure it will all be positive.

The Top Of Paris. The region of Montmatre is quaint and very special. Nearly every movie made in Paris features scenes from this suburb. There are many interesting shops, the church and museum at the top of the hill (quite a walk) but there is a funicular railroad to assist if you don't like steep walks. The views from up there challenge the view from the top of the Eifel Tower but they are quite different. Also at the top of the hill you can get an artist to sketch or paint you (or her) face for a smallish fee. Overall, it's a bit touristy but quite unlike any other part of Paris. It's not likely to disappoint you.One word of warning: The climb out of Abbesses Metro station is a long, long circular staircase. Look for the lift at the top of the first flight of stairs. It takes you most of the way.
Tourists galore but still charming. It's a beautiful place. Enjoy the market. Wander around and check in at a cafe for a drink. Get your portrait done. Think of tin tin...

Visiting Monmartre is like a contact sport!. Extremely touristy. The French are so tired of Americans here. We all have this idea of Paris as a beautiful and romantic city. But it's really hard to feel the beauty when you're bumping up against a horde of tourists, or have to wait a half hour at a restaurant for someone to come over and say hi (or bon soir). And we were there in October, after the tourists supposedly go home. Also, it was dirty and little too trashy for our taste. Honestly, we felt like we were in LoDo (Lower Downtown Denver) after the bars let out on a Saturday night.I advise another part of the city, and you may have to lay out some money to do it right. And maybe even another city. And I LOVE French culture! What's happened to Paris? Or was it always a dream?

Full of character and memories. We stayed in an apartment on rue Lepic roughly two thirds of the way up the hill for a week. This was a great choice. The area is full of history which is why tourists flood into this part of Paris every day. The advantage we had was that as tourists left in the evening we were only minutes from 'home'. The Place du Tertre is aswarm with tourists for much of the day, has a mass of artists doing portraits and caricatures, has the usual tourist tat but also has some very nice eating places and is just fun to be in. Sacre Coeur is just around the corner and while being a magnificent church to visit also provides a great view over Paris from the steps. At the foot of the hill are three patisseries/boulangeries which are all great value and the rue Lepic has a large number of restaurants that are small and intimate with good food. If we are in Paris again the temptation would be strong to stay in an apartment in Montmartre.

Montmartre. Fantastic church with hugely impressive architecture, rather spoiled by the large number of street sellers and buskers. The approach steps to the side seem to be regularly used as a toilet area and smelled horribly.

Montmartre -colourful, buzzing place to be. Colourful, buzzing hilltop district north of Paris. Once home to many famous artists such as Picasso and Vincent van Gogh. Well worth a day visit to Montmartre, nice atmosphere, great energy at the artists markets. We had lunch at "Au Cadet De Cascogne" front row view of the traditional artists market soaking in the wonderful atmosphere.

Boheme Paris. As mentioned already, go early or go late.This is the former boheme neighbourhood of Paris, and most great artists have passed from here.Especially in the golden years of Belle Epoque, walking these streets would mean you mere almost certain to come across one of the living legends of the time.Nowadays, however, you'll mainly find a diverse hodgepodge of migrant portrait artists from anywhere in the world, having nothing to do with Montmartre, except that they work there.The 'early or late' suggestion at the top of the page, refers to the views of the city you can get fro the top of the hill. You'll have rather dramatic light over Paris earl or late in the day.While you are there, don't miss the Basilique de Sacre Coeur.

Amazing Place-Not to be Missed. This is one of my favorite places to visit in Paris. A place where you can overlook all of Paris, eat at fabulous restaurants, watch local artists at work and enjoy musical entertainment. I enjoy going there in the evening to see all of the city lights. I go here every time I am in the city. You can stroll, eat, snack, and mingle with the locals. Be careful of watching the city lights while walking, as some of the cobblestones are loose and one can trip (as I did).

Hidden little gem up in the hills. . I absolutely loved Montmartre. Amazing views of Paris from the hill side and cute shops and restaurants. Super artsy area.... I purchased art on the square and love it. Must see if you go to Paris and love the artisan culture. Friendly people up on the hill as well. Be forewarned that there are not a lot of cabs or busses to take there.... we ended up on a trolley... a small res and white train if you will. Check out transportation options before you go.

Go Early or Late. Montmarte is a lovely place, which offer great views and opportunity to have a portrate done. The problem is that it suffers from its own sucess, this means it gets very busy and full of tourist, con artist, tourist tack and poor quality resturants.Go early in the morning before 10am, and you get most of the place to yourselves, where you can actually see the place and enjoy a coffee and watch the excitment and tourist build up.If you are into Dahl, there is show of his sculptures at the back of Montmarte, it is sign posted, but you will need to look out for them.Tip,Go early or late to miss the crowds.Do not eat at Chez Eugene, (see its reviews, we were should of).Watch out for Gypsy pick pockets, their method is to ask you sign a petition for "the children", then ask you to donate some money, at that point a second child appears and watch you take and replace your wallet, while you are giving the donations, the first child distract you while the second takes your wallet. We saw them at work and took great pleasure in let the poor victims know and stopping them.

My favourite in Paris. I have done so much research before going to Paris and I am so happy that it helped me to navigate the city and amazing places. I downloaded the Montmartre self-guided walking tours from Paris48 website. Hands down to whoever wrote that guide because it is the best day we have in our Paris trip.We got off at Lamarck-Caulaincourt station and continue our self paced walking tour. We saw amazing places such as Place Dalida, Maison Rose, Au Lapin Agile, Vineyard and Sacre Ceour. The guide will take you to 18 different spots in Montmartre and finishes off at Abbesses Metro station.The best part is that you see locals around the areas and not tourists and definitely no scammers that will hassle you.

Very, very crowded and petty criminals aplenty!. My husband and I visited the Montmartre area on the Saturday of our Paris trip. It was claustrophobically crowded and full on petty criminals, ready to scam visitors with their tricks! The church is very beautiful inside though, and the view from the top of the hill is lovely. We couldn't wait to get out of there!!Hold onto your purses and don't engage with anyone trying the gold ring trick, the string around your wrist trick or someone asking you to sign a petition because they are deaf. Maybe mid week or mid morning is better.

An unexpected delight. We took a train or tram to the top of Montmarte. Once at the top, there is the city of Paris below you. The views are breath taking. Montmartre itself is an artists village. There are several restaurants, souvenir shops, a church and interesting shops to scout out. On a back street there was the Dali Museum. We stayed here about 3 hours. I could have stayed a lot longer had time permitted. Going down the hill, the small, winding streets have shops on both sides of the street. I had a delightful afternoon.

Never a Dull Moment on the Hill!. I have been to Montmartre many times, and have always enjoyed seeing the Sacre Coeur and the Artists, etc. This time, I decided I wanted to see the things I hadn't seen before. A friend who used to live in Montmartre put together a walking tour for me that took me 6 hours to complete. I thoroughly enjoyed seeing the side streets, the windmills, the Water Tower, the Montmartre Museum, and a host of other places that a tourist would normally not see. If you get to Montmartre, take some time to get off the beaten path and observe how the residents live, etc. You'll be rewarded for your effort.

Great views. We took a taxi to Montmartre from the Picasso Museum ( happened to be closed till Dec) . The area is wonderful with shops, restaurants and on the hill Sacre Cour with spectacular views of the city and very steep stairs /ramps to get down . Stopped at the Dali museum on a quiet out of the way street. Took the metro back to the left bank and it's always a fast way to travel in Paris.

Beautiful Village. We visited Montmartre after hearing about this very quaint and beautiful village by Steve Reeve's. We took a quick subway ride from our hotel in Paris and ended up with the option of an elevator.....we chose the stairs and there are about 150, so be prepared.....but then you get to a very beautiful Montmartre......wow. We walked to the Sacre Coeur Bascillica and chose the trolley to get to the top. The Basicillia is just outstanding. All of the intricate paintings and carvings....then you get to see the city of Paris which is great. There is a statue on a pillar right at the bottom of the stairs and as you get closer you realize it is a real person......amazing. This is also where you will find the Moulin Rouge.....so after you pray and want to take in a little action there it is ........Very worthwhile trip and not far outside of the city. We loved it and will definitely return.

Amazing!. We just happened to fall upon this Festival. It was wonderful. You want to try French wines? You want to try French cheese? You want to try French Sausages? This is the place. It was wonderful. I plan on going next year!

Beautiful area. The apartment we rented for 3 days was in this charming little corner of Paris, and I'm so pleased we stayed here. Just a 5 minute walk away from La Basilique du Sacre-Coeur, we well and truly stumbled across a gem. Well connected by Metro links, but we mainly walked from here to the city centre just to make sure we didn't miss anything along our travels. Would definitely recommend people to stay here. It's easy to lose yourself in the romanticism of the little market place, the cobbled streets and cute restaurants here. Such a beautiful area.

Wonderful part of Paris. Montmartre with Sacre Cour on the top of the hill offers a lot of small shops with all kinds of cool stuff, cosy cafés, good restaurants, lots of galleries and an amazing wiew of Paris.But beware of annoying street wenders and pickpockets.

Charming town. Had a day planned there when we mentioned it to some people received mixed reviews almost didn't go but so glad we did. It was one of our favorites. Did the trip up the tower @ Sacre Cour and it was worth it! Great view. Great charming town. Not scary at all.

be wary of montmartre despite its charm and wonderful position. i suppose some places can get so busy and so full of tourist shops selling rubbish and restaurants selling cold food that the charm can fade my main problem is the potential for pickpocketing and other scamsNow it is very crowded but i would advise anyone to be careful and careful i wondered also about these geezers with their board games with their enthralling female fans who must be in on the scamits 35 years since i was mugged so i did not like the 2 occasions in paris in where it was attemptedHowever when in montmartre the annual fete de vendanges was on with a huge variety of stalls with producers selling food produce from rural france ;particularly localities that are less heard offi would return next october if i could;i should add this part of montmartre up on the hill was full of first aid staff ;security staff from the mayors office and police of various sortsLastly anyone who has their silhouette scissored on montmartre needs the capacity to laugh at themselves my friends really enjoyed montmartre for this festival and it was wonderful but next time i will be very wary-nothing worse than becoming ill ;mugged or losing passport or wallet on holiday

Not that charming place anymore :(. I've been to Montmartre when I visited Paris 10 years ago, I remember it was the highlight of my trip, this time I couldn't wait to take my boyfriend there I've told him so much about it! When we got there I was shocked and embarrassed; the place I liked wasn't the same anymore it was very crowded and full of beggars that won't leave you in peace besides it wasn't clean; a lot of garbage and empty bottles left by the visitors what a shame ! I was really disappointed that such a charming place is not well kept.

Overcrowded place. As time is going by the charme of this place is fading.- Now it is overcrowded by tourists and people that try to sell something to you.- Not to say the painters that doesn't let you to make a step without bother you.-
OK. Not a "must see" attraction.. if you want to get yourself painted, it gonna cost you at list 50 euro. (Plus the price for the cover that saves it)

You cant take Paris out of Monmartre. Climb 130 m and you scaled the Mount Everest of Paris. Montmartre is a hill in the north of the city,in the 18th arrondissement,a part of the Right bank. Its claim to fame is not the cool shops,the exuberant galleries, but the white- domed stunning Basilica of the Sacre-Coeur, at its summit. However,once your diligence in paying respect to your maker is done,the area is nightclub central. Many artists had studios or worked around the community of Montmartre,including Monet, Dali,Picasso, Modigliani and Van Gogh. A sway of films have centered this precinct in its epics. To get here could not be easier. Its served by the following stations:Metro line 2.... Pigalle, Anvers & Blanche with Line 12 offering Pigalle, Lamarck-Cailaincourt, Jules Joffrin and Abbesses. If you get lost.....ask someone!! The word Montmartre originates from the latin "Mount of Mars",which became "Mountain of the Martyr" ( Saint Denis who was Bishop of Paris as well as Mayor,chose the cathedral on the outskirts of Paris). The hill has been used by armies,both local and foreign,to bombard the city with artillery. There is a memorial sign on the wall of one of the eateries in The area that says:on 30 march 1814- here the Cossacks first launched their famous bistro and thus on this summit occurred the worthy ancestor of our bistro". This is a popular drinking area,freewheeling with decadent entertainment (yeeppee) at the end of the 19th century. In the popular cabaret,the Moulin-Rouge and Le Chat-Noir,some of France's greatest artists played to filled houses. With the urbanisation of Haussman underway,it drove the inhabitants of the effected areas to the edge of the city to Clichy,La Villette and the' hill' with the view of the city, Montmartre. Stroll along the boulevards,while you hum Charles Aznavour's 'La Boheme',his best song lamenting the fading bohemian scene and see if you can spot the sites of the movies, La Vie Rose which told of the life of Edith Piaf and her times in the slums of Paris. Who can forget Amelie, which is set right here in contemporary Montmartre and back in 2001 Moulin Rouge,with my favourite artist Toulouse- Lautrec. Down hill,metaphorically,is the red light district of Pigalle which hosts a large variety of instruments... not those types,naughty.... .but guitars and rock music stores.  If you are too lazy to make the assault up the hill,there is a funicular railway to take you up. You will look like a burk,but you wont raise a sweat!. Come and join me and 350,000 people for the very popular Fete des Vendanges of Montmartre during the 1st weekend of October. Its a sensational event. You must be exhausted and famished by now. Get your Euros out,but skip the tres- ordinaire eateries and head for the terrific restaurant...La Mascotte...... Read about this in my forthcoming review. Bon appetite.

Montmartre, the bohemian area of Paris. Montmartre is a hill in the North of Paris. At the summit of the 'butte Montmartre', the highest point in Paris (after the top of the Eiffel tower), stands the Basilica of Sacre Coeur, a beautiful church which is well worth a visit and the views of the city from here are fantastic. It can be reached by the metro (Anvers station), a short walk and then climbing hundreds of steps which is exhausting but there are seats at different levels (alternatively you can take the funicular railway to the top). Once home to many of the great artists such as Toulouse-Lautrec and Picasso and famous for the Moulin Rouge and its nightlife, Montmartre is a very busy, vibrant area with a bohemian atmosphere. The cobbled streets are packed with artists, buskers, beggars and tourists. In the square the artists try to sell you their paintings and to paint your portrait. Restaurants and cafes abound, most with outdoor seating. Prices are 'Parisien' but more affordable than in many of the other districts. There is also an abundance of tourist shops selling cheap souvenirs. Montmartre is definitely one of the tourist highlights in Paris but it is not for the fainthearted.

Artistic village. This is where Van Gogh, Picasso, Tolouse Lautrec, Edith Piaf used to live. Take an organized walking tour or download one on your iphone. This will allow you to truly understand the cultural importance of this neighborhood. Expect to spend at least 2-3 hours walking along the lovely cobble stoned streets, along Rue Lepic, Rue des Abbesses. Visit the Sacre Ceur, the Place du Tetre. If you are a fan of Amelie, you will enjoy the neighborhood even more.

Very expensive but lovely atmosphere. We walked up to Montmartre to see the artists , it was very busy but enjoyed seeing the artists at work. We had already eating lunch but had a beer in a street cafe which cost 9 Euro but nice to soak up the atmosphere

Now this IS Paris. Montmartre was definitely the highlight of our visit to Paris. We took the Metro and walked the 200 or so steps up to the street and then all the way over to the Funicular which will take you up to the Sacre Coeur unless you take the stairs, another 190 or so. But at the top of this hill you will discover the true joie de vivre, cafes, artists, street dancers all in a setting of winding cobble streets and narrow stone buildings. We stopped at a corner café for a drink along the sidewalk to take in the ambiance. We enjoyed it so much that we returned later for dinner and a bottle of wine, superb! While in the district you must also walk by the Moulin Rouge which is at the bottom of this area, just because it is such a landmark. We did not have any trouble with scammers although we did see some young black men carrying colored strings for making the bracelets that we read about here. We had no trouble on the stairs and as with any city just ignore unwanted approaches and keep walking. We left the area before full darkness so perhaps that would be our recommendation if you are at all nervous. Definitely a must see area to spend time in the artists square and a tour of the Cathedral. We paid a few euros to go up to the top of the cathedral to watch the sunset, fabulous!

A mix of gift shops, artists and cafes.. This is a good place to visit after visiting the Sacré-Cœur. There are places to eat and numerous places to have your portrait painted. It does of course have the usual gift shops selling everything from tat to tiaras.... well almost. Some of the keepsakes are actually quite nice and not too expensive. You also have chocolate and cakes shops where you can put on 3 pounds in weight just looking in the window. It is worth allowing plenty of time to wander round in your own time and take everything in.

Beautiful but beware of scammers. The steps of Montmarte are gorgeous, but you have to beware of a few things. There are many scammers in this area. When we were here in July 2013, the string was the popular one. I would suggest reading up on this area so you are ready to handle the people appropriately. This district is also famous for its red lights. Be prepared with this also. While the steps are gorgeous, I wouldn't wander too far away if you have children. There are plenty of sex stores lining the streets below to give adults many laughs, though. There are pubs and eateries around here which are great. The view is worth it!
best area in Paris. young and vibrant area without the fuss of Paris, full of street arts and brasseries on right and left, great place to explore and stay.

Must See in Paris. Excellent place to visit. If you find time to visit Eiffel Tower you should find time to visit Montmartre. Tourist information Centre never mentioned about this place when we went there. The only reason my husband and I ended up here is because of TripAdvisor. I had researched from home and had found this place on TripAdvisor's unbeaten path.The Basilica is nice & it is free to visit. It is on the top of the hill. It is like a small town in Paris which is so lively. There are lots of different artists showing different ways of art. One of them made me stand in front of him and got a cut out of my face out of paper in less than 3mins. It is amazing. There are lots of cafés, restaurants & beautiful shops. There's 1shop particularly that interest me Gallerie D'Art beautiful work. I think we went the easiest way. Didn't have to climb too much though it is at the top of the hill. You get off at Lamarck Station turn right as soon as you come out of the station and climb the stairs. As soon as you finish climbing you will come in front of roughly 3 or 4 streets. Just cross ahead & take the flight of stairs, you will soon be behind the Basilica
Tourist shops galore. We were on our way to Sacre Coure and had to go through the section that had the tourist shops..But we did find some reasonable priced goods and a fairly good local restaurant.
One of the best areas of Paris. I could stay here for days....the small little shops, the cafés, the atmosphere is just great! Also some of the best views of Paris! One must absolutely go here!

Not nice at all. I have been there at night. The panorama was nothing special, the place was full of people trying to sell you those little things you see in every part of the world. Always the same. Moreover they were to persistent in that. I was feeling very uncomfortable. Moreover the place seems to be a place just for stupid tourists willing to lose money.

Best place for a pano view!. Hello, I was visiting Paris in May and I saw that neighbourghood, that special called Montmartre. Montmartre is a place where you can find a lot of people that sells things in the street. Basically merchandising and some handmade products of Paris. You can have a long walk through the shops in the street. Be patient if you´re with your wife or girlfriend cause for sure the will be stopping you at each shop in the middle of the street. You will have to walk in zig zag between the people but if you´re lucky you can walk easy. Take some time to get up to the Sacre Coeur. You´ll see the best view and the best sunset.Roman.

Go at night. If you're young go there at around 8-10 pm, there's a huge crowd gathering at the stairs to sit, watch the view and chill out.
Bring beer/wine with you cause there are guys walking around selling overpriced beer they bought at a local supermarket.
A lot of good restaurants nearby too.
Awesome place to hang out in the evening.

Beautiful bohemian paradise. I spent my last night in Paris in Montmartre (and a few others too). I love the vibe the area give off as well as many choices of funky cafés, restaurants and bars with a good range of cuisines. As well as this there a designer and vintage stores and art galleries. Definitely my favourite part of Paris!

Great Place!. We walked to Montmartre from our hotel (Mercure) through the steep narrow back streets. It was quite a hike, but well worth it. We walked past picturesque facades, a couple of windmills, curio and souvenir shops, and cafes teeming with people - all of which made us realize that we were finally in Paris! There were street performers, scooters zipping up and down the streets, and a myriad of pleasant aromas as you walked past specialty shops and restaurants. At the end of the long walk was the Sacre Couer basilica (which in itself was a gem) and the best view of Paris bar none! We took the steps going back down, which in retrospect was a better idea because climbing those stairs would have been harder and much less interesting than the back street route that we took to get up the hill. The only thing that took away from the overall experience was the number of street hawkers/vendors/hustlers that always seemed to be in your face trying to sell you their wares.

Don't miss Montmartre on your Paris trip. We spent our last afternoon in Paris in Montmartre and I'm so glad we did! It is the beautiful, picture perfect neighborhood that you will sigh and smile about years later. Transportation: Abbesses metro station. Easy and cheap to get to from any location. Took us maybe 15 minutes from Eiffel Tower.Eat: We had a fabulous 3 course meal for 14 euro at Le Deli's (and ice cream and sweets along street). Sightsee: Took funiculare to Sacre Coure. Beautiful church and view of city. Walked around without goal and saw beautiful streets, artwork, and mimes (yes - mimes).

Very Interesting Neighborhood. We stayed at the Holiday Inn Montmarte since we wanted to stay near the Sacre De Coeur.Its an exciting neighborhood with myraids of interesting places, restaurants, including the cemetery which has unique tombstones.Particularly interesting is the restaurant street of Rue Lepic.

Excellent if "touristy". We love this area with all the cafes and the artists. The paintings are quite formulaic (obviously created for the tourist trade) but they are hand painted and I guess would make a good souvenir - the artists didn't seem to mind people taking photographs to their work and of them painting.You can also have your portrait done for you on the spot (natural or caricature style) - quite expensive I think, but still a good souvenir.For eating, check all the cafes thoroughly, they all have various deals, pick one that has more people eating there as that will probably be better quality.

Just beautiful atmosphere. It is worth the trip to this beautiful cathedral, the view is spectacular and there are many little markets with plenty of souvenirs at a very reasonable price. We loved it and spent quite a bit of time there.

Long Walk Beautiful Views. Take the time to go to Montmartre and the church. Once you has survived the walk, we took the stairs not the funicular, have a seat on the church steps and be wowed by the view of Paris.

Beautiful in most parts. Montmartre is big enough that you can't stick it all in one box. It ranges from beautiful old cobblestone postcard-worthy streets to "gritty" working class areas at its far eastern edge. It also ranges from quiet and local to some parts that are so overcrowded with tourists that it's a huge turnoff. Throw in the sex shop strip near Place Pigalle and you've got it all. Don't let any one part of the neighbourhood cloud or rarify your view of the other areas. Overall it is definitely worth seeing. Are the tales of scammers near Sacre Coeur true? Yes, although probably exaggerated and overly cautious. There are a lot of people, some of them are sketchy, the vast majority aren't. 99% of the people in the area, even in Pigalle and in the far eastern side along Clingancourt and into la Goutte d'or near Chateau Rouge Station, are just minding their own business and will leave you alone. The 1% that don't can be pretty annoying, but remember there is a pretty thick line between annoying and dangerous. I'm not saying nothing bad ever happens here, but just exercise as much caution as you would in any major city, especially around subway stations and in very crowded areas, and you'll be fine. You'd be doing yourself a real disservice by not coming to Montmartre. We stayed in the area and spent three or four full days there, plus plenty of evenings out, and really enjoyed it. Best parts are Rue des Abesses, Caulincourt, the Montmartre cemetery and the actual Sacre Coeur church. View from the top of the church dome is spectacular. Lots of activity in front on the steps down the hill too. We were intimidated at first but went there at sunset one night to soak it in and ended up sitting around with hundreds of other people (and a few machine gun toting soldiers) so really no trouble at all. This is probably one of the nicest neighbourhoods in Paris save for a few spots that are overrun with tourists and the scam artists that inevitably follow them.
Nice neighborhood. Nice neighborhood, but some spots should be avoided, especially on your way to the metro stations, some streets are very smelly. But buildings are to die for
Great place to visit. This is the artist's corner and the real Paris for me. Loved the atmosphere and the view. Sacre Coeur Basilica is awe inspiring. One place to buy paintings.

Fantastic views of Paris. This is one of the best views of Paris you will get for free. The little town up the road behind the church is full of artists and is fascinating to walk around, spend some time, and have a break to take in the ambiance of the surroundings.
Best view of Paris. The view is the best one I've seen of Paris. Buy a baguette, cheese and wine and enjoy what Paris has to offer.

Delightful. Another must for the Paris visitor. Seeing all the different artist's work and the little cafes. Typical, iconic Paris. We didn't have that long a stop there because we were on a viator tour but will deffinitely return as it's so lovely.
Beautiful. Excellent area to visit and see another side to Paris. Enjoyed the shops in this area. Nothing to dislike

Nice place. Nice place, Montmartre is just a Plaza with artist everywhere, especially painters everywhere but be aware they don't like people to take pictures.they are some restaurant around but we did't eat there because we were always looking for the "MENU" witch is firs plate, second plate and some of them have dessert some others include the drink but never both. You can find them form 12 euros.

Montmartre Walking Tour. Walked around Montmartre for a few hours using Rick Steve's tour guide.Once you get away from the main section behind the church where all the tourists are, it is an great walking tour in a beautiful historic neighborhood. Bring your camera!!Stay away from the main street and Moulin Rouge area.

Over crowded, over rated dump.. In Paris for our first visit we kind of knew we would have to do all the big ticket items before we could really relax and get down to seeing the real Paris, away from the tourist meccas.With that in mind we caught the metro out to Montmartre to see the old hill top part of the city and have a look, of course, at Sacre-Coeur.The cathedral itself once you get there is probably worth the effort, some nice mosaic work inside but rather plain otherwise, the issue is actually getting there, the whole area surrounding the site is full of scam artists, pickpockets and dodgy looking groups of shifty eyed men. The streets are crowded with the worst kind of tourist tat for sale, all of it rubbish, think 3d postcards, model Eiffel towers, plastic sun glasses and the like. The worst experience of all however, comes when you attempt to reach the cathedral. there are guys at the base of the steps leading up trying to "offer" you some kind of rubbish string bracelet, these guys are really pushy and aggressive, literally grabbing hold of you and not letting go.It made for a very poor experience and we will not be back.

Keep your wits about you . Sacre Coetur is full of men trying to hassle you quite aggressively by trying to tie 'bracelets' (bits of string) on you. One even tried to physically stop me crossing the road at the bottom of the Sacre Coetur hill. Just say 'non' and walk away. Once you have got through that there are the conmen card tricksters, illegal street sellers and pickpockets. Once you get to the top you have a fantastic view and the building itself is stunning. But just avoid eye contact with anyone. Anyone who talks to you will want your money. Very sad. However once you move away and down Rue Lapic etc. then you have some charming streets full of character and beautiful shops and friendly restaurants. Lovely cobbled streets and old buildings to wander around. Down near the Moulin Rogué you just have a load of tatty sex shops. Men and women will be hassled by ladies trying to lure you into strip clubs. In all honesty I'd say half a day is enough to get a feel for the place. There are some nice bohemian streets and shops but the majority is sleaze and a sense of unease. The armed police and soldiers have a good presence there and the conmen and bracelet sellers move quickly away when they arrive only to set back up again immediately after!

Seducing and artistic, even though commercialized. I didn't want to leave this area. When you climb the stairs to the church Sacre Coeur, the whole another world/small town is revealed to you. Not only that you get the best view of Paris from this point, but you can feel some of the old Paris - many cafes, and restaurants with artists drawing and painting before you. Very seducing and bohemian.

Great Place. on the top of a hill, provides an incredible view of Paris, with the Sacre-Coeur Church on it's peak you would enjoy a sit on the stairs where if you don't stumble upon an artist doing some show (dance, music....) you would definitely enjoy a peaceful moment and definitely a romantic one. opt to go up to the Sacre-Coeur Dome you would enjoy a 360degree view of Paris.moreover, right around the corner, a square where you would find artists restaurants sweeping you off to a magical world as if you were in a movie scene of an old street with merchants all around you

Annoying beggers. Going to Monmartre and seeing the Scare Coer was lovely but very very crowded. Got some brilliant pictures but there are also a lot of "artists" asking you can they draw you for money which is irritating as there are loads of them. There are also those Romanian women walking around here too (these seem to be everywhere in Paris, putting a real dampener on things) the amount of times you have to tell people "no" is unbelievable. Also we stopped at an Irish bar for 2 pints of coke. 14 Euro! Bloody rip off, avoid this place. Wasn't anything Irish about the place either.

Hellish dump. This area would be lovely if there was a constant significant Police prescence. The whole area is full of scam artists, pickpockets and people selling crappy souvenirs. In fact, every tourist area in Paris is the same. The rule of law seems to have virtually broken down. Absolutely no way I'm returning to Paris by choice until the Mayor of Paris puts significant resources into tackling the problem.

Lively and fun but be aware!. We went on a Sunday morning to Mont Martre and we wanted to go up to Sacre Coeur church. We climbed up the steps as there was along queue for the funicular up to the main piazza. The climb isn't too bad if you use the steps around the side and not the main straight up steps. Once up there, the views of Paris are stunning. We didn't go into the church as there was a service in progress and up around the dome, as the French do well at this, there was some sort of protest with banners unfurled.A walk around to the left go the church brings you to the Artists Quarter. This is busy and bustling with many coffee shops and art shops. After a coffee and a bit of people watching, we got the funicular down for €1.70.The streets are full of gift shops but please be aware of the many people that will try and separate you from your money! There are girls with phoney petitions that are organised pickpockets and the "flim flam" gangs. Just be aware of who is around you and you'll have a great visit.

Go at twighlight, watch the night rise, and then check out the Pigalle area. This area is as colorful and bohemian as I thought. I came two nights in a row. The streets are a photographer's paradise, and the juxtaposition of the Pigalle with the quieter upper streets near the Sacre Coeur was facinating. Great food up here, too. And it isn't horribly expensive.

A walk is how you'd get to know this place. Not as loud as most other places in Paris but a charm much beyond what the up-towns like Opera n'all can offer. The cobbled inclined walks, small restaurants calling out to you, the place just seems to be alive.You should opt for one of the walking tours to Montmarte and you'll never regret it.Google Paris Walks and you're bound to find more than a dozen. Hit up any of em, meet up at Metro Blanche (Moulin Rouge) and walk it up from there with the guide. It's an awesome experience as you pass by some really amazing narrow-lanes and slopes to arrive at the Basilica of Sacre-Coeur, where from after being a little exhausted by the walk you feel the cool air and the panoramic view of Paris, the city as it is.

Paris of the Movies. First off I think the people that comment about the bracelet people and the unsavoury characters would probably walk directly into an oncoming train too. They have to be oblivious to seeing the potholes and instead of walking around the people they decide to walk to them, inviting their bad time. We stayed in an apartment on Rue Gabrielle and it was fabulous and COMPLETELY SAFE at all times day and night. Don't go up to the plaza next to Sacre Coueur because you will get what you deserve. If you do please remember the phrase, "Non, merci.". That way the rose guy and the artists who will try to charge you 80 euros for a bad sketch of yourself will not bother you. Montmartre is beautiful and charming and tons of cafes near the abbesses that you can just leisurely enjoy the day. I spent five days there and never saw a homeless person or someone urinating on the steps. Just all kinds of folks enjoying themselves.And by the way, I had read all of he reiews that said how sketchy it was and was a bit apprehensive about the place, but after the first day I felt foolish even heeding advice from any of these folks.

Beautiful if you go the right way.. There is a main touristy street up to Montmatre that directly goes up to the Sacre Couer. While, when you get up this hill the view is stunning, this hill is full of tourist traps and tacky shops and street conmen. I recommend going an alternate route past the Moulin Rouge. This way you get to see one of the most famous sites in Paris (which is worth an evening visit to the shows) and the streets are stunning. They're very cute and village-life like and a lot quieter to the alternate route. This way takes you to the back of the Sacre Couer through a square full of art sellers. These are busy streets but are worth a browse. There are bars, cafes and shops - well worth a look. Once you get to the Sacre Couer the views are amazing. You can see all the way over Paris. There is a view of the Eiffel Tour near the back of the Sacre Couer but it is not visable from the steps. Montmatre, while controversial in its time, is a beautiful area of Paris and so worth a visit.

Fun!. I loved this neighborhood. When you first come by train esp near moulin Rouge, It is crowded, dirty, strip club, weird people but I was lucky I was with the free city group tour of paris and we went much deeper into the neighborhood where there are beautiful views and streets. I would definitely recommend visiting with a group tour! It was one of my favorite neighborhoods!

Go there to have fun. the church is not that much interesting to go there to visit itBut specially the restaurants around it are the bestKind and funny waiters Lovely atmosphere Good place for drinking wine Recommend u to go there near sunset or night

Disgusting!. My partner and I recently visited Montmartre while in Paris as we had been recommended to go there by a few different people. It was the most disgusting place I have ever been, and this was during the day!... The main street is covered in sex shops and second-hand clothing stores. We decided to walk up to the church on the hill. Instead of going up one of the main paths we thought it might be nice to go up some scenic little stairs... this was a bad idea... turns out it is used by a urinal for the local homeless.. as we started walking up urine was dripping down the steps so we turned around and decided to go up the main path. As we got further towards the church there were homeless people sitting around drinking alcohol. There were all the tourist traps I had heard of up there... the girls with petitions, the men trying to tie bracelets around people's wrists and people selling handbags and metal Eiffel towers. As we walked up another set of steps to the church (this time the main route up) a man just decided to start urinating about 1m in front of us with people around everywhere. We turned around and left never to return again.

I found a new neighborhood for my Paris vacations!. I usually stay on the Left Bank when in Paris. I thought about trying something different and discovered Montmartre. I love the vibrant and edgy energy of this neighborhood! People watchers would be in paradise! The restaurants, clubs and even tourist attractionshave such a stark contrast (in a positive way) to the Left Bank.

A friendly enviroment. this area is not for those kind of "busy" tourists whom just want to visit historical places as fast as possible and just take some photos. here is to relax. here is to enjoy the streets. to enjoy the people. to just find the peace while sitting in a cafe and drinking sth.

Mixed Emotions. We walked from the hotel, about a 40 min walk. The area was very busy leading up to the church. On word of CAUTION! The peddlers standing on the bottom of the steps leadin up to the church are not very nice. They use the bracelet trick to get to to buy a bracelet to go to the church. They are not very nice and will just grab your hand, and before you know it they have a bracelet started on you finger. Then they ask for money and 2 euros won't satisfy them. Just keep your hands in your pocket and barge through. Or take a side street up to the top. Once at the top of the steps the views were incredible. The church was awesome and the little restaurants and village was really cool. If you can plan and avoid the trash at the bottom of the steps you are in for a real treat. I would go back and will be better prepared for the experience. This was our first experience in Paris and it didn't provide a nice image. But as the trip went on we really enjoyed the city.

Dirty, busy and some unsavoury characters.. I was looking forwards to a quaint little series of streets with art shops and fashionable coffee bars.That was half right, a lot of the shops were good, as were the restaurants, but what spoilt it was the sheer size of the crowds of people.All of the bars / restaurants were full to the brim, queues in the shops, and people barging there way past each other. The crowded nature of the place did make it slightly unpleasant.I also felt slightly uneasy due to lots of 'suspicious' looking characters, combined with a 0 police presence, pick pocketing is apparently rife in the area, and I'm not surprised.I really wanted the place to blow me away, and the view kind of did. But with so many other good vantage points in Paris (Eiffel Tower, Arc de Triomph etc), I can't recommend visiting.

Take a wander. Soak up the atmosphere!. The area of Montmartre is great for wandering around day or night. There is a great view from outside Sacre Coeur over Paris. The Place Du Tertre is buzzing with restaurants and artists. Lots of bars and restaurants and a few shops make this area a 'happening' place.At night, crowds gather on the steps at the Sacre Coeur to 'hang out'. Grab a crepe from the nearby square and go and join them! At the base of the hill, there is the street with the 'find the lady' scam artists. Don't get sucked in! Leave that to other naive tourists. They work in crews and the only people that win are their under cover buddies. Be warned - no matter how easy it looks! If the steps are too much, take either the funicular or the land train.

Edith Piaff's old stomping ground!!!. Lots of cute winding streets all the way to the top,with an amazing view over Paris,we sat on the stairs and had a little picnic,then meandered around the markets watching all the artists trying to make a dollar selling their paintings.Overall a very interesting place.

Loved it! A lot to see!. Loved it! Go during the day, at night you have to be very careful.But during the day, it was beautifull, we walked in many of the streets, we saw the Moulin Rouge, the Café des 2 moulins (café in the movie Amelie), we saw the cimetary, Sacré-coeur, Place du Tertre, Dali museum, etc. There is a lot to see! Loved it! :)

go during dusk. This is a place not to miss. Try to reach the top just before dusk, sit on the stairs and wait till sun down to see the city illuminated gradually. The views are just amazing and you won't fail to miss the lively street performers keeping you entertained throughout the evening. Hop on the Funicular to descend or climb down the stairs and get lost into the streets of Montmartre where you'll find a market full of souvenir shops on your way to Pigalle.

Montmartre Paris. Stayed at Ibis Hotel, Montmartre Paris. Just a 10 minute walk to Moulin Rouge and Sacre Coeur. Tube station literally 2 min walk and buses running frequently. Hotel good value for money.

The town on the hill..... Commanding view of Paris....worth the visit....symbolic contrasts with the Sacre Coeur dominating the landscape and Moulin Rouge and red light district in its shadow...experience Parisian culture, particularly the painters with some of the most interesting shops....Little known fact - the most expensive wine in the World is grown in the Montmartre Vineyards perhaps half the size of a football field......

Disappointing. Montmartre was famous for its artists and there displays surrounded by lovely little cafes and restaurants. Unfortunately the number of "artists" has reduced significantly and have been replaced by either restaurants or sketch artists impacting on the romantic feel it used to have.Also the area around the Sacre Couer has lost it's lustre and is grubby with lots of beer bottle tops, broken glass, drink and other stains and a gang of annoying people selling cheap junk who are ready to make a quick escape if the local police arrive. The Sacre Couer itself is a magnificent structure and well worth the visit.There is also a Montmartrain that runs every 35 minutes taking you around the local area including Moulin Rouge. When we arrived the train was full and the driver advised us that he would be back in 35 minutes, so we waited in line for the 40 minutes and when it arrived the driver told us that we could not get on because a tour group had a booking for the whole train. All in the queue were far from impressed and were quite angry and could not understand why the driver had not told us this 40 minutes earlier. He did say that there would be another train in 5 minutes but surprise surprise it did not show up.IT is unlikely that we would return to this area on future trips to Paris.I
Imagine. Wonderful to just sit on a sunny day beneath the Sacre Couer and watch the scenery, Paris and people. Wander the market streets too, surprises await!

A beautiful view complementary to the Eiffel Tower. We went to Montmatre on the 3rd day of our 4 day Paris trip. We had been there 10 years ago. It's an easy walk from the Metro. We walked up to the Church as the funicular had a long line due to one car being repaired. The ticket office is around the left of the church. We bought a crypt and dome ticket but the crypt only takes a few minutes. The dome ascent give you a beautiful view of Paris including the Eiffel Tower. We had noticed that Montmatre seemed to be the same height as the Eiffel tower when we visited it. Difficult to take photos on the dome due to the sun glare reflecting off the white stone. The kids liked the climb and were not bored. Afterwards we had lunch at one of the restaurants on the way back to the Metro. Would definitely make it a must do for your visit to Paris.
Amazing place. This is a cultural feast in a stunning location. It all goes here.. it's sort of bohemian and cosmopolitan. People of all walks of life mingle here. My ideal type of place.

Tourist madness trap with a surprising side trip for fabric. I looked forward to seeing the area where so many famous artists made their home. It is on a hill overlooking Paris, great panoramic view. There are local artists who,have a license to exhibit their art in the square and then shops along side streets that sell the Chinese knockoffs of Impressionists. Viewing the art work, I think there must be a lot more value in receiving a permit from the city to exhibit than the value of the art for sale. There were too many little stalls selling souvenirs and junk that it felt like a border town along Texas-Mexico border. I did find one store that sold tapestries made in Flanders that were nice quality. It was crowded, way too many charcoal portrait sketch artists, and pickpocket heaven because it was so crowded. The basilica, Sacre Couer is located in Montemarte. Be prepared for long lines to go in and the vendors selling mementos. It all had a carnival atmosphere. A tip for sewists that visit Montmarte. skip the artists in the square and take your money down the hill to the fabric stores along the street where the carousel is located. Remnant ends of fabulous fabric are for sale. The remnants may be 3/4 meter to 5 meters and if you buy the fabric called coupons, you buy the entire folded amount. I bought Italian wools, silks, and Italian men's shirt cotton, lace, buttons, trims. It was a favorite part of my trip. I found one piece of silk that was from the scarf/fabric designer, Celine. If you check eBay for Celine scarfs you will get an idea of the fabulous fabric available. There is also a local art gallery there that has a lovely coffee shop and sandwiches. I hired a personal guide prior to arriving in Paris. She works as a costumer for the French film industry and she took me to all her favorite sewing shops. Her help and expertise was well worth the fee. The stores at the base of Sacre Couer that I recommend are Sacres Coupons and Tissus Reine. There is usually at least one person who speaks English at the shops. Marche St. Pierre has changed ownership and fabrics are not the quality of selection as reputed in the past. Pictures are not allowed in the shops. August is not the best time for all shops because August is the holiday month for Parisians.Lastly, bathrooms are limited in France. Public restrooms are not pleasant, but if you go to a coffee shop and buy a coffee or give the waiter a Euro, you can probably use the bathroom.

The side streets of Montmontre. In June I did a walking tour of Montmontre. We saw the I Love You wall, the statue of The Man in the Wall, St Steven's statue with his head in his hands and the bust of the singer Dalida. I have been to the Sacre Coeur area many times in the past, but not to all these out of the way sights. We chose to walk down the steps by the Basilica instead of taking the funicolare....all 257 some odd steps. Whew, that after all the walking up and down the cobblestoned streets. But it was wonderful.

What a view!. Highest point in Paris. Massive white church. Nice old winding streets. Bit touristy, and the artists won't leave you alone. I think there were as many of them trying to draw pictures of tourists as there were tourists. Worth the trip. Use the Metro and there's a tram lift up/down that's included in your Metro ticket.
Art and only!. The great place of Montmartre! The art, the culture and an old Parisian air will make you feel different, Α great man in dreamy place! Buy a painting or make your own portrait!

Fun if You Get Past the Sleaze. Montmartre isn't the most attractive neighborhood at night, with sleazy clubs and loads of partiers. However, during the day and off the main streets, it's a joy to stroll around here: there are cute/funky shops to browse through and the Sacre-Coeur basilica is beautiful inside and out. The nightlife in the regular (not topless) bars is also fun. Get away from the general tourist streets and you'll enjoy yourself much more.

Favorite Non-Touristy spot. This is a must-see neighborhood, not only because it is home to the Moulin Rouge, but it is the highest point in Paris. The narrow streets with street cafes, wine bars, and shops, is much quieter and less touristy than other Parisian neighborhoods. It was my favorite spot in Paris and I'm so glad we stayed in this area. I definitely want to go back.
