Love this place. Love the view love the Sacred Coeur love the artist section great for people watchingWatch for pick pockets especially on metroYou can eat all you like cos you will wear it off up down a zillion stairways

good for a short break. Montmartre is a really nice place for a short break, if you're prepared to tackle the endless slopes and stairs. There are lots of market shops that sell amazing French bread (for a euro!) as well as fruits and desserts. It's a very quaint place and very quiet with some impressive views and interesting buildings, but with a decent nightlife too. I stayed for three days and found that was enough for me, but it's very easy to connect to other areas via the metro, so it makes an excellent resting place alongside a few busy days out exploring.

Montmartre - 18th arrondissement rive droite. AMAZING! don't miss this section of Paris! Be prepared for a hilly hike but so worth the excerise. awe inspiring views and so quaint. if you can't get out of the city due to a short visit, then you must spend at least a few hours soaking up the artsy villiage atmostphere that you won't find anywhere else in the city.

Nice on a Sunday. When many places are closed in Paris on a Sunday we decided to go to Montmartre and weren't disappointed, We saw the Sacre-Coeur first and then walked around, we went off the tourist beaten path and found a street full of locals doing their Sunday afternoon grocery shop. The area near the Sacre-Coeur and Place du Tertre is touristy and Montmartre wouldn't be enjoyable if you just went to these 2 places because they cater to tourists. I wouldn't really recommend coming here if you are short in time while in Paris but I would definitely return to Montmartre.

Great place for a short term apartment. I took a short vacanza to celebrate my birthday in Paris. Instead of a hotel I stayed at my friends place in Montmartre. What a delightful nabe. Now it has its drawbacks but I think for renting a place out there it isn't bad. Lots of great attractions from the Sacre Coeur to Dali Espace and if Pigalle at night time is your thing there is something for you too. However, if you wish to buy some artwork while staying here do head over to: http://www.art21concept.com/ I purchased from them in 2012 and then I just purchased another piece of work on 08/21/1983. Bruno and Simona are great. It is a well curated gallery. Do take a visit while here in this hamlet like This is my second time in Montmartre and it felt great just to have a personal place to myself.

Rather disneyfied. There's a clever street graffito repeated throughout the margins of the area that reworks the Disneyland logo into a outline of the Sacrecoeur with the words Montmartre Paris in a Disney-esque font. Says it all really.
Trendy and artistic walk around. Another world, full of art and painting. Wandering around is really fascinating. Off course pay a visit to Saint Coeur cathedral.

Why not during the day. Never again at night.. Took the metro and then walked up the hill in the mid of the afternoon.Nice view, beautiful church. It was nice to stroll up and down, enter the stores, sip a coffee. However, those little streets are nothing special and the same goes for the stores, cafes, and restaurants. But as I said on the title, why not? If you have time and wants to relax.Late pmWe stroll at the base of the hill. Bunch of sex stores, "massage places", strip clubs. The moulin rouge and other cabaret shows (la nouvelle eve is a great cabaret show and cheaper than the moulin rouge)NightAfter a great cabaret show, I thought it would be a good idea to see the church at night and enjoy the view by night. Never again.It smells like piss everywhere. The people hanging at the church steps are drunk people. And not just a bit drunk.On our walk back to the metro I felt unsafe, I smelled pee, I saw a penis, and my husband was getting ready to fight a group of man who were making sexual comments.

Not that special. I had never visited the Montmatre area previously, so I booked on a walking tour.I was hoping to be thrilled, however for me it was a lot of walking up/down hills, without that much benefit.(I did already have blisters & was in pain walking, so that no doubt dampened my enthusiasm)I didn't really see anything that interesting, however it was a different side of Paris, so I'm glad that I did.

Montmartre. We had a recommendation to check this out for a view of the city! We took the train to Abbesses on line 12 and took a stroll into a lovely little area of a paris and then we tackled the stairs. The stairs aren't to bad and the rewards when you get to the top are amazing. The view of Paris and the Sacrē-Cæur are brilliant. Be wary of people selling stuff they can be forceful in some way but you just have to be firm. Police are actively about.

nice feeling when you at the top. placed slightly away..requires better directions from the rail station..gave a lovely feeling on the top. loved the quaint village setting .Sipping coffee at one of cafes overlooking the artists and their works was what that gave a feeling good factor.The chapel is ok.

Dont know why it's so famous. It’s just an average site, not that beautiful to be a famous hill. The architecture, design and the quarters leading up to the hill are so so. The sight was very similar to many places I have seen in France. The space on top of the hill was much smaller than I had expected. Not really magnificent as people say

Just not disappointing.. Have read about a lot of times about this area in novels and when being there personally is a quite different experience. Maybe because I didn't find the right way, just can not get the view of Eiffel from the top.

Lovely walk. We walked up from the Abyssee metro, fun for my kid and great exercise for me, decent views of Paris but not spectacular. Skip the basilica if u are not religious, we found it boring. Walked all the way back to our chateau Landon area hotel which was fun except for the con artists with their tricks on the way. Junk tourist shops... get some baguette, Brie & sit on a park bench, enjoy the view.

Good hillside attraction. Montmartre, meaning the mountain of the martyr is one the places with high historic significance behind it. You can see Picaso's favourite eating place there, a vineyeard which is a rare sight, the artist Dalida and an magnificant church Basilica of the Sacred Heart of Paris

Not sure what others see in this area. We got off the Metro stop and found a pretty sketchy area. I think there are closer stops, but based on the line we were near this is where the Metro app told us to get off. Thank goodness for GPS on the phone to get us to Sacre de Couer. There were some nice views of Paris, but we had already gotten those from Arc De Triomphe and the Eiffel Tower. The church was pretty, but worth the 30 minute metro trip. I was expecting to see artist, studios, cafes, but didn't come across much. I did see some people on a free tour, maybe you need to do that to get something out of Montmarte

Magnifique Montmartre. I am staying in Montmartre for 5 days. It is on arrival a busy place with nothing much to offer. I am staying in a hotel on the Place de Clichy. My first day starting out at about 9am after flying in from Australia, after a quick shower and power nap I turned left and headed off across the bridge straight across the cemetery. Cemeteries in Paris are surprisingly interesting places and this one houses Degas as one of its guests. I just walked in no particular direction without a map. August is a time when most Parisians go South for the holidays and so though it was a Thursday it felt like a weekend. The little cafes however were pumping. The streets are lovely, pretty flower boxes filled with geraniums, gorgeous trees lining the streets, just what you expect to see in Paris.There are charming delicatessens, patisseries, boulangerie and specialist stores.This little adventure took me up the back steps of Sacre Couer. Not a tourist in sight except for me. Locals sitting in treed alcoves, so charming. It's a different story when you reach the top as there are hundreds of tourists on the site. However, it's lovely, the view is spectacular and though I didn't venture into the church on this occasion, it's still a very nice experience.After taking some shots and doing some people watching I ventured down the hill and into the throng.You need to be prepared. Read all the internet sites about how to keep what you have. I walked into the abyss. I don't buy in areas like this as usually they are more expensive and also I don't want anyone to see where I go for my money. I stopped to watch a game of stealth to see if I could spot the scam.The next thing I realise I am being drawn into it! I see two girls each win 50 euros each and the man tells me to choose as the girls did. I say no I'm not interested. He gives me E50 and says now tell me, I say no and try to give the money back. He shows me which one to choose and then gives me another 50 euro. I end up with 200 euro and he asks me to swap it for two x 100 Euro notes. I guess this is where I show where my money is and I take his arm, shove his marked, possibly fake notes into his hand, tell him I have no money and I don't want his and walk away. I'm sure I was marked. I am alone, a small woman but not a stupid one. Don't let people like this spoil what is in fact a very interesting part of the city of Paris. My walk took me down some very lovely streets and then into Pigalle which is the red light district. The same as red light districts in most cities of the world. Not that I'm an officiando, I have on a previous visit been to the Moulin Rouge show and though it is squashed and expensive, it's not nasty or sleazy. The thing I remember most is the comedian they had then, was the funniest I had ever seen. It was all mime and just wonderful. It's summer so it's light until after 9pm so I have been out to dinner, but I don't walk alone at night as I wouldn't anywhere. It's life with all its variables!

Picture perfect setting. Without doubt, our favorite place in Paris. the majestic views overlooking the Effiel Tower and the City and the commanding presence of a vibrant and worshipful cathedral, set amongst the canvases and small narrow streets of restaurants and artists make this an ideal setting for a day strolling through this magical area. The only drawback is the filth of the red light district through which you must pass to arrive. So plan an alternate route and the day will be unspoiled.

Fascinating place. Loved the people watching and the feeling of a slower and more creative pace of life there. We spent some time eating a pastry from a local cafe while watching the world go past and felt like we wanted to stay for the rest of the day. Very enjoyable

Risqué Paris. The old village of Montmartre is full of tiny cobbled streets and is an ideal place to spend an afternoon. Sunday morning it is full of artists selling their works, and is the gateway to visiting the Sacre-Coeur. The Pigalle area is a bit grubby.

Fun Area. This was a nice place to just walk around. I loved Secre-Coeur and also the many side streets. I would suggest finding some food on the Rue Abbesses. It was a nice area with many cute cafes.

One of the most beautiful neighbourhoods of Paris!. I loved this area: small shops selling sweets and souvenirs, typical French houses, greenery and flowers everywhere, artists in Place du Tertre and chic cafes. This area, although crowded near Sacre-Coeur, has a typical Parisian charm. I enjoyed it very much. There are indeed a lot of kitschy souvenir sellers and tricksters, but just ignore them and get lost among the narrow streets!

A village in Paris.. It is one of the most recognizable and popular tourist destinations of Paris is one I’ve had the pleasure of visiting quite a few times during my trips to that fascinating city. I reccomend it.

Beautiful basilica, thieves and scam artists abound, all about money. Sadly, the once unique and Bohemian neighborhood of Montmartre, the setting for La Boheme, the Moulin Rouge, and so many other tales of artistic striving and nostalgia, and centered around the majestic Sacre Coeur basilica, has been transformed into a burlesque of itself--- a Hollywood version of Bohemia with a Las Vegas underbelly. It is overrun by tourists wanting an instant, authentic experience, surrounded by shops loving international money but staffed by xenophobes, swarming with thieves and aggressive scam artists picking out their marks as soon as you disembark from the Metro. Altogether, this is an unpleasant experience for travelers searching for emotional purity but finding a purity of greed and survival. Mind you, the basilica is still majestic, if you can find it within the hoards of people pushing to get in, or walking around alternately talking loudly and shushing each other. The climb to the dome and the crypt are worth the extra charge. The view is beautiful, although not much compared to the view from the Notre Dame tower or the Eiffel Tower. Everywhere in Paris, as we posed for photos, people (such as tram conductors) shouted out in English, "One, two, three!" As well, I wish that just for one day in Paris, I could go through a single day without someone shouting out "Arigato!" "Ni hao!" or other race-baiting phrases. I am Asian-American, but I speak fluent American English and good French. It is assumed that Asian-appearing tourists are subhumans who are incapable of understanding insults and therefore---maybe---deserving of being insulted. A lamentable situation. I know that these are not representatives of Parisians, but it does not give a visitor warm feelings. As in other tourist areas of Paris, most of the shops sell very forgettable merchandise. One of the shops selling genuinely fine merchandise is a Fragonard parfumerie at the base of the funicular. Their website is here:http://www.fragonard.com/parfums_grasse/GB/fragonard/paris/the_boutique_montmartre.cfmMany of the sample perfumes are exquisite, alluring. We spent more than 100 Euros on perfumes and soaps. Despite our purchase, they could not direct us to any bathroom nearby. As we were leaving, my young son bumped his hand into the door and began crying in pain. He sat down on the step near the door. Because he was crying too hard to explain what hurt, I examined his hand and his legs, to make sure that nothing was bleeding. This took about three or four minutes. During the entire encounter, the staff of the shop (5 or 6 employees) stood in the back of the shop, talking amongst themselves, looking at us, not speaking to us or coming to our aid. I wish I hadn't purchased anything, and if it wouldn't have taken more time in the shop, would have returned the merchandise. The perfumes might be exquisite, but they now have the stench of condescension. American dollars welcomed, Americans, not so much. It is a jarring experience to see these resplendent sights in an atmosphere of meretricious mockery.

Special place. Montmartre is a part of Paris with a wholly different feel. It is different to be in Paris where there are hilly streets and no bustling traffic or grand boulevards. At the top, such as by Sacre-Coeur, are interminable views of Paris, and one gets the feel of being on top of the whole city. There are several cafes and restaurants to add to the atmosphere of the place. It is a really worthwhile place to go when one is tired of other Parisian attractions.

Looking for a quite corner to relax from the husle at Place du Tertre?. Go to the corner of rue du Mont Cenis and rue Cortot, there you will find Square Claude Charpentier, a small square with a tower, benches and big trees which provide beautifull shadow during the hot afternoon. If you want to take coffee or a cold drink you can walk up rue du Mont Cenis just a few 100 m. where you will find cafes with take away.

Careful of pickpockets and local scams. Wondered into Montmatre square following sacre coer, some of the 'artists' are actually just scams which cut out a silhouette for20 euros. If stopped and approached just walk on. Also, don't eat in the restaurans in the square- they're crap.

A taste of France in a cozy ambiance. This place is great for all ages. First you arrive to Montmartre and walk through the streets that lead you to the Sacre Coeur, a beautiful church. Then you continue walking and end up at the Place de Tertre where all the artists art. For 30 euros you can have a great drawing. Then, you can eat in one of the many restaurants around.
Great place to visit. The area is pretty with drawers district and beautiful church , but watch out of thief and robbers at night, one of my friend did got robbed at night in this area.

Sweet area, stay on the hill. We loved the area and sacre cour, the steps were like climbing a piramid, beautiful view of the city from the top. The hassles are a bit of a gauntlet, but just hold onto your bags and keep going. The small winding streets with cafes were the best part. Get down into the gritty part of the city and it's not so great. We took a walk down to get a look at the Moulan Rouge, took a picture and climbed back up the hill for the calm and beautiful. There are other moulans behind the sacre cour that we never got to, but are apparently more authentic....another trip.

Not a good day in Montmartre. We had heard that this was a neighbourhood not to be missed so we hopped on the metro from our rental on the Left Bank and got off near Sacre Coeur. Our first stop was at a convenience store to get a drink and my youngest son was bitten by a cat inside the store when he (unadvisedly) tried to pet it. Not a a good start.As we approached the cable car by the church, we found ourselves among dozens of groups of dark skinned men who were hustling tourists. They would tie a string around the victim's wrist and then quickly braid a bracelet and then tie a knot and ask for money, now that the bracelet is knotted and therefore, impossible to remove. I saw them entice a little boy and only stopped when his mother physically pulled him away, and then they approached my teenage son. We eventually managed to rid ourselves of these men but not before my son almost got caught in the scam.The cable car ride up to the church was brief and underwhelming, as was the basilica itself. We had already been to Notre Dame earlier in the week so we had had our fill of churches. The view was okay but obstructed somewhat by trees to the west. The little studios, galleries and shops on the cobblestone streets were quaint but rife with more hustlers wanting to sell you trinkets or paint your portrait. We had a decent dinner in a little cafe and then walked to the Moulin Rouge for a photo before heading to the Pigalle metro station to go home. Going through the turnstiles, my husband was pushed from behind by a fellow who appeared to try to sneak through without paying but as it turned out, he quickly had his hand in my husband's pocket, and, even though the pocket was buttoned, managed to steal his wallet. My husband realized right away but those guys are so fast and work in teams so we had no idea where to go after him.So that was our experience in Montmartre. Personally, I would not recommend this area to families or any tourists unless you are on a chartered bus with a private tour. There are so many other wonderful areas of Paris where you do not feel so vulnerable and uneasy. Having said that, anywhere there are tourists, there are going to be hustlers so keep a sharp eye out for potential pick-pocketers and keep your valuables at home. Bring with you only what you absolutely need and keep that in a money belt under your clothes whenever you are in big, jostling crowds. We managed to cancel our credit and debit cards before they were used but this guy got over 100 Euro (we had just been to the bank) and caused us a lot of inconvenience. Thankfully, my husband wasn't knifed (or worse) but we certainly didn't expect this kind of experience in broad daylight in a historic Paris neighbourhood. Be warned!

Nice place. Like most places in Paris, Montmartre is easy to access. I walked uphill on a narrow road full of shops. I bought some tasty food from a small store, and ate it in a children’s playground. It is not easy to find a public bathroom in Paris, but here there is a fancy and free one. You do not even have to flush the toilet, and after each use, the entire toiler will be washed and dried. The downside is that it took much longer time. Nearby you could use your metro ticket to ride a cable car to the top of the hill, where the Basilica of Sacred Heart sits. This is the highest ground in Paris, and offers a beautiful view. Historically many fought to control this place. After I visited the majestic basilica, I walked downhill. Many just sat on steps to enjoy the view. A black athletic young man climbed a lamppost, juggling a football. People enjoyed his performance.

Lots of people!. This destination is a must but understand that during the tourist season, it is PACKED with lots and lots of people! If crowds bother you then you might want to get up early and head up to Montmartre and the beautiful church, Sacre Coeur. It was a very warm, sunny day when we arrived and instead of the 'finicular' (tram), we decided to walk the curved stairway up to the top. I've been here before but always took the funicular. This way up was much prettier and gave us more opportunities for great picture-taking! The little shops that line the 'square' are, for the most part, full of the touristy stuff. If you'd like to have your portrait drawn, there are many different artists to consider! Smack-dab in the center of this square are a couple of outdoor restaurants which are always packed with customers. We ate at one of these and found the service to be quick and the food very good with portions, huge! However, when ordering food, I would avoid ordering a drink of any kind. I ordered iced tea and when the bill was presented was amazed that it cost 12 euros!! The church, Sacre Coeur, is quite lovely and is worth a look. Again, if the crowds are there, it will take awhile to get inside. Once inside it is quiet and serene...filled with beautiful mosaic work and soaring ceilings...quite beautiful!

Charming neighborhood. Montmartre, once a refuge for poor artists, now houses only Paris’ aristocracy. And, though much of its original history is preserved, the neighborhood definitely has more of the newer resident’s vibe. Montmartre is filled with little specialized food stores and markets, as well as boulangeries, brasseries, cafés and restaurants. People in Montmartre like to eat, and like to eat well, that’s why a nice stroll along the neighborhood finds a great closure on finding a charming place to have dinner. The neighborhood is safer than the Sacre-Coeur basilica at the top of the hill, so it’s not a problem to tour around at night. That’s why I’d recommend to first go straight to the top, visit Sacre-Coeur and then take your time around Montmartre streets.

Beautiful view of the city. Well worth the hike upWe took the feniculare so it was greatThere are a lot of non desirable up there including ones who play a game with a string that they put on your wristBe aware of them just say merci and keep on walkingWe ate in a bistro very expensive but well worth it

Enjoy walking the streets. Impressed with the Sacre Coeur Basilica and the view. Enjoyed walking the neighorhood especially the Place du Terte with all the local artists displaying their artwork. Had fun shopping the shops on the rue des Abbesses and rue Leprie. Made our way down to the Moulin Rouge which was disappointing and not in a good area.

A different side of Paris. Take the green [metro] line to Pigalle (or the double-decker again) and walk NE on Bd. de Clichy until you see Moulin Rouge. The boulevard is lined with kebab shops, cheap souvenirs, and sex toys shops, so you won’t want to linger, unless you’re into that sort of stuff ;-) As for the Moulin Rouge, frankly it looks better in pictures, although I hear the show is quite spectacular… Snap a pic yourself and then head up the hill, turn on Rue des Abbesses, find a nice sidewalk café (preferably around one of the small squares in the area) order a glass of wine and set in for an interesting people-watching experience. You deserve it!Once rested, explore the area around the basilica, which some call Paris’ response to the Village in NY (although just as in that case, artists and writers no longer can afford to live here, and it’s now more of a tourist attraction). Nonetheless, it’s a neighborhood with plenty of character and lots of history. Ultimately, you’ll get to the top of Montmartre, where the imposing Sacré Coeur basilica (100 years old next year) presides over the hill, the highest point in Paris. It’s very crowded, therefore somewhat difficult to enjoy (especially with all the accompanying trinket peddlers, gypsies, etc.) but it also offers a nice Paris panorama, from a different vantage point. I've been to Paris 3 times and have amassed a lot of information. Check out my blog, full of ideas, recommendations, etc.:…blogspot.com/2013/07/paris-mon-amour.htmlHope you enjoy!

Beautiful city views. We went up to Montmartre to experience the funicular ride and to enjoy the artistic ambience. Predictably, the place was crowded with other tourists, but it was still possible to relax near Sacre Coeur and explore the side streets. We enjoyed watching the artists drawing portraits of people.

Well worth a visit. We walked from the Pigalle area up to Montmatre and really enjoyed it. The narrow streets, bars and small shops are all interesting. There are lots of restaurants in the square, surrounded by artists offering their wares. It is a lovely way to spend a morning strolling about.

full of life, attraction for reasonable prices. We took the Metro (Anvers stop) to the Montmartre area and 'lifted' up the hill and up the huge staircase to the Sacre Coeur Basilica. We used Metro ticket and took a stairs lift ride on same ticket. You can do it if you are in 1,5 hrs. limit and we got there on the top for 1,70 Euro. A way to travel to save money and your energy during hot summer day! We did our Paris gifts shopping there; reasonable prices and people home love it all. It distance from the church the streets are full of artists who are eager to draw caricature portraits of visitors for a fee, to start negotiation.... The artsy feel of the area felt quite authentic. We walked the narrow cobblestone streets and viewed the classic French architecture. This area is different from Latin Quarters, very dynamic and fun....I will be back soon!

The atmosphere is amazing.. From Montmarte is located on the beautiful basilica, the Sacre-Coeur. Walk between among small shop. The atmosphere is amazing. bottom of the stairs is a beautiful carousel. The 234 steps of the Basilica of grass and a lot of people a lot of rest, read, play music talk. Lots of young people. The terrace has beautiful photographs can be taken. The building behind the painters square. I understand why he lived in Dali, Picasso ...The main road from the famous Moulin Rouge and all kinds of Erotica erotica shop and museum. There are many small cafes to the more intimate neighborhoods. (Pigalle)
The best day in Paris. Did a wonderful walking tour - starting from the bottom at the Moulin Rouge and working our was yo the top. So informative and magnificent.

Daytime is great!. We took the Metro (Anvers stop) to the Montmartre area and walked up the hill and up the huge staircase to the Sacre Coeur Basilica. A short distance from the church the streets are full of artists who are eager to draw caricature portraits of visitors for a fee. The artsy feel of the area felt quite authentic. We walked the narrow cobblestone streets and viewed the classic French architecture. It was a nice visit and from reading other reviews we are happy to have visited in the morning as we understand night time has the potential to get a bit dicey.

Bad vibes. Son and I decided to go to Montmarte last nite. The only place in Paris where I felt uncomfortable. We were cases by one guy for several blocks even when we doubled back also constantly hassled by hawkers and hucksters. We left after about an hour. Again, the only place in Paris we felt this way. Every other place we were comfortable even after midnite

Lovely view, well worth a visit. Go early morning in mid summer as it can get very busy and hot. Easy to reach by Metro rail and bus service available if any problems with mobility - quite a steep climb but worth every step.
Amazing. Best area in Paris. So much to see and do. You could walk all day and not get bored. Check out sacre coeur, Montmartre cemetery, and the moulin rouge.

What a gem of a place and the best view of Paris. Loved this ecclectic place full of artists and the view was lovely (although smoggy). Spent a good half day strolling, eating, drinking...a great place to relax.
Beautiful. This was an awesome place to visit metro took us to the end of the street it was very beautiful and the view was spectacular

Very dissappointing. We took the metro to Pigalle and walked around a bit on our way to and from Sacred Coeur, the area didn't feel safe, it was dirty and smelly, and crowded with cheap souvenir shops and shell game hawkers, not a very nice area. While waiting for the bus to take us back to town we witnessed an ugly fight right in front of us. I was very disappointed as I had expected more art and better conditions.

Great views from all angles.. I enjoyed our trip up to the top of the attraction. It took over 300 steps to get the top. But well worth it. Could see all the top attractions from the viewing area on top. On the way down on the church steps, it was odd to see guys selling bottles of beer on the hillside. Recommended for anyone who can make the climb

Not at all what I expected. We got off the L'Open Tour bus to visit Sacre'-Coeur and get a taste of Montmartre. What a huge disappointment! The whole area is very seedy (or "sketchy", as my grown granddaughter termed it), with shell games going on in the street, hawkers of stores trying to stop you. The Cathedral is lovely, as is the view from those infamous steps. The funicular was fun to ride and helped avoid the long climb up the hill, but it cost way too much for the about 40-yard length!As for the Moulin' Rouge, it looks very run down. We didn't stop or go to a show. The entire many-block neighborhood is filled with sex-oriented shops, giving us a very squeamish feeling! And I'm not a prude! If you have lots and lots of time in Paris, you could go there, but take some vehicle/route that doesn't leave you much of a walk through that neighborhood. Eat somewhere else, all the cafe's at the top of the hill looked very so-so. For the best view in Paris, of course you want your reserved ticket to the top of the Eiffel Tower (AND maybe another look at the First or Second Levels). I've heard Tour (Tower) Montparnasse is a good view also.

Montmatre harpist. We visited Montmatre in September 2011 and thoroughly enjoyed a few hours browsing the area.While there, we sat on the steps in front of Sacre Coeur and listened to a fabulous harpist. He was selling CD's of his music but I neglected to buy one, now I wish I had.Can anyone tell me if/where it is available on-line.......... Thanks.

Monmartre-Avoid unless you travel with bodygaurds. I have to agree with all of the negative reviews on Monmartre. It was our 1st stop in Paris. We had been warned about scammers and pickpockets so I was sort of ready for them, but it was scarier than I had expected. I'm a small woman and was traveling with my 14 year old daughter, and as we were heading up the ramp to the cathedral, we were blocked by a menacing group of very dark men, arm in arm creating a barrier so we'd be forced to walk through the rest of their gang. My daughter was terrified, so I was trying to hang on to her while holding my bag to my chest, and one of the guys grabbed my arm to put a piece of string on my wrist (for which he would later demand money, had he succeeded). They do this to get your hands off your purse so they can get into it. I had purposely purchased a travel bag that was difficult to get into, so they didn't succeed at that, but it was very scary and I was very, very angry. I agree that Paris needs to do more to curb the thugs, thieves and beggars that are EVERYWHERE there are tourists. It could be a great place to visit--the sights are beautiful, the history rich, but it is not worth a visit when you have to be fearful everywhere you go.The cathedral itself was very nice, but the area is very crowded and very unsettling. We didn't even get the benefit of the great view as it was cloudy. I could tell it had the potential to be pretty amazing, however (as long has you a firm grip on your kids and your valuables as you try to enjoy it).

The artists quartier. Just walk around the Sacre-Coeur, and you will be amazed to the little secrets this quartier offers - the funny mortuary masks on the walls (they look so real!), the violoncelo player, the bass relief in buildings, wind-mills, stair streets, the square of the street artists, offering to draw a picture of you, boulangeries, etc. Watch out the folks below Sacre-Coeur trying to catch you by the wrist, I don't know what they wanted, they scared me, I quickly deviated from them.

be artist. this is a must visit if u r in Paris, the lanes, the uphill reach n all that, artist making portrait of tourist for pleasure are nostalgic, u time travel to the artist era of Van gogh, Dali, Picasso to name few. the basilica ( Basilique du Sacré-Coeur de Montmartre) , it is as beautiful inside as it is from outside. there are many roadside cafe/ bistro, with good food.

Busy - get to the top as quick as you can. Hated the crazy, tourist-thronged streets at the bottom of the basilica. However, a quick climb up and it all changes. The view from the steps is worth the climb, and after a visit to the Basilica you can get lost in the quiet streets behind it and forget the crowds.
Touristy but exciting. We had a lovely day wandering around this bustling arty area. Expect the crowds and the con artists but enjoy the atmosphere.

You have to go up here!. I thought I would just go and explore because I heard of Montmartre. It turned out to be like a little town of its own and was really fun, along with having the beautiful Sacre Couer. A big plus is that you can overlook most of the city from here.

Fantastic views. We disembarked from our open top bus tour and walked to the top of the hill. The views of Paris are fantastic from here. We then took our time walking around the cathedral which is a magnificent building. It is a very busy attraction but sitting down on a quiet pew and taking the detail of he building in is very worthwhile.
Excellent. This area of Paris has a really good atmosphere and it really is well worth the visit. There is plenty to do as there are loads of cafes and shops

Loved this place and area.. This is well worth the trip over the river. We LOVED this place. If you want to see the Artsy community in all its glory make sure you go here. The church is spectacular, the views superb and the area fun and amazing. We watched artists at work outside the church and up and down the beautiful streets. Want to go back here again!

Loved Montmartre!. We have so enjoyed our time in Montmartre! We rented an apartment on the hill and as long as one stays away from the area around the Pigalle metro station, this neighborhood is fine. The Abbesses area is particularly charming with lots of interesting shops and restaurants. I found the locals polite and friendly. We were not bothered at all by aggressive vendors or scam artists. I would recommend this area as a good base for a stay in Paris.

Cool neighborhood topped off with the Sacre-Coeur. This is a most interesting neighborhood that was far enough away from the center of town that it was technically outside of the city for centuries. We got off the metro at the Blanche stop (avoided Pigalle and the sleaze this time) and just walked around until we reached the top of the hill that is the high part of the city. A few decades ago it was the part of the city where you could find many artists and writers and a rather Bohemian lifestyle. I suppose there is still some truth to that today. There are a few things that you might not want to miss if you go there and walk around like we did. Near the Blanche stop is the famous Moulin Rouge nightspot. On Rue Lepic and Rue des Abbesses there are tons of food shops and restaurants. On Rue Lepic is the brasserie/cafe called des Deux Moulins where quirky Amalie worked in the French film of the same name. Van Gogh's brother Theo lived on the same street. Keep your eyes peeled- You can probably spot a couple more windmills. This is the neighborhood where artists Utrillo (no one showed Montmartre better than Utrillo and he's one of my favorite painters), Modigliani, Picasso, and Renoir and singer Dalida used to live and with luck you will find markers for some of them. Look for the strange statue of a man walking through a wall too (Passe-Muraille) which is exactly what it says. Keep looking and you will even find a vineyard and a cemetery. You can visit a museum dedicated to Montmartre. Near the top of the hill is the famous square- Place du Tertre which is lined with places to eat and drink and swarming with tourists and artists trying to sell their visions of Paris (especially Montmartre) and others trying to convince you to select them to do your portrait (some are good and some are only cartoonists). Bargain carefully if you are tempted. And finally, at the top of this famous hill, is the rather new church known as the Sacre Coeur. Great views of the city and a few con artists and thieves are drawn here too. You can walk up the stairs from the bottom of the hill to get to Sacre-Coeur or also use a metro ticket to get up part way in a sort of elevator/tram. We chose to slowly walk up as I described earlier and then walk down the stairs after walking through the church. You can have a great afternoon walking up the hill, finding places for a drink or snack in order to break your climb, and enjoying the haunt of many famous people, and one of the most famous churches in the world.

Surprising highlight of Paris. It is worth the climb to visit the Sacre Coeur Basilica, however walk on into the village square where there are artists galore, found a lovely couple to sketch our daughter's portraits, try & find Fleur and her partner on the Eiffel Tower side of the square, they are lovely people. Warning: It is worth pointing out that there are scammers, stringmen & pickpockets around, if you are sensible, can say no and walk on, and are not distracted, you will enjoy the area immensely. This is common around all the tourist places, you must have money belts hidden under your clothing in Paris.But it remains a great place to visit.

The Best of Paris. We really liked the feel of Montmartre with its cobblestone streets and artists and restaurants. It was very pleasant there, and while there were some street vendors, they were gracious and did not force themselves on you once you said "No, merci." Food was very good here, as well. I would suggest that if you go to Paris and have the time, definitely go up to Montmartre--and you will see a great view of Paris along with the rest of the experience.

Nice, but not worth the time. After visiting Paris three times we headed up the hill to Montmartre to do a tour. It was somewhat disappointing. The tour was good, but the area is rather rough with many pickpockets near the transportation areas. It's the only time during my visits to Paris I had to forcibly push a pickpocket away. They are mainly 11-13 year old boys, but they want what you have and the Police do little to stop them. Sacre Courer was impressive and the view was nice, but overall, I wouldn't take the trip to Monmartre again, nor would I recommend it for anyone else. There are too many things to do in Paris so spend time there.

Worth the price to go to the top of the church. The area around the top of the church is full of artists and cafes. It’s quite nice. The streets at the base of the hill tend to be full of pickpockets. Beware of folks coming up to you with “surveys” asking if you speak English. It’s a set up. Back to the church…the inside is nice (free). The climb to the top costs about 6 Euro each, but it’s worth it. The view is unobstructed and your are at about the highest point in Paris. The line for the top wasn’t nearly as bad as Notre Dame’s. The climb is tight and spiraling…about 400 steps, but if you can do it, it’s worth it.

Find a great apartment here. Montmatre has been great to stay in. My 9 year old daughter and I stayed in Montmatre, and if you stay focused on enjoying the area, and ignore the annoyances e.g. the number of tourists in parts of the area, the people trying to sell things, then you can coexist with the locals well. It is like living in real Paris as we got to stay with locals and explore the streets. We found the best bread shop in the world, we believe! The area is full of things to do and my girl loved every part of it. It is easy to deal with the people trying to sell you things; we found that being polite and saying no, we were left alone. Also, just being aware of what is happening around you gives you the enjoyment every tourist should have! The best part was getting off the beaten track and just walking through the streets. The Sacre Coeur was magnificent, and another cool thing to do was to people watch on the stairs in the front. Lots of fun!
Wandering in Montmarte. beautiful day!breath-taking views lots of wonderful cafes to watch the world go by it is an area with lots of shops / stalls with art and crafts a plenty to enjoy and buy

Very Nice View, planned walking trip recommended. I've visited Montmarte in the last week. We found a planned tour on the internet with information about the area, and it was amazing. Highly recommended, terrific view.
There is a beautiful cathedral in Montmarte which is a must-see.

montaserry, a place where artists hangout. well you need to be a hiker to climb the steps. a place to be visited in the evening where city of lights i,e Paris can be seen from height . one will encounter many artists who would offer to draw your portrait for a sum, do bargain for the prices . The place is surrounded by many restaurants and yeah lot of Asian i.e Indian and Sinhalese restaurants are nearby i.e La Chapelle a good romantic place to hangout will go once again in future with better half. A lot is said about presence of pickpockets and antisocial elements in this place but it seems wrong as people were warm and helpful to show directions here
Beware street crime.. Stay in a large group or with tour tour guides. Not safe on the streets here for tourists, pockpockets and petty thieves in broad daylight.

A must. It can be a bit of a hike, it's on a hill, but the views are splendid.The Sacre Coure is just the most fantastic vista of frescos art work and history.Didn't like the fact that a lot of people took photos inside the church, despite being asked not to. And didn't like the stree sellers all around the church.Lovely square, Place Du tertre but as you might imagine everything was very expensive.

Waste of time!!!. Just too many tourists and a complete waste of time. The street vendors are pushy and the restaurants don't care any longer about their patrons. My fiancé didn't feel very safe and we left.

Glad we checked it out. We did a walking tour through the area and this is a great way to be introduce to the history and some if the less touristy parts. Loved walking around the artists who are so talent and part of a legacy that has been apart of Monmatre for a long time. Grat way to spend a couple of hours

So sad. Having been here over the years since the 1980s, I was so sad to see how it has changed. The area is so overwhelmed by tourists and the commercialism it brings, I was very sad. Worth a visit, if only as part of a talk about how Paris used to be...
Gorgeous!. I was there in June 2013 and it's so beautiful to walk around. You have a picnic outside the church if the weather is nice.

An Artist Area & Market. After riding the funicular up the hill and visiting the Basilica Sacre-Coeur walk around the corner to the artist area and look around. It is still nice to see some artist working, but remember this is a very high tourist area with many hustlers. Unfortunately the area is not the same as when I came here forty years ago. Few artists live here anymore, too many tourists etc. After seeing the area with a map try to lose yourself in the steep and cobbled streets of one of the most historic and interesting neighborhoods in Paris. Remember that the Basilica of Sacre-Coeur (the big white church) sits on the crest of the hill, so as long as you are heading down hill there is little possibility of being lost for long. At the bottom of the hill is the Boulevard de Clichy which is lined with bars, kebab shops.

Art, Souvenirs, Crowds, Street Performers and Food. What more could you want on a Sunday afternoon in Paris! We had just arrived after an overseas flight and needed stimulation to keep us awake--this was just the place. Of course it was crowded, you almost had to flow with the sea of humanity! We thoroughly enjoyed the artists--wish there were more of them--and bought a few small pieces. Took a quick look in the souvenir shops and ended up with two beautiful photographic place mats with Paris scenes. We stopped quickly for a coffee, and were next door to musicians performing outside. To us, it was quintessential Paris--sidewalk cafes with music--even if it was all for the tourists. There was other street entertainment as well--jugglers, dancers. Then we walked down the great hill, past the beautiful Parisian apartments, the vineyard and the Lapin Agile, and on to the Metro and a comfortable bed.

Lots of stairs!. We only went here on our way to a restaurant and we were not all that impressed! The view isn't all that great compared to the view from the tower and there are guys everywhere practically grabbing at you as they try to sell you stuff!If i wasnt with my fiancee i would have felt very intimidated by them!All in all i wouldnt say it was worth a visit!

Mini Tour of Montmartre. I would recommend visiting Montmartre, with the main focus on visiting Sacre Cour. It is an incredibly beautiful church. And since no pictures can be taken inside, it is well worth visiting to see it your self. Paris is crowded - period! So expecting to go to a famous site and not be in the midst of crowds(especially in the summer) is unrealistic. Plan according and be prepared for rude people and possible pick pockets. We were with a tour group which visited Sacre Cour and had lunch at a café. We also had time to walk around, visit shops and view artists. There were no major problems, except the rain, which didn't stop us. Go with realistic expectations and enjoy!

Dodgy Hustler problem at Mantmartre. Although I really wanted to enjoy this place, the fact i had rude, dodgy and in your face street hustlers harassing me - took away from the experience. Other tourist attractions around Paris are well patrolled by Police, however none were at the church. I was physically grabbed and almost cornered into a wall by one of these thugs who was very aggressive in trying to sell me some thread of string. He would nit take no for an answer even thought i was politely refusing. It was only when I yelled no very loudly did he stop. He then proceeded to yell abuse calling me ugly and noisy. it was very offensive. They are present on the way up to the church, and on the way down. The church and community need to do something about this.

Turist trap. High rate of crime and scams. Police nowhere to be found and local don't give a dam. Gipsy working in groups, attacking mostly elderly people. I seen may be 3-6 "artist" who tried suck money out of my family by making quit drawings. Total BS. Areas/plaza were real artist use to be is bunch of restaurants and cafes all overpriced with crapy food. Church not worst to clime to. On o top of it, all that surrounded by Paris ghetto. Do not waist your time and watch your pockets. Sorry it doesn't matter, they will get into them anyway you want it or not.. They just dong give a crap

Montemartre Festival, A la une. Be there in June 2014. It was Sat June 15, they had 6 acts walking and performing in the streets. Drumming bands, marching bands, it was sensational like a mardi gras. Then a band played, fantastic, lots of seventies music, Supertramp, Tom Jones, Pink Floyd, Amy Winehouse they had it all, plus tradional stuff from an older lady. It got wild later in the day, but band played non stop from 6pm till 11pm. Best event Ive ever been to. Chris from, Shepparton, Australia.

Something for everyone. I have been in this district on all three of my visits and each time I have discovered something new. The church at the top of the hill is just stunning and is a perfect photo opportunity. Please do not go here with luggage or a baby buggy because you will have some difficulty getting up the steps. The tram only takes you part of the way up the hill but if you don't mind carrying luggage or your time is short and you want to get in the most popular sites then definitely go here.

Ideal place to stay in Paris. Montmartre is very different from the wide boulevards of the rest of Paris, it has a more village-like feel, with lots of little shops and cafe's and some wonderful art attractions, Le Bateau Lavoir, 54 Rue Lepic was Van Gogh's home and 49 Rue Gabrielle was Picasso's home. Also Moulin de la Galette immortalised by Renoir. It is very touristy but hey, so is the rest of Paris.

Watch the world go by. The old artistic quarters of Paris today a major tourist trap, but that's the fun of it. Just sit down on a sidewalk bistro and watch the world go by - all of the world. You won't get the cheapest drinks or the best service. But you will have a lot of fun just watching. Walk around Place de Tertre and see the "Art", but go around the corner to eat or drink.Word of caution - if you are disabled this might not be the area for you. *Mont* in Montmartre means Hill and this is a hilly area, many and long stairs all over and steep streets with cobblestones, not the best place for wheelchairs.But not impossible, there's funicular to go up and down and a little train drives around the area so you can see some of it without walking.

Must see place in Paris. IF you have paris pass, you can go to the top by cable car, no need to climb all those steps.This is a church but eye catching place with lots of beautiful arts.If you can go there around 7.00 pm , you can listen to the nice catholic sermons preached by the sisters in there.

Montmartre is different than other parts of Paris - in my opinion. We enjoyed Mantmartre a lot. We walked all the streets up and down hills. We stopped into several establishments and all of the French people we met were very friendly. The area is a little more diverse than other parts of Paris. It is louder and the people are more "expressive". Don't buy any souveniers on Champs Elysees - buy them here and save some Euros! They have a lot of touristy souvenir shops and many are the same. We had dinner at a fantastic little cafe where our waiter Fredrick was my all time favorite Frenchman of the entire trip. We spent some time at Sacre-Couer which is amazing. I enjoyed the area, the people and the Church and I recommend spending a few hours of your trip to Paris in this area.

Mind Break. I will always remember the first time I took the last step and looked back to see Paris, and everytime was a first time, you can't go to Paris and miss it, it is the old Paris so you can't expect less, bring a snack and drink with you, set on the stairs and enjoy, and make sure then you walk behind the church in the tiny old streets and why not have a crape and an espresso.

Culinary Tour of Paris with Jean Paul. We booked two days in Pairs with Jean Paul Fortney to tour Montmarte and the Latin Quarter for his "culinary tour" experience and absolutely loved it! We were traveling with two teenaged daughters and they really enjoyed it as well. Jean Paul is friendly, informative, fun and provides a very interesting time with up to 8 people (so it's still very personal) touring, eating and drinking in some of his favorite spots. The restaurants were local places and he knew the folks well and provided a bit of history about each one of them. The food was delicious and the wine was great too. Jean Paul is able to keep you entertained, fed and happy for 4 hours in Paris while you learn a great deal about the special places authors and artists frequented in the past....what could be better than than!I will add that booking this via info@culinarytoursofparis.com is easy and efficient. Jean Paul answered the email in a timely way and we paid via paypal before our trip so everything was all set. The other option is to pay in cash when you arrive, which some folks chose to do. Jean Paul asks the right questions about you so that he is prepared just in case you have any food allergies and/or other issues. In my case, I am a vegetarian (which is a big problem in Paris generally) but I do eat sea food and cheese occasionally, so that worked out great!We traveled France for 2 weeks but my two teenaged daughters continued to talk about the two days with Jean Paul and how much fun it was to experience Paris with him. We recommend these tours wholeheartedly!

Not for inexperienced travelers! Only if nothing else to do. My daughter took a tour here with her first trip to Europe. After half a day she can't wait to get out of France! She's going to DisneyParis rather than spend another minute in the city. I'm not impressed with Montmartre after several trips to Paris. Unsafe, not clean, sacre coeur not old enough to bother with. Absolutely broken hearted that my daughter now hates Paris- My Paris, based on this awful experience!!

Mixed Reviews here. On the one hand, the area, the architecture and many of the shops are very charming. On the other hand, this was unbelievably crowded and edgy. A sea of unending people. Lots of junky touristy souvenir shops. They are all alike. These are mixed in with cute little cafes, boutiques, and other local shops. Be very aware of your belongings here. I held the zipper closed on the bag I was carrying close to my body to avert pickpockets. Pickpockets are looking to create distractions to get into your things. The views from the hill are awesome.

Montmartre with Rick Stevens. We used Rick Stevens walking tour guide and spent a good part of the day exploring Montmartre. We saw areas and learned things that we would not have seen without the guide book. A great day. Lots of up and down walking.

Such a shame there are so many shady characters. We visited Montmartre for the day and were impressed with the beauty of the Sacre Coeur and the surrounding streets. It's a shame that we were harrassed constantly by men trying to braid some sort of string on tourists' fingers. When told 'no', these men have no qualms in physically grabbing your arm and when told by my partner not to touch him, my partner was sworn at. As other reviewers have said, there are also a lot of conman itching to rid you of your money by playing games which obviously involve some trickery and we were surprised in the number of tourists handing over 5 or 10 euro notes to 'guess where the white disc was'.The quaint little streets with shops selling art, sweets and biscuits were fascinating and this is the area I loved wandering around and getting lost. Definitely worth a visit, especially to see the artists set up in the market - very very talented!
Favourite place in Paris. Absolutely loved Montmartre, it's beautiful and has such a great vibe. Next time I will stay in this area!
A must see. The neighborhood is so vibrant and colorful, with something new and awe inspiring around every corner

Fascinating. Montmartre was really a fascinating place. Just based on feel and atmosphere, it was my favorite neighborhood in Paris. I had my portrait drawn by a street artist, and he wasn't out to scam me or my friends by any means. We negotiated with him a little bit, but for the most part he seemed like a nice guy and he did a great job.In general, we didn't have a lot of trouble with shady characters in Montmartre—at least not any more than we did in other parts of Paris. Sacre Coeur was beautiful and the area by the stairs were milling with all kinds of different people. Awesome for people watching. I'd suggest walking to the back side of Sacre Coeur through the streets and either leaving that way or walking down some stairs than run parallel to the main stairs. We took those when we left and reached the bottom twice as fast.

Bohemian Feel. This is where we based ourselves in Paris, so glad we did. The area has such a nice feel, even though it has the seedy side the rest makes up for it. Didn't feel unsafe walking around.Could write heaps but if you visit Paris this is the place to come and spend some time

Charming place. Montmartre is a awesome place to walk and get lost on those narrow streets. The view of Paris from Sacre Coeur is just breathtaking. There is a small street market full of artists drawing, painting etc, very nice just to walk by and watch

Montmartre-not what it used to be. It took me a while to realise that I couldn't find any of the beautiful places in Montmartre that I had seen in 2005 because they no longer exist. I've been a little bit disappointed by the whole thing. Perhaps I was naive back then as I was a teenager on a school trip or perhaps it really has changed...Anyhow, the people are shady in certain areas and the place is riddled with beggars, "salesmen" and fraudulent "games". There's a game that my partner and I fell victim to which involves slight of hand and also trickery. It is a rigged game. I won't get into the specifics but Wikipedia or google "shell game". Anyway, basically please do not get close to anyone, do not engage with strangers no matter how friendly they look and absolutely trust no one. Keep your wits about you. Mind your belongings and make sure you know where they are at all times. Montmatre is simply not that romantic place that it is in our heads. Sacré Coeur is beautiful and I recommend going up the back way - it feels much safer and you don't get harassed at all. Although going up the stairs is pretty impressive I think you only have to read other reviews to know that it's just not worth it.Moulin rouge is underwhelming and the area it is in is truly offensive and dangerous. Particularly the street it is on.The must see's are Sacré couer (the safe way), place du tertre (real painters and artists who want to paint you not just for money but because they genuinely love what they do and are talented). Other than that, it's just a tad shady to really recommend much else.

Wonderful but a lot of shady people. Wonderful area with the Sacre-Coeur at the top of the hill. Recommend a visit but be mindful as there are many people trying to scam you and many shady folk waiting for their prey....

The old village charm. We had six days in Paris, five of which were spent doing all the usual stuff in inner districts and Disneyland. All this while, Montmartre kept nagging me, I was determined to visit this outer district and discover for my self what here charms millions of travelers every year. So on the last day we set out for the Anvers Mtero station, coming out you can see a bustling street called Rue de Steinkerque, leading up to the funicular going up to the Basilica of the Sacre Coeur. On the way you will find souvenir shops, street artists, musicians, carousels, fast food shops and the time just flies.At the top of the hill, we had a hard time deciding which way to face. The Basilica with its lovely dome and steps full of artists and tourists bewitches you. But behind you is the most spectacular view of Paris, one that rivals the Eiffel tower. After clicking a lot of pics, we moved to the next metro stop called Pigalle. The walk from Pigalle to Blanche is amusing as this is the red light district of Paris. We did it for the experience and had our share of laughs, gasps and cat calls. Moulin Rouge is close by if you are in to that sort of entertainment. Overall, an afternoon well spent.

Montmartre, home of the impressionists. It is a charming neighborhood to visit, though I'm not sure I'd want to stay there. At least on Saturday evening, it was jammed with tourists and locals flocking to watch the sunset on the steps of le Sacre Coeur. The crowds attracted the souvenir vendors and the pickpockets. This is were Van Gogh lived and worked. It still has much of that same charm that drew him there.

A mixed bag. Lots of people really like Montmartre, but my experience was mixed. Of course, you have to travel here to visit Sacre Coeur, which is lovely. However, the neighborhood around was a little sketchy with some beggars asking for money.

Absolutely must do!. Take the metro to the Blanche Stop. Enjoy the View and take pictures of the Moulin Rouge. Then do some exploring and start walking up the street to the right side of the Moulin Rouge. Continue uphill through the streets and see the wonderful village and the outdoor market and painters and artwork. A great way to spend the morning. Reach the church at the top and enjoy the amazing view. Worthwhile adventure.

Love it!. The atmosphere of this place is excellent. Love those narrow, beautiful streets and artists. The view from it is really amazing. Unfortunately it was very crowded, but you can't avoid it probably.

Montmartre. We spent a morning at Montmatre. It is busy, very touristy and appallingly scuffy in places (particularly at the bottom of the hill around Anvers) and the street sellers take something away from the experience. However, it still retains some of it's original charm and the place de tetre is a nice place to wander or sit and enjoy an overpriced coffee whilst people watching and looking at the artists.

Underwhelmed. It may have been the weather (rained during our entire trip), but we were underwhelmed by Montmartre. We walked from Moulin Rouge up the hill on lovely old streets, but I didn't see much that I cared to photograph. I hiked to the top of Sacre Coeur, and the views were interesting but not fabulous. If we visit Paris again in better weather, I'll probably visit Montmartre again, but we were both a bit disappointed compared with our expectations.

artists haven and mountain church. Espace Dali was really cool. the church was really breathtaking with its view of the city. food was good , get yourself drawn or painted for 20 bucks by a real artist . wish i had kinda, ...they told me i was making a regretful decision, when i said no
Sacre Coeur. Even on a drizzly day, the view from Sacre Coeur is stunning. Looking out over the rooftops of Paris can stir your soul. Always one of my favorite places.

No longer Bohemian.... Bustling area with lots of Street Artists trying to draw your portrait, for a variable fee, fortunately they were not too pushy. Cheap souvenir shops and expensive Cafes dominate the area, so it is not really very bohemian anymore. The lower part, one set of steps down, is much quieter and arguably more pleasant. A must visit in Paris but dont go in with too high an expectation.

Montmarte a magnificent site. A walking tour of this area is recommended. When you get to Montmarte you can catch a mini train which will take you around all the streets. A number of famous artists resided here Toulouse Lautrec, Picasso, Degas etc. The white Sacre Coeur church built near the top of the hill is absolutely glorious. It is a must to dine further up the side of the hill as there are many restaurants. Once again you can get to and from this area by the Metro train.

Favorite!. This was by far my favorite part of visiting Paris. Montmartre is such a unique little area, this is what I think of when I think of a Parisian street (thank you disney world). The little markets out on the narrow street, cobblestone, food everywhere. Beautiful area.

Still Wonderful!. We enjoyed walking around and having lunch in Montmartre the first time we came to Paris, so I wanted to share it with my stepmom and younger brother when they came out to visit us in Europe. It was raining pretty steadily, so I was afraid it wouldn't be as fun, but we still enjoyed it. Our backs got a little wet as we ate lunch in the big square (we were at the edge of the tent), and all of the smoking is unpleasant, but it's pretty much impossible to get away from the smoking anywhere in Europe. The artists were still out working, despite the rain. So, while I would recommend it more during clear skies, it works in the rain, too.

artist colony. If you want a caricature drawn, this is the place with so many talented artists. The area is quaint, old and very well preserved. Cafes abound and walking the hilly, narrow streets is an adventure.

Parisienne history coming alive. You haven't seen Paris if you have not been to Montmartre. We went VERY early in the morning, easily got into Sacre-Ceur and strolled down the hill. If it wouldn't be for the harassment of the "artists" on the way down it would be perfect. Really a historical piece of Paris and if you can beat the crowds you have a chance to enjoy it.
Lovely even on a rainy day. Truly what you envision Paris to look like. Enjoyed a lunch in the square of French onion soup and wine. Browsers the artist displays and visited the church.

Great Parisian atmosphere - loved staying in the Montmarte area. After previously staying in the 6th and 5th Arrondissments on previous trips, we really enjoyed our 10 day stay in an apartment in Montmarte. Accomodation was significantly cheaper in Montmarte, which we appreciated, but I actually enjoyed staying here more than in busy central paris. A village like atmosphere, with lovely local parks, good food, and the beautiful Sacre Couer on the hill, it was totally idyllic. We also got very fit with the many stairs and hills in this area - which was a bonus for us however if mobility is an issue, or if you have young children I wouldn't recommend staying in this area due to this, but for everyone else, it is a perfect Paris experience.

Montmartre the closest you'll be to God. Starting with the exquisite sacré cour this awe inspiring building is a iconic part of Paris with one one of the best views over Paris save from père la chaise. Go there for 11pm on a Sunday and attend the sung mass, directed by nuns, you are never closer to God in your heart. At the back of the basilica is the famed area of Montmartre with its intertwining streets, artisan shops and fairly good restaurants...be careful because this is a tourist trap. Watch where you park if you have your car,be careful of pickpockets and research the places to eat. However this is a MUST do on any bodies list.

Situated on Paris's highest point. The infamous hangout of famous artists like Picasso, Renoir, Degas and others. The whole area is overrun by tourists unfortunately but explore the little steep streets.

Touristy but still some good artists to be found here. A walk around Montmartre is to remember Toulouse-Lautrec and others. Today it is full of tourist shops and cafes. On Sunday there was a market where real artists display their work. Don't expect high art but you could pick up a nice oil painting for 45-60 euros.
So Romantic. What else would you expect from Paris? Winding streets, artists, cafes and a fabulously romantic atmosphere. A stunning location.
Very romantic and beautiful. Very beautiful places, nice bistros tho drink a glass of wine and relax. Great view of the city from the top.

Bohemian History. Ignore the people that so don't go because it is busy, dirty and crowded. This is a tourist area of Paris of course it is busy. But if you do your research before you go you can find quiet local squares and churches to visit. My advice just wander and soak it all in. Don't eat or drink in the main tourist areas, wander down an alley way and find out where the locals are eating.

Best memory of our trip.. We didn't know what to expect and headed there after a visit to Sacre Coeur. It was wonderful, first we walked a gauntlet of artists wanting to draw us, some were good, some not so much. We found an artist who's style we liked, however he was drawing another couple so we wandered further. Around the corner were 30-40 artists painting primarily land & city scapes, but all were very talented. We returned to our original artist in time to be drawn iin a unique and impessive style, and very suitable for framing! A great way to spend an afternoon!

Great town and beautiful Sacre-Coeur. The town was amazing - Montmarte is full of uphill cobbled streets and quirky shops. Be sure to wear comfortable shoes due to all the uphill walking - especially when climbing the steps to the Sacre-Coeur - there is a lift but the stairs are fine. There's gardens to relax at as well as taking the view in from the Sacre-Coeur itself which is brilliant!
Best for wandering the narrow streets. If you avoid the tourist traps near the Church at the top of the hill, it is the best! Loved just strolling around and musing over this beautiful area.

Lame, dirty, crowded.. People say this is a must see, but it was super crowded, dirty, and seemed to be full of hustlers and pickpockets. I would avoid it like the plague. It was supposed to be full of bohemian artists. I only saw one old lady paiting in a cafe.

So lovely & quaint. Loved Montmartre. SO much character, art, vibrancy, lovely cafes with friendly waiters / waitresses. After all the exploring, we had a lovely lunch, plenty of wine and was just happy to sit back and people watch in this gorgeous little gem of a place.

Great spot. Montmartre would always be on my to visit list for Paris. Plenty of bars, restaurants and cafes and close to the Sacre Cour and Pigalle. The area has a lot of atmosphere and is probably a bit cheaper than elsewhere

A mixed bag. Montmartre is located in the northern tier of the 9th a. and includes several distinct areas. The Moulin Rouge is located in Montmartre on one of Paris' seediest streets, lined with every kind of sex shop imaginable as well as numerous sex show houses. This is the red light district, to be avoided except maybe for the curious, who can safely take in the scene from the walkway along the street's center island. I must say that our favorite place for ribs in Paris is located directly across from the Moulin Rouge. This is the area served by the Pigalle metro station. To avoid this part of Montmartre, take the train one more stop, to Abbesses, and you will be rewarded with one of Paris' most delightful and spectacular areas. It has everything; steep winding streets lined with picturesque shops and restaurants, pretty churches, and the wonderful Butte Montmartre, with it's panoramic view of the city high on a hill topped with the iconic Sacre Cour Church. You can walk to the top or take the funicular for one metro ticket. It is on top where you will find Paris' foremost artist community, mostly evident in a square teeming with tourists and where the artists will gladly sketch your portrait, for a fee, of course. The same small square is shared by a dozen or so restaurants of varying quality. Overall, Montmartre is a varied and interesting part of Paris and should not be missed.

My favorite part of Paris!. We took a trip from London to Paris over a long weekend and thoroughly enjoyed it! The highlight of our trip was by far Montmartre. We found a suggested walk in our Lonely Planet which took us to all the places of interest. A must do!!

Montmarte. A wonderful place to visit and unable to resist paintings! Sacre Coeur is a superb place with fantastic atmosphere - see the talented acrobat outside on the steps with amazing control of football - even whilst climbing the lampost!

Nice and typical place. Really nice place in Paris, with a lot of street painters, art galleries, bistrots... and a lot of tourists. The visit to Sacre Cour is a must (while the climbing to the cupule is a "should" hehehe).

Many stairs. Much to see, and lots of stairs, this is the highest elevation in the city of Paris. However, start at the top and walk down. There is a funicular, just to the left of the entrance to the Bascilica. A small fee will get you up and down. The view of the entire city is fabulous. You won't see the Eiffel from here, unless you go to the left side of the Monte. Don't miss the artists' district. In the warmer months, the cafe's take over the square here. Walk the Pigalle area in the day time, just to say you did. There is a small vineyard, on a hillside. Many historic stops on each street. Don't skip the Moulin Rouge show, or Follies Bricharie for the Can Can. Tasteful Topless costumes. If you have seen Vegas shows, this is the real thing.

So much to see!. I kept coming back to this area - there was so much to see! Little churches and cafes, artists out on the street, lots of people watching! Be careful as there are a lot of pickpocketers in this area and when I was there, a group of deaf children would ask for money but this was a scam, also men try to put ribbons on your wrist and then take your money - however, if you just ignored them and kept walking there was usually no trouble. Also, I went back a few months later and I noticed there was a much stronger police presence. The Scare Coeur is beautiful if you have the chance try going at different times of the day as they have a singing service. A trip up the tower and into the crypt is well worth it.

My favorite part of the city. There is nothing I don't love about the winding, steep, and narrow roads that make up this area of Paris. There's so much history here (and windmills!) as well as new shops and restaurants. And, oh, the views! Montmartre absolutely stole my heart.
Watch your wallet. Beautiful place but terrible environment. Many pickpockets. Many guys wanting to tie something in your arm or hand and then take your money. Scarying. Don't go.

Charming Parisian neighborhood. Montmartre was very charming - Sacre Coeur, typical Parisian cafes, boutique shops and houses. From this hill you can see Eiffel tower far away and most of Paris. We walked around for couple of hours checking out the shops and residential areas. We had lunch at one of the many authentic French restaurants there. Overall awesome experience!

Prepared for the worst, but found nothing bad.. Having read all the reviews of the area on here, I was prepared for a pickpocketing hell hole. That's not what I found at all, what I did find was a very busy, very touristy place. The church itself was beautiful from the outside, but was too busy to venture inside. The streets were teeming with people, more so here than anywhere else in Paris.I know the lack of "shady characters" when I was there was probably down to nothing but luck, I did see quite a few police that day too. One thing I did notice was how ridiculous people were with their possessions. I saw people taking pictures with their iPads everywhere! It's never a good idea to wave your expensive gadgets around, especially something like a tablet.Overall, I wouldn't say Montmartre was a must see, it was far too busy to really enjoy the surroundings and get a feel for the place. Maybe a visit very early in the morning would change my mind?

So much vibe and atmosphere. The real Paris. Stayed in a great duplex off feeling paris website which I can't find on here. Was right on the main street but through a court yard. Close to metro which is very easy to use. Less than 500 metres from sacre cour and the artist markets. 10 min walk to moulin rouge. Thriving with atmosphere and fun. Very safe. Great little cafes away from the tourist trap. Loved it.

Favourite spot in Paris.. Fantastic bustling area to explore. Good walking shoes are a must to tackle all the stairs to the market square which is full of amazing French portrait artists. My daughter watched several, chose and was not disappointed with her pencil and charcoal sketch on grey paper. Stunning! The Basilica at the very top is well worth visiting and the views of Paris day and night are excellent. Ignore all the many souvenir market stalls as they are all the same, visit some of the little corner stores on the walk up and down and definitely have a meal in the market square where the waiters are dressed as 'very French' with waistcoats and caps. Montmartre is definitely worth visiting.

Great experience. Fab views from the top of the hill. Great to wander round and experience live art in the backstreets even if it is very, very busy. You'll struggle to get away from the vendors without buying one form of art! Great then to walk down through the streets into the city. Well worth a visit.

Loved our stay in this neighborhood. Montmartre is fabulous and we stayed at a hotel in this area. There are plenty of markets, shops, pâtisserie's, restaurant's and parks. Simply go to the market to pick up fresh bread, cheese, fruit and wine for a picnic in the local park. Stop by the corner café and belly up to the bar for an espresso or café crèam longue. There are Parisians everywhere going about their daily lives. Take it all in, embrace the life. The area we stayed in was very safe, however, looking at some reviews, there are some areas that are less desireable and use common sense when it comes to tourist areas like Moulin Rouge and Sacre Coeur as con artists and pickpockets may be present. There are several metro stations and buses in the area so map your route of things you want to see and pick the best station. Abbesses takes you right to the bottom of Sacre Coeur and you can head to Moulin Rouge or Sacre Coeur depending on which way you go. Be forewarned though, if you take the steps in this station, be ready for a long climb. There is an elevator that will take you up. Since you will be climbing up to Sacre Couer, might save you from some sore calves. Spend a day here or better yet, stay here and walk in the footsteps of the artists from many moons ago.

Achieved what I wanted to and more.. Our last few hours in Paris and what to see?. It was a hot,sunny day so we decided to arm ourselves with bottles of water and walk to the Montmatre district and take in the Sacre Coeur as well. I had long held a hope that one day I might walk up or down the famous steps of Montmatre(I am a hopeless romantic). I now have pictures to prove it, and although it was very busy my husband managed to get one of me on my own with the lamp lights.I had done some research prior to our trip(just in case) and was armed with a good map. As others have said once you leave the busy and vibrant,colourful area directly around the Basillica the streets become less crowded and you can see how old they are. I was amused to see better quality shops tucked in amongst less salubrious ones. There are lots of pavement cafes to choose from and many different cuisines.Yes it is a busy place but to me that adds to the attraction. You don't need to get caught up in all the cheap tourist tat that there is on offer, just have good shoes,water to drink, a good map and while away a few hours.
