Would not go on a Sunday-too crowded!. Everyone loves the place but I took my daughter on a Sunday and the crowds were so extreme, we could not get a sense of the ambience. I am sure it is fabulous but I would not go on a Sunday! Sacre Ceur was worth the trip and to me, more beautiful than Notre Dame. The streets looked adorable but with so many people, it took away the charm.
Fun fun fun. We loved exploring this little town! Sacre Coeur, Dali museum, the artists plaza, Moulin Rouge, etc. We printed off a walking tour and learned alot. It has a great atmosphere.
What a place!!. we had a wonderful time walking around and seeing the sights at time made even me blush!!! the atmosphere in the area was very lively and jovial

Also visit the back streets of Montmartre. On my first to Montmartre a few years ago I, probably like most people, concentrated on seeing Sacre Coeur and the adjacent areas. This time I also did a tour of the little streets where folk have lived for centuries. Here are schools and kindergartens, play areas, the remaining two of forty windmills, a tiny vineyard, St. Peter's church consecrated in 1147, the statue of the beheaded Patron Saint-Denis and the oldest street which dates from when it was a farming area. The varied housing shows the varied social mix in the area. You will also recognize streets and buildings painted by famous artists in the past.

An overcrowded must do. In case you did not realize it: Montmartre is NOT real Paris; it is a Parisian version of the Disneyland concept. Everything is artificial, but meant to be entertaining. This is one these places where you wish there would be no tourists; and then you realise you are one of them, and if there were none it would probably mean it is not worth a visit, etc... As a result, it is just a must when you are in Paris; however I would suggest you wander away in any direction from the heaving center, and you are likely to discover gems of authenticity and current Paris.

Pick Pocket Central--beware!!. Take heed! The warnings are real. I was there some time ago and lost my wallet within minutes upon arrival. They work in groups. One will usually distract you by being friendly and engaging while their accomplice pick your bag/wallet etc. Don't even try to report it to the police after. Its futile even if you speak French. Best to bring a some small change in your coin purse for coffee and cakes and leave all other valuables, passport etc locked up securely your hotel. Apart from that Montmarte is a great place to hang out!
Terrific. Starting from the metro walked to Le Bateau-Lavoir and ended at Moulin Rouge. Spend most of the day but well worth it and wonderful.

Interesting area, arbitrary venue whether to visit or not. We walked up from the opera district and took the funicular to sacre coeur. It's an impressive structure, able to look down over Paris. We went at around 2015; maybe the police have cleaned up the area but we were not troubled by scammers. Just the usual trinket sellers but not aggressively. We walked down to the moulin rouge and back to opera district. It was all pretty tame really, were invited into shows etc but low key compared to Amsterdam and Bangkok for instance. The church was nice with a couple of oddballs inside surreptitiously begging. Bottom line, why bother? There is superior architecture in the city and you know where there is sex on sale you are going to get clipped. It was a pleasant one off walk, nothing more

Warnings of pickpockets over-stated. Felt like we had to batten down the hatches before heading to Montmarte, and this was the only place I saw posted warnings of pickpockets. Thankfully, we enjoyed a beautiful day without incident or ever feeling too pestered.We rode the funicular up to Sacre Coeur, another of the city's beautiful bascilicas. Then wandered the streets down the hill, in search of the street artists we'd come to patronize. Alas, while we found many charming shops and cafes, we never spotted the artists we'd heard so much about. Ended up jumping on the little train to see if that would steer us in the right direction - and learned if we'd only walked around the SIDE of Sacre Coeur, they were there all along.Again, we never felt accosted and found some lovely original watercolors to take home. One peddler did try the bracelet scam, but a stern NO was all it took to get rid of him.Best shopping for us was at a ceramic studio on the top of the hill. Really gorgeous stuff, very reasonable priced.Don't be scared off. Tuck your money away and enjoy a day up that way. It's charming.

Really nice, but lots of beggars and street artists. Normally you have excellent views, sadly it was very misty the day we visited. We took the furnicular up as we both have bad knees and would not cope with the walk up the steps (even in my youth). My most practised french phrase on this day was "Non" due to the number of beggars and street artists. One argued with my wife because we wouldn't stop so he could draw my daughter. Worth the visit for the view and how most people think of Paris. Due to a miscalculation of where we were in comparison to the furnicular station at the top, we had to make a painful walk down the stairs. There's some good souvenier shops round here and they will haggle for a bargain.

Busy, but worth a visit. We visited Montmartre last year and I don't think there were as many aggressive peddlers and beggars this time. Last year we were accosted by a lot of young people (teenaged and early 20s); this year that didnt happen except for a few artists offering free sketches. There was also a group offering "free hugs" but they didn't bother individuals passing by. Be aware though, this is an extremely busy place (we were there on a Saturday) with the crowds so thick that it was hard to move or get close to the artists' stands. The Sacred Heart church was also packed, not to sit down, but people shuffled around the perimeter of the inside clockwise and then as a pack shuffled out. The steps were also very crowded, but it was a gorgeous day and I can inderstand why everyone was out...it's been cold and rainy and a beautiful day is cause for celebration. Montmartre is definitely worth a visit. We took the funiculaire up the mountain, for which you need a regular metro ticket. Also, should you arrive at the Abbesses metro stop, take the elevator up to the top, otherwise you will be climbing and climbing and climbing a lot of stairs!

Shops & sights. Although it was really busy, it's an experience not to be missed. Problems with 'artists' constantly pestering us to draw portraits, but some good stuff in the market and great little shops.

Lovely area for a walking tour!. We heeded the advice of many travelers and approached Montmartre from the Lamarck metro stop so as to completely avoid the aggressive scammers and pickpockets. We actually followed the route of a self-guided walking tour that I found online at Paris 48. I would recommend downloading a tour or taking an organized tour to get the most out of your walk - it's nice to know a little bit about the history of what you are seeing. We used the TA City Guide app to locate a cafe for lunch (we chose Le Consulat - nice people, good food). The only time we hit crowds was at the Basilica and the Place du Tertre - other than that, we had a lovely relaxing walk around this picturesque neighborhood! Note - We did finish our tour at the Moulin Rouge as some of our party wanted to see the famous landmark - those of you with children need to know that this area is one sex shop after the other with graphic items on display. My almost-18-year-old daughter was rather surprised and proceeded to tell her friends about it later - those of you with small children might want to avoid this area or be prepared to answer a lot of potentially uncomfortable questions.

Interesting little district. Had a wonderful time in the district. Ate some fresh maccorrons, that were to die for from a local store near the square adjcent to the Basilica. Lots of painters are roaming around.

Picturesque streets. Montmartre is a special district in Paris, and we had to pleasure of staying in a hotel located directly there so we got to stroll in these streets every night. Montmartre's gem is obviously the Sacre Couer cathedral, but spend time walking the streets below and getting lost there. Remember, Montmartre was home to a community of artists such as Dali, Picasso, van Gogh and Monet who found inspirations in its streets, cafes and cabarets.Lose the crowds, go to the quieter streets and enjoy the unique design of Montmartre. Try to allocate at the very least half a day to visit Montmartre and the Sacre Couer.

Nice afternoon. Very cool on a sunday late afternoon evening. We took the metro to the back side and walked the shorter distance up (lamerack stop) but realized later we could have done the normal way and there is a cable car to take you up the worst of the stairs for the fee of a metro ticket. Be warned the metro seems like its saving you the walk but then you have to walk up 122 stairs inside and the elevator wasn't working. There were musicians and guys doing tricks at the top by the church and people selling beers, tons of people just hanging out and relaxing. Although a bit of a younger crowd (under 30). Also stop in at the Maison Larnicol, coolest chocolate shop we spend a while just wandering around the store goes on forever.

Finding the Edith Piaf in you. This was one of the highlights while visiting Paris, i absolutely loved Montmartre for its arts, small streets, friendly people, mime artists full of color and creative ideas to earn a living. I could easily live here. While walking around and starring at the diversity of people, it started raining, but even with the wet shiny roads the place just looked more beautiful. Montmartre is a true escape from big cities and the ordinary. I am convinced we all have a little bit of art in us. I heard Edith's beautiful voice in my head, and i can just imagine her starting with her career on the street corners here... The little sparrow.

Where the Crowds Go. When you're in Paris, you have to see "La Butte" with the famous Sacré Coeur and the adjoining Artists' Quarter. It's a beautiful part of town but, naturally, extremely crowded. Try to go early in the morning. The restaurants closest to "Place du Tertre" are the most expensive. Only a few metres earlier or farther, they are more reasonable. Check the menu for prices before entering.At the foot of the stairs to Sacré Coeur, African peddlars have "friendship bracelets" for sale. Once they're slipped over your wrist you have to pay for them. It's best to walk past your hands in your pockets.

Get ready for climbing!. Get ready for climbing if you wanna visit Montmartre which you should. It is like a very small town isolated from other neighbourhoods with looonngg stairs and lively in the evenings with romantic restaurants. If you have others plans for evening go there in the morning because it is a little far from center compared to other attractions.

Buzzing. We stayed on Rue Lamarck in Monmarte for a week and loved the area. The winding streets, the architecture, the atmosphere, the cafes and bars, all add up to make this one of the most beguiling areas of Paris. It is steep and hilly in places (of course) and there are flights of steps to negotiate but well worth the effort. The Sacre Coeur is amazing (I will do a seperate review for it) and the views across Paris at day and night must be seen. The Eiffel Tower in the evening is stunning.Of course the area has it's share of tourist shops and catering for all restaurants, but where does not?A sunday morning in the area was full of locals shopping, patronizing cafes and it really felt like a community with atmosphere. A stroll down Rue des Abbesses, Rue Lepic and the surrounding streets was a treat.Much has been said on TP regarding hawkers, pickpockets and scam/con artists. As with any major city, be sensible: keep your wallet/valuables in an inside pocket, bags strapped acorss your body, be observant and just be assertive when dealing with any unsavory characters. We went out every evening in the area and encountered no problems at all.Loved it!

steep climb. i took the train to see the cathedral ,the area was very crowded,lots of stores and restaurants,i climb up the endless stairs to the top ,wow,i was out of breath but i made it to the top,the inside of cathedral was lovely,but the view of paris from outside the church was worth the long steps up,simply magnificent,i took the funicular down,low price stores abound in. areas of catherdral

Keep your eyes open to enjoy the view and avoid unpleasant situations!. Yes it's famous and another must-see in Paris but I am not convinced it totally worths it. It gets too crowded and as its a tourist magnet everybody is after your money, artists, painters (not necessarily talented ones), cafe shops and souvenir shops. We went on a relatively sunny Sunday so it was really busy but it wasn't that nice as what I expected. Too much fuzz...

Montmart. Try to allocate a half day visiting the Basilic of Sacre Coeur. It is easy to be there by the metro. The steps are not that difficult to go, but if you want there is the funicular. It is worthed to enter the Basilic and it s good to appreciate what is inside. There is the Holy Mass at particular times. I'm sure that at 11.00 am there is one celebrated. The view from there is nice and it is good to spend some time there enjoying it and taking pictures. One can also appreciate the talented people who play instruments. There are also quite a number of souvenir shops that make the visit more interesting. Some walking distance away, one finds himself in a total different atmosphere, I am referring to the Moulin Rouge. It is a must to go to Montmart and into the Basilic.

Quaint, Historical and Nice. We were earlier apprehensive about taking a walk tour at Montmarte. But having heard experiences of our friend , we decided to go ahead. It was an absolute delight to walk through to the top of the Hill with stories at every stage. Passed by the houses of Picasso, van gogh, etc, vine yard, small historical cabarets, windmills, beautiful houses, cobbled streets and what have you. We finally reached the top of the Hill for a breathtaking view of the entire City and to the Sacre De Cour. Do walk through the artists square to pick up a potrait if you want to. Was one of the better experiences in Paris combining a local flavour with history and sight seeing- would highly recommend taking a walk tour with one of the operators to make your visit worthwhile.

Fun place to dine and shop. I ended up going to this area 4 times during my trip. They have some great restaurants, plenty of snack food places and tons of shops. It was easy to get there by metro from wherever I was at.

Incredible History and What a View. Anyone travelling to Paris must do Montmartre. The Sacre Coeur Cathedral that graces the top of the hill stands out like a monument over paris. Home to many of the great artists it is a testimont of the architecture of the time. The views from the many vantage points around the cathedral are spectaclualr taking in most of Paris. We took a taxi from The Eiffel Tower district. This takes about 30 minutes and gives you a good insight into the outer areas of Paris. Travelling up the hill thru Pigalle is just Paris perfect. Tree lined streets with Paris boutiques and cafe's is just wonderful. Duringt he ascent to the top of the hill you take in the numerous stair cases that provide access to many levels of this picturesque town. We took the "Petit Train" ride back down the hill to Pigalle (about EUR 5.00 per head but well worth it) where we hopped off and walked the main strip. This is also home to Moulin Rouge but beware as the strip is full of strip places and adult stores (probably not good for the kids!). This was a great half day and one of many highlights of our 3 days in Paris.

Two Montmartres. A bit of two neighborhoods extending out from Sacre Coeur. The area in "front" of the cathedral, facing the Seine, was seedy, dirty and had trash all over - a full 12 inches deep piled in an abandoned store front. Sacre Coeur had chalked warning signs in bright pink alerting tourists where pickpockets hang out.Later we returned, going to the far side on the metro and the neighborhoods were much more quaint, had a scenic walk down Rue Caulaincourt. Rue Lepic was also a great walk - crowded - but had some great shops as well as the apartment where Van Gogh lived with his brother and the cafe from Amelie. Great views of steep stairways.Was a great way to spend some of the day, particularly when we got away from the SC and Place du Tertre.
cute village feel. Many, many shops with 'kitck' and souvenirs. Many artists selling pictures. Cute bistros and snack shops. Fun little area.

Magnificent view of Paris!. We climbed there in the afternoon and the humidity of December made the scenery as if it had come out of a fairy tale!If you think that you exercise enough, try to use the stairs. Otherwise there are other ways to go up the hill.
Favorite walk in Paris. Can seem a little touristy in places, but the side streets and little cafes are great. Be sure to go around the corner and see the Dali museum.
Beautiful views of city. Another must see in Paris - wear comfortable shoes as there is a great deal of stair climbing and hillls. The views rival those from the Arc and the Eiffel tower!

A break from the big city. We were in Montmartre during the last week of March/2013. It is a cool place with character. Enjoyed lunch under the tent, although the waiter was very elusive. The area has that historic feel to it and it is a nice departure from the big city below.

Everbody's favorite place in Paris. During my stay in Paris, I visited Monmartre several times. Initially, I would just go to the Sacre Coeur cathedral and lose myself in its charm. I would revel at the breath-taking view of Paris from there. One day, I joined a group of tourists on a walking tour of Monmatre and voila! a whole new fairy-tale place unveiled itself before my eyes. I saw so much in that one day! - the legendary pubs where legendary singers performed; the single vineyard that produces very bad wine, which is nevertheless celebrated every year; the former dwellings of celebrated artists (singers as well as painters); the bust of the singer Dalida; the writer stuck in a wall; places patronized by kings and queens; old windmills; artists sitting by the road and creating portraits and caricatures with equal expertise; Moulin Rouge; and oh! the wall of "I love you's" right beside the Metro station. Thereafter, I made several attempts to take another walk along the same route to relive the experience, but got distracted but new surprises at various nooks and corners of the narrow serpentine paths going uphill and downhill.

The land that Paris forgot. Twenty years back there were little kids there begging, now there are guys who actually start making a bracelet on your arm and then charge you for it if you can't get away before they finish. Montmartre is incredibly dirty, there is lots of graffiti and the main square has been spoilt by lots of cheap tourist shops and restaurant tents. It seems to have lost a lot of its charm. I would really not bother going there if pressed for time. Our trip was redeemed by the wonderful Studio28 independent cinema. There also seem to be a few good restaurants at the bottom of the hill. It could be lovely if it was cleaned up and a few policeman were sent there.

Horrible Place. Yes - the Cathedral is impressive and nice to see, but the people and surrounding area is horrible.I was charged 17 euros for 1 cup of tea and 2 crepes which were cold when they finally arrived at the table after 10 mins.Then i asked for my portrait to be done with my partner and the artist was awful - drew our heads at the top and bottom of the page even though we asked for a couples portrait! really hacked off after paying 35 euros - i should have refused payment but i think i was covered in guilt - being almost 50 euros down encouraged us to move on to the city at the bottom of the hill which was like a dodgy part of London - very inhospitable and my fiancee was scared to be there so we jumped on the metro and left - a very dirty and squalid place to be - filled with scammers and thieves

Step back in Time. Montmartre was the heart of artistic Paris in the late 1800's and early 1900's. The artists have all died or moved away, but the charm of Montmartre still exists. Sure there are plenty of tourists and tourist traps, but you can still find that old Parisian charm here. This area is a must visit for your stay in Paris. Tip: Begin your journey at the Anvers metro stop.

Quaint little area. Loved the Montmartre area. There is the Moulon Rouge, the statue of the man i the wall, the Sacre Coure church, the oldest windmill in Paris and of course the main area with quaint stores and artists painting in the square. The restaurants there however are tourist traps and you are best off not eating at one of them and going elsewhere to a better restaurant.

Exactly what Paris means to me. First of all, do not even think about not going. Second, don't get distracted by anyone, forget the entertainers and everything. Third, make sure you download Yann Tiersen's Le fabuleux destin d'Amelie Poulain soundtrack on your mp3 or iPod. Put your earphones on, go at sunset, walk around and daydream about the overwhelming history that took place where you are standing.

Beware. This is a hot bed for scammers, thieves and pickpockets. You're best off keeping away. Even the most savy of tourists lose out here. If you go, take the side routes up and down from abbesses station, the main bulk of thieves are in front of the basillica.
Recommended. If you go to paris this is a must see! Stay away from the scams. Even laugh at them. But a great view and it would be even more amazing on a clear day.

Tourist Trap Supreme. My husband and I visited Montmarte on the 25th March 2013, what a total tourist trap, the shops in the area sell all the same souvenirs that you can get all over Paris, the graffitti and rubbish in the area were very off putting. The area is full of hustlers, from some dude wanting to perform a magic trick by tying string on your finger ( when we refused the one actually grabbed my husbands arm) .. to the artists..who want to draw your portrait but refuse to give you the cost before hand , but tell you that you are under no obligation to buy ...yeah right!!!!!! the restaurants were dirty and cramped ... do not waste your time !!!!!!

Artists Galore and a Great Walking Tour. A wonderful village set on a hill with beautiful views of the city. The Sacre Coeur Basilica is breathtaking. There are street artists and portrait sketchers and winding streets to get lost in! Paris Walks did a nice walking tour for Montmarte.The tour is in English, inexpensive and no reservations are needed.

You need to choose the best day weather wise for this place. The day we went here was overcast and this then put a damper in the views you could appreciate, we could still see plenty but the pictures are not as good as they could have been. We did call into the church but as it was a Sunday and a service was in mid flow this felt wrong gong in, next time we will go on another day so we could look around properly.

More to Montmartre than a hill and a church!. A lot of people on here complaining about the security. Personally, I only encountered this around the funicular to and from the Sacre Coeur and so my advice would be to take care, show no interest and then enjoy the rest of the area. If you believe that visiting Montmarte is just to walk from metro and up to Sacre Coeur then I think you are missing out on one of the most atmospheric areas of Paris. All around the hill are gorgeous streets, with great views and dozens of eating and drinking establishments. And don't forget a visit to the cemetery!

Best New Year's Eve. I would recommend anyone to visit Montmartre (and Sacre Coeur too), if you're planning to visit Paris.We had a wonderful New Year's Eve at a nearby restaurant, then we went up the hill to watch the Eiffel Tower's Lights.

Bustling. Breezed through very quickly because we didn't have much time. My wife bought a Parisian hat. Lots of things going on, tons of places to eat and see, and will definitely spend at least half a day the next time we end up here.

Dont go alone. Nice views and some great street performers ...but the place feels so unsafe and would be (probably is ) a haven for pickpockets ... If you want a nice view with beggar's, crowds, trinket sellers, to be hassled by bracelet sellers on the steps or ripped off by a shonky card game this is the place for you . One point for the view and another for the cool soccer ball street performer ....Save your time and go to Jardin du Luxembourg or any other Notre Dame .......
beautiful scene. Would recommend to visit Montmartre (and Sacre Coeur as well) if you visited Paris.You can see beautiful scene from up hill.

STAY AWAY - not worth it!. You can get better views from the top of Notra Dame, the Eiffel Tour, or Montparnasse Tower WITH NO HASSEL! It is dangerous here! Don't go! Seriously it osnot worth pushing through 15 mean men who will pusj and elbow you. That's what they did to me. And the girls on the steps with clip boards try to gran your purse or pickpocket you! Stay away! Be afraid!

Oh Montmartre... Looking for the bohemian atmosphere in Paris.... don't go there at night..on daylight it's a definitely must-see of the city. Full of restaurants, bistros, sex shops ..... be aware of pickpockets.

A very special part of Paris. We went to Montmarte to visit one of our favorite bakeries/breakfast spots in Paris called Coquelicot on Rue des Abbesses. We would have walked around more after we went to Sacre Coeure but the snow hampered the walk so we went to our other favorite bekeries - Au Levain d"Antan, Le Grenier a Pain and Gontran Cherrier all a block from each other.

Thieves and pickpockets around Sacre Coeur. To reach Sacre Coeur you will saunter leisurely through the narrow streets crowded with tourists and street stalls but, be very careful of the thieves and pickpockets who work this area very successfully. You will be invited to play various betting games but you can't win because these are expert tricksters who work with plants in the crowd, no doubt relatives and associates sharing the profits. The church and views from the hill are spectacular and well worth a visit but just be very alert and careful when handing over money to vendors because where you place your wallet is being noted by gypsy elements who make a living robbing unsuspecting tourists.

Not Tourist friendly area. A lot of scammer here: nigerian/black people bracelet scammer guide every entry. Break them lose and you will be fine. Where are the security ? Very lousy. To let these guys hang here and the way they make money.

Tourist warning scam. In the bustling shopping lane adjoining the Sacre Couer are a number of lowlife three card monte swindlers. Working in small groups these thieves prey on unsuspecting tourists. The cleverly orchestrated scam lures the naive visitor into playing a rigged game they can never win. What is despicable is that the authorities tolerate this activity and allow these crooks to ply their 'trade' and rob tourists.It is bad for tourism and is robbing the French economy of tourist dollars which are ending up in the pockets of criminal syndicates. Visitors be warned - you are entering a lawless environment.
Best views in Paris. Always good to visit even when the weather is awful and there aren't many artists at work. The Sacre Couer is interesting too

If you have a mental "image" of Paris, this is what you're thinking.... Hilly, quaint part of Paris, with windy streets, lots of Bistro's, a Saturday artists gathering at the square...this is what we thought Paris would be like. The only negative was the "hustling" by artists by the church for a portraiture. When I politely declined, I was chided by one is a very condescending way...
Place du Tetre. Go there, sit in a cafe and watch all the activity, then go round and see all the amazing art work being created. Excellent way to spend the day.

Be sure to go to the top. First of all BEWARE OF THE NIGERIAN braclet scammers waiting to greet you. In a flash they will place a string around your wrist and proceed to make a "friendship braclet". After they are done they will try to extort money from you. I saw people giving them 5 Euro and they demanded 20!!! Stay away and dont let them grab your wrist. Anyway the church is beutiful and it is worthwhile to buy a 8 euro ticket to climb to the top.

A must visit in Paris.. Great place to slow down ur pace and stroll around the area. Enjoyed the scenary and admired paintings along the streets.Sat outside a coffeehouse opposite Moulin rouge and enjoy people watching.especially during winter.One of my fav plc in paris.

Arty Farty Atmosphere. Montmartre is not be missed when you visit Paris. Creative, bustling and unique with art around every turn and sloping street. It has seems teeming with tourists and locals, which is always a good sign. Plenty of interesting boutiques like Chine Machine have a great selection of vintage and chic fashion.The famous cobblestoned square of Place du Tertre really lives up to its reputation. I really loved the atmosphere and the variety of talent on display. Quirky street art, seriously funny caricatures, unbelievably accurate portraits and intricate representations of famous Parisian streets and attractions are some of the works of art that will distract and delight you while you carefully navigate around the crowds, easels and art equipment. My sister and I ended up having our caricatures done by a smooth talking artist. 2 of us in a drawing for 40Euros, seemed like a bargain until we realized the chap next to him was doing 2 for 25Euros. O well, next time we will know better.There are plenty of ways to get up to this place, some involving terribly steep slopes or steps including the the route we took which was from Abbesses Metro.

Quaint, Charming. A real experience of Paris.. Certainly worth spending an afternoon and evening in Montmartre. The Sacre Coueur basilica is amazing, a great place to watch the sun set over Paris. The food in the area is also great, and cheaper than elsewhere in central. A magical evening was had here.
wow. for me, the best part of Paris, you really don't want to miss that.Little restaurants, music, nice people on the hill with magnificent view on Paris...very calm

Dont miss Evensong at Sacre Coeur. A 'must see' attraction, this area of Paris with the most astounding views is much much more than Sacre Coeur itself although evensong sung by the nuns, especially on Fridays, will bring a tear to the hardest of hearts.Around the corner in the artists square with cafe bars and restaurants to sit in while watching the myriad painters, sketch artists at work, is a great place to spend your evening - unless of course you just want to watch as your loved one is drawn or painted.The smaller church much older than Sacre Coeur, St Peter Bassilica sits off the square and is a haven of peace and tranquility.Down the hill into Montmartre there are several eateries and drinkeries - try Le Frog and Rosbif for a cheap beer and curry, and on the right hand side at the bottom of the hillis one of the most amazing pattisseries - a work of art in the window made up of cakes, macaron, and other delights daily.

Place Emile Goudeau (Bateau Lavoir), Montmartre, Paris. "Relais de la Butte" on Place Emile Goudeau where Picasso used to live ("Bateau Lavoir") (Place Emile Goudeau is at the top of Rue Ravignan which is the first street going up on the right hand side after the Cocquelicot bakery, if you're coming from the Abbesses metro) has one of the best views of Montmartre and is sunny during the day and great for people watching !http://www.tripadvisor.co.uk/Restaurant_Review-g187147-d877268-Reviews-Relais_De_La_Butte-Paris_Ile_de_France.htmlAlso don't forget to stop by the little inconspicuous gallery at 58, rue des Trois Freres, just next to the "Collignon" cornershop/grocery store from the Amelie movie. It hosts surprising art showings of artists showing and selling thei affordable art. This week until 3 March: the young artist emma pauline www.emmapauline.com / www.galerie3f.comIf you can get a room (ask for a view) at the TIMHOTEL Montmartre, you are a very lucky person! One of the best romantic spots in Paris. www.timhotel.comAfter Place Emile Goudeau, walk on up and in stead of going to the Sacre Coeur, explore the North Side of Montmartre, around rue Girardon and then walk down to Lamarck-Caulaincourt / rue Caulaincourt, which is much less touristy than the Abbesses ans Place de Tertre areas.Enjoy!
While you're in Paris... ... You go up there to see the Sacre Coeur, in general, Montmartre is very busy, loads of tourist trap restaurants... A must see, but then again.. Not all that.
very pretty. great spot for a sunday walk..very pretty lovely little areathis is where all the men sell fake handbags if thats what you are looking forcheap shopsand some gorgeous restaurants

a not-miss----just rid the panderers, s'il vous plaît!!!. great views on easy climb...best maccaroons at 16 rue Norvins...funky artists...warm crowds...just hate the plethora of panhandlers in the streets/stairs as my enjoyment wans as i have to be on constant alert of my purse/camera/euro; still a must see on any paris trip....just be on alert

interesting and artsy. while I didn't really enjoy Sacre-Couer, once I walked over to the open-air art market and sat on a cafe patio watching the action I could see the appeal of this part of Paris. A little more funky than other parts, it has an energetic, youthful vibe. Buy a piece of art from a local vendor as a one-of-a-kind momento that will last a lifetime - I did!

My favorite place in Paris. If you have a bohemian heart, you must visit Montmartre. Take a basket with all things necessary for a picnic, and sit in the skirts of Le Sacre Coeur, to enjoy the city and have some wine and cheese.Then go for a walk around to admire the paintings of street artists. Beautiful.

On a Trail in Paris - Montmartre!. I had 5 days in Paris; the first 2 I spent travelling from Spain and on ‘must-see’ touristy attractions – the Eiffel tower, the Louvre museum, the shopping areas of Galeries Lafayette and Champs-Élysées, and then the remaining 3 exploring neighbourhoods. I was ready to agree that the City of Lights is indeed overrated at the end of our 2nd day; but the charm of Montmartre and the Latin Quarter (in another review) changed that. Where we stayed & how we travelled aroundWe rented a studio apartment on Rue Bobillot in the Gobelins neighbourhood (13th arrondisement), a suburb that’s about half an hour away from the city. There are 2 metro stops near where we stayed – Place d’Italie and Tolbiac. We bought a 3-day Paris Visite (about 20-plus Euro) pass that lets us shuttle between metro, busses and trains, primarily using the metro to travel. Metro rides are something that I enjoyed too in Paris, as it’s really easy and kind of fun to navigate around and you get to your destination fast! I recommend getting this pass if you’re planning to explore Paris on your own.Montmartre!Stopping at Chateau Rouge metro stop, we were at first taken aback by how crowded it was. But I guess, the trick when you’re travelling independently is to walk on like you know where you’re going (even if you don’t, like we didn’t most of the time!). We wandered for a bit, consulted our maps discreetly, and ventured into little shops selling unique souvenirs, before finding our way up to the Sacré-Cœur Basilica. This is the summit of Montmartre. As you can see from the picture, it is a vivacious neighbourhood bustling with activities! Walking down and about, the street curvatures lined with cafés and shops, I suddenly remembered that Montmartre is where the café featured in the French film Amelie is located! Map in hand and with the aid of Google on smart-phone, we traversed more curvatures, passing through Place du Tertre – a popular square with artists, asking shopkeepers for directions, walking down quieter residential lanes, to locate Rue de Lepic. It was a long walk down! We finally arrived at Café des Deux Moulins, where we enjoyed a nice dinner of Roast Chicken with Tarragon Sauce and Baby Potatoes each and shared a Crème Brulee! The food is good and the service staff friendly. After dinner, we walked further down to the nearest metro stop, Blanche. And there, diagonally across this metro stop is the infamous Moulin Rouge. We didn’t plan on finding it, we chanced upon it! I reckon this stretch is the sleazy area (what with ‘SEX’, ‘GIRLS’ and more ‘SEX’ plastered on window shops everywhere I turn to!) and so after a few shots of the Moulin Rouge, we made off. Blanche is your stop if you’d like to visit the Moulin Rouge and/or head up to the Café des Deux Moulins the shorter way.This was how we spent our 3rd day in Paris and this was when I started falling for the Parisian charm. One day, I will go back to explore more Parisian neighbourhoods.

Walk where the masters trod. Admittedly I was there in the winter but I was virtually alone on the streets and I did the climb to Sacre Coeur twice (I put my foot down when my visitor wanted to do it a third time). The streets are steep cobbled and fabulous. Sights around every corner and you really get a feel for how the Impressionists felt and why they painted small (humping canvas and easels up and down those streets is laborious). Yup I would love to visit here many more times. Once at Sacre Coeur it's all down hill from there so pay for the Funicular and walk down.
Wonderful. The most picturesque place of Paris, nice view from tha church of sacre coeur, and lovely squares with cafes, and artists drawing portraits(if ts not rainning). Dont loose this!!!
Such a good view of Paris, and lovely watching the artists work!. It was lovely, the view is amazing, and it was lovely sitting in a cafe, with a hot chocolate watching the artists work :)

Stereotypically Parisian, lovely. Didn't realise this area was so nice when I booked our accomodation, got really lucky. Little streets with patisseries and cafés, you definitely feel like you're in France. So romantic, lovely to walk in the day, very lovely at night towards Place de Clichy, which was good, our hostel/hotel was just far away enough to be easily reachable and yet out of earshot. Would highly recommend looking for accomodation in this area.

Always lively!. Watch the world go by in the square by taking a coffee in one of the many restaurants and cafes that surround it. Or simply walk around the various paintings on show by the many artists in situ or become a masterpiece yourself by posing for the many casual painters and sketchers on hand.

Impressive architecture !. The neighbourhood of Montmartre is resting. It doesn't feel like Paris. The street are paved, small and nice. Goind to the Sacré Coeur, you will also have a panoramic view of Paris. Don't take the elevator to go up, prefer walk in the small garden under the Sacré Coeur, you will have a nive view to take pictures of the Sacré Coeur.

Bring back the old Montmarte. I have visited many times and was a bit disappointed this time. It used to be such a great spot to have a coffee and watch the world and the artist but now they have added too much to the area and it is far too crowded. So crowded that the artists are not there like they used to be. It's not such an easy thing to get there so I was disappointed this time. May have just been the busy spring season.

Too crowded by the tourists. Nowadays Montmarte is just filled with tourists and locals have used to this - and respond with a rude attitude. Ok, but Sacre Coeur in the evening, sitting at the stairs looking for an amazing view and lisnetning to a trubadur is worth standing the other tourists :)

The most romantic part of Paris. The shops, the streets, the lights, the sights, the artists, its very beautiful. We drank 2 bottles of incredible wine on a restaurant just off the place where the painters meet, a place with a Piano and a guy playing Radiohead songs. (where in the world would you find that?) I asked my wife to marry me just behind the Saint-Chapelle church.If you are looking for the old Paris this is it.One tip, when we got there via metro we got down on the station near the Moulin Rouge (BTW DO NOT GO THERE, POOR POOR SHOW), and started to walk along Clichy Av which is loaded with sex shops and peep shows. I told my wife we were going to the mos romantic part of Paris and ended up walking past the sex street. Was good for a laugh but remember to go UP the hill to get to the real thing.

Village & Artistry like Atmosphere. I enjoyed my visit at Montmatre due to the nice village like atmosphere you feel here. First of all the Basilique du Sacre Coeur is a very nice chuch externally and internally with nice architecture. The visit to Eglise de St. Pierre was also pleasing which has a longer history when compared to Sacre Coeur. Between these two churches one finds a huge number of street artists asking to portrait you - I had no time but if you're interested, it takes a few mins a its not very expensive.The artistry aspect of the visit continues with the french singing lady in front of St. Pierre church leading to Place du Tetre where you can enjoy several artists selling their work and working on one of their peices in front of you. Once there you can several restaurants which offer french cuisine.Views from Montmatre are generally speaking nice but not outstanding. I would not personally visit the area for the views but rather more for the aspects I just mentioned. I would definitely recomend a visit here given it offers something that the rest of Paris (and many other cities) do not!

Super super touristic but somehow nice. Don't expect the things around you to be french or parisian, expect them to be there cause people like us (tourists) would like them to look this way. This area is very very visited by tourists and is in fact very nice to be an area that is so visited. Even parisians go to this place as "tourists". Nice restaurants and bars. Lots of private flats for rent and cheap hotels around. Go here and have a strole around and you'll find a nice place sooner or later.

Great views and some wonderful artists in action. We walked to the square at Montmartre which is full every day with a wide variety of artists displaying and selling their work and also doing portraits on the spot.Most of the paintings were of the local area and the most popular tourist sight of Paris particularly the Eiffel Tower and Arc du Triomphe. They were generally friendly, but they did not seem to be too keen to haggle.There are lots of cafes and gift shops and galleries and you have a wide selection of postcards in colour or black and white.
Enjoyed every minute. The tour we took, the beer at a cafe,people watching. Monmarte had it all. The artists were charming the girl on rhe accordian, i can't say enough good things about Monmatre.

A must.. A must see. Go here for the buzz and the chance to have your portrait painted. To feel the idea of the position of Montmartre walk from Gare St Lazaire up to the Montmartre Cemetry then up to the Moulin. Walk the coble streets and visit other attractions close by then up to Sacre Coeur.

Fantastic Place. Such a beautiful place to walk around. We downloaded a walking tour on the iPad and had a great tour of Montmartre. Little cobble stones and hills together with the beauty of the place made this a must see in Paris.
Great Atmosphere. I always enjoy the wander around here. I love watching the artists painting and the hustle and bustle of the streets

most romantic place in paris. this place should be visited. i visited during autumn and at christmas time. it is very nice with the christmas decoration. i like the fact it is on a hill and the view over paris is nice! it brings a good birds view. the artists on the place are worth visiting and you need to take your time because quality and price differs. very nice restaurant in the neighborhood and not really overpriced.

Amazing view - neat area. Don't miss the Sacre Coeur - don't miss the artists in the square - don't miss the musicians on the steps. What a neat little area of Paris tucked way out and way up on a hill. Worth the trip to see the whole city from the Sacre Couer. Just lovely!

Mont-marvellous. What do I like about Montmarte - what don't I like would be an easier question! The whole vibe is just fantastic from the beautiful Sacre Coeur to the artists who do a great caricature! If I were ten years younger (and had an ounce of creativity) I would live on the steps and paint to survive

If you are in Paris, you have to go here!. I went here my last evening in Paris. Monmartre, is gorgeous and truly a must see. Walking around you do not feel as though you are in a big city, yet instead, in a tiny village. It is a great place to wander around and people watch as well. If you need to do souvenir shopping, there are many places to buy nice gifts including prints and paintings (I found some for 1 euro each). When I think back on my trip, my time in Monmartre is one of my most fond memories.A word to the wise, there are pickpockets and people that try to do the bracelet scam. Just keep walking and pretend you don't understand what they are saying and you will be fine. Please do not let this deter you from coming here, it truly is a wonderful place to visit!!!

We had no Idea - make it part of your tour. When planning our trip to Paris, Montmartre was not on our list of things to see. We enjoy walking and discovering new things, and a walking tour of the Montmartre area showed up in a search. We are very glad it did.The walk from the Metro is a bit challenging as it is uphill all the way to the Cathedral but well worth it with an incredibly rewarding view of the city and its many landmarks. This is a very diverse part of Paris that seems to get little mention but we enjoyed it very much especially as our walk eventually took us to the infamous Moulin Rouge
art. walking around montmartre is funny with all the artist and paints around you. it is nice to have a pint for you as a sevioner of your paris trip

Amazing self-guided walking tour. My wife and I did the walking tour in Rick Steve's Paris guidebook. It was absolutely phenomenal and one of the highlights of our trip to Paris. The views from Sacre Coeur are amazing. Be very wary though of the guys trying to scam you with friendship bracelets at the base of Sacre Coeur. The atmosphere of Montmartre is so different from the rest of Paris. More artsy and laid back. Highly recommend this walking tour.

A must!!!. This was the first place in paris i visited and for me nothing topped it. The atmosphere walking through monmarte was unbeliebly welcoming. Every one so happy and having a laugh. Reached the sacre coeur and looked over the city. was a beautiful view! and a so much to take in. a must see!

WOW!. Loved the view, the restaurants, the wine, the people, just everything. Had the most wonderful waiter and he was SO friendly and not the least rude as some of the others we encountered. The street sales were fun. The steps were intimidating but well woth it!

Worth a visit. To tell you the truth in my mind Montmarte represented something different, an era that no longer exists and it is true that the "butte" as the Parisians call Montmarte has something romantic from the past. But you have to stroll yourself to the streets to find it while trying to avoid all the "touristics" shops selling countless souvenirs from Paris that have distroyed the atmosphere of this cultural neighbourhood. Walking to the main boulevard of Montmarte (de Clichy) you will only find sex shops and sex museums that terribly represent Montmarte now comparing to the past.

Favorite part of Paris. This was my first time to Paris but my fiancé third. She said Montmartre was her favorite part of Paris and I can see why. No, it's not what you maybe had envisioned after watching "Moulin Rouge", but its still a remarkable section of Paris which shouldn't be missed. There are some lovely street shops and cafes to be experienced. Not to mention the must see landmarks like the Basilique du Sacre Coeur and Moulin Rouge. We were there on New Years Eve and felt very safe and everyone was very accommodating of our lack of "parley-vous francais". The view from Sacre Coeur is arguably the best in Paris!
Very nice, romantic, but be aware. It is a true parisian place. Should not be missed, but be aware! Where there are many tourists, there are many people as well that want to take advantage of this.

Nice to visit. Visiting Sacre Coure is worth the trek but the real fun is watching the artists ply their skills - there are actually some older artists there that remember the good old days and are delightful in conversation...just have to take time to listen. Yes, there are tons of tourists and yes it is crowded but go early and beat the crowds. The Christmas booths were fun to visit and watching the children was really fun! We had a nice and friendly lunch at a small bistro on the square - lots of visitors but what can you expect? We usually use the back streets instead of the "main streets" so we accidentally found Hemingway's first apartment in Paris. Nice touch!

charming little town in the midst of paris!. we absolutely adored montmarte! it was so cold, we bought wool ponchos from one of the many vendors that lined the quaint streets. then we had a piping hot crepe cooked to order, and roamed through the art center-picking out some terrific pictures to take home with us. and sacre couer is the stunning center of this area. the view is terrific, and time seems to stand still in this little town. out of everything we did in paris, i think this was one of my favorite things.

Visit early in the morning. We visited early in the morning in Dec 2012, around 8 AM. The sun wasn't quite up yet and we took the funicular to the top at Sacre Coeur and watched the sun rise over the city. Beautiful views, but there are quite a few pan handlers and scammers in the area, even first thing the morning so be on the look out.

Area with cozy restaurants. We went there in late afternnon and it's getting dark. Nothing special, but an area to relax and have a chat with friends. We had very god food there, and went to the royal heart church..

Beautiful views, lots of character, must be visited. My partner and I stayed fairly near Blanche metro station which is at the bottom of Rue Lepic. Once you get over the tacky street by the Moulin Rouge (lots of sex shops which we chuckled at) and climb Rue Lepic up and round towards the Sacre Couer, you discover a different part of Paris. There's more character up in Monmartre, more variety in shops (although lots touristy) more variety of cafes, bistros, patisseries, boulangeries, etc, lots of stairs to climb but the view is worth it - and the Sacre Couer is beautiful. We found visiting this area in the evening our favourite, at night it's just as popular. Cute cobbled windy streets and lamposts line the way. The Sacre Coeur is open to go in, and the artists square is lovely. I did note some of the prices... Ouch... But who can put a price on art??The view of Paris is good but limited view of the Eiffel Tower (can only be seen from a certain point which got busy). If you want a better view the Montparnasse Tower can give you that.The downside of this area is the amount of beggars outside Sacre Couer. It's sad to see. At the bottom of the lift there were also a bunch of men who were extremely pushy in selling us something, and started physically pulling my boyfriend to one side to get him to buy. They're hard people to shake off so be wary. Rose sellers also v annoying!!! Didn't see any pickpocketing but just be careful as you would be any place that's busy. Overall this area was our favourite. We enjoyed the challenging hill climb, people watching, little bistros, shops and overall ambience of the area. Tres Paris!!

A taste of french culture. This is a great place to grab a bite yo eat, walk around and enjoy french culture. Great people watching in this "artsy" part of france. Visited in november, tge weather was crisp but not too cold to enjoy walking around in this area.

Incredible views of Paris.... If you take the metro to Montmartre and get off at Abbesses, take the elevator!!! It is one of the deepest metro stations in Paris. If you walk up you seem like you will never get to the top.Great place to have dinner and people watch, though the artists will interrupt your dinner quite often to see if you want a portrait....

New Years Eve in Montmatre. As the cost of most restaurants etc for NYE in Paris was very high and also many restaurants are closed we purchased a picnic and went up to the Sacre Cour in Montmartre. Unfortunately it was raining and windy so the beautiful service inside the church was a welcome surprise and shelter from the weather. It was extremely crowded but we did manage to find a space to look over the city. The view is beautiful. Unfortunately it is a "pickpockets" dream so be very careful that you keep hold of your wallets, phones. There were two incidents right by us and understandably some very upset people. These items were actually in their pockets and being lifted and handed on straight away so difficult to pin down the culprits. What was a great shame is there was not a main firework display. I had read several reviews before going and it was a mixed bag, some saying there are and others saying not. We could see a few in the distance but certainly no main one was visible. The Eiffel Tower was lit with beautiful gold and silver at midnight and as the law allows anyone can let off fireworks wherever they stand! I am sure in better weather it would have been more enjoyable but perhaps worth booking a meal in a restaurant nearby beforehand so at least you can sit in the warm until the magic hour.

great view but a tourist Trap for restaurants and Beggers. It is a great place for a lunch that you have brought with you for the steps of Sacre Coure. The beggars are relentless and more than bothersome. The restaurants are made for tourist with horrible fast food grade choices...

Very busy but enjoyable.. We had a few days in Paris post Xmas and spent most of our time walking to the sights as we were well located.As one would expect this area was heaving with people, as expected - but the Xmas stalls albeit some of them containing the usual tourist rubbish- gave a seasonal feeling despite the wet overcast weather.We had a sketch picture done of our kids, a price wasn't agreed before hand but our understanding was that if you don't like it walk away. Well we didn't like it - 15 minutes of work and he wanted 120 Euros. No way - it was poor and we told him so. He wasn't happy and got very aggressive. He wouldnt accept it back and insisted on being paid well we gave him 20 Euros and walked off. Be warned that there are some baddies out there, this one was called Antoine. Anyhow, we cast the issue aside and spent several hours wandering and enjoying the atmosphere - there are some fantastic artists and something to suit allm tastes. The 'TAT' shops are in every walk of life so just walk on by.

Montmartre / Pigalle experience Van Gogh and Toulouse' Paris. The tour through Montmartre exceeded my expectations. I expected a seedy side of Paris. Don't get me wrong, near the Moulin Rouge there are many vendors and shop owners peddling erotical. Deeper into Pigalle, the cobblestone roads, ivy laced buildings, artists shops are reminiscent of Van Gogh's years spent during the Bohemian Revolution. I would strongly suggest having a tour guide who is knowledgable to guide you through the ends and outs of this area. We did a walking tour, and without a guide would have missed details such as the apartment that Van Gogh lived in or the studio were Toulouse and other artists worked. Make sure you are physically able to handle the winding cobblestone roads and the hilly terrain. You will want to reach Sacre Coeur located at the highest peak of Paris. The view from there is breathtaking. There are some small trolley like trains to get you to the top if the walk is too much.

Wow, what a look into the Paris of old!. A trip up to Montmartre is an absolute must for anyone in Paris 3 or more days. To me, there are three separate components that make this place special.First is the Sacre Coeur Cathedral, which is simply amazing. The architecture and interior design are spectacular. It is definitely worth spending 30 minutes walking through.Next is the artist village and area atop the "mount" where you see how Paris likely looked even 80 years ago. The artist square has legit (and illegit) artists drawing personal and scene scapes. It's fun to watch them in action. The area is also nice to walk around. You can see some sights, like Toulouse Le'Trec's house and other features, as well as just stroll around a fun, vibrant series of streets.Lastly, is the area further down the mount, which is a bustling part of Paris. Lots of evening activity (including the famous moulin rouge) and shopping areas. This area is a bit "fringe" much like the east village was in New York City up to 10 years ago. Not all streets are nice and some seem a bit shady. But overall, it is a rich area with lots to see and do. There are also some excellent restaurants around here, including La Balancoire and Marguerite.Definitely carve out a few hours to spend time at Montmartre, ideally during the day but maybe also into the early evening.

Feels like the heart and soul of Paris. Montmartre seems like a step back into the 1800's, just with less artists, and more pickpockets. It is clear very early on, that there are A LOT of people selling bracelets from the street side. This proved a little intimidating to my Girlfriend, who was a bit shaken from this. However, once inside the main square of Montmartre, the art and photos were enchanting. Beware of scammers, but try and loook past people selling things, and take a look at the fantastic architecture.

Come Prepared & Enjoy!. Montmartre can be intimidating since it's far from central Paris, requires a metro ride; and once you are on the hills, the streets are twisty, narrow, confusing, and littered with scam artists. However, a visit to Paris wouldn't be complete without exploring Montmartre--a realm all its own, with art at its very soul. Everywhere you look, you will find art of all sorts and a charming atmosphere that can simply not be compared with any other spot on the planet. Just arrive prepared for climbing stairs, spotting scammers, and getting a little lost.When at Montmartre, visit Sacre Coeur, Saint Pierre, Place du Tertre, Dali Museum and the Moulins. Sacre Couer’s pure whiteness and delicate lace-like details are gorgeous miles away but better up-close; the interior pales in comparison to its exterior, but do pop in for a look. There's no entrance fee unless you visit the crypt or climb the dome. When finished visiting Sacre Couer, you might wander the top of the hill and enter nearby, much older Sainte Pierre church which is built on an ancient Roman temple to Mars (Montmartre is originally named after the Mount of Mars). Also nearby is Place du Tertre which is full of the artist stands and cafes that we often expect of Montmartre—charming although touristy. If you have time, visit the Dali Museum off Place du Tertre. You might want to wander then to find the last of the still-producing vineyards in Paris and the moulins (windmills) of Montmartre—Moulins de la Galette is on Rue Lepic and the more famous Moulin Rouge is beneath the hills of Montmartre, steps from the Blanche Metro stop.TIP: If you aren’t fond of climbing, then you can take the little tram that runs up the side of the stairs in front of Sacre Couer to access the church and the top of Montmartre. Also, you could always approach Montmartre from its backside. Get off at the Lamarck Metro stop rather than the more popular Abbesses stop. (Beware of Abbesses station since the climb out of the station is a HUGE trek, alone!) Take Lamarck Street until you see the back of Sacre Couer. You will climb a relatively short set of stairs, past a hidden Montmartre park. This approach is not only less crowded and less demanding on the legs, but it is also beautiful.

Artist Scam Courtesy of Valentino the 2nd Near Sacre Couer in Artists' Square By Mere Catherine. This is a lesson for anyone getting a portrait done at Monmartre. I'm sure most of the artists are honest and straightforward but this is what happened to me today. Just be aware of this "angle".Valentino the 2nd - that's what he calls himself - tells me that for two it will cost 140E but for one 80E. That's the catch. We begin here: I show him two photos: one of four people, one of two people. We agree the one of four isn't clear enough - the one of the two people is better. He then says "you want two for 140E or one for 80E?" I say "well, we agreed that you'd do the one photo - 80E". Okay - agreed. I come back two hours later.I go to hand Valentino the 2nd 80E and PRESTO! Voila! He says it's 140E. I say that's not what we agreed on and he takes out his little menu again and it says beside 80E "personne" meaning person. He argues that it costs 80E a face! I walk away - he's left with the sketch - which was quite good. After 40 minutes, I return and fall prey to the same scam anyone else would: how many times will you be in Paris? I pay and I go over to another artist. She sketches me for 50E.Be clear - VERY clear what you're paying for. I think this is a regular and routine scam and well - it didn't ruin my visit because I have the joy of spreading this trick to all of you - and this trickster's name. I doubt he'll be suing me under international law and I'll not be suing him in Parisien Artist's court!

Feel good place. The basilica de Sacre Coeur is situated up a flight of stairs. This offers a splendid view of the city. There is a provision to take the Funicular, but we preferred taking the stairs. Unfortunately we did not visit the bell tower. All around are streets filled with tourists and locals shopping for affordable souvenirs or gambling at the many stalls. On the stairs, you will see musicians or solo singers performing in front of a crowd. Look out for the band ‘Presteej’ for their foot tapping music, which will remain with you for a long time.The Place du Tertre is a colourful square where you will see people getting there portraits done or buying paintings. It has a very lively atmosphere to it, what with the jugglers and other entertainers performing.A good place to visit, although not exactly a must see. Would seem like the ideal place to relax for a few hours enjoying good music and good company.

Dream away for a couple of hours. This is one of my prefered places in Paris. I don't know how many times I've been to Paris, but Montmartre is a place to dream away. Let yourself go into the history of the city of Paris...dream away, and try to imagine how it was in the earlier days, and times. I very much love this place and it's hard for me to stay away every time I'm in Paris.....

Montmartre Paris 18th district / arrondissement PICK POCKETS AT LARGE. I should have posted this review sooner but when something unpleasant happens you try to put it out of your mind, don’t you? On this trip we did the requisite trip to Sacre Coeur because the day was clear and we knew the view would be spectacular. I started the walk up to the church ahead of my companions who were taking pictures. There were men selling Eiffel Tower key chains (5 for 1 euro). Having just pushed past the gauntlet of key chain sellers I was unprepared for the next falanx of petitioners with their sign up sheets and wailing ‘for the blind and deaf madame’. I could not move so could not avoid looking too long at the sheets - which I slowly perceived were rubbish - scribbles for names, no place for full addresses and - hidden by a thumb, a place to commit to a subscription of 10 euros. I finally pushed my way through. One companion, pointing out a site with her arm outstretched, found herself enwrapped by a string bracelet seller who demanded “10 - ok 2 euros madame”. Furious, she complied. Our other companion, happily and unconcerned carrying a two year old on his shoulders, found himself being patted down by a multitude of hands while the petitioners shoved their forms at him.I don’t like to advertise products, but when things work the way they are supposed to, I think it’s a good time to pass that message along.One of us had read Rick Steeves thoroughly so recognized the petitioners for what they were. Tilley clothes with velcro pockets, Merrill jackets with zipper pockets, Mountain Equipment Coop jackets with zippers and velcro everywhere and Baggelini purses that rest at the front with a multitude of zippers all work as they are supposed to.We needed all of that and luck. We were shaken by the experience, but the rest of our trip has been as lovely and joyful as this happy traveler could possibly wish.

The artistic part of Paris. Montmartre is the artistic part of Paris, but it's not quite as bohemian as I expected. Our main two attractions in this area were Sacre Coeur and The Museum of Salvador Dali. We worked our way up to the hill with the Funicular, which was a lovely experience. You'll face the annoying street vendors even before you enter the Funicular, and you'll meet a whole lot more when you get out from it at the top of the hill, below Sacre Coeur. We didn't show any interest to them, and passed them quickly, so they didn't really bother us. However, if it wasn't for the annoyance of the street vendors and their scams, I would rate this as an excellent attraction.Anyway, the views from the top of the Funicular are wonderful. Sacre Coeur is magnificient close-up. Pictures are not allowed inside it, which is understandable. Montmartre area is full of lovely, little streets. We walked through few of them on our way to Salvador Dali. On our way there, we passed the central square of art, where the artists are drawing and painting their works. It looked pretty artsy there.The street leading to Salvador Dali's Museum is beautiful. The Museum itself is amazing. I'm a huge fan of Dali. Thus, it meant a lot to me to see this place. Working our way down from the hillside was nice, going down a whole lot of stairs. We eventually came down to Moulin Rouge from our Montmartre trip.The area has lots of nice little cafes. Step inside one of them and have Crepes. We did, and enjoyed them a lot.

Romantic with beautiful views. Though Montmartre has lost some of its authentic artsy feel over the years, it's still one of the most romantic and charming places in Paris. The small streets play host to many artists (yes, many want to sell you a painting or paint your portrait), charming and reasonably priced restaurants and shopping opportunities aplenty. Even now, it is easy to see why artists flocked there to spark creativity. A long walk from the Sacre-Coeur down through Montmartre is wonderful and offers a lot of history as well as you can still see many former residences of great artists like Van Gogh and Toulouse Lautrec. This is certainly a must do for any visitor to Paris who hasn't gone before or anyone enjoying a romantic getaway. Beware of scam artists and pickpockets near the metro entrance and at the Sacre-Coeur.

Quintessential Paris. A must see while in Paris. The Sacre Couer is an amazing place and the surrounding neighborhood can be crowded but worth the hassle. Moulin Rouge is in same area...we did not go inside but felt the need to have at least a picture in front of this historic Paris landmark. Lots of street artists ans good creperies. Also great views of the city.

Victim of own success. Sacre Couer and hilltop location with views over Paris make this a must do. It`s also near Moulin Rouge. However, even in December the crowds were off putting, and the `looky looky` street vendors a pest. There is a square where the artists display and paint, but none of it is really authentic any more.

Magical place with great views. Magical place you will enjoy the view and if you are in Christmas time do not miss it :)Some hints to go there be sure you reach "Abbesses" Metro station and its so easy from there if you ask about Montmatre and to prepare your self you will climb high stairs so its not that quick easy visit unless you are athletic or used to stairs :)

Overrun. We were there only five years ago...but what happened? Same time of year but now so crowded with tourists, and people bugging you to buy stuff that it felt entirely 'over-touristed'. Only five years ago, at the same time, I could take a photo of my spouse on the street...now impossible with the crowds. Only five years ago were real shops and galleries but now replaced by t-shirt and souvenir shops. UGH.The only thing resembling 'real Montmartre' are the signs on the buildings that are above the touristy restaurants and trinket shops.

Montmartre - Art District. After being in Piazza Navona in Rome, we were disappointed in this art district but the food was the best price on our whole 2 week trip. Paintings didn't impress us much but it's worth walking around if you have lots of time on your hands

A great view of Paris. it's a must see place when in Paris! the view is nice and you can take a short break to enjoy on the steps overlooking the city. Just walk along the narrow streets arond the cathedral.
Look from above. On the skyline of Paris see the City, The white walls of Thelma church and the many tourists that always are around. Simply and cosy sunset.

romantic forever with little street. we went up there by motorbike at the back side.it so great for walking around and drinks hot wine.a little street around with shopping souvenir area and not too expensive same then another place in paris .some cafe is so great but one thing please check the price before order some coffee if you want to sit out side front of resturant .i love montmarte and enjoys very much there.but one thing is important please be careful who is wark near by metro and try to do business with you or try to come to asking you where you come from something like that.they try to get your money that special if you can't speak France.

The Real Paris. We went up the hill to see the Sacre Coeur (the short cable car ride is worth a try) and stumbled across the actual centre of Montmarte. Admittedly it was a bright sunny day but we had a lovely wander through the square with all the artists and had lunch at a side-walk cafe. We went back the next day and had brunch at a different cafe and both experiences were wonderful. Reasonable prices, great food with good service (English speaking waiter/waitresses). Perfect places, perfect experiences. Even enjoyed the souvenir shops!
Historic, artsy place.. Plenty of artists to chose from. Many nice places to eat. Take time to stroll the streets. Study up on the history before you go to totally enjoy the experience.

Insightful walking street. Always a great walk to be re-visited when in Paris. We followed the Frommer's Walking Streeting recommendation which took us about 2.5 hours bringing us to all the nooks and crevices of Montmartre. There were quaint little arts and craft shops, dotted with many souvenir nic-nac shops and artists soliciting for individual sketches of tourist. The highlight was the scenic landscape of Paris in front of Sacre-Coeur Basilica, the view was magnifique! As you wind down the streets, surprisingly you will pass by a vineyard which was grown out of nowhere on a small piece of land in between many Parisian-style houses. The hilly residential area will sometimes reveal beautiful street corners of houses overhang with evergreen groves and tiny little parks for rest. As we wind down the street, we also pass by the apartment that Vincent Van Gogh and his brother used to stay before stopping at one of the cafes for lunch and ending our walk at the huge Windmill ---- Moulin Rouge. Late summer with its cool weather is the best time for such a walk.

When in Paris, you have to visit this.... If only words could describe this place!Get down at Abbesses on Metro line 12, the moment you step out of the station, Montmartre would cast its spell on you! Though most of Paris has its old world charm but this is something different. Atop a hill, the idyllic, rustic setting of this district, in my eyes is what truly sketches out the real Paris. Take the funicular up to Basilique du Sacré-Coeur. In front, you'll get a chance to see artists performing some unique acts, sing and the likes...Sit on the stairs and be a part of the show while simultaneously enjoying a spectacular view of Paris! It really is breathtaking. I enjoyed it more than being at the Eiffel Tower.Don't just limit your visit to Sacré-Coeur. Go around the baslilica, into the winding streets and soak in, the atmosphere. Blessed are those who live there. The houses are beautiful, painted in pastel colors...It's just amazing! Walk your way down to the metro station.Once there, the area is dotted with cafes, bakeries, restaurants and souvenir shops. Pick one and enjoy!

An experience. Going to 'la butte' is great, but make sure you also go beyond the basilique du Sacré-Coeur and the Place du Tertre. Montmartre starts after those 2 attractions. Push further to the Musée de Montmartre, the Lapin Agile, the only vineyard of Paris, the Moulin de la Galette, la Maison Rose, the staircases next to the funiculaire and just lose yourself in the small streets. You can almost smell the lilacs ;-)

Parisien Bomhemia thats right up my street!!!. I adore the whole bohemian feeling of this place!!! Steeped in history!!! With places such as the Sacre Coeur Basilica and the Moulin Rouge!!! This bustling place is overflowing with gorgeous little shops (some are a little racy) the people are friendly for the most part though I think you'd be trampled in the pursuit of a bargain!!! Be careful at night here as the pickpockets are rife (hold on tight to your bag/purse/wallet) though on the whole this is a jovial place that is rich with culture and is weirdly sophisticated!!!

Nice place to visit. Such a nice area of Paris many little streets that sell millions of different things. At the top of Montmartre is the Sacre Coeur, a beautiful church which has some of the best views in Paris as it is the highest point. Well worth a visit.Watch out for the street vendors, they are very persistent and some of they may even grab you ( this happened to me). You just have to be really firm with them and tell them no and keep walking, just dont stop.

Relaxing , romantic and interesting. Montmartre is a great place, the highest point in Paris . It's quite different from the rest of Paris. Winding streets , old small buildings, plenty of small shops and bakeries galore. A lot of small restaurants and of course famous cabaret le Moulin Rouge are located there too. Montmartre is supposed to be the neighborhood of artists. You can spend several hours here just walking around and watching the Artists fill the Place du Tertre. The Sacré Coeur Church is very impressive. There are an awful lot of steps up from it , but it is worth ! There is a fantastic view of Paris.Montmartre is everything I imagined Paris to be. I will go back there again if I have opportunity.

vivid area. When visiting Paris I definately recommend this area. The area is lively and nice. You can take the lift up to Sacre Cour the beautiful huge white church. From there you see the immense Paris. Around the area there is very much small bistros and selling of art and handicrafts. They also have some very cliseish "pariensiens" around in costumes. But the actual view and the athmosphere is nice.

nice walk. The transition from Paris as designed by Haussmann to older winding streets and smaller buildings makes this a good walk. There are plenty of small restaurants as the hill gets steeper, with even more at the top of the "mountain". On Saturday it was a mecca for young folk who enjoyed listening to a singer with guitar on the steps below Sacre Coeur. The view is not as colorful as looking down on Florence, but it is interesting to see the expanse and contours of the city spread out below. A funicular covers the last bit of the climb - or you can take stairs. Be sure to wander around the church and the streets at the top. Just be careful to come down the same side of the mountain as you went up.

Very touristy. A tad over commercialized, but still enjoyable. The Sacred heart church is well worth a visit and the views are spectacular. We visited the Moulin Rouge which was an experience in itself,

Montmartre - 3rd time here. As always, Montmartre does not disappoint you. A great little village.....lots of shops and restaurants and bakeries galore. Some people are mentioning to avoid the Abbesses metro because of the stairs........I guess they never found the elevator which eliminates those nasty stairs. Lamarck metro also has an elevator......look around people. When you get off a metro, always look for the signs for an elevator or escalator. They are there in the ones which have a million steps! And others too.And don't miss Rue Lepic......for an absolute beautiful area .... Full of restaurants and shops.The tourist souvenir shops are mainly around Sacre Coeur. Be brave! Venture off on the side streets!Bon chance!

Great for exploring. We loved exploring this town, from the cemetery at one end, to the markets and quaint little souvenir stores, to specialised food stalls and cafes, to churches, to open air art markets, to more shops and pubs. You can walk the whole town and not be bored - an easily lose track of time.

Fantastic view. Montmartre is a great place to go to for a fantastic view of Paris, you can either walk up lots of steps to reach the top or you can opt for a tram which traverses the hill diagonally, if you want to get to the top you will have to walk up some stairs so those of you who struggle with steps may have trouble as I could not see another way to access the top.Beware there are lot of people trying to sell you things (i.e caricatures etc) and peddle to you and you have to be a bit stern to get rid of them unless you want to buy something you don't need or want but generally this place is quite safe.There are several café's and an artists market which is very beautiful and then there's the view which is stunning. We took a picnic up with us and ate it on the steps overlooking the whole of Paris.This is a free (except the tram) and is a great place to see if you are visiting Paris, just beware of the pedlars and you have a great time like we did.

Love it, love it, love it!!!. Montmartre is the oldest village in Paris and is just lovely! Lots of winding streets, lots of stairs, lovely cafes and even though there are lots of gift shops and stalls it doesn't seem over-touristy.Defintely take the "petit train de Montmartre" and the "funiculaire" just keep an eye on your bag in the crowded areas. Gorgeous views of Paris from the "Sacre Coeur" and it's free!
