Awesome area but watch out for pick pocketers!. Montmatre is definitely worth walking around as it's quite different from the rest of Paris. Really enjoyed the cute little cafes however watch out for pick pocketers (especially the gypsy kids) as they do come up to your table and distract you and take your stuff!

Montmatre. France is a very unfriendly country but, Montmatre is fantastic. Nice coffee shops, bistros, restaurants and plenty sightseeing. Easy and fantastic metro and rail system. Fresh( pain) baguette all over the place. The fantastic fruit and veg available on every corner. I would go back there again given the opportunity.

Well worth the visit for the views but a bit trippery. You can either walk the streets to the top to see the amazing view of Paris or cheat by going up in the funicular- great fun for kids. Sacre Coeur is a beautiful catholic church and a worthy place to light a candle for a loved one. There are plenty of cafes and restuarants and Artists fill the Place du Tertre. Lovely but a bit over run with tourist souveniers.

a place worth visiting.. Montmartre is a place to be visited. You have to get the feeling of the place by walking through the alleys of this place and go up and down the hill, see the small vineyard , it is really a Parisian village. The Sacré Coeur Church is very impressive also and if you have time, it is worth going to mass at 10pm. Do not stay too long on the Place du Tertre which can be extremely disappointing as it is filled with too many tourists. Instead, walk the streets of the "village" as I suggested above.

Fabulous!!. From Sacre Coeur to the tiny winding streets loaded with cafes and restaurants and painters- this part of Paris is just fab. If you love watching painters paint, or buying freshly painted art, or enjoying a delicious meal with a great view, go here. You cannot go wrong. The streets are just adorable. Must-see while in Paris.

Great part of Paris. If you arrive at Abesses metro station, be warned! There are an awful lot of steps up from it! But the trek is worth it! I love the hustle and bustle of the area and the fact that Sacre Coeur is often just visible. Walking up the steps to Sacre Coeur is busy and monotonous, but going up via the side streets is much more interesting as there are lots of shops to look at and detours to make, such as to see the vineyard and the au Lapin Agile nightclub. The Place du Tertre, although crowded is always fascinating, I love looking at the artists and their work.

One of the nicest part of Paris. It may have something of the tourist trap, but Montmartre somehow managed to retain its typical Parisian atmosphere. Many painters had their studios there (some of them now part of the Musée de Montmartre), and of course famous cabarets such as le Moulin Rouge and le Chat Noir were located there too. Plenty of nice restaurants and small shops to enjoy.
a must do. go here to see the real paris quaint streets and artists galore plus the sacre coeur which has the best views of paris from it's dome

live like a parisian. We stayed for a week in Montmartre, on Rue Caulaincourt, and it was the most beautiful, convenient and pleasant location! Streets throughout are picturesque, relatively quiet, easily walked, and full of grocery stores, specialist stores selling pattisseries, cheeses, small goods, fruit and vegetables etc, pharmacies and cafes. We were 40m from the metro station and went everywhere. The Marie d'Issy line is very frequent, safe and a lot,more pleasant than some other metro lines we used. I always felt safe on the metro - even in the evening on my own.All the people we spoke to were friendly and helpful, formal but very willing to assist when needed and we were always trying our best to speak in our basic French. Really, we knew only 5 or 10 key phrases and we were hardly ever caught out (when it did happen, just apologise - in French - that you don't speak the language and people will invariably assist in english).

A 'must see' district in Paris. We spent the best part of a day visiting the beautiful Montmartre. It is relaxed, interesting, vibrant and well worth the trip for the views of Paris alone, but there is so much more. Shopping, cafes local modest original art and crafts and the lovely Sacre Coeur basilica are all worth climbing the hill to visit.
A feel for Paris. When you are in Montmartre area you feel like Amelie Poulain in the movie!! Love the atmosphere you find there!!

nice place to relax. Montmartre (French pronunciation: [mɔ̃.maʁtʁ]) is a hill in the north of Paris, France. It is 130 metres high and gives its name to the surrounding district, in the 18th arrondissement, a part of the Right Bank. Montmartre is primarily known for the white-domed Basilica of the Sacré Cœur on its summit and as a nightclub district. The other, older, church on the hill is Saint Pierre de Montmartre, which claims to be the location at which the Jesuit order of priests was founded. Many artists had studios or worked around the community of Montmartre such as Salvador Dalí, Amedeo Modigliani, Claude Monet, Piet Mondrian, Pablo Picasso and Vincent van Gogh. Montmartre is also the setting for several hit films. This site is served by metro line 2 stations of Anvers, Pigalle and Blanche and the line 12 stations of Pigalle, Abbesses, Lamarck - Caulaincourt and Jules Joffrin.Montmartre big area in Paris in good location for eat cakesand drink coffee.excellent night life if you are looking for nightlife.
typical french village. montmartre look like a village, place du tertre is nice, lot of painters, i bought one painting 20 euros instead of 40, gret discount if you ask

Slightly disappointing visit.. Montmartre is supposed to be the neighborhood of artists. It seemed somewhat touristy and crowded. You get there by riding a "funeiul" (forgive my spelling) or walking up a lot of stairs. Our visit was hampered by rain, so this might be better on a clear day when one can enjoy the view.
So busy *May 2011. Maybe May is a bad time to visit. Montmatre was so busy it was difficult to move, literally crammed. Difficult to see anything or relax at all. Worst day of holiday.

What Paris is all about. We walked from the top where the little square has all the artists merrily painting down to the cemetery at the bottom. This is how you imagine old Paris to be, tiny winding streets with nick nack shops, restaurants and tree lined avenues. Plenty of people sitting in the Autumn sunshine having a glass or two of wine and eating moules and frites. Incidentally we never saw any hawkers or street pedlars at all.

Great family day. This is a great day for all ages and groups in Paris. A quick tube ride takes you to Blanche station. This exits opposite the Moulin Rouge. We went on a Free Walking Tour which meets here as there is only one exit from Blanche metro. Grab a coffee, not Starbucks, try a French one and head up the hill. Take your time to explore the side streets. The Free walking Tour took 90 minutes at stop start slow pace with an excellent guide on the way. We had kids (3,9 and 12) with us and they enjoyed walk. At top enjoy the view. We went to main square and enjoyed a wonderful, reasonably priced, lunch. For 60 euro we had the 3 kids drawn by one of the many artist in the square. Small hint, watch them draw for 5 min before you choose who is going to draw. Very touristy but still a wonderful experience. 3 year old feel asleep while being drawn and we had to hold his head up, most amusing. A nice slow trip down the hill with an ice cream topped off an excellent day. There is a cable car but walk is nice

Not was I expected, but still worth a visit. Moulin Rouge is my favorite movie, so of course I had to visit Montmartre. It wasn't what I expected, but it was definately well worth the visit. If you're going, it's best to devote most of a day to it. There's a lot of amazing restaurants (I couldn't find it on here, but Le Cave des Abbesses is awesome for wine and appetizers), art by original artists displayed, etc. The sites are definately interesting...Make sure to visit the Montmartre museum (not sure if that's the name...). Also, bring your camera...The view from the top is AWESOME!

old paris'. This is what I thought all Paris should look like, old and cozy, cobblestone, beautiful church and village with shops, art work, great restaurants, must visit, in the vicinity of moulin rouge, but we took a small trolley (train) to top of hill and walked down or else it's a long flight up. will definately enjoy - go around 7 and walk and eat and shop!

It's what old Paris is all about.... The highest point in Paris, Montmartre is beautiful. Small cobblestone streets, artists, restaurants, etc. You can spend several hours here just casually walking around, looking at the local art, eating in the outdoor cafe's, etc. At the bottom of Montmartre is the famous Moulan Rouche but between the top of the hill and the bottom are great shops and cafe's. Truly a unique section of Paris.
Amazing. A must go when in paris amazing views of city! BUT watch for pick pockets in the area, No photos allowed inside which is a shame cause beautiful inside, get the cable car up if you need to.

I love it.... I expected a lot from Montmartre,knowing history of that part of Paris,and I was not disappointed.Some people says that is not as it was 20-30 years ago,but it is something you can expect.Some says it is too touristy,and I do not understand that.We are talking of world¨s top tourist city.I found Montmartre very charming and very Parisian.You can start with Sacre Coeur basilica,which is great,and then wander through that bohemian part of Paris.Charming streets,full of people,cafes,shops,artists...something you should not miss.Go to the Place du Tertre to see artists doing some portraits,have a drink or meal,and visit Pigalle with all that sex shops and night clubs,including a famous Moulin Rouge.For us,it was a fun.We walked down the neighbourhood and stopped in front of A la Pomponnette where some older guys and girls were dancing on the street,accompanied with some guy singing some chansons.We made a great video there.If you are in Paris,even just for 2-3 days,do not miss the Montmartre...
Incredible. We got up early in the morning and heading to Montmarte. The tiny street and shops you might forget you are still in Paris and think you are in another french city. Love it

Must see but.... We came to the artists quarter 25 years ago and this place as changed so much. It's very commercial now and you can't see the artwork from the crowds, what a pity. It has last it's soul. But don't be put off, its still well worth seeing.

Paris. All you expect from Paris can be found in Montmartre. History, witth the Basilique du Sacré Coeur and the small buildings and roads around it. Art,street art at place des artistes, cafès and nightlife, sometimes flirting with the limits of decency in Pigalle. Romance and everything you came to Paris for.

Great area - glad we ignored the negative reviews. We took the dark blue (#12) metro to the Anvers station and headed uphill from there. Shortly, we hit the funicular on the left and rode up the hill. Once on top, we took a right directly to the beautiful Sacre-Coeur Basiliaca. After viewing both the cathedral interior and the immense panorama of Paris below from it's steps, we walked the small alley toward the Place de Tertre where artists abound much like in the days of Van Gough, Gaughan and many others who lived in this virtual artist colony. We stopped for lunch inside one of the cafes rather than under the canopies on the square since the weather was nippy but still could view the activities on the square.After browsing the area along Rue Norvins and others, we headed down Rue Ravignon, bobbing and weaving down the hill past the Jean-Baptiste Clement House, the patio at TimHotel, the St Jean-de-Montmarte cathedral, and other interesting attractions. We ended up on Boulevard de Clinchy at a cafe sipping coffee across from the Pigalle metro station before our return to the hotel.We both thoroughly enjoyed our wandering through this historic, Bohemian area of artists and cafes with the fabulous views of Paris. There is no doubt that we will return to Montmarte again.

Magical. What a beautiful day we had here! One of my favorite days in LIFE> we enjoyed a glass of wine while people watching... shared a beautiful meal... did every little touristy thing we could possible imagine... ate some more... and some more... bought beautiful art... and even shared champagne while oggling the views. Perfection. A must for anyone visiting Paris!

Proper Paris?. I went to Paris to mainly see Montmartre. I realise this may be the subject of debate, but, for me, Montmartre is everything I imagined Paris to be. Small winding cobbled streets, a bakery on every corner, artists on the streets.. I loved every minute of it. Even though people say it has become more touristy than it used to be, it is still worth a visit. We walked all around the streets, up the hill and to the moulin rouge. At no point did we feel unsafe.

Dirty and commercialized. I suppose Montmarte was too much reality for me. Being on Holiday, I was looking to do fun, beautiful things. Montmarte has too much graffiti and too many closed businesses for me to give it better than an average rating. The Cemetery was absolutely wonderful and was the one thing that made the trek out to worth it.

You've got to hook this one off.. You can't come home from Paris and say "Montmarte - no we didn't see that - is that any good?" Good or no good - this is is a must to see. The stairs leading to the church was for us more interesting than the church it self. A lot of people sitting and listening ti various artist playing beautiful music, watching the breathtaking views or just enjoying themselves.After visiting the church, take right and go to the back of the church. There are several very nice lunch restaurants that we really enjoyed. The artists walking around in traditional outfits are no longer poor and authentic (as we judged it), but you can cope.

Tourists Galore - Not the Real Paris. After walking for over an hour to get here, we're were disappointed to see how commercialized this area has become. The town square is packed with sketch artists and food vendors. While the scenery is cool over the city, both the Eiffel Tower and Arc de Triomphe have much better city views.With all the classy venues paris has to offer, spend your time elsewhere.

Incredible view of Paris from this beautiful Cathedral. We rode the Metro here (the Paris Metro is the only way to get around in Paris) and toured the Cathedral and enjoyed the amazing views of Paris from the front side of the Cathedral. After our tour, we went to the side & back of the Cathedral and discovered that there was an artist's gathering going on, where one could purchase or just admire, a great deal of painters and paintings.The area where the painters were gathered, also had snacks, wine and other drinks for sale, so we were able to extend our stay there, without having to be pondering where to eat.Parking is tight in this area, so I would not suggest that anyone drive there, the Metro is barely 2 blocks away !
Put on your walking shoes. You can easily spend a day strollong around the streets of Montmarte but when you finally make it to the top if will be well worth your time.

Remarkable landscape.. Great landscape, seeing from below. Also from above.
The Catedral is great, but Montmartre isn't behind.

Must go to Montmartre. we went to Montmartre the first day we arrived in Paris, it was a lovely day of august and the information at the metro station tell us to go to the abessess station which not very closed to the hill, you have to walk about 15 min to arrive. A very beautiful church with a very large viwe of Paris, up of the hill to the left you will find some cafe and souvenirs boutiques and some bad artists: me and my friend choose 2 artists to paint our 2 daughters (each paint at 15 euro) but they was awful we didn't take them.At the front of the church there is a beautiful white train who take u at 8 euro in a nice tour around the hill.

it is nice but that's all. Montmarte has a great view at night especially if you stay somewhere closeby.The place is full of people (especially tourists) on weekends which makes it a target for pickpocketing and street vendors. Some of these vendors can be very cheeky as well!Try to visit the place during the week if you have a long time in Paris and go around and about, visit little ice-cream shops and coffees.

So-so. We visited Montmarte recently and were somewhat disappointed. First, it was a Sunday, so all the tourists were there. Second, the pick pockets were abundant, spoiling the experience. Who wants to relax and take in the view of Paris while guarding against being robbed. We didn't spend much time there because of all the people and the chance that we might be victims of thieves. Think twice about spending time getting in and out of there, as you can see it from various other places in Paris. Guess I'm not really into rooftop views of cities either.

You will see the other side of Paris. I was in a business trip in London. I did my job in a few days so i went to Paris by the express train in 2 hours and 50 mnts. Because of my very short tome, I went Montmartre. It's very close to the downtown, you just take a direct train to there in a 15 mnt you will reach. It's on a highland so you will see Paris with very nice view. You will find a lots of painting and art works wherever you are. You will find in the intrence of the church a very nice and small train to have a quick city tour in a 15 mnts.

Left our hearts in Montmartre!. Can't begin to describe how much my husband and I loved Montmartre when we went to Paris recently for our honeymoon. We only had 7 days in Paris but ended up going to Montmartre twice - that is how much we enjoyed it. The first time we went was a nice sunny day. We took Line 2 on the Metro to the Abbesses stop and walked from there to the Funiculaire, which takes you up the steep hill to the base of the Basilisque du Sacre Coeur. The view from the grounds of the church is incredible, one of the best in Paris. We also took pictures of the church but did not enter that day as it was very busy. Just beware of the many "vendors" on the steps up to the church that will try to sell you cheap trinkets/knockoff purses/pieces of thread to tie to your wrist. Don't even say anything, just walk by them.After seeing the grounds of the church, my husband and I went wandering in search of Place du Tertre, which is a famous area in Montmartre for street artists and performers. It was amazing! The streets are all cobblestone (so beautiful!) and full of old buildings. Although there are many touristy souvenir shops and galleries in the area closest to Sacre-Coeur, if you keep walking past that area there are more unique shops and restaurants. Some that stick out in particular are La Galette des Moulins (patisserie with the most amazing strawberry tarts and eclairs I've ever had), La Biscuiterie de Montmartre (amazing macarons and biscuits), and Galerie D'Art (handmade pottery store). The two sweet shops are located on Rue Norvins and the pottery store is located on Rue des Saules. It is so worth the time to spend your day wandering the streets and immersing yourself in the area that famous artists such as Van Gogh, Toulouse-Lautrec, Renoir, Dali etc. lived and worked. My husband and I both agreed that Montmartre most closely matched our romanticized idea of what Paris would be like. Not sure if this matters to anyone, but we were surprised to find that so many people in Montmartre spoke English so well, as it seemed to be the least touristy area we went to.After spending the afternoon there, we headed far down Rue Lepic (where Van Gogh used to live!) and towards Rue de Clichy, where the Moulin Rouge is. It was something I have always wanted to see but it honestly wasn't worth the long walk - it's in Pigalle, which is the area below the Butte Montmartre. Very seedy and sketchy neighbourhood filled with sex shops and strip clubs. Whatever magic it may have had in its heyday it has lost now. I think this must be the area that people in these reveiws are discussing when they say they didn't like Montmartre. As long as you avoid this area (unless you're desperate to see Moulin Rouge) then I don't see what's not to love about Montmartre!The second day we went up there, we actually walked up the steps to Montmartre instead of taking the Funiculaire. They were made famous by a Hungarian photographer who took an amazing picture of them. We also got the chance to walk around the grounds of Sacre-Coeur without being bothered by vendors, as it was pouring rain and I guess they decided not to be out in it. We also got the opportunity to go inside Sacre-Coeur this time and it was beautiful. We spent the day wandering through the cobblestone streets in the rain and loved every minute of it - one of the most romantic days of my life.If we were to ever go to Paris again, we would stay in Montmartre. It was truly incredible and I recommend taking at least a day or two to head up there and experience it for yourself!

loved this area!. It's quite a hike up all the steps to the highest point in Paris--and once we were at the top we discovered we could have taken a tram! the view is spectacular! the whole city of Paris is laid out before you. We also had some entertainment. A young man had climbed a light pole and was doing some amazing moves up high to music with only his hands and feet connecting him to the pole.We were at the bottom of the stairs to Sacre Coeur and there were a lot of people sitting on the steps (most likely resting after the strenuous climb up the steps!We walked back down along streets full of shops and cafes. The sun was setting and we were hungry so we found a cafe that looked appealing and enjoyed the Marais shoppers while we enjoyed a glass of wine and dinner.

Absolutely stunning!. Montmatre for me was simply the best in every way. Stunning building, stunning views, stunning surroundings. There was also a typical little French village with a square where artists were painting and music was playing. Absolutely stunning. Can't wait to see it again!

Region of some awesome celebrities. I've been to Montmartre this summer and I have to say, it's a cool, more or less quiet place. People are nice, and there are a couple of attractions you can check out like the Basilique Sacre-Coeur. And Moulin Rouge on Pigalle.What's cool about Montmartre is that it's the place where you can find cool celebrities. They usually like to live there. Like Vanessa Paradis (Johnny Depp's ex-wife, and singer) for example. And I met Vincent Cassel (Irreversible and Black Swan) there.All together, I really liked it. And it's close to a lot of other cool places in Paris.

the most romantic place. loved the area,loved the view,loved everything. even though is upper so you have to almost climp to the montmartre,for sure deserves it. i enjoyed so much a coffee,i had a walk and i visited the famous church.

Obviously a neat place to visit, but basically a massive tourist-zone. Of course many people come here to say that they came here. And for many, that makes it worth the trip. You can wander up & down streets and get some nice photos of the neighbourhood with Paris stretched out below you.However, just know that this is not what it was. And if you're looking for a taste of that bohemian atmosphere, it's pretty much been replaced with souvenir shops and street vendors.TIP: if you want cheaper souvenirs, walk down the street toward the Moulin Rouge. It's maybe a 10 minute walk and the souvenirs get cheaper the further you go down the street.Also, many Parisians told me to watch my pockets in Montmartre, so please do the same. It can get crowded and some of the street vendors here are quite bold. I saw them take total strangers by the arm to get their attention....and once they're in that close to you it woudn't be easy to slip into your bags, etc.

Can't wait tot go back. We spent a half hour on packaged tour and I feel cheated that I couldn't stay longer. This is the type of place that you could spend all day in this area. There is so much to see and do. The shops, restaurants and Sacre Coeur make this visit well worth it. I can't wait to go back so that I can see what I missed.

Overcrowded, dirty and a waste of time. Avoid. When we arrived around lunch time there was no single space to squeeze and take a picture. Place was so overcrowded nd taken over by the dodgy souvenirs sellers, cheap entertainers and other tourist harassers! Broken glass everywhere, cars parked at each side of the road! Not the place you want o visit . Perhaps visit first thing in the morning would be recommended.

Good view of Paris but not the best. So we came here on a long subway ride, hoping we will get a panorama view of Paris but to my disappointment, we didn't. We couldn't even see Eiffel Tower or Arc de Triumphe from the Church. There are a lot of people just hanging around the church and on the lawn nearby. The nearby area is full of souvenir shops and coffee shops so it has turned quite touristy already. You can get off at the Absess Stop and take a short lift to go to the top and just walk down so you are not exhausted from climbing. Another thing to be aware of is there will be locals trying to force a bracelet on you. Do not let them do it because you will have to pay for it.

A brilliant part of Paris. Almost like a village in the heart of the city, Montmartre has its own atmosphere. Wander away from the tourist hotspots (Place du Tertre) and there are wonderful small shops, cafes, bistrots etc. Visit the excellent Musee du Montmartre to get an idea of the history of the area, and some of the characters who lived there.

Parisian village ambience with flair. Montmartre has more positives than negatives , the chief negative being the tourist traps which are obvious and best avoided. The charms of Montmartre are many and not to be missed. Lets begin at the top of the Butte, reached by funiculaire and with a marvellous view of Paris. The beautiful Basilique du Sacre Coeur and Eglise St. Pierre nearby. The many reminders of great artists who lived and died here -- where they lived, worked, loved, drank, laughed and died. Many are buried at the Cimetiere du Montmartre.The narrow, winding cobblestone streets, and numerous steps leading you up and down the Butte. The squares and gardens and windmills and museums and vineyards, scattered hither and tither.The cabarets , grand ( Moulin Rouge ) , old ( Lapin Agile ) and otherwise. Place Pigalle and the surrounding district. Place Blanche which reminds one of Amelie. Place des Abbesses with its charming square , Belle Epoque Metro station and Carrousel.The tempting artisanal boulangeries , award winning patisseries , boucheries and fromageries and eateries of all types -- you will be spoiled for choice.It's all there and its genuine. These are real people leading real lives in an atmospheric village in the heart of Paris. There's no other place quite like it. I would go there a million times -- and learn enough about the area to ensure I avoid the not- so- genuine tourist traps.

Love. I like it in the rain. You have to go to the top of the hill for sure ...It made me want to sing a french song in a french accent. It would be a great place to go with your lover. You could sit up there and kiss. Then walk arm and arm down the cobble stone street. The Eiffle tower sparkling through the grape vines on the wrought Iron fence. I think it is my favorite spot in Paris. Montmartre is the place I try to go every day or night when I am there. There was also a health food store across from Van Goghs place , that had the best Wheat Free baguettes . So you do not have to miss out if you are on a wheat free diet.

Yes, go to Montmartre. We did this on our last day and almost didn't have time for it. Really a must see. Go ahead and hike up all of those steps to Sacre Coeur if you can make it to see the basilica. Great views atop the city. The only other spot for views like this is the L'Tour Eiffel. Walk around the surrounding streets to Sacre Coeur. You will find small gardens to walk in and great places to stop for a snack. We got here in the afternoon and really enjoyed ourselves. **Watch out for performers or shady people on the big steps. I thought my mom had held on to my arm while walking up, it was about 10 seconds later I realized it was a man in a mask sneaking around holding on to me.

Beautiful!. This place is simply beautiful! Perfect place for my hubby & I to celebrate our 20th anniversary. Some reviews we read said it was a major tourist trap, however, I find that was not the case at all. The shops had lots of choices & reasonably priced, The view, well you have to see it to believe it - its a "must see" if you're planning a visit to Paris!

Great place to visit but watch where you eat!. Montmartre is a great walking area and filled with interesting people and things to buy. Although I know it's a tourist area I had the WORST crepe in my life (and I'm American!) at Chez Eugene. It was like eating a hot pocket - chewy and overall horrible! And the service wasn't much better.

Worth the Trip. Montmarte is a short trip on the very convenient Metro from hotel Dauphine St Germaine. Line 4 then 2 very easy to navigate your way ther. Once there lots on offer including the moulin Rouge other windmills, Van Goghs house and shops and the basilica on the hill. Do go.

The real Paris?. As you ascend the funicular ( well you could walk but I didn't) to the top of the hill not only do you have the dome of Sacre Couer above you but stunnig views of Paris below you. All those sites you've visited are now laid out like a Paris from the air photo. It had drizzled a little that morning and so as we emerged from the art nouveau metro station the cobbles were highlighted with a wet sheen and a strong aroma of garlic escaped from one of the bars. The little shops were full of tempting goodies, vintage clothes, covetable bags and shoes, amazing lamp shades and home accessories. After the grandeur of the Louvre, the splendour of the Champs Elysees this was paris on small town scale. It was all the books I'd read brought to life. Go, enjoy.

Spent hours here - and could have stayed longer. This area is amazing. The streets are fascinating, as are the artists. Wandered aimlessly, watched several artists working and purchased one drawing of Sacre Coeur. Good food and atmosphere, despite the crowds. Stop by during the week instead of on the weekend.

Love it! .. not sure why. I guess it's just one of those places, unique and atmospheric. There's a choice of routes to the top from the tube.. take the street on the left, and theres a meandering series of steps through the fairground or the 'fennicular (?) steep train thing. The right hand street leads to about a million steps and a few kebab shops. Go left and follow the crowd!The view is a big part of the attraction. It must have been used in a thousand films, and explains why this place is so busy at sunset. Then there's the courtyard which has local artists queing up to paint your picture, either normally or as a charicature. Loads of Restaurants and pavement cafes all doing pretty much the same thing. Like many places though, being there is fine, but it's when you look back you realise how nice a place is. We'd never go to Paris again without visiting Montmarte and would recommend you do too.If you're reading this review because you've been there and are using other peoples views to reminiss (we all do) watch the film 'Amelie' if you haven't already.

Montmartre unforgettable!. Came here the 2nd time this year. Got a little lost looking for our way to Montmarte but manage to find it in the end. The view here is very nice, you can see the whole Paris city view from there. There are always some street performers there. This time when I was there, there was a musician playing harp making the whole visit more perfect! If you have the time & energy I suggest you to climb up the dome. Around 234 spiralling steps lead you to the basilica’s dome. The journey was unforgettable and the view was spectacular. It is worth every steps. Most important the queue to get up was clear compare to Notre Dame.

A Victim of it's Success?. The character of Place du Tetre has changed completely....Mammon has taken over and the artists stances are crowded out by the greedy restaurateurs! No accordionists to be seen or heard . So sad to see a wonderful place SPOILT! Ditto Sacre Coeur .....unfettered tawdriness with no regulation of hawkers. BUT the Basilica and view can never be diminished! Still worth a visit.

Beautiful but touristy . Great views of Paris and sitting on the church steps whilst relaxing and listening to a street artist was a highlight for me. Top part is full of same-old, same-old gift shops and people offering to do do our portrait. Wondering the lower streets is a much nicer experience.

Mixed bag--plenty of charm in the least touristy areas. I came here in the 1980s for the first time and was eager to return and show my husband and teenage son. Either I romanticized my memories--or the place has changed considerably.We spent a night walking around. I was no longer impressed by the Place du Tertre, it seems like there are more restaurants now than artists, very sad. The Moulin Rouge looked neglected and only partially lit and the Pigalle area is simply disgusting all around.However, we enjoyed our visit to the steps in front of the Sacre Coeur church--certainly touristy, but still magical with a great view of the city and several musicians performing. We then some of the "back streets", away from most of the tourists and found some charming restaurants and galleries and views that looked picture perfect--exactly as you imagine Paris to be. If you go, make sure to venture "off the beaten path" or you may end up disappointed.
Dreamy. Loved it, like being in Funny Face with Audrey Hepburn. Very picturesque and authentic!Well worth a look!

Montmartre for me!. Montmartre was a high-light of my Paris experience. All the comments on this site are accurate - very touristy, crowded with some high pressure rip-off men at the Sacre Coeur steps. But Still - I loved the bohemian atmosphere - I can see why the artists used to hang out here. The steep crooked little streets that hide treasures at every turn. Rue St. Vincent immortalized by the Yves Montand song - I wandered around the St Vincent cemetery enchanted by the elaborate memorials. We ate our lunch in the front garden of the oldest cabaret in Montmartre - the Lapin Agile (we did not know this at the time - we just thought it was a lovely little house with an open front garden). Rested on a bench in a divine little park with a memorial to A Steinlen (the Le Chat Noir artist). There is something exciting and relevant at every turn. All presided over by the ever-present Sacre Coeur basilica which seems to spring into view at the most unexpected moments. If I ever return to Paris, this will be my first stop.

Fun to Visit. Would go back to Montmartre in a heartbeat. Just walking through this offbeat town was so much fun. Had late lunch at a little restaurant called La Maison Rose. Food was excellent and the service was sweet and attentive. Lots of cute shops to investigate.

Disappointing Very Touristy Area. Having heard so much about Montmartre, we were extremely eager to see it during my family's recent week long stay in Paris. Unfortunately it turned out to be the most disappointing, perhaps the only disappointing, part of our trip. it was crowded, extremely touristy and somewhat tawdry. Sacre Coeur was very nice, though with so many beautiful cathedrals to visit in Paris, it is not worth making the trip to Montmartre to see this one.

Montmartre and the locality. We were taken aback by the view and beauty of the place. On the way up to the sacre coeur (which is a steep climb up stairs) we noticed a distinct culture change within the city to a more artisan style, on reaching the place of worship there is a mix of tourists, worshipers and tradesmen who have no shame in trying to flog you water, beer or cheap nick knacks (a bit annoying) but it was a great atmosphere with a singer doing a set on the stairs. We enjoyed a beer in one of the bars on the way down which was cheaper than the extortion of the champs Ã©lysÃ©es. Overall a must for any visit to Paris.

i like this place. one of my favorite places in paris lots of things to do and to see small streets and sacre coeur and moulin rouge and a little dali museum and all the people painting and a good view over paris

Run down and badly managed. Montmartre was an area of Paris my husband was keen to show me when we visited recently, on holiday. He had many happy memories of his previous visit there, many years ago. When we arrived, the area seemed rather tacky. We took the funicular, which is not really necessary as the walk is quite short up the steep hill. Sacre Coer was very beautiful and the view over Paris breathtaking if not a little overwhelming with its sea of buildings seemingly going on forever and with so little green. But a spectacular sight. When we got to the little square where the artists used to be, we found that it was largely occupied by a group of eateries that had been set up there in a makeshift camp for the summer and the artists were crowding on the pavement and the little space left for them. The eateries looked very unappealing, dirty and depressing, with few patrons. And such a pity that this area had been taken over by the eateries when it was famous for the art and artists it used to be known for. It all had a tawdry mass touristic atmosphere that was disappointing and very off-putting. Walking back down from Montmartre to the metro we were unimpressed by the dirt and decay all around us despite some picturesque little houses and flats. It all appeared very seedy and all we wanted to do was leave. What a shame for what should be one of Paris' attractions. I would not recommend it to anyone. It was our only disappointment in Paris.

Lovely views but not the best in the city, rather seedy neighborhood.. Montmarte is a great place from which to glimpse views of the city, but the views are not more spectacular than those you get on top of the Eiffel tower, and it is quite a bit out of the way for most tourists. There is a great map of Montmarte that you can get for free in the airport tourist information center which points out the attractions of the quaint, cobbled streets around this part of the city. They include an outdoor city square filled with artists selling their paintings, two windmills, a museum dedicated to Dali, and, perhaps, most famously after the Sacre Coeur church, the Moulin Rouge cabaret. Don't bother with the little car that takes you up a bit of the mountain to the view; you can easily take a train that gets you closer to the church and views without paying for the funicular. A caveat: The neighborhood is not very nice. It seems rather overrun with indigent people trying to sell things or beg, and though the absolute center of the area is filled with tourists and feels very safe, some stations near the area don't feel safe. Bathrooms are at the foot of the Sacre Coeur church. They are clean and free, but the people who clean them request donations at the end.

Lovely walk up the hill! One of Paris' best!. Definitely one of the highlights of our trip to Paris! We took the metro to Pigalle and followed a Frommers walking tour up the hill (free directions from their website). As always, read the directions for a general path and then go wherever your heart (and interests) take you. We have breakfast at a little cafe on the way up the hill (GREAT!), and took in Place des Abesses, the Boat Washhouse sqaure (there was an old man playing the accordeon, made my day) and we really enjoyed the laid back atmosphere. Once you get closer to Sacre Coeur it gets VERY touristy, lots of shops, restaurants, etc. I say the closer you are to the church, the more likely the places are a rip-off.

Montmarte - a must visit. Montmarte’s surrounding place has a lot to see, the gardens, the cobbled streets. The basilica on hill-top is beautiful. The best way to get there is on the funicular railway otherwise its a couple of hundred steps. Be sure to take in the breathtaking view of Paris as its the 2nd highest place.There are Black people who try to sell small things. Just ignore them politely.The walk on the cobbled streets is a must, though they are crowded. Do not lure yourself into street gambling, which you would find in every street.
bohemian. nice area in the daytime with lots of great priced shops, but not for kids at night as many of the shops on the main drag are very adult.

Lovely place to visit. Nice neighbourhood to stay in when visiting Paris. Lively area with plenty of attractions, museums, restaurants and shops. Nice atmosphere, and felt like a very safe area. Pretty crowded, particularly around the Place de Tertre and the Sacre Coeur, but still possible to get the feel of the more authentic Montmartre area if you step away from the more touristy streets.

Only if you have time and ONLY to see the basilica!. Maybe if you have some time then you can go there but only for a quick walk.I didn't like the atmosphere in this area at all. The basilica is beautiful (and there's a nice view on the city in the basilica area) but that's it! the shops and restaurants area is only for tourists, i didn't like it at all and nothing special to do there in my opinion.

Montmartre. Don't miss the "Love Wall" behind Abbesses Metro Stop. It is in a little garden. I Love You is written on tiles in 133 languages. A nice way to take a break and sit on a bench trying to find "I Love You" in your language.
lovely atmosphere. j aime Paris, a lot of tourists, the food is excellent - you have to find the places, all restaurants are not good. Pigalle without my wife

A Must of Paris. I visited this area almost 50 years ago and to my surprise it has hardly changed. The best way to get there is on the finicular railway otherwise its a couple of hundred steps. The street artists are here mingled in with many good price restaurants. Paris is exspensive but up here there are good deals. Be sure to take in the view of Paris as its the 2nd highest place. Hopefully it will be a clear day. A good time to visit is in the afternoon as several hours are needed and then take in Dinner.
Beautiful place. this place has a lot to see, the gardens, the streets, the VIEW! awesome view of all paris! really beautiful, dont miss it! its quite impressive.
more tourist than art. We enjoyed Sacre Coeur and then walked the area. Some shops, some cafes, some artist, but the tons of tourists certainly kill the mood.

Loved it!!. I wasnt aware that this was supposed to be the seediest part of Paris. Really??? I thought that it was one of the nicer places. This area felt very safe. It is filled with coffe shops and restuarants and bakeries. This is where the sacred basilica church is , and is very much a must see area when in Paris!! There ar Black people who try and shake your hand so that tey can place a friendship ring on your finger and sell it to you for 2 euros. Just dont shake anyones hands and you will be fine!!

Lots to eat and see. Not a lot to do during the day apart from see the Sacre Couer but livens up at night. It is not the seedy place I was lead to believe. There are many traditional French restaurants to try and the famous Moulin Rouge (beware: It is expensive at 100euro for a show). We had many an amazing meal here and enjoyed the bohemian attitude of the locals.

Cute and quaint area.. This was a really fun place to walk around. We took the Rick Steves' walking tour of this place. Actually we got lost from the directions in his book but met up with another couple doing the same tour, and we finished up with them. We loved this are.

Creative environment and loads of fun!. Artists, great shops, silhouette artists, mimes, so much to see with a flavor all of its own. If you decide to get a face portrait, visit the artists in the artists row rather than those hawking on the streets holding a tablet. Far more superior and offering the same price.

Artistic, inspirational Parisian area. This is one of my favourite areas to walk around and grab a cafe or vin. It's where famous artists such as Picasso, who used to hang out, spend time drawing, painting and also like Edith Piaf who would hang out here too, many times, singing on the street corner hoping to make ends meet before she was discovered. A truly enchanting area to visit and walk around. My tip, find a cute place to have a street crepe and walk around. You can always sit down just for a beer or glass of wine.
Old Paris. We spent a lovely Sunday afternoon here..crowded, but a nice afternoon...get off the main streets...lovely artists..fun to watch them work.

Hustle and Bustle. I saved this as the last activity in Paris. I was afraid my fiancé would think it was too shady, however, he ended up loving it! We took the metro and made our quickly to the funicular. The step of Sacre-Coeur were crowded and there were a few street performers. The view was a beautiful as I remembered from years ago. Sacre-Coeur is such a beautiful place and it was nice to take a few minutes and reflect on our trip while inside. We walked along the side street and found a great place for dinner. We loved the hustle and bustle that was missing from our side of the city. Surprisingly, we did not feel any more unsafe than we had in any other part of the city. The cobbled stone streets, cafes, and storefronts are truly the epitome of Paris to me. I do hope there will be a movement to clean up the area and perhaps eliminate the vendors hawking flying plastic birds, glow sticks, and the like in front of Sacre-Coeur. It cheapens the experience as it is a distraction. Like anywhere else you will travel, be aware of your surroundings and trust your instincts. This is a great place to visit, perhaps pick and choose the time of day you go. I stayed off the Barbes metro stop when I was in college and know this area feels rougher than most. There is a larger mix of nationalities in these out arrondissements and the lower end stores attract a certain clientele.

Good with some problems. I liked Montmartre very much. Beautiful view and photos from up there...But... BE CAREFUL. There's a problem which is growing and is a problem already now. There are 2 sides how you can get up the hill. On both sides black "gangs" are controlling the path. When you try to pass them, they try to grab your hand and try to wrap kind of threads around your hand or fingers and then ask money for that... It's kind of impossible to pass them without getting into a problematic situation. They all are Africans, as I understood. We were with my girlfriend, mom and one of my a friends, who is boxer. We almost get into fight with them. They wanted to stop us, and to grab the hand of my girlfriend. Then one of them roughly pushed her. Then he was roughly swearing in pure English language. And all the hill was full of these black people doing such activities. Of course, police was not near, but walking on the top of the hill and on the bottom with the machine guns... Soon Paris will lose this beautiful place because no one will go there because of the idiots Africans doing the business their way

This was Paris. I have visited this area numerous times, and while it is something that one must visit if you go to Paris, somewhat to say you have been there, and take in the beautiful view of the city from this location, it has gone considerably down-hill over the years. The square has always been filled with aspiring artists looking to do your portrait, but the artists today are overly agressive, to the point of being rude (and they aren't that good).The stairs by Sacre Coeur do offer a beautiful views of the city, but they are littered with trash and a mass of humanity that is difficult to wade through. The restaurants and bars that populate this area are below the level of tourist traps in terms of food quality, price and service. While the area is out of the way, if you must see it - don't plan to spend much time, or do any shopping or eating while you are there. Just get in, enjoy the view, take a quick walk around, and get out.

Seedy - I agree. We were there last week and how dissapointing. Montmarte like Paris has lost its lustre. They will seriously have to clean up. This once stunning area is now full of litter and hawkers selling illegal alcohol and drinks. It is full of streett people sitting around drinking, broken bottles. Restaurants in the area are still good and plenty to choose from but rundown. Choose carefully and watch your bags

Must see. It is definitely worth the time to visit Monmartre and the Sacred Heart. It's quite easy to get there by Metro from anywhere in the city and offers great views, good food, and a look at the old artsy area. Touristy, but still a good time. Take the tram and save your feet.

Favourite part of Paris. I spent 4 days in Paris and this is my favourite part of the City.I consider this to be the 'real' Paris or at least how I imagined it - narrow cobbled stoned roads, lined by beautiful buildings with shutters and people cycling in the street.Wondering the streets and exploring by foot is great - the lonely planet has a nice walking route that I followed which took in the main sights - Moulin Rouge, the cafe from Amelie and Sacre Coeur, among many other things.There is also some cheap, delicious food from the local pattisseries and boucheries, as well as some touristy shops to get cheap souvenies and postcards etc.Sacre Coeur itself is an amazing building - a sight to behold on top of the monmartre mound. A tour inside is free and to get views from the top costs around €10 (I didn't do it as I had been the top of 3 other buildings and am a student running out of money! ha). But the views just from in front of the cathedral are still fantastic as you are quite high up. There is also a lovely garden/park leading down to the town, where you can enjoy a relaxing moment eating lunch etc. The only pain are the gypsies who hassle you to buy there goods.
Monmatre art and view across paris. Great place to wander and test your haggling skills if buying art.View is worth the trip up Cares provide reasonable lunch

a favorite spot but avoid Pigalle. Find a sel-guided walking tour in one of the popular travel books and explore this beautiful neighborhood in Paris. Don't miss the Sacre-Couer and the spectacular views. There are a number of good places to eat away from the busy tourist shops. The prices in the souvenir shops vary significantly, shop around before buying if you have the time. Avoid the art shops with the mass produced paintings, instead shop the artists in the square, however this quality varies significantly as well. Be prepared to spend some money if you wish to take home an original painting. A few of the artists are quite good, expect 100 Euros for a small painting of excellent quality, 40 Euros plus for a small piece of good quality art. There are multiple portrait artists in the square as well, avoid the ones walking the street. Restrooms are scarce, plan to visit a cafe to enjoy a beverage and use the WC. Explore the side streets, many beautiful spots, just wish there wasn't any graffiti. Avoid Pigalle and beware of the red-light district. It is noted as harmless but it is unpleasant when walking with your family.
Artists Abound Here. The great choice of Oil paintings from genuine ArtistsI purchased an excellent one of a typical Parisien scence

Seedy and touristy. A once beautiful corner of Paris, ruined by its own fame, allied with the always edgy street- and nightlife vibe, is now a bad combination. Hawkers abound and even the Police treat some of its murkier bits as no-go areas. Don't risk it at night and watch your valuables.
Typically French. It is all about soaking up the French atomsphere, yes there are lots of tourists but the French way is still there. I loved the atomsphere, the architecture and even the crowds.

Great neighbourhood to wander through. Spent a good part of a day here just wandering around, very interesting, from the shops, the artists selling their paintings, Basilica Sacre-Coeur and the view of the city is awesome from here.

Montmartre. Lovely place with lots of cobbled streets. It is very busy but we did a walking tour around it and found out about the history of the place. Very quaint with lots of interesting artist haunts, cafes including Amelie's cafe! Well worth the visit.

So much to enjoy: Place Du Tertre, Sacre Coeur, Rue Lepic, painters, street artists .... This is the higher part of Paris (aka Butte Montmartre) where you can find the area with the painters (Place Du Tertre) and the Sacre Coeur basilic delivering a wonderful view on Paris. It’s an excellent spot for makings photos or camcorder recordings. I always love to stroll and have a look on all those artists (perhaps you meet the imitations of Popeye and Napoleon) and painters, this is Paris at its best if you have a creative mind! Unfortunately it’s also very crowded, especially the many busses with Japanese tourists are infamous…But I don’t mind and focus on the fact that in the 19th century the Montmartre was the place where famous painters like Van Gogh (go to the Rue Lepic where he lived), Degas and Monet once roamed. If you keep that in mind, you will even more enjoy this area. Recommended: take the subway to Montmartre very early on a clear day and go to the top of the stairway of the Sacre Coeur, what an awesome view on Paris waking up!
Climb. Huge hill leading up to this bustling area. Lots of tourists but still fun. Check out the tower of the Basilica.

Great place to explore..... I explored this place on a walking tour - which I thought was the best way to take in the area. There is so much history that having a guide was perfect. The place was called Discover Walks. If you walk all the way to the top - the view is spectacular! At the bottom, it's where the Moulin Rouge is....a definite must see! There are also a lot of places to eat and shop - loved the area very much!

Charming Parisian District. Montmartre is one of my favourite districts in Paris. It's so charming, with the main attraction being the Sacré-Cœur Basilica. You'll find lots of souvenir shops with a wide variety of items for sale including shirts, paintings, craft etc. There are also several great cafes and bars. I'd definitely recommend it in the late evening, especially as it approaches sunset. The view of the Sacré-Cœur Basilica is amazing. To get there, get on Line 2 and alight at Anvers.

A Highlight of My Paris Visit. I must do! I don't mean just the essentials such as Sacre Coeur Church, Views of Paris and Place du Tertre. The greatness lies in walking around the neighborhood behind Sacre.As the Paris streets expanded by Napoleon III, this area remained the same.I highly recommend a walking tour through this area. Walking by Lapin Agile, where many writers and artists hung out. The story of martyrdom of Saint Denis one of the patron Saints of Paris who carried his head for 6 miles and is thought of as founding the lesser known Saint Pierre de Montmarte. The famous vineyard where very expensive bottles of wine are produced, not so much for the content as much for the artists who paint the labels. You can take the metro to Abbesses station,there is a small white "petit-train" which looks like a kids ride but will drive up the hill and picks up across from Moulin Rouge
Amazing view, worth the climb. This is possibly the biggest tourist trap in Paris, but well worth braving the crowds (and the stairs). The view once at the top is amazing.

Don't miss the vineyard. Sacre Coeur is a must see, and a vineyard in the middle of Paris is amusing. The view from the top is beautiful. As we see it, you can easily skip Moulin Rouge and the sex industry.

Montmartre, c'est jolie.. Montmartre, a place I will never get sick off. Been there so many times, highest point in Paris with amazing view. Sacre Coeur, amazing church. A very nice place to hang around with friends or just yourself. Best place for tourist from café to shops. Souvenirs, paintings by local artists, Paris t-shirt, jacket etc. If shopping is not your thing, relax at a café where Amélie was filmed or watch artists paint or get a picture of yourself painted. Montmartre can be easily access by the metro and if you do not feel like walking, take the funicular to the top of the hill.

Montmartre. I hadn't been to Paris since college in 1983, and I was really excited especially to visit Montmartre. I was not disappointed. This part of the city, highlighted by the beautiful Sacre Coeur church, is the highest point in Paris and indeed the view is breathtaking. What really does it for me is the quaintness of this part of Paris. Everything from the cute cafes to the plethora of street painters in the "Greenwich Village"-type atmosphere really excudes charm. Highly recommended.

A beautiful church that is worth the trip. We took the Metro out to see Montmarte. It was well worth the 20 minute ride out to the site. They have a great square to buy paintings from local artists. Although you can take a funicular to get to the top of the hill, the walk up the steps is not too bad. If you want to spend the extra money, there is a tour to the dome at the top of the church. I thought it was a bit pricey since the views from the steps were pretty spectacular.
Nice area to vist, walk around, up and down. This area is quite diverse taking in steamy "adult" areas, to art galleries, wine and sacred churches. Worth spending time walking around and exploring.
Always good to visit.. Winding streets, shops and cafes full of character and the best views of Paris available. Great place to visit and lose yourself in wandering for a few hours.

Charming!!. Love that little place, full of little artists and cute little alleys. The bohemian section of paris for sure. The church is fantastic and the way is even better! Watch out for the "deaf" albanian kids wanting you to sign and the give money....they are not deaf, just little rat scammers, just a heads up but apart from that, a grade!!!!

Always love it. The first time we went to Montmartre was in 2001, and we love it ever since. This is our fourth visit to Paris and we decided to stay at this area. Montmartre seems never sleep, it was always full of people, given that the Moulin Rouge is just in the corner of Rue Lepic, across Blanche Metro. Full of restaurants along the street towards Basilique du Sacre Coeur. Lots of souvenirs shops and the cheapest one is in the Blvd de Clichy on the direction to Place de Clichy. Visit place du Tertre, to get self portrait by amateur artist and continue the journey to Sacre Coeur. It was fun especially during the sunset, people crowded in the stairway to watch many attractions that last early in the morning. Love it.
Fun visit for Family. Fun little cafes to people watch, atleast thirty artist seated around the square, About 50-100 euro's for a sketch. Had one done of my wife and child about 100e

A terrific neighborhood, although quite touristy. You can easily visit Montmartre via metro and the funicular, but don't try to walk all the way up unless you are in top cardiac condition. Walk around and inhale the artsy atmosphere, home to artists for over 125 years from when it was just a village on the outskirts of Paris. Now it is fully integrated into the city, but still seems many miles away in it's attitude. Watch the artists at work in Place Tertre, the main square. But for a good, reasonably priced meal wander away from Tertre. Don't miss the working vineyard on the backside of the hill and marvel that such valuable real estate, surrounded by yuppie-ish gentrafication is still used for this purpose many decades after all other agricultural uses have vanished from here. Do visit the Montmartre Museum, an interesting surprise. When you are through with your visit, walk down the Rue de Martyrs back into Paris proper--going down is easy.

Dangereux. Oh what has happened to Montmartre? This used to be a beautiful church in a quaint part of Paris with wonderful artists at Place Teutre. Nowtheo ly thing to see except Sacre-Coeur is the footballeur performing on the steps!

Beautiful view of Paris!. We approached the hill leading to the Sacre Coeur from the Blanche Metro stop. We saw the Moulin Rouge and walked up the hill stopping at the Cafe from Amelie and past shops with cheaper souvenirs than other areas and up the massive hill. Beautiful architecture all around! We saw a mime and many artists with work for sale and creating portaits. There were crowds and tour groups but we still found the area charming. Finally at the summit we enjoyed the church and sat to take in the view and a talented street performer bouncing his soccer ball around. Walking in Monmarte made me appreciate my health. If hiking isn't your thing take the trolley up and enjoy yourself!

Montmartre is fab!. People run Montmartre down saying it is "tacky" "expensive" etc. There is nothing tacky about it as far as I can see - it is a great experience and one that should not be missed when you visit Paris. Apart from the Sacré Coeur itself, which is beautiful, the view from around there is amazing, especially at night. You can see the Eiffel Tower from there, and watch the Tower's "twinkles" every hour after dark until it closes. Admittedly, it can be noisy around the steps of the Basilica at night, and there are always a lot of tourists about, some of them a bit rowdy, but it is still unmissable.The Place du Tetre is full of cafés which may be a little more expensive, but I have never failed to get a good meal there. Beware of some of the street artists though - they can be pushy, and make sure that if you buy from one, it is from one who actually is situated in the Square itself and not just wandering around. Also, before you ask them to draw/paint you, watch them at work to see if you like their style. Don't rely on the examples of their work that they have around them - they have had hours to perfect those! There will only be a few minutes to draw you and you want it to be good. So make sure you are completely happy with them.When planning your visit to Montmartre, avoid weekends if you can, but if you must go then, go early in the day, or late at night when the crowds are less. Above all - enjoy it! Don't expect perfection, Nowhere is perfect but just soak up the atmosphere and remember it for ever! My husband and I adore it and always stay in a hotel nearby so that we can walk up there whenever we want. Bliss!

Beautiful part of Paris. Driving to Montmartre was through heavy traffic so it lasted like forever.We came at dusk, and it was a rainy day, so we weren't lucky enough to see it in full glory.Still, this was a very good experience: charming streets, colourful, an old part of town where time sits still.
Fantastic little town. Just a short metro trip but worth it just to get out of the middle of the city, great views, great cafes, bakeries and nicer aces to have a afternoon drink.

Great View but. Its a fantastic view once you climb the 300 steps in a small circular walk way. Hot and not for anyone with a heart condition.Once on top its a great view but you now need to go down 300 steps - Its not fun - Plus the surrounding on the steps is OK. If you like the zoo and the very carnival like atmosphere you will like it. We did not - Very dirty area

This is Paris. One of or the highest point in Paris offers you fantastic views on the right day all free of charge. The 'Basilique Du Sacre-Ceur' is beautiful inside and again free to visit.However when you visit the area do not forget to walk through the square just slightly north west of the church (1minute walk) as this is where all the artist paint and sell their work from. The square is busy and full of all types of first class artwork - all for sale if you can afford it!Well worth a visit

Not to be missed. My favourite part of Paris, especially in hthe evening when the artists fill the Place du Tetre. Although the narrow steep streets on the way up to the Sacre Coeur are bustling with tourists, the area is full of atmosphere. The church is absolutely beautiful and the views from its steps are breathtaking. The area is full of good restaurants and in my opinion there is nowhere better in the world to sit and enjoy a refreshing drink or two.

Not really worth your time. If you've already seen Notre Dame de Paris, a visit to Montmartre will be anticlimactic. Once you get off the Metro, you appear on a street down the hill from the church, surrounded by tacky souvenir stands and Roma girls pestering you for donations to scam charities. You walk up a street that honest to goodness reminded me of Playa del Carmen, Mexico - more tacky souvenir stands, beggars and awful throngs of irritating tourists. But worst of all is the gangs of African immigrants pulling the "friendship bracelet" scam (you can read all about it online). They're almost impossible to avoid and extremely annoying. You can take the funicular to the top or climb stairs to reach the basilica, where you are greeted by - you guessed it - more annoying souvenir peddlers. You are granted admission for free but are asked to make a donation to a legitimate charity. The inside of the basilica is spectacular, but again, if you've been to Notre Dame or even St. Paul's in London, it's nothing special. If, like me, you hate crowds, tawdry tourist attractions and souvenir shops, and super annoying scammers, this area is to be absolutely avoided.
Excellent. well worth a visit, windy streets, lots to see, enjoyed the walking tour around the area very much and was well worth t get the most out of the area.

Boutiques, cafes, Sacre Coeur. Lots of interesting little boutique stores, most of them priced very reasonably. The cafes are cute and quaint, nice stop for afternoon tea. Also you must walk up to the Sacre Coeur and the streets filled with artists! A really fantastic part of Paris.

See the church and then leave quickly. OMG....so many tourists and tacky souvenir shops. The church is so beautiful, but the surrounding area is so tacky. Full of beggars and thieves. Do not even think of booking a hotel in this area. Paris at its' worst!

Full of History. We had a great experience thanks to a walking tour we took. I would strongly recommend taking a guided tour. We took Sight Seeker's Delight walking tour and had an amazing experience.
Great City View. A great view to enjoy sunlight, and city view. I think this is a great zone must to visit when in France Paris.
Plan with at least a day here. Just get lost in Montmarte, and explore the nice restaurants, and other places.

Definitely worth a stroll around for food and drinks.... This area has gentrified quite a bit over the years. It reminds me a bit of Palermo Soho in Buenos Aires. It has a younger feeling air to it. The main draw to the area is the Sacré-Cœur of course but there is still plenty to see and do in the area. We've returned several times during our month long trip to eat and drink here.There is a wide variety of places to eat. One of our favorite Vietnamese restaurants is here with the most delicious food. There are several stores that opened and and seem to be catering only to foreigners like a cupcake store we found on the back streets. A beautiful area and if you have kids, there is a carrousel ride right in the center of town as you get off the Abbesses line Metro. Kids love it. 10 rides for 10€.
Loved it. Its the most magical part of Paris. The streets take you back in time as you walk up and down the cobble stone.

A Must. A must experience at least once when visiting Paris. We made the mistake of driving up, and we could not find parking or a parking garage anywhere. My husband had to keep turning around while i walked with the kids for a little bit. Next time I am making everyone walk it all the way up.

Beautiful place, but avoid the fly-by-night scams. The MOST beautiful part of Paris, in my opinion. The place where the streets fold up in the movie Inception (2010) is right here in Montmartre!The place is just incredibly rustic, yet stunningly pretty. However do note that this is sited on a hilly area, and there and many steps around, which could prove inconvenient to the mobility impaired.THE ONE THING that tourists must take note of, is to avoid ALL fly-by-night businesses, or patronise them at their own risks - brick-and-mortar places are alright. I shall not not repeat in detail what criminals are capable of (accosting, harassing, fleecing, pickpocketing, snatching, selling fake goods etc), and thus I recommend visiting in the earlier hours of a day (leave before 2-3pm!), and a weekday rather than a weekend. Because these are the periods when the most tourists groups visit, and also when many of these shady "businesses" follow.There are many nice restaurants in the area, but those at the top of the hill near Sacre Coeur are quite expensive. Those nearer to the bottom of the hill would be more inexpensive.
Highlight. Love the place, love the area, love the atmosphere.

Montmartre. I really loved wandering around this neighborhood and have to say that maybe it was my favorite place in Paris to explore. Place du Tertre with it's artists displaying their work and doing portraits is really interesting.
Lovely neighbourhood. My wife loves this place so much as it's rather quiet yet beautiful neighbourhood to be in... a lot of nice cafes. Also the gateway to the famous Sacre Cour...

A great place to visit on a Sunday morning. The walk up to sacre coeur was just excellent and once you reach the square in Montmartre relax have a glass of wine and watch the world go by. Interesting to see all of the artists and their own styles. Take your time and the village you will not want to leave.

Not the bohemian Montmartre of old- SAD. Visited Montmartre a couple of weeks ago and was so disappointed from the minute we got off the Metro and started walking the streets. Crowded (not the issue) but with thugs, thieves, and street racketeers EVERYWHERE. We immediately became protective of our items, and the entire neighborhood felt more like a Beirut bazaar than the Montmartre of old. We couldn't WAIT to get out of there...Very sad to see the demise of what was a great neighborhood in Paris for a long time. Unless I read a bunch of reviews saying they've cleaned up the neighborhood (of a LOT of sketchy people, and NOT french) I will not be coming close to Montmartre again. Maybe mid week when no one is out and you can enjoy a nice view from the Sacre Coeur.

Montmartre: Historical Home of the Starving Artists - Picasso included. The highlight of my second trip to Paris, France was actually climbing to the top of Montmartre in 2009. You would do well to do some background research on the historical significance of the place before going, in order to get some understanding of what it was then and what is has become now.I appreciate Montmartre for the ground breaking artwork that propelled visual art into the Modern Art arena of the 21st century. It was - at one time - the cheapest run down area in Paris for the poor to live. Hence lots of "starving artists": Vincent Van Gogh (Dutch), Salivador Dali (Spanish), Pablo Picasso (Spanish), Modigliani (Italian), etc., had lodgings in this area and the alfresco cabaret (which was at the top of the hill) was a major magnet for the life style seen in the paintings of Renoir.So, to climb the hill and see artists sketching is not surprizing. They're just carrying on the artistic tradition though I doubt they live there since the rents seem extremely high now. Just don't ask any of these "living" artists about the dead artists who made this place GREAT!!!! They don't want to hear, especially considering that most of these artists weren't native to France.Personally a search for a good art historically based walking tour through Montmartre would be the icing on the cake topped by the marvelous view --- and the church, of course.

Dirty and unappealing ( The Soho of Paris). Worth the visit to see the world famous Moulin Rouge , but that is all. The streets were pretty dirty and had mostly cheap tourist shops , nothing wrong with that if that is what you want. Better to work out which metro (place de Clichy) and go straight there.
great to see!!. Walking to the top was my favorite part. sellers/painters around the area can be distracting. The streets are good the area is good to see while there.

Montmartre - My favorite place in Paris. While it is no doubt a place where you want to be aware of your surroundings...like anyplace else..just be smart when traveling anywhere in Paris. I personally think that the peace and beautiful vista one has sitting on the steps leading up to Sacre Couer is, by far, one of the best experiences anyone can have in Paris. If it is a sunny day, then the sun feels amazing as you sit there and gaze down onto the rooftops of the city. If it is a cloudy day with strong cumulus clouds, then count your lucky stars. These clouds will make your pictures extra dramatic and just beautiful. I would recommend that you visit during the week to avoid some of the scammers that you'll see during some of the busier times on weekends. Additionally, take the side streets and "look up" ... always look up in Paris as the buildings' history extends beyond the ground floors.

Charming despite the hype. This is a quintessential Paris landmark and worth the trip. Lovely streets leading up to the church and yet another good area for strolling and taking in the Paris atmosphere. On the way down again, there are many pleasant cafes and brasseries. Yes, it's touristy with a capital T but your family will enjoy the views and the buzz.

Well worth a visit. I would recommend a bit of time in Montmartre, walking around the top. On some days when you go you can see artists drawing/painting tourists. (it is a bit annoying that people with keep asking if you want your picture drawn, but a polite 'non merci' works wonders!)It's a beautiful area of Paris, and if you go midweek in the morning, there are not so many people.

Beautiful spot, dangerous thugs. This is a beautiful spot, there is no doubt, really beautiful. However, the physically aggressive gangs of bracelet scammers really detract from the experience. At the base of the hill, there are two openings that the majority of people will use. As soon as you cross through the opening you will be confronted by a wall of 6 - 8 large men, literally standing shoulder to shoulder and simply not letting you pass. While you continue to say no and attempt to walk around or through them they will move to surround you, they also grabbed our arms in attempt to stop us from walking by. The police showed up a couple times chasing these thugs out of the area, but it only lasted for a few minutes and then they all reappeared. I saw one young woman, alone, get surrounded and followed up the hill for 20 or 30 meters before they finally left her alone.It was beautiful, but it was also ugly. If you go, make sure all your valuables are very safe, and be prepared to feel physically threatened.
Nice walk. This place is very glamourous, very parisian. Just wander abou the streets to feel the spirit.

Paris tourist spots. All of Paris's tourism spots are loaded with Fraunders, Robberys, and Pickpocketers.Paris is a nice tourism destination? Put all of them into the Jail. It's the first step to invite tourists. There are many other good places in the world before you go Paris.

2 weeks in an appartment in Montmartre- call me an old romantic. We had rented an apartment in the Ornano area for our 2 weeks stay. With metro lines 4 & 12 a couple of minutes away we could go easily to any other arrondissement. The metro system is better than most, but be prepared to walk & climb stairs. You can plan ahead with it's interactive web site. You can walk the historic part of Montmartre easily but again be prepared to walk uphill & stairs. If your French is good enough, you could contact Alaiin Barta, a real Montmartre native, for a guided tour. Look for the Société d'Initiative de Montmartre web site. More anecdotes than you can shake a stick at. They're located at Place du Tertre which is somewhere you want to be in very early morning to be able to see it with less than a thousand tourists milling about. On boulevard Ornano there's a street market 3 days a week. Imagine coming out of your apartment with a cheese stand right in front of the doorway. A few steps away for a croissant au beurre to write home about. Sorry I have to go, this is making me hungry.

Seedy. Visited after the sacre coeur and was excited to see the Moulin Rouge. The area is full of sex shops and lots of drunks hanging around even though this was around 9.30am! I wouldn't bother. Shame

Great Views but the stench!!. We took the varnicular railway upto Monmartre (I know but it's been a long day). Then as we walked the last few steps to the top, we noticed the stench, and what we thought was water coming down the steps. When we got to the top we realised what the smell and the water was. Men we peeing behind as kiosk, to such an extent it was running down the steps, and fouling the air.Shame as the view was stunning, but I wouldn't go again.
Stay Away From Here. The great view of the city is destroyed by terrible crowds and hustlers that must be ducked as you go up the steps. It is just unpleasant. Go elsewhere for views in Paris.

A perfect Sunday Morning. If you have a Sunday in Paris then you must make your way to Monmartre. It is a hike up there and it is very touristy but it is worth it when you get there. There is a great buzz around the place. You can get a caricature of yourself if you are into that or sit down relax and take in the atmoshere and have an overpriced coffee but that is all part of the experience.

Excellent. Simply a beautiful area to walk through. Following a walking tour found in the Rick Steves Paris book we enjoyed the many hours we spent there, stopping for a drink in a cafe, dinner at a creperia. Go in the late afternoon so you're there at night so you can see beautiful Paris at night. The view is breathtaking!

Beautiful area. This place is how I imagine Paris in my head. Cafes and patisseries in beautiful buildings with wooden shutters on the window and artists dotted around the streets with tourists bustling around the area. We visited Montmartre and took in the glorious view before wandering some streets of Montmartre. This I think is definitely my favourite area of Paris!

Must try. Spent 2 days in this area with friends for my birthday and had the best time. From the first eavening where we ventured along Boulivard De Clichy by the Moulin Rouge and suroundingcafe,s and pubs to a small italian cafe (Sparticus) where we had a decent meal and drinks for 5 at a very reasonable 150Eu . We did not come across the prices I read in some reviews and at no time felt uncomfortable, Staff everywhere we went were cheery and helpfull.The next morning we visited Sacre Couer (taxi up and walk down) with fab views over Paris and lunch on way down . All in all decent prices and great experiance
