Beautiful Church. Visiting Montmartre area worth to take a walk in the square with the artists while at the top of the hill you can find the beautiful building of "Basilique du Sacré-Cœur" church. The location of the church is very beautiful due to the panoramic view to the city of Paris.

Monmartre, France Guided Tour. We schedule a combination guided tour for Paris Historic including Notre Dame, Musee du Louvre, and Montmatre through Gray Line. The cost of the one day combination tour was around $160 per person.The Montmatre part of the tour was excellent. It was very interesting to hear about the history of that area as an "American Ex-Pat" haven.This is a great combination guided tour. One probably should wear comfortable shoes if the combination guided tour is chosen since there is a moderate amount of walking in the Montmartre part.

Beautiful, worth seeing. After climbing stairs upon stairs, we arrived at the Montmartre church and it was worth the walking. I found it more beautiful than Notre Dame. They also had a great farmers market the day we went there which was really fun and enjoyable. We also purchased a painting from the adjacent square which was also enjoyable. Be careful of pickpockets as the police arrested a few while we were there (which was quite a show for the tourists)

skip the bs reviews about having a drink.... stick to the right walking up- hydrate and rest.I walked all the way up. took pics...saw the inside- no pictures allowed- and marvelled at the Huge Touchdown Jesus that greets parishioners up front.please do not take offense. it is beyoutiful- I just get "churched" out in Italy and France.not Christian ans Jewish leaning towards agnostic. but syillna high school history teacher.Sacred Couer c'est tres magnifique!

Street Thieves. There are street thieves with a game that consists of three black pucks, one which has a white dot on the back. The dealer tells you he will give you 50€ if you guess the location of the puck with the dot. After he shuffles the pucks he has those around him, who pretend to be tourists but are really part of his sceem, select the puck. His helpers are always successful and "win" the money. However, they also assist in distracting the actual trusting tourist while the dealer switches the pucks. No one ever wins this game other than those in on the sceem DO NOT EVEN STOP TO WATCH! These are true street thieves.

Beware of prices. Loved walking around the artists painting and drawing but plagued by beggars again. The views were stunning but the costs of eating and drinking were extortionate - 10 euros for a pint of cola...please!!!

Must visit. If you go anywhere exploring Paris, you should not miss Montmartre. It's magical and romantic. Make your way to Basilique du Sacré-Cœur. Take a free tour by Discover Walks. http://www.discoverwalks.com/paris-walking-tours/montmartre-paris-walking-tour/

Arty Montmartre. Take a taxi to the top of the hill, sit on the steps of the Sacre Coeur and enjoy the view over Paris. The public toilets just around the corner (female!) are worth a visit! ;) Walk to the small park then around to Montmartre village. It is unapologetic in it's tourist atmosphere but gets away with it! After strolling around viewing the artists at work, sit over a cup of coffee and a citron tart and watch the passing parade. An acrylic 'cafe scene' by one of the top painters in Montmartre was bought for me by my traveling companion which I treasure. The lady who sings Piaf is another attraction. Walk the lanes and buy the posters; they hang on my walls as a reminder of the magic of Montmartre. Walk down the hill past the windmills, flowershops and boutiques to the Moulin Rouge.

LOVE. This was one of my favorite places! After my husband and I walked up the stairs to the Sacre Coeur we walked to this lovely little square where artists sell their paintings. You can have your picture drawn here. I bought two beautiful watercolors from two different artists ... they are stunning. When I got them home and opened them for the first time ... they brought such happiness that I cried.

Follow in the footsteps of the great artists. This whole area is simply amazing and oozing art and culture at every street corner! In order to see more than just the art shops and cafes, it is worth taking the time to follow a short walking tour to explore some of the key points of interest in this area. I took a short tour from the Sacre-Coeur and finished at the Moulin Rouge. On my way I saw the Musee de Montmatre, a delightful small private vineyard, a couple of windmills and the house where van Gogh stayed with his brother.Great walking tours don't have to cost you much at all! (only fee was at the Musee de Montmartre should you choose to go in).
idyllic paris!. get lost in the tiny side streets, visit a cafe nestled next to a staircase, check out all the cool street art, and definitely wander into all the fabulous vintage boutiques~

artists and restaurants. Beautiful Paris small streets, nice to spend an afternoon looking at artists having coffee or eating in some nice or little restaurants,there is lots of them enjoy a nice afternoon in Paris

Touristy but cute. There are some great restaurants and lots of artisans in this area. If you are already visiting Sacre Coeur it is worth the time to walk over. The main square is extremely crowded, particularly because people stop to watch the sketch artists. There is a great view of the Eiffel Tower and other Paris landmarks from the edge of the promenade. There are many little tourist boutiques, perfect for picking up postcards or little souvenirs.

Worth a visit but too many tacky tourist shops & touts. You can still sense the appeal of this area of Paris but you have to work hard to get beyond all the crowds, the tacky tourist shops and touts all vying for your attention. The views of Paris are amazing and the areas away from the immediate vicinity of the Sacre Coeur are quiet and well worth visiting. Be prepared for a lot of stairs and uneven streets.

Comme ci, comme ca.... That's what the French say when they mean, "so-so", and it's the perfect way to describe Montmartre. It used to be home to artists, poets and writers who were on the forefront of the "free-thinking" movement that gave Paris its artsy, bohemian vibe, but now it's nothing more than a gathering place for sketch artists who'll draw a portrait of you - or your kid, or your dog - with a gigantic head standing outside of Sacre Coeur. It's Disneyland without the authenticity of, well, Disneyland. The landscape - the only hill in Paris that provides such winning views of the city at large - is still lovely, and the architecture, particularly as you head toward Rue Marcadet, is worth seeing. But beware pickpockets and avoid the extraordinarily cliche shops touting Eiffel Tower keychains and - yes, even in Paris - air brushed t-shirts.
Worth the climb uphill.. Of course when we arrived at the Sacre Coeur we realised we could have taken an easier way by venicular.

Art and night life.. All Parisian artists used to flock here in the past, including Lautrec who created a place for Moulin Rouge in art history.I especially liked the Basilica of the Sacre Cour. The place was so lively with a huge crowd singing English pop song, an Asian group getting ready for a public performance, a man playing ith football on top of a pole - so lively. Liked the spirit of the place. But inside the cathedral one goes in full silence, properly dressed without showing sleeves or calves.

Heads up for eleven year old cell phone thiefs in Montmarte. Enjoying a great Paris visit with son and his wife and sat at a charming square below the Sacre Couer cathedral, where the street performers gather and several art and flower hawkers strolled by. They were pleasant, but not insistent and it did not seem unusual at first, that two young boys approached and placed two pieces of paper over my hand on the table, which was next to my iPhone. I glanced at the paper and it looked like a pharmaceutical advertisement and said no no. Then they insisted again and I took my hand out from underneath to show 'No' with my hand waving over the papers. I looked away to ignore them and they walked away with papers and after ten more minutes, I discovered, my phone as well.. We called police, no help.. We stopped two motorcycle cops a little later in the area. Still no help.

Favorite Place In My Visit To Paris. I visited Paris back in Nov. 2009. This was hands down Mine and my Sweetheart's favorite place. We stayed here for hours just people watching and sipping fine wine. Yeah there will be pan handlers, and people trying to sell you, but what do you expect when you visit any major touris destination??? Just use percaution and enjoy the atmosphere! This place will remain one of my most favorite & romantic memories of all time. Cheers!
Worth a visit but take care. Great views, but a haven for pickpockets. Take care

A truly magical place in one of the World's most romantic cities. The setting here is just oustanding. The stairs of the Basilique gives you a one-of-a-kind panoramic view of Paris, especially at night. The narrow paved streets, small cafes, painters, musicians, and other street artists, gives Montmartre a unique feeling you won't find anywhere. This is a must when in Paris.
Interesting. Worth a walkaround if you have more than a few days in Paris. Lots to see in the area.

Top views a little bit of village Paris. Start at Place de Abbesses for the Nouveau Metro station. Then go to finicular to the iconic church Sacre Coeur. Great view of the city here. Now don't miss s circular walk starting behind the church that includes the Agile Lapin, the oldest vineyard in Paris, and the windmill. Along the way you are in the old village of winding lanes. This is why so many people chose to do art here long ago.

Avoid this place!. I admit, the view from the Sacre Coeur is probably one of the nicest in Paris, but the area is definitely not! I've visited this neighbourhood many times over the past years and I can't help but noticing the decline of this area! This place has turned into a giant tourist trap with people trying to sell you all kinds of worthless items and so-called artists constantly annoying you to draw a picture of you. We tried to escape the madness in a café at Place du Tertre and paid €10 for a beer! What a scam! Place du Tertre itself is a nightmare with tourists trying to catch a glimpse of what used to be a nice and artistic little square! I really can't understand how people can enjoy this! This will definitely be my last visit. There are many, many nice places and neighbourhoods to visit in Paris, but Montmartre is no longer one of them!

Beautiful location but BEWARE of dodgy businesses. To add to my tour de paris, Montmartre was a classic suggestion by my friends. They were 100% right. Its a beautiful place and the view was nearly as good as from top of the Eiffel tower, as the church is on top of the hill. Climbing the hill through the busy market streets was a fun and an exercise, whcih we thoroughly enjoyed. There are quite a lot of street shows, which we enjoyed as well. But, please be aware that there are set of crooks who try to make as much money as possible by selling some sort of colourful thread (claiming it to be holy!). **Stay away from them**

Go with an open mind and be street wise!. I have been to Montmartre several times and I do agree that it is a district of Paris worth exploring. Just be careful though because Pigalle at the base of Montmartre is extremely seedy and felt a bit daunting to me. Montmartre itself I didn't have a problem with. The square with the artists is lively and there are some who hassle you to draw your portrait but if you ignore them there are some excellent artists painting anything parisian. They are happy for you to watch them paint without plying for trade. I own two oil paintings bought there which are great and weren't overly expensive.Obviously a must when you are in this area is to visit the Sacre-Coeur. It is a long walk up the steps but must have the greatest view of the Parisian skyline. It is a magnificent Basilica but spoilt somewhat by gypsies trying to sell you their cheap and tacky wares. Nevertheless don't let them put you off visiting the Basilica itself.

It is a shame - it is now a tourist trap. We have been going to Montmarte for years when visiting but nothing prepared me for what a shabby and touristy area. You cannot even walk near it without be accosted by a want to be portrait artist. What a shame.
Old and colorful, but little seedy. Colorful old neighborhood with the highlight being St. Chapelle , however be aware of your surroundings

Can't resist. Usually catch a cab up, and then walk/meander down. Don't particularly enjoy being chased by the "artists" wanting to "paint" me, but I like the area, and the souvenir shops are quite good up there. THe restaurants are a bit average up there, so would suggest just a snack and find something else on the way down, even a baguette with ham and cheese from a deli.

Shambles. How can such a beautiful city allow one of it's top tourist spots to become such a mess. I have visited this part of Paris on numerous occasions and always loved it. But after walking up towards Sacre Couer through the most awful streets were we witnessed people being arrested by the police, and saw pick pockets it was very disturbing.I am not a country girl I am pretty streetwise coming from and being a tour guide in one of the North of Englands city's but I was appalled at the way people were being accosted to buy string bracelets from hundred of sellers on the steps of the cathedral.Then to walk into Mont Martre and be tormented by the "artists" I was upset to see how cheap and nasty it had all become, I won't be returning and definately won't be taking my children until Paris cleans up it's act.

Get there early, get out before it gets dark.. Because it gets packed. There's a lot of life up there. Art, commerce, people and yes, pickpockets. We were told by the locals to be back before it gets dark, and we could tell why. I recommend getting the metro up there and on your way back. Still, the place is very fun and nice, so enjoy it! P.S. The cable car is not necessary unless you are REALLY tired.

Great for slow walk but don´t fall for the tourist traps. Walking from Sacre Coeur to the main square is a dream come tue. You must do it if you are in Paris. Great atmosphere but you have to be careful. Most restaurants in my opinion are tourist traps. Beware of the ¨fixed menus¨ as in one the fixed menu was 15 euro and they charged us 9 euro for a coke. Walk away from the main square for a better dining experience. The views. . .the views are incredible!

Have your portrait drawn. Carefully pick the artist, there are a lot... Bargain, bargain, bargain but place is much better than how it was 2 years ago... Also do not miss old painter with clown paintings...
Loved it!. Great atmosphere. My husband and I talked about our visit there and we both said, if we were to move to Paris, Montmarte is where we'd like to live. Loved the market.

Great place. Very Nice ..great place surrounded by small restaurants ..lotsof history  on the walk to Sacre Coeur - beware of thieves and gipsies who are playing gamble games ...on a paper box .. with 3 covers ....do not play with them under any circumstances .. they wil let you win at first and then you will loose all your money ..all the other people who are playing ... are fake they are with them ..beware
A must visit. Brilliant views over Paris. Fascinating to watch all of the painters. Plenty of Cafes, not that expensive.
Waste of time. Except for Sacre Coeur, which has a great view. Montmartre is one big yard sale and circus combined. And not in a good way.
a must see. we went to montmartre which is full of artists. its great to wonder around and watch them at work.
Great atmosphere in Montmatre. Cozy places all over, but be aware of scam artists and touristy squares.
What a view!. View is amazing! 360 of the Paris. Make sure to walk there and not take a cab.

Just relax and let the artists, environment, cafes inspire you !. This is the only and the best place to have some 2-3 hours free for yourselves to relax and let the artists, environment, cafes inspire you while you are visiting Paris ! Walk around the lovely paintings, have something to eat and drink at the very narrow and small pavement cafes watching passerby...

Montmartre-Artists and Altitude in Paris. Montmartre, a high point in Paris, has the Basilica of the Sacre Coeur, the Moulin Rouge and all the artists you want or need. It was the center for art in Paris in the late 1800s and you can find numerous Picasso-hopefuls there today. You can get your exercise or use public transportation to enjoy it.

Love this area. This is a very lively and young area with lots of restaurants and bars and some great places for souvenirs. It is a bit of a dodgy area though so I wouldn't recommend any a girl to go alone. We went as 2 girls and just stayed vigilant and together at all times and were fine so don't be too put off!! If you're in this area make sure you visit the Sacre Coeur the views are beautiful, if you get off at Anvers station you are right in the middle of the montmarte area!

Not my favorite area of Paris. The residential areas of Montmartre are pretty as a picture...cobbled side streets and ivy covered walls, and the views from certain vantage points are spectacular but best to steer clear of everything else, especially the over-crowded Basilique du Sacré Coeur, Place du Tertre, and other commercial areas. They are just plain seedy...a real cash grab!

Magical Montmartre. Getting off the Metro was an eye opener - filthy, garbage piled high, crowds of men on street corners, no women around. For the one and only time, I felt unsafe in Paris. Not what I was expecting.Got away from this section of town fairly quickly and started walking towards Sacre Coeur. The landscape and atmosphere changed for the positive.Many different ways to approach the Basilica - taxi, funicular, bus, small tourist "train". I chose to walk. (Street signage not the best; make sure you have a map!) Took awhile winding through the streets and then the grounds itself, but it was lovely. Lots to see. Once at the Basilica, the view was breath taking. Lucky enough to attend a church service and to see the end of a wedding. The nuns singing was yet another bonus.Around the corner at the back of Sacre Coeur was the heart of Montmartre with it's restaurants, artists, galleries (look for Galerie d'art at 11 rue Poulbot) and another hidden gem - a Salvidor Dali Museum - Espace Dali.Rambling through the back streets, also came upon Musee de Montmartre at 12 rue Cortot. It is located in one of the oldest houses in Montmartre. Many artists (e.g. Renoir) have lived in the house. The gardens were beautiful.Definitiely well worth visiting this whole area of Paris.Take your time. Don't rush. Don't limit yourself to the 'known' tourist area/s. Explore. You will be delighted with what you find.

A place to see. My favorite place in Paris, as it is the highest point of the city, you have a nice view of the roofs of Paris. The atmosphere is very agreeable, with different artists performing (singers, acrobats etc). The Baslica of the scare coeur is worth visiting.
Atmosphere. As you walked through the streets to get to the Basilica, you mixed with all the different types of street vendors - what a great experience.

Just try to see the real Monmartre. Get off the main streets, visit some of the lovely old streets and enjoy a morning walk. There are plenty of the touristy places is you want, but we learned so much by getting of the beaten path. See the few windmills left on the hill and end up down near Moulin Rouge (not what you expect). There are several routes to take that are very enjoyable

Gorgeous Hilly Landscapes of Paris Streets.. Montmartre is mainly known for Sacre-Coeur Basilica (Sacred Heart) but it is a beautiful neighborhood of winding and hilly streets. Artists (Vincent van Gogh, Henri Matisse, Edgar Degas, Claude Monet, Pablo Picasso and many famous others) gathered here and still do to this day. Montmartre is the highest point in Paris so you get spectacular views from up there.
Like Disney's vision of Paris. The Montmarte area is like a Disney vision of what Paris should be. Lovely streets and squares with character to spare. Hollywood could not come up with a better set.

Opportunity to see beyond the major sights. Montmartre is worth walking through if you are tired of visiting the major sights in Paris. It's really a walk through a neighborhood where you can get to the highest natural point in Paris, visit the Sacred Heart church, watch artists do paintings and visit some art related places.If you reach via the metro, your ticket should still be usable on the funicular within the allowed time for transfer.I must agree that some sections are touristy. Many souvenir shops here as well. Nevertheless, it is still a great place to visit. No issues with safety as well.

Fascinating. With such a wierd and wonderful history it is hard to not be taken in by Montmartre. There are lots of beggars and those pesky women with petitions in Montmatre but merely say "Non" and they will leave you alone. Be sure to explore

Beautiful but too crowded for me. Sacre Coeur is magnificent but for me, Montmartre was just too crowded and too "touristy" . Younger visitors loved sitting on the steps below the basilica and listening to the buskers and open mike sessions, but I like a few less people around me . Maybe go early in the morning - that's true of everything in Paris.

My favourite part of Paris. This really is a beautiful part of an amazing city. The steep little streets that lead to the Scare Couer are interesting and pretty with plenty of places to eat and drink (including the famous Two Windmills cafe from the film Amelie). At the top of the hill is the famous catherdral and of course many, many artists. It can be incredibly busy up here but worth spending an afternoon wandering around and taking everything in. The views of the city from the basillica are excellent, make sure you have a camera with you! In the opposite direction, at the bottom of the hill on the main road, is the very famous Moulin Rouge as well as the red light district. This area is the exact opposite of the streets just a few minutes away and doesn't feel entirely safe at night but overall, Montmartre is a fantastic area of Paris!

Beautiful place. A taste of old Paris. Beautiful village streets and bistros, artists and souvenirs make this place a must see.After riding on the funicular to the top of the hill, you see an interesting white church, and have a nice view of Paris (Eiffel tower, Centre Pompidou, La Defense, etc.). But the real charm is when you start walking the narrow and crowded streets. You´ll see plenty of souvenir shops, also bistros, and creperies, but the main attraction are artist, mainly painters, altought some musicians and mimes too.They weren't as heavy as I expected from other reviews. Only a couple guys offered to knit a band on my wrist but were easily dismissed. We saw many people having their portraits done.Back from the hill is a 10 minutes walk to Moulin Rouge, although beware: it is not a family friendly place to walk. We very uncomfortable but before we quit were lucky to join 30 people from a tourist bus, finish the walk, and take some pictures of the iconic place Toulusse Lautrec portrayed.

Lovely atmosphere - fab portrait of our daughter. We spent a lovely afternoon here and Agnes, a lovely lady with dark hair on one of the inside rows, did the most beautiful portrait of our daughter in charcoals, she captured her perfectly, her eyes really look out at you from the drawing, it is like she is alive, amazing. Cost, £40, having this work of art, priceless,can't wait to get it framed and up on the wall.

Lovely Christmas Market beside Sacre Coeur. Last December I had the chance to spend Christmas in my favorite city Paris. As I had time to roam the city, I decided late afternoon to go up Sacre Coeur in Montmartre district. Little did I know that there was also a Christmas Market around the basilica and it sure was pretty! Overlooking the whole city of Paris, I loved strolling around the small christmas kiosks, drinking the warm mulled wine very much needed in that chilly Parisian evening.
another must have seen. it's very full, of course, but painters do not bother you as much as they used to
One of my favorites in Paris!. What an adorable place...you can see yourself living there. The church, the streets, people living, kids running around after school, shops etc. loved it!

Historic place - You have to visit Montmartre. This is the place where the history of Paris resides. Though, we didn't spend much time here, we were glad to see the sites that Montmartre offers. Would surely recommend Montmartre.
We were lucky to see a Bollywood shooting as well for a movie names Ishq.

Quaint. Spent our last day in Paris visiting Montmarte. Lots of artists and street vendors and some shopping. Great view of Paris from the top. Too many stairs for seniors, must use the incline lift which requires a metro ticket. You can purchase the ticket on site. The day we visited you only needed a ticket to go in the up direction. Check before you purchase a second ticket to go down. Very crowded, felt safe, but watch your belongings. I would not stay in this area as it is very distant from other areas in Paris.

Nice part of town for shopping. We stayed on the hill, near the graveyard. Near our hotel were lots of sex shops. An interesting experience. We also strolled up to street to the Sacre-Couer at the top of the hill which has more artistically oriented shops.

And there's more...... We hadn't planned on staying in the Montmartre area that long,...just a funicular ride up to Sacre Coeur and a quick look around. There were so many interesting, winding strreets, restaurants and of course the artists all around selling their work. We ended up spending hours up there. An area not to be missed.

Is worth going there be carefull from pickpockets. walking over ther feela like u are in a different century,the feeling that u get is hard to explain. U must go there in daylight and in the eve,just be carefull form thieves
too crowded. I was here on a saturday at around noon and I found the church and its sourroundings too crowded. Also the view of Paris was not particularly interesting to me.

Nice square with artists. This is another little Paris secret. As many have said, you have to beware of scammers but the artists in the square have some real talent that is amazing to watch them do on the spot!

Full of Personality and Activity. A trip to Paris must include walking the streets of Montmartre! There are many street vendors, painters and illustrators in this area. The sidewalks follow the steep hills, make twists and turns, and become narrow and intimate; these sidewalks make for great sight-seeing. There is also some great street art and cafes in this area. I wouldn't stay in a hotel in this area only because it is far from many of the major sites, but it is definitely worth visiting.

Nice, but be careful of scams. I visited Monmartre after 20 years. And I am afraid it has lost some of its bohemian charm. It is worth visiting Sacre Coeur and the artists' square and there are nice city views from the top of the hill. However, be very careful of con artists, especially near sacre couer. There are groups of people who pretend to have a disability and beg for money showing a donation card. Do not fall for this as it is totally fake. They will tell you that they can give you change and when you ask for change they just run off with your cash. It was a group of young girls who were involved.
Just perfect!!!. It was soooo beautiful! By far, my favorite area in Paris!

Great place to stay. Great walking neighborhood. Mostly locals unless you're right at Sacre Coeur. Lots of food options, including good-sized markets down toward Pigalle. Pigalle may have a bad rap, but if you're not looking for trouble it doesn't seem to look for you.

Vibrant but rough around the edges. If you want to visit an area with lots of shops, restaurants, people and not a lot of pretense then this is the area for you. The cemetery is interesting both for the people buried there and for the highway that is built over part of the cemetery . The crypts actually rise to reach between gutters from the roadway. Of course this is where you will find the Moulin Rouge, along with the accompanying peep shows, sex and DVD shops. Not the pretty side of Paris but it is the area where a lot of famous artist spent much of their time and money supporting the local enterprises. Worth a wander.
Very Busy, lots of gypsies and vendors. We like that we could walk around and look at some local artists, but it was very crowded with people trying to sell you things.

Once was not enough for me!. It's a real climb to get to this charming little town, but worth it to us - twice. If you're an artsy kind of person, this is your stop. The square if filled with artists displaying their unique types of art. If you want an caricature drawn, it can be done in several mediums. The little shops along the way are small but offer up some unique dining options. It's narrow and winding but worth the time to enjoy. We went twice just to soak up the atmosphere and see the beautiful artwork being created before our eyes. The street preformers add lots of flavor as do the musical preformers. It's just a lovely stroll on the hill with a little culture around every corner.
A specific atmosphere. Walking the small streets between the mill (real one), the vineyards and church brings you in another dimension (but for the tourists)

Charming walkable Montmarte. The first thing to remember about walking in Montmarte is that it is a hill, so the going might be a bit tough if you're not used to walking. You start the ascent by either taking the funiculaire or the 260+ steps up the Rue Foyatier, but the view of Paris from the top is definitely worth it. The Basilica of the Sacred Heart cuts an imposing white figure on top of the hill. A few steps from the church is the Place du Tertre and its cafes, street performers, and artists. There is also the Musee de Montmarte (where the painter Maurice Utrillo lived), the house where Toulouse-Lautrec used to live, the Cabaret du Lapine Agile (where Van Gogh, Matisse, Renoir, Degas, Picasso, Modigliani, and Toulouse-Lautrec used to hang out), the Place Dalida -- where you can rest your weary feet before continuing on to Moulin de la Galette, and then the Moulin Rouge at the Pigalle downhill. You can also check out Rue Lepic and its Les Deux Moulins café, made famous by Amelie, and Le Chat Noir.All in all, my Montmarte walk was very pleasant and charming, and not at all dangerous as I expected it to be given the reviews that I have read about the place. Maybe it depends on the time of day when you get to visit -- I was there from lunchtime and a few hours thereafter, well before the setting of the sun and the turning on of the lights in the red light district.

Guided Tour of Montmarte. Met up with our New Europe Tour Guide Filipa opposite the Moulin Rouge last Sat, didn't know anything about Montmarte so didn't know what to expect. We heard a few racy stories about the area we met in then we climbed the winding hill up to Sacre Couer, Filipa stopped regularly (& not just to give us a breather) to bring the area to life for us, we saw where Van Gogh lived for 2 years, the cafe where Picasso paid for his meals by drawing on the napkins, the only surviving vineyard in Paris arriving eventually at the Sacre Couer, worth a visit for the panoramic views of Paris alone. Filipa was a wonderful tour guide, irreverent, amusing, knowledgeable and fun, could not recommend this tour more, we had a great time and the free glass of wine at the end was the icing!

beautifull but be carefull !. Montmartre is a high hill and a district in Paris, located in the 18th arrondissement; The hill is some 134 meters high. Montmartre is one of the most famous tourist sites of Paris. On top of Montmartre is a beautiful city views. The Montmartre district attracts many artists have long and especially painters. On the Place du Tertre, on top of the hill, the specially-made paintings sold to tourists. Be carefull of pickpockets near the metro and I m not feel secure on nightime in this area because of some drug dealers so better to be with guys. Anyway, police are always here also because lot of tourists coming there for Moulin Rouge or cabaret. This is for sure the hottest area in Paris with at least 100 sex shop ...
quaint. lovely restaurants and bars where you can sit outside and watch the world go by with a delicious glass of wine. A more relaxed part of Paris.

old area like an old village. nice streets, old houses, famous area for artists. not exactly Paris, montmartre like a city in the city. but restaurants are not so good and expensive. A nice moment in this well-known litlle city of montmartre....and lot of secret streets you can discover, charming area and beautiful view of Paris, great place to take photos

je vous parle d'un temps... sometimes people criticize it for being too touristic, but Montmartre has an undeniable charm that is unique.. the view, the streets, the brasseries and cabarets.. a nostalgic reminder of the old paris of black and white movies..

Love it here. Its some time since I was at Montmartre. 15 years ago when I was a teenager. An artist did a fantastic picture of me I still have to this day for only a few francs. Great fun bargaining.
Beautiful. this the place to relax and unwind , you can have your face caricature done by talented artists for 5Euros

nice view. too touristic. Like said in the title, the view is breathtaking, but the surrounding are is horrible. full of tourists. The bohemian atmosphere is fake. and nothing much to see except very expensive restaurants with arrogant waiters !

Take a walk here. The streets are small and full of interesting shops. The artists painting on the side of the street give this place its unique touch.
There are very good eating places in the area!

LOVE THE LITTLE VILLAGE ON THE HILL. This area will surprise you! Once you make it to the top of the stairs, be sure to walk around the back where it opens up into a lovely little village with tons of shops, restaurants, artists etc.
Lots to see!. One of my favourite places in Paris. Watch out for the small vineyard behind Sacre Coeur. Great place to people watch in the artists square eating a crepe!

So pretty. Obviously this place is a crazy tourist trap...which doesn't make it any less awesome. Beware of pickpocketers, and people trying to put braided bracelets on you. Get your portrait done and buy really great post cards.
That which makes Paris great. Reward for having to negociate the traffic to get to Paris. Enjoy.

MUST SEE beautiful view from the top and just sooo beautiful quarter. So beautiful and romantic go there in the late afternoon youll see all of paris and stay until the evening paris at moonlight its just wow . take a little walk around the area and walk down back to the center simply unforgettable!

You can't leave Paris without passing by there. Totally artistichal... great atmosphere, great people, good prices on the streets to by souvenirs from Paris, cheaper that other touristic places... enjoy the visit and eat something around there, may brasseries and patisseries

Magical....walking Montmarte. Monmarte , Paris Walking this district- start from the graves just off the metro, the one 1 like the most is of the singer Da lisa.Past the garves up to the old charming studios of tester years, spot a few of the windmills left out, up to the wineries. As you walk up the stairs don't miss looking down to get peek sneaks of the amazing city below.The loveliest is to spot the golden dome of Napoleans tomb! up around the winding allies walk up to the Dali museum.The artist corner...filled with musicians , painters showcasing their art. laze at a cafe , grab a wrap and coffee and watch the sun about to go down in the backdrop of the stunning city, at the cathedral. Walk back or take the train down to Pigalle, strangely appealing, though supposedly sleazy, visit the sex museum and catch a show and dinner at the amusing Moulin Rouge. It has been 7 years...each image and moment still vivid in my mind...

Lovely location - great views - charming cobblestone streets. Even knowing that Montmartre is not considered as artistic as it used to be by the locals with a very strong inclination to the tourist population it is still a charming place to visit with the beautiful narrow streets and old cafes where the artists used to gather.The square where the artists exhibit their art is quite touristy buy if you have patience to go around you can find some original paintings of the city amongst all the caricatures being made on the spot. At the top is Sacre Coeur Church that unfortunately is full of people selling tacky replicas of the Eiffel tower and they can be quite pushy and intimidating towards you sometimes.

Amazing by day and by night. A must see, during the day, wander around and watch the artists at work and explore the many art galleries... by night the streets come alive and the atmosphere is incredible. I had read that it was a seedy and unsafe place at night, but providing you stick to the main streets, and considering the French eat late and the restaurants stay open late there are plenty of people around and I felt safe there at night whilst there were people still on the streets.
Wayyy too touristy. This place is like a toy town, and the Sacre Cour isn't nearly as impressive as I thought it would be.
Go By Night. Great for people watching and have a funny potrait done is a must

Another part of Paris, you should not miss. If you are planning a trip to Paris, don’t miss the grand Montmartre, the highest Paris hill at 130 meters. Beside the famous Sacre Coeur Basilica (the big white church) and lovely Moulin de La Galette, one of the last windmill in Montmartre. Take a stroll at the Place du Tertre, where the legends of 20th century artist used to roam. Now, the many painters or street artist are ready to sketch your beautiful face but bear in mind, it is expensive. The streets are also lined with cafés, do spend some times relax and try the delicious steamed mussels in white wine and a glass of champagne and round up with a cup of latte and macaroon or crepe chocolate with banana in a charming ambience. The price is reasonable. Not forgotten, Montmartre is famous for its steps. The steps are classic with lined by pretty lampposts and deciduous trees. It is a good place to snap a few romantic photos. There are often street musician who perform at the bottom of the steps.One can walk your way up to the hill, if you are physical fit or you can choose to take a small white ‘mini train’ ride through the narrow alley and up to the hill. At the top, the view is the most spectacular in Paris. At night, the view is even more impressive. Tips :1. Take a metro and stop at Blanche Station, start your walk from here. 2. funicular service which you can ride to the top if you are the elder.
Romantic place. A nice place to visit, see artists and relax wih a good glass of wine...but its expensive. You can let the artisits make a painting of yourself.

Take Discoverwalk meet at metro Blanche opp Moulin Rouge - fantastique!. Our party consisted of grandma and our 4.5 year old son.We visited Valentines Day a Tuesday and took a Discover walk tour. Caught the METRO and got off at Blanche station to meet our guide Phillipe.The metro stop is right opposite MOULIN ROUGE. Our guide was fanastique and most knowledgable, his passion for this neighborhood was addictive and charming. To sum up Montmarte =souveniour shopping, sex district, (we avoided these parts as travelling with a child this is where our guide was very helpful!)and of course a look at local produce no supemarket in this area every thing is there and fresh fresh fresh! Bohemian feel with lots of vintage shops clothes homewares everything!It was a steep and winding walk upto Sacre Coeur but we didnt notice much as so much to see! Highly recommend going later in the day and watching the sunset at sacre cour church on the hill. You will even see the `Eiffel tower lightup every hour on the hour whilst buskers entertain you on a huge flight of stairs directly opposite the church. Wear your walking shoes and take plenty of cash ladies you could go crazy shopping here! Watch out for pickpokets too. Great district buzzing with a truly unique vive that is Paris! TIP: Take Discover walk these guys KNOW paris and will save you time and you get to see things you wont see on other tours. `Suggested fee for walking tour is 10 euros per person attending =cheap for what you recieve in return which is a real education!If you dont like walking and have a bad back dont go.Recommended.If going to sacre ceour be aware streets are NOT PRAM FRIENDLY due to condition and steep hills!Not busy as we travelled low season.

beautiful and quiet -. An uncrowded and trendy part of the city - very artistic. We stayed in Montmatre and walked to the local bakery each morning for fresh bagettes and croissants - amazing! The streets are quiet and very pretty - with lots of little cafes scattered about.Its generally not as expensive as the main parts of the city. It was so relaxing to explore and see where we ended up or what we found.

Art, dinning and winning. This is my first time to go to this place in winter, i went before twice but it was summer time. In summer the place was very crowded at night, painters are in the center of the square painting and selling their paints, the restorants surronding the squre were very crouded and i had to wait half an hour to find a table to set to. In this time in December the place have little people, though there was a small christmas market, the restaurants were empty and the atmosphere was completely different than in summer. I advise travellers to visit this fantastic place but not in winter.

Worth to go... Montmarte is probably one of the coolest places in Paris. Once you finish Sacre Coeur, head down to the street. You can buy many kinds of souvenirs from some little shops. But some of them are real tourist traps. My friend wanted to buy a bottle of water and she was told that it was 2 €. You could also ask some artists (!) in the street to have your charcoal drawing.

Lovely day trip for art and biscuits and pommes frites. Love the walk and souvenir shopping here, as well as the picturesque biscuit shops and gallette shops. Fun to have caricature or sketches of family. Fois gras and pommes frites for lunch.
Cool Area to Visit. Great area to walk around, browse the shops, walk to the sacre ceour and viewing point of the city.

One of the best areas in Paris. This area is very special as it has it's own spirit - artistic, cosy, charming... The Montmartre is unforgettable. Take a walk outside of touristic noisy streets and go deeper inside the hill, you will find beautiful small narrow streets where local people are living, their houses are so different and outstanding. You can find even private vineyard in the heart of the area, it's awesome. Don't spare a couple of hours and walk around, Montmartre is worth visiting, don't miss it's real Paris obviously. I'll definitely come back there when return to Paris.

Beautiful!!!. This was one of the best places I visited while in Paris! This is not typically the number one place tourists think to go but they should. It's absolutely beautiful and a great view! And getting up there you pass lots of cute cafes. Great for a Sunday brunch activity. Plan a few hours if you are walking up and stopping at a cafe. The Monmartre itself doesn't take long to go through. It's mostly neat from the outside.

Wonderful.. It was a slightly wet day, but after the long step climbing adventure, we reached the gorgeous front of the montmartre, where we were met by a group of south american dancers, although they were busking they provide a good 100 people with hilarious entertainment, dancing etc... and from this point you can see over the landmarks of paris. Beautiful.

You need to visit, but the spirit of Montmartre is declining. We visited Montmartre on our first trip in 2007 & loved this neighbourhood. We walked through all the streets and little shops. This time around we were there for an hour & left. It is dirty, there is beggars everwhere. The bracelet sellers & gamblers are taking over where ever you go. We didn't had such a great experience this time around. You need to visit Montmartre on a trip to Paris, just be street smart!

A true escape. A must see if visiting Paris. We visited Montmarte on a Sunday, we spent the day meandering the small old Parisian streets and shops, watching the artists undertaking their work and sipping coffee at a typical French cafe. Spectacular views over Paris and so relaxing and enjoyable.

The best place to people watch in Paris. There are so many little winding streets here and little cafes to sit back and enjoy the ever changing view. This does have a reputation as a tourist trap, but it is ever so charming that it is impossible to resist! The atmosphere here what most envision old Paris to be about. Highly recommended!!!
Not missing much. We wanted to see Montmartre, the streets are pretty dirty and there are alot of sex shops along the street. Not for kids.

Beautiful. Montmartre is beautiful to see both in the daytime as well as at night. The only negative I have about Montmartre is from our first night in Paris. We had gone to see this beautiful view in the day, and decided to return after dinner once the sun had gone down. We were sitting on the steps enjoying the view and live music when all of a sudden a fight broke out and someone kicked then punched the singer. I'm sure this doesn't happen all of the time, but it was enough to make us uncomfortable and not return at night again.

The neveending symbol of Paris.. Located in the north of Paris in the 18th arrondissement, Montmartre has long been known as the premier artist's enclave in the city. Symbol of a lavishing and colorful bélle époque, Montmartre( "mountain of the martyr",derived from the martyrdom of Saint Denis), this is a touristic must-see.As a designated historic area, little development is allowed in Montmartre so, thankfully, it has retained much of its character and village-like charm. Just walking around the district is a treat, but if you want to do some sightseeing or cultural visits, head to the Musée de Montmartre, where artist Maurice Utrillo once lived and painted, as well as the mansion behind it, which was once occupied by Renoir.A trip to the Montmartre Cemetery is also in order, and guests can view the graves of many great artists. Of course, you may also want to take in dinner and a show at Moulin Rouge or one of the many other nightclubs in the neighborhood. Oh, and don't forget to search for the little Musée Salvador Dali. If you appreciate the artist, you'll love it!

Worth a Few Hours, a Little Overrated.. There's the world famous Moulin Rouge and tons of bars and souvenir shops. At night the area looks alive with all the lights but beneath the surface there are shady people and everything is overpriced and low quality. Some small stuff I bought at souvenir shops here was falling apart when I got home. I went on a pub tour here and was told there are more scams in this area than most places in Paris. There are many glamourous looking sex shops which are nothing more than an adult DVD store in the US. I visited the erotic museum which was ok. This place is worth walking around in and there are major attractions in the area (as noted on previous posts) which overshadow the downside but considering this is in Paris, I could think of many other places I'd rather walk around in.
Best view of the city. It is a really tall building, and you get a great 360-degree view of the city, including a great view of The Eiffel Tower. There is an indoor and an outdoor view.
Very touristy. pick pocketers everywhere, keep and eye on the people casing you

A lovely piece of history. On our first trip to Paris, stayed in Montmartre because we found a good deal on an apartment (through Vacation in Paris - very good!). It was lovely to be amidst the history of Lautrec, Picasso, Van Gogh and Dali, the Moulin Rouge, and Sacre Coeur. And 'Amelie" of course. The shops and cafes are very trendy. The cobblestone, windy, narrow streets are quaint. Convenient to central Paris via metro stops on two different lines, to the bus and train stations, make Montmarte a great base and visit wherever else you want to go. Beware of the portrait artists around the Sacre Coeur - they are harmless, but swarm (my teenage daughter didn't feel comfortable).
Do you reall ywant that portrait?. Too many bad artists. Too touristy. Too crowded. Disappointing.

High on a hill in Paris. High on a hill overlooking Montmartre Village stands the impressive Sacre Couer Basillica. This will be described in a separate review.The village is a maze of streets on which are situated the inevitable souvenir shops. The wares that they sell are many. The majority of items being made in China. Some of the goods are reasonable, some are tacky and cheap looking. The choice is of course the buyers. There are numerous roadside cafes where one can rest, eat and drink. The beauty of doing this of course is that you can watch the world and the many people go by. The village was also in the past the home to many famous artists such as Picasso.To day, in the village square, which is called Place du Tetre many artists ply their talents. Paintings and drawings that depict the Eiffel Tower, portraits,still life and many other subjects abound. The prices are varied like the quality of the work.It is an area that has atmosphere and is certainly worth spending time after visiting the Sacre Coeur

Paris views without the Haussmann effect. Montmartre is one of those neighborhoods that not only affords you great views of the city below, but offers a glimpse of the Paris of old, rather than the remade Paris of Haussmann. Well worth visiting time and again if only to wander about and hopefully get lost for a while.

The hill. One of the highest hills of Paris, full of attractions. Tourists usually visit the Sacre-Coeur and Place du Tertre. I syggest to take the time to go around the hill, and feel the atmosphere - both of ancient times and current lodgings. Look at www.theParisMap.com and find all that there is to see.
Vibrant and Interesting. An area with beautiful small roads and wonderful outdoor cafes. Would visit again.
Indie and funky.. Great restaurants and a relaxed, indie feel on the streets. Loved it!

A Must See. A trip to Paris would not be complete without a visit to Montmartre. First you have to take a look at the beautiful Sacre Coeur Church and see the inside of the church. From the church you have wonderful views of the city and it is a good place to take photos.Then you can wander the square where you find the artists selling their paintings. All the buildings seem to be picturesque and it is interesting to enter the small stores and see what they have to sell.

Looking for Lautrec?. Some things never change and it may be corny, but there's nothing like getting a family member's sketch done as an unforgettable memory of Paris. Scout around for the best talent before negotiating a price but don't be cheap. These artists work hard and out in the elements even in the winter.

White house of peace Montmartre. Because up there you pray for Peace it is worth climbing the long stairs or taking the funicular to the Montmartre church, which is really stunning. The view form the top is the ultimate reward.

Beware!!. A lovely quaint suberb of Paris, nice little food and souvenier shops, artists market and much much more. HOWEVER as you go up the road to Sacre Cour there are 4 or 5 gangs of con artists that are 'hiding a counter under 3 large counters' and encouraging you to play along. They have 2 or 3 young people "winning" who are obviously part of the con and they want 50 euros to play. Just beware as it is so easy to stand there and get drawn into the game. Luckily we guessed what was going on so avoided it. Some didn't and got caught out but as there are groups of 4-5 you cannot make anyone aware as they look like they would 'sort you out'. Just be careful and avoid them!!!

Nice place to visit, but watch out for the tourist "traps"!!!. This is a nice place to visit on your way to Sacre Coeur with all of the ambiance of a bustling Paris. However, do not fall for the people who want to wrap strings around your fingers or who want to sell you something. These people just want to get into a fight so that they can steal your wallet or purse when you are not looking. The place is nice and safe to walk through, but just be street smart!

Too many tourists. Good location and nice views of Paris if it's a clear day. Otherwise it's yet another tourist trap and a average catholic church. If you choose to go, go early ahead of the crowds. Not a must!

Savour the ambience. I love the Sacre Couer and the market place with the artists everywhere. It's very touristy, but watching the world go by at a street cafe is a must do, and there is no better place than here to do it!

Really?. So, other than the Basilica de Sacre-Coeur, we've got strip clubs, sex shops, tourist-trap restaurants, hack "artists" trying to sketch your portrait and scammers trying to steal your money. Maybe "in its day", it was an artists community, but those days are long gone. Skip it.
It used to be the place. I like touring this area just because of the history of jazz and art. It was truly a hot spot in Paris in the 1920s and 30s.
Okay site, view is beautiful but a bit too touristy.. Take the walk up to the top of the duomo. The view of Paris is amazing. Otherwise, mostly tourist type shops in that area.

The Most Beautiful Parisian Neighborhood. Montmartre impresses since you step in the neighborhood. The Sacré Coeur, its steep stairs. The whole place, its restaurants, Amelie's restaurant, the ambience, the smell of crepes and fresh bread.

Love! Love! Love Montmartre!. If I could live anywhere in Paris it would be in Montmartre. Quaint and yet edgy, urban and suburban, this area has it all. From one corner to the next there are patissaries, boulangieries, poissonaries, cafes, bars, restaurants, groceries, wine shops and every type of store and boutique imaginable. This is the real Paris.The Blvd de Clichy which could be called it's "Red Light District" is a busy strip with all types of people; prostitues, pimps, families out for a walk after dinner, elderly couples walking to the grocery, college students and business men all mix and mingle going about their daily business with no class distinctions. The famous Moulin Rouge and metro are conveniently located on this street, as well as a metro on almost every other block for easy access.I was a single, female traveler, walking alone in all parts of this area and I felt safer than I have in my own city in the USA. All you have to do is follow common sense, blend in and use situational awareness, which everyone should do no matter where you are living.I love sitting in the front tables of the different bars and cafes late at night people watching while having a good beer, glass of wine and a French cigarette. Everyone was helpful and kind, just as long as you try to speak French in greeting. I will say that you do have to be a bit aggressive for certain situations,when standing in line for boarding trains, getting drinks at bars, etc; there is a different level of politeness then you find in Paris. It is sort of every man for himself. If you are too slow, someone will step in front of you without apologizing for it. Aggressive politeness? Something like that.Note: People in Paris allow their pets to relieve themselves on the sidewalk. Watch were you are walking because it is not mud you are stepping in.The Basilica Sacre Coeur was the first place I went upon arriving and I was brought to tears by the beauty of all of Paris, as far as the eye can see. I didn't feel the need to go up in the Eiffel Tower after seeing Paris from the Basilica.If I could live anywhere in Paris, it would be Montmartre. It is not the high-end, glamourous, overly polished Paris that the bourgeois like to shop around (Champs Elysee), but the real Paris that feels like coming home.
local artists. Brilliant area to visit and maybe get yourself sketched or painted by a local artist fun area just having a drink and watching everybody

Not what I expected. We found it a little dirty. To crowded for my taste. We went to visit the Sacre Coir on Sunday, I don´t recomend it , to many people. Good view of the city from the church explanade. Beware of your belongings if you go to Montmatre.

Half a day.. Spend half a day, it would be more than enough. Felt very local parisian. To note: Be very careful as there are many "artists'' there trying to con you. Especially if you are dressed to look very tourist-alike. Good shopping district to get local souvenirs as well.

A village within Paris. A seat by the white-domed Basilica of the Sacré Cœur is a great place for viewing Paris from a very different world. I reached Montmartre on metro L12 in the afternoon. From Abbesses station walking uphill few minutes towards Rue Norvins, I found myself stepping on a classic town of boutique taverns and traditional bakeries. Ever since Rue Norvins has housed lines of pubs which must be favorite haunts of such artists as Van Gogh or Picasso who used to live around the area. Via olden Saint Pierre church, I was en route for the Basilica of the Sacred Heart sitting on the summit. From the highest point of the city, the hill afforded me a simply breathtaking landscape. Thereby the glimpse of Paris skyline was so flawless that even a sneak peek from the above of Eiffel Tower or Notre Dame tower could not compare with. What is more, Montmartre won my best favor for its unique surroundings. Passing Louis Michel Square in front of the Basilica, I met another vintage shopping street from which Moulin Rouge is in few minute walk afar and altogether promises the best nightlife for visitors of hoards.

Rainy day in Montmartre. On a recent trip to Paris we spent a rainy afternoon in Montmartre . From our hotel We walked up from our hotel and went into a few of the shops. A good vintage clothes shop with some good designer pieces. Just a shame that the two american women who were working in there showed such little interest in engaging with their customers, showing little passion about the clothing and no interest in being helpful. A little further we found a charming cafe on the corner and had a nice bowl of onion soup for lunch. The cafe was busy with a comfortable cozy atmosphere. After lunch we mounted the steps up towards the top of the hill and once there found ourselves in some very pretty cobbled streets approaching a beautiful piazza with lots of restaurants/cafe's around the edges and in the centre many artists with their easels and their work whichMostly consisted of portraits of people that they have attempted to draw. The ability of the work varied between competent and beginners. Some technically very good and many different styles. We had a wander around and one of the artists, An older man approached me to sit for him and have my portrait done. He said that he would do it in 10mins. I glanced at his easel to get an idea of the price and I am sure it said 10 euros. After seeing this I thought that it was not too expensive and that it would make a good memento of our trip. After some time of sitting for the portrait I was shown the drawing which I was not convinced had been successful in the artists attempt of capturing my likeness. He then produced a typed bit of paper that had 70 euros and 50 euros printed on it. He asked me to pay 50 euros discounted from 70 euros. I refused to pay the 50 euros and although I didn't think that the artist was hassling me too much i felt that I had been misled. I ended up negotiating a price of 35 euros which as an artist myself didn't mind paying as he obviously had some talent and was after all trying to make a living through his art but I think I paid too much in terms of the piece itself. We then wandered around for a bit but realised the shops in the immediate vicinity were very tourist driven so made our way up to Sacre Coeur. As we entered the Cathedral there was a service taking place. It was a magnificent place very warm beautiful music which made me think of Faure's Requiem and exquisitely crafted mosaics of gold leaf. There is also a strange mural of Jesus and the disciples on the ceiling that looked like something out of a comic book. There were loads of candles lit in the church 2 euros for a small nightlight and 10 euros for a big pint glass sized one. We walked in a big circle around the sides if the cathedral along with many other visitors and thoroughly enjoyed the experience. A good example of a functioning church and a tourist destination operating in a symbiotic way and well organised. It was very uplifting and an elevating experience and a great end to the afternoon. After leaving the cathedral we looked out on to a spectacular and impressive view over Paris and descended towards Pigalle.

Look out for the restaurants!. Missed this area the last time. Actually was very nice. Just be on your toes for ripoffs. Too many "artists" plying their wares. And the only place we ate that robbed us. Nice views of the city.

La Boheme.... Montmartre on a rainy day is the best ! So Parisian....so typical for those years-the 20's.... Wear good shoes, as it is all in cobblestone going up and down. A glass of hot wine in a cafe on those narrow streets, a climb in the funiculaire to the Sacre Coeur, a splendid view on Paris from atop, a visit to the Musee Montmartre and don't forget the Lapin Agile land mark or the painters in Place du Tertre......Aznavour caught it best in his song ' La Boheme', trust me !!!
Artist heaven. Lots of artists dispalying lots beautiful work in a plaza like atmosphere. Most even take visa cards

So many artists ... so little patience with them. This artist's area is absolutely worth the trip. The artists are hugely talented ... and they're everywhere. So remember: this is a buyer's market. You don't need to insult and artist by offering a LOT less money for a personalized work, but definitely make at least one counter offer. We met a guy who wanted to sketch my daughter in the street. He started at 30 euro. As I politely said, "No thanks" and started walking away, the price went to 25. "Maybe later" and the price went to 20."OK. I'll come back in 20 minutes" and the price dropped to 15 euro. Not all artists are as flexible, but like I said, it's a buyer's market. The work is all ... to some extent ... beautiful. But results DO vary, so remember:Your best bet is to say "no" to every personalized offer until you've looked around the square, because odds are very good that 10 steps away from your 20-euro sketcher is a 30-euro painter who has just finished a perfect painting of another family. You will find artists in this crowd who can do an exceptional job of capturing the look in your daughter's eye. There are others who just want to get the artwork done and get your money. Be very selective.This place is surrounded by restaurants and great food ... and heck, you'll need to use the facilities anyway. Remember, if you sit outside and face the square, you WILL be approached by artists who WILL start sketching you just because "you're stunning." And then, they'll ask you for 30 euro and act insulted when you refuse. Again, if you really want the portrait, the artist needs to do it right. As far as accessibility ... you can reach it by subway and then take a lift up to the square. I have serious concerns about accessible restrooms ... as most joints in France seem to come standard with extremely steep staircases to a restroom below. It's a charming little spot to visit ... and the view of the city from St. Pierre is stunning. The artists are amazing. But be tough and don't pay for what you really don't want.

Sadly shrunk. I always love looking at the artwork in the square. The economy appears to have effected the artists. Far fewer of them on this visit. Stil a beautiful area with great views of the city.

skip!!!. Skip Montmartre. It is filled with shady looking people who look like they are about to steal your stuff. As one Parisian told us on the subway: it is the Bronx of Paris: you do not go to Bronx as a tourist, so why should you go there!

Walking Tour Montmatre District. Great walking tour of the Montmartre district. Lots of information provided in a light and humerous way by our guide Camille. Took in sights such as the cafe from Amelie :-) , the Moulin Rouge site of course ..Van Gogh's residence while he lived in the area, Sacre Coeur - with time for a quick look inside, the Agile Rabbit Cabaret site, the Vineyard, the last windmill in Montmartre, the fountain where St Denis washed his loped head, the place where Picasso lived , and other quirky pieces from the area including some little space Invader icons. Finished the tour with a lovely glass of wine. The walk was very easy and the streets were not crowded where we walked. Highly recommended.
Montmartre. Montmartre is a great place to stay. Fantastic views of the city, great shopping and dining. Also more peaceful and quiet than Latin Quarter. More to do than around the Eiffel Tower.
Still a gem. Don't miss the tiny village of Montemartre, especially on top of the hill behind Sacre Coeurs.

Beautiful but let down by the hawkers. An amazing and beautiful place but sadly let down by the masses of immigrant hawkers selling rubbish souvenirs. The city council needs to act on this. Go early in the morning if you want to miss the crowds. Unfortunately you probably won't miss the hawkers.

The painters of old. Lots of very interesting things to see. We did a 2 hour walking trip with pariswalks.com
The best way to see any part of Paris . So much history you miss without a guide
Renior's home. Van gogh apartment , Toulouse-lautrec home

Midnight in Paris. reminded me the movie. this was the second time I was in Paris and love this area very much. It's so nice to chat with local people at cafes and restaurants and the art gallery was wonderful with its very special gift items. Souvenir shops were nice and ofcourse watching the painters were so nice.

Disappointing. We stayed at a B&B in Montmartre and that was a mistake for several reasons, including that it took half an hour by Metro to get anywhere. The main street has the Moulin Rouge and several erotic enterprises which attracts a lot of tourists. We went up the hill to see the Sacre Coeur which was very popular with young people.

Picturesque but go early to avoid crowds. Always beautiful but boy a tourist trap! The most expensive cafes in town!! Do explore the side streets by the Lapin 'Agile & the lovely Museum of Montmatre you will see the chat noir!! Great views of the city.

Lovely Neighborhood. We took the metro to Abbesses (I'm pretty sure), where there is a very long spiral staircase to get out. Just beware. From there, it's a short walk to the funicular to get up to the top, near Sacre Coeur. The funicular is included in the Paris Transportation Pass. It was cramped and smelly, but better than all of the steps it would otherwise take to get to the top. Sacre Coeus is lovely, as is the whole neighborhood. We wandered down the hill towards the Moulin Rouge and saw lots of pretty buildings and alleys. There are plenty of shops and cafes on the hill, just know they're pretty expensive. The Moulin Rouge is very small from the outside. As a fan of the movie, I wanted a picture opportunity. I knew the elephant was gone, but I still expected more. Ah, well. The shows are very expensive, so we didn't go to see one. (yes, children over 6 are allowed)
Cool nice area. Small but nice artist ares. Small local resturans with nice Franch food. you can have a half day visit there. The way up is full with arabs, but on the hill it is nice and quite.

nice atmosphere. yes every time i come to paris i come to monmartre this is a must for mei like looking to these painters trying to sell their paintings and making the portraits for the people passing bysomething new this year ,, too many artists working on cutting your portrait in a piece of paper nice you have to bargain to have the good price and before this try to find the best artist between the ones present ( some artists are not here every day )

Best place to see..... Montmartre could be the best place to be in Paris...u can see the highest hill ....and it is so magical...with all the musicians...the painters....the crepes caffes...it was one amazing night....i was drawed by a frensh painter and it was so lovely!
Same city but totally different to rest of Paris!. Lovely around here, beautiful shops and eateries and lovely and quite at this time of year!

I'd rather be in Paris. As a true travel enthusiast, I am always happiest on a trip. Recently, my mother gave me a bracelet that says, "I'd rather be in Paris" and it is true. There is really no where I would rather be than Paris. A perfect trip to Paris includes a visit to Montmartre where strolling the square and wandering in galleries is de rigueur. But, first I stop in at Fragonnard, the best place for a true souvenir- something special & elegant to remember your visit to France. Then, I take the steps or funicular and once I've arrived up top, I stop for the best view of the city that seems to spreads out forever. There's time for a brief stop inside Sacre Coeur to contemplate life and give thanks. Then I follow the cobblestone streets and just wander. Stop in for a bite at le Moulin de la galette or for a fresh macaroon at the biscuiterie de Montmartre. I prefer to make Montmartre my first stop of the day, it's a completely different experience after dark...

Dont give Montmarte market a miss!. If you visit Sacre Coeur, make sure you go around the Montmarte market. its a bustling little place full of life and colour. Quite literally, since there are lot of artists painting on the spot and its awesome to just watch. And a lot of stuff to buy, that is if you have the money!

Amazing view!. Montmartre is a must-see when you are in Paris! It's a very nostalgic part of the city. The view was amazing! The hill is around 130m high, with 300 stairs. There is also a monorail if you don't want to walk. If you have a ticket from the public transport( i had a day ticket)than it's free.The place is very crowded during weekends. The best thing to do is to go eaurly during the week. During the night is also very nice! It's nice to sit on the stairs and eat something. There are a lot of streetartist to enjoy you.

Painters, Shopping, and Cog Rail to a View. Taking the Cog Rail (fee) up to Montmartre in Paris was a fun way to gain a good view of the city. We found a huge crowd on the steps to the Sacre Couer Basillica enjoying the evening, a puppet show, painters and good food. A good mix of tourists and citizens of Paris enjoying their city. We would return again if in Paris and have a painting especially made for our home. You can climb up the stairs for free or ride the cog for a fee. Check in advance for tours of the Basillica, and with several restaurants for seating availablity.

come and night and enjoy the views, the basilica, the masses on the steps and the tricket salesmen. Got the M12 metro to Abbesses. You can take the funicular railway nearly to the very top, or get your walking shoes on for lots of steps. If you are feeling lazy you can drive/taxi to the top. You will be greeted by a mass of people sat on the steps admiring the view of Paris. Shame you can not see the Eiffel tower (unless they cut a few big trees down). The Sacre-Coeur is serenely lit on the outside. Go inside and admire the beauty and the masses of candles. Back outside you'll be pestered by the tricket salesmen who do an interesting range of glow-in-the-dark toys that you throw in the air (and I assume loose) and well as flashing Eiffel towers. This just adds to the atmosphere. If you have a spare hour then it is worth it. You can always play "count the steps" with the kids.

montmatre district tour.. Definetly recomend the tour www.neweuropetour.eu we did the montmartre District Tour. They also have it in spanish... 12euros and you will walk around and have a great experiencie.

Great place to watch the sunset over Paris. This is a great place to see the sunset over Paris and the Basicica Sacre-Coeur is beautiful on this inside. But that is all Montmarte has to offer. The place is crowed with the local riffraff selling all of the cheap trinkets and when the sun goes down the stairs at the front becomes an outdoor bard with new riffraff now selling glass bottles of beer and 2 or 3 guys are having a sing a-long. This pushed me over the edge, this is a religious site and there seems to be no religion there. Also, watch out for the “String” guys at the end or the funicular. They want to try a string around your wrist and then push you into giving them euros for it. I would go at sunset but leave quickly.

The highlight of our Paris vacation!. If you've read any of my other reviews of our Paris trip, you know we had a hotel in a great location for seeing all of the sites along the Seine -- but the highlight of our trip was our walks to Montmartre. My wife and I walked from our hotel in the 8th ARR two evenings in a row. It's abut a 4-5 mile round trip and a bit strenuous considering all of the steep streets and steps to get to the top, but once we arrived, it was all well worth it.Montmarte has the Sacre Coeur as its centerpiece, but our favorite spot was the square, lined with wonderful shops and restaurants -- and a real feeling of old Paris. In fact, it feels so perfect both me and my wife though it seemed more like something Disney would have created -- but it's the real deal. If we visit Paris again -- and we would love to -- the one thing we'll repeat is our visits to Montmartre,
A place not to miss.. A place not to miss.Mythical place, with street artists (painters, portraitists) and one of the most magnificent views over the city.

Ooozing history. From the Moulin Rouge to all the haunts of the greatest artists and writers in the last 150 years the bohemian quarter provides a variety to Paris. the Square is delightful, as you will have thirty offers to have your portrait, caricature, or profile painted drawn or cut. the artists are selling original, the cafe's cater to tourists....still fun....

So many steps!. Great for a visit, but i would never choose to stay here unless you are a mountain hiker and want to stay in shape. Too exhausting and on cobblestones. Great area of Paris - a must see - but go prepared to either debark at Lamarack Caulincourt metro at the top (apologize for the spelling errors) or take the funicular. Be wise at the steps of the Sacre Coeur.

Beautiful Old Neighborhood. There is a lot to see and experience in this neighborhood. We went in early October, 2011 and were there during their annual Wine Harvest Festival. A great way to spend a day.

you have to spend an evening here. One of the highlights of our trip to Paris last year and this year too was an evening in Montmartre... have a croque madame at Clarion de Chasseur and listen too the good guitarists with a glass of wine or a nice beer. Then walk around, take in Sacre Coeur, but beware the artists who want to do your portrait.... you very well might end up with something that looks nothing like you... there are a few scam artists floating around... don't expect the best...Nice atmosphere and old world style ... I gather that it is forbidden to change anything there... like a heritage site... good, because that is what makes it Montmartre.

Scenic but crowded neighborhood. We strolled through Montmartre on a surprisingly busy Christmas Day. It was one of the few areas in Paris that was open for business that afternoon, so we enjoyed a filling lunch at a neighborhood bistro and a pastry from a boulangerie. It was a great way to spend the afternoon, but it was incredibly crowded.One of us had been to Montmartre on previous visits to Paris, in the spring and the summer, and remarked that it was equally busy on those occasions. There must always be massive crowds around local icons like Café des Deux Moulins (from Amelie) and the Sacré Couer. The area is packed with tacky tourist trap shops selling poor Toulouse-Lautrec and Degas reproductions and hastily made crepes, while modern day artists vie to paint portraits of passersby for cash. They probably make a good living selling to the tourists crowding the area's main streets.Don't let this intimidate you, Montmartre is worth visiting, especially if you explore the area behind Sacré Couer. The backstreets are full of attractive homes, including several by esteemed architects. That is also where you'll find the only operational vineyard in all of Paris. Just down from the vineyard is the famous Lapin Agile. We haven't been, but friends of ours enjoyed a really fun evening there. The view of Paris from the front of the Sacré Couer is devastatingly beautiful, and the view from the top is more so. It's worth dealing with the crowds for that world class view. And take a few minutes to explore the Montmartre Cemetery. We joined up with other cinephiles to pay our respects to Francois Truffaut, who is among the notable Parisians buried there.

An out-of-the-way gem. Relative to other attractions in Paris, Montmarte is somewhat far removed, but it is easily reachable by Metro (Anvers stop) and definitely worth the trip. The white-domed Sacre-Coeur (visible in the distance from other landmarks like the Eiffel Tower and Arc de Triomphe) sits on the highest point in Paris, and the view from atop the many white steps is impressive. A short walk behind the church and around the corner leads to side streets filled with shops and cafes and then to Place du Tertre, a square filled with artists at work, with more shops and cafes around its perimeter. Although I agree that it is rather touristy, this area is steeped in culture (birthplace of the term "bistro" no less) and is overall rather charming and relaxing, so much so that we even returned later in our trip to take another look around.Practical info: Once you get off the Metro, it's all uphill. You walk a few blocks up a narrow street crowded with souvenir shops to the base of the hill where the steps up to the church begin. There is also a carousel here, not sure why. You can either climb the steps or take the Funiculaire railway/elevator to the (almost) top. We climbed and it was fine. The steps are wide, low-rise, and varied so you can easily go at your own pace, plus you can stop and sit on the steps or the expansive grass at any point to rest and enjoy the view.
