No photos permitted inside the church. On the way to Place du Tertre, artists might approach and ask if you would like them to sketch you or someone in your party, but they were not intrusive at all. We like to pick up some kind of artwork when we travel and this is a good place to do that. All artists were friendly and open to negotiations. One warning: if you buy a painting, make sure it's dry before you pay for it.And about those gypsies: You will likely run into a few (faux) deaf-mute girls with clipboards at nearly every tourist attraction you visit in Paris. These are gypsies looking for money (we were informed by a tour guide) and there did seem to be more of them at Sacre-Coeur. Simply shake your head or wave them away and they won't bother you. The guys with the string that other reviews have mentioned are the same. They might look more intimidating, but simply ignore, walk past, and you're fine. I noticed a couple of women get freaked out by them and run away, a spectacular overreaction. You are warned of pickpockets everywhere, but we did not have a problem. Anyway, these distractions are only around the lower level of the steps. Once you're past that, you won't run into them again. And nobody bothers you on the way down.
A must see. Take a day preferably a sunny day to explore the amazing little town and its artists. Relax in the main court and take in the surroundings. IRS a busy lively place with lots of atmosphere

Enjoy - Don't be Afraid. I had read reviews about visiting Montmartre and the cons in the area. We visited on a weekday, during the day, and had a wonderful time. We did encounter the "deaf" girls shoving the petitions in our faces, but just walked right by. After all, they are supposed to be deaf and not able to speak, right? So, they can't even yell at you to stop. So non-threatening, it's almost funny. Once we passed them I turned around and they were chatting to one another as they waited for the next visitor to come up the steps from where they were standing. We also encountered the "string scam" and simply did not stop walking, speak to or look at the men. None of the cons physically tried to stop us or abuse us in any way. My main point is that visitors should not stay away from Montmartre due to frightening reviews they may have read on this site. I also want to say that I feel badly for people who have had wallets, purses, etc. stolen, but it is truly easy to avoid this kind of heartache. Keep larger sums of cash and credit cards in a wallet made to be worn inside of slacks. Keep passports stowed away safely in your hotel room. My husband carried a backpack and I had a smallish size handbag all the time. But the items we kept in these bags were of no great value, and if they had been taken from us, the joke would have been on the thief. Enjoy your time in Paris, and do not miss Montmartre.

Best view in town. Monmartre is a must on your agenda during your visit to Paris. Time has just about stood still in this part of the city with its narrow cobble stone streets, old houses and churches. Be prepared for crowds everywhere; in the streets, cafe's, restaurants churches. I recommend that you visit on a weekday. There are lots to see an experience like Place du Tertre, the Sacre coeur church and Pigalle. Not to forget Moulin Rouge. Sacre Cour is a peacful church, a perfect place to take a breather to calm down. But the best reason for the visit to Monmartre is the panoramic view from the steps in front of the Sacre-Coeur. It is definitely the best view of Paris. I had a light luch on the steps while taking in the view. Just amazing and memorable. Take care and beware of pick pockets in the busy streets then nothing will ruin a truly great experience.

Alway wild and crazy and a must to see!. Montmartre is a must-see in Paris. The view from the Sacré-Cœur steps is always gorgeous even if it is a hazy day. The winding hills are fun to walk; the street performers are entertaining; La Maison Rose is our favorite place to eat. Each year we return to this very touristy area because it is a lot of fun. The church is beautiful inside and out and it's great to be up close and personal to the church you can see from la tour Eiffel or behind the clock in the Orsay on a clear day. All of Paris is "favorite" for us but we always make time for Montmartre.

Montmartre and Sacred Heart. Spent about 4 hours touring Montmartre and Sacred Heart. Did this at the end of July and the site was crowded. Lots of people on the grounds and sitting on the steps. Walked along with the crowds and had lunch at one of the outdoor cafes--watching the artists sketch. A lot of the artists are very good and the portraits are worth the price. Some take longer than others--make sure you watch a few of them sketch their subjects before making your choice. Restaurants are good and the service is fast. Good place to spend a few hours. The view overlooking Paris is spectacular.

Best views of Paris.. We did not have any trouble with street sellers or beggars. The area is interesting some nice cafes. It would have been nice to see the sun go down over Paris but the fact it contains the red light area I don't know if it would be good to visit at night.

Beware of conmen who could rip you off. Beautiful but dangerous.. We took the metro to Montmartre on what was a very pleasant July morning. We had broken away from the fixed itinerary of a package tour to really explore a quaint and interesting area of Paris, or so we thought. But after lunch at a bistro and appreciative stops to listen to street violinists and pick delightful souvenirs at the local shops, we reached the artists' square right before the church where WE HAD ALL OUR MONEY STOLEN. The technique was - a man engaged us in conversation while cutting out a paper silhouette of my daughter - something we had not asked him to do. another couple of men stood around us, also making inane conversation like asking what my son's tattoo signified. Then, the silhouette cutter asked for the sum of 20 euros. Aghast, but feeling obliged to pay, I reached for my purse, which was GONE on the 4th day of our 11 day trip. It was simply awful. I would advise travellers to be very careful of such conmen in this part of Paris. The worst thing was, after stealing our cash, he actually had the gall to blame it on 'little gypsy girls'. We didn't see a single child anywhere there, and pieced together what had happened to us only a while later, after we were over the initial shock.

The old artists quarter. As the high point of Paris at 130 metres or so, Montmartre has it attractions and interests by long association with struggling artists but it is also a bit of touristic cliche. The street artists today are not that gifted generally but it all adds to the colour and in a sense, continues the tradition. Apart from the narrow streets and lanes and houses where famous artists and others once lived, there is a vineyard which produces rather awful wine. The steps of Rue Foyatier and others are also very Montmartre, a fitness fanatic's dream, as well as being popular themes in the rather awful contemporary art produced there. Renoir and Degas are long gone and their talent has gone with them!The most interesting part is the cemetery where there are many now obscure people buried but others of great and lingering fame as well: Degas; Dumas; Nijinsky; Offenbach; Madame Recamier; Emile Zola and also the German writer, Heinrich Heine who is also honored by a statue.Sacre Coeur has a certain interest as well by virtue of its location and sheer dominance at the high point of Paris, but as a building, it is not one of the great edifices of Paris, looking like a giant and over-dressed wedding cake.Still, Montmartre will always be over-run with tourists. Many of the streets running back towards Rue des Abbesses and Rue Le Pic have some interesting shops and of course there is Boulevard de Clichy and Pigalle, which is an interesting shopping precinct, gradually moving upwards in the social scale. Much of the old seediness is going, being replaced gradually by a new chic look and shops to match.Go visit but do so, not expecting too much beyond the overtly touristic.

Montmartre - small village, big contrasts. Montmartre divides opinion - some Trip Advisor reviews rave about it, others hate it.I guess it depends on expectations, and whether you venture away from the tourist traps of the Place du Tertre and the steps of Sacre Coeur.In Place du Tertre on a Saturday afternoon, portrait artists swarm like paparazzi, eager to capture your likeness in charcoal. We didn't find them too pushy - a simple 'non, merci' is enough. If you walk round the back of Sacre-Coeur, the crowds disappear, the nick-nack shops thin out, and you can enjoy the picturesque streets in peace. There is a tiny vineyard, some bijou appartments, elegant villas and the famous Lapin Agile cafe-bar, which features in so many Utrillo paintings. The Moulin de la Galette (as painted by Picasso, Renoir and Van Gogh) is on the top of the hill, to the west of Sacre Coeur.We stayed in rue Theloze, a small street off the rue Abbesses. This is a great area with lots of nice bars and restaurants, walking distance from Abbesses metro and Amelie's cafe des 2 Moulins on rue Lepic. There is a small cinema on rue Theloze, which shows films in their original language.If you are visiting Montmartre for the day, take the metro to Abbesses - it has one of the few remaining Guimard metro entrances and is opposite an interesting Art Nouveau church. All the sights are within walking distance from here (no need to take the tacky tourist train up to the top of the hill!)Further down the hill is the seedier side of Montmartre - sex shops line Boulevard de Clichy from Blanche metro station to Pigalle. My children wanted to see the Moulin Rouge, so we walked round the corner from rue Lepic and took some nice pictures of the windmill on a sunny morning.Around the rue des Trois Freres there are quirky shops and some reasonably priced restaurants. The creperie at number 15 rue des Trois Freres was particularly good. After dinner, walk up the hill to see the Sacre Coeur by night - it is beautifully illuminated and you get a great view of the Eiffel Tower from up there. Even the Place du Tertre seems less tacky after dark.Overall, we loved Montmartre - it was the best place I've ever stayed in eight visits to Paris.The seedy bits and the touristy parts are easily avoided, so don't be put off.

See the city from a quiet view. Smaller number of people and great views. A must do tower's sights are great. Most people don't go here and the number of people was under 100 so very easy to move about and see the Eiffel Tower and every other major site from the roof top. Amazing views to be remembered.Purchase the Paris pass it was included again you will see this statement in almost all of my reviews 141 euros and includeds so much

Montmartre- the best of Paris!. This is one of my favourite parts of Paris ( after disneyland ahah).Montmartre is seriously adorable, there is not a more parisian place than this.Besides having the Sacre- Coeur in the background, you also find all these lovely coffee-shops, art galleries and street artists.You can really feel the spirit of living «la boheme». prices are a bit expensive there, but hey, it's worth it, we are speaking about Montmartre, right?

Beware if you have children. Lovely views yes...but at the cost of having to brave the numerous shady and aggressive street vendors pushing cheap merchandise in your face. Also, streets smelled of urine...unlike other areas of Paris, a very dirty place overall. We went on a national holiday so it was a bit of a mosh pit....if you go, do so on weekdays to avoid the crowds.

Best views in Paris. First of all its right in the heart of the tourist area , so be prepared for crowds , bus cafe's , restaurants ,and everything else the comes with 1000's of people in little narrow cobbled streets.It has retained much of its character over the years, thankfully, and is a great place to visit if in Paris.Place du Tertre,Sacre coeur, Moulin Rouge, Pigalle, its all here and within walking distance .The panoramis views from the steps in front of the Sacre-Coeur is the best place to view down into paris...... the only problem is that on a warm day there is hardly room to move as visitors sit and admire the view. Seek out small restaurants in the back streets awayfrom the crowds for some authentic food and ambience .Beware of pick pockets in the busy streets , (advice from others), not that i was unlucky that way .

Amazing Views but Beware of Pickpockets!. Montmartre absolutely has the most amazing views in Paris! Definitely a photgraphers dream! My only piece of advice seems in line with what another reviewer mentioned. BEWARE of the guys on the steps trying to sell you things. Especially the guys with the string trick... A friend of mine made the mistake of holding out her finger when one so charmingly approached her. A few other guys came around and appeared to be 'watching'... She ended up giving the guy a few coins from her pocket before realizing that her wallet was gone! Quelle Horreur!This is not really meant to scare anyone. These people will leave you well alone if you just give them a firm 'no thanks' or 'not interested.'

Beware of deceptive street hustlers. Attraction is lovely, nice pictures, must see if you're in Paris. Nothing new there. My sole reason for taking the time to write this review is to warn unknowing travelers of deceptive sales practice by the street vendors at the very beginning of the attraction, as you enter towards the steps. There are dozens of guys there that practice sneaky/deceptive sales practice trying to sell you little colorful thread bracelets. They will aggressively approach you and simply ask you to hold your index finger out. Then they will loop a thread around your finger then proceed to create a bracelet. When you tell them you are not interested, they repeatedly tell you there is no cost, they will represent themselves as somehow associated with the church. Once they complete the bracelet, they will guilt you into paying for it, and will use the line that it is a donation for the church. It was easier for me to give them the few coins I had and continue on to see the attraction. I've travelled to many places with street vendors, Mexico, Jamaica, Caribbean, but this was one of the most deceitful sales I've ever witnessed. I'm shocked that the tourism authorities allow this at such a well known attraction. If I can save one reader from falling for the deceitful sales, then I've done my job. Just ignore and walk past these guys (unless you do want to buy one).

beautiful monument, amazing city view.. If you want to enjoy the trip, take a walk from pagalle towards montmarte. It will not take more than 20 minutes to reach there. The roads, the atmosphere, the landscape is totally different from the rest of the Paris. The monument is just amazing. The cathedral is a treat to watch. Its impeccable from inside. No pictures inside the cathedral. You get the best view of Paris from the hill top. While in Paris, do not miss it.

what has happened to Montmartre ?????. Went to Montmartre with 3 other couples, in July, and was most disappointed. The Place du Tertre has been taken over by "buvettes" (bars covered with tent awnings....cheap and tacky) and only a few painters remain...(unfortunately not the best...). A coffee cost 6,50 euros at the terrace of a tacky bar, and a beer was 10 euros...The journey there was horrendous (by tube....to Barbes !!!) Barbes was like the souk in North Africa but worse, fake jewellery, scarves and bags everywhere, we felt unsafe and we could not wait to get away !I think there are much nicer areas in Paris so perhaps give this one a miss ! What a pity as people can get a wrong impression of this SO BEAUTIFUL AND MAGICAL city ! ...But perhaps it was only because it was high season (July...) I hope so ! But I am not ready to go there again to check...THE REST OF THE WEEK-END WAS SENSATIONAL HOWEVER !

Amazing food, ambiance, service by sacre coeur. I can't remember the name of this amazing restaurant but it is slightly hidden (next to Espace Dali) on the touristy montmartre hill. If durning outside, it is magical, a wisteria plant twists through the center table and colored glasses sit on the tables. the food and service were excellent and quite reasonable for the busy over-priced area.

Colorful and Fascinating area. This hilltop neighborhood boasts restaurants, artisans and the last remaining windmill and vineyard in Paris. The home of historical dance halls, some seedy shoppes and a fascinating mix of Parisians and tourists. The Basilica of the Sacre Coeur is here. Plan to spend hours wandering the streets and soaking up the atmosphere here.

Beautifully French. Such a lovely neighborhood. I loved exploring Montmartre. It is touristy on several streets but there are so many side streets and little avenues you can get away from the crowds. Of course there is the church on the top of the butte to see but there are also tons of little brasseries and street artists selling their work. Its very easy to get to by metro and very much worth seeing.

Great area- very touristy- but a must see!. This is a fun neighborhood with a lot of character. I think it makes for a fun evening stroll and has some great shops and restaurants. It is very touristy and the meals are probably much more expensive (for a smaller amount of quality) then other parts of Paris, but you are paying for the atmosphere. It is full of outdoor cafes with live music. The shops are mainly selling tourist souvenirs, but you can also find some great art. We bought a few prints to take home with us. In the day, you can find great crepe windows and great espresso stops. There is also a lot of modern street art- some of it quite impressive. I really enjoyed the neighborhood- full of life and very vibrant. Also, the steps of Sacre Couer are a great place to drink some wine, experience a great view and really look out onto the city- a great place to meet a lot of other young travellers. Also- you don’t need to take the tram to the top of the stairs. They might look terrible, but it never took us longer than ten minutes to climb. There are other streets right near the tram that are less steep as well.

Quaint place to explore. My wife and I are here for our honeymoon. Although we are here for a short time (1 hr) just to have a cup of coffee at one of the cafes after exploring the Butte funicular and the facade of Sacred-Coeur, we are impressed and will probably return in future

Great area of Paris to explore. Montmartre is a great neighbourhood in Paris to explore - its good just to wander round and take in the sights and atmosphere.We took the Metro to Abesses and walked to the base of the hill at Sacre Coeur. You can take the hill train or walk up - its not too bad if you're in decent health. Nice carousel for kids at the base of the hill. Lots of people around when we went which added to the atmosphere of the place. The main area round the Place de tetre has lots of restaurants and artists. We have eaten here before - not this time - and had a great meal we went off the main square and found it very reasonable and good quality. We have also had a picture done of our son, i would recommend you watch a few of them first so you know how good they are, we did and got an amazing picture, agree your price first too. Have also an original piece of artwork from here. It is a great place just to experience - can be a bit touristy - but worth the trip out. Few beggars round the hill train trying to attach bracelets - just say no firmly and walk off they don't tend to hassle you. We have also done the 'little train' which is good to give you an overview and some history about the place too. See that some people mention about only going in the day - we have been at night, not this time, and never had an issue. As long as you are careful and not wandering off the beaten track I'm sure you'll be okay. We've never had a problem.

Lovely area, great to get lost in the back-streets. After visiting the Sacre-coeur, we decided just to go for a walk around the back streets of Montmartre and we are so pleased we did this. Literally about 3-4 mins after leaving the church, the crowds disappear and you are left alone in some beautiful street in Paris. There are some great little cafes and restaurants, which hardly any tourists have found. The streets are quite hilly and have lots of stairs, so if you don't like walking this may not be for you. However for everyone else I'd highly recommend this as something to do as they are really picturesque and very quaint.

Go early. We went there early and were on the first finicular of the day; you can also walk up Montmartre, but even the walk from the Metro station (Anvers Metro) to the finicular exhausted me. Maybe grab a croissant beforehand, instead of the night befores leftovers.The views from up there on top of Montmartre are just stunning. It is so quiet up there away from traffic and overseeing one of the worlds greatest cities and unique skylines. Can imagine it gets a little busy later on but also by going early the sun is not in your eyes either. As said, it is a hilly area, be wary of that. Montmartre does not have the greatest reputation but the area seemed safe enough to me. Definitely recommend a visit. Did not go in Sacre Coeur; I'm not sure the inside could have topped the outside or the views from Montmartre??

really nice. I followed the path recommended by lonely planet - which starts at the metro station next to the moulin rouge, heads past the cafe in Amelie and the (real) windmills painted by Renoir, stops in at the big white church whose name I can't spell or pronouce, then heads down the hill to another metro station - I'm glad I did, going the other way would mean walking up a really steep hill!Some parts of Montmatre are touristy and/or sleazy, but much of it is really pretty and quiet, I think it's definitely worth a visit if you have more than a day in Paris.

I never stay anywhere else. I have been to Parismany times and for the last 10 years I have always stayed in Montmartre and can't imagine staying anywhere else. The area comes alive at night and most day trippers have returned to the sterile inner arrondissements, leaving the bars and restaurants to locals and those who want to be there. I have stayed here with my wife and kids and I have stayed with "the lads" and have never had a negative experience. To those who complain about the sleazey shops, they are in the 9th, Montmartre is in the 18th. Speak to the locals and you will discover a friendly neighbourhood and people who are proud of their area and concerned for its future and preservation.

Unique, and both quiet and touristy!. We were staying in a B&B near the bottom of the hill by Jules Joffrin metro, so we walked up the dozens of stairs and were rewarded with a hidden gem! The Sacred Heart Basilica is beautiful and unique. The little tourist shops nearby are perfect for getting those little souvenirs. But the cafes, restaurants and plaza with the dozens of artists waiting to draw you for 30 to 60 Euros were the icing on the cake!

:). For me this is a one of the best places in Paris, "must see in Paris".I love this place becouse of the view from stairs in front of Sacre Cour, becouse of great pancakes, becouse of best roasted hot dog I'v ever ate ;)Becouse of artistic soul of this place and a lot of souvenirs that you can get from there :)I think that this is great place if you have some more time in Paris to spend there even half a day.I reccomend it to all of you to visit this place, if you don't have much time, at leat see the landscape of Paris from there.

Great view and nice corners. When in Paris it must not be missed to walk up the hill of Montmartre to the nice church of Sacre Coeur. Even though it can get sweaty on a sunny day, you are rewarded with an incredible view over the city.Even though the alleys and places on the hill are quite touristy - and were very crowded at the time of our visit - it is still possible to find some very nice and even quiet corners with relaxed restaurants.

PICTORESQUE AREA OF PARIS. Cozy area of Paris with nice and trendy streets, tipical stores like french boulangeries (bakeries) and patisseries (cake stores), bistros, CanCan cabarets, sea food and flowers stalls... and the touristic Place du Tertre where the artists are, searching for some tourist to draw or paint. In the top of the hill there's the Sacré-Coeur basilica, the ex-libris of Montmartre.

Montmartre - my one and only choice to stay in Paris. Montmartre - lots of opinions here on TripAdvisor. My advice ?? Go see it for yourself. I have been to Paris twice, and am going back in March 2011. I was here in July 2007 with my 2 daughters, aged 19 and 29. We rented an apartment in Montmartre and were soooo very pleased!! There is nothing like living with the locals !! So much to see here. Of course just always be aware of your surroundings. There are pickpockets and weirdos everywhere you go in this world. Just ignore them would be my advice. We were here for 10 days. The last 3 days we spent just wandering in Montmartre. It was the highlight of our trip. So very relaxing. The restaurants are great. The take-out is great. The markets are great. I am going back in March with my husband for 5 days. We've rented a one bedroom apartment, which is quite more reasonable than renting some postage size hotel room. I am going with the same rental company and would definitely recommend it highly. www.vacationinparis.com They have apartments for everyone's budget. Can hardly wait to go !!!!

Beautiful lively neighborhood. I found Montmartre to be one of the most beautiful and lively areas of Paris. Yes it was a little touristy, but you have to take the good with the bad. I've read a lot of negative reviews in reference to the pickpockets and hustlers, but you have that in every city you go to, so you can't hold it against Montmartre. There are so many neat shops and bakeries and sights to see that you have to visit it if you are in Paris. Spend the afternoon walking around Montmartre and you will see why Vincent van Gogh and his brother Theo, Auguste Renoir, Claude Monet, Amedeo Modigliani, Toulouse Lautrec, Fransesque Poulbot, Maurice Utrillo, Max Jacob, Pablo Picasso, Georges Braque and others chose to live there. There's a vineyard that dates back to Roman times, and it seems no matter what street you look down, there's something worth seeing. It's a beautiful area and as long as you are aware of yourself and those around you, you won't have a problem.

Wine festival in Montmartre. This festival takes place in first weekend of october. I have been to this place last year. I'll highly recommend to visit this place specially at that time of year. You don't need to fond of wine to be there. The whole crowd and mood is different at that time.highly recommand.

Montmartre, Hot, Hilly, and Rude Teen Boys (?). In all fairness, I had read the previous posts on Trip Advisor warning about the shady people in Montmartre. I kept an open mind, and I visited Montmartre during the day (on a Monday) with my husband. Today was extremely hot and humid, so be prepared to walk a lot, sweat a lot, drink lots of water, and look for bathrooms. We visited the Sacre Coeur, and at the bottom of the steps there is a nice place to eat (with nice bathrooms). While my husband and I were walking back up the steps to continue our journey, there was a group of teenage boys that started shouting at me the phrase, "Knee-how?", over and over again, which I think is (a) a Chinese phrase that translates to "How are you?" and (b) a reference to the fact that I am half-Chinese. Although I am a professor, I do not speak Chinese, so I said, "Non!" and shook my head no. The boys continued laughing and shouting the phrase at me, and I simply didn't understand what was so funny. I guess that is what people are referring to when they say to be careful in Montmartre.

My favorite place to stay in Paris is Montmartre. If you want to immerse yourself in the French culture, stay in Montmartre rather than in the heart of Paris..It is an old village in N. Paris with small, winding,narrow, hilly streets, cobblestoned. (bring good walking shoes.) It is replete with small shops, restaurants, bakeries, open markets with fresh fruit, vegetable, flowers and seafood , old churches, an old cemetery - even the home of the famous Moulin Rouge!Ready access to buses and to two metro stations although I strongly advise against using the Abesses metro because there are SO many steps that you're tired before you get anywhere!Try out your french; people appreciate t he effort and most do speak some degree of English..Check out the Terrass Hotel in Montmartre.Our entire week's experience was magical!Sandy

A bit touristy but still brilliant. I stayed in Montmartre about 15 years ago & it is a little more touristy but still brilliant.I visited with my wife for 3 nights in May to visit the Moulin Rouge.During the day the windy narrow streets , artist , steps , sacre coure are all worth seeing but Montmartre comes to life at night. The bars & people are eclectic - but this makes this area what it is.You can also walk down the Hill to Pigalle / Ave De Clichy for the Moulin Rouge / Sex shops / Striptease etc & again this is what makes this area.During the day/early evening this area is fine but it can be a bit seedy at night. We had no trouble but were speaking to 3 american girls who found it very intimidating as they were being shouted at in the street , pestered etc. I find it no different to any other city break keep your wits about you & you will be fine.

There are better places to visit in Paris.... Spent a few hours in Montmartre on a weekday afternoon in late May. Visited the Sacre Coeur, walked part of the Boulevard de Clichy, and explored several of the dense narrow streets packed in between.I admit you cannot beat the view offered from the top of the hill -- even on a cloudy day. The Basilica is an architectural masterpiece not to be missed. I also enjoyed resting in a quiet garden tucked behind the church. I believe the name was either Toulure or Tulure. Definitely a nice romantic nook for couples.However, I was generally underwhelmed by the neighborhood. Granted, the architecture is generally nice, but the streets (especially the main ones) are overrun by tourists, very aggressive hawkers, and overpriced retail businesses largely selling tacky souvenirs and mediocre food.I recommend spending no more than a couple of hours in the neighborhood. See the basilica, see the vista, see the Moulin Rouge perhaps, and move on. There are better places to visit in Paris. There are also better places to buy food and souvenirs.

Disney Does Paris. I couldn't disagree more with the many positive reviews below.Monmartre is what Paris would be like if Disney did it (then again, millions of people love Disney World, so maybe I'm the one whos off track!) The streets Are curvey and cute, but its all too cute. Its packed with tourists and feels like an "attraction." My 9 euro onion soup wasn't as good as Campbells from a can (In contrast, the other meals we had in Paris were outstanding). The whole thing was just horrible. This isn't Paris.We rented an apartment in the Maris district and had a blast -- the metro out to Montmarte was the only down part of a great week.

A visit to Montmartre is a must.. A short metro ride from anywhere in the city, Montmartre is easy to get to. Strolling along the narrow streets is a delight.; stop at a patisserie for a freshly baked chocolate croissant, a taste of creamy brie or sharp bleu at one of the many fromageries, a succulent orange you'd swear was fresh from the orchard. Then stop at a petit cafe to enjoy a cafe au lait while watching people stroll by. And if you're lucky a jazz band on the street corner will be playing some snappy tunes. The funniculaire takes you up to the top of the hill where you can watch artisans at work or enjoy a delightful meal at one of the many bistros. Every visit presents something new and exciting while still offering all the things you love. Want a little more excitement? Just a few steps away you'll find Moul;in Rouge and Rue Pigale where you must visit the Musee d'Eroticisme. ENJOY!

Paris encapsulated, even if a trifle over touristy. I wasn’t sure what to expect when staying in Montmartre: some reviews described it as seedy and exploitative of tourists, and not what it was.That’s probably true, but it actually doesn’t matter much. Yes, there are hawkers who try to rip you off, and there are the [--] shops on Blvd de Clichy, but there is so much more to Montmartre than this. It’s charming, full of life and abounds in little bars, cafes and restaurants everywhere you look. It encapsulates what my romantic idea of Paris ought to be, so I found staying here to be a delight. Tellingly, there are many locals who both live here or are Parisians visiting.Being built on a hill, there are windy streets with rustic apartment buildings and crowded pavements where you can buy a beer or cafe and watch the world go by. The hilltop contains squares where artists still work and tourists gather. Beware the artist with a charcoal pencil and sketchbook loitering nearby: faster than you can say Toulouse Lautrec, he will have done your portrait and demanded an outrageous amount for payment. One guy caught me and wanted 80 euros, I had to laugh out loud. My husband eventually gave him 10 just to get rid of him. The restaurants are eclectic; you can get Vietnamese as well as local, and they vary in quality. If you want an authentic experience, avoid menus written in English. Locals do not patronise these, and they are more expensive.Highlights to visit: the cemetery at the bottom on Avenue Rachel, full of history and charm. The Sacre Coeur at the summit is extraordinarily beautiful, especially at sunset, and the views over Paris are gorgeous from there. You can walk down the famous Montmartre steps to the cafes below, where you will be besieged by hawkers trying to sell you rubbish souvenirs of the Eiffel Tower.I also found it quite safe and had no qualms about walking back alone at 10m. I wouldn’t do it at 2am but then where would you do that anyway? There are enough people around at night to make it a safe area, just use the usual caution and avoid dark unpopulated spots.Bottom line: a real romantic Paris experience, even if it is more of a simulacra these days. Go for the charm and beauty, and turn a blind eye to the expense and cheap tourist shops.

a favorite in Paris. One of our favorite areas in Paris.I highly recommend taking the metro to Montmartre and spending an afternoon exploring the hill. The neighborhood is very unique with narrow, cobble stone streets winding throughout the hill. There are plenty of excellent cafes. Great people watching in front of Sacre Couer or just around the corner, in the square where many street artists can be found painting and drawing.And if you're up for experiencing the seedier side of Paris you can walk down the hill to visit the supposed birthplace of the striptease and home to the Moulin Rouge--Pigalle.

Great for a during the day! Scary at Night!!!. We went to paris for 3 days, our party was 3 girls between 22-25, we are used to travelling on a budget, so we tried to find the cheapest hotel. After researching the Montmartre area, and speaking to friends, we decided to book here...During the day for sightseeing, eating out etc. it was great, we were only a tube station away and the impressive Moulin Rouge was 5 mins away. It was not at all seedy or creepy during the day like some other reviews may say.However, going for a meal and some drinks in the evening was completely different. Being 3 young girls wearing high heels and jeans, with a mac, we stuck out like a sore thumb, men were leering at us and shouting across the street at us, this was pretty scary and intimidating. On one occassion, a man actually followed us down a side street to our hotel! I would like to point out that as budget travellers, we are not easily put off, or fussy about where we stay, but this was different. I would not recommend staying here if the party is all female and definetly not to get the subway around this area at night. We then got taxis for the rest of our stay immediately from the hotel and back to the grands boulevard and champs elyees (spelling not great)! These, we found, were the best places for night time for a few drinks and cocktails. I would absolutely recommend the Hard Rock Cafe, it was delicious! I would definetely return to paris as it was a beautiful and exciting city, I would stay in another location however.

Stay right in the heart of montmarte. We stayed in an apartment on place du terte and had a wonderful experience, the apartment was fantastic, the location was great, the people were lovely (ok one artist gave us hassle) the small winding streets were lovely and like nothing else in Paris. There is so much to discover here, we never had a problem or felt unsafe apart from dodging the lookie lookie men at the bottom of the Sacre Coeur, and having a little of the French language to tell them where to go helped I suppose but overall a fantastic experience.

Montmartre with children. Go to Montmartre where the painters sit. Just for fun and show we used the funiculaire. Of course you will pass Sacre Coeur. My boy refused to enter another church after the Notre dame waiting experience. Apart from the Eiffel tower, the Seine cruise for french speaking children, the Montmartre experience was the third hightlight of my boy. I payed € 50 for a portrait which is not all that great, but he enjoyed the experience thouroghly. After that we had dinner on that pittoresque square where he even gladly ate escargots! Proudly he returned to our hotel with his portrait under his arm. All in all I can warmly recommend this experience.

Old Hill art village. Montmarte is a nice place to visit when you are in Paris. Dont stay at Montmarte though. I found that the affordable hotels were old, small, and damp. Of course, I am sure the hotels may be originals! Montemarte use to be a place where artists gathered. Think moulin Rouge (which isnt really that far from montemarte) Many drug induced artists littered the streets of montemarte, but while i think absinthe, artists and tourists, montemarte is still a historical place to visit. Sacre couere sits right there next to it, but to me, wasnt the main attraction. On montemarte you get a decent view of the rest of the city. There is alos a carosal, and if you have seen the french flick, amelie, then you might recognize the steps going up to montemarte. visit montemarte in the daytime, or early evening before it gets too dark. Montemarte still reminds me of a bit of a rowdy scandalous place. There are little tiny caffees and a bunch of tourists shops. They are ok. I like the little cobbled streets, the view, and the artists (though i couldnt afford any of their paintings). If you really want to shop there is some decent prices souvenir like places at the bottom of montemarte.

Beautiful Hilltop Village. Montmartre was the first place we visited during our stay in Paris this October for our honeymoon. We loved this beautiful hilltop village. The whole town still remains its color of 19 century's village. It feels like the Time Machine took you back 200 years. You almost can imagine vividly how the life was there. We discovered many lovely gardens, houses, cafes and magnificant views of Paris while we walking on the winding cobble stoned street. The afternoon we spent there was so nice and relaxing. We didn't stay in montmartre, so didn't notice any problems that the previous review mentioned. Montmartre is definetly site for walking tour if you visit Paris.

Dog-poo slalem. My husband and I spent a week in Paris in July and had fabulous and not so fabulous experiences. My main advice is for people to not stay in the part of Monmartre that we did! We thought that being two streets back from the Sacre Cur would ensure us a great stay - wrong! Our nearest Metro stops were Anvers and Chateu Rouge (one of the few Metro stations that the Lonely Plant guide tells you to avoid at night - for good reason - it is scary!) and the short walk to each of them was quite horrible. We knew that Parisians weren't as environmentally friendly as what we were used to, but nowhere in Paris did we see so much filth - and so much dog poo - as we saw between our hotel and the local stations. We read an article in a tourist magazine about people roller-blading and walking down the foot paths doing the "dog-poo slalem" - we thought it an accurate description. As we left on our last morning to catch a train to the airport, we rolled our suitcases down the centre of the road to avoid messing up our wheels! While most or Paris - and most of Monmartre - was quite fabulous, that walk was enough to dampen a great day and make us feel yukky. We stayed at the Hotel New Monmartre, which our friends from London said was better than their rented flat, but which we found dirty, tiny and uncomfortable. The other side of the fabulous church on the hill was charming and lovely and we wished we had stayed there or in another region. Our trip highlight was a Mozart concert by a string ensemble at Saint Chappelle (right near Notre Dame) and a bus tour around the city, admiring the stunning architecture. We will have to return to Paris one day, just to stop the Monmarte experince from tainting our memory of such a beautiful city.
